title.en-US: 3 reasons why what you eat could help reduce stress during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know:
Eat balanced meals and snacks throughout the day to keep your blood sugar levels stable. This can help you feel less stressed.
Slowing down for a warm cup of tea or a warm meal can also help you feel calm.
Limit caffeine and processed foods. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Pregnancy can be a stressful time between getting ready for baby, trying to keep yourself healthy, and getting done with
all the things
you need to do before you deliver. Juggling all of that while growing life is a lot!

What you eat or drink might not be the first place you think of when it comes to lowering some of that stress. But hear us out—there’s actually a reason to focus on eating well in times of stress. Read on to learn why.
1. Keeping your blood sugar levels in check can help your body feel less stressed

Lots of products out there claim to lower your stress. But one of the best things you can do is keep your blood sugar balanced. You can do this by eating balanced meals and snacks throughout the day, says Maven Nutritionist Aubrey Phelps.

Here’s why: “When we're stressed, our body increases cortisol production. This prepares us for fight or flight,” she says. “This then increases blood sugar levels so that our body has the energy needed to do either of those activities. If blood sugar remains high, that can increase the need for fight or flight. It can also create inflammation that will stress out the body more.”

Focusing on building your plate around healthy fats, protein, and non-starchy veggies can help keep those sugar levels balanced. (Think peanut butter on whole wheat toast or a veggie stir fry with lean beef and brown rice.) And try to eat regular meals and snacks— 3 meals and 2 snacks every day is great.
2. Slowing down for something warm can feel soothing when you’re stressed

Eating fast, in front of a screen, or on the go is also more likely to increase or create stress. “When you rush through your meal, you prevent your body from going into the rest and digest phase and you stay in that fight or flight mode,” Phelps says.

On the other hand, slowing down to eat or drink something warm and cozy can help you feel less stressed.“In many cultures, warming foods are all thought to be soothing. Think broths, soups, teas, and even warming spices like cinnamon, ginger, and turmeric,” Phelps says. “Try something that feels cozy and requires you to slow down to consume it like hot soup or steaming tea. Slowing down helps move your body into that calm state so you can relax.”
3. Limiting caffeine and processed foods (when you can) can help lower stress, too
It’s hard, but try to limit caffeine and processed foods like fast food when you can. You might find yourself feeling less stressed. (The occasional cravings are totally still acceptable!)
“Anything that's going to ‘rev’ the system up, like caffeine, sugar, and processed carbs like white bread and pasta, are more likely to lead to imbalance and stress,” Phelps says.
The bottom line:

Not every meal you eat during your pregnancy is going to be perfect. Sometimes you’ll be on the go and need to get something down fast. (And sometimes you’ll just need a pizza and fries!) On the other hand, taking time when you can to slow down and eat balanced, soothing meals might help lower your stress during this busy time. If you need more ideas on managing your stress, you can reach out to a
Maven Mental Health Provider
for free online anytime. You can also talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
about more stress-busting meal ideas.

title.en-US: What you need to know about HCG levels during pregnancy

content.value: If you’re trying to conceive—or you’re recently pregnant—you may have heard about hCG, a hormone that your body starts to make when you conceive. Here’s everything you need to know about hCG, including what high or low levels may mean for your pregnancy.
What is hCG?

Human chorionic gonadotropin—most often known as hCG—is a hormone that your placenta (an organ that you only have during pregnancy and provides your baby with oxygen and nutrients) makes when you’re pregnant.

Your placenta will start to release hCG into your blood about 11 days after conception (when sperm fertilizes an egg) and into your urine soon after. If you take an at-home pregnancy test a few weeks after you conceive, it will detect higher levels of hCG in your urine.
Normally, hCG levels rise over the first few weeks of pregnancy, peak around 10 weeks, and decline for the rest of your pregnancy.
What does hCG do during pregnancy?

When your placenta starts making hCG, your body will also produce more estrogen and progesterone, other hormones that are important for a healthy pregnancy. These three hormones work together to thicken your uterine lining (to support the fertilized egg) and stop your body from menstruating.
How is hCG measured?

Your hCG levels are measured through a blood test or a urine test. Your pregnancy provider may take blood and urine samples at your first prenatal appointment to measure your hCG levels and confirm your pregnancy.

When you become pregnant, your hCG levels increase very quickly—levels typically double about every three days until the 10th week of pregnancy. Everyone is different, so there isn’t an exact level you should have at any point in your pregnancy. It’s more important that your levels are increasing.
If your hCG levels are increasing and your pregnancy is progressing normally, your provider most likely won’t need to measure your levels again.
What do high hCG levels mean?
Increasing levels of hCG can confirm a pregnancy, but very high levels of hCG might signal:
You’re carrying multiple babies
A molar pregnancy (when the cells that form the placenta don’t develop correctly)
Growths on the uterus
That you didn’t estimate the date of your last period correctlyREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Remember, every person is different, so your pregnancy provider won’t know if this is the case just from your hCG levels. They may recommend any other testing, like an ultrasound, to figure out the cause of high levels.
What do low hCG levels mean?

First, know that having lower hCG levels doesn’t necessarily mean there’s a problem with your pregnancy—many people with lower-than-average hCG levels have healthy pregnancies. But if your hCG levels are measuring low or declining, your pregnancy provider might recommend measuring them again after two to three days, or using an ultrasound to look at your uterus.
If hCG levels are low or are declining over time, that could signal:
A blighted ovum (when an embryo doesn’t develop or stops developing and leaves an empty gestational sac in the uterus)
Miscarriage (when a pregnancy ends before 20 weeks)
An ectopic pregnancy (when a fertilized egg implants and starts to grow outside of the uterus, like in the fallopian tubes)
That you didn’t estimate the date of your last period correctlyREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

It’s important to remember that lower hCG levels don’t always mean there’s a problem with your pregnancy. Your pregnancy provider will use your hCG levels (and other tests) as tools to figure out what’s going on.
The bottom line

Increasing hCG levels are an accurate way to confirm a pregnancy, but having low hCG when you’re pregnant doesn’t necessarily mean there’s something wrong. Your pregnancy provider will use your hCG levels and other tests, like an ultrasound, to check on your pregnancy’s progress.
If you have questions about hCG levels or are ever concerned, talk to your pregnancy provider or a
Maven OB-GYN
for advice.
Resources:
Cleveland Clinic

title.en-US: Why tummy time is important for your baby

content.value: What you need to know:
Tummy time is when you lay your baby on their tummy for a few minutes a day.
Tummy time helps your baby’s neck, shoulder, back, and arm muscles get stronger.
Only do tummy time when your baby is awake and alert. (Never put baby on their tummy to sleep.)
Always watch your baby closely during tummy time. Never leave them alone during tummy time. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Tummy time is a simple, but important exercise that helps your baby grow stronger.
Here is everything you need to know about tummy time, and ways to make tummy time fun for your baby.
What is tummy time and why does my baby need it?
Tummy time is when you place your baby on their tummy to play, instead of on their backs. Giving your baby a few minutes of tummy time a few times every day is good for their development.

Tummy time is an important exercise for babies. It helps baby build strong muscles in their neck, shoulders, back, and arms, so they can hold their head up. It also helps them develop the major motor skills they will need to sit up, roll over, and crawl.
How much tummy time does my baby need every day?
Start by trying tummy time for 3 to 5 minutes, 2 to 3 times every day.
As baby gets used to tummy time, you can do longer sessions a few times every day.
By the time your baby is 3 months old, they should do up to 1 hour of tummy time a day.
When should I start tummy time?
The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) says you can start tummy time the day you bring baby home from the hospital or birthing center.
How do I do tummy time safely?
It is a good idea to do tummy time when your baby is fed, rested, and happy.
Here is how to get started with tummy time:

Clear a small area on the floor. Make sure there are no cords, outlets, or other dangerous things close to baby. Never do tummy time on a high or soft surface, like the couch or bed. If you have other kids or family members, make sure they know baby is on the floor, so they are extra careful when walking around.
Put a clean blanket, towel, or baby playmat on the floor. Place your baby on top of it on their tummy.
Show your baby some of their favorite toys or books while they lay on their tummy. This will help baby lift and turn their head.
Try to keep baby on their tummy for 3 to 5 minutes, 2 to 3 times every day.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Your baby should always be awake during tummy time. Never leave baby alone during tummy time—even for a few seconds. Babies can suffocate if they are facedown and their muscles are not strong enough to turn their heads.
(Remember to never put baby to sleep on their tummy. The only time it is OK to put baby on their tummy is during tummy time when you are watching them very closely.)
What if baby does not like tummy time?
It is normal if your baby is fussy during tummy time. Many babies do not like tummy time at first! If they are very upset, it is OK to stop tummy time, pick them up, and calm them.
While it is normal if your baby does not like tummy time at first, it is important to do every day. So give it another try later!
Here are some ways to make tummy time more fun for your baby:
Do tummy time with baby.
Get down on the floor next to baby. Talk, sing, or make funny faces and noises to keep their attention.
Show baby a mirror.
Put a small or toy mirror in front of baby so they can see their face. Try moving the mirror around them, so they can practice lifting and turning their head.
Use baby’s favorite toys.
Place a few of your baby’s favorite toys or books just out of their reach. This will help baby exercise the muscles they need to reach, sit up, and crawl.
Place baby on your tummy.
Lie on your back and put your baby tummy-down on your own belly. Looking at your face will make tummy time more fun for your baby
and
exercise their neck muscles.
Try different times of the day.
For example, if you tried tummy time after baby ate and they were fussy, next time, try doing tummy time before they eat.
We are here to help
If you have any questions about tummy time or want to learn other ways to help your baby’s development, you can video chat or message with a
Maven Pediatrician
online for free at any time.
Sources
Mayo Clinic

title.en-US: How much protein you really need during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know:
Getting enough protein in your daily diet is important for your baby’s growth and development.

Every person is different, but it’s generally recommended that pregnant people eat between 60 and 100 grams of protein per day (that’s like eating one to two cups of diced chicken, one cup of beans, two hard boiled eggs, and a Greek yogurt every day).
If you’re vegetarian or vegan, talk to your pregnancy provider or a
Maven Nutritionist
about easy ways to work more protein into your diet. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Protein from lots of different food sources is important for your health, but when you’re pregnant, it’s extra important to not skimp on this essential nutrient. Here’s what you need to know about protein during pregnancy, and healthy ways to get it in your daily diet.
Why protein is so important during pregnancy

The amino acids that make up protein are essential for a number of reasons—they help cell growth and function, hormone production, muscle development, and more. You need extra protein during pregnancy to support your changing body and to support your baby’s growth and development, too.
What’s more, research from the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) found that getting enough protein during pregnancy is one of the best things you can do for your
baby’s brain development.
How much protein you need during pregnancy
The amount of protein you need during pregnancy depends on a few things:
How active you are
How far along you are in your pregnancy
How many babies you’re carryingREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Every person and every pregnancy is different, but as a general rule, Maven Nutritionist Aubrey Phelps, recommends anywhere from 80 grams to 100 grams of protein per day from a variety of food sources (more on what that could look like below).
Eating a balanced diet usually provides the right amount of protein for pregnant people, but it’s important to know that getting too little protein can be harmful to you and your baby.
Too little protein have been linked to:
Pregnancy loss
Intrauterine growth restriction (or IUGR, when baby doesn’t grow as expected in the womb)
Reduced growth after baby is born (due to missing out on certain amino acids)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you’re not sure how much protein you need, talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
or your pregnancy provider for free personalized advice.
Healthy sources of protein during pregnancy

Like we said, eating a balanced diet with lean proteins (like chicken or low-mercury fish and shellfish), eggs, dairy products, and fruits and veggies can usually provide enough protein. But if you’re looking for some other healthy sources or have concerns, consider adding these foods to your rotation:
1 cup of cottage cheese: 28 grams of protein
3 ounces of lean ground beef: 22 grams of protein
1⁄2 cup of tofu: 10 grams of protein
1⁄2 cup of lentils: 9 grams of protein
1 cup of milk: 8 grams of protein
2 tablespoons of peanut butter: 7 grams of protein
1 egg: 6 grams of proteinREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you follow a special diet—like
vegetarianism
or
veganism
—talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
about simple ways to add more protein to your diet.
Why you shouldn’t rely on protein powders, shakes, or bars

Adding a protein shake or bar to your daily diet may seem like the easiest way to bump up your protein points, but, unfortunately, these types of products aren’t usually recommended for pregnant people. Here’s why:
Protein products aren’t regulated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

Like other supplements, protein products aren’t regulated by the FDA the same way medications are. That means there probably isn’t a lot of research around their safety during pregnancy. Plus, the ingredients list may not be totally accurate, and could contain ingredients that are unsafe for pregnancy.
Protein products could contain heavy metals.

“Protein powders, especially plant-based ones, can be very high in heavy metals,” says Phelps. “Unless the company has sent you heavy metal reports verifying that they don’t contain any heavy metals, I recommend avoiding them completely.” Heavy metals, like mercury or lead, can be extremely dangerous for you and your developing baby, and cause serious health issues.
Protein products can contain a lot of added sugar.

Some protein powders can contain as much as 23 grams of added sugar per scoop. For reference, the American Heart Association (AHA) recommends a total of 24 grams of added sugars per day for women and 36 grams per day for men. Eating too many added sugars during pregnancy has been linked to a range of health problems, from gestational diabetes to preeclampsia and preterm birth.
The bottom line

Protein is an important nutrient for your baby’s growth and development. The good news is that eating a balanced diet usually provides all you need. But if you’re vegetarian, vegan, or follow another special diet, it’s a good idea to talk to your pregnancy provider or a
Maven Nutritionist
about your protein intake. They can help you figure out easy ways to get the daily recommended amount.
Sources
Experimental Biology and Medicine
Harvard Medical School
Mayo Clinic
Nutrients

title.en-US: How to ease test anxiety while pregnant

content.value: What you need to know
Being anxious or concerned before prenatal testing is totally normal: worrying doesn’t make you weird!
Maven providers
are here to help talk you through your questions anytime.

If you have access to your test results online, it might be worth it to wait until you can speak with your care team to look at them. The wording can be confusing and cause unnecessary worry.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

You might not ever go to the doctor more than when you’re pregnant. The constant appointments, scans, and testing can feel like an anxious person’s nightmare. If you have test anxiety, you’re not alone. Prenatal testing anxiety is common and normal.
Here are some tips to help ease your mind.
Mental Health Providers
are always here to help on Maven, and you can get second opinions to ease your concerns or ask questions about test results from an
OB-GYN
anytime, too.
What kind of prenatal testing will I need?
Even though the kinds of tests you’ll get will depend on your individual pregnancy, most everyone gets these same routine tests:
Blood tests:
You’ll have blood tests from the beginning of pregnancy onward to test for things like genetic abnormalities or your blood sugar (glucose) levels.
Urine tests:

Urine tests are when you pee in a cup and are done from the beginning of pregnancy as well. They can help confirm your pregnancy and tell you things about your protein levels and bladder or kidney health.
Ultrasounds:

Usually, ultrasounds start around the 12th-14th weeks of pregnancy. They give you and your doctor a look at your baby inside the womb to see how they’re developing. Around week 18, you’ll also have an anatomy scan for an in-depth look at baby’s organs and anatomy.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
No one enjoys the uncertainty of testing, especially during pregnancy. Find out more about all the different kinds of prenatal testing you might have
here
Should you click that “results” email?
If you have access to your prenatal testing results online or through an app, you might get an email that lets you know results are ready for you to see.
Before you click, consider this: It might not be very helpful for you to look at any test results before your doctor has had a chance to put it into context for you.

You might see an “abnormal” result and think that something is seriously wrong—when really it’s just a clue that further testing might be necessary. Or you may be put on unnecessarily high alert for something minor, like a slight Vitamin D deficiency that can easily be addressed.

Pregnancy can be stressful enough without having to figure out complicated medical results yourself—something that may turn into a real (and totally understandable) fear or anxiety. If you know you’re likely to get worried or overwhelmed, ask your doctor or nurse practitioner to call you with lab results before you try to decode them yourself on your computer screen.
It’s a lot easier to put things into perspective when a provider you trust is there to explain and answer questions.
Take your mental health into account

If you’re someone who worries before any testing—much less prenatal testing where your baby is concerned—you might avoid the doctor and even cancel prenatal appointments. Even though it’s understandable to want to do this, it’s important to go to all of your doctor’s appointments while pregnant to make sure that you and your baby are healthy.

Try having a support person come along or drive you to make sure you get there. This could be your partner, a friend, family member, or another trusted person that helps ease your mind while you’re there too. You can share a calendar or app reminder with them if that feels helpful, too.

You have to take care of your mental health as though it’s your physical body: because it is! Allowing stress and anxiety to take over isn’t good for you or the baby, which is why putting yourself and your feelings first (and asking for help) is vital.
Share how you’re feeling

Your doctors and nurses should feel like teammates, not opponents. Let them know how you’re feeling so they can approach your care with this in mind. It also can help ease anxiety to learn how to advocate for yourself if you have concerns. If you don’t love the idea of sticking up for yourself or asking more questions of your care team, take a support person with you to appointments with your written-down questions that can prompt them (or you!) to speak up.
Ask questions

On that note—your providers totally expect you to have some questions, especially if this is your first pregnancy. No question is a silly one, and it’s better to get answers specific to you and your body than doing random web searches.
If you have questions about a test before you go in or your results after, reach out to your provider or a
Maven provider
. They’ll help you understand what the test will entail, what to expect, and what your results may mean. This might help you feel a little more in control and comfortable.
One last thing
If you couldn't resist clicking on your test results and you're feeling worried,
Maven providers
are available day and night to provide answers, guidance, and reassurance.
Book a free online appointment or message them anytime.

title.en-US: What to do if your baby has a fever

content.value: What you need to know:
If your baby is under 3 months old and has a fever of 100.4 degrees F or higher, call your pediatrician or go to the emergency room right away.

If your baby is over 3 months old and has a fever over 102 degrees F, call your pediatrician. They’ll let you know if you should give them a fever reducer like Tylenol or let the fever run its course.
Most of the time, fevers aren’t a sign of anything too serious. Your pediatrician will let you know what to do. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Your baby is burning up. You’re worried or you know they have a fever. What should you do?
First, don’t panic. Fevers are scary. But they’re not always a sign of anything serious.

If your baby is under 3 months old, you should call your pediatrician’s office or go to the emergency room right away. Any fever over 100.4 degrees F in young babies needs to be checked out by a doctor. For older babies, call your pediatrician.
How to take your baby’s temperature
You’ll want to use a thermometer to take your baby’s temperature. (Don’t just rely on a hot-to-the-touch test).
A rectal (in their bottom) thermometer works best in young babies.
Here’s how to use it:
Turn on the thermometer
Put a bit of petroleum jelly (or Vaseline or coconut oil, if you have it) on the tip of the thermometer
Put your baby on their back
Lift their thighs
Gently put the thermometer into their bum (only go 1⁄2 to 3⁄4 inch (or the length of the silver tip of the thermometer) No need to insert too far.)

You can also use a forehead thermometer to take a baby’s temperature. Or put a digital thermometer under their arm. Ear thermometers aren’t always as reliable. But if that’s what you have at home, you can go ahead and use it.
Taking it orally (in the mouth) isn’t recommended until your child is 4 years old or up.
What counts as a fever and when should you call the doctor?
REPLACEWITHIMGWCAPTION
What else to know about fevers
Pay attention to other symptoms
A fever can be caused by many things. Your baby’s other symptoms can offer clues about what could be wrong.
Look out for a fever and:
Runny nose and congestion (probably a common cold or in more severe cases, the flu or COVID-19)
Vomiting and diarrhea (could be a stomach bug)
Ear tugging (might be an ear infection) REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Let your pediatrician know about your child’s other symptoms. They’ll be helpful to know if they need treatment or not. (More on that below.)
Fevers don’t always need to be treated
A fever is a sign that your baby’s body is fighting off some kind of infection. Always check in with your pediatrician if you’re worried about your baby’s fever.
They might recommend just letting the fever run its course for a few days. That’s usually OK if your baby isn’t uncomfortable. Or the fever doesn’t go any higher.
If it does go up, call your pediatrician again and ask what you should do.
Fever reducers

If your doctor recommends a fever reducer like Tylenol, the dosage will be based on your child's weight, not age. Ask them about the dose, or how much to give your baby. (For younger babies, the dose might not be listed on the box.)
If you aren’t sure how much to give your baby, ask your pediatrician or make an online appointment to ask a
pediatrician on Maven
for free.
Know that:
Tylenol (Acetaminophen) is OK for babies older than 2 months with your pediatrician’s OK
Advil or Motrin (Ibuprofen) aren’t safe until your baby is 6-months old
Have more questions?
Book an appointment online for free with a
Maven Pediatrician
. They can help put your mind at ease. You can ask them any questions about fevers in babies.

Remember, whatever your child’s age, The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) says to always seek immediate care if a fever spikes above 104 degrees F or lasts for longer than three days. Call your pediatrician’s office first. If they cannot see you, go to your nearest urgent care.

title.en-US: What to eat when you feel morning (aka all-day) nausea

content.value: What you need to know:
If you’re very nauseous, stick to easy-to-eat meals like scrambled eggs, dry toast, and smoothies.
Let your doctor know if you think you have extreme morning sickness or are dehydrated.
Try to eat when you feel like it, but don’t stress. Eat whatever sounds OK to you during this time. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

It might be called morning sickness—but as you may already know all too well—that doesn’t mean it only happens in the morning. If you’re one of the (un)lucky ones in pregnancy who feels nauseous and throws up all day, every day, know that you’re not alone.
Some pregnant people do feel better starting in the second trimester. But some people feel nauseous their whole pregnancy (and so sorry if this is you).

Fingers crossed you get some relief at some point during your pregnancy. But on days when nausea strikes hard, Maven Nutritionist Lauren Olofsson shares what you can try to eat or drink to feel a bit better.
Nausea and pregnancy 101

Sadly, nausea and pregnancy often go hand-in-hand. Especially in the first trimester. High amounts of the pregnancy hormone HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is probably behind your nausea, along with extra estrogen in your body.

Know that even if you’re feeling extra sick, though, it likely doesn’t mean that anything is wrong with you and your baby. “Your body is able to rely on your nutrient stores when the going-gets-tough in the first trimester,” Oloffsson says. Taking your prenatal vitamin and drinking plenty of water to stay hydrated is still a must, though.
If you have severe vomiting and nausea, can’t keep anything down, and feel dehydrated, you might have a pregnancy medical condition called
hyperemesis gravidarum
. There are ways to manage this condition, so be sure to talk to your provider. Dehydration can be dangerous during pregnancy, so be sure to let your doctor know how you’re feeling.
Prenatal vitamins when you’re nauseous
If you do have trouble keeping down your prenatal vitamin, it’s also important to reach out to your OB or midwife and let them know. You can also book a free online appointment with a
Maven Nutritionist

anytime. There are other options out there beyond the hard-to-stomach kind of prenatals. You could try a gummy or chewable vitamin instead, for example. But note that chewables and gummies might not have the same value nutrition-wise as some other prenatal vitamins.

“There are many prenatal vitamins on the market, and while some of the best quality and nutrient-dense options are ideal, they can be hard to stomach,” Oloffsson says. “Let your provider help you find a gummy or chewable you can potentially keep down until the nausea/vomiting are under better control and you can switch back to a different kind.”
Easy-to-eat meals and snacks for rough days
As for what to eat, some days you might not feel like eating much at all. Some weeks you might only feel like eating one thing. That’s OK!

Even if there’s not a vegetable in sight, eat what you can, when you can. Not eating anything can actually make your nausea worse! “Sometimes it’s just whatever you think you can handle/keep down,” Olofsson says. “For some pregnant people that’s a cheeseburger. For others, it’s a bagel with cream cheese.”
Some other simple ideas you might be able to stomach:
Scrambled eggs:
Enjoy them with dry toast and fruit
Smoothies:

“These are typically easy to keep down even if you’re nauseous, and thankfully have no nauseating smells from cooking!” Olofsson says. Try yours with any fruit that sounds OK to you, add nut butter or a pregnancy-safe protein powder like collagen. (Note that some
protein powders

contain ingredients that aren’t safe during pregnancy or have high amounts of sugar and should be avoided.) You can also add leafy greens, hemp seeds, or oats if your stomach can handle them. A good, simple option is just banana, peanut butter, and your milk of choice.
Fortified breakfast cereals:
Think Cheerios, Frosted Mini Wheats, or Rice Chex. “These are great to keep at your desk or in your purse to help keep something in your stomach and decrease nausea,” Olofsson says.
Soup and crackers:
A classic combo when you’re not feeling your best.
Drink up and stay hydrated

If you’re throwing up a lot, remember it’s easy to get dehydrated quickly, too. Water is always a must. Try to drink 8-12 cups (64 to 96 ounces) of water each day, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommends.

But you might need electrolytes, too. “It’s definitely OK to just drink water, however, if you’re throwing up a lot and becoming dehydrated you may need some extra electrolytes,” Olofsson says. “Many companies offer electrolyte mixers now (like Liquid IV, Re-lyte, and LMNT).
You can always reach out to a
Maven Nutritionist
if you’re not sure which is best for you.
Some other ways to stay hydrated:
Pasteurized juice is pregnancy-safe (just look for “pasteurized” on the label)
Hot water with lemon, ginger root, and honey
Ice cold water with lemon
Ginger ale
Hydrating fruits like watermelon and cantaloupe
Smoothies (see above)
Other tips to help with nausea
Here are a few other ideas that might help with nausea:
Try to eat every 2-3 hours:
This helps stabilize your blood sugar and can decrease nausea.
Get plenty of protein:

When you’re up for eating, try to get 20 grams of protein with breakfast and at least 5 grams of protein with each snack. (One egg has about 6 grams of protein, 2 tablespoons of peanut butter has about 8 grams, for example.) Why protein? “Protein and healthy fats along with carbohydrates can be really helpful in stabilizing your blood sugar, helping with nausea, and helping your energy levels overall,” Olofsson says.
Learn more about protein during pregnancy.
Try Vitamin B6
: “Research has shown that Vitamin B6 can help with nausea,” Olofsson says. Reach out to your OB-GYN to ask if Vitamin B6 is safe for your pregnancy. You can also talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
if you have more questions or want a recommendation for which brand to look for.
What to eat when you feel a little better
If your nausea gets a little better at some point, you can slowly start adding more fruits, veggies, and other healthy foods back into your day.
Some foods to go with are:
Eggs:
“The yokes are a wonderful source of choline and various vitamins and minerals,” Olofsson says. “They’re one of the first foods to reintroduce or eat daily if you can throughout pregnancy.”
A source of iron:
Try red meat, well-cooked shellfish, dark leafy greens, beans, peas, or iron-fortified cereals (check the label)
Fruits and vegetables:
Aim for 5 a day! They have vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants.
The bottom line

Pregnancy nausea can really mess with your day-to-day life. Keep a lookout for simple foods, drinks, and ways you can keep anything down during this difficult time. Maven is also here for you. You can book an appointment with a
Maven Nutritionist
anytime you need some extra support or more ideas for what to eat when you feel up for it.

title.en-US: Everything you need to know about vaginal tearing during labor

content.value: What you need to know:
Vaginal tears are injuries that happen to the skin and/or muscles around the vagina during birth.
About 40% to 80% of women have some vaginal tearing during childbirth.
Many vaginal tears can be treated quickly with a few stitches and some can even heal on their own.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
We are not going to sugar coat it—some vaginal tearing is common if you give birth vaginally. But there are steps you can take before birth to help prepare your body and lower your risk of tearing.
Here is what you need to know—and why vaginal tearing is usually not as bad as it sounds!
What is a vaginal tear?

A vaginal tear (also called a perineal laceration) happens when there is a tear in the skin and sometimes the muscles around the vagina and perineum. The perineum is the space between the vagina and anus.
What causes a vaginal tear?
Vaginal tears are common during vaginal childbirth.
When you have a vaginal delivery, the skin around your vagina starts to thin and stretch out. This helps baby pass through the birth canal more easily.
Even though your vagina is meant to stretch out during childbirth, some things can make it more likely to tear, like:
If this is your
first vaginal delivery
If your baby is very large
What position baby is in (babies who are face-up are more likely to cause a vaginal tear)
If you have a very fast labor and delivery (because the skin and muscles do not have time to stretch)
If your OB-GYN or midwife has to use forceps or a vacuum to help baby out
If you had an
episiotomy
(a cut made by a doctor between your vagina and anus) during a previous delivery
What are the “degrees” of vaginal tears?
There are 4 degrees of vaginal tears. The higher the degree, the more serious the tear.
First-degree tear:
This is a small (or minor) tear in the first layer of skin around the vagina and perineum.
Second-degree tear:
This is a tear that goes through the first layer of skin and into the muscle around the vagina and perineum. This is the most common tear from childbirth.
Third-degree tear:
This is a tear that goes from the vagina to the anus. It hurts the skin and muscle around the vagina and perineum, and the anal sphincter muscles (the muscles that help you go to the bathroom).
Fourth-degree tear:

This is a serious tear, but it is not common. This is a tear that goes from the vagina to the anus and into the rectum (the last section of your large intestine). It hurts the muscles in the vagina, perineum, and anus.
Do vaginal tears hurt when they happen?

Every person and every birth is different, but some people do not feel vaginal tears while they are giving birth. Especially if you have an epidural because you will be numb from your belly button, down.
Is there anything I can do to prevent a vaginal tear?
There is no way to prevent a tear during childbirth. But some research has found taking these steps might lower your chances of a bad tear:
Try perineal massage

This can help the skin and muscles around your vagina stretch. Your OB-GYN may use perineal massage during your labor, but you can also do it at home in the weeks before your due date. Ask your OB-GYN if doing perineal massage at home is a good idea for you.
It is OK if you do not want to do perineal massage or have your OB-GYN do it while you are in labor. It is your body and your choice. Be sure to tell your OB-GYN and you can also include it in
your birth plan
Here is how to do a perineal massage:
Wash your hands (or ask your partner to wash their hands if they are helping you). You can also wear latex gloves if you prefer.
Place two fingers inside your vagina and move them side to side while gently pushing down (towards your anus).
Do this for 5 minutes, 1 to 2 times a week for 4 to 6 weeks before your due date.
Push gently and slowly (if you can) during labor
This will give the skin and muscles around your vagina more time to stretch out. Your OB-GYN or midwife will help you do this.
Try laboring in different positions

Instead of lying on your back during delivery, ask your OB-GYN or nurse to help you get into a safe, upright position or onto your side if you can. This may help you avoid tearing. If you have an epidural, you might not be able to move around as much.
How are vaginal tears treated?
After your baby is born, your OB-GYN or midwife will check your vagina, perineum, and anus for tears.
Vaginal tears are treated with dissolvable stitches. If you have a first-degree tear, you might not need any stitches. But second-, third-, and fourth-degree tears have to be stitched to heal.
Dissolvable stitches fade away on their own in about 6 weeks. You do not have to go to your doctor’s office to have the stitches removed.
How long will a vaginal tear hurt after delivery?
It depends on the type of tear you have. But for most people, pain and soreness goes away after about 2 weeks.
During that time, there are things you can do to help pain and soreness. Here are some ideas:
Use a squirt bottle (called a peri bottle) to clean yourself with warm water after you go to the bathroom. (If it burns when you pee, try squirting warm water on the area
while
you go the bathroom.)
Ask your doctor about taking a stool softener or laxative if it is painful to go to the bathroom
Sit on a cushion or pillow to keep pressure off your stitches
Freeze a maxi pad, then put it in your underwear
Take a pain reliever, like Tylenol or Advil (just ask your doctor first)
How long does it take for a vaginal tear to heal?
Everyone is different and heals at different rates. For many people, it takes about 6 weeks to completely heal. Deeper or more severe tears can take longer.
It is important to look for signs of infection while your vaginal tear heals. Call your OB-GYN right away if you have any of these signs:
A fever
Feeling very cold (chills)
Bad smelling discharge or pus around your stitches
Pain that does not go away when you take pain medication REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have any questions about the healing process for vaginal tearing, be sure to talk to your OB-GYN or a
Maven OB-GYN
at no cost.
Can I have sex if I have a vaginal tear?

Most doctors recommend waiting 6 weeks to start having sex after you have a baby. It is important to let your tear heal completely before you have sex. Your OB-GYN will let you know if it is safe to have sex at your 6 week postpartum checkup.

It is common for sex to feel different or even painful after you give birth. Especially if you have a vaginal tear. Using a lubricant or taking a pain reliever (like Tylenol or Advil) can help pain and soreness during and after sex.
If sex is painful for several months after you give birth, let your OB-GYN or midwife know. Or make a free appointment with a
Maven OB-GYN
for advice.
Learn about the importance of birth control after birth
We are here to help
If you have any questions about vaginal tearing or healing after birth, schedule an online appointment with a
Maven OB-GYN
or
Midwife
for free advice anytime.
Sources
[Cleveland Clinic](
https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/21212-vaginal-tears-during-childbirth#:~:text=A%20vaginal%20tear%20(perineal%20laceration,opening%20in%20a%20controlled%20way
Journal of Midwifery and Women’s Health
Mayo Clinic

title.en-US: 5 of the top rules for good nutrition during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know
Even though it seems like you’re eating for two(or more!), your calorie intake won’t change much until you’re in your third trimester (weeks 28-40+)
You shouldn’t deprive yourself of what you’re craving–it’s usually your body’s way of telling you that you need something—just make sure you’re eating plenty of nutritious foods, too
Variety is the name of the pregnancy foods game to make sure you and baby are getting the nutrition you both need during this timeREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
For some people, food during pregnancy is a sore subject—for others, it could be their favorite topic of conversation. No matter what’s going down (or coming up–looking at you,
morning sickness
) during your pregnancy, it’s important to eat foods you love and foods that give you a good balance of vitamins, nutrients, and calories.
If you have any questions about what a healthy pregnancy eating plan might look like after reading, feel free to talk to a
Nutritionist
on Maven. Or message your Care Advocate to help lead you to the right provider for you.
Here are 5 simple things to keep in mind at meal time:
1. Keep an eye on your portions
Pregnancy is a time where our bodies require (some) extra calories, and that can definitely make our eyes bigger than our stomachs—or at least bigger than our actual needs.
Try to make your plate look like this:
Fill:
1⁄2 with vegetables
1⁄4 for protein
1⁄4 for complex carbs (like beans or potatoes) and/or fruit REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
While you may be growing another human, remember they are tiny beings—so you're not actually "eating for two."
2. Eat more variety

A varied diet can help you make sure you meet your daily vitamin and mineral requirements, as well as your needs for other nutrients such as fiber and fatty acids. If you’re a “cheese, bread, repeat” kind of eater, no judgment! But try to add these to your snacks and meals too:
Fruits and vegetables
Different grains such as farro or barley
Beans and lentils
Dairy
Lean proteins like greek yogurt, lentils, or lean beef
Eggs
Nuts and seeds REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Meet your seafood quota (eight to 12 ounces per week) by trying to eat a range of fish that’s low in mercury and high in omega-3 fatty acids, such as salmon and sardines. The variety will also help keep you from becoming bored with your pregnancy diet.
3. Think about how many calories you need

Every pregnancy is different: and so is every person’s dietary needs while pregnant. Pregnant people who are at a healthy pre-pregnancy weight might not need any additional calories in the first trimester, about 340 extra calories a day in the second trimester, and about 450 extra calories a day in the third trimester.
Those starting off with a lower weight may need to add more calories by increasing the size and/or frequency of their meals and snacks.
People with higher pre-pregnancy weight may need to focus only on the quality of their meals in order to gain an appropriate amount of weight.
Your Maven team of
Nutritionists
and
OB-GYNs
can help you find out what works best for your body and pregnancy any time.
4. Consider the amount of weight gain that’s right for you
First things first: every pregnancy and every body is different, so talk to your provider or a provider on Maven to figure out what pregnancy weight gain is going to be right for you.
Here’s a rough guideline to help you have that conversation:
If you were underweight before pregnancy, you should aim to gain 28-40 lbs
If you were a healthy weight before pregnancy, you should aim to gain 25-35 lbs
If you were overweight before pregnancy, you should aim to gain 15-25 lbs
If you had obesity before pregnancy, you should aim to gain 11-20 lbs
5. Take a prenatal vitamin

Think of this as your insurance plan. Pregnancy comes with cravings, nausea, fatigue, and food aversions. So even if you know the best way to fuel your body, it can be difficult to eat properly every single day.
Taking a prenatal vitamin

will help cover your bases for any nutrients you may not have eaten in the right amounts each day. These vitamins are especially important in the first trimester (and even before getting pregnant) to ensure you are getting the right amount of folic acid which can help prevent birth defects.

title.en-US: Vaginal bleeding during pregnancy: Causes and when to call your doctor

content.value: What you need to know:
Vaginal bleeding is fairly common during the first trimester of pregnancy and isn’t always a sign of a problem.
Causes of bleeding can range from irritation to the cervix, to more serious pregnancy complications that need medical care.

Always call your doctor if you have any bleeding from your vagina during pregnancy. Call your doctor or go to the emergency room right away if you’re bleeding heavily (enough to fill one pad in one hour), vomiting, and have dizziness or fainting. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Bleeding during pregnancy can be scary, but it isn’t always a sign of a serious health issue. In fact, according to the March of Dimes, about 25% of pregnant women experience bleeding or spotting (a few drops of blood on your underwear) at some point during their pregnancy. But in some cases, bleeding might be caused by a condition that needs to be checked out by your pregnancy provider right away.
Here’s everything you need to know about bleeding during pregnancy.
When to call your doctor

It’s important to call your pregnancy provider right away if you have bleeding or spotting at any time during your pregnancy—even if it’s very light or stops. “Any amount of bleeding during pregnancy can be concerning and warrants a call to your provider's office,” says Maven OB-GYN Yi-Lo Yu.
Causes of bleeding during pregnancy
Always call your doctor to be sure, but here are some common causes of bleeding during pregnancy.
Common, but usually harmless causes of bleeding during pregnancy:
Implantation bleeding:

When a fertilized egg attaches to the lining of the uterus 10 to 14 days after conception, it can cause very light bleeding called implantation bleeding. Implantation bleeding is common during the first trimester, and usually isn’t a sign of a problem.
Irritation to your cervix from a pelvic exam, routine test, or sex:
Pregnancy hormones make your cervix extra sensitive, so it can become irritated and bleed from things like pelvic exams, cervical swabs, or sex.
Subchorionic hematoma:

Also known as subchorionic hemorrhage, this is a blood clot that can form between your placenta and uterine wall. It’s fairly common—making up about 10% of all bleeding during pregnancy, according to Cleveland Clinic—and usually goes away on its own without causing any harm to you or baby.
Cervical polyps:
These are benign (non-cancerous) growths on the cervix that can bleed due to higher levels of the hormone estrogen.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Have questions about light bleeding or spotting during pregnancy? Make an appointment with a
Maven OB-GYN
or
Midwife
for advice.
More serious causes of bleeding during pregnancy:
Infections:

Certain sexually-transmitted infections (STI), like chlamydia or gonorrhea, can cause light bleeding during pregnancy. Urinary tract infections (UTI) may also cause some bleeding. If you think you have any kind of infection, tell your pregnancy provider right away. You might need treatment to keep yourself and your baby safe.
Ectopic pregnancy:

An ectopic pregnancy happens when a fertilized egg implants outside of the uterus. According to the American College of Gynecologists and Obstetricians (ACOG), about 90% of ectopic pregnancies implant in the fallopian tubes. An ectopic pregnancy can be extremely dangerous, and even life-threatening in some cases.

If you have vaginal bleeding, cramping on one side of your pelvis, and lower back pain, tell your pregnancy provider ASAP. If you have sudden, severe pain in your pelvis, abdomen, or shoulder, and dizziness or fainting, go to the emergency room.
Molar pregnancy:

A molar pregnancy causes a tumor to form (rather than a fetus) when a fertilized egg implants in the wall of the uterus. Molar pregnancies are very rare, but can cause serious complications. Some signs of molar pregnancy are bleeding, severe nausea and throwing up, and pressure or pain in the pelvis. If you have any of these symptoms, call your pregnancy provider right away.
Placenta previa:

Placenta previa is when the placenta covers part or all of the cervix. It can cause bright, red bleeding, but usually isn’t painful. Many cases of placenta previa go away on their own. If it does not, baby may need to be delivered by a cesarean (C-section) delivery.
Placenta accreta:

Placenta accreta is when the placenta attaches to the wall of the uterus too deeply. Normally, the placenta detaches from the uterus after baby is born, but in cases of placenta accreta, part or all of the placenta can remain attached. This can cause serious blood loss after delivery.
Placental abruption:

Placental abruption is a rare, but very serious complication of pregnancy that happens when the placenta partially or completely detaches from the uterus. It can be extremely dangerous for baby—without the placenta, they won’t get enough oxygen or nutrients. It can also cause heavy bleeding in the parent.
Placental abruption happens quickly, so if you have bleeding, back and abdominal pain, and very fast contractions, call your pregnancy provider immediately or go to the emergency room.
Preterm labor:
Preterm labor is when you go into labor before 37 weeks of pregnancy. Some major signs are bleeding, contractions, and your water breaking.
If you have any of these signs, call your pregnancy provider or go to your birthing hospital right away.
Depending how far along you are, your provider may try to slow labor with certain treatments.
Miscarriage:

Miscarriage is when a pregnancy ends before 20 weeks of pregnancy. It may cause bleeding that gets heavier over time and strong, painful cramps. You may pass blood clots (large clumps of sticky blood) through your vagina. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKSadly, there isn’t anything that can be done to stop a miscarriage. Many miscarriages can happen on their own at home, but later miscarriages may need to be removed. You may also choose to have medication or a procedure to quicken the process. Your pregnancy provider may ask you to come in to confirm that you are having or have had a miscarriage with an exam or an ultrasound. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have heavy, fast bleeding that does not stop (bleeding through one pad in one hour) go to the emergency room right away.
What to look out for
Every person and every pregnancy is different, so not everyone will have the same kind of bleeding. If you’re bleeding during pregnancy, be sure to tell your pregnancy provider:
The color of your blood.

“Bright red blood is usually a sign of active bleeding, which is most concerning; pink blood or pink-tinged discharge or urine is a sign of minimal bleeding; and brown blood is a sign of old blood,” says Yu.
How much you’re bleeding.

This can range from a few light drops of blood, to heavy bleeding that fills a maxi pad. This is very important for your pregnancy provider to know, so they can figure out what’s causing the bleeding.
If you have any other symptoms.
Cramping, pain in your pelvis, abdomen, or back, and dizziness or fainting can be signs of more serious issues.
The bottom line

Bleeding or spotting is concerning, but fairly common during pregnancy. Even if you have light spotting or bleeding that stops, tell your pregnancy provider right away. Bleeding or spotting isn’t always the sign of a problem, but it is important for your provider to figure out what’s causing it.
Sources
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
Archives of Medical Science
Cleveland Clinic
March of Dimes
Mayo Clinic (Placenta accreta)
Mayo Clinic (Implantation bleeding)
Mayo Clinic (Molar pregnancy)
[Mayo Clinic (Placenta previa)](
https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/placenta-previa/symptoms-causes/syc-20352768#:~:text=Placenta%20previa%20(pluh%2DSEN%2D,baby%20and%20to%20remove%20waste

title.en-US: How should I deal with morning sickness at work?

content.value: What you need to know
Just because it’s called morning sickness doesn’t mean it only comes during the morning—pregnancy nausea can happen during any time of the day.
Your workplace has to make some accommodations for you during pregnancy, and this includes when you’re sick. If you have any doubts about your rights or options, a
Maven Career Coach
can talk you through it anytime for free.
Bland foods and snacks that have lots of carbs (think crackers, breads, or ginger ale) can be really helpful to keep morning sickness in check.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Dealing with morning sickness—or more likely “all day sickness”—is particularly tough on the job because it can happen before you’re ready to share the news that you’re pregnant.

Don’t be afraid to use a sick day if you’re feeling especially awful. It can be easy to do so, but try not to feel guilty for taking care of yourself first. Of course, there will be days when you have to get things done, and that’s when you’ll want to find some coping strategies that work for you. Here are some tips from Maven Career Coach Mary Beth Ferrante.
Make bland snacks your BFF
Carbohydrates and food without lots of seasoning can help combat queasiness. These are foods like:
Crackers
Dry cereal
Toast without butterREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If they help you, keep some in your desk drawer.
Ginger is your new go-to
Ginger tea (or even just grating fresh ginger into hot water) or sucking on ginger candies can also help with nausea. You can also try:
Ginger ale
Ginger lollipops for pregnancy (these can be found at pharmacies)
Ginger chews
Medication may be an option

If your nausea is very bad or you can’t keep food down, ask your provider about prescription medication options that would be safe to try. Never take any medication or supplements during pregnancy without talking to your doctor first.
If you work in person
Take as many breaks as you can:
Getting some fresh air or resting for a moment can help keep nausea away if you’re able.
Keep bland snacks handy:
Like we mentioned before, these will be a new workday staple for you.
Bring a toothbrush:

Just in case you DO toss your less-than-flavorful cookies, you might want to consider having a toothbrush and toothpaste with you at work. Few things make you feel more nauseous than that feeling in your mouth after getting sick.
Working (and feeling nauseous) from home

Working from home may sound like a pregnant person’s dream—like you get to rest and recover as much as you need. But when you actually do work remotely you know you’re still expected to do as much (and sometimes more) work as you would in person.
Here are a few work-from-home tips to help you find morning sickness relief:
Schedule time on your calendar:

Block off time if you use an online calendar as though they’re meetings–do it in 15 or 20 minute blocks several times a day if you can. This gives you time you need to build in rest like it’s an appointment that you can’t miss.
Communicate with your supervisor:

Make sure your supervisor (and Human Resources, if you have one) knows if you plan to block time off and why: this not only means they should respect and support you needing to take time to not look at a screen and lay down, but also covers you from a legal standpoint. Make sure you email as many communications as you can should you ever need a record of it.
Rest, rest, rest:

Whether you’re blocking time off on your calendar or just choosing to tune out for your lunch break, it’s important to let your body get some time to regroup. Try eating lunch at your desk while working (if you can stomach it) and then take a quick nap or a warm bath during your lunch hour.
Change your schedule:

If your job allows, shift your working hours to when you feel best. This might mean starting and finishing work later than before. A lot of companies have experimented with more flexible work options as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and it can be a big benefit. Ask your supervisor what your options are.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
The truth is, one of the best ways to manage pregnancy symptoms including morning sickness is to speak with a
provider on Maven
to learn personalized coping strategies that will work the best for you.

title.en-US: Real talk on staying connected to my child's birth mother

content.value: Amy
Health Educator
California
Why did you decide to adopt?
Because at some point it was more important to be a parent than it was to be pregnant. I had three failed IVF attempts and the desire to parent.
How old was your children when you brought them home?
The first child we adopted one was 2 1/2 days old, and the second was brought home on the actual day of birth.
Did you choose domestic adoption, adoption from foster care, or international adoption? How did you make that decision and what was your experience like?

Domestic adoption. I wanted to start raising my kids from infancy, and I wanted an open adoption where I had a relationship with the birth parents/birth mother if possible so there were no secrets with my children.
Did you choose to work with an adoption agency?
No. I worked with a private attorney both times—not an agency.
It’s no secret that the costs involved with adoption add up. Roughly how much money did you spend on this process?
The first adoption was relatively inexpensive, about $5,000 start to finish. The second was about $20,000 because we paid living expenses for the birth mother.
What is one thing that could be improved about the adoption process for families in the future?
Keep adoptions open.
Did you have an opportunity to meet the birth moms? If so, what were those experiences like?

Yes. The first time we flew to where the birth mom lived to pick up our daughter. It has remained open for the last 30 years and I am grateful for that. The second time, we were actively involved in the pregnancy and birth and filmed a documentary for the Learning Channel on our journey. 20 years later that relationship is also still open. I look on them both as extended family, giving us the most precious gifts of our lives.
What kind of relationship do you have with your child’s birth mom today?

Open relationships with both birth moms. One lives in Florida, so I don't see her that often (maybe 5 times in the last 30 years). The other lives in Colorado, and we are Facebook friends. I send them both Mother's Day cards every year and thank them for allowing me to become a mother. It's very friendly and open. I would welcome either one of them at my house if they showed up.
When and how did you tell your children they were adopted?

From birth on; we used the word in everyday conversation, so it just became a fact of their lives, like blond hair and blue eyes. For example, "We love you so much and are so glad we adopted you." We talked about "the nice lady" whose tummy our child grew in. When my daughter was 7, she asked for a picture of the "nice lady" and we gave her one which she taped on her closet door.
How did people in your life react to your adoption decision?
Ecstatically! We had 3 baby showers and an endless parade of friends and relatives over who wanted to see the miracle.
Once you brought your child home, were there any challenges you didn’t expect?

I expected breastfeeding to be instantaneous, but it was hard. It took 5 weeks for milk to come in, and I had to use a supplemental nursing system to augment my milk with formula because I wasn't producing enough. (A supplemental nursing system, or SNS, works by helping babies suckle at the breast while also consuming milk or formula through a tube.) The second time, since we had warning, I started using a breast pump a month or so before she was born, and my milk came in 5 days! The body remembered. I still needed a supplemental nurser but it was easier this time around. I would encourage all adoptive moms (of infants) to breastfeed. It helps so much with the bonding process that needs to happen.
If you adopted as a couple, how did adoption impact your relationship with your significant other?

Since I wasn't pregnant with either of them, we kind of had equal standing in the relationship of parenting. Aside from the breastfeeding which I did, she also drank out of bottles so Dad could feed her as well.
If you were talking to your best friend who was thinking about adoption, what advice would you give her?
Give up the fantasy of recreating your DNA and embrace adoption as the wonderful option that it is.
Tell your children everything from the start. Don't keep any secrets from them.
At some point, the information about being adopted becomes your child's, not yours. Let them decide if they want to or don't want to share it at school. You shouldn't label them.
What’s the one thing you’d like to see change about the perceptions around adoption?
The concept of "real" parents versus "adoptive" parents. I'm every bit as real even if my kids didn’t emerge from my body. Using those terms is pejorative and diminishes my standing.

title.en-US: Is there any way to prepare for breastfeeding while pregnant?

content.value: What you need to know:
Every breastfeeding journey is different, and there can be a steep learning curve.
Take a breastfeeding class and meet with a lactation consultant during pregnancy.
Prep for common obstacles and have a list of supplies on hand.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you’re interested in breastfeeding, doing some preparation before your baby arrives can help you feel more confident about what to expect. That’s true whether you’re a first-time parent or an experienced one, because every baby is different—so every breastfeeding relationship is different, too.
Here are some ways to get ready for breastfeeding before your baby is born.
Take a breastfeeding class

Breastfeeding classes can give you a general idea of what to expect, and answer some common questions like: How do you start breastfeeding after your baby is born? How can you tell if your baby is getting enough to eat? What are some common breastfeeding positions?
You can get a class recommendation from your OB-GYN’s office or a local parenting group, and Maven’s free
Breastfeeding 101
class is a great online option.

“I cannot recommend meeting with a lactation consultant and taking a breastfeeding course enough,” says Maven Lactation Consultant Lauren Olofsson. “Around 35 or 36 weeks into your pregnancy is a great time to schedule this, unless you know you’ll be delivering early.”
Research common breastfeeding issues
Knowing what to do
when breastfeeding hurts
or how to deal with
clogged milk ducts or mastitis
can make those experiences feel less overwhelming if they do happen to you.
Find out what resources are available at your hospital

Many hospitals have lactation consultants available to meet with you after you give birth. They can help evaluate your baby’s latch and offer tips on breastfeeding positions, how to spot baby’s hunger cues, and more. Check if your hospital has lactation consultants, and if there’s anything you need to do ahead of time to make sure you can meet with one after baby is born.
Research some breastfeeding supplies

If you have never breastfed before, you may be surprised to find yourself wanting supplies. Though technically all you need to breastfeed is a baby and a breast, common items you might want are nipple balm, reusable or disposable nursing pads, nursing bras, and a nursing pillow. It’s also helpful to have some nursing-friendly outfits easily available, like button-down shirts or PJs.

Pumping is a part of many breastfeeding journeys. All health insurance plans need to cover a breast pump, so you can contact your insurance company for details on what you can get and when and how to get it. You may also want to get a pumping bra, milk storage bags, and some bottles for feeding baby pumped milk.
Even if you don’t make any purchases until your baby arrives, you’ll thank yourself for doing some research and saving links ahead of time.
Let your doctor know you are interested in breastfeeding

Your OB-GYN or midwife may ask about your plans for feeding your baby, or you can proactively let them know if you are interested in breastfeeding. They might recommend local groups or lactation consultants, give you reading materials, suggest a class to take, or make a note in your medical records that you hope to breastfeed so they can support you in this.
Know that there will probably be a learning curve

“Breastfeeding can be hard,” Olofsson says. “It usually takes 2-3 weeks of a big learning curve for both you and your newborn to begin to feel like it’s ‘normal,’ ‘natural,’ or ‘easy.’ Educating yourself and knowing who to call when you have questions can make a huge difference in your journey.” That said, breastfeeding doesn't always become easy or natural for everyone, and that's OK, too. The important thing is to reach out for help to figure out what’s best for you and your family.
Meet with a Maven Lactation Consultant
If you have questions about breastfeeding and how to prepare for it, Maven is here to help. You can make a free, confidential video appointment with a
Lactation Consultant
any time—while pregnant and after baby has arrived.

“Breastfeeding is a lot like riding a bike... you can’t actually ride the bike until you get on it,” Olofsson says. “But knowing where to sit, and where the handlebars and brakes are, makes it much easier to figure out how to ride that bike.”
Sources
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
Office on Women’s Health

title.en-US: What you need to know about food poisoning during pregnancy

content.value: If you’ve ever had food poisoning, you know how miserable the fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea can be. But if you catch food poisoning when you’re pregnant, it can feel even worse—and could be dangerous for you and your baby. Here’s everything you should know about food poisoning during pregnancy, including simple ways to avoid it.
What is food poisoning?
Food poisoning—sometimes called a foodborne illness—is a sickness that happens when you eat or drink something contaminated with certain bacteria, parasites, viruses, or chemicals.
Many cases of food poisoning are caused by:
Eating raw, undercooked, or spoiled meat, poultry, fish, or eggs
Eating unwashed fruits and vegetables, like sprouts, or those that haven’t been washed thoroughly (like vegetables from a garden)
Eating food that has come into contact with human or animal feces (poop)
Eating deli meats, cold foods from a buffet or salad bar, and undercooked hot dogs
Drinking unpasteurized milk or juice
Why is food poisoning dangerous during pregnancy?
Being pregnant changes the way your immune system works and can make you more likely to catch certain infections and illnesses.

Being pregnant can make food poisoning dangerous for both you and your baby. Oftentimes, food poisoning is mild, but types of food poisoning or very severe cases can have serious risks. Some of these risks include:
Miscarriage, when a pregnancy ends before week 20 of pregnancy
Stillbirth, when a pregnancy ends after week 20 of pregnancy
Preterm labor, when you go into labor before week 37 of pregnancy
Premature birth, meaning baby is born before week 37 of pregnancy
Low birth weight, meaning baby is born weighing less than 5 pounds, 8 ounces
Fever and diarrhea in baby after they’re born
Serious infections in baby, like meningitis, an infection that causes swelling in their brain and spinal cord
What are the symptoms of food poisoning?

Cases of food poisoning can range from mild to severe. Symptoms vary from case-to-case, but most types cause stomach pain, diarrhea, and vomiting. Some kinds of food poisoning can be confused with a cold or the flu because they have flu-like symptoms (without the respiratory symptoms of cold and flu, like sneezing, coughing, or congestion).
If you’re pregnant and develop any of these symptoms, call your pregnancy provider right away:
Stomach pain or cramping
Vomiting (outside of morning sickness)
Diarrhea or blood in your poop
Fever or chills
Headache or a stiff neck
Confusion or trouble balancing REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

These can be signs of a serious foodborne illness, so it’s important to get medical care ASAP. Depending on your symptoms, your pregnancy provider might do a blood test or stool sample to check for bacteria, viruses, or parasites.
How is food poisoning treated?

The treatment for food poisoning depends on how sick you are. In most cases, you’ll just need to rest and drink a lot of water or an electrolyte drink to stay hydrated. If necessary, your pregnancy provider might prescribe a pregnancy-safe antibiotic to protect you and your baby from infection.
If you have a severe case of food poisoning, your provider could recommend hospitalization, so you can receive IV fluids and be monitored until you’re better.
It’s always better to be safe, so be sure to call your pregnancy provider if you develop any symptoms of food poisoning or learn about contaminated foods or outbreaks during pregnancy.
What are the most serious types of food poisoning?

Certain types of food poisoning can be especially dangerous for pregnant people. If you think you could have been exposed to any of these while pregnant, tell your provider right away—they’ll want to run some tests and possibly treat you with medication.
Some serious types of food poisoning include:
Listeriosis
Listeriosis is caused by the
Listeria
bacteria, which is commonly found in dirt, water, animals, and animal waste.

Fortunately, listeriosis is rare. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there are about 1,600 cases of listeriosis in the U.S. each year. And of those 1,600 cases, only about 200 occur in pregnant people (out of 4 million pregnancies each year).
Although it’s rare, listeriosis can pass from parent to baby through the placenta and have serious health effects.
Some foods that are more likely to be contaminated with
Listeria
bacteria are:
Soft, unpasteurized cheeses, like feta or queso fresco
Deli meats, hot dogs or dried sausages (these are safe if they’re heated to the point of steaming)
Unwashed fruits and vegetables
Cold salads, like potato salad or coleslaw, from delis or salad bars
Unpasteurized milk and juice
Smoked, jerkied, kippered, lox, or nova-style fishREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
It can take a long time for symptoms of listeriosis to appear—ranging anywhere from a few days to 2 months after eating or drinking contaminated food.
Be sure to call your pregnancy provider or chat with a
Maven OB-GYN
right away if you develop any gastrointestinal flu-like symptoms or have a stiff neck.
Toxoplasmosis
Toxoplasmosis is caused by a parasite called Toxoplasma gondii and can be found in contaminated foods and cat poop.

Many people have already been infected with toxoplasmosis, so the chances of catching it during pregnancy are very low. If you do happen to get it for the first time during pregnancy, it can be dangerous for your baby.
Some foods that are more likely to be contaminated with Toxoplasma gondii are:
Raw or undercooked meat
Unwashed fruits or vegetables
Unpasteurized goat milk
Untreated water
Raw or undercooked oysters, mussels, or clamsREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have a cat, try to avoid changing its litter box while you’re pregnant. If you have to change it, be sure to wear disposable gloves and wash your hands with soap and water after.
Some other things you can do to protect yourself include:
Changing the litter box daily (the parasite doesn’t become infectious until 1 to 5 days after it has been shed through cat poop)
Feeding your cat commercial cat food (avoid giving them raw or undercooked meat)
Keeping your cat indoors, so they can catch rodents or birds infected with toxoplasmosis
Avoiding stray cats or kittens
Wearing gloves if you garden
Salmonellosis
Salmonellosis is caused by a bacteria called
Salmonella
. It’s found in foods that are contaminated with
Salmonella
and in animals including pet reptiles and birds.

It’s rare for salmonellosis to spread from parent to baby during pregnancy, but the baby could be exposed during delivery. They could be born with a fever, diarrhea, or meningitis in very serious cases.
Foods that are more likely to be contaminated with
Salmonella
are:
Raw or undercooked meat, fish, or poultry
Raw or undercooked eggs
Fruits and vegetables that come into contact with animal poop while they’re growing and are not washed correctly REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
You can also cross-contaminate foods with
Salmonella
. For example, if you use a cutting board to cut raw chicken and then cut vegetables without washing the cutting board, you could spread
Salmonella
from the chicken to the veggies.
Coming into contact with certain animals can also expose you to
Salmonella
. If you have a pet reptile or bird, or keep chickens, ducks, or geese, be sure to wash your hands with soap and water after you handle them.
Salmonella
can be spread by touching an animal’s fur, scales, or feathers, or coming into contact with their poop, food, or bedding.
Trichinosis (also called Trichinellosis)
Trichinosis is caused by a parasite called
Trichinella
and is most often found in raw or undercooked meats, especially pork products.
Although there’s some evidence that trichinosis can pass from parent to baby, the good news is that trichinosis is extremely rare—it affects about 10,000 people worldwide per year.
The foods that are more likely to be contaminated with
Trichinella
are:
Raw or undercooked meat, especially pork
Meat that hasn’t been stored or refrigerated correctly
Meat from infected wild animals, like deer, moose, elk, boar, and birds
How can I avoid food poisoning?
There are a few simple steps you can take to protect yourself and your baby from food poisoning:
Avoid eating food that has been sitting out for 2 hours or longer
Wash your hands with soap and water before handling your food
Always completely cook meat, poultry, and fish
Thoroughly wash fruits and vegetables before you eat them
Avoid deli meats (unless heated to steaming), unpasteurized soft cheeses, unpasteurized milk or juice, and cold salads from delis, buffets, or salad bars
Avoid cross-contaminating knives, cutting boards, and other kitchenware by washing them after you prepare raw meat or unwashed fruits or vegetablesREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Remember, if you develop any gastrointestinal flu-like symptoms, it’s important to call your pregnancy provider right away. Depending on your symptoms and risk factors, they might want to check your blood or stool for infection.
The bottom line

Pregnancy can make you more vulnerable to food poisoning, but the good news is, very dangerous infections like listeriosis, toxoplasmosis, and trichinosis are very rare. Practicing good hand washing, thoroughly cooking meat and cleaning produce, and avoiding certain foods can protect you and your baby from foodborne illnesses.
If you have any questions about food poisoning, you can make an online appointment with a
Maven Nutritionist
for advice.
Sources
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Cleveland Clinic
March of Dimes
U.S. Food and Drug Administration

title.en-US: Why you should take a prenatal vitamin during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know:
During pregnancy, your baby takes the nutrients they need to grow from you. So you need extra nutrients to support you both.
Taking a prenatal vitamin every day and eating healthy food will help keep you and baby healthy. They also help protect your baby from certain birth defects.
Read your prenatal vitamin’s label to make sure it has folic acid, iron, calcium, choline, and vitamin D. These are most important during pregnancy.
Don’t start taking a vitamin without asking your doctor or a
Maven provider
if it’s safe first!REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

When you’re pregnant, your body needs extra nutrients to support your growing baby. It can be hard to get all the nutrients you and baby need from food alone. So, it’s a good idea to take a prenatal vitamin every day.

Lots of stores (like Walmart, Target, or your grocery store) sell prenatal vitamins. You can also ask your doctor for a prescription for prenatal vitamins that will be covered by Medicaid. If you are not sure which prenatal vitamin to take, talk to your doctor or a
Maven provider
to help you choose.
What are prenatal vitamins?

Prenatal vitamins are vitamins for people who are pregnant or who are trying to get pregnant. They are usually a pill or gummy. They have vitamins and minerals that pregnant people need. Taking a prenatal vitamin along with eating healthy foods can help you have a healthy pregnancy and baby. They can also help protect your baby from certain birth defects.
How often should I take a prenatal vitamin?
It is important to take a prenatal vitamin every day when you are pregnant to support your body and your growing baby. Make sure you read the instructions on your vitamin’s label.
When should I take a prenatal vitamin?

If you want to get pregnant soon, start taking a prenatal vitamin now. Taking a prenatal vitamin early in your pregnancy can help your baby develop. If you are already pregnant, it is not too late to start! Talk to your doctor or a
Maven provider
about the best prenatal vitamin for you. They will make sure it has the right amount of nutrients for you and baby.
What should I look for in a prenatal vitamin?

When you are pregnant, you need higher amounts of certain nutrients. Prenatal vitamins are made with higher levels of these important vitamins and minerals. But they do not have the full amount you and your baby need. That is why it’s important to both eat healthy foods and take a prenatal vitamin every day.
These are the most important nutrients to look for on the label of your prenatal vitamin:
REPLACEWITHASSET
Do I need to take extra vitamins?
Your doctor might ask you to take a prenatal vitamin and an extra supplement (or pill) if you have:
Food allergies that keep you from eating certain foods
A special diet, like a vegetarian or vegan diet
A higher risk of having a baby with birth defects in the brain or spinal cord (called neural tube defects)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Taking too much of a vitamin or mineral can be dangerous. Always check with your doctor first before taking anything.
Will prenatal vitamins make me feel sick?

Sadly, some people might feel sick after they take their prenatal vitamins. If taking a prenatal vitamin hurts your stomach or makes you feel like you need to throw up, try to take it at night. That way, you are asleep when it starts to bother you. If you have to take your prenatal vitamin during the day, make sure you eat something first. You can also try a gummy version. Some people think gummies are easier on the stomach.
Where can I get prenatal vitamins?
