Remember to talk to your doctor or a
Maven provider
first about the right prenatal vitamin for you. You can find prenatal vitamins at lots of stores, like:
Walmart
Target
Walgreens
CVS
Rite Aid
Your grocery storeREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have WIC benefits, you can get free or low-cost prenatal vitamins. Call your WIC office or your doctor to learn more about discounts.
You can also ask your doctor for a prescription for prenatal vitamins that will be covered by Medicaid.
Need help?
If you have any questions about prenatal vitamins,
ask us
! You can video chat or message any question to any Maven provider for free.
Sources
ACOG
March of Dimes
WICHealth.org

title.en-US: One third trimester exercise you’ll be glad you did

content.value: Surprise—it’s not a Kegel!

The pelvic tilt is a simple exercise with lots of benefits during pregnancy. For one, it can be very effective at managing back pain that’s common among moms-to-be, especially in the third trimester. What’s more, as you prepare your body for childbirth, a strong pelvis is key. The problem is that many women don’t know how to do pelvic tilts correctly and end up activating the wrong muscles.
Here’s a step-by-step guide to help you master the movement. As always, check with your doctor before adding this or any other new moves to your workout regimen.
Stand up straight with your back against a wall and your feet about shoulder-width apart.
Place your hand in the small of your back, and you should feel a space between your back and the wall.
Now try to press your back against your hand to reduce the size of the space and flatten the lower part of your spine.
Hold this position for a moment and then relax. Aim to complete 2-3 sets of 10 repetitions each.

Remember, the focus should be on your pelvic floor muscles. One common mistake women make when doing this exercise is clenching their buttocks muscles. Try to keep those relaxed so your pelvis does the work.
One last thing... Working with a pelvic floor physical therapist during pregnancy can go a long way to protecting your pelvic floor health.
Book an appointment
to video chat with one of the PTs in Maven’s network, and childbirth and recovery may go a lot more smoothly.

title.en-US: Nesting: Should you nest before baby?

content.value: What you need to know:
You might feel like nesting, or suddenly want to organize and clean your whole home, in the second or third trimester.
Some ways to nest include prepping and freezing meals, organizing baby’s nursery, and packing your hospital bag.
There’s no pressure to nest—if you don’t feel like it, put your feet up and rest during this time. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Nesting, or the sudden urge to
Home Edit

your entire life in the second or third trimester, may or may not happen for you. But if it does, you might feel like you suddenly want to spend time cleaning, cooking, organizing, and have everything you need ready and waiting for when baby makes their debut.

But know that if you don’t get the nesting urge, that’s normal too and there’s no pressure to nest at all! The last months of your pregnancy should be about resting, putting your feet up when you can, and taking care of your mental and physical health. Ignore whatever you see on your social media feed or have heard from others and do what feels best for you.

“Not every person experiences an overwhelming urge to nest and that's OK,” says Maven Mental Health Provider Cynthia Coffelt. “In fact, I highly recommend using the time before baby comes as an opportunity to decrease stress, rest, and recharge as much as possible. If working on baby's nursery or other baby-related prep is nurturing for you, then do those things. But if not—engaging in activities you enjoy, spending quality time with loved ones, and resting is also very important before you deliver.”
If you do get the nesting urge, here are some ideas for what to prep.
Cook and freeze meals

Preparing and freezing a few meals now can go a long way after you have the baby. That way, you will have something healthy to eat when you’ve got your hands full. (Or to have on hand for late night feedings when you’re starving.) Look online for a few recipes that sound good to you.
Some ideas for meals and snacks to freeze are:
Soups and stews
Bean or chicken chili
Meatballs
Lasagna
Casseroles
Pot pies
Muffins or banana bread
How do I freeze meals?

Once your meals or snacks have cooled off, you can freeze them in gallon-size freezer bags. Or, for casseroles, wrap them in layers of plastic wrap and then a layer of aluminum foil. Just make sure everything is sealed airtight so you don’t get freezer burn.
Hit the grocery store

If cooking and freezing meals isn’t your thing, you can also nest away at the grocery store. Look for snacks and foods for the pantry that won’t go bad. Pick up your favorite healthy snacks (and some treats) that you could eat at all times of the day and night. And that you can eat with one hand while holding a baby. Some easy-to-reach for options might be:
Popcorn
Nuts like almonds, peanuts, cashews
Dried fruit
Canned tuna or salmon
Peanut butter
Crackers and pretzels
Canned or boxes of soup
Instant oatmeal
Cereal
Dark chocolate chips
Yogurt cups (or instant mac and cheese cups, let’s be honest)
Organize the nursery
Get everything ready for baby and make it easy for you to find:
Put together the crib and/or bassinet (have your partner, friend, or family member help with the heavy lifting)
Paint the room (just make sure you keep the windows open to get some air!)
Make a cozy corner with a glider or rocking chair, pillows, and baby books. This is a great place where you can breast or bottle feed your baby and spend time reading together.
Put together the changing table and stock it with diapers, wipes, and diaper cream
Wash any new baby clothes or pajamas you have and put them away in the closet or dresser
Other ideas
Make a
postpartum care plan
Pack your hospital bag
Take out your breast pump (if you’re using one) and sanitize all the parts
Wash and sanitize bottles
Install the car seat base
Set up “stations” around your home where you can change, feed, and hang with baby
Don’t forget to care for your mental and physical health
Feeling like you need to nest isn’t a bad thing—it means you can get a lot done before baby arrives.

Just take care not to overdo it or push yourself when you need to rest, too. For you, resting and caring for your mental health might mean taking a nap, going for a walk, listening to your favorite music, or calling a friend or family member.

“If you find that these nesting activities provide satisfaction and a sense of accomplishment, then keep going,” says Coffelt. “However, if your thoughts are constantly thinking about your ‘to do’ list and your mental and physical well-being suffers, it might be helpful to reach out for support.”
Book a free online appointment with a
Maven Mental Health Provider
anytime.

title.en-US: Estimating your out-of-pocket costs

content.value: Due to COVID-19, your doctor and hospital's policies around in-person versus virtual appointments, who can accompany you to appointments, and who can be present during labor and delivery may differ from the information below. Consult your doctor or hospital if you have questions about their COVID-19 policies and procedures.

Found a provider you love? Congrats! Now it’s time to talk cost. If you live in Canada or Europe, your public health system has you covered. But in the U.S., maternity costs are often a mystery until you get the bill. Read on to learn what to look out for and how to make a quick estimate from Maven Director of Care Advocacy (and benefits guru), Kaitlyn Hamilton.
First things first

The cost of pregnancy care and delivery can vary dramatically based on where you live, which hospital you choose, and of course, your insurance coverage. But the fact remains that many moms get sticker shock when it comes to having a baby. The good news? With a little preparation, you’ll be able to better predict your out-of-pocket expenses, advocate for yourself, and avoid tough surprises.
The first phone call you should make

Very early on in your pregnancy, we recommend calling your insurance company and asking these key questions. It’s also a good idea to write down the representative’s name and the date and time you spoke.
Can you confirm my copays, deductible, coinsurance, and out-of-pocket maximum?
Are there any common prenatal, labor and delivery needs are not covered by my policy?
What prenatal tests are covered (ultrasounds, amniocentesis, genetic testing, etc.)?
Will I need pre-authorization for any of these parts of prenatal care?
Which hospitals in my area are in my insurance policy’s network?
Do you cover birth center/home-births or only deliveries in a hospital?
Are the healthcare staff providing care to me or to my newborn who may be out of network?
How long of a postpartum stay is covered after delivery?
[If you have identified a provider] Is my provider in-network?

Once you’ve done the legwork to understand what your current plan covers, what are your options? Unfortunately, pregnancy is not one of the life events which qualifies you for a special open enrollment period. (Once you give birth, that changes.) However, if you’re coming up on the open enrollment period set by your employer, you’ll be able to switch plans if the one you currently have isn’t cost-efficient. There’s no one right plan for everyone, but our guide can help you choose wisely.
Consider a low-deductible health plan with robust coverage

Before you got pregnant, you may have only needed to check-in with a provider a few times a year—say, for a general check-up and a lingering cold or two. But during your pregnancy, you’re guaranteed to have many more visits (even if they are, for the time being, mostly virtual). With this in mind, you may want to consider selecting a low-deductible health plan even if it looks more expensive on the benefits selection sheet. Here’s why: With a low-deductible plan, you’ll likely pay more for your premium (the up-front amount you pay each month), but your coverage will kick in sooner, and you’ll only be responsible for copays and a small percentage of the total costs (your coinsurance). If you have a high deductible plan, you’ll likely end up paying more in the long run, because you’ll responsible for paying more medical costs in full before your coverage kicks in. Speak to your doctor's office about how many appointments you can expect to have to help you decide.
Understand your plan's out-of-network benefits

The best way to lower your pregnancy costs is to apply your insurance coverage and to use in-network providers whenever possible. That said, pregnancy and birth are life events in which you want to feel extremely confident about the health team in your corner. If you have your eye on a particular practice or provider that is out-of-network, it’s a good idea to opt for an insurance plan that has more favorable out-of-network rates. Keep in mind, even if your current plan does not have out-of-network benefits, you might still be able to apply for an exception for your maternity care. You’ll also want to have a discussion up front about the level of assistance they’re able to provide in submitting out-of-network claims. Many practices have experienced billers who can help you understand your benefits and help you advocate for the highest reimbursement rate possible.
Spot potential hidden charges
The vast majority of hidden costs during pregnancy come about when something isn’t covered by insurance but you were expecting it to be. Here are a few common factors that end up in surprise bills.
Genetic testing

Genetic testing comes in a variety of forms (like non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT), chorionic villus sampling (CVS), and amniocentesis). This can be amazing for information gathering, but be sure you know exactly what’s covered before you agree to a test. Coverage is often authorized in high-risk pregnancies, but it may require pre-authorization or documentation of a medical necessity before you move forward. The lesson: Don’t wait until after the test is done to call your carrier, because it could be too late.
Ultrasounds that aren’t medically indicated

It can be incredibly exciting to see your little one, but usually only a small number of ultrasounds throughout your pregnancy are considered medically necessary. A three-dimensional ultrasound, which provides very clear images of your baby, can be done in addition to a traditional, two-D ultrasound. But before you order one, be sure to check with your insurance company. If your doctor hasn’t recommended a 3D ultrasound, it could end up being one very expensive keepsake.
A private hospital room

Depending on your hospital, there may or may not be enough real estate for each patient to have a private postpartum recovery room. If privacy is important to you and you aren’t guaranteed your own room, remember that the additional cost typically isn’t covered by insurance. Do your homework to find out the cost of an upgrade because the bill will vary greatly based on where you live and the hospital where you’re giving birth. (It could tally anywhere from $50 a night to upwards of $1,000.) You can also have a conversation with your provider about when it would be okay to head home. Sometimes there are important reasons to linger in the hospital for observation and support, but if you and your provider feel comfortable with a check-out that comes before the end of a typical stay (which is often 48-72 hours), it’s something to consider.
Anesthesiologists and pediatricians in the hospital

Most patients are able to find an OB-GYN/midwife who is in-network because they’re able to plan ahead. But when it comes to last-minute providers you may need at the hospital, staying in-network is a little trickier. Our advice? Before you go in, call the hospital’s billing office to discuss whether all of your providers are in-network during your stay. Then, designate an advocate (like your partner or a doula) to be responsible for confirming that all of the providers who are a part of your care team are in-network. When you’re in labor, you’ll likely have other things on your mind!
Be savvy about keeping costs down
Here are three smart ways to avoid unnecessary spending.
Take advantage of Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) and Flex Spending Accounts (FSAs)

. HSAs and FSAs let you put money into an account pre-tax so you can use these funds exclusively for certain out-of-pocket medical costs (such as copays, deductibles, coinsurance, and prescription drugs). When you’re pregnant, these accounts can save you hundreds of dollars.
Understand when your deductible resets.

You may have to pay two deductibles if your prenatal care spans two calendar years. This might be avoided if your provider uses global billing (a one-time billing which includes all your prenatal care, plus labor and delivery fees). Sometimes plans will offer carry-over programs so be sure to call your provider to ask what your options are. Knowing what to expect in advance will help you budget accordingly.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Be thorough about record-keeping so you can advocate for yourself when necessary.

It’s crucial to keep detailed records of all the care that you receive and each bill you get. If you see something on a bill that doesn’t make sense to you, ask questions! Sometimes it may take multiple phone calls and many sets of eyes (and therefore a heap of patience and persistence!) to get to the bottom of things, but you deserve to understand each and every charge. Common clerical errors include double billing, charging for a longer hospital stay, cancelled orders (like for medical tests), or fees for services that were never performed. A billing error can be a nightmare, but the more you document up-front, the more confident you’ll be in advocating for yourself. If you believe that you have been overcharged, call your insurance company and request reimbursement.
Questions?

If you have any additional questions, or you need more advice on dealing with your insurance company, don’t hesitate to reach out to your Maven Care Advocate. However, please note that Maven and the Care Advocacy team are not financial advisors. This guide and all discussions via Maven are not financial advice or a guarantee of pricing (which varies widely and is subject to change), and should not take the place of consulting with a certified financial planner, tax or legal advisor, and your healthcare providers and insurance carrier.

title.en-US: The truth about diastasis recti (and how to treat it)

content.value: Losing weight after pregnancy can be a challenge for anyone, but sometimes a lingering stomach “pooch” can be an indicator of something else: diastasis recti. Many women have some form of diastasis recti after giving birth and even one year postpartum. According to a 2016 study of 300 first-time mothers, diastasis recti was prevalent in 33.1% at 21 weeks of pregnancy, 60.0% at 6 weeks postpartum, 45.4% at 6 months postpartum, and 32.6% at 12 months postpartum.

While diastasis is common and can be treated, most moms have never heard of it, been assessed for it, or know how to prevent it. Here’s what you need to know to take care of yourself according to Maven Physical Therapist Heather Brooks.
What is diastasis recti?

Diastasis recti is a separation of the six-pack muscles (or, rectus abdominis) that are above, below, and at the belly button. The line of tissue that runs down the middle of your abs (called linea alba) naturally separates to make room for your growing baby, but how much it separates can vary depending on how strong or weak your core muscles are prior to and throughout your pregnancy.
How do I know if I have diastasis recti?
The best first step is to speak to your OB-GYN or chat with a physical therapist on Maven. They can perform the following assessment and recommend exercises that can help.
How to check for diastasis recti:
Lie flat on your back with knees up.
Place one hand palm down with fingers toward the pelvic area over the belly button.
Apply pressure above and below the belly button while lifting your head and shoulders.
With the head and shoulders lifted, you will feel the separation at your fingertips.
Measure how many fingers are between the right and left separation.
If the separation is 3 fingers wide or great, this is characterized as a significant separation.
Can it be treated?

The good news is that diastasis recti can often be treated and a lingering “pooch” can be reduced with proper strengthening exercise and diet. See below for some recommended exercises—but remember, doing exercises the wrong way can worsen the condition and, in some cases, diastasis recti can be serious enough to warrant surgery. It is always best to speak with your OB-GYN or a physical therapist first to get an assessment and recommendations.
What happens if diastasis recti is left untreated?

If left untreated, diastasis recti can cause back and/or pelvic pain, put you at risk for hernia, and may limit your ability to perform daily activities so it’s important to be assessed by your doctor and pursue physical therapy if needed.
Which exercises can help?

The deepest layer of your abdominal muscles is the transverse abdominis (TrA). It acts like a corset that flattens your belly and supports your pelvic floor and back. Strengthening the TrA is crucial to decreasing or “closing the gap” of diastasis recti. Women with minor separation will almost always see improvement with physical therapy. Women with more significant separation can also see improvement with time and correct exercises.

The below exercises can all be performed before, during, and after pregnancy. These exercises can be started 24-48 hours after vaginal delivery, but should not be performed until at least 6 weeks after a C-section. Always speak with your OB-GYN or chat with a Physical Therapist on Maven before performing any diastasis recti exercises as doing exercises the wrong way can worsen the condition.
Exercise #1: Transverse abdominal contraction
Lay on your back with knees bent.
Tuck belly button to spine as if you are zipping up a tight pair of jeans.
Hold for 10 sec while breathing normally, then release.
Repeat about 10 times and throughout the day during activities like lifting, carrying, getting in and out of bed, washing dishes, etc.
Exercise #2: Sheet technique
Lie on your back on top of a sheet or towel with your knees bent.
Take both ends of the sheet in each hand and criss-cross them over the area where the separation is most severe (left end of the sheet in the right hand, right end of the sheet in the left hand).
Pull your hands apart so that the sheet is cinched tight (this assists the abs in coming together).
Take a deep breath in, activating the deeper abdominal muscles by pulling your belly button in towards your spine, and raise your head off the floor in a crunch-like position.
Then, breathe out slowly as you lower your head and shoulders back to the floor. Repeat this as often as you feel comfortable, aiming for about 30 times per day.
Exercise #3: Modified cat/cow
Get down on all fours.
Contract your abdominals as tightly as you can.
Pull your belly button towards your spine, feeling the belly being drawn up to the ceiling to activate the deeper abdominal muscles.
Hold a few seconds.
Release and repeat
Other treatments can include (but are not limited to) kinesio taping, biofeedback, dry needling, and connective tissue massage.
Can I do sit-ups?

A quick search on “diastasis recti” brings up a lot of mixed information about sit-ups and crunches. For the record, Brooks says, “Sit-ups and crunches won’t cause diastasis recti, but they can make it worse if not performed correctly. It’s important to be aware of how to perform the correct abdominal strengthening without causing increased pressure and strain to the rectus abdominis in order to prevent a larger “gap” in the muscle tissue.” Speak to your OB-GYN or a Physical Therapist for help and if any exercises are painful, stop and talk to your doctor.
What if the exercises don’t work or I’m in pain?

If performing the exercises above regularly doesn’t lead to improvement—or you’re experiencing sharp, chronic pain while completing everyday tasks—it’s time to speak with a doctor. According to Brooks, if there is a separation that is greater than 3 fingers wide, and abdominal muscles stay weak and don’t heal properly, abdominal contents can protrude through the muscle wall and cause a hernia so it’s important to speak with your doctor.
Will my diastasis recti ever heal?

Know that healing diastasis recti takes time and effort. Physical therapy exercises like those listed above and others can make a big difference if done regularly and correctly. If you’d like personal advice on the best exercises for diastasis recti, video chat or message with a Maven Physical Therapist for help from the comfort of your own home.

title.en-US: 7 reasons to join a parents’ group

content.value: It’s true that it takes a village to raise kids, so joining a parents’ group can be a major help. From parenting advice, to local referrals, to gently used baby and kid gear, there are plenty of reasons to find an online or in-person parenting group in your area.
Here are 7 reasons why it’s a good idea to join a parents’ group, and where to find one that fits your family.
1. You can meet people

Staying home with your kids can feel lonely sometimes—especially with a new baby that needs care around the clock. Joining a parents’ group gives you the opportunity to socialize with people you may not have met otherwise.
2. Your kids can meet other kids

Socialization isn’t only important for parents—it’s vital to your kids’ growth and development, too. If you join an in-person parents’ group, your kids will have lots of opportunities to play and socialize with other kids their age. If you join an online group, find out if they have any opportunities for community members to meet in-person. Lots of parent blogs, for example, have reader events in different locations.
3. You can ask for parenting advice
Many of us rely on fellow parents to help us sort through the questions that pop up during that first year (and beyond).
When is a good time to start solid foods? When should I try to potty train? Why is my child allergic to sleep?
Having a go-to group to turn to can be super helpful when you’re trying to navigate parenthood.
4. You can learn about different parenting styles

We all have our own parenting styles and might not always have the opportunity to see other parents in action. But joining a parents’ group—whether it’s online or in-person—can expose you to all kinds of parenting styles. You might even pick up some pointers from parenting styles you didn’t think were for you.
5. You can find local referrals

Looking for a new pediatrician? Or a daycare? Local parents who have been there, done that, can give you referrals for all things child-rearing in your area. Having that insider information can save you a ton of time and energy when you’re looking for a new service.
6. You can find gently used gear (or honest reviews)

The cost of gear for babies and kids—especially if you’re a first-time parent—can add up quickly. Local parents’ groups are a great place to buy stuff you need (or swap) without spending a fortune. They’re also a solid place to get honest baby product reviews.
Is that swing/swaddle/sound machine really worth the hype?
7. You can find support from other parents
Connecting with other parents who are going through similar ups and downs can help ease the isolation that many parents feel.

“Having someone recognize and validate your situation, someone you can vent to, who can identify and tell you what you’re experiencing is normal, is really important and satisfying,” says Kaitlyn Hamilton, Director of Care Advocacy at Maven.
Where to find a parents’ group that works for you

Finding the right parents’ group for you and your family depends on what you’re looking for. Do you want to socialize with other parents in-person? Are you looking for a specialized group that practices yoga? Or identifies as LGBTQIA+? Do you want to chat online with parents from your couch?
Here are a few ways to find the right parents’ group for you:
Larger groups might advertise in your local newspaper or on community bulletin boards. Keep an eye out for listings for groups that seem interesting to you.
Search on Facebook or online for local groups in your area or check out apps like Peanut that link parents locally or by interest.
Ask other parents’ at your kids’ school or favorite playground if they know about any local groups
If you want to join a digital group, there are thousands of options online and on Facebook. This can be especially helpful if you want to join a specialized group.
Can’t find the group you’re looking for? Consider starting your own! Facebook, Reddit, and other online communities make it easy to start connecting with like-minded parents

title.en-US: What's a birth plan and why do you need one?

content.value: Getting ready for baby? Don’t forget to make a plan for your labor and delivery!
Don’t know what to put in a birth plan? Don’t worry—We’ve got you. You don’t have to do it alone.
Maven offers
free birth plan appointments
. Trained providers will walk you through everything you need to know on a video call.
Here’s how to get started and how to make a free birth plan appointment on Maven.
How do I book a free birth plan appointment on Maven?
After week 28 of pregnancy, you can book a free birth plan appointment on Maven.
Send your Maven Care Advocate  a free message when you’re ready. They’ll book the birth plan appointment at a time that works for you. It’s as simple as that!
Are there any materials I should read to help me prepare for my appointment?
Check out
My Maven birth plan guide
before your appointment to get an idea of the information you’ll go over with your provider during your session.
Explore your
My birth preferences checklist
. Your provider will help you fill this out during your session.
What is a birth plan, exactly?
A birth plan is a list of how you want your labor and delivery to go.
You can list out:
Your wants and needs for when you’re in labor (like if you want to use a birthing ball or stool)
How you want to deliver your baby (like you want your support person to cut the umbilical cord)
How you want things to go after you give birth REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

You can print your birth plan out on paper or have it saved on your phone. You can share it with your pregnancy provider before you give birth. And when you arrive at the hospital, you’ll give your birth plan to the nurses and staff.
That way, your care team knows exactly what you want your birth experience to look like.
Of course, you don’t need a birth plan—it’s optional. But it can really help the staff know your wants and needs. This can help you have a better birth experience.
When you’re in labor, it may be harder to think clearly about what you want, too. A birth plan helps you plan in advance. That way, you’ll be ready for whatever comes up.
Will my birth plan work out or be followed?
There’s no way to know how your baby’s birth will go. Actually, most births don’t go exactly according to plan. That’s why it’s so important to be flexible.
Still, it’s nice to have an idea of what you want written down, anyway. If something goes differently (and it probably will) you’ll be ready.

For example, what happens If you want a vaginal birth, but your doctor recommends a cesarean delivery (or C-section)? You can write in your birth plan some options you want to try first if it's not a medical emergency. (But be sure to ask your doctor why they’re recommending a C-section—sometimes they are necessary).
Your hospital care team should try their best to follow your plan. If they aren’t—don’t be afraid to speak up. Or, ask your support person to help you.
What goes in a birth plan?
A birth plan should include anything important you want your support team to know. Are you planning to have a natural birth? Do you want an epidural? Be sure to include that!
Your birth plan can say:
Who you want with you in the room for support
How bright or low you want the lights in the room
Do you want to move around while you’re in labor? (If you have an epidural, this might not be possible.)
Pain management—epidural or no epidural?
Will you breastfeed right after you deliver or use formula?
If you’ve given birth before, do you want anything to go different this time?

title.en-US: What you need to know about fresh versus frozen embryo transfers

content.value: What you need to know:
An embryo transfer is used during in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment. A fertilized egg placed in the uterus, so it can (hopefully!) implant and become a pregnancy.
Embryo transfers can be done with fresh or previously frozen embryos.
There are pros and cons to both methods, so you’ll work with your fertility provider to figure out which option is best for you. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Going through an embryo transfer can feel nerve wracking, and having to choose between transfering a fresh or frozen embryo may add even more pressure. The good news is, several studies have shown that both fresh and frozen embryo transfers can be successful, but which will work best will depend on your individual case.
Here, we look at the pros and cons of each method and explain what the science says about your chances of success.
How an embryo transfer works
Embryo transfers are used during in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment. All of the
steps of IVF
can get confusing, so here’s a quick refresher on where embryo transfers come in:
After eggs have been retrieved and sperm has been collected (or donor sperm is prepared), they're combined in a petri dish for fertilization.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If an egg has been fertilized, it will be allowed to develop for 3-6 days.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Next, embryo grading
is used to figure out which embryos have the highest chance of implanting in the uterus. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Your fertility provider will then place (transfer) the highest graded embryo in the uterus. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
The two-week wait to find out if you’re pregnant begins! REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

These steps will be slightly different if you choose a fresh or frozen embryo transfer (more on that next). Your fertility provider will go over each step and timeline with you before your embryo transfer.
What it means to be “fresh” or “frozen”
So, what, exactly, do fertility providers mean by “fresh” or “frozen”?

During a fresh embryo transfer, your eggs and sperm are combined to form an embryo. Then, the embryo is transferred to your uterus 3-6 days after the eggs are fertilized. A frozen embryo transfer follows the same steps, but rather than transferring the fresh embryo to your uterus, it’s frozen in a lab setting. After several weeks (or months, if you prefer to wait longer), the frozen embryo is carefully thawed, then transferred to the uterus. It’s important to know that the amount of time an embryo stays frozen doesn’t affect its chances of successfully implanting in the uterus.
The pros and cons of fresh and frozen embryo transfers
Here’s what you need to know about each type of transfer:
Fresh embryo transfer
Pros:
A shorter time to pregnancy.

If you’re not freezing your embryos, they can be implanted in the uterus right away. This would reduce your time to possible pregnancy by a few weeks to a few months, depending on how many cycles of IVF you do.
Embryos won’t be affected by freezing or thawing.

There’s a small chance that embryos can be damaged when they’re frozen or thawed. It’s estimated that 1% to 2% of embryos are damaged during the freezing or thawing process, according to Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist Wael Salem.
You don’t have to pay for embryo freezing or storage.
It can cost around $3,000 to $5,000 to freeze and store embryos, and many insurance companies don’t cover it.
There’s more scientific data on fresh transfers.
Fresh embryo transfers have been around for longer than frozen transfers, so there’s more data about their safety, risks, and rates of success.
Cons:
Your uterine lining may not be ready to receive an embryo.

When you’re undergoing ovarian stimulation to produce multiple eggs, your progesterone and estrogen levels become very high. These high levels make it difficult for providers to figure out the perfect time to transfer an embryo (or when your uterus is most likely to absorb it).
There’s a higher risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).

OHSS, a condition that makes your ovaries feel swollen and painful, can happen when your body has too many hormones from IVF medications. Both fresh and frozen transfers need these medications, but if your hormones don’t have time to return to normal levels between your ovarian stimulation and your embryo transfer, there’s an increased risk of developing OHSS. Maven Reproductive Nurse Hailey Baker adds, “Your provider will estimate your risk for OHSS based on ovarian reserve testing, your age, and your medical history.”
You’re unable to do genetic testing.

Embryos have to be frozen in order to do preimplantation genetic testing (PGT), which screens for imbalances in the embryos’ chromosomes. An imbalance can lead to the development of certain genetic conditions.
Fresh transfers have been linked to certain complications.
More research is needed to determine why, but fresh transfers have been linked to preterm delivery (delivery before 37 weeks of pregnancy) and lower birth weight.
Frozen embryo transfer
Pros:
Frozen embryos can be tested for genetic conditions.

“Many fertility clinics are choosing to do frozen transfers because it allows providers to do genetic testing,” says Baker. “Data suggests higher pregnancy rates with frozen embryo transfers, but this increased success rate is mostly due to those embryos being genetically tested.”
You can use your embryos later.
If you freeze your embryos, you can use them to conceive at a later time, do multiple rounds of IVF, or donate embryos to science or other families.
There’s a lower risk of OHSS.
Frozen transfers happen several weeks after ovarian stimulation, so your hormones will have more time to return to normal levels. This lowers your risk of OHSS.
You have more flexibility when timing your transfer.
Fresh embryos have to be transferred right away. If you use frozen embryos, you can choose when you want to have them transferred.
Cons:
A longer time to pregnancy.

Freezing your embryos and undergoing PGT can add a few weeks to months to your possible pregnancy timeline. “Your fertility clinic might also require a one to two-month break [in your IVF cycle] for recovery or further testing,” says Baker.
Freezing and storage can be expensive.
Many insurance companies don’t cover the cost of freezing or storing embryos. (Remember that can run around $3,000 to $5,000.)
Frozen transfers have been linked to certain complications.
Researchers aren’t exactly sure why frozen transfers are linked to pregnancy complications like preeclampsia and higher birth weight. More research is needed. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn every step of the embryo freezing process here.
What the research says about fresh versus frozen

So, should you opt for fresh or frozen? The answer is: it depends on your individual case. It’s true that some people can benefit from a fresh transfer, while others can benefit from a frozen transfer. But several studies say fresh versus frozen doesn’t appear to have a statistically significant (in other words, a major, measurable) difference in terms of pregnancy loss or live birth rates. This research is ongoing—and more research is needed—but at this time, fresh and frozen embryo transfers seem to have almost equal rates of success.

Like all things fertility, there’s no one-size-fits-all approach to embryo transfers, so whether you transfer a fresh or frozen embryo is between you and your fertility provider. Some clinics have a preferred recommended process, but your provider should still discuss all of the pros and cons of each option with you, and what they recommend for your particular case.
The bottom line

Some people will benefit from a fresh embryo transfer, others from a frozen transfer. But when it comes down to the rates of live birth, there isn’t a major difference between the two. Many fertility clinics have a preference, but either way, you’ll work closely with your provider to choose the best option for you.
Have questions between appointments with your fertility provider or want a second opinion?
Maven Reproductive Nurses
are always here to help. Make your free appointment online today.
Sources
BMJ
Cochrane Reviews
Maven Clinic

title.en-US: My child was conceived with help from a donor—should I tell them?

content.value: When you’re trying to conceive with the help of fertility treatment, like in vitro fertilization (IVF) or intrauterine insemination (IUI), you’ll face some tricky decisions.
What should be done with extra embryos? How many cycles am I willing to try?

And if you successfully conceive with the help of donor eggs, sperm, or embryos, you might wonder how to talk to your child about their conception in the future. There isn’t a single “right” way to do it, and every parent will approach this conversation differently. But it’s a good idea to think about how (or if) you want to talk to your child about their conception, so you can feel fully prepared when the time comes.
Keep reading for advice that may help.
Do I have to tell my child they were conceived with help from a donor?

How and when you tell your child they were conceived with help from a donor—if you tell them at all—is totally up to you and your partner (if you have one). You will know your family and your child best—and every person is different—so everyone will have a unique take on the subject.

Many reproductive endocrinologists do encourage parents to be open with their child (or children) about their conception, but having that big talk can be easier said than done. If you’re not sure how to start the conversation, see if your fertility clinic offers post-treatment counseling to patients. Or you can make an appointment with a
Maven Mental Health Provider
or a
Pediatric Mental Health Provider
for guidance.
Everyone has their own personal reasons for telling or not telling their child about their conception—and those reasons are totally valid.
When is the best time to tell my child about their conception?

Don’t feel pressured to talk to your child about their conception if you don’t feel ready, or feel that they’re not ready to know. Every person and every family is different, and operates on their own timelines.

That being said, many experts recommend telling your child early on, explains Maven Pediatric Mental Health Provider Janise McNally. “Studies have found that stress, anxiety, and depression levels are lower in families who choose early disclosure,” she says. “Research shows that telling your child during the preschool years or before age 5 has the best outcomes for parent-child relationships. Their conception story becomes a natural part of your child’s identity and gives them an opportunity to absorb the information over time. Younger children are also less likely to ask really hard questions, giving you an opportunity to ease into the conversation.”
Again, every child is different—some may be ready at a younger age, and some may be ready at an older age.
How do I talk about conception with my child?
“It’s important to be open from the beginning. This means being the one to start the conversation and talk openly about your child’s origin story
before
they might even ask questions about it,” McNally says.

“If your child is older and you haven’t told them about their conception yet, it’s never too late to be open and honest. Keep in mind that your older child could be angry or hurt that they didn’t know their conception story sooner, so it’s important to allow space for their emotions,” she adds.
So, how can you get the conversation started? McNally has some key recommendations:
Make this a very positive and happy story that’s shared in a matter-of-fact manner; focus on themes of family building, love, helping, sharing, and gratitude.

Think of sharing the donor conception story with your child as an opportunity to show just how wanted and loved they are. It can also be a way to connect with your child and instill trust in your relationship.
Talk about and normalize how there are many different types of families.
Start with the basics and don't get too far ahead of your child. Try to answer their questions and leave the door open for more, and layer in more details when needed.
Refer to the donor as a “donor” or “helper,” but not as mother or father. That may confuse your child.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Keep in mind, this probably isn’t a one-time conversation. It’s one you’ll want to consider revisiting throughout the years and adding details as your child gets older and can better understand.

McNally advises, “Don't assume that if your child doesn’t talk about it or ask questions that they’re not thinking about it. While this might be the case, it’s also possible that your child senses that the topic is uncomfortable for you, so they keep their thoughts and questions to themselves. It’s the parent’s job to raise the subject, ask for questions, and support the child in processing emotions and thoughts.”
The bottom line

Telling or not telling your child they were conceived with help from a donor is a very personal decision. How and when that conversation happens is different for every family. Finding the right words may be tough, but McNally says, “Remember you don't have to have the perfect words. The way you share the information is often just as important, if not more so, than what you say.”

title.en-US: 5 fertility treatments for same-sex female couples

content.value: If you and your partner are assigned female at birth (AFAB) and you’re ready to start a family, we’ve got great news! Today, there are several assisted reproductive technologies (ART) that can help you achieve your goals and provide options for how each partner wants to participate in the experience—from providing the egg to incubating the embryo to carrying the pregnancy.
Here’s what you need to know about the assisted reproductive technologies available to AFAB couples, so you can choose the best option for your growing family.
1. Intrauterine insemination (IUI) with donor sperm
The gist: Donor sperm is placed directly into the uterus (yours or your partner’s)
If you decide to use
intrauterine insemination (IUI)

to become pregnant, your provider will place specially prepared donor sperm through your cervix and directly into your uterus (or your partner’s). This allows sperm to travel from the uterus to the fallopian tube, where fertilization happens. Your provider may recommend IUI around the time of your regular ovulation, or medications can be used to stimulate ovulation or cause several eggs to ovulate.
2. Traditional in vitro fertilization (IVF) with donor sperm
The gist: Donor sperm and egg meet in a lab setting, the embryo is then transferred into the uterus of the partner who provided the egg

One of the more common assisted reproductive technologies is called in vitro fertilization, often known as IVF. With IVF, the sperm fertilizes the egg outside the body, in a lab setting. The embryo is then transferred to your uterus or your partner’s.

With “traditional IVF”, the same partner who undergoes egg retrieval also undergoes the embryo transplant (and carries the pregnancy if the embryo implants). Other types of IVF, like reciprocal IVF (more on that below!), allow both partners to be more closely involved in the pregnancy process.
The
key steps in traditional IVF
are:
Ovarian stimulation:
Your fertility provider will treat you with
hormone medications

that make your ovaries produce several eggs at once—rather than the usual one egg per month—so they can try to fertilize multiple eggs. Not every egg will be suitable for fertilization, so your provider will try to
up the chance of success
by using several eggs.
Egg retrieval:

While you’re under IV sedation (asleep), your fertility provider will insert an ultrasound probe (called a transvaginal ultrasound) into your vagina. This probe helps them find ovarian follicles (where eggs are stored in the ovaries). Then, they’ll use a very thin needle to carefully go through the vaginal wall and remove eggs from the follicles. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If your provider is unable to see your ovarian follicles with a transvaginal ultrasound, they might use a regular abdominal ultrasound to guide the needle to the ovaries.
The embryos will then be incubated (allowed to develop) in a liquid called growth medium.
Fertilization:
Using sperm from a donor that you and your partner have chosen, your provider will combine sperm with mature eggs for fertilization. When eggs become fertilized, they’re called embryos.
Embryo transfer:

Between two and five days after egg retrieval, your provider will transfer one or more embryos into your uterus using a small catheter (a tube) and an ultrasound for guidance. If the embryo transfer is successful, the embryo will implant into the lining of your uterus six to 10 days after the egg retrieval.
3. Reciprocal IVF
The gist: Donor sperm and egg meet in a lab setting, the embryo is then transferred to the uterus of the partner who did not provide the egg
Reciprocal IVF has many of the same steps as traditional IVF, including:
Hormonal therapy to grow multiple eggs
Egg retrieval
Egg fertilization with sperm
Embryo transferREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

But unlike traditional IVF, one partner can donate their eggs to be fertilized with donor sperm, and the other partner can undergo the embryo transfer and carry the baby to term. This allows both partners to be involved in the pregnancy after the egg has been fertilized and incubated in a lab setting.
4. Effortless IVF
The gist: Donor sperm and one partner’s egg are placed in a capsule then inserted in the same partner’s vaginal canal to be incubated. Then, the embryo is implanted in the uterus and carried to term.

In effortless IVF, one partner’s egg and donated sperm are placed inside a small, plastic capsule called an INVOcell. The INVOcell is then inserted into the vaginal canal to be incubated. After a few days of incubation, the embryo is
not
transferred to the other partner, like it is during reciprocal IVF. Instead, the partner who provides the egg and incubates it also carries the pregnancy.

Although effortless IVF only allows one partner to carry the couple’s baby, it’s a more affordable option than traditional IVF or reciprocal IVF, which require incubation in a lab setting. Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, M.D. says, “Effortless IVF was actually designed to cut down the costs of traditional IVF and therefore make IVF available to more people.”

It’s important to know that effortless IVF has lower success rates than traditional IVF, and many fertility clinics do not yet offer the INVOcell. Be sure to discuss the pros and cons of effortless IVF with your provider.
5. Reciprocal effortless IVF

The gist: Donor sperm and one partner’s egg are placed in a capsule and inserted in one partner’s vaginal canal to be incubated, then removed and transferred to the other partner’s uterus to carry to term.

Reciprocal effortless IVF is a newer type of IVF that allows both partners to be a part of the process by carrying the baby at different stages. Because this type of IVF is so new, not many fertility clinics offer it yet.

Here’s how reciprocal effortless IVF works: your fertility provider combines an egg with donated sperm in an INVOcell. The INVOcell is then inserted into one partner’s vaginal canal, which acts as a natural incubator for an embryo to form. After several days, the INVOcell capsule is removed and the embryo is transferred to the other partner’s uterus for implantation. This allows both partners to carry the baby at different points of the process.

The key difference between reciprocal effortless IVF and other types of IVF is using one partner’s vaginal canal as a natural incubator and then transferring the fertilized egg to the other partner’s uterus.
Have questions about IVF or other types of assisted reproductive technology? Talk to a
Maven Reproductive Nurse
for more information.
How much do different types of fertility treatments cost?

The cost of fertility treatments depends on your insurance plan. Some insurance plans may not cover fertility treatments, which can be very expensive. Plus, not many fertility clinics offer newer technologies, like reciprocal effortless IVF. It’s important to do the research and find out if there’s a local provider who offers the type of IVF that’s best for you.
If you need help understanding your fertility benefits or finding a fertility provider, message your Maven Care Advocate. They can put together a personal referral list for you for free.
Are there any cons to these fertility treatments?
It’s important to know that certain fertility treatments might not work for everyone. Some couples may need to go through several rounds of treatment before they become pregnant.
Your fertility provider can help you decide which is a good option for you and your partner. You can also talk to a
Reproductive Nurse
or
Reproductive Endocrinologist
for free online on Maven for advice anytime.
The bottom line

There are a number of ways for AFAB people in a same-sex relationship to have a baby. Some types of IVF, like reciprocal effortless IVF, aren’t offered at all fertility clinics, but it’s a good sign of advances that keep happening in reproductive medicine, and increasing options for everyone who wants to start a family.
Sources
Mayo Clinic (In vitro fertilization)
Mayo Clinic (Intrauterine insemination)

title.en-US: Understanding embryo grading and why it’s important for IVF success

content.value: What you need to know:
Embryo grading is an important step in in vitro fertilization (IVF) to figure out which embryos are the most likely to implant after being transferred into the uterus.
Fertility scientists use a “standardized grading system” to identify the healthiest embryos.

Having a lower grade does not mean your embryo is unhealthy or will grow into an unhealthy baby. Embryo grading only predicts the chances that an embryo will implant in the uterus. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you’re trying to conceive with help from in vitro fertilization (IVF), you may have heard about embryo grading. Here’s how it works and what you need to know so you can feel fully informed before you transfer.
What is embryo grading?

An embryologist—a special kind of fertility scientist who joins eggs and sperm together in a laboratory to make an embryo—uses embryo grading to figure out which embryos are the most likely to implant in the uterus, so you can use them for your embryo transfer.
Embryo grading isn’t a perfect science, but it can help providers figure out which embryos have the best chances of becoming a pregnancy.
It’s important to know that embryos with lower scores are often still able to implant and develop into a pregnancy—and using an embryo with a lower grade does
not

mean your baby will be unhealthy, says Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist Wael Salem. “An embryo’s grade has no prediction of the health of that embryo, or the health of the baby. It can only predict the chances of it implanting.”
What happens before embryo grading

After an egg retrieval, an embryologist will combine the eggs and sperm in a petri dish, where (hopefully!) the sperm will fertilize the eggs to form embryos. Timing may vary from clinic to clinic, but generally, embryos are left to develop for 3-6 days after they’ve been retrieved and fertilized. Once they’ve reached this important stage of growth, an embryologist will use a grading system to decide which embryos are most likely to implant when transferred to the uterus. If you choose to do
genetic testing on your embryos
(called preimplantation genetic testing, or PGT), they’ll be tested during this period, too, so you can get results and make a decision before implanting.
Embryo grading, explained

Although embryologists use a standardized grading system to score embryos, scoring is still a bit subjective because it’s done by a human being. Meaning, two embryologists could give the same embryo two different scores.

Some fertility clinics use their own custom grading system, but the most commonly used system is called the Gardner grading system. Embryologists use it to give embryos a “score” based on their structure (how they’re built). Salem explains, “The Gardner system looks at characteristics of embryos that are associated with higher rates of pregnancy.”
Here’s a closer look at what the Gardner grading system measures:
1. Expansion
Expansion looks at how much the embryo has grown in the culture medium (the solution they’re put in for five to seven days).
Expansion can be graded from 1 (the least growth) to 6 (the most growth). This is the number that appears first in the grading chart below.
2. Inner cell mass (ICM)

ICM looks at the number of cells in one of the embryo’s main structures: the inner cell mass, which will eventually grow into the fetus. This is the letter that appears second in the grading chart below.
ICM can be graded:
A (highest quality with many tightly packed cells)
B (medium quality with many loosely packed cells)
C (lowest quality with very few cells)
3. Trophectoderm epithelium (TE)

TE looks at the number of cells in the trophectoderm, which will eventually become the placenta (the organ that delivers nutrients and oxygen to baby while they’re in the womb). This is the letter that appears third in the grading chart below.
TE can be graded:
A (many cells forming an even layer of tissue)
B (many cells forming a loose layer of tissue)
C (very few cells)
Charting out an embryo’s grade

Using these three factors above, an embryologist will assign an alphanumeric score (a combination of letters and numbers) to each embryo. The alphanumeric score will include the expansion score, ICM score, and TE score, in this order. Scoring looks like this:
REPLACEWITHASSET

Based on this grading system, a score of 6AA would be the embryo with the highest chance of implanting (although a score this high is very rare) and a score of 1CC would be the least likely to implant.
Have questions about the results of your embryo grading?
Maven Reproductive Nurses
are here to help. Make a free, online appointment now.
How embryo grading impacts IVF success
Embryo grading isn’t a perfect science, but it is a helpful tool for your embryologist to use when choosing the embryos your fertility provider will transfer.

Generally, higher grade embryos are more likely to result in a live birth. One study, for example, found that transfers with embryos graded AA had a 41.1% live birth rate; embryos graded BB had a 31.1% live birth rate; and embryos graded CC had a 13.3% live birth rate.
Another study found that embryos that were graded 4 to 5 in expansion, A in ICM, and A or B in TE (resulting in a score of 4AA, 4AB, 5AA, or 5AB) should be the first-choice embryos for transfer.

Although there’s some evidence that higher grade embryos have higher chances of success, keep in mind that embryo grading isn’t the only factor that determines whether or not you’ll have a baby. Other factors, like how quickly an embryo matures, play an important role, too. Salem says, “Embryos that mature quickly are more likely to implant and lead to a pregnancy. Meaning, embryos that are matured after five days [in the culture medium] perform better than embryos that mature by day six or seven.” The thickness of the endometrium (the lining of the uterus) and timing fertile windows are also important to success, he says.

It’s important to note: If you and your provider decide to do PGT-A testing (which checks for abnormal chromosomes in your embryos) the results of this test take priority over embryo grading. Meaning, embryos will be chosen for transfer based on their PGT-A result. The grade they’re assigned will be considered second in the evaluation.
The bottom line

Embryo grading helps embryologists and fertility providers determine which embryo is the best for transfer, but it’s not the only factor of a healthy pregnancy. If you have questions about embryo grading, be sure to talk to your fertility provider or a
Maven Reproductive Nurse
, so you can feel confident going into your embryo transfer.
Sources
Fertility & Sterility
Frontiers in Endocrinology

title.en-US: Your questions about embryo freezing, answered

content.value: Embryo freezing—also called embryo cryopreservation—is the process of freezing and storing an egg that has been fertilized by sperm (an embryo), so it can be used in assisted reproductive technologies (like IVF) or to start a family later. Read on to learn more about embryo freezing, and if it’s a good option for you.
How is embryo freezing different from egg freezing?
Embryo freezing is the process of freezing and storing
fertilized
eggs. Egg freezing is the process of freezing and storing
unfertilized
eggs.
How does embryo freezing work?
Here’s a quick breakdown of the process:

Eggs are retrieved from the female partner’s or donor’s ovaries and fertilized with the male partner’s or donor’s sperm. This creates an embryo, which is grown in the lab for 5 to 7 days. Your fertility provider will retrieve as many eggs as possible. Unfortunately, not all of the eggs will develop into embryos.

The embryo is allowed to develop for 5 to 7 days, and is treated with a cryoprotective agent (CPA) that will protect it from forming ice crystals once frozen. Then, the embryo is frozen in liquid nitrogen at -321 degrees Fahrenheit (or -196.1 degrees Celsius). Embryos are usually frozen for 1 to 3 months, but can be stored for up to 20 years.
When it’s time for use, the embryo is thawed to a normal temperature. Then, it can be implanted in the female partner’s or surrogate’s uterine lining.
Why would someone choose to freeze an embryo?
There are many reasons people freeze embryos.

Certain assisted reproductive technologies, such as in vitro fertilization (IVF), work by fertilizing an egg with sperm outside of the body. Oftentimes, more than one egg is fertilized during IVF so there can be multiple embryos.
Some people choose to freeze their extra embryos for these reasons:
To use them to try to conceive in the future
Postponing IVF procedures until a later date
Wanting back-up embryos in case early fertility treatments don’t work
Wanting to donate embryos to people who have trouble getting pregnant or to scienceREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

It may also be beneficial for those who want more time to start a family. Embryos stay the quality they were when they were frozen. Meaning, if you freeze embryos when you’re 30 and want to use them when you’re 40, the embryo still has the quality of a 30 year old egg. This gives people a lot of time to start their family.
Your fertility care provider will talk to you about the risks of embryo freezing, so you can make a fully informed decision.
Are there risks to embryo freezing?
There are some risks to freezing and storing embryos, including:
Damage to the embryos during the freezing or thawing process
Creating embryos that don’t survive the thawing process
Trouble getting pregnant after embryos are implanted into the lining of the uterus
Higher risk of certain pregnancy complications, such as preeclampsiaREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Your fertility provider will discuss all of the pros and cons of embryo freezing and storage before you start the process.
What happens if you don’t use your frozen embryos?
If you decide you don’t want to use your frozen embryos for any reason, you have a few options. You can:
Ask your fertility provider to remove your embryos from the freezer and let them thaw, so they’re not viable and can no longer be used
Donate your frozen embryos to someone who has fertility issues or to science and research
How much does embryo freezing cost?

The cost of embryo freezing and storage depends on your insurance plan (if you have one). Some insurance plans may not cover fertility treatments, which can be very expensive. It’s important to do the research and find out if embryo freezing is covered by your plan and/or in your budget.

If you need help understanding your fertility benefits, call your health plan directly for more information. If you’re having trouble, message your Maven Care Advocate. They can help you figure out what’s covered (and what isn’t) by your insurance plan.

If your insurance plan doesn’t cover fertility treatments or you don’t have insurance, ask your fertility provider if their office offers monthly payment plans or discounts that can help you manage the cost.
The bottom line

Embryo freezing, or freezing and storing fertilized eggs, can be beneficial to people who are undergoing IVF treatments or want to preserve their fertility and start their family later. There are a number of pros and cons to embryo freezing, so be sure to ask your fertility provider if embryo freezing could work for you. It’s important to get all of the information, so you can make a fully informed decision about your fertility and family planning.
You can also make an appointment with a
Maven Reproductive Nurse
for advice at any time.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
Johns Hopkins Medicine

title.en-US: Glucose screening test: Everything you need to know

content.value: What you need to know:
The glucose screening tests for your risk of gestational diabetes. (Where your glucose levels are too high during pregnancy.)
It’s usually done between pregnancy weeks 24 to 28. Your doctor may want you to test early if you’re high-risk.
Gestational diabetes can be scary. But you can manage it and have a healthy pregnancy and baby. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Has your doctor scheduled you for a glucose screening? This test checks for gestational diabetes.
This is a type of diabetes that can show up during pregnancy.
Here’s everything you need to know.
What is gestational diabetes?
Insulin is the hormone that controls the amount of sugar in your blood.
During pregnancy, insulin levels may be too high. That’s because pregnancy hormones can mess with those insulin levels.
If this happens, you may be diagnosed with gestational diabetes.
This type of diabetes is similar to other types of diabetes. But it’s only diagnosed during pregnancy.
It’s also common. If you’re diagnosed, it can be scary. But your doctor and Maven Care Team can help you make a plan. You can still go on to have a healthy pregnancy and baby.
What are the risks?
Gestational diabetes does have risks for you and your baby. That’s why it’s important to be tested for it. It’s also important to follow a treatment plan if you test positive.
Some risks of gestational diabetes are:
Having a large baby
Increased risk of cesarean (C-section) delivery
High blood pressure which can lead to preeclampsia (a serious complication) and preterm birth (when baby is born before 37 weeks of pregnancy)
Baby having trouble regulating their blood sugar after birth (and possibly needing to be in the NICU, a hospital care unit for newborns)
StillbirthREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you’re diagnosed with gestational diabetes, you can still go on to have a healthy pregnancy and baby. You and your doctor can work together to make a plan. You can also talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
or
Diabetes Coach
anytime.
When is the glucose screening test done?
The glucose screening test is usually done between weeks 24 and 28 of pregnancy.
But your doctor may want you to have it done earlier if your pregnancy is high-risk or you live with a chronic condition.
What happens during the glucose screening test?
You don’t need to do anything before the test. There’s no need to fast, or not eat. Just eat and drink what you usually do.
You may take the test at your doctor’s office. But usually you will go to a different clinic that does blood tests.
After you arrive at the clinic:
You’ll drink a sweet, syrupy drink. It has 1.8 ounces (50 grams) of glucose, or sugar.
You’ll wait one hour.
A nurse will draw your blood. This is to measure your blood sugar level. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
After the test, you can go back to work or home. You can go back to whatever daily activities you want.
Your clinic will call you with your results when they’re ready.
How bad is it?
We’re not going to sugar coat it, The glucose screening test might not be fun for everyone.

The glucose solution might taste really bad to you. Especially if you get morning sickness or throw up a lot during your pregnancy. But some people don’t mind the taste at all! It is usually cold and flavored (like lemon lime).
Hang in there. If you feel sick or worried, try to take some deep breaths while you wait. And remember, this test will help you have a healthy pregnancy and baby.
What if my test results come back normal?
If your test shows that your blood sugar is at a normal level (less than 140 mg/dL) , you’re all set. You can continue with your normal pregnancy diet and routine.
What should I do if my test results come back high?
If your blood glucose levels are high (more than 140 mg/dL), your doctor will schedule you for another test.
This second-round test is called the glucose tolerance test.
This time you’ll be asked to not eat 8-12 hours before the test (you can have water).
You will have your blood drawn when you arrive at the clinic
You’ll then drink 3.6 ounces (100 grams) of glucose
Your blood will then be tested every hour for three hoursREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
With these results, your doctor will be able to rule out or diagnose you with gestational diabetes.
Next steps
It can be scary if you’re diagnosed with gestational diabetes. But you can work together with your doctor. They can help you make a plan to keep your pregnancy healthy.
You also can talk with a
Maven Nutritionist
or
Diabetes Coach
anytime for free. They can help you keep gestational diabetes in check.
Make a plan together to:
Check your blood sugar regularly
Eat healthy foods
Get to your in-person prenatal appointments
Stay active with safe activities like walking
Take medicine, if needed REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Gestational diabetes may go away after you deliver.
But if you’re diagnosed, you’ll have a higher risk for developing diabetes. (With future pregnancies and later in life.)
Ask your doctor if you need to be tested after your pregnancy.
Sources
Mayo Clinic
March of Dimes
ACOG
American Diabetes Association
Mount Sinai
CDC
American Diabetes Association

title.en-US: Best morning routines for parents with multiple kids

content.value: What you need to know:
Getting organized is a must when you’ve got multiple kids to get out the door in the morning.
Prep the night before or get up early before your kids—your choice!
Be patient with yourself. Morning routines take practice and get better with every passing day. Make adjustments as needed. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

With your first baby, you might have had time in the mornings to feed them, sip your coffee, and still get out the door on time. But now with multiple littles to get up, dressed, and fed, some mornings can feel like a chaotic whirlwind of stress.

But with a bit of prep, it doesn’t have to be like that (at least not every morning). Getting organized is a challenge—but it’s also so important. Especially when you have multiple charges and yourself to get out the door for daycare, school, and work, or back home in time for your first Zoom meeting.
Since your routine will be different now that you have multiple kids, we’ve compiled the ultimate checklist that’s sure to set you up for the win!
Prep the night before, get up slightly earlier in the morning, or prep on the weekends

Dealer’s choice! Some parents prefer to prep everything the night before. That way, it’s all organized and good to go come morning time. If you find yourself too exhausted at the end of the day (understandable!) another option is to get up before your kiddos in the morning to get breakfast and lunch together. Factor in extra time if you want to shower in the mornings, too. Not a morning person? Even getting up a half hour before helps!
You could also do some of these tasks on the weekend so they are ready to go for the week ahead.
Breakfast

If you like your kids to have something warm for breakfast like oatmeal, or even pancakes, prep it the night before, make a big batch on weekends, or start it up when you wake up. Do a quick reheat in the microwave or on the stovetop if you pre-cooked it. Pre-wash and cut any fruit you might serve up as well.
Lunch

Prep lunch—which can include making sandwiches, putting leftovers into containers, and chopping veggies—and put them into airtight containers and lunch boxes. Pop them right in the fridge or freezer, or right into the lunch boxes.
Clothing
Lay out everyone’s clothes for the next day, or choose outfits when you wake up. If your toddler likes to be part of this, give them time to pick their clothes with you.
Bonus round: Do the laundry and put together all the household’s outfits for the week on Sundays. That includes socks, underwear, diapers, and whatever else your kids wear.
To-go items

Keep items that will be leaving with you by the door or in the same spot where it’s easy to find every day. This can include water bottles, sippy cups, shoes, backpacks, snacks, diapers, breast pump and supplies, homework, car keys, laptops, work folders—you name it, having it in one place makes it harder to forget it.
Shower
Shower the night before if you can. Being all washed and ready is a big time-saver in the a.m.
If that doesn’t work for your schedule, wake up earlier in the morning to get yourself ready.
Extra credit
Once you’ve established a good routine, consider prepping lunch for the whole week. This can be done on a Sunday and stored in the fridge making weekday mornings even easier.
Sample morning routine
Rise and shine

You’ll want to wake up at a time that allows you to get ready without rushing (whatever you usually do, tack on an extra 30 min to start). The key is to move as seamlessly as possible through your morning. Some parents choose to get up earlier than the kids to have a little quiet time before the routine begins.
Assemble breakfast

Have your breakfast items ready to go. Some parents pull out previously frozen muffins, fruit for smoothies, or that oatmeal we mentioned earlier. Low sugar yogurt, cereal, or frozen waffles work in a pinch!
Play some tunes
Playing music for kids who don’t like to wake up is a great trick. You’ll be shocked at how well a few bars of a favorite song will awake their little senses!
Avoid checking in
If possible, save social media, news, and responding to Slack messages for after you’ve dropped off the kids. Not only will it zap your time, it might sour your mood.
Divide and conquer

Everyone should pitch in. If you have a partner in the house, they can help with the toddler while you breastfeed or give the baby a bottle, and toddlers can lend a hand, too! Encouraging independence and a helpful nature in your little ones now can help them as they get older, too.
The bottom line:

Most importantly, be patient with yourself. Morning routines take practice and get better with every passing day. Make adjustments as you go along, ask other parents you know what works best for them, and trust that it will all fall into place with time.

title.en-US: Alcohol, tobacco, and drug habits that can harm your baby (and how to get help)

content.value: What you need to know
Using alcohol, tobacco, or drugs during pregnancy can be very dangerous for you and your growing baby.
Serious health conditions like Fetal Alcohol Syndrome Disorders (FASD) or Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS) have long-lasting effects on babies.
Do not be afraid to
ask your doctor
or a
Maven Provider

for help quitting alcohol, tobacco, or drugs. The most important thing is to tell them as soon as possible, so they can get you the right treatment and lower health risks for your baby. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

We all have habits that are hard to break. But if you have ever wanted to quit alcohol, tobacco, or drugs, being pregnant is a great reason to do it! Habits that can hurt your health can also hurt the health and development of your baby.
Here is everything you need to know about habits that can be harmful to your growing baby, and how to find help.
Remember, you are not alone. If you need help quitting, schedule a free appointment with a
Maven Provider
today. They can give you a safe, judgment-free space to get the help you need.
Remember to be honest with your pregnancy providers

Talking to your pregnancy provider about your health (including if you use drugs, tobacco, or alcohol) is a big part of prenatal care appointments. When your provider asks, it is important to tell them the truth, so they can give you and your baby the best possible care. Your providers are not there to judge you—they are there to help you and your baby be healthy. But keep in mind that this information might be reported if it is
legally required in your state

If you do not feel comfortable talking to your doctor about substance use—or do not feel like your current doctor is being supportive—message your Care Advocate  for help finding a new one. It is important to feel supported and respected by your pregnancy providers.
Drinking alcohol
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Smoking and using other tobacco products
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Using marijuana or CBD
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Using cocaine
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Using heroin, fentanyl, codeine, morphine, oxycodone and other opioids
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Benzodiazepines (benzos, like Valium, Klonopin, or Xanax)
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
What to do when you are ready to quit

Quitting is not easy, but you can do it with the right support. Always talk to your doctor or midwife before you try to quit on your own. They can help you put together a quit plan that is safe for you and your baby, and lowers the chance of relapsing.
Learn more about quitting alcohol, tobacco, and drugs—and where to find support—here.
We are here to help
Do not be afraid to tell your doctor if you need help with an alcohol, tobacco, or drug habit. What is most important is to tell them as soon as possible, so they can get you the right treatment.
Quitting these habits is very hard. But it is possible and the benefits to your growing baby are big—and sometimes even life-saving. Speak with your doctor today or chat with a
Maven Provider
for free help.
Sources
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
Maven Clinic
Maven Clinic
March of Dimes (Street drugs and pregnancy)
March of Dimes (Cocaine)

Even if you have friends or family members who drank alcohol while pregnant and had healthy babies, it is a good idea to avoid alcohol completely when you are pregnant. Research says there is no safe amount of alcohol for pregnant people. This includes wine, beer, liquors, and mixed drinks.

When you drink alcohol while you are pregnant, it enters your blood and crosses the placenta. In other words, if you are drinking alcohol, your baby is, too. This can cause serious damage to baby’s development.
Drinking alcohol while you are pregnant increases your risk of miscarriage and having a baby with Fetal Alcohol Syndrome Disorders (FASD). A baby with FASD might have these at birth or later in life:
Low birth weight (weighing under 5 pounds at birth)
Certain birth defects, like a very small head or facial features that are not
considered normal
Learning disabilities
Trouble paying attention, remembering things, or making decisions
Vision or hearing problems
Problems with the heart, kidneys, or bones
The good news is, FASD is 100% preventable by avoiding alcohol during pregnancy. If you need help quitting alcohol, talk to your doctor or a
Maven Provider
for advice.

Using any kind of tobacco product, like cigarettes, e-cigarettes (vapes), and chewing tobacco, is not safe during pregnancy. When you use tobacco products, nicotine and other harmful chemicals found in tobacco products enter your blood. Then, these chemicals pass through the placenta to your baby. Plus, the carbon monoxide in tobacco smoke can keep baby from getting enough oxygen in the womb.
Being around smoke from another person (also called second-hand smoke) can be just as dangerous for pregnant people and their developing babies with the same serious effects listed below.
The safest place for you and your growing baby is a smoke-free environment. If you live or work with someone who smokes, ask them to smoke outside and to wash their hands when they are finished.
Using tobacco products (or being around second-hand smoke) during pregnancy increases the risk of:
Preterm (early) birth (even smoking 1-2 cigarettes a day can raise the risk)
Low birth weight
Birth defects around baby’s mouth and nose
Damage to baby’s brain and lungs
After birth, smoking or second-hand smoke raises the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). SIDS happens when a baby under the age of 1 year dies suddenly.

Quitting tobacco is hard because it has a very addictive substance called nicotine in it. But it is possible to quit with the right help. Call your state’s quitline at 1-800-QUIT-NOW, talk to your doctor, or speak with a
Maven Provider
for free on Maven to get judgment-free support.
Even though many states are legalizing marijuana for recreational use, using marijuana is not safe during pregnancy.
