Like tobacco smoke, being around second-hand smoke from marijuana can hurt you and your baby, too. Avoid being around smoke when you are pregnant and after your baby is born.
CBD is not safe to use during pregnancy, either. It can damage your baby’s developing brain. Remember, just because a product is “natural” does not mean it is safe to use when you are pregnant.
Research has found that using marijuana or CBD during pregnancy can:
Cause preterm birth
Slow down baby’s growth and development
Raise the risk of baby needing special medical care in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) after they are born
Cause developmental problems in kids later in life
Raise the risk of having a stillbirth
Talk to your doctor or speak with a
Maven Provider
for a safe space to talk about drug use and what you need to do to quit.

Cocaine is a very addictive drug that has many health risks for you and your baby if it is used during pregnancy. Cocaine passes through the placenta to your baby. It also takes longer for a developing baby to clear cocaine from their body than it takes an adult. Using cocaine when you are pregnant can cause serious health problems for you and your baby.
Some health problems cocaine can cause in you are:
Heart attack
Stroke (when a blood vessel in your brain is blocked or bursts)
High blood pressure
Seizures
Trouble breathing
Infections, like hepatitis or HIV, from sharing needles
Serious weight loss
Some health problems cocaine can cause in baby are:
Placental abruption (when your placenta detaches from your uterus and baby cannot get oxygen or nutrients)
Preterm birth
Low birth weight
Vision or hearing problems
Developmental delays and learning disabilities
Miscarriage

Babies who are exposed to addictive drugs, like cocaine or opioids, during pregnancy can also develop a serious health condition called Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS). When a baby has NAS, they have withdrawal from the drugs they became addicted to in the womb. Some symptoms of NAS are:
Seizures
Vomiting
Dehydration
Tremors (shaking)
Excessive (a lot) crying
Kids born with NAS also have a higher chance of developmental delays and trouble speaking.
Cocaine is very addictive, so quitting can be very difficult. But your doctor or a
Maven Provider
can give you the tools you need to quit.
Using opioids, like heroin or prescription opioids, is not safe during pregnancy. Opioid use during pregnancy can cause serious health problems in you and your baby.
Using opioids can cause many health issues, such as:
Poor growth and development
Preterm birth
Issues with the placenta (the organ that gives your baby oxygen and nutrients)
Birth defects
Miscarriage or stillbirth
Viruses, like hepatitis or HIV
Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS)
Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS)
Death in the mother
If you have taken opioids before or during pregnancy, make sure you tell your OB-GYN or midwife right away, so they can help. The sooner you start treatment, the better off your baby will be.
If you were prescribed opioids by a doctor, tell them you are pregnant right away. They will help you stop taking opioids and switch to a pregnancy-safe option.

Do not quit opioids suddenly. This can be very dangerous for you and your baby. Your doctor will help you create a safe quit plan. They will also give you medication that will help ease the symptoms of withdrawal for you and your baby.
If you need a safe space to talk about opioid drug use—and get advice on quitting—make an online appointment with a
Maven Provider
right away. We are here to help.

Certain prescription drugs that are used to treat anxiety, seizure, and sleep disorders, can be dangerous during pregnancy. These drugs are called benzodiazepines (also called benzos) and can harm your growing baby. When you take benzos, the medication enters your blood and passes through the placenta to your baby.
Abusing benzos during pregnancy can raise baby’s risk of:
Low birth weight
Preterm birth
Problems with their breathing
Birth defects
Symptoms of withdrawal
Miscarriage or stillbirth

If you were prescribed benzos by a doctor, tell them you are pregnant right away. If needed, they will help you switch to a pregnancy-safe medication. Do not stop taking benzos without talking to your doctor first.

title.en-US: Maven’s ultimate guide to prenatal nutrition

content.value: What you need to know:
You and your baby need healthy foods plus your prenatal vitamin each day.
You can eat healthy without spending a lot of money! Grocery store basics will help keep you and baby healthy.
Eat different foods from different food groups at each meal and snack. If fresh fruits and vegetables are hard to come by, add them when you can.
Sign up for
WIC
to help pay for groceries during and after your pregnancy. Look for other resources in your community that can help. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Why try to eat healthy foods during pregnancy? So many reasons!
Diet is so important to help your baby grow and develop strong and healthy.
There’s no need to buy fancy or expensive foods, though. Eating healthy on a
limited budget
is possible. Basics from the grocery store and a daily prenatal vitamin will help keep you and baby going strong.
And with programs like WIC and SNAP to help you out, you can eat a healthy diet on a budget.
Read this guide to learn about:
Nutrients you and baby need
What to shop for at the grocery store
How much to eat each trimester
Easy pregnancy meal ideas
Prenatal vitamins
What not to eat
Community resources to help
Nutrients you and baby need
Nutrients are the building blocks of a healthy diet. Eating healthy foods and taking your prenatal vitamins every day will give you and baby the nutrients you two need.
Here are some of the important nutrients during your pregnancy. Learn more about why they’re so good for you, and which foods to get them from.
REPLACEWITHIMGWCAPTION
Shopping list ideas
Not sure what to shop for at the grocery store?
Buy foods from each of the food groups below.
When possible, try eating different foods from different food groups at each meal and snack. (Like rice, beans, and vegetables. And maybe some fruit or 100% fruit juice.)
Grains:
▢ Whole wheat or whole grain bread
▢ Cereal (Buy whole grain when you can)
▢ Rice
▢ Pasta
▢ Oatmeal
▢ Tortillas
Protein:
▢ Peanut butter
▢ Beans
▢ Lentils
▢ Eggs
▢ Chicken
▢ Ground beef
▢ Canned light tuna or salmon
Vegetables:
▢ Frozen or canned veggies like peas, carrots, and corn
▢ Fresh vegetables like potatoes, onions, greens, snap peas, and collard greens
Fruits:
▢ Fresh or frozen,
▢ Canned fruit (Should be packed in water or 100% juice or say “without added sugar” or syrup)
▢ 100% fruit juice
▢ Unsweetened applesauce
Dairy:
▢ Milk
▢ Cheese
▢ Yogurt
Easy pregnancy meal ideas
Not sure what to make? These are some ideas for meals and snacks you can make from the grocery list above.
Breakfast:
▢ Bread with peanut butter and banana
▢ Oatmeal made with milk and dried fruit
▢ Cereal with milk
▢ Scrambled eggs with cheese and onions (or a different vegetable)
▢ Boiled eggs with a piece of fruit or 100% juice
Lunch:
▢ Bean or ground beef burrito
▢ Avocado, rice, and beans
▢ Soup
▢ Peanut butter and jelly sandwich
Tuna pasta salad
Easy peanut noodles
Dinner:
▢ Bowl of pasta with ground beef and veggies
Baked chicken and vegetables
3-can chili
Snacks:
▢ Yogurt
▢ Hard boiled eggs
Looking for more recipe ideas? Check out these free, budget-friendly websites:
WICShopper Recipes
Over 300 free recipes. Search by meal or by food category.
USDA MyPlate Kitchen Recipes
: Allows you to find and sort recipes based on nutrient or food group focus, kitchen equipment, and cost)
Good and Cheap: Eat Well on $4/Day by Leanne Brown
: A free cookbook with recipes to help you eat well on a budget.
Fast food and processed foods

Everyone eats fast and processed food sometimes. It’s affordable, convenient, and an easy way to get in some calories. And that’s OK from time to time! Throughout your pregnancy, just try your best to reach for fresh, healthy options when you can. And save fast and processed foods for when you need a treat or for when you don’t have other options.
If you’re having trouble affording healthy foods, see our resources below.
Prenatal vitamins
Remember, even if you eat healthy foods, it’s still important to take a
prenatal vitamin
every day.
Why are prenatal vitamins so important? They help your baby get the right amount of nutrients they need to grow and develop.
Pregnant and breastfeeding women also need some extra nutrition, too.
Your prenatal vitamin should include:
Folic acid
Iron
Calcium REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you need help buying prenatal vitamins, talk to your doctor. They should be able to help. Your health insurance may cover the cost of prenatal vitamins. In most states, prenatal vitamins are 100% covered by Medicaid insurance. (A prescription might be required, though.)
Not sure which prenatal vitamin to take?
Ask us!
How much to eat every day
First trimester
You might not feel like eating much the first few months of pregnancy. That’s OK! Even when you’re nauseous or feeling sick, keep taking your prenatal vitamins.
Also, drink plenty of water.
Some ideas for days when you don’t feel like eating much might be:
Crackers (with or without cheese or peanut butter)
Cereal with milk
Toast (with or without butter, cheese, or peanut butter)
Soup
Baked or mashed potatoes
Fruit (with or without cheese, peanut butter, or yogurt)
Second trimester and third trimester
You need about 300-450 extra calories each day. That’s about one or two extra snacks. Make them count by trying something healthy. Try a bowl of cereal with milk or a couple of hard boiled eggs.
If you’re worried about gaining or losing weight during your pregnancy, ask your doctor how many calories you should be eating each day.
What not to eat (or drink)

Getting sick with a food-borne illness (from foods that have unsafe bacteria in them) during pregnancy can be dangerous for you and your baby. Try to avoid foods that can make you sick, like the ones on the list below.
During pregnancy, you should not eat:
Raw fish or seafood
Unpasteurized milk or cheese (dairy should say “pasteurized” on the label)
Raw or undercooked eggs
Unwashed fruits and vegetables
Unpasteurized juice
Hot dogs or lunch/deli meats unless they are cooked until steaming hot
Avoid buffets at restaurants, they may increase your risk of infection
What about caffeine or alcohol?
Limit your coffee intake to about one or two mugs (standard size, not jumbo!) each day.
Also, cut out drinking alcohol, beer, and wine. It’s not safe for your baby.
If you need substance use support, you can always talk to a
Mental Health Provider on Maven
for free anytime.
Community resources
Need help getting healthy food near you? Look out for resources in your community.
WIC:
This program can help you pay for groceries during your pregnancy and after. Sign up
here
Farmer’s market nutrition program (FMNP):
You may also be able to use WIC to get FMNP coupons. These are accepted at some farmer’s markets and roadside stands around the country. Learn more
here
Want one-on-one nutrition advice for free?
Talk to a Nutritionist
online on Maven for free anytime!
They can help you:
Learn more about what you should eat and shouldn’t eat during pregnancy
Manage a health condition through diet
Eat healthy on a budget
Answer any of your pregnancy nutrition questions
And more!
Sources
March of Dimes
WIC Shopper
HealthyArkansas.gov
Mayo Clinic
Source:
March of Dimes

title.en-US: Your guide to newborn baby care

content.value: What you need to know:
Your baby’s basic needs are: food, sleep, a clean diaper, comfortable temperature, to be held, and to be kept safe from harm.
It may not sound like a lot, but it can add up because baby’s needs are around the clock. It is important to ask for help.
Making sure your baby is fed is very important. If you’re having trouble feeding them, reach out to their pediatrician or a free
Pediatrician on Maven
right away for help.
Giving your baby a safe place to sleep is the most important thing you can do to protect them.
If your baby is crying a lot and you are getting frustrated, it is OK to put baby in a safe space (like their crib) and step away for a few minutes to calm down. Talk to a
Maven Mental Health Provider
or
Pediatrician
for free support without judgment.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If this is your first rodeo or if you are already a parent, taking care of a new baby is a lot of work! Follow this guide to help you keep the whole family happy, healthy, and (hopefully) rested during the newborn phase.
Maven has classes that can help
Maven has free, on-demand classes that can help you through the newborn phase.
Visit the Library
for classes like:
Newborn care 101
Breastfeeding 101
Newborn and infant sleep 101
Infant CPR 101
Feeding your new baby

Whether you breastfeed or bottle feed with infant formula, newborn babies need to eat every few hours, even at nighttime. In fact, most newborn babies eat 8 to 12 times in 24 hours! It seems like a lot, but it is very important for baby to eat every few hours. It can be dangerous for their health, growth, and development if they do not get enough breastmilk or formula.
This is what you need to know about feeding a newborn.
Learn your baby’s signs of hunger

If your baby is chewing on their hands, smacking their lips, opening and closing their mouth, feeling around for your breast, or turning their head into your body, they are probably hungry. Crying is a late sign of hunger.
Signs a breastfed baby is getting enough milk
Every baby is different, but most newborns eat every 2 to 3 hours. When breastfed babies are going through a growth spurt or cluster feeding (nursing very often), they might eat every 1 hour.
Some signs your breastfed baby is getting enough milk are:
Your baby seems full
Your baby has 5 to 7 (or more) wet diapers every day, and poop looks yellow and like there are seeds in it
Your baby sleeps a few hours at a time
Your baby is gaining weight (your pediatrician will check this)
Your breasts feel empty after your baby nursesREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Breastfeeding can be hard. If you are struggling, in pain, or have questions about breastfeeding, get help right away. Make a free, online appointment with a
Maven Lactation Consultant
today.
Formula and bottle feeding your baby

Most newborns will drink between 1 and 3 ounces of infant formula every few hours. But remember that every baby is different. As your baby grows, they will drink more.It is very important to follow the exact instructions on the label to prepare your baby’s formula. You should never water it down or use fewer scoops of formula than the instructions say to make the container last longer. Giving a baby watered down formula can be very dangerous to their health.
How to burp your baby

It is normal for babies to swallow a lot of air when they are nursing or drinking from a bottle. This can cause uncomfortable gas to build up in their bellies. Gently burping baby after every ounce of formula or when you switch breasts while nursing can help.
When it is time to burp baby, hold them up with their head against your shoulder (remembering to support their neck). Gently pat their back with your other hand until they burp.
Prevent major spit-ups
Burping your baby while they nurse or bottle feed and holding them upright for 10 to 15 minutes after they finish eating can help keep baby from spitting up a lot.
Supplies you need for baby
It may seem like you need a ton of supplies to care for a new baby, but you really only need a few important items:
▢ A safe sleep space with a firm, flat surface
A bassinet, playard, or crib with a firm, flat mattress and tight-fitting sheet are good options.
Learn more about safe infant sleep here.
▢ Formula and bottles.

If you do not want to breastfeed or cannot breastfeed, have some infant formula and clean bottles ready. If you have WIC benefits, you can get free or low-cost infant formula. Call your WIC office for information.
Learn more about infant feeding here.
▢ Diapers
New babies pee and poop a lot. You can expect to use at least 12 diapers every day—that is 336 diapers per month! Choose a type (cloth or disposable) and brand that fits your budget.
If you need help finding diapers, you have a few options:
Look for churches or diaper banks in your area that give out diapers for free
Contact your local food bank or food pantry and ask about donated diapers
Ask your pediatrician for help finding diapers for a lower costREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
▢ Wipes
You will use a lot of wipes with a newborn, too. There are many different brands to choose from.You can also use (wash and reuse) soft washcloths with water.
▢ Towels

. Even though newborns do not need a bath every day (once a week is fine in the beginning), it is a good idea to have some clean, dry towels on-hand. You can use them for bathtime, cleaning up spit-up, or on the floor for
tummy time
. Muslin or flannel swaddling blankets can be used, too.
▢ A baby bathtub or wash basin

. Sometimes it is hard to give a wiggly baby a bath! An infant bathtub with a sling seat can help. If you do not have a bathtub, you can also fill a small basin with a few inches of water. Some babies even fit into a clean sink for their first few baths. Remember to never leave baby alone during a bath—not even for a second.
▢ Baby clothes

. You do not need a lot of clothes for your newborn, but it is important to dress them for the temperature outside. If it is warm, short-sleeve onesies or pajamas will keep them cool. If it is cold, long-sleeved onesies with pants or warm pajamas will keep them warm. You can find discounted baby clothes at thrift stores, consignment shops, or parent groups on Facebook.

Many hospitals and birthing centers will let you take some baby care supplies home after you give birth. Be sure to ask about ready-to-feed formula, diapers, wipes, and other items that you can bring home for baby. For other items, contact your local WIC office or family services, or check Facebook groups for new parents.
Always practice safe sleep
It is important to always use safe sleep habits for your baby, even during naps. Safe sleep protects your baby from danger, like sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS), choking, or suffocating.
▢ Make sure your baby’s sleep area is safe.
If you buy a used crib or get one from a family member or friend, check
cpsc.gov
to make sure it meets today’s safety standards.
▢ Always put baby to sleep on a firm, flat surface.
A crib, playard, or bassinet are good options. In an emergency, a cardboard box on the floor can be used until you can find safe sleep space.
▢ Always put baby to sleep on their back.
If your baby can turn onto their tummy or side by themselves, it is OK to leave them in that position. But you should never put them on their tummy or side for sleep.
▢ Make sure baby’s sleep area is completely empty.
Do not put pillows, blankets, toys, bumpers, or any other items besides a pacifier in your baby’s sleeping area. They can cause your baby to suffocate.
▢ Do not bring your baby in your bed to sleep.
It may feel tempting when you are tired, but this can raise the risk of SIDS, choking, and suffocation.
If you are not sure if your baby’s sleep area is safe, video chat or message a
Maven Pediatric Sleep Coach
or a
Maven Pediatrician
for help.
Holding and carrying your newborn
It can be exciting (and a little scary!) to hold a newborn for the first time. Here are a few things to remember when you or a loved one is holding your baby.
▢ Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.

Newborns do not have strong immune systems, so they can get sick more easily than older babies and kids. Make sure anyone else who holds baby washes their hands or uses hand sanitizer before picking them up.
▢ Support baby’s head and neck.
Since young babies do not have strong shoulder or neck muscles, it is important to support their head and neck when you carry them, hold them upright, and lay them down.
▢ Make sure baby is secure in their carrier, stroller, or car seat.
Check all of the straps and buckles to make sure your baby cannot fall out.
▢ Never shake your baby.

Babies cry a lot. Not being able to calm your baby down when they are crying can feel hard. Never shake your baby, swing them by their arms or legs, or try to quiet them by putting a blanket, pillow, or something else over their face. It is OK to step away for a few minutes if baby is in a safe space, so you can calm down.
Learn about what to do if your baby is crying here.
How to diaper your new baby
If you do not have a lot of experience with babies—or it’s been awhile—this guide can help.
Remember, babies need their diapers changed a lot. You should change your baby when it feels full (or the stripe on the front of the diaper changes color) or when baby poops.
Watch our video on how to change a diaper
or follow the steps below:
Lay baby down on the changing table. (Remember, never walk away from the changing table while baby is on it—they can easily fall off.)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Take off the dirty diaper, wipe, and put the old diaper to the side. Make sure it is far away, so baby cannot kick it.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Open the new diaper. The tabs on the sides of the diaper should be in the back. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
While baby is laying on their back, lift their legs up and put the diaper under their bottom. Put their legs back down. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Pull the front of the diaper up and between baby’s legs. (If baby still has a cord stump, be sure to fold the front of the diaper down. The diaper should not touch baby’s cord stump.)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Open one tab and pull it straight across the front of the diaper to attach it. Repeat with the tab on the other side. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have a baby boy, you might want to put a washcloth, wipe, or clean diaper over his penis while you change his diaper. It is very common for baby boys to pee during diaper changes!
What to know about diaper rash

It is common for babies to get diaper rash. It is a red rash babies get around their genitals and bottoms. It happens when a baby is in a wet or poopy diaper for too long. Serious cases of diaper rash can cause fevers, yeast infections, or skin infections.
If you notice a red rash on your baby’s bottom, try putting a thick layer of diaper rash cream or an ointment (like Aquaphor) on it. This will protect baby’s skin from wetness and let the rash heal.
If the rash begins to spread or your baby has a fever, call your pediatrician right away. Fevers in babies under 3 months are considered medical emergencies.
Taking care of your baby’s umbilical cord stump

The umbilical stump is the small piece of umbilical cord that is left in baby’s belly button after they are born. It will fall off on its own after 1 to 3 weeks. But until then, follow these steps to care for baby’s umbilical stump.
▢ Keep the umbilical stump dry.

Exposing baby’s umbilical stump to air can help it heal faster. Do not put any ointment, rubbing alcohol, or other treatments on it. Make sure the front of baby’s diaper is folded down, so it does not cover or rub against the stump.
▢ Do not pull on the umbilical stump.
It is important to let baby’s umbilical stump fall off by itself.
▢ Look out for signs of infection.

It is normal for baby’s umbilical stump to bleed a little or scab. But if baby’s skin turns red or swollen, or if the stump leaks pus or turns wet and pink, call your pediatrician right away. These can be signs of an infection.
Call your pediatrician or chat with a
Maven Pediatrician
if your baby’s umbilical stump has not fallen off by itself after 3 weeks.
Giving your newborn a bath
Newborns do not need a bath every day, but it is a good idea to do a sponge bath every few days or so. Remember these important tips for bathtime.
▢ Never leave baby alone in the tub, sink, or wash basin.
Leaving your baby alone during bathtime is very dangerous—even for a second. If you need to leave the bathroom, wrap baby in a towel and bring them with you or place them safely on the floor.
▢ Do sponge baths until baby loses their umbilical stump.

Avoid soaking their full body, and stump. Instead, lay baby down on a clean, dry towel on a safe surface. Then, wipe them down with warm water and a soft washcloth. Be sure to focus on folds in their skin where milk, spit-up, and sweat can build up.
▢ Try a tub bath after the umbilical stump falls off.

After the umbilical stump falls off, you can put baby in 2 to 3 inches of warm water for a bath in a baby tub or clean sink. You can use a washcloth or your hands to gently wash baby’s hair, face, and body. Be sure to protect their eyes when you rinse their hair.
Have questions about caring for a newborn?
Ask us! Make an online appointment with a
Maven Pediatrician
or
Lactation Consultant
for free advice anytime.

title.en-US: Maven’s guide to baby feeding

content.value: What you need to know:
Fed is best when it comes to your baby. You can breastfeed, pump and bottle-feed breast milk, use formula, or do a combination!
Breastfeeding can be hard, but it shouldn’t be painful. Get help from a Maven Lactation Consultant for free at any time. They’re here for any questions you have about breastfeeding.
If baby isn’t eating or if you feel like they aren’t gaining weight, reach out to their pediatrician, or a
Maven Pediatrician
, right away.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
When it comes to parenthood, everyone warns you about losing sleep. But you may be surprised to learn that feeding your baby can be one of the biggest challenges of all.

We’ve all seen happy pictures of breastfeeding on social media. The truth is that feeding can be really hard. Remember that this is a new skill for you and for your baby, too. It can take time (and a few changes) to find what works.
Whether you are bottle feeding or breastfeeding, here are all the basics you need to know.
If you ever have questions along the way, we’re here for you! You can video chat or message with a
Lactation Consultant
for help breastfeeding or a
Pediatrician
for help choosing a formula or feeding tips for free on Maven anytime—day or night.
Remember, fed is best

If baby is having a hard time with eating, reach out to get help right away. There’s more than one way to feed them. They can have breast milk, formula, or a combination of both, and your pediatrician can help you decide what’s best for your baby. Your milk might take 3-5 days to fully come in, and that’s okay: but it’s still great to have a trusted lactation consultant to chat with.
Breastfeeding:
Breastfeeding has so many benefits if it works for you and your family. Some of these include:
Lower risks of breast cancer for you
Lower risks of ovarian cancer for you
Lots of good immunity is passed from you to baby
You can do it anytime and anywhere, for free
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Pumping:

Once your breast milk supply is in and you and baby have a good feeding routine (around 4-6 weeks), you may want to start pumping to store some breast milk. Sometimes you need to pump sooner, like if baby isn’t latching and that is OK!
Storing milk makes it easier for others to help with feedings. This means you can be away from baby when you need to, and it can also help you get ready for going back to work.
(For tips on choosing a bottle and feeding positions, see the formula and bottle feeding section below.)
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Formula and bottle feeding:

Remember: fed is best. If you choose not to breastfeed or can’t breastfeed, that is OK and baby will still get the nutrients they need. The important steps for formula feeding are choosing the bottle and formula that your baby needs and likes. (Babies may be small, but they get picky about these things!) Here are some tips to help you along.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Sources
American Academy of Pediatrics: Infant Food and Feeding
Mayo Clinic
World Health Organization
American Academy of Pediatrics
Breastfeeding can be tough, but it should never be painful. If you’re having any trouble feeding your baby, reach out to a
Lactation Consultant on Maven
right away.
Help is here for you, for free.

It is best to feed baby soon after birth or within the first hour (if you are recovering after a C-section). This will give you and baby a chance to learn how to latch. “Latching” is when baby’s mouth is positioned on your nipple and feeding the right way to get milk out.

In the first couple of days, it is more important for your baby to feed often than it is for them to feed for long amounts of time. This will give baby the nutrition they need and help your milk to come in.
Colostrum is the first milk your body makes. You might hear it called “liquid gold”.
When you first give birth, your breasts may not feel full yet because you will make colostrum before you make milk.
It may not look like much (it’s usually semi-clear or yellowish), but colostrum is full of nutrients and all your baby needs in those first few days.
It is common for babies to lose a little weight the first couple of days as they feed on colostrum, and then to gain it back in the next week or so as your breast milk comes in.

items.header: When your breast milk will come in

content.value: Often your milk will come in between 3-5 days after giving birth. You will know it is coming in because your breasts will feel engorged (very full and firm to the touch) and the milk that comes out will get a thinner, white appearance.

It’s totally normal for it to take a few days for your body to really start making milk. Until then, colostrum is all baby needs. Babies have tiny stomachs and won’t need more than you’re making unless you notice you aren’t making milk at all.
If you don’t see your milk coming in within 3-5 days after having baby, talk to your doctor or care team.
Breastfeed your baby “on-demand,” meaning as often as they show signs of hunger. This will be about 8-12 times in 24 hours during the first month of life. This means you will need to feed baby:
At least every 2-3 hours during the day
And go no longer than every 4 hours at night. This often means waking your baby up to get them to feed at night.
Your baby will show you signs that they are hungry, such as:
Smacking their lips
Rooting (or searching for your nipple by putting their face into you)
Sucking on their fist to let you know when they’re hungry
You can hold baby in lots of positions while breastfeeding. These might include:
Side lying:
Lay on your side and let baby feed from your breast. It’s usually easier to use the same side and breast.
Cradle hold:
Hold baby and breastfeed them at the same time, making sure to support their head and guide them to your breast.
Laid-back hold:
Lay back with a pillow behind you, and hold baby rest on your stomach to feed from either breast.
Keep your baby at the breast as long as they are suckling. This usually is 15-20 minutes at each breast or about 40 minutes total when they are newborns.
You might have to wake your baby after feeding on the first breast to get them to actively latch and nurse on the second breast.
If your baby prefers one breast over the other, don’t worry. Just remember to keep feeding at both breasts to keep your breast milk supply even.

items.header: How to know if baby is getting enough milk

content.value: One way to tell if baby is latching properly and getting enough milk in the first couple days of life is to look at your baby’s poop. It should start to change in color over a few days, from:
Black to greenish
Then greenish to yellow and seedy
Baby’s poop will be yellow and seedy looking when your milk has fully come in. Your baby will often start pooping after every feeding for the first month of life.
By 5 days old, your baby should also have at least:
5-7 wet pee diapers in 24 hours
Pale, colorless pee (it shouldn’t be dark yellow or another color)
They should also seem satisfied for about 1-3 hours after nursing

Burping helps your baby get rid of gas after eating. A gassy baby isn’t usually a happy one, so burping them after every feeding is important. You can do this by holding baby upright against your chest and lightly patting their upper back until they burp.
If you are exclusively breastfeeding your baby, sometimes you will also need to give baby a vitamin D supplement or iron. Talk to your baby’s pediatrician or a
Pediatrician on Maven
anytime about which would be best. Formula-fed babies may not need supplements.
The
World Health Organization
and the
American Academy of Pediatrics

recommends breastfeeding exclusively for the first 6 months if possible, and up to 2 years or longer along with safe and nutritious foods. That said, feeding is a personal decision made by you, with help from your child’s pediatrician.

Breastfeeding your baby any amount until they are 6 months old is great for you and baby if it works for your family. And, you can continue to breastfeed longer if you and your baby want to or use formula in addition to breast milk.
Lactation Consultants are here for you on
Maven
to use anytime for free.

In order to pump, you’ll need to get a breast pump. Contact your insurance company or WIC to get a pump. They can let you know if they cover the cost of a breast pump and you may have to choose from their list.
There are a few pump options:
Electric (one you plug in or that uses a battery)
Manual (one you pump by hand)
Single or double pumps (for one breast or both)
Other supplies you’ll need include:
Bottles that fit your breast pump
Milk storage bags
Cooler for keeping milk safe while you’re out or at work
Pump cleaning wipes
Pumping bra if you want to be hands-free
You can pump:
After feeding your baby
In the middle of the night when baby is sleeping a longer stretch
When you are away from your baby, at the times they would normally feed
You may find that you make the most milk during the night and in the morning.
Decide if you want to store your milk in bags or bottles (and make sure you have a lot!). Once you’ve pumped milk,
do not let it sit out at room temperature for longer than 4 hours
. This is to keep your milk safe for baby to eat!

You can put breast milk in the refrigerator for up to 4 days, or put it in the freezer. You can freeze milk in a refrigerator freezer for 3-6 months and in a deep freezer for up to 12 months. When freezing milk, it’s best to do so in small amounts (such as 2-3 ounces).
Always label the container with:
The date the milk was collected
How much milk it is
The name of your baby (if daycare will be thawing it)
To heat up breast milk from the refrigerator, you just need to put the bottle in a bowl of warm water. To unthaw from the freezer, you can:
Put it in a bowl of warm water
Put it in the refrigerator overnight
Put it under warm running water
Remember: Never use a microwave to heat breast milk or any bottle. It might not
heat all the way through or could burn baby’s mouth.
Once it’s thawed you can store it in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours. If you don’t use it by then it has to be thrown away. Thawed breast milk can’t be put back in the freezer.

To slow the spread of germs, always keep your pump parts and baby’s bottle parts clean. Wash them by hand with warm water and dish soap or in the dishwasher (according to the instructions provided on the packaging).
For extra protection, clean feeding items daily for:
Babies younger than 3 months
Babies who were born prematurely (or earlier than their due date; usually before 37 weeks)
Babies with weakened immune systems
Follow these instructions from the Centers for Disease Control
Before you return to work, ask for a private spot where you can pump. There are federal laws your workplace must follow, including providing you a private space and time to pump.

To keep a good milk supply, pump as often as you would feed your baby (usually every 2-3 hours) if you can. Skipping pumping sessions can decrease your supply, meaning you start to make less breast milk.

Think about how often you will have to pump at work and how much time you will have for each session to help you figure out which is the best pump to bring to workfor you. For example, if you’ll be pumping at work, a double electric will be quicker than a single manual pump, but you may need access to an outlet.
It’s important to know that your job is required by law to give you time to pump at work.
Maven Career Coaches
are available to help you speak up for yourself and your needs when returning to work and pumping.
Find more details on pumping at work and what your rights are
Formula is sold at grocery stores and places like Walmart or Target. Programs like Women, Infants and Children (WIC) cover all kinds of formulas. Contact your local
WIC to learn more

The options can be overwhelming. Luckily, you can rest assured that all formulas in the United States are checked and all are Federal Drug Administration (FDA) –approved (yep, even the store-brand ones). This means they are safe for your baby and have the nutrition they need.
Ask your baby’s pediatrician what formula may be best for them or ask a
Pediatrician on Maven
It may take a few different nipples to find the one your baby likes. Look for the stage on the package to make sure the nipple is recommended for newborns (and size up as they grow).
These stages affect how fast the milk will flow out, starting with a small hole for a slow flow, and then a larger or additional holes for a faster flow as your baby learns how to eat.
Always sanitize nipples before first use following the instructions on the package.
You can find great deals on bottles and nipples at children’s consignment stores, too!

Glass or silicone bottles are great because they are easy to keep clean. Often, it’s best to choose one bottle type and one nipple type and stick with it so your baby is familiar with it. Don’t be surprised if it takes a few tries to find the right combination.

items.header: How much to feed during the first few days of life

content.value: You can also use this formula to figure out how much to feed your baby:
Baby’s current weight in pounds x 2.5 ounces = Total ounces to feed per day (Example: Baby weighs 8 lbs x 2.5 ounces = 20 ounces per day)
This formula can be used until they are approximately 15 pounds or 2-3 months of age. Check in with your
Pediatrician on Maven
anytime to make sure.
Formula can be liquid or powder. Liquid formula is ready to feed and doesn’t need to be mixed with any water.
Powdered formula is mixed with water according to the directions on the back of the can. Follow these general steps:
1. Wash:
Wash your hands, bottles, nipples, and work area to protect your baby from germs or bacteria.
2. Measure:
Follow the instructions on the package of formula to measure out the water first, then add the powder.
Always put in the exact amounts on the formula can.
If the formula is too weak, your baby won’t get the nutrition they need. If it’s too strong, it can make your baby’s digestion system go into overdrive (and lead to a cranky/gassy baby).
Be sure to use clean water. If you have any doubts about your water quality, boil and cool the water before mixing with formula, or use distilled bottled water.
3. Check the temperature:
Room temperature formula for baby is just fine.

If your baby prefers it a little warmer or it has been in the fridge, run the bottle under warm (not hot) water from the faucet for a minute or so (taking care not to get water in the bottle’s nipple).
Never use a microwave to warm a bottle. It can cause heat spots and burn baby’s mouth.

items.header: How to hold baby while feeding

content.value: A few tips
Feed your baby in a semi-upright position
Have the formula fill the nipple completely so your baby does not get too much air
Don’t feed baby while they are lying down. They can choke and milk can come back up. This can cause an ear infection.

To prevent the spread of germs that can make your baby sick, always keep bottles and nipples clean. Wash them by hand with warm water and dish soap or in the dishwasher (according to the instructions provided on the packaging).

Burping helps your baby get rid of gas after eating. A gassy baby isn’t usually a happy one, so burping them after every feeding is important. You can do this by holding baby upright against your chest and lightly patting their upper back until they burp.

title.en-US: How chronic conditions can impact your future fertility

content.value: Whether you’d like to have children someday or you’re not sure, it can help to know how your health today may impact your reproductive plans for the future. Some chronic conditions are known to affect fertility, while some seem linked but aren’t entirely understood yet. If you have any of these conditions, don’t panic. “Women with chronic health conditions can conceive, have healthy pregnancies, and give birth to healthy babies,” Maven OB-GYN Dr. Audrey Lance says. “Start by working with your doctor or a
doctor on Maven
to learn how you can manage your condition to improve your odds of conceiving when (or if) you’re ready.”
Chronic conditions that affect fertility
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
A note on medication

“If you take medication for a chronic condition be sure to share this with your doctor before you plan to become pregnant,” Lance says. “They can help make sure that your treatment plan is safe for you and your baby, or help you change to a new one if you need to.” It’s important to never start or stop taking medication without speaking with your doctor first.
The bottom line:

Many people with chronic conditions go on to have the family they’ve always wanted someday, but it’s important to get chronic conditions under control first. Set up a checkup with your OB-GYN or chat with one on Maven to talk about your overall health, learn how to manage specific conditions, and put future you in the best possible position should you choose to become a parent.
Sources
RESOLVE
March of Dimes
American Diabetes Association
European Respiratory Journal
American College for Advancement in Medicine
Women’s Health
Reuters
US National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health
Mayo Clinic
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
(Such as inflammatory bowel disease, Crohn’s disease, lupus, multiple sclerosis, psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis, or celiac disease)

An autoimmune disease is when your immune system attacks your body, and there are many different types. According to the American College for Advancement in Medicine, autoimmune diseases can lead to reproductive disorders. “Autoimmune diseases may also play a large role in cases of unexplained infertility, when the cause of infertility isn’t known,” Lance says.

Diabetes is a group of diseases that result in the body being unable to produce or properly use insulin, which results in too much sugar in the blood. Research has found that Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes are associated with infertility, although the exact reasons are unclear. “However, one study found that by managing their diabetes, individuals were able to increase their fertility rate close to that of those without diabetes,” Lance says.

Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue grows outside of the uterus. As many as 50% of people with endometriosis may have trouble becoming pregnant, according to the Mayo Clinic, but many with mild or moderate cases have gone on to have healthy pregnancies and treatment can help improve your fertility.

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is a virus that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) by weakening the immune system’s ability to fight infection and disease. Studies show that women who are infected by HIV have a 25–40% lower rate of fertility than those who are not. This may be the result of a weakened immune system and other conditions such as pelvic inflammatory disease. “Females with HIV are also more likely to have irregular menstrual cycles which can make it difficult to conceive,” Lance says.

Hyperthyroidism is a condition caused by an overactive thyroid gland releasing above-normal thyroid hormone levels. It affects your metabolism and critical body functions. “If untreated, hyperthyroidism may cause your ovaries to stop releasing eggs (this is called anovulation), which can make it difficult to conceive,” Lance says.

Hypothyroidism is a condition where your thyroid gland doesn’t produce enough thyroid hormone to regulate your metabolism and other critical body functions. Without treatment, low thyroid hormone can affect ovulation by preventing the release of an egg each month, which makes it difficult to become pregnant.

Obesity is a disease that involves an excessive amount of body fat. It’s usually defined by a body mass index (BMI) of 30.0 or higher. Many studies have found that obesity reduces pregnancy rates, usually due to irregular ovulation, which can cause irregular periods. “There is also a strong correlation between obesity and polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which can interfere with fertility,” Lance says.

PID is an infection of the female reproductive organs caused by bacteria. PID can lead to scarring in the fallopian tubes which can block an egg from being fertilized. If untreated, PID can cause long-term issues including infertility. According to The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 1 in 10 people with PID will become infertile without proper treatment.

PCOS is a condition that affects the way ovaries work which can lead to irregular ovulation and make it difficult to become pregnant. PCOS is one of the most common causes of female infertility, according to the National Institutes of Health.

Chlamydia and gonorrhea are STIs which, if left untreated, can cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), an infection of the reproductive organs. “If you have chlamydia or gonorrhea and don’t receive treatment, or have contracted either STI multiple times, this can lead to scarring and cause damage to the fallopian tubes which can lead to infertility,” Lance says.

Asthma is caused by tissue inflammation in the lungs, which can make it difficult to breathe. Some studies have found a link between asthma and infertility for women who use short-acting relief inhalers, but more research is needed.

title.en-US: How chronic conditions can impact your fertility

content.value: If you suffer from a chronic health condition, you may be wondering if it will make it harder to become pregnant—the short answer is, it may. Some chronic conditions are known to affect fertility, while some seem linked but aren’t entirely understood yet. If you have any of these conditions, don’t panic. "People with chronic health conditions can conceive, have healthy pregnancies, and give birth to healthy babies,” Maven OB-GYN Dr. Audrey Lance says. “To help ensure this, talk to your doctor or a
doctor on Maven
before conceiving to learn how to manage your condition. This is the best way to improve your odds of becoming pregnant and having a healthy pregnancy.”
Chronic conditions that affect fertility
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
A note on medication

“If you take medication for a chronic condition be sure to share this with your doctor before you plan to become pregnant,” Lance says. “They can help make sure that your treatment plan is safe for you and your baby, or help you change to a new one if you need to.” It’s important to never start or stop taking medication without speaking with your doctor first.
The bottom line:

title.en-US: What you should know about drug abuse and your health

content.value: The reasons that people abuse drugs are as varied as their drug of choice—but for many, drugs are a form of escape from pain, sadness, trauma, or the stresses of everyday life. But once the feel-good effects subside, drugs leave a host of negative side effects in their wake, from dry mouth and irritability to intense symptoms of withdrawal, like convulsions and vomiting. Over time, drug abuse can lead to heart disease, cancer, stroke, or even death. With some, using just once can be enough to cause a fatal heart attack. Maven Physician Dr. Carolyn Riley explains exactly how drug abuse devastates your health and how you can get help to stop using.
What is drug addiction?

Addiction is a disease of the brain. With repeated use, your brain forms a tolerance to a drug. In response, you need larger doses to feel high, which makes your brain produce even less dopamine, causing a vicious cycle. “Essentially, the more you use drugs, the further away you get from the ‘reward’ sensation while simultaneously becoming mentally and physically more dependent on drugs, making it more difficult to stop despite the harmful consequences,” Riley says. “This is the definition of addiction.”
What if I only use drugs on occasion?

“There is no ‘safe’ level of drug abuse,” Riley says. “Because street drugs aren’t regulated there’s no way to know exactly what they’re made up of or the dosage. Abusing prescription medication is just as dangerous and can lead to difficulty breathing, heart failure, or seizures.”
How do drugs negatively affect my health?
“Drug abuse affects nearly every system in the body,” says Riley. “These effects can be both physical and psychological and some are irreversible.”
Drug use can cause health concerns including:
Impaired judgment, mood, and memory
Nausea and abdominal pain
Decreased appetite and weight loss
Weakened immune system, increasing risk of illness or infection
Seizures, stroke, brain damage
Heart disease
Liver damage or failure
Cancer
Lung disease
Increased risk of infectious disease such as HIV/AIDS or hepatitis
Mental illness (including depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia)
Loss of memory
Acne and skin lesions
Baldness or male pattern hair growth
Tooth damage and gum disease
Mood swings
Hallucinations, paranoia, psychosis
Overdose
Suicide
What are the particular health effects of common drugs?

“Drugs have both short and long-term effects,” Riley says. “The short-term effects occur while you take the drug and after it wears off. The long-term effects build over time as the drug chips away at your overall health.”
Source:
See a full list
from the National Institute of Drug Abuse
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
What are the health effects of injected drugs?

“Injecting drugs by needle can increase the risk of contracting serious infections such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), hepatitis C, and other infectious diseases,” Riley says. Drug injection is linked to 1 in 10 of cases of HIV according to the National Institute of Drug Abuse. Bacteria that can enter the body through needles can also lead to heart infections known as endocarditis and skin infections known as cellulitis.
Are drugs linked to mental health disorders?

“It’s common for people to abuse drugs as a way to self-medicate for mental health issues. But, drug use can make mental health conditions worse or trigger them, including anxiety, depression, and schizophrenia,” Riley says.
How can I get help quitting?

“Quitting drug use is hard, but the results on your health and your life will be immense,” Riley says. “Remember, you don’t have to do it alone. Work with a doctor who will help support and encourage you.”
If you’re struggling with drug abuse, we’re here to support you.
Talk to a doctor on Maven
or send them a message anytime you need to on Maven. Not sure who to talk to? Message your Care Advocate for a personal recommendation.
Sources
National Institute of Drug Abuse
American Psychiatric Association
Gateway Foundation
Short-term:

Narrowed blood vessels; enlarged pupils; increased body temperature, heart rate,and blood pressure; headache, abdominal pain and nausea; euphoria; increased energy, alertness; insomnia; restlessness; anxiety; erratic and violent behavior; panic attacks; paranoia; psychosis; heart rhythm problems; heart attack; stroke; seizure; coma
Long-term:

Loss of sense of smell; nosebleeds; nasal damage and trouble swallowing from snorting; infection and death of bowel tissue from decreased blood flow; poor nutrition and weight loss; lung damage from smoking
Short-term:

Lowered inhibition; false sense of affection; enhanced sensory perception; visual changes; increased heart rate and blood pressure; muscle tension; nausea; faintness; chills or sweating; sharp rise in body temperature leading to kidney failure or death
Long-term:
Long-lasting confusion; depression; problems with attention, memory, and sleep; increased anxiety; impulsiveness; less interest in sex
Short-term:
Euphoria; dry mouth; itching; nausea; vomiting; slowed breathing and heart rate; respiratory failure
Long-term:
Collapsed veins; abscesses (swollen tissue with pus); infection of the lining and valves in the heart; constipation and stomach cramps; liver or kidney disease; pneumonia
Short-term:

Confusion; nausea; slurred speech; lack of coordination; euphoria; dizziness; drowsiness; disinhibition; lightheadedness; hallucinations/delusions; headaches; sudden sniffing death due to heart failure (from butane, propane, and other chemicals in aerosols); death from asphyxiation; choking; suffocation; convulsions or seizures; coma
Long-term:
Liver and kidney damage; bone marrow damage; limb spasms due to nerve damage; brain damage from lack of oxygen that can cause problems with thinking, movement, vision, and hearing
Short-term:
Increased wakefulness and physical activity; decreased appetite; increased breathing; increased heart rate; increased blood pressure, increased temperature; irregular heartbeat.
Long-term:

Anxiety; confusion; insomnia; mood problems; violent behavior; paranoia; hallucinations; delusions; weight loss; severe dental problems (“meth mouth”); intense itching leading to skin sores from scratching
Short-term:

Enhanced sensory perception and euphoria followed by drowsiness/relaxation; slowed reaction time; problems with balance and coordination; increased heart rate and appetite; problems with learning and memory; anxiety
Long-term:
Mental health problems; chronic cough; possible loss of IQ points when repeated use begins in adolescence

title.en-US: What is infertility and when do you need to worry about it?

content.value: “Infertility” isn’t a dirty word. In fact, 1 in 8 couples struggle with infertility in the United States, and in the developed world it affects 1 in 4 couples, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). If you’ve been struggling to conceive, you’re not alone—and if you’re unsure if what you’re experiencing is infertility, we’re here to help. Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist Dr. Kari von Goeben explains everything you need to know to get support on your path to parenthood.
What is infertility?
“The most commonly accepted definition of infertility is being unable to become pregnant after 12 months or more of regular, unprotected sexual intercourse,” von Goeben says.
What causes infertility?

“Infertility is often incorrectly spoken about as a female issue,” von Goeben says. “In reality, the causes of infertility are evenly split between the sexes. Men and women can both have a health condition that’s affecting their ability to conceive.”
Infertility is 30% male factor, 30% female factor, 30% unexplained, 10% a combination of factors
Causes of infertility
• Male factor (such as structural abnormalities or sperm production problems)
• Diminished ovarian reserve (low egg count)
• Blocked fallopian tubes (this may be genetic, or caused by pelvic inflammatory disease or other infections)
• Ovulation issues (irregular or no ovulation)
• Hormonal imbalances (such as thyroid disorders)
• Abnormalities of the uterus (uterine anomalies from birth or due to fibroids ,polyps, etc)
• Endometriosis
• Combination of male and female factors
• Unexplained infertility
When do I need to see a professional about potential infertility issues?

“If you’re 35 or younger and have regular menstrual cycles and have been having regular unprotected intercourse for 12 months with no conception, I recommend seeing a doctor to have an evaluation,” von Goeben says. “If you’re older than 35, I recommend seeing a doctor for an evaluation after 6 months of trying. If you’re 40 or above, I recommend seeing a doctor before trying. I would also recommend seeing a doctor before trying if you have any risk factors for infertility like irregular menstrual cycles, a history of sexually transmitted infections or prior surgeries in your pelvis.”
What are common forms of infertility treatment?

If after speaking with a fertility specialist you decide to pursue fertility treatment to become pregnant, your doctor will recommend treatment tailored to you. “We usually recommend a specific treatment based on the cause of your fertility issues, and female age,” von Goeben says.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
How successful is fertility treatment?

Many couples successfully become pregnant through fertility treatment. However, the success rates are approximate and can vary widely based on the reason for infertility, maternal age, if medication is used, and many other factors.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
The bottom line:

Infertility is nothing to be ashamed about. If you’ve been trying to conceive without luck, talking to a doctor can help. For some, learning how to better time intercourse or taking medications to regulate your cycle may do the trick. For others, IVF or IUI may be part of your path to parenthood. No matter how you get there, Maven is here to support you every step of the way. Talk to a
Maven Fertility Specialist
anytime you need to.
Sources
RESOLVE
World Health Organization
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologist
National Library of Medicine
The odds of becoming pregnant using timed intercourse is approximately 14-23% according to one study published in the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews.
If a couple has an IUI procedure performed each month, success rates may be as high as 20% per cycle according to the American Pregnancy Association.
According to the American Pregnancy Association, the live birth rate for each IVF cycle started is approximately:
41-43% for women under age 35
33-36% for women ages 35 to 37
23-27% for women ages 38 to 40
13-18% for women over age 40
Timed intercourse
Method:
Track your natural ovulation cycle (or ovulation stimulated by medication) to ensure you have intercourse at the ideal time to conceive.
Good for:
This method can be good for couples with ovulation issues (irregular or no ovulation), no evidence of male factor infertility, and normal anatomy.
Process:
Usually involves coming in for an ultrasound and/or bloodwork around the time you expect to ovulate.
Intrauterine insemination (IUI)
Method:
A higher concentration of mobile sperm (aka “good swimmers”) are placed into the uterus around the time of ovulation to encourage fertilization.
Good for:
This method can be good for couples with mild male factor infertility or who have no known infertility issues but haven’t been able to conceive naturally.
Process:

Sperm is washed, concentrated, and placed into the uterus. You may take oral or injectable medications to stimulate ovulation or to increase the number of eggs ovulated. You may also have an ultrasound.
In-vitro fertilization (IVF)
Method:
When one (or more) embryo(s) are transferred into the uterus.
Good for:
This method can be good for patients with blocked fallopian tubes, diminished ovarian reserve (low egg count), or more severe male factor infertility.
Process:

You’ll receive medications through injections that will encourage multiple eggs to develop and prevent them from being released (so as many as possible can reach maturity). These eggs will then be retrieved and either placed in a dish with a high concentration of sperm or injected with sperm to try to create embryos. Usually, one embryo is then transferred back to the uterus (aka “single embryo transfer”), although in some cases more than one embryo is transferred.

title.en-US: Tampon safety: Everything you've ever wanted to know

content.value: Chances are you have a tampon in your bag or your bathroom right now—that’s because this little wonder is a period staple. But how much do you really know about how they work and what they’re made of? We talked to Maven OB-GYN Carol Russell, DO, to learn everything there is to know about tampons and how the products we use during our periods can affect our health.
What we like about tampons

Tampons are all about ease—they’re easy to carry around, easy to use, and make it easy to go about your regular life while you’re having your period. You can swim, work out, do yoga or any other activity while wearing a tampon without anyone knowing and without the discomfort that a bulky pad can sometimes bring.
How they work

A tampon is a small, usually cylindrical, plug that you insert into your vagina to absorb menstrual fluid during your period (this fluid includes blood, secretion, tissue, and cervical mucus). Some tampons come with an applicator that helps you insert it.
How to insert a tampon
“It shouldn’t hurt to put a tampon in or have it in, but it can take a few tries to get used to,” Russell says. Here’s a refresher:
Wash your hands with soap and warm water
Squat, sit, or put a leg up

Push the tampon into your vagina slowly with the applicator or your finger. Aim toward your tailbone at a 45-degree angle until your muscles hold it in place (if you can feel the tampon being pushed out when you stand, it’s not high enough yet).
Put wrapper and applicator in trash (don’t flush in the toilet, even if it says “flushable”—trust us)

“If you’re using a tampon without an applicator, you can put a little water-based lubricant on the tip to help with insertion (just avoid oil-based lubricants because they can promote bacteria growth),” Russell says. If you’re experiencing pain, speak to your doctor or video chat or message with a
Maven OB-GYN
for help.
What they’re made of

Tampons are usually made of cotton (a natural fiber that comes from a crop), rayon (a synthetic fiber), or a blend of both. The string is usually made of polyester or cotton. Some tampons also come with applicators which are made out of plastic or cardboard. You can buy organic tampons made out of 100% organic cotton, which is grown and sourced according to USDA standards. However, organic tampons don’t undergo any more testing than non-organic options (and there isn’t evidence that they’re safer).
Safety

Different countries have different safety regulations for tampons. In the United States the U.S. Food and Drug Administration requires every tampon manufacturer to report the safety of materials, use standardized absorbency labeling (light, regular, super, etc), and ensure that their tampons don’t alter normal bacteria growth (to prevent toxic shock syndrome). In the European Union, tampons are regulated by the General Product Safety Directive. Manufacturers have to meet safety standards for raw materials and finished products, as well as provide comprehensive instructions for how to safely use tampons.

That said, no country requires a label with the complete list of product ingredients used to make tampons. It is possible for raw materials to be contaminated (i.e. cotton can be grown with pesticides) and there can be trace substances left behind after processing. For example, most tampons are bleached to make them absorbent and white. Chlorine dioxide can be toxic in large quantities but it’s considered safe in small doses. In fact, it’s regularly (and safely) used to bleach things we ingest all the time, like flour and drinking water.

All in all, studies have found that the quantities of any potentially hazardous materials in tampons are too low to pose a health risk, but if you’re worried about ingredients like chlorine, you can always buy chlorine-free tampons which are unbleached and just as absorbent. There are also bills in the works and independent agencies calling for full ingredient disclosure, so stay tuned for more transparency coming soon!

“If used correctly, there isn’t evidence that tampons can cause harm,” Russell says. “That said, there also hasn’t been much research on tampon safety or the effects of long-term use. What we do know is that the materials that were once related to toxic shock syndrome are no longer used in tampons today.”
Toxic shock syndrome
You’ve probably seen toxic shock syndrome warning labels on your box of tampons, but may not know exactly what it is or how to stay safe—here’s a quick lesson.

“Our vaginas naturally have bacteria and our bodies regulate this bacteria, making sure that the levels stay balanced,” Russell says. “Some of us also have a specific strain of bacteria in our vaginas called Staphylococcus aureus—it’s perfectly normal and healthy, unless too much of it grows. When the levels of this bacteria become too high, it can produce a toxin which can cause toxic shock syndrome (TSS).”

In the 1970s and 1980s, certain materials used in superabsorbent tampons accidentally created an ideal environment for this Staph bacteria to grow, leading to a rise in TSS cases. Once researchers found the source, these materials were banned and are no longer in tampons today. According to a study published in 2019, the rate of TSS is 0.8 to 3.4 per 100,000 women in the United States (which is very low) and less than half of these cases are related to tampons.

While TSS has become rare, it is very serious and life-threatening if it isn’t treated right away. TSS can lead to septic shock, organ failure, and can be fatal in up to 50% of cases according to the U.S. National Library of Medicine.
If you notice any of these symptoms while using tampons, let your doctor or
a Maven provider
know immediately:
Headache
Sudden high fever
Diarrhea
Nausea and vomiting
Confusion
Muscle ache
Fainting, lightheadedness, or dizziness
Seizures
Widespread sunburn-like rash
Safety guidelines

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, at least 40% of menstrual TSS cases affect the 13 to 19 year-old age group that may not be as educated on how to safely use a tampon. To lower your risk of TSS, always follow these guidelines for safe tampon use:
Use the lowest absorbent tampon needed (i.e. don’t use a super plus tampon on a light day)
Change your tampon every 4-6 hours (never leave in for longer than 8 hours)
Wear pads overnight instead of tampons if you will be sleeping longer than 8 hours
Don’t use tampons when you don’t have your period
Avoid scented tampons
Tampon myths debunked
And in case you were wondering...
Can my tampon fall out?
“A tampon put in properly won’t fall out,” Russell says. “If you can feel it when you walk, it may not be in high enough.”
Can my tampon get lost in my body?

“No, tampons cannot get lost in your body,” Russell says, “The muscles of your vagina keep them in place without you even knowing (or feeling) it. You can think of your vagina as a pocket. There’s only one way out!”
Sources
U.S. Food & Drug Administration
U.S. National Library of Medicine
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Harvard Library
AHPMA
European Parliament
European Chemicals Agency

title.en-US: What everyone should know about PCOS

content.value: Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is a common condition, affecting 6-12% of women, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In the U.S. alone, that’s as many as 5 million people. But as common as it is, the exact causes of PCOS aren’t completely understood—and the symptoms can be hard to spot. In fact, many people with PCOS don’t learn they have it until they have trouble conceiving. We spoke with Maven OB-GYN Scott Osmun, MD, to learn what to watch for.
What is PCOS?

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is a condition where instead of an egg being made and released every month as part of a normal menstrual cycle, the egg doesn’t grow properly or isn’t released so you don’t ovulate regularly.
What causes it?
While common, the exact cause of PCOS isn’t entirely understood. Most experts believe that there are several causes.
PCOS may be caused by:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
What are the symptoms?
If you have any of the following symptoms, be sure to tell your doctor so you can talk about whether they’re signs you could have PCOS.
These are some common symptoms of PCOS:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
How is it diagnosed?

“Currently, there’s no diagnostic test for PCOS, which can be frustrating to those who may be suffering from it and often, they go undiagnosed as a result,” Osmun says. “That’s why it’s extremely important to know the symptoms and to tell your doctor if you’re experiencing them.”

To diagnose PCOS, your doctor will likely ask about symptoms and perform a visual exam. If any symptoms are present, they’ll likely proceed with further testing, such as a pelvic exam. If all other conditions have been ruled out and there are 2-3 symptoms confirmed from this testing, you may be diagnosed with PCOS.
Steps your doctor may take to diagnose PCOS:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Are there health conditions that increase my risk?
“PCOS can happen to anyone, however, you may be at a higher risk if you’re overweight, obese, or if you have family members with PCOS—specifically your mother, sister, or aunt,” Osmun says.
Does having PCOS put me at risk for other issues?

When left unmanaged, PCOS can also increase your risk of other health conditions, so it’s important to seek treatment. While these conditions may not be directly caused by PCOS, they are commonly seen together.
Other conditions that may be linked to PCOS:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Can it affect my fertility?

PCOS is one of the most common causes of female infertility, according to the National Institutes of Health, but that doesn’t mean that you can’t become pregnant and have a healthy pregnancy if you have PCOS. “Basically, PCOS affects ovulation and if you don’t ovulate regularly, it makes it difficult to become pregnant,” Osmun says. “But there are ways to help regulate your cycle if you have PCOS and your doctor may prescribe one of a few different medications to help you ovulate. If this doesn’t work, people with PCOS can often successfully become pregnant through in vitro fertilization (IVF).”
What are the treatment options?
There isn’t a cure for PCOS, but your doctor or a
Maven OB-GYN

can help you manage it and curb long term side effects. “Your doctor will talk to you about your overall health and your plans for the future,” Osmun says. “If you’re at risk of other health conditions like diabetes, obesity, or heart disease, adopting healthy eating habits and exercising can actually help your body use insulin more effectively and even help regulate your period. Hormonal birth control can also help regulate your cycle, lower your risk of endometrial cancer, and reduce the common PCOS side effect of acne. If you’d like to have children someday, your doctor can help you take extra steps to maintain your health and increase your odds of conceiving.”
The bottom line:

PCOS is quite common, but far too many people go without help managing the symptoms because it can be so hard to diagnose. Get to know the symptoms and keep track of them in a notebook or on your phone, including tracking your periods. Sharing this information with your doctor can help them make a diagnosis, and help you get the support you need to manage PCOS and stay healthy.
Sources
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
NHS
Mayo Clinic
National Institutes of Health

People with PCOS tend to have more androgens, or male hormones related to the development of male traits. “Women naturally have androgens but when they’re at higher-than-usual levels, they can lead to hair growth on your face, chin, or chest, moderate to severe acne, and also prevent ovulation,” Osmun says.

People with PCOS also tend to be insulin resistant. “Insulin is a hormone that controls how we turn food into energy,” Osmun says. “When you’re insulin resistant, your body doesn’t respond normally to insulin which can lead to increased levels, especially if the person is overweight, obese, or has type 2 diabetes. We believe that this can contribute to PCOS.”
“Some research suggests that PCOS is linked to certain genes,” Osmun says. “It’s also more common to have PCOS if a close female relative has it as well.”
PCOS can cause your periods to happen more frequently, less frequently, or go away altogether.

About 70% of the time, people with PCOS grow hair on the face, chin, or other areas where it’s not typical, according to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. While PCOS can cause hair growth in uncommon places, it can also cause hair loss on the scalp—including thinning hair or a receding hairline.
PCOS can cause acne on the face, upper back, and chest.
Skin may be noticeably darker under the breasts, in the neck area, or in the pelvic area. You may also notice small flaps of skin (called “skin tags”) around the neck or armpits.
PCOS can lead to weight gain or make it difficult to lose weight.

items.header: Step #1: Ask about your medical history

content.value: Including whether or not you have irregular periods, skipped periods, or have experienced sudden weight gain.
Your doctor will look for outward symptoms of PCOS such as acne, dark skin patches or tags, or excessive hair growth.

They may perform a pelvic exam to check for any growths or abnormalities of the reproductive organs which may be causing abnormal bleeding (such as polyps) or a large ovarian mass that could be releasing testosterone.
They’ll test for higher than normal androgen hormone levels.
They may perform an ultrasound to check for polycystic ovaries (which tend to have a “string of pearls appearance” when the eggs don’t ovulate).
According to a 2007 study in
Clinical Obstetrics and Gynecology,
more than 50% of women with PCOS develop prediabetes or diabetes.
PCOS is linked to higher levels of bad cholesterol (LDL) and high blood pressure, which can increase the risk of heart disease and stroke.
Women with PCOS commonly suffer from depression and anxiety, although the link between them is unknown.
Women with PCOS, specifically those with obesity, are at increased risk of endometrial cancer (cancer in the lining of the uterus or womb).

title.en-US: What everyone should know about breast cancer

content.value: When was the last time you had a breast exam? If you’re drawing a blank, it may be a good idea to start making it a habit. Breast cancer is the most common cancer for women worldwide, affecting as many as 1 in 8 according to the World Cancer Research Fund (WCRF). Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, MD, explains what you need to know about breast cancer and the preventative measures we should all take to stay healthy and safe.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Sources
World Cancer Research Fund International
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
National Breast Cancer Foundation, Inc
American Cancer Society
JAMA Network

Breast cancer is when the cells in the breast tissue grow abnormally and the excess cells cause tissue masses (or tumors) to develop. “If our bodies are functioning normally, old cells die off and new ones develop in their place,” Stone says. “When someone has cancer of any kind, this process isn’t working properly. Instead of the old cells dying off, they keep growing, forming abnormal cells at an uncontrollable rate.”

In most cases of breast cancer, carcinomas are the cause. Carcinomas are a type of cancer that begin in the cells of the skin or tissue lining. Breasts are made up mainly of fat, glandular tissue, connective tissue and ducts. With breast cancer, abnormal and rapid cell growth occurs in the breast tissue, leading to masses or lumps and can spread to other parts of the body through blood vessels and lymph vessels. Breast cancer most commonly develops in the epithelial tissue that lines the breast ducts (the intricate pathways where milk travels to the nipple when breastfeeding).

Hormones play a big role in breast cancer. The tissue in our breasts respond directly to our hormones, which is why they get tender or swollen before your period, for example. Cancer cells can be receptive to the hormones that our bodies naturally produce, such as estrogen and progesterone. In some instances the cancer cells can also produce their own hormones that stimulate tumor growth.

items.header: What causes breast cancer, and what doesn’t?

content.value: “The cause of breast cancer isn’t completely understood, but most researchers agree that it’s likely a complex interaction of several factors including genetic makeup and hormones, as well as lifestyle and environmental factors,” Stone says. “But if you’ve heard that antiperspirant, underwire bras, and coffee cause breast cancer, that’s highly unlikely.”

items.header: What are the risk factors for breast cancer?

content.value: Research has found that there are some factors that increase your chances of developing breast cancer. Some can be avoided, like drinking less alcohol, and others can’t, like genetics. That said, we know it can be scary and frustrating to hear, but some people without any known risks will still develop breast cancer, and some with many risk factors won’t. In fact, according to the National Breast Cancer Foundation, 60-70% of breast cancer patients have no known risk factors and only 30-40% do. “The main risk factors are age and sex, so even if you don’t have any others, you should familiarize yourself with your breasts and alert your doctor if you notice anything abnormal,” Stone says. Though guidelines vary a bit by organization, it’s generally recommended that you begin talking with your doctor about annual mammograms at age 40 and start getting them no later than age 50.
The top risk factors for breast cancer are:
- Being female
: Breast cancer can occur in men but it’s rare.
- Advanced age
: Most breast cancers are found in women who are age 55 and older.
Some additional risk factors include:
- Family history of breast cancer
: Having a first-degree relative with breast cancer (i.e., a mother or sister) can double your risk.
- Hereditary gene mutations:
Most commonly associated with BRCA1 and BRCA2
- Having had breast cancer before: In the same or other breast
- Having benign breast disease:
Such as fibroadenomas, ductal hyperplasia, and intraductal papillomas
- Having dense breast tissue
: Your doctor can help you determine if you have dense breast tissue (usually by performing a mammogram).
- Getting your period early
: Before the age of 12
- Going through menopause late
: After the age of 55
- Not having children
- First pregnancy after the age of 30
- Drinking alcohol
: Drinking even low levels of alcohol has been linked to breast cancer and the risk increases with the amount consumed.
- Being overweight or obese:
This one is tricky as studies have shown that after menopause this is a risk factor but before menopause, being overweight or obese can actually decrease your risk.
- Not being physically active
- Exposure to ionizing radiation
: From medical treatment to the chest such as X-rays
- Hormone therapy: Often administered after menopause
- Hormonal birth control:
Some studies have shown a slight increase in risk for those who use hormonal birth control.
- Being taller
: This may seem like an odd one, but several studies have found that height can increase the risk of breast cancer, though the reason is unclear.
Source: American Cancer Society
Cancer may not have any symptoms until it’s advanced, but there are some possible warning signs to be aware of, including:
A lump in the breast or armpits
Breast swellingIrritation or dimpling on the skin of the breast
Newly inverted nipple (when the nipple sinks inward instead of pointing outward)
