Red or flaky breast or nipple skin
Nipple discharge (other than breast milk)
A change in the size or shape of the breast
Pain in any area of the breast or nipple
Keep in mind that these symptoms can be related to other conditions so if you experience any of the above, tell your doctor so they can examine you.

items.header: What are the different stages of breast cancer?

content.value: Breast cancer is diagnosed according to stages. “The stages refer to the size of the tumors and the growth of the cancer, if it’s local (in one area) or has spread to other areas of the body,” Stone says.
Stage 0:
Limited to inside the milk duct
Non-invasive
Stage I:
Small tumors
Have either not spread to the lymph nodes or very limited spread
Stage II:
Larger than Stage I tumors
And/or have spread to nearby lymph nodes
Stage III:
Larger than Stage II tumors
And/or have spread to nearby tissue or nearby lymph nodes
Stage IV:
Tumors that have spread beyond the breast and nearby lymph nodes to other parts of the body (commonly the bones, liver, or lungs, sometimes the brain)
Source: American Cancer Society

“Catching breast cancer at its earliest stage provides the best possible outcomes,” Stone says. Survival rates for breast cancer vary widely, but thanks to access to medical care and better screening, as well as more awareness in general about breast cancer, survival rates have generally been improving.
According to WCFR, in many countries the 5-year survival rate for women who are diagnosed with breast cancer is:
Stage I/II
: 80-90% 5-year survival rate
Stage III/IV:
24% 5-year survival rate

items.header: What can I do to lower my risk?

content.value: While breast cancer can occur in individuals without risk factors, strong evidence has been found that being physically active and breastfeeding can both lower your risk. Though not as strong, there’s also some evidence that your risk of breast cancer can be lowered by eating healthy: specifically non-starchy vegetables (ex. asparagus, broccoli, cauliflower), foods with carotenoids (ex. carrots, oranges, tomatoes, spinach), and calcium-rich foods (cheese, yogurt, milk, dark leafy greens).

“There’s some evidence that decreasing red and processed meat and increasing fruits/vegetables, phytoestrogens (soy), or eating a Mediterranean diet can lower your risk for a number of health conditions, including breast cancer,” Stone says. “However the evidence isn't conclusive. That said, you can be a very healthy person and still get breast cancer due to genetics or other factors which aren’t entirely understood. So in addition to a healthy lifestyle, I recommend that you stay familiar with your breasts to note if anything changes.”

items.header: Can I be tested for breast cancer?

content.value: “You can be tested for genes associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome,” Stone says. “Discuss your family history with your doctor, particularly if you have a first or second degree family member with ovarian, fallopian tube, primary peritoneal, prostate, or pancreatic cancer; if you have a first or second degree family member who was diagnosed with breast cancer in both breasts or early onset breast cancer; or if you have multiple family members on the same side of the family with breast cancer.”

items.header: Should I perform self breast exams?

content.value: According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), self-breast examination is no longer recommended if you are low risk (see risk factors above). “I recommend breast self-awareness—know what your breasts generally feel like, and alert your provider if you feel something different,” Stone says.

While there’s no evidence that self-exams increase cancer diagnoses, it may be helpful for high-risk individuals to perform monthly checks to help them stay familiar with their breasts and spot changes early.
Here’s how to perform a self breast exam:
1. Stand in front of a mirror without wearing a top or bra
2. Start with a visual check
Inspect each breast for visible changes. This could be the size or shape, any new dimples or ridges or nipple inversion.
Perform this visual check with your hands at your sides, then arms lifted over your head, and then by lifting each breast individually.
3. Next, check with your hands
Perform this exam lying down and then standing up, starting with one side and then the other.
Lift your arm up and inspect your breast with your opposite hand.
Using the pads of your fingers, massage your breast in a spiral pattern beginning at the nipple and moving out.
Be sure to massage the top of the breast, near the breastbone, and near the armpits.
Squeeze your nipple lightly and make note of any discharge.

If you notice anything out of the ordinary, tell your doctor and make an appointment for an exam. “Keep in mind that breasts can be lumpy and bumpy naturally, and this often has nothing to do with cancer, but it’s always best to get it checked out just in case,” Stone says.

items.header: How often should I get a mammogram?

content.value: Because the recommendations vary, it’s best to ask your doctor about your personal risk. Here are some general guidelines according to ACOG:
Below age 40:
Mammograms are recommended every 1-2 years if you’re high risk
The decision to get a mammogram should be shared between doctor and patient
Most national professional societies recommend annual or once every other year mammograms if you are low-risk
After age 75:
Shared decision making is recommended regarding whether or not to continue screening

“There’s little evidence that clinical breast exams (at your doctor’s office) are helpful in addition to mammography for detection of breast cancer in average risk individuals, but it’s usually performed as part of a complete physical examination every 1-3 years for those age 25-39 and annually in those 40 and over and is recommended in higher risk individuals,” Stone says.

Treatment for breast cancer usually depends on the type of breast cancer and the stage. Your doctor will recommend the treatment options they believe will be most effective based on your condition. “If cancer is caught in a very early stage, removal of the cancerous tumor, called lumpectomy, can be curative,” Stone says. “Other times, removal of the entire breast, called mastectomy is necessary. These surgeries may be performed with or without chemotherapy or radiation to treat the cancer or prevent recurrence. Hormonal therapies are also often given depending on many factors to prevent recurrence. If the cancer has spread to distant organs (stage IV) chemotherapy or hormonal therapy is often used, but it can be difficult to cure.”

title.en-US: What to do if you have an unplanned pregnancy

content.value: If you’re pregnant and didn’t plan to be, know that you’re not alone and we’re here to support you.

Nearly half of all pregnancies are unintended according to the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention. Deciding what to do about an unplanned pregnancy is deeply personal, but that doesn’t mean you have to do it all on your own. Speak to a doctor or counselor in person or
video chat or message with a provider
on Maven for help talking through all of your options in a safe and supportive space.
Get to know your options:
Parenthood

If you’re ready to have a child, even if unplanned, you can choose to continue your pregnancy. “You’ll want to make an appointment for a prenatal checkup with your OB-GYN so they can confirm your pregnancy, approximate how far along you are, and provide advice on what you can do to ensure a healthy pregnancy,” says Maven OB-GYN Dr. Jackie Stone. “But even before that first prenatal appointment, there are three immediate steps you should take.”
If you choose to continue your pregnancy, you’ll want to do a few things right now:
Start a prenatal vitamin with at least 400 mcg of folic acid as soon as possible
Stop any drug use or alcohol consumption immediately

Consult your doctor or a Maven provider regarding the safety of any prescription medications you may be taking (prenatal vitamins are considered safe and available over-the-counter so no need to wait on those!).
If you’re considering parenthood but aren’t sure if it’s for you right now, here are a few questions to help you decide:
Will I have support as a parent—either from a partner, family, or friends?
How do I feel about being pregnant, giving birth, and raising a child?
How do I feel about placing a baby up for adoption?
How does choosing to have a baby affect my plans for the future?
Is anyone pressuring me to make or not make this choice?
Termination of pregnancy

A termination of pregnancy (also known as an abortion) is medication administered or a procedure performed by a doctor to end a pregnancy. Globally, 25% of all pregnancies ended in abortion in 2010-2014 according to the World Health Organization and as many as 1 in 4 people will have an abortion at some point in their life.

Terminating a pregnancy is a complex topic that many people have strong feelings about. We’re here to support you with trusted information and access to doctors who can answer any questions you may have.
About the procedure

Most abortions are performed within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy, but a later term abortion may be possible depending on the clinic and the laws of your particular state or country. “If you choose to have an abortion, it’s crucial to work with a licensed doctor to ensure a safe procedure,” Stone says.
Your doctor will perform an ultrasound to determine the gestational age.

Medication is most commonly used to terminate a pregnancy prior to 10-11 weeks gestation. You will be given one medication at the doctor’s office and then you will usually take the second one at home.
The medications will ripen your cervix and cause uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy.
You may experience cramping, some bleeding, and passing of tissue. Most can go back to their normal activities within a day or so.
Your doctor will perform a second ultrasound to ensure that the abortion is complete.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
An early-term surgical abortion involves having your cervix dilated with medication, followed by a procedure where a suction device is used to remove the pregnancy.

Late-term abortions are not common for unwanted pregnancies. This procedure is often reserved for pregnancies in which the mother's life is in danger or the fetus has a disease that's incompatible with life.
Laws and restrictions
The laws around abortion vary by state and by country, so get to know yours before you make any decisions.
Learn more: Is it legal for me to get an abortion and if so, where can I get an abortion?
Additionally, some insurance plans exclude elective abortions, so checking coverage is important.
Learn more: Navigating the financial side of abortion.
If you’re considering having an abortion, here are a few questions to help you decide:
How do I feel about having an abortion?
How does choosing to have an abortion affect my plans for the future?
Do I have strong personal or religious views about abortion?
Is anyone pressuring me to make or not make this choice?
Adoption

You can work with an adoption agency or attorney to place your child with a family after you give birth. If you decide to place your child for adoption, it’s important to do your research. “A good program will hold your hand through every step of the adoption process,” Maven Adoption Coach Megan Friend says. “Ask about the program’s process for screening adoptive families, if you will be able to choose the adoptive parents yourself, if you will have a relationship with the child or not, and if they offer counseling and support services to help you with this difficult decision before and after the child is placed.”

You can work directly with an adoption agency or attorney or a social worker who may have experience working with reputable agencies. Additionally, depending on state laws, the adoption agency or adoptive parents may be able to help with medical or living expenses during your pregnancy.
Types of adoption

There are open adoptions where you’re able to have some contact with the child throughout their life in the form of photos, updates and possibly visits, closed adoptions where there’s no contact, and semi-open adoptions where you can receive updates and pictures without direct contact. “In most situations, the birth parents choose the family that they want to place their child with and decide the level of contact they wish to have,” Friend says.
If you’re considering adoption, here are a few questions to help you decide:
How do I feel about adoption?
How do I feel about being pregnant and giving birth before adoption?
How does being pregnant now affect my future plans?
How does choosing adoption affect my plans for the future?
Do I have strong personal or religious views about adoption?
Is anyone pressuring me to make or not make this choice?
We’re here for you
If you’d like to speak to a doctor or a counselor to learn more,
message or video chat with any provider
on Maven from the privacy of your own home. We’re here to help.
Sources
Centers for Disease Control & Prevention
Center for Reproductive Rights
Planned Parenthood
World Health Organization

title.en-US: Your ultimate guide to egg freezing

content.value: Maybe you’ve read about it in the news or know someone (who knows someone) who’s done it—but the actual process of egg freezing may still feel like a bit of a mystery. We chatted with Maven Reproductive Endocrinologists Scott Morin, MD, Sam Najmabadi, MD, and Jonathan Kort, MD, to learn exactly what egg freezing is all about so you can decide if it’s the right move for future you.
Before: The facts you need to know before you freeze
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
During: The egg freezing procedure step by step
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
After: How to use your frozen eggs in the future
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
The bottom line:

Egg freezing is a big decision, but for some the peace of mind is worth it. Do your research and then do some soul (and bank-account) searching to decide what it would mean for you to make this investment in your future. If you have any questions at all,
talk to a Reproductive Endocrinologist
on Maven anytime you want! Need help finding a high-quality egg freezing clinic in your area? Just message your Maven Care Advocate for tips.
Sources
Reproductive Biomedicine Online

items.header: What are the possible benefits of freezing my eggs?

content.value: Like retirement savings or a 10-year plan, you can think of freezing your eggs as another way to plan ahead. Freezing your eggs gives you the option to use those eggs to try to become pregnant later in life. Because the quality and quantity of your eggs both decrease over time, freezing your eggs now, at a younger age, may give you access to more eggs of higher quality should you have trouble conceiving in the future.

items.header: What are the odds of successful pregnancy using frozen eggs?

content.value: “We usually tell patients to expect about 20% of frozen eggs to result in an embryo,” Najmabadi says. Keep in mind that success rates can vary widely but the key thing to remember is that every egg you freeze doesn’t necessarily have a 100% chance of leading to a baby. The live success rate completely depends on the individual, especially how old they were when they froze their eggs.

items.header: Is there an ideal age to freeze my eggs?

content.value: “The percentage of eggs that survive at every stage of the process will be higher for younger eggs,” Najmabadi says. “And embryos from younger eggs are more likely to lead to viable pregnancies.” Some data suggests that individuals who freeze 10 eggs at age 36 have anywhere from a 30 to 60% chance of having a baby with them. Those odds go up for individuals who are younger, but fall considerably with age. So the short answer may be: there’s no time like the present.

items.header: Will I have fewer eggs in the future if I freeze my eggs now?

content.value: There’s a common misconception that stimulation “uses up” your egg supply or diminishes your ovarian reserve, but that’s not the case. As part of your normal menstrual cycle, your ovaries produce many follicles each month and one matures into an egg that’s then released as part of ovulation and all of the others follicles die off. When you undergo the egg freezing process, the hormonal medication you take stimulates your ovaries to release multiple mature eggs in one cycle (instead of just the one). So rather than using up your supply, you’re actually using follicles that would have naturally died off otherwise.

items.header: Are there any risks of undergoing egg retrieval?

content.value: Like any surgical procedure, egg retrieval carries a small risk of bleeding, infection, and damage to the organs around the surgery site, and anesthesia always carries a low level of risk as well. But egg retrieval is generally low-risk, Morin says. “That said, the procedure does present certain risks for some patients, including those with bleeding disorders and severe asthma. Be sure to ask your specialist if you’re a good candidate based on your overall health.

”Additionally, OHSS is a condition where the ovaries become painful and swollen as a result of the excess hormones taken before egg retrieval. Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain could ensue, but these symptoms are usually mild and go away on their own within a week or sooner. Severe OHSS affects less than 1% of egg freezing patients, but it can be life threatening. It’s characterized by rapid weight gain, severe abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and blood clots. Alert your doctor right away if you experience any of these symptoms.

Your doctor will try to determine your sensitivity to hormones and risk of OHSS in advance by asking questions about your health before starting you on hormone injections and will tailor your medication protocol appropriately (people with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), for example, have a higher risk of OHSS). This is another reason why you’ll come in for regular checkups during the ovarian stimulation process. People who are at risk for OHSS, may receive an injection of a drug called Lupron instead of hCG during the stimulation phase. (Why doesn’t everyone get a Lupron trigger shot? While it reduces the chance of OHSS, it can also lead to fewer eggs retrieved and hamper the egg maturation process. So experts advise using it only when needed.)

items.header: Are frozen eggs more likely to carry birth defects?

content.value: You’re probably tired of hearing the answer, “there isn’t a lot of data,” but it’s the only honest response to many questions about egg freezing at this point. The good news is that based on the limited research that exists, it looks reassuring. One 2009 study looked at 936 children who were conceived from previously frozen eggs, and found that, “compared with birth defects occurring in naturally conceived infants, no difference was noted.”

items.header: How long are frozen eggs good for?

content.value: In some countries, the length of time eggs can be frozen is limited by law. In the U.K., for example there’s a 10-year limit (a law that some fertility experts are trying to change, arguing that technological advances now allow eggs to be frozen, potentially indefinitely, without being compromised.) In the U.S., there’s no such law.

Remember, frozen eggs don’t change over time. “When you thaw an egg that was frozen using vitrification, that egg doesn’t know whether it’s been frozen a second, or a year, or ten years,” Najmabadi says. But because vitrification technology is so new, there isn’t a lot of data about the absolute expiration date. However, studies have shown that healthy babies have been born from eggs that were frozen longer for than 10 years.

items.header: How much should I expect to pay?

content.value: A single round of egg freezing can cost anywhere between $5,000 to $11,000, plus the cost of medications (which can add another few thousand dollars to the bill) and annual storage fees, which can range from $300 to over $1,000 and aren’t based on how many eggs you bank. Why such a wide range? “Where you live could dictate how steep your bill is, especially when it comes to storage,” Kort says. New York City, for instance, is one of the priciest cities to store your eggs, with a price-tag of $1,100 per year, on average. If you live in San Francisco, on the other hand, an annual storage fee could be less than half of that amount.

Most patients have to pay out-of-pocket, but it’s still worth calling your health insurance provider to ask about your coverage. Some plans, for instance, cover the fertility consultations and diagnostic tests, even if they don’t foot the bill for the actual procedure. Make sure you understand exactly what’s included in your clinic’s quoted fee, and the factors that may affect your total bill. For example, “if your ovarian reserve is lower, you’ll likely need more drugs to get results,” Najmabadi says. If you’re older or have significant fertility issues, you may end up paying significantly more.

You can also always ask your clinic about ways to bring down costs; some offer financing plans where you get a deal if you prepay for a year or more of storage instead of making monthly payments, for example.

items.header: How safe are my eggs at a storage facility?

content.value: You’ve probably seen news headlines about reported mishaps at egg freezing clinics but these instances are rare, and any clinic worth using has an ironclad system of safeguards in place. “Your doctor should know how the system is monitored and take the time to explain it to you and answer any questions you have,” Kort says. “It should raise a red flag if your clinic doesn’t know the answers to your questions.”Here are a few questions you should ask when you’re evaluating potential clinics:- Has your facility had any issues with equipment failure in the past?- Can you explain your clinic’s safeguards that keep the eggs secure?- Does the equipment have independent alarm sensors and if so, who’s alerted when the alarm goes off? - How frequently are the nitrogen tanks checked?

items.header: What is the procedure for egg freezing?

content.value: 1. Screening and preparation: 1 to 4 weeks

Once you’ve found a clinic, you’ll have 1-2 initial appointments to check your overall and reproductive health, including assessing your current egg supply (or ovarian reserve). You’ll likely have some blood tests and a transvaginal ultrasound (that’s when an ultrasound wand is inserted into the vagina). This will help your doctor understand if you’re a good candidate for egg freezing and how much medication you may need to stimulate your ovaries.

You’ll also be required to get certain tests done before you can freeze your eggs—like a Pap smear, a TSH blood test (thyroid stimulating hormone), a CBC (complete blood count), and screenings for sexually transmitted infections (STIs). If you’ve already done these tests recently, you can bring the results with you and may not need to do them again.
2. Ovarian stimulation: Up to 2 weeks

Once you’ve completed all the testing and have the go-ahead, your doctor will likely wait for your period to begin before starting you on hormone medication. They may prescribe short-term birth control medication to help multiple follicles grow at the same rate (follicles are the sacs in your ovaries that contain eggs). Birth control can also help with timing your egg retrieval.

Once your period starts, you’ll be prescribed hormonal medication (this is often referred to as the stimming or stimulation phase). You’ll take a synthetic form of FSH (it’s based on a hormone our bodies naturally release) to encourage your ovaries to produce multiple eggs (instead of the one that typically gets released in a normal menstrual cycle); this helps ensure there are enough eggs to collect. In some patients, a combination of FSH and luteinizing hormone (LH) may be used. You’ll give yourself these hormones through self injections once or twice a day for about 10-12 days.

During this time, you’ll visit the clinic every 1-3 days for blood work and a vaginal ultrasound so your doctor can track how your ovaries are responding and dial your medication dosage up or down as needed. Depending on your body’s response to FSH, your doctor may use an “antagonist” medication (such as Ganirelix) halfway through your cycle to prevent your ovaries from releasing eggs too early. If needed, antagonist medications are typically injected daily for a few days leading up to the trigger shot.
3. Trigger shot: 36 hours

Once your eggs have matured, you’ll be given a final injection called a “trigger shot” that encourages your ovaries to release the eggs. This trigger shot is usually a synthetic form of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), the same hormone produced by your body during pregnancy. You’ll be ready for egg retrieval roughly 36 hours after the trigger shot is given.
4. Egg retrieval and freezing: 20 minutes

To retrieve your eggs, the doctor will use an ultrasound probe inserted into your vagina to see your ​ovaries and locate the follicles. A needle attached to the ultrasound probe punctures the follicles and gentle suction removes the egg-contained fluid from within (don’t worry, you’ll be under light sedation so you won’t feel this). The process takes about 20 minutes and right after your eggs are retrieved, they’re brought to the embryologist to be frozen and stored for future use. (You may feel groggy due to the sedation so clinics require that a designated driver takes you home.)
5. Recovery: Up to a week

Recovery time after the procedure is different for everyone. You can be back to normal as soon as the next day or take up to a week to feel 100%. You might experience cramping, bloating, and nausea and feel a bit tired for several days. k

items.header: Do I really have to give myself shots every day?

content.value: If you’re needle squeamish, it might put your mind at ease to know that the injections are subcutaneous—that means that the needle goes in a layer of fat just under the skin, not a muscle (it’s actually the same small needle that diabetics use to give themselves insulin). “At our clinic, we have fake skin that the patients learn on, and after sitting with the nurse for a 30-minute training session, the patient usually feels much more comfortable with the injection process,” Kort says. You can also enlist a friend’s help, or ask if you can visit the clinic daily for a nurse to give them to you.

items.header: Are there any side effects from the shots?

content.value: “Different people react differently to injections, but the most common symptoms are bloating and other PMS-like symptoms (think headaches, mood swings, tiredness, breast tenderness),” Morin says. “You may also have soreness or bruising around the injection site.”h

items.header: How many eggs will be retrieved?

content.value: “Unfortunately, the typical egg isn't capable of producing a viable pregnancy, so your doctor will attempt to retrieve as many as possible in a safe manner,” Morin says. “However, the number able to be retrieved varies quite a bit between individuals. Some might produce only 5 or 6 eggs, while others can produce 25 or more in a single cycle.”

Egg quality has a lot to do with fertility potential and because egg quality declines more rapidly with age, you can generally assume that the older you are, the more eggs will need to be retrieved to increase your odds of successfully conceiving later. (Keep in mind, this could mean having to do several rounds of egg freezing to achieve the recommended supply.)

items.header: What happens after the eggs are retrieved?

content.value: As soon as your eggs are collected they’ll go directly into an incubator where they’ll be inspected by an embryologist. Most clinics have in-house labs, so eggs are simply transferred from the operating room to the laboratory. The embryologist will strip your eggs of the surrounding cells to observe each egg closely and identify which ones are mature. This step is really important since only mature eggs have the potential to be fertilized. Usually, anywhere from 20 to 40% of the collected eggs aren’t fully mature and won’t be frozen; the rest will proceed on to cryopreservation (more on that next).

Cryopreservation is the technical term for egg freezing and huge strides have been made in the past decade in terms of the techniques used, especially with the introduction of vitrification (aka a “fast freeze”). “Eggs are tricky to freeze because they’re water-filled cells, and the previous method of slow-cooling made it possible for ice crystals to form. This would frequently damage the cells and rupture them,” Najmabadi says. With vitrification, eggs are first treated with high concentrations of cryoprotectants (aka anti-icing chemicals), then rapidly chilled by being plunged into liquid nitrogen. The result is that they’re much less likely to be damaged while being frozen. According to Najmabadi, vitrification is considered the “gold-standard” method for reputable egg freezing clinics.

items.header: When should I use my frozen eggs?

content.value: “Success rates depend on how old you were when you froze your eggs and how old you are when you chose to use them,” says Najmabadi. While the quality of eggs that you don’t freeze will decline with age, eggs that are frozen will remain the same quality they were at the time that they were frozen. For example, if you freeze your eggs at 30 and thaw them at 38, they’ll be higher quality than your current eggs. And that’s great news! That said, even if eggs are frozen in time, the body is not and age does increase the risk for certain pregnancy and delivery complications. Since every person is different, and may have unique personal risk factors, it’s a good idea to talk to an OB-GYN about a healthy age for you to become pregnant.

items.header: What happens when I'm ready to use my frozen eggs?

content.value: In the future, if you decide you want to try to have a baby with your frozen eggs, they’ll need to be removed from storage and thawed. It’s not as easy as taking something out of your kitchen freezer and letting it warm up though. Lab technicians move eggs through a number of steps that warm them up slowly and strip the cryoprotectants that were added when they were frozen. After the right temperature is reached, an egg is able to be fertilized using a form of in vitro fertilization (IVF) called intracytoplasmic sperm injection, or ICSI.

Sperm will be collected from your partner or a sperm donor. With ICSI, the sperm will be injected directly into the egg—this makes it easier to penetrate the egg’s membrane (which tends to harden during freezing). If fertilization occurs, a fertilized egg will develop into an embryo, which will be allowed to grow for approximately five days in a lab (at this point it’s called a blastocyst). It will then be transferred into your uterus and pregnancy happens if this embryo implants itself in the lining of your uterus.
In short: If all goes well, the egg is successfully fertilized in the lab, an embryo grows in a lab for about 5 days, it’s implanted in your womb and pregnancy occurs. Voila!

items.header: Can I transfer my eggs to a new storage facility if I move?

content.value: Yes. You’re not tied to one storage facility for your frozen eggs. Because the Federal Aviation Administration doesn’t allow liquid nitrogen to be shipped, the eggs are transported in a special container called a dry shipper, which keeps the contents sufficiently chilled while in transit. Some clinics handle the shipping logistics themselves, but if yours doesn’t, you can contact a company like Cryoport to make arrangements.

items.header: What happens to eggs that I don't use?

content.value: Frozen eggs that you don’t use will be discarded at your request. But if you’re not comfortable with your remaining eggs being discarded, one option is to donate them to research. You can also donate your eggs to a specific person, like someone you know who is undergoing IVF. However, you can’t sell them to an egg bank because egg donation is highly regulated by the FDA and there are separate screenings you would have to go through before freezing your eggs in order to be cleared.

title.en-US: These resources can help you get your finances in shape

content.value: If you feel like you don’t know what you’re doing when it comes to managing your money, you’re not alone. After all, they don’t teach personal finance in school. (We’ll save the question of why they don’t teach personal finance in school for another time.)

If you’ve decided that now is the time to make your money work for you, here are five reliable resources that will help you address every aspect of your financial life, from budgeting to credit to investing.
YNAB (You Need a Budget)

You can’t take charge of your finances without understanding your cash flow—aka how much money is coming in and how much is going out. If you’re not currently tracking your spending or setting a monthly budget, take some time to calculate your total income, add up all your fixed expenses, like rent, health insurance, a car payment, and utilities, and see what’s left. Then spend some time thinking about your goals for the future, and what you’d ideally like your finances to look like.
That’s when
YNAB

comes in. YNAB (You Need a Budget) is a favorite among personal finance experts. It’s a combination of budgeting software and a set of rules that can help you think smarter about spending and budgeting. Those rules are:
Give every dollar a job, meaning as soon as you get paid, be thoughtful about where that money is going to go instead of spending it impulsively.
Embrace your true expenses, meaning put money aside monthly for large, infrequent or unexpected expenses.
Roll with the punches, meaning if you spend too much on something, don’t beat yourself up about it and just try to do better next month.
Age your money, meaning you should be spending last month’s cash on this month’s needs and wants.
YNAB can help you figure out where you’re spending more than you’d like to and reassign that money toward your goals.
The National Foundation for Credit Counseling
If you’re significantly in debt, be it from credit cards, medical bills, or student loans, the
National Foundation for Credit Counseling
can help you set up a debt management plan to get you out of the red for good.

The experts there can help you consolidate your debt into a single monthly payment, lower your interest rates and manage calls and letters from creditors. Their financial coaches can also help you set goals for the future and give you the strategies you need to get there.
Personal Capital

You may be saving for retirement in an IRA at one financial institution, have 401(k)s from various jobs at other institutions, plus have credit cards from two banks, neither of which are the bank where you keep your checking and savings accounts. With all your money spread out like that, it can feel impossible to keep track of it all.
Personal Capital

is a desktop and mobile app that solves this issue. You can sync your checking account, savings account, credit cards, retirement accounts, investment accounts, student loans, mortgage, you name it—all in one place. That way, you can get a clear picture of your financial situation all at one.
The app helps you track your net worth and cash flow, keep an eye on your investments, and stay on track for retirement with charts and graphs.
Credit Karma
Credit Karma
helps you get a handle on your credit by tracking your credit score and alerting you when there’s a change in your credit reports (which could mean identity theft!).
The site also has a wealth of resources that can help you understand why your score is what it is, how to improve it, and why putting effort into improving your score is worth it.

If you’re planning on buying a home, getting a new rewards credit card, or taking out a loan to start a business, understanding your credit profile inside and out is absolutely crucial. But Credit Karma is a great resource for anyone who’s trying to take control of their financial life, no matter how big or small your money goals are.
A robo advisor
If you want to invest your money for retirement and other future goals but don’t know where to start, a robo advisor like
Betterment
Wealthfront
or
Ellevest
could be a great choice for you.
Here’s how it works:
You answer a bunch of up-front questions about your financial situation and your savings and investing goals.
The robo advisor, using an algorithm, invests your money in the market according to your goals and your tolerance for risk, or your ability to remain calm and wait out the fluctuations of the market.
You sit back and relax, making changes manually if you’d like to.

Many robo advisors offer goal-setting options, charts and graphs of your progress, and supplementary articles that can help you build your investing knowledge. They also charge a significantly lower fee than a human financial advisor would. For example, both Betterment and Wealthfront charge .25% of the assets you invest with them per year for their services, while a traditional financial advisor generally charges about 1%.

title.en-US: The easy way to predict your period

content.value: If you feel like your period is that friend who always shows up unannounced, we’re here to help. Period tracking is actually a lot easier than it looks and can help put you in control of protecting yourself. It’s especially helpful when you’re trying to plan a trip, a date, or if you want to become pregnant. We chatted with Maven OB-GYN Carol Russell, DO, to learn the best way to do it.
How to track your cycle
Step 1: Learn

If you know the gist of what happens during your period, but maybe not all the details, you’re not alone. “While every person is different, there are the steps that our bodies go through during our menstrual cycle,” Russell says. “This is based on an average 28-day cycle. If your cycle tends to be a little shorter or longer than that, that’s totally normal. You’ll still go through these same general steps.”
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Step 2: Record

Because everyone is different, it’s important to get to know the pattern of your period. Use an app, memos, or jot it on a calendar—whatever is easiest to remember. “Start recording the first day your period begins each month for at least 6 months,” Russell says. “Recording it for 12 months is even better as the more information you have, the easier it will be to find a pattern. It’s also useful to share this info with your gynecologist.”
Step 3: Calculate

Once you have 6-12 months recorded, it’s time to do some math! Look at the month you began recording and find the first day your period started. Now count how many days there are until the first day of your next period. Jot that number down and keep recording the number of days between periods until you have the whole set.
Here’s an example chart to help you:
REPLACEWITHASSET
To find your average cycle length, add up all the numbers in the “Days between cycles” column and divide by the total number of cycles you recorded.
Example:
29 days + 32 days + 30 days + 28 days + 29 days = 148
This is 5 cycles recorded so 148 divided by 5 is 29.6. That’s the average number of days between cycles.
Step 4: Plan

Now that you know the average number of days between your menstrual cycles, you can plan around it! Mark the week your period is likely to fall and pad with a couple of days on either end as well to be safe. Then book that tropical vacation, set that date, and take control over your calendar.
Some other helpful tips
Use birth control to regulate (or skip) your period
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf your period is irregular or you’d like the option to skip it on occasion, hormonal birth control can help. Ask your OB-GYN or a
Maven OB-GYN
for help deciding on the best method for you. (And don't miss our Related Reads below for more info!)
Get to know your cervical mucus

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKHear us out. Our vaginas naturally make cervical mucus—the sticky substance you see when you wipe or on your underwear sometimes. The texture changes throughout the month and is thinnest but the most abundant when you’re close to ovulating. To test it, using two clean fingers swipe your vagina. If the mucus is clear and sticky, stretching as you pull your fingers apart, and resembles the consistency of egg whites, you may be ovulating or near ovulation. This is a helpful hint that your period is about two weeks away.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Use an app

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThere are many period trackers available for free on your smartphone. Ask around to see which ones your friends like and try them out. Some can even help you manage period symptoms like headaches and PMS.
Day 1: Period starts
Most menstrual periods last 4-8 days.
Days 5-8: New egg grows
Follicles begin to grow in your ovaries. One will continue to grow and become an egg while the others will be reabsorbed.
Days 8-11: Lining thickens
Hormones rise and your uterine lining thickens.
Days 11-14: Egg is released

A single egg is released from your ovary (this is called ovulation) and lives for 12-24 hours. You’re most likely to become pregnant if you have sex during ovulation and the 4-5 days prior. This is called the “fertile window.”
Days 14-24: Egg travels

The egg makes its way down your fallopian tube. If sperm reaches the egg in the fallopian tube it can become fertilized and travel to your uterus where it will attach and grow (the official start of pregnancy).
Days 24-28: Egg breaks down
If the egg is unfertilized, it will now break apart. The unfertilized egg and uterine lining leave your body—this is your period (or menstruation).

title.en-US: How to safely skip your period

content.value: Have you ever felt like your period is just waiting to ruin your plans? Period right in the middle of your beach vacation. Period the first time you try those new white jeans. Period on a date, or on your wedding day. We know the feeling. If you’ve ever wanted to have more control over your period, we talked to Maven OB-GYN Carol Russell, DO, for step-by-step instructions on how to safely skip it for special occasions.
Is it safe to skip your period?

“Yes,” Russell says. “There isn’t any data that shows it’s biologically necessary to have your period every month. That said, I usually advise patients not to skip too many cycles in a row because it seems to increase the risk of breakthrough bleeding, which is unpredictable (and can be annoying). My general advice is to get yourself into a pattern of having a period every other month to every 3 months, or just skipping a cycle once in a while as needed to accommodate your plans.”
How do you do it?
Skipping your period is easy to do with hormonal birth control, here’s how:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Are there any benefits to skipping my period?

“Skipping your period can help you manage many of the bothersome symptoms associated with having your period,” Russell says. “For example, if you have heavy periods, skipping gives your body a chance to recover from iron-deficient anemia. If you have headaches prior to or during your periods, skipping can give you a break from that as well.”
Will there be any side effects?

You may have some spotting the first few times you delay your period. But as your body adjusts, this tends to go away. Another potential downside to skipping your period is that it can be harder to tell if you’re pregnant (because a missed period is often the first sign).
Will skipping my period affect my fertility (now or in the future)?

Nope! Occasionally skipping your period will not affect your fertility. However, your fertility can be temporarily affected by certain birth control methods. “With birth control pills, patches or rings, once you stop using them, your fertility returns to normal—meaning you should expect to ovulate within 2-4 weeks,” Russell says. “Similarly, when an IUD is removed, you’re fertile again right away. Depo-Provera is the only method with a long delay in the return of your fertility. Depending on how long you’ve used Depo-Provera the return of your fertility can be 6-9 months.”
Sources
Mayo Clinic
Use a pill with both estrogen and progestin in it (these are called “combination pills”).

You would normally take 21 pills with hormones in them and 7 without (getting your period somewhere in these 7 days “off”). To skip your period occasionally, simply skip the 7 reminder pills and move immediately on to your next pack.
When you want to have your period again, just return to your usual routine of taking 7 days off the pills.
There are also specific birth control pills that are designed to take continuously, so talk to your doctor or
video chat with a Maven OB-GYN
if you’d like to regularly skip your period.
Hormonal IUDs reduce your period over time and getting a high-dose IUD can help stop your period altogether (though it can take a few years to stop it completely).
It’s important to note that copper IUDs might increase bleeding in some people. It’s safe for most people to skip their period altogether, but you always want to talk to your doctor or
video chat with a Maven OB-GYN
first to be sure it’s safe for you.
To skip your period, instead of removing the ring once a month and leaving it out for 1 week, simply replace with a new ring.
Want to get back to your normal period cycle? Just return to regular use, removing the ring once a month for 7 days (you will get your period then).
Instead of going patch-free for one week every month, just put a new patch on every week to skip your period for that month.
When you want your period to return, get back on the recommended schedule of three weeks wearing a patch and one week without a patch.
The depo shot can reduce your period or eliminate it altogether over time. All you have to do is get it quarterly. The longer you use it, the more likely this is.

title.en-US: The difference between hyper- and hypothyroidism

content.value: At the base of our neck, just above our collarbone, we all have a tiny butterfly-shaped gland called a thyroid gland. It plays a big part in regulating our metabolism and vital body functions including how we process fats and carbohydrates, the amount of calcium in our blood, our body temperature—it even affects how fast or slow our heart beats. Our thyroid does all this and more by releasing hormones, but sometimes these hormones fall out of balance and can cause conditions known as hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism. Maven Advanced Practice Registered Nurse Michelle Thomas explains the difference and the symptoms.
Hyperthyroidism vs hypothyroidism—the short version
A good word trick that can help you remember the difference between hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism is in the prefix of these words: hyper and hypo. “Hyper” means above and “hypo” means below.

“When we say someone is “hyper” we usually mean that they’re overactive,” Thomas says. “Same goes with hyperthyroidism. It means that someone has a thyroid gland that is overactive or that the hormones it’s releasing are “above” normal levels. Whereas when someone has hypothyroidism, that means their thyroid is underactive, or that the hormone levels are below normal.”
The basics on hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid)

Hyperthyroidism is when your thyroid gland makes too much thyroxine, a hormone that helps control your metabolism. “The symptoms of hyperthyroidism show up the way you might imagine a ‘hyperactive’ metabolism might look,” Thomas says. “It can make it difficult to maintain your weight, often causing sudden weight loss. It can also cause your heart to beat very quickly. You may feel anxious or have trouble sleeping. You may also sweat frequently or overheat more easily.”

“If untreated, hyperthyroidism can become serious,” Thomas says. “It can cause heart problems, brittle bones, and vision issues including bulging or swollen eyes. So, if you’re having any of the below symptoms, tell your doctor so you can get care.”
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
The basics on hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid)

In the case of hypothyroidism, your thyroid gland doesn’t make enough of the hormones needed to maintain your metabolism. “The symptoms of hypothyroidism often develop very slowly so they can be hard to detect,” Thomas says. “It can start with a sense of tiredness or weight gain, for example, which you may attribute to other things like stress. But over time, as your metabolism continues to slow down, it can lead to more serious conditions. If untreated, hypothyroidism can lead to obesity, heart disease, infertility as well as other health problems.”
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Sources
Mayo Clinic: Hyperthyroidism
Mayo Clinic: Hypothyroidism
Sometimes there are no symptoms or they’re too subtle to notice, but common symptoms include:
Weight loss
Rapid heartbeat
Irregular heartbeat
Increase in appetite
Anxiety or irritability
Tremors in the hands or fingers
Sweating
More frequent bowel movements
Overheating
Irregular periods
Fatigue
Trouble sleeping
Brittle hair and hair loss
An enlarged thyroid gland (this can look like swelling at the bottom of your neck)

“In rare cases, you may experience thyrotoxic crisis,” Thomas says. “This is when the above symptoms of hyperthyroidism suddenly ramp up and become extreme. If you experience a high fever or rapid heart rate, seek care immediately.”
Hyperthyroidism can be caused by other conditions, including:
Graves’ disease: An autoimmune disorder and the most common cause of hyperthyroidism.
Hyperfunctioning thyroid nodules: A condition where your adenomas produce too much thyroxine.
Thyroiditis: Inflammation of the thyroid gland that sometimes occurs after pregnancy.
While anyone can get hyperthyroidism, you may be more at risk if:
You have a family member with hyperthyroidism
You’re female
You have an autoimmune disease (such as type 1 diabetes, Graves’ Disease, or Hashimoto Thyroiditis)

“Your doctor will look for physical symptoms, including moist skin, eye changes, reflexes as well as look for a tremor in your hands or fingers,” Thomas says. “Then they’ll perform a blood test to measure hormone levels. If this is high, it may be a sign of hyperthyroidism and your doctor may order additional tests to confirm such as an iodine test or an ultrasound.”

“Hyperthyroidism can be treated and it’s essential to seek care to make sure this condition is managed and doesn’t become more serious,” Thomas says. Depending on your health and the severity of your symptoms, your doctor may recommend a few types of treatment including:
Radioactive iodine: This can help shrink the thyroid gland and help alleviate symptoms.
Anti-thyroid medication: Can help your thyroid gland stop producing excess hormones.
Beta blockers: Can help ease symptoms while undergoing other treatment, but doesn’t treat thyroid levels.
Surgery: In rare cases removing part of the thyroid gland is recommended.
Your symptoms can depend on how imbalanced your hormone levels are and become more severe over time as your levels continue to drop. Common symptoms include:
Fatigue
Weight gain
Constipation
Feeling cold
Dry skin
Slow heart rate
Feeling physically weak
Depression
Muscle aches
Painful, stiff, or swollen joints
Heavy or irregular periods
High blood cholesterol
Thinning hair
An enlarged thyroid gland (this can look like swelling at the bottom of your neck)
Hyperthyroidism can be caused by a number of different conditions including:

Autoimmune disease: "This is the most common cause of hypothyroidism,” Thomas says. “When you have an autoimmune disorder it can trigger your body to essentially attack itself by producing antibodies. These antibodies can sometimes attack your thyroid gland.”

Hyperthyroid treatment or surgery: Medication for hyperthyroidism can sometimes lower hormone production too much and cause hypothyroidism. If you’ve had surgery for hyperthyroidism, where a part or all of your thyroid gland were removed, this can also cause hypothyroidism.
Radiation: Radiation used in treatment for cancers in the head or neck may affect your thyroid gland and cause hypothyroidism.
Certain medications: Some medications can impact the hormones produced by your thyroid gland.

“It’s less common, but also possible to be born with hypothyroidism if the thyroid gland did not develop properly in the womb,” Thomas says. “It’s also possible to develop hypothyroidism during or shortly after pregnancy as a result of antibodies.”
Anyone can develop hypothyroidism, but you may be more at risk if:
You have a family member with hypothyroidism
You’re female
You’re over 50 years old
You are pregnant or had a baby in the last 6 months

“Your doctor will ask about your energy levels, if you’ve noticed weight gain, constipation or other physical symptoms,” Thomas says. “Based on this information, they’ll perform a blood test to measure your hormone levels. Sometimes our pituitary gland will produce more hormones to try to stimulate our thyroid gland, so it’s common to test for this hormone called TSH (thyroid stimulating hormone).

The most common treatment for hypothyroidism is oral medication to replace the hormones that your body is lacking. Your doctor will likely recommend a daily dosage of a synthetic form of the hormone your thyroid makes called levothyroxine. “It’s important to note that this medication should be taken on an empty stomach and you shouldn’t eat for 30 minutes after taking it for it to work properly,” Thomas says.

“The great news is that medication for hypothyroidism is fast-acting and can help alleviate symptoms, including weight gain, quickly,” Thomas says. You may need to take medication for hypothyroidism continuously to regulate your hormone levels and get regular checkups to make sure you’re taking the right dosage.

title.en-US: The Maven guide to periods

content.value: Ever wonder how many periods you’ll have in a lifetime? The answer is about 450. And while this number may seem shocking, what’s more surprising is how little most of us know about this mysterious thing that happens every month—and just how much it can be an indicator of our overall health. If the details of your menstrual cycle are a bit fuzzy, consider this your crash course with help from Maven OB-GYN Dr. Carol Russell.
What your period really is

Your period can go by a few names: menstruation (the sciencey term) or simply bleeding. But it’s actually more than just blood. “The proper term is ‘menstrual fluid’ because it actually contains blood, secretion, tissue, and cervical mucus,” Russell says. “Basically, about 2 weeks after your ovulate and don’t conceive a pregnancy, your uterine lining breaks down and leaves your body—this is your menstrual fluid or your period. This happens about once a month and marks the beginning of your menstrual cycle.”
The steps of your menstrual cycle
“Everyone's a little different—some have longer or shorter cycles—but these are the general steps your body goes through during an average 28-day menstrual cycle,” Russell says.
Average cycle steps:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
What your period color means

Throughout your menstrual cycle, you may notice that the color of your period changes. Some days it’s bright red, others it’s dark brown. “Varying shades of period blood is totally normal,” Russell says. “It changes based on the different stages of your cycle, how fast it’s flowing, and how much time it’s spent in your uterus. For example, you may notice that your period is darkest in the mornings, because it hasn’t been flowing out as much while you’re lying down.”
Here’s a quick color breakdown:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Learn more about what your period color means
How to predict your period

The best way to predict your period is to track it. Follow the steps below to get started. “I recommend recording when your period starts for 6-12 months and then going over that information with your OB-GYN or a
Maven OB-GYN
,” Russell says. “They can help you determine if there are any issues with your cycle.”
Mark the first day of your period on a calendar or period tracking app
Do this for 6-12 months
Then count the days between each mark (this is your cycle length)
Find your average cycle by adding them all together and then dividing by how many months you tracked for
Use this average to predict the time frame for your next period
Learn more about period tracking
How to safely skip your period

If your period has ever ruined your best laid plans, you’ll be happy to know that it’s safe to skip your period using hormonal birth control. Follow the link below to learn how to do this based on the kind of birth control you’re using.

“There isn’t any research that proves it’s necessary to have your period every month,” Russell says. “When you need to, you can use hormonal birth control to skip it by just starting your new birth control right away instead of taking a week off (depending on the form of birth control you take).”

Keep in mind that skipping your period can cause breakthrough bleeding, but this usually resolves over time. While it is generally safe to use hormonal birth control to skip your period, it’s best to talk to your doctor first.
Steps to safely skip your period
Period issues
If your period is more than just inconvenient and causes you pain, prevents you from daily activities, or is irregular, it’s always best to speak with your doctor or a
Maven OB-GYN
. There’s likely a solution that can make your period much more manageable.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Period gear
Part of having a period is figuring out the protection that’s going to work best for you. Learn more about tried-and-trues and new gear that’s quickly becoming a period go-to.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
The bottom line:
There’s a lot to know about our periods and you aren’t alone if you learned a thing or two just by reading this. By tracking your period and sharing this information with your OB-GYN or an
OB-GYN on Maven

, you can learn more about your cycle and get advice on how to make it less of a monthly pain and more of a manageable part of your life (remember, you may have 450 of them over the course of your lifetime, so it’s worth it!).
Most menstrual periods last 4-7 days.
Follicles begin to grow in your ovaries. One will continue to grow and become an egg while the others will be reabsorbed.
Hormones rise and your uterine lining thickens.

A single egg is released from your ovary (this is called ovulation) and lives for 12-24 hours. You’re most likely to become pregnant if you have sex during this time compared to other days of your cycle.

The egg makes its way down your fallopian tube. If sperm reaches the egg in the fallopian tube it can become fertilized and travel to your uterus where it will attach and grow (the official start of pregnancy).
If the egg is unfertilized, it will now break apart. The unfertilized egg and uterine lining leave your body—this is your period (or menstruation).

This color usually appears between periods when it’s mostly cervical fluid. “While pink spotting is usually normal, if you notice pink spotting for more than 1 day a month for 3 months in a row, tell your doctor,” Russell says.
You’ll usually notice this color at the beginning of your period or heaviest days.
This hue normally appears in the mornings or heaviest days when menstrual fluid isn’t flowing quickly.
Menstrual fluid can appear brown at the beginning or end of your period when it isn’t flowing quickly.
Gray is not okay. “If you have gray or off-white discharge, especially with an odor or itching it’s best to call your doctor or
speak to a Maven provider,
” Russell says. “Gray discharge can be associated with infection.”

The average menstrual cycle is 28 days long. “Unless you’re on hormonal birth control, it’s unlikely that your cycle is this spot-on, but it should be within this range, give or take a week,” Russell says. “If it’s much shorter or much longer than 28 days, if you skip months or have multiple periods in a month, be sure to share this with your doctor. If you’re unsure, a great way to find out is to track your cycle.”
Irregular period cycles are defined as:
Shorter than every 21 days
Longer than every 35 days
Varying more than 7-9 days every month

An irregular period can be caused by a number of factors—from stress to something more serious like polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or a thyroid disorder. “Also, if you’d like to have a more regular period, speak to your doctor or
video chat with a Maven OB-GYN
about your options,” Russell says. “In many instances, hormonal birth control can help you regulate your period and make it more predictable.”
Learn the common causes of irregular periods

It’s normal to have a few heavy days during your period, but there is such a thing as bleeding too much. “It’s true that some of us have heavier flows than others, but you definitely want to make sure there isn’t an underlying issue,” Russell says. “If any of the below apply to you, speak to your doctor.”
You have trouble maintaining your daily activities during your period, for fear of bleeding through tampons or pads too quickly
You consistently need to double-up protection to control your flow (super tampon plus a pad)
You’re soaking through pads or tampons hourly
You wake up at night to change protection because you would bleed through if you didn’t
You’re bleeding for longer than 7 days (consistently for several months)
You’re passing clots larger than a quarter
Use this checklist to learn more about heavy bleeding

Iron-deficiency anemia is when your body lacks healthy red blood cells due to iron shortage. “Because blood is rich with iron and we lose blood during our periods, if you have particularly heavy or long periods, this can increase your risk of iron-deficiency anemia,” Russell says.
Signs to watch for:
Weakness
Fatigue
Dizziness
Headache
Coldness
Shortness of breath
Pale or yellowed skin
Brittle nails
Learn more about iron-deficiency anemia

Tampons can be lifesavers during your period, but like anything that you put into your body it’s important to know how to use them properly. “If used correctly, there isn’t evidence that tampons can cause harm,” Russell says. “That said, there also hasn’t been much research on tampon safety or the effects of long-term use. What we do know is that the materials that were once related to toxic shock syndrome are no longer used in tampons today.”
Here’s a refresher on how to safely use tampons:
Use the lowest absorbent tampon needed (i.e. don’t use a super plus tampon on a light day)
Change your tampon every 4-6 hours (never leave in for longer than 8 hours)
Wear pads overnight instead of tampons if you sleep more than 8 hours
Don’t use tampons when you don’t have your period
Avoid scented tampons
Learn more about what tampons are made of

Menstrual cups are a safe, environmentally-friendly, and money-saving way to make your period just a little more bearable. If you’ve been curious about exactly how they work, we’ve got the details. “A menstrual cup is a small bell-shaped cup made out of silicone or rubber that you insert into your vagina to collect menstrual fluid,” Russell says. “They can collect up to 3 times more than a tampon and you only have to change them once or twice a day. Plus, they’re reusable and they aren’t absorbent, so you don’t have to worry about exposure to toxins or toxic shock syndrome.”
See what other people are saying about menstrual cups

Tired of pads, tampons, and not interested in menstrual cups?? Period underwear is just like regular underwear but with added layers that can absorb menstrual fluid. You can wear them with or without extra protection (based on your flow), then wash and reuse (the planet will thank you). “Period underwear is designed to pull moisture away from skin, and neutralize odor and bacteria,” Russell says. “There isn’t research on how well they work yet, but they are safe to use. That said, if you’re someone who has UTIs more than once or twice a year, I would just advise that you change your period underwear more frequently to decrease any extra risk.”
See more pros and cons

title.en-US: When to stop taking birth control if you want to become pregnant

content.value: If you’re making a plan to start trying to have a baby, you’re probably wondering when you should stop taking birth control. The short answer is, it depends. Follow this step-by-step guide from Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, MD, to help you know when the time is right.
The best time to stop taking birth control is 1-3 months before trying

“I generally advise my patients to stop taking birth control 1-3 months before they want to become pregnant,” Stone says. “But everyone is different and it may take longer or shorter for your body to adjust after stopping birth control. It will also depend on the type of birth control you use. With birth control with hormones, such as the pill, IUDs, or the patch, it may take a few cycles for you to begin ovulating again. With barrier methods that don’t have hormones, such as condoms or a diaphragm, your ovulation isn’t affected and you can become pregnant immediately after you stop using them.”
Ask yourself this: “Am I ready to become pregnant tomorrow?”

“I also recommend that you ask yourself how you would feel if you became pregnant immediately,” Stone says. “Even if it’s normal for it to take up to a year to conceive, it’s possible to become pregnant the first time you try, even if you’ve only been off of birth control for a day. So make sure that you’re really ready to become pregnant the moment you stop using birth control.”
You don’t need to wait for your period to return to start trying

“Waiting until you get your period can help you and your doctor figure out when you conceived and what your due date is,” Stone says. “However, after you stop taking birth control, you don’t have to wait for your period to return to start trying to conceive.” If your period has not returned within three months of stopping birth control, consult your doctor.
When to stop per birth control method

The hormones in certain birth control methods may delay ovulation for several months, while others have no delay. “Don’t worry though—using birth control doesn’t have any long-term effect on your fertility, no matter what the method or how long you’ve been on it,” Stone says. Find your birth control method below for the best time to stop taking birth control if you want to conceive.
Head’s up: If you’re not quite ready to get pregnant immediately, be sure to use a backup method like condoms as soon as you go off of birth control.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
The bottom line:
Every body is different so it may take more or less time to adjust after stopping birth control. Talk to your doctor or an
OB-GYN on Maven
for a personal recommendation on when to change up your birth control plan if you want to start trying to conceive.
Stop taking it 1-3 months before trying.
You may begin ovulating immediately or it may take a few months for your cycle to regulate.

It’s safe to stop the pill at any time in the pack. However, finishing your pill pack rather than stopping mid-month can help you avoid irregular bleeding and make it easier to predict your period and thus, when you’re ovulating.
Hormonal IUDs: Have it removed 1-3 months before trying. (Some hormonal IUDs affect ovulation so you may begin ovulating immediately or it may take a few months for your cycle to regulate.)
Copper IUDs (Paragard): Have it removed as soon as you’d like to become pregnant (they don’t affect ovulation).

items.header: Birth control implant, patch, or ring

content.value: Have it removed 1-3 months before trying.
You may begin ovulating immediately or it may take a few months for your cycle to regulate.
Stop getting it 10-18 months before you start trying.

It can take from 10-18 months for you to start ovulating after you stop getting the shot. So if you plan on becoming pregnant within the next year, you should switch from the shot to another method of birth control. It’s possible to miss just one shot and become pregnant, but it’s rare.
Stop using them as soon as you’d like to become pregnant.
Has no effect on ovulation so you can become pregnant immediately.

title.en-US: How timed intercourse works for becoming pregnant

content.value: When people say they’re “trying," they’re usually referring to timed intercourse, or scheduling sex during the fertile window of a person’s menstrual cycle to up the odds of conceiving. We spoke with Maven OB-GYN Audrey Lance, MD, to get all of the information you need about how this method works.
What “timed intercourse” means

It sounds clinical, but timed intercourse just means being aware of when the most fertile window of your cycle is and having sex during that time. Your fertile window is the five days leading up to and the day of egg release during your cycle, and there are a handful of ways to pinpoint when your window will happen (more on that below).
Who should try timed intercourse?

“Almost everybody should try timed intercoure as your first method unless you or your partner already have a diagnosis of infertility,” Lance says. “For example, if you’ve had surgery to have your fallopian tubes removed, which isn’t common but can happen with bad pelvic infections, you wouldn’t be able to become pregnant naturally. Or if you or your partner have ever had cancer, you may want to talk to your doctor to get a workup before you start trying, because treatments like chemotherapy or radiation can make it more difficult to conceive.” Polycystic ovarian syndrome, or PCOS, is another condition that may warrant a conversation with your doctor or a
Maven provider

first. “Talk to a doctor about how long you should try with timed intercourse in that case,” Lance says. “They may suggest you don’t wait a full year of trying before getting a workup or starting interventions.”
How many times should I be having sex during your fertile window?

Probably not as often as you think. Every other day is best, Lance says. “Having sex every day can lower sperm count, plus sperm can live up to 5 days after sex so you really don’t need to have intercourse every day.”
How long should I try timed intercourse for?

Unless you have any of the conditions explained above, give it a year. “For most patients we say a year of trying timed intercourse and that coincides with doing all the other right things like healthy eating, not smoking, not drinking,” Lance says. The other exception? If you’re 35 years or older. “We know that there’s age-related fertility decline so at that point we usually try to investigate after 6 months rather than waiting the full year,” Lance says.
How will I know when my fertile window is?

Ovulation kits can make it pretty simple to figure out when your fertile window is, but if you don’t have access to ovulation kits or would prefer not to use them, there are three other methods you can use to track your fertile window, according to the U.S. Office on Women’s Health:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Sources
U.S. Office of Women’s Health

Your basal body temp is your temperature as soon as you wake up in the morning. Your body temp is slightly elevated when you’re ovulating, so the idea behind this method is that by tracking your basal temp for a few months, you’ll be able to predict when you’re ovulating and schedule sex accordingly (romantic, we know, but effective). Your basal temp increases by very slight amounts when you’re ovulating, so it’s best to use a basal body temperature thermometer (as opposed to the one you keep handy to detect fevers). You will likely have ovulated within three days after your basal body temp spikes--you’re most fertile two to three days before that spike and up to 24 hours after ovulation.

In order for this method to work, you have to be strict about taking your temperature at the same time every morning, and doing your best to avoid factors that can affect it like drinking alcohol or smoking cigarettes the night before, having a fever, not getting enough sleep, or doing anything before you take your temperature in the morning (bathroom trips included!). It should literally be the first thing you do when you wake up.

This one takes advance planning (and some math!). You’ll start by tracking your cycle on a calendar for 8 to 12 months. The first day of your period is Day 1--you want to note the total number of days your period lasts for each cycle for that 8 to 12 month span.

With all of that data, you can figure out your most fertile days for your upcoming cycles. Find the first day of your fertile window by subtracting 18 days from the total number of days in the shortest cycle you’ve had since you started tracking. Count ahead that many days from the first day of your next period--that’s the first day of your fertile window. Find the last day of your fertile window by subtracting 11 days from the longest cycle you’ve had since you started tracking. Count ahead that many days from the first day of your period--that’s the last day of your fertile window.

Because this isn’t an exact method and your cycle lengths may vary, the Office of Women’s Health recommends using other fertility tracking methods in addition to the calendar method instead of using it on its own.

This one isn’t for the squeamish. It involves tracking changes in the amount, consistency, and color of your cervical mucus over the course of the month. As the egg that’s about to be released matures, the mucus in your vaginal opening becomes yellow or white, sticky and cloudy. You have the greatest amount of mucus in right before ovulation, and it has the look and consistency of raw egg whites. When you mucus has that appearance, that’s when you’re most fertile. (Make sure you’re washing your hands with soap and water before you check.)
Like the calendar method, the cervical mucus method isn’t reliable for everyone, so you’ll need to use another fertility tracking method in addition to it for greater accuracy.

title.en-US: How to pick a prenatal vitamin and when to start taking it

content.value: Prenatal vitamins aren’t just important during pregnancy. Making sure you’re getting your daily dose of essential nutrients while trying to conceive can help you ensure that your little one gets the vitamins and minerals they need from the get-go—even before you know you’re pregnant. Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, MD, explains everything you need to know about how to choose and when to start taking a prenatal.
What are prenatal vitamins?

Prenatal vitamins are daily pills that are made of essential vitamins and minerals. They help you supplement the nutrients you absorb through food to ensure you’re getting enough of the important nutrients that help promote a healthy pregnancy and your baby’s development. Prenatal vitamins can come in the form of a pill, soft-gel, or a gummy.
What do prenatal vitamins do?

“During pregnancy, you’re supporting not only your nutritional needs, but also those of your growing baby,” Stone says. “That means you’ll need more vitamins and minerals than usual so that both of your needs are met. Taking a prenatal vitamin, in addition to eating plenty of healthy foods, will help you get those extra nutrients that can support you and your baby’s health.”
When should I start taking them?

There's no hard and fast rule on when to start taking prenatals, but experts agree it should be before you start trying to conceive. “I recommend starting a prenatal vitamin with folic acid at least 1 month before you start trying to become pregnant,” Stone says. “The first month of pregnancy is one of the most important times because this is when your baby’s brain and spinal cord begin to develop. By taking a prenatal vitamin in advance, you can help ensure that your baby has access to essential nutrients as soon as they begin developing.”

“Specifically, taking at least 400mcg of folic acid daily reduces the risk of certain types of birth defects called neural tube defects (think spina bifida). Since the neural tube closes at 6 weeks of development—before most people know that they’re pregnant—it’s important to begin supplementing with a prenatal vitamin at least a month prior to conception,” Stone says. “As a bonus, folic acid has also been shown to reduce the risk of nausea and vomiting during pregnancy.”
What should I look for in a prenatal vitamin?
According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, these are the most important nutrients to look for and recommended daily doses:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Is it possible to take too many vitamins and minerals?

When it comes to vitamins and minerals, too much of a good thing can be a bad thing. Always speak to your doctor before taking additional vitamins and minerals on top of your daily prenatal vitamin, as overly high doses of certain nutrients can be toxic (especially calcium and iron).
Does taking a prenatal mean I don’t need to mind my diet?

The best way for your body to absorb nutrients is through a variety of healthy foods including fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and proteins. So prenatal vitamins should be treated as a supplement. “Prenatal vitamins can’t replace food,” Stone says. “If you were to take them alone and not eat healthy foods as well, you would not be able to meet the daily nutritional requirements for a healthy pregnancy.”
Are there any side effects of prenatals?

It’s possible to have a negative reaction to prenatal vitamins. For some, prenatal vitamins can cause nausea, especially if taken on an empty stomach or if you’re already suffering from morning sickness. They can also cause constipation. If either happens to you, talk to your doctor. These side effects can sometimes be settled by switching to a different brand of prenatal vitamins, changing the time of day that you take them or making sure that you take them with a small snack.
“To prevent constipation, be sure to keep your fluids up and add fiber to your diet through foods like broccoli, bananas, apples, and beans,” Stone says. “Daily exercise can also help.”
Should I keep taking prenatal vitamins once I’m pregnant?
Yes. Continue taking prenatal vitamins throughout your pregnancy as advised by your doctor.
Where can I get prenatal vitamins?

You don’t need a prescription for prenatal vitamins. You can buy prenatal vitamins over-the-counter in most pharmacies as well as online. There are a lot to choose from, so be sure to do your research and ask your doctor or a
Maven provider
for recommendations.
The bottom line:

Prenatal vitamins are an important part of your entire pregnancy journey. It’s best to start taking them at least 1 month before trying to get pregnant, throughout your pregnancy, postpartum, and for the duration of breastfeeding—so it’s important to pick one that gives you all the essential nutrients you need. Need help? We’re here for you. Ask your doctor or an
OB-GYN on Maven
for advice on the best prenatal vitamin for your needs.
Sources
Mayo Clinic: Prenatal vitamins
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
The American College of Obstetrics and Gynecologists

Folic acid is a B Vitamin. Getting your daily dose of folic acid is crucial in the first trimester as it helps your baby's brain and spine develop properly and can help lower the risk of your baby developing neural tube defects.

You may see it listed as folic acid or as folate on the label. Folic acid is the synthetic form and folate is the food-based form.
