For some people, the synthetic form may not be easily absorbed. “You can get additional folic acid from eating leafy greens, citrus fruits, and legumes like lentils but it’s difficult to get the recommended amount from food alone, which is why getting this nutrient from prenatal vitamins is essential,” Stone says.
If you’ve already had a pregnancy where your baby developed neural tube defects, or sickle cell disease, you may need to take more folic acid. Speak to your doctor or a
Maven provider
for advice on the correct dosage for your needs.

You also want to make sure that your prenatal includes iron, a mineral that helps prevent anemia and supports baby’s growth and development. Your body needs iron to produce red blood cells. Anemia is a condition where you don’t have enough healthy red blood cells. “Iron is needed to help red blood cells carry oxygen throughout your body,” Stone says. “When you’re pregnant, you need even more blood and oxygen because you’re supplying it to your growing baby.”

items.header: Calcium (1000 mg) and vitamin D (600 mg)

content.value: Calcium and vitamin D support baby’s bone growth and keep your bones healthy as well. “Look for a combination of calcium and vitamin D,” Stone says. “These two nutrients work hand-in-hand because the vitamin D helps your body better absorb the calcium.”

DHA is an omega-3 fatty acid that may support your baby’s brain development, eye health, and nervous system development. “DHA may be related to decreases in preterm birth and other adverse pregnancy outcomes,” Stone says. “However, most research studies DHA found in fish, not in supplements, so it’s best to get DHA from consuming 2-3 weekly servings of fish—just being careful not to consume too many fish with high mercury content, like swordfish, mackerel, tilefish, and Ahi tuna. If you don’t eat fish, experts recommend that you take a DHA supplementation of 200-300 mg daily.”

Choline is a nutrient that may also support baby’s brain development. This micronutrient is important for development of the central nervous system and cognitive function, as well as placental function. “It’s available in foods like broccoli, eggs, nuts, poultry, fish, as well as whole grains, but you should supplement with at least 450 mg daily if you aren’t getting it in your diet,” Stone says. “Most people don’t get adequate amounts from diet alone.”

title.en-US: Internal ("female") condoms: Everything you've ever wanted to know

content.value: Condoms aren’t just for people with penises. If you’ve never heard of the internal condom, or aren’t quite sure how it works, welcome to your complete guide! Often called the “female condom,” the internal condom can prevent pregnancy and the transmission of STIs—plus, it puts you in control of protecting your own body because you can place it before having sexual contact. It’s a great option to pair with other forms of birth control that can’t protect against STIs (like pills, the patch, IUDs, the DepoProvera shot or the NuvaRing). Internal condoms can be a little harder to find, but they’re easy to buy online or at a clinic (they’re also available at some pharmacies). We chatted with Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, MD, to learn more about how they work.
The basics
Effectiveness at preventing pregnancy:REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKCorrect use: 95% REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKTypical use: 79%
Plastic pouch
Use every time you have sex
No prescription needed
Protects against STIs
$2-$3 each
What is it?

An internal condom is a loose-fitting pouch that goes inside the vagina. (It’s also sometimes called the “female condom” but you don’t have to identify as female to use it.) It‘s made of polyurethane and synthetic latex (so it’s safe for people with rubber latex allergies) and is made for one-time use only.
How do they work?

Internal condoms create a barrier that prevents sperm from reaching an egg, helping to prevent pregnancy. They also reduce the risk of STIs because they cover the inside of the vagina, decreasing fluid and skin-to-skin contact. There’s an inner ring and an outer ring that help hold it in place and help with insertion and removal.

One serious warning we must mention here: Do not use an internal condom with an external condom (the kind that goes over a penis). The friction can cause them to tear and then you will not be protected.
Are they effective?

If you use an internal condom perfectly, they’re about 95% effective. But the actual effectiveness is closer to 79% because they aren’t always used correctly, according to the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services. To make sure you’re getting the most protection possible, follow these tips:
Check the expiration date on the condom package
Check for any holes or tears
Make sure the internal condom is correctly inserted in the vagina before any contact
Wear every time you have sex for the entire time you have sex
Make sure that the internal condom stays in place during sex
Pair with another form of birth control to increase the effectiveness and prevent pregnancy
Pro tip: Pulling out before ejaculating lowers your risk of pregnancy significantly
Are internal condoms right for me?

“Internal condoms can be a good option if you want control over your own protection, because you don’t have to depend on your partner to wear a condom,” Stone says. “Some say they can actually increase sexual pleasure, because the inner ring can stimulate the penis and the external ring can stimulate the clitoris. Just be sure to use them every time you have sex to prevent pregnancy and to lower your risk of STIs. Keep in mind that 21 out of 100 couples who use internal condoms without any other birth control method over the course of a year will have an accidental pregnancy. So consider pairing the internal condom with another form of birth control and keeping emergency contraception on hand just in case!”
Is there a “right” way to put an internal condom in?

Yes! You should always insert the internal condom before you have sex to be protected. You can insert it up to eight hours before sex. They come pre-lubricated with silicone-based lubricant so they’re easier to insert. Here’s how to do it:
Find a comfortable position (like lying down, squatting, or putting one foot up)

Squeeze the sides of the inner ring at the closed end of the condom and insert into your vagina (same way you would insert a tampon). You want to push this inner ring up to your cervix, until you feel it can’t go any further.
The outer ring should stay outside of your vagina by about an inch.
Before having sex, always hold the condom open to make sure it doesn’t move during insertion.
During sex, make sure that the condom fully surrounds the penis at all times and that the outer ring stays outside.
To remove, just twist the outer ring and gently pull it out of your vagina, making sure not to spill any semen that may be inside. Wrap and throw away. Don’t flush or reuse.
Are there any side effects?

Unlike other forms of birth control, internal condoms don’t contain hormones, so for most people there are zero side effects. For some, there may be irritation from friction—but that’s nothing a little additional lubrication can’t solve. Insertion may take some getting used to but should feel similar to inserting a tampon.
What do I do if the internal condom breaks or moves?

“If the condom breaks or moves, stop right away and use a new condom,” Stone says, “Also, be sure to keep emergency contraception on hand if you’re not using another form of birth control. Plan B is 95% effective if taken within 24 hours of unprotected sex (or condom breakage), and is still 89% effective for pregnancy prevention if taken within 72 hours. Ella (available by prescription) is effective for up to 120 hours. If the condom breaks and you’re not in a monogamous relationship, you should also see your doctor for STI testing.”
Where should I store internal condoms?
Female condoms should be stored in a cool, dry place. A bedroom drawer would be a good idea, but not a bathroom where it can become moist.
How can I tell if an internal condom is damaged?
Always check the expiration date before using it and check for any holes or tears in the condom before inserting it.
Do internal condoms protect against STIs?

They do! In fact, both internal and external condoms (aka “male and female” condoms) are the only form of birth control that protect against STIs. So even if you’re on the pill, have an IUD, or any other form of birth control, always use a condom as well if you’re at risk of STIs. However, while condoms are the best protection against STIs, remember that they’re not 100% protection. According to USAID, if used correctly the internal female condom is 94% effective at preventing HIV and 66-75% effective at preventing other STIs. The external male condom is 98.5% effective at preventing HIV and 66-75% effective at preventing other STIs.
Will internal condoms affect my fertility?
“Internal condoms have no effect on future fertility,” Stone says. “If you want to try to become pregnant, simply stop using them.”
Not sure which birth control method is right for you?
We're here to help!
Book a vdeo chat or message
with an OB-GYN on Maven anytime to chat through your options.
Sources
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
Mayo Clinic
USAID

title.en-US: How to maintain a healthy blood pressure

content.value: We all know that high blood pressure is bad—but that may be the extent of our knowledge. High blood pressure actually affects nearly a third of all adults and is the leading cause of cardiovascular disease-related death worldwide. If you’ve always wondered what those two numbers mean when your doctor takes your blood pressure, or how to maintain healthy levels, you’re in the right place. Maven Advanced Practice Registered Nurse Michelle Thomas explains what blood pressure is and the best ways to keep yours in check.
What is high blood pressure (aka hypertension)?

Our heart pumps oxygen-rich blood throughout our body by way of our blood vessels, so our tissues and organs have the oxygen they need to function. When our heart beats, the pressure pushes blood into these vessels. Blood pressure is a measurement of how strong this pressure is.

If your blood pressure is high, that means your heart is having trouble pumping blood through your vessels, which puts extra strain on your heart and arteries and may lead to heart attack, stroke, or kidney failure. “High blood pressure often has no symptoms until it’s quite developed,” Thomas says. “That’s why you should get your numbers checked and work to keep them in a healthy range. Because the higher your blood pressure levels are, the higher your risk is for health problems.”
How is blood pressure measured?
Blood pressure is measured in millimeters of mercury (mmHg). When your doctor takes your blood pressure, they record two levels that appear like a fraction (ex. 125/80):
REPLACEWITHIMGWCAPTION
Best ways to maintain your blood pressure

“Blood pressure can be lowered or maintained at healthy levels with simple lifestyle changes you can start making right now,” Thomas says. “Studies show that lifestyle changes can be just as effective, and in some cases more effective, than taking medication for high blood pressure. Be sure to always work with your doctor to come up with the right plan for you.”
1. Maintain a healthy weight

One of the most effective ways to reduce elevated blood pressure is weight loss. “A body mass index (BMI) chart isn’t the be-all-end-all when it comes to weight, but it can be a helpful place to start,” Thomas says. “Work with your doctor to determine what a healthy weight is for you and remember, losing just 5-10 pounds can make a difference on your blood pressure readings.”
Calculate your BMI using an Adult BMI Calculator like
this one
available from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
2. Find your kind of exercise

Exercising just 30 minutes every day can improve your blood pressure. Rather than trying to find time for a really intense hour-long exercise class once a week, start by going for a brisk 30-minute walk once a day. “Consistency is much more beneficial than occasional exercise,” Thomas says. “If walking isn’t for you, put a song on once a day and dance to it or go for a bike ride with a friend. If your schedule is tight, work exercise into your day like walking to work.”
3. Eat the rainbow

Fruits, vegetables, and whole grains are your friend. When you make a meal, or grab a snack, try to eat a wide variety of nutritious foods. “A good trick for making healthy food choices is to choose foods that are naturally rich in color,” Thomas says. “Think, less neon orange chips and more bright orange peppers, deep blue blueberries, and dark green kale.”
Try these heart-healthy foods:
Fruits and veggies
Whole grains
Legumes (beans, lentils, etc)
Lean meat and fish
Low-fat dairy
Healthy fats (like avocados and olive oil)
Keep these foods to a minimum:
Foods high in saturated fats (red meat and full-fat dairy)
Foods high in trans fats (fried foods, baked goods)
Processed carbohydrates
Salt
Sugar
Alcohol
4. Pass on the salt

Sodium (aka salt) can have a negative impact on your blood pressure. Aim for less than 1,500 mg of sodium per day to help maintain or lower your blood pressure. “Reading all of your food labels isn’t always realistic, especially when you eat out,” Thomas says. “But many of us eat up to three times the recommended amount of daily salt, without even knowing it. A good trick to reduce your salt intake is, if you’re cooking at home, don’t add salt to your recipe and if you’re eating out, don’t add salt on top of your meal.”
Salty chips may be obvious, but the American Heart Association also recommends limiting these “sneaky” high-sodium foods:
Breads and rolls
Cold cuts and cured meats
Pizza
Poultry
Soup
Sandwiches
Canned vegetables and canned vegetables juice can also be high in salt, so pt for fresh or frozen whenever possible. (And if we just listed all of your favorite foods, take heart. Moderation is key!)
5. Skip that second glass

Drinking too much alcohol can raise your blood pressure. How much is too much? According to the CDC, the recommended daily limit is one drink for. As a bonus, cutting down on your alcohol intake can also help with weight loss.
6. Say goodbye to smokes

Smoking can damage the walls of your blood vessels and reduce the amount of oxygen in your blood. This can cause your heart to work harder to replace that missing oxygen, raising your blood pressure and putting you at higher risk for heart attack and stroke. This goes for tobacco cigarettes as well as vaping. “The good news is that your risk of heart disease drops from the very first day you quit smoking,” Thomas says.
We know that quitting smoking is hard. Speak to your doctor or
video chat or message with a provider
on Maven for help making a plan that can help you quit for good.
7. Consider cutting back on caffeine

“For some, a daily cup of coffee has little impact on blood pressure,” Thomas says. “But if you’re more sensitive to caffeine or have multiple cups a day, cutting back can help improve your blood pressure readings.”
8. De-stress daily

If you feel like your blood pressure rises when you’re stressed, you’re right. Stress can also lead to unhealthy habits that are bad for blood pressure, like overeating or excessive alcohol consumption. “Stress isn’t just mental; it impacts your overall health,” Thomas says. “The next time you’re feeling stressed try to get to the root of what’s causing it and make a quick list of some things you can do to change it or change your reaction to it. If it’s a demanding job, is it time for a vacation? If it’s financial trouble, could you make a plan to pay off your credit cards? If it’s an unhealthy relationship, consider talking to someone about it or, if you can, trying your best to steer clear of this person who causes you stress.”
9. Know your numbers

The first step towards maintaining a healthy blood pressure is to know your starting point. Make an appointment with your doctor to get your blood pressure checked and have a conversation about the easy steps you can take to keep it at a healthy level.
Sources
American Heart Association
Mayo Clinic
Source: American Heart Association

title.en-US: The Maven guide to birth control

content.value: Birth control doesn’t just help you prevent pregnancy, it gives you the ability to control what you want your life to look like—today and in the future, too. Choosing the right method for you is personal, but with so many options out there it’s also hard to know where to start. To help you make the best decision for you, we got all the details about the most effective birth control methods (including top pros and cons) from Maven OB-GYN Dr. Jackie Stone.
The most effective forms of birth control:
If used correctly, the following forms of birth control are 98% effective or higher at preventing pregnancy.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Other forms of birth control:
These forms of birth control are less effective (95% or less if used correctly) at preventing pregnancy.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Permanent forms of birth control:
The following methods involve a permanently surgical procedure to prevent pregnancy.
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
REPLACEWITHCALLOUT
Not sure which birth control method is right for you?
We're here to help!
Book a video chat or message
with an OB-GYN on Maven anytime to talk through your options.
Sources
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
Intrauterine device (IUD)
Effectiveness: 99%
Plastic T-shaped device (hormonal or copper) in uterus
Lasts 3-10 years (depending on type)
Insertion by doctor or nurse practitioner
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$1300 (depending on insurance)
The basics

IUDs are highly effective. A tiny piece of plastic (about an inch big) is inserted into your uterus by a doctor or nurse and protects you from pregnancy for several years. Copper IUDs are hormone-free because copper naturally repels sperm (copper = sperm kryptonite). Hormonal IUDs release progestin, which prevents you from ovulating and thickens your cervical mucus to block sperm.
Learn more about IUDs
Implants
Effectiveness: 99%
Hormone implant in upper arm
Lasts up to 3 years
Insertion by doctor or nurse practitioner
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$1300 (depending on insurance)
The basics

A birth control implant is a matchstick-sized rod that a doctor or nurse implants in your upper arm (it sounds a little sci-fi, but it only takes a few minutes and doesn’t hurt). The implant releases the hormone progestin which stops ovulation and thickens your cervical mucus to prevent sperm from swimming. It’s very effective and provides pregnancy protection for several years (and no one can even tell it’s there).
Learn more about implants
The shot (aka Depo-Provera)
Effectiveness:
Correct use: 99%
Typical use: 94%
Hormone shot
Get it every 12-13 weeks (or about 4 times a year)
Injection by doctor or nurse or at-home kit
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$150 per shot (depending on insurance)
The basics

Also called the depo shot or Depo-Provera, the birth control shot is an injection that you get in your arm or butt about four times a year (at your doctor’s office or do it yourself at home.) The shot releases the hormone progestin to prevent ovulation and thicken your cervical mucus so sperm can’t swim to meet an egg. It prevents pregnancy for about three months and is very effective. You just have to remember to keep scheduling your next shot on time.
Learn more about the shot
The pill
Effectiveness:
Correct use: 99%
Typical use: 91%
Hormone pill
Taken orally daily
Requires prescription
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$160 per month (depending on insurance)
The basics

“The pill” is actually a pack of pills and you take one pill by mouth daily. There are two types: combination (with estrogen and progestin hormones) or mini pills (progestin-only). Combination pills stop ovulation and thicken your cervical mucus to block sperm. Mini pills don’t reliably stop ovulation; they work mainly by thickening your cervical mucus. The pill is very effective if you take it daily at around the same time—but if you tend to forget things, it may not be the best choice.
Learn more about the pill
The patch
Effectiveness:
Correct use: 99%
Typical use: 91%
Hormone skin patch
Change it once a week
Requires prescription
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$150 per month (depending on insurance)
The basics

The patch looks like a square band-aide and releases hormones through your skin (aka transdermal contraception). Simply place it on your belly, back, butt or upper arm once a week. It releases the hormones progestin and estrogen which curb ovulation and thicken your cervical mucus so sperm are blocked off. The patch is very effective if changed once a week on the same day. If you don’t remember to do it though, the effectiveness drops.
Learn more about the patch
The ring
Effectiveness:
Correct use: 99%
Typical use: 91%
Hormone ring insert
Change it monthly
Requires prescription
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$200 (depending on insurance)
The basics

Also known as the NuvaRing, the birth control ring is a flexible ring (looks like a hairband) that you insert into your vagina. It releases the hormones progestin and estrogen which your body absorbs through your vaginal lining. The hormones prevent ovulation and thicken your cervical mucus to protect you from pregnancy. The ring is very effective if you replace it on time once a month.
Learn more about the ring
Condoms (aka male condoms)
Effectiveness at preventing pregnancy:
Correct use: 98%
Typical use: 85%
Rubber or plastic sheath
Use every time you have sex
No prescription needed
Protects against STIs
$2-$3 each
The basics

Condoms are a thin sheath that goes over the penis during sex to capture semen. It’s the only method that protects you from both pregnancy and STIs so you can pair them with other methods for extra protection. They’re made of latex, plastic, or lambskin (note: lambskin condoms don’t protect against STIs) and they’re very effective if used correctly every time you have sex for the entire time.
Learn more about condoms
Internal condoms (aka female condoms)
Effectiveness:
Correct use: 95%
Typical use: 79%
Plastic pouch
Use every time you have sex
No prescription needed
Protects against STIs
$2-$3 each
The basics

The internal (or female) condom is a loose-fitting plastic pouch that you insert into your vagina to capture sperm during sex. Like male condoms, it can prevent pregnancy and the transmission of STIs. You can pair it with other methods (just don’t pair with male condoms because the friction can cause breakage). But learning how to insert it correctly takes practice, so the effectiveness is lower than external condoms.
Learn more about internal condoms
Diaphragm
Effectiveness
Correct use: 94%
Typical use: 88%
Reusable disc
Use every time you have sex
Prescription needed
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$75 (depending on insurance)
The basics

A diaphragm is a saucer-shaped disc that covers your cervix to prevent sperm from entering. You add spermicide to it and insert it into your vagina before sex (spermicide helps it stay in place and slows sperm down). You can insert a diaphragm up to 2 hours before sex and should leave it in for at least 6 hours after sex and up to 24 hours total. Then remove it, wash it, and store it away for next time.
Learn more about diaphragms
Sponge
Effectiveness
Correct use: 91%
Typical use: 88%REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
*The sponge is not recommended if you've had a baby because the cervical opening is larger, making the sponge less effective (about 76% for typical use).
Plastic sponge
Use every time you have sex
No prescription needed
Does not protect against STIs
The basics

The birth control sponge is a small, soft piece of plastic that looks a bit like a soap sponge (hence the name). You insert it into your vagina before sex to cover your cervix. The sponge contains spermicide already so it has the added benefit of slowing down the sperm’s ability to swim.
Fertility awareness methods (FAMs)
Effectiveness:
Timed correctly: 88%
Not timed correctly: 76%
Tracking ovulation to prevent pregnancy
Does not protect against STIs
The basics

Each month, your ovaries release an egg which can be fertilized (aka ovulation). During this time and right before it, you can become pregnant. With the fertility awareness method, you track when you’re ovulating and don’t have sex (or use birth control) around that time. This method does require dedication to measuring your daily temperature, checking your vaginal discharge, and charting your menstrual cycle.
Cervical cap
Effectiveness
Correct use: 86%
Typical use: 71%REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
*The cervical cap is not recommended if you've had a baby because the cervical opening is larger making the cervical cap less effective ((about 71% for typical use).
Small reusable cup
Use every time you have sex
Prescription needed
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$90 (depending on insurance)
The basics

A cervical cap is a small cup that you insert into your vagina before sex that covers your cervix, blocking sperm. It’s smaller than a diaphragm and you can leave it in longer (up to 48 hours), but it’s less effective. The cervical cap works best when used with spermicide to help it stay in place and slow sperm down. Leave it in for at least 6 hours after sex and up to 48 hours total then wash and store it.
Female sterilization
Effectiveness: 99%
Permanent surgical procedure
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$9000 (depending on insurance)
The basics

The most common forms of female sterilization are tubal ligation and salpingectomy. Tubal ligation (or “getting your tubes tied”) is a permanent surgical procedure where your fallopian tubes are blocked so an egg can’t travel down and sperm can’t meet it. Salpingectomy is another permanent procedure where the fallopian tubes are removed (it also reduces the future risk of ovarian cancer).
Male sterilization
Effectiveness: 99%
Permanent surgical procedure
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$1000 (depending on insurance)
The basics

A vasectomy is when the tubes of a man’s scrotum (the vas deferens) are cut or blocked. The man can still ejaculate, but there won’t be any sperm (no sperm = no pregnancy). It’s often an out-patient procedure that’s done at a doctor’s office or clinic and you can return home the same day. A vasectomy is meant to be a permanent procedure (there is a possibility of it being reversed, but it’s rare.)

title.en-US: How to tell if you're ovulating

content.value: What you need to know:
Ovulation happens when the ovaries release a mature egg. After an egg is released, it travels to the fallopian tubes, where it can be fertilized for the next 12 to 24 hours.
Your chances of becoming pregnant are the highest right before and during ovulation, so it’s a good idea to have sex at least every other day while you’re ovulating.

Knowing your menstrual cycle and when you ovulate (usually between 14 and 16 days before your next period) can help you figure out exactly when to have sex to increase your odds of becoming pregnant. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

The best days to become pregnant are right before and during ovulation, but our bodies don’t exactly send us a calendar invite when they’re about to release an egg. So how do you know when it’s happening? According to Maven OB-GYN Kathleen Green, MD, it’s all about getting to know the signs and setting a schedule.
Step 1: Get to know your cycle to predict when you’ll ovulate

During a normal menstrual cycle, an egg is released every month and makes its way down the fallopian tube—this is ovulation. “Ovulation usually happens 14 to 16 days before your period starts and it’s the ideal time to conceive,” Green says. “So a great first step is to start tracking your period to predict when it’s going to happen and planning on having sex roughly two weeks before that.”

Not sure how to track your menstrual cycle? There are tons of apps that can track for you—all you have to do is enter the first and last day of your period each month. But if you want to track your cycle with good ol’ pen and paper, here’s what you need to do:
Learn your average period length and menstrual cycle length:

You’ll have to do some mental math before you can start accurately tracking. First, figure out how long your period usually lasts by marking the day it starts and ends and counting the days (many last between 2-7 days, for example). This is your period length. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKNext, figure out how long your menstrual cycle is by counting the days between when your last period started and your next period began (most will be between 21-35 days). This is your menstrual cycle length. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKKnow that everyone’s cycle is different—and you may even have different length cycles each month. Tracking both your period length and menstrual cycle length over several months (at least three) can give you a better idea of your average than just tracking one month. Menstrual tracking isn’t an exact science, but it can give you a good idea of when you’re ovulating. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Estimate when your next period will start:

Once you’ve figured out your menstrual cycle length, you can estimate when your next period will come. Start with the first day of your most recent period and count out the number of days your menstrual cycle usually lasts (typically from 21-35 days, but everyone is different). Write down the date you land on as the estimated start of your next period, so you can refer back to it in the next step.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Count back 14 to 16 days from your next estimated period start:

Ovulation usually happens between 14-16 days before your next period, so use the date you predicted for your next period from the previous step and count backwards 14-16 days. Then write down the three dates you land on as days you may possibly ovulate. You can increase your chances of getting pregnant by having sex every other day during these dates, also known as your “fertile window”.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
This is what your period tracker might look like if you have a 28 day cycle:
REPLACEWITHASSET
Have questions about tracking your menstrual cycle?
Maven providers
are here to help. Make an appointment today.
Step 2: Look for signs of ovulation

Along with tracking your menstrual cycle, look for signs that you’re ovulating. “Some people feel cramps when they begin to ovulate, but for most the hints are much more subtle so it helps to know the symptoms and stay in-tune with your body,” Green says.
Stretchy cervical mucus

This technique isn’t for everybody, but it can be effective. “Right before ovulation, you may notice a clear and sticky substance when you wipe or on your underwear,” Green says. “Our cervical mucus changes throughout our menstrual cycle and is stretchiest around ovulation. If you swipe two fingers over your vagina and then pull your fingers apart, look for mucus that stretches across them.”
Basal body temperature spike

Our body temperature naturally rises when we’re ovulating. “Take your basal body temperature, that’s your temperature while resting, and record it,” Green says. “Do this every day at the same time, I usually recommend first thing in the morning, before you get out of bed. Your temperature may only rise half a degree after you’ve ovulated, which is normal. When you have a few months recorded, you’ll start to see a pattern of your temperature rising slightly. The slight rise in temperature shows when you’ve already ovulated, so the next month you would plan to have intercourse a few days before you predict that your temperature will rise.”
Breast tenderness

You may associate breast tenderness with your period, but it's actually a sign of ovulation. “If you notice your breast tissue or nipples becoming tender, it’s a great time to start having sex,” Green says.
Mild pelvic pain
Some people can feel ovulation occurring in their lower abdominal area. It can feel like a slight twinge or a series of cramps.
Bloating

If you’re feeling bloated in the abdominal area, this may also be a sign of ovulation. Because of extra fluids and blood flow that can increase when an egg is released, you may get a distended feeling in your stomach.
Sex drive
You may notice your sex drive get a boost when you’re about to ovulate (thanks Mother Nature!).
Step 3: Use an ovulation test kit

Ovulation test kits are available at most pharmacies and can help you better pinpoint when you’re ovulating. “Ovulation kits include urine sticks that test for a specific hormone (LH or luteinizing hormone) that rises right before ovulation,” Green says. Luteinizing hormone signals ovulation and the release of an egg, so higher levels usually mean ovulation is on the way.
When you’re shopping for an ovulation kit, you have a few options:
Stick ovulation tests.

Similar to a basic pregnancy test, stick ovulation tests have a control line and line that shows if your levels of LH are rising. After urinating on the test stick, if the second line is as dark or darker than the control, you may be ovulating soon. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKStick tests can be difficult to read, but they’re the most affordable type of ovulation test.
Digital ovulation tests.
Like a digital pregnancy test, digital ovulation tests have a window that will tell you “yes” or “no” (or some variation of these) after you urinate on it.
Digital ovulation monitors.

The most expensive kind of ovulation test kit, digital monitors track your cycle, daily symptoms, and even analyze your urine. It’s important to track at the same time every day, so your monitor is accurate. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Once you choose a test kit that works for you and your budget, here’s how to use it:
Read the instructions in your test kit closely. Your kit may have specific instructions about when and how to use it. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Estimate the day you’re going to ovulate based on your period tracker (or calculating yourself using Step 1 above). REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Around the time of ovulation, urinate on your test stick during your first bathroom trip of the day. (Morning pee is the most concentrated.) REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Lay your ovulation test on a flat surface. After the amount of time specified in your kit’s instructions, check for a positive or negative result. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Your LH levels may rise later in the day, so consider testing again around lunchtime or in the early evening. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have a positive result, try to have sex the same day and the day after to increase your chances of becoming pregnant. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

It’s important to know that ovulation kits aren’t always 100% accurate, and can sometimes produce a false positive or a false negative. But they can still be a helpful tool in your conception toolkit. "If you pair [ovulation testing] with timing ovulation and looking for signs of ovulation, you’ll have a good shot at becoming pregnant,” says Green.
Learn more about how to use ovulation predictor kits here.
Talk to a Fertility Awareness Educator
Tracking your ovulation can be tricky. Book an appointment with a Maven
Fertility Awareness Educator
for help.
Sources
Planned Parenthood
Mayo Clinic

title.en-US: The real deal on menstrual cups

content.value: Do you have a friend who won’t stop talking about her Diva Cup? While the menstrual cup has been around since the 1930s, it feels like it’s gone from unknown to all the rage overnight. If you’ve been on the fence about giving it a go, read on as we share all the details, including experiences from people who’ve tried it and Maven OB-GYN Carol Russell’s take on whether they’re safe.
What it is

A menstrual cup is a small, flexible cup (under 2 inches). It’s shaped like a bell with a stem on the end and is made of silicone or latex rubber. There are several brands of reusable menstrual cups, as well as a few disposable versions. They cost about $10 for a 6-pack of disposable cups or about $20-$40 for a reusable cup.
Pros
Eco-friendly:
Menstrual cups are better for the planet (nothing to toss in the trash).
Wallet-friendly:
They’re a big cost-saver if you buy the reusable kind.
Long-lasting:
You can comfortably wear one for most of the day (up to 12 hours)—unlike tampons which need to be changed and thrown away every 4-6 hours.
Effective:
It can hold three times more menstrual fluid than a regular tampon.
Safe:

Menstrual cups don’t absorb your menstrual fluid (like tampons), they just collect it, so the cup may be less likely to alter the natural levels of bacteria in your vagina. “Although there have been a few reports of toxic shock syndrome associated with menstrual cups, there doesn’t seem to be a direct cause and effect relationship, Russell says. “More studies on the various types of menstrual cups available worldwide and their safety are being conducted.”
See the latest study here
Toxin-free:
Unlike some tampons and pads, menstrual cups are free of chemicals because they aren’t bleached.
Flexible:
You can swim, exercise, run, or do any other activity while wearing a cup.
Odorless:
You may notice less odor than when using a pad because your menstrual blood isn’t exposed to the air.
Cons
Learning curve:
Menstrual cups can take some getting used and can be difficult to insert and remove.
Can be messy:
They can be messy while you're learning to use them (it’s a cup full of menstrual fluid, after all). The trick is to remove them slowly.
Requires cleaning:

You’ll need access to a sink to wash it, so a public restroom with multiple stalls isn’t the best spot. But because they can work for up to 12 hours, you can time your removals to happen in a more convenient place.
Very manual:
If you’re used to using tampons with applicators or putting on a pad, the menstrual cup requires more manual use to insert and remove from your vagina than you may want or be comfortable with.
Size challenge:
It can be hard to choose the right size (more on that below) and you may need an OB-GYN to help you decide the right size for you.
How it works

You insert a menstrual cup into your vagina during your period and it collects your menstrual fluid. The rim of the cup creates a suction seal with your vagina to prevent leaking. At the base of the cup is a stem which helps you get it into position and remove it when you need to empty it.

Reusable menstrual cups can work for up to 12 hours, depending on your flow. When it’s time to empty it, just remove gently (follow the instructions below for tips), empty in the toilet, rinse with soap and warm water and dry off, then reinsert if needed. If properly cared for, you can reuse one menstrual cup for several months to several years (depending on the brand).
At the end of your cycle, sterilize your cup in boiling water and store in a breathable container (most cups come with one).
Effectiveness
A comprehensive study of 3,319 individuals published in
The Lancet Public Health

found that menstrual cups are just as effective as pads or tampons, and some of this data suggests that they’re actually more effective at preventing leaks. This study also found that there are no increased health risks of using a menstrual cup or negative affects on the natural bacteria of the vagina.
An OB-GYN weighs in

“Menstrual cups are completely safe and effective. When individuals first discover them, most think it’s weird, but those who try a menstrual cup usually like them a lot,” Russell says. “But if you’re latex-allergic or latex-sensitive, be sure to get the silicone version.”
How to choose the right menstrual cup

“Your OB-GYN can help you choose which size will work best for you,” Russell says. “They tend to come in sizes small and large, but it has nothing to do with how tall you are or how much you weigh, but rather on things like the length of your cervix, the shape of your vagina, the strength of your pelvic floor muscles, and how heavy your periods are—all of which an OB-GYN can help you learn more about.”
How to insert and remove
Inserting a menstrual cup isn’t very different from inserting a tampon—it just takes practice. Here are the steps to follow:
To insert:
Wash your hands with soap and warm water
Wet the rim of the menstrual cup with water or a water-based lubricant
Fold the cup in half with one hand
Insert the cup into your vagina rim up. Just like a tampon, you want to make sure it’s high enough that your vaginal muscles can hold it in place.
Once it’s in, rotate the cup so the top springs open creating a leak-proof seal. If it’s in correctly, you shouldn’t be able to feel it and it shouldn’t leak.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
To remove:
Wash your hands with soap and warm water
Insert your index finger and thumb into your vagina and grab the stem of the menstrual cup
Pull the stem down just enough so that you can reach the base of the cup
Then pinch the base of the cup to break the seal and pull gently down and out (if you pull it out by the stem the seal may not break gently and you may have a mess)
Empty the cup into the toilet, wash with soap and water in a sink, and reinsert.
Menstrual cups and IUDs

“Some brands advise against wearing a menstrual cup if you have an IUD,” Russell says. “The concern is that when removing the cup, you could accidentally pull the IUD strings. And recent research suggests that there’s a higher risk of IUD expulsion when using a menstrual cup. It’s definitely something you want to be careful with though, so it’s best to speak with your OB-GYN or a
Maven provider
before trying the cup if you have an IUD.”
Menstrual cups and sex

“Reusable menstrual cups do need to be removed before sex, but the disposable versions don’t,” Russell says. “Unlike the bell-shaped reusable cups, the disposables are shaped more like a diaphragm. They collect your menstrual fluid during sex so there’s no mess and you and your partner can’t feel them.”
What we’ve heard from people who’ve tried them

“I love my menstrual cup! It's eco-friendly because there is less waste involved, and it's a lot more affordable than buying boxes of pads or tampons. Many menstrual cup brands say they last for a year or more! There definitely was an initial learning curve switching over to the cup, but you get used to it pretty quickly. I stopped worrying about leaks, and only have to empty it once in the morning and evening. With all the pros that come with it, I wonder why I didn't switch earlier.” - Jae

“I find menstrual cups to be so much easier as I used to have to replace tampons 2-3 times a day. Now, I just insert the cup in the morning and empty it before bed. It’s also so much safer for my body because it’s made from medical-grade silicone, better for the environment, and better for my wallet because I only have to buy a new one every year or two.” - Mary

“Once you get comfortable with menstrual cups, you’ll never want to go back! I like that you can set it and forget it! It holds so much more than you'd think. Even on my heaviest days, I empty it in the morning and at night and that's it. Of course, I love that it's so low waste. I have an IUD and my periods are very unpredictable. If I have a hunch my flow is coming, I just pop it in for peace of mind. What I dislike is that you need to be close to a sink when you're emptying it. If there's a way to do that in a restroom stall, I haven’t figured it out.” - Katie
The bottom line:
Like all period products, the menstrual cup is great for some but it’s not for everyone. Overall, they’re safe to use and people seem to like it once they get the hang of it. In fact,
The Lancet Public Health

study found that 73% of people chose to continue to use the menstrual cup after they learned how to use it. If the learning curve is putting you off, just take a moment to remember the first time you used a tampon.
Sources
The Lancet Public Health
US National Library of Medicine National Institute of Health

title.en-US: These resources can help you get financially ready for a baby

content.value: When you’re trying to conceive, it’s normal to have a lot on your mind. How long will it take to become pregnant? What will our lives look like with a baby? Odds are money is on the worry list as well. Research from wealth management company AMP found that parents-to-be are more worried about money during pregnancy than any other time in their lives.

Financial stress often starts before sperm actually meets an egg, though. Luckily, there are steps you can take to ease your money stress and get on solid financial footing before baby is in the picture. Here are five resources that can help you get financially ready to have a child.
Fabric

When you’re in the trying phase, you may not have given much thought to your financial legacy. But when you have people who depend on you, both financially and otherwise, things like a will and life insurance become critically important.
Enter
Fabric

. The experts at Fabric can help you create a simple will online, for free—though if you have a complicated financial situation, like a very high net worth or a family member you help care for financially, you may want to tap an expert for help. A will establishes who will inherit your financial assets and who gets guardianship of your children, as well as laying out your wishes for final arrangements like a funeral and burial.

You can also use Fabric to purchase a term life insurance policy tailored to your family’s needs. Life insurance acts as a replacement for your income if something were to happen to you. That way, your family can stay in their home and maintain their standard of living if you pass away.
It may not be fun to think about, but having your estate-planning ducks in a row can save your family a lot of stress if a worst-case scenario were to happen.
YNAB (You Need a Budget)
If you’re not already tracking your spending and setting a monthly budget to keep that spending in check, now is a great time to start. After all, life tends not to get any
less
expensive once a baby is in the picture.
YNAB

(You Need a Budget) is known as the holy grail of budgeting software among personal finance experts. It’s a combination of budgeting software and a set of rules that can help change the way you think about spending and budgeting. Those rules are:
Give every dollar a job, meaning as soon as you get paid, be thoughtful about where that money is going to go instead of spending it impulsively.
Embrace your true expenses, meaning put money aside monthly for large, infrequent or unexpected expenses.
Roll with the punches, meaning if you spend too much on something, don’t beat yourself up about it and just try to do better next month.
Age your money, meaning you should be spending last month’s cash on this month’s needs and wants.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

YNAB can help you figure out where you’re overspending to free up more money in your budget for impending baby expenses. You can also use it to set savings goals for things like child care, school and college expenses, and other baby-related necessities.
529 plan

When you’re trying to conceive, college feels like it's ages away. But any parent will tell you that the years pass quickly once your kiddo arrives (and that college isn’t cheap), so it’s never too early to start saving.

A 529 plan is a tax-advantaged savings vehicle for college and other education expenses. When you invest money in a 529, it grows tax deferred, meaning you don’t have to pay taxes on the earnings as the balance gets larger. Plus, when you withdraw the money, you don’t have to pay taxes on it as long as it’s used for qualified education expenses, like tuition. There’s no official limit to how much you can contribute to a 529 plan each year in the eyes of the IRS, but generally speaking, the total account balance can’t exceed what the beneficiary's education will cost. Individual plans also have ceilings for how high the balance can be.

It can be a great idea to open a 529 right when a baby is born, or even before, because loved ones can make contributions to the account as gifts. Many family members and friends love to add to a baby’s 529 as a baby shower or birthday gift. (One note: If you open a 529 before your child is born, you’ll have to list yourself as the beneficiary, then change it to your child once they’re born.)

Each U.S. state offers its own sponsored 529 plan. You’re not required to use your state’s plan, however—though some states offer tax deductions if you do. Do some research on different plans before making a choice on which one is best for your family.
Digit
When baby arrives, your budget might feel a bit tighter than it did before. And that’s okay!
Of course you want to be diligent about saving money for baby’s big expenses, but
Digit

could be a great way to save a little bit more without even having to think about it. Digit analyzes your cash flow and spending habits over time, then withdraws a certain amount of cash each day and places it in a savings account. It often withdraws just a few dollars a day, but those dollars can add up if you stick with it. Its smart algorithm knows not to take out so much that you can’t pay your bills and can even assign the saved cash to several different goals (like summer camp, holiday gifts, or a parents’ date-night fund!).
Sources
Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
AMP

title.en-US: Diaphragms: Everything you've ever wanted to know

content.value: If you think of diaphragms as a thing of the past, they may be worth a revisit. For some, diaphragms are making a comeback as a hormone-free method of birth control that’s—once you get the hang of it—easy to use and remove when you need to. Find out if diaphragms may be the right birth control for you with help from Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone, MD.
The basics
Effectiveness:REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKCorrect use: 94% REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKTypical use: 88%
Reusable silicone disk
Use every time you have sex
Prescription needed
Does not protect against STIs
$0-$75 (depending on insurance)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What is it?

A diaphragm is a small, reusable saucer made of flexible silicone that you insert into your vagina before sex. You’ll need to visit a doctor to receive a prescription for it. “The most popular diaphragm on the market currently is called Caya,” Stone says. “It’s one-size-fits-most and doesn’t require sizing by your doctor. You use it with the Caya contraceptive gel and both are usually covered by insurance.”
How does it work?

The diaphragm must be inserted before sex, each time you have sex. Once inserted, the diaphragm covers your cervix so sperm can’t enter. It’s most effective when used with spermicide which helps slow sperm down. You can put your diaphragm in up to 2 hours before sex and should keep in at least 6 hours after to ensure you’re protected (because sperm that are left behind after sex can swim through to the cervix if the diaphragm is removed too soon). It can stay in for a total of 24 hours. When you remove it, rinse it with soap and warm water and then store it safely away in the container it came with for the next time you need it.
Is it effective?

“When used correctly, a diaphragm is 94% effective, but it can be hard to get a hang of how to insert and position it correctly so typically, it is more like 88% effective,” Stone says. “In other words, about 12 out of 100 people using the diaphragm as their only method of birth control will become accidentally pregnant each year.”
The most effective way to use a diaphragm:
Use it every time you have sex, inserting before you have sex
Use it with spermicide
Practice inserting it before you need to (you shouldn’t be able to feel it if it’s placed correctly)
Keep the diaphragm in for at least 6 hours after sex
Is a diaphragm a good choice for me?

“If you’re looking for a hormone-free method of birth control that doesn’t require a daily reminder, a diaphragm may be a good choice,” Stone says. “Unlike other non-hormonal birth control like condoms or sponges, a diaphragm can be reused for up to 2 years. It’s also good for women who want a back-up birth control method in addition to condoms, but don’t tolerate hormones well. However, because they can be difficult to use correctly, their effectiveness is lower than other methods of birth control, like the IUD or the patch. It’s also a very hands-on birth control so if you aren’t comfortable inserting your fingers into your vagina, it may not be the best choice.”
Is it safe?
Diaphragms are safe for most, but may not be the best choice for you if:
You have an allergic reaction to spermicide or silicone
You frequently get urinary tract infections (for some, diaphragms can increase UTIs)
You have pelvic organ prolapse (which can prevent the diaphragm from being inserted or placed correctly)
You’ve given birth or had an abortion in the last two months (as your cervix may not be fully back to its normal size and positioning)
You’ve had toxic shock syndrome in the past (diaphragms can increase your risk of TSS)
Are there any risks?
If you experience any of the following while using a diaphragm, let your doctor know right away. These symptoms could be the sign of an infection or of Toxic Shock Syndrome:
Irritation
Bleeding
Painful urination
Abnormal discharge
A sudden high fever
A rash
Diarrhea or vomiting
Achiness
Dizziness or fainting
How do I get one?

“Diaphragms require prescriptions and your doctor can help you decide on size (or you can try Caya, a one-size-fits-most diaphragm),” Stone says. “Visit your OB-GYN to be sized and then they’ll provide you with a prescription. They’ll also show you how to insert and remove it and how to use spermicide, which is a must for making sure your diaphragm is the most effective it can be. Spermicide can be bought at your local pharmacy without a prescription.”
How does sizing work?

“It’s important that your diaphragm fit correctly and your doctor can help you decide on the right size for you,” Stone says. “It’s also important to let your doctor know if there have been any significant changes that might affect sizing, such as significant weight loss or gain or becoming pregnant. You can also choose to use Caya, a one size fits most diaphragm that claims to fit 94%.”
How do I insert and remove a diaphragm?
“You’ll want to practice putting your diaphragm in before you’re in a moment to use one,” Stone says.
To insert:
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water
Put spermicide in the cup side of the diaphragm
Put one foot on a chair or squat, the same way you would when inserting a tampon
With the domed side facing down, fold the diaphragm in half
Then push the diaphragm up into your vagina, as far back as it can go

Make sure the lip of the cup is behind your pubic bone so your cervix is covered and remove your finger. If it’s inserted correctly, you shouldn’t be able to feel it when you walk. If you can feel it or it’s uncomfortable, try again. If it continues to feel uncomfortable, it may be the wrong size. Speak to your doctor for help.
To remove:
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water
Insert two fingers into your vagina and grab a hold of the lip of the cup
Break the seal by pulling the lip back and then gently pull the diaphragm down and out of your vagina
How do I clean my diaphragm?
After each use, simply wash your diaphragm with soap and warm water. Then let it air dry and store it in a clean place for next time.
How do I check for damage?

“You should occasionally check your diaphragm to make sure there aren’t any holes or tears,” Stone says. “The best way to do this is to run water into it and see if there are any drips and then hold it up to a window so you can see if any light comes through.”
Can my partner feel my diaphragm during sex?
It’s unlikely that your partner will feel a diaphragm during sex. And “if you have sex multiple times, leave the diaphragm in but apply more spermicide to your vagina,” Stone says.
Does a diaphragm protect against STIs?
No. The only form of birth control that protects against STIs are condoms. If you’re at risk of contracting an STI, use your diaphragm with condoms for protection.
How will a diaphragm affect my fertility?
“Diaphragms have no impact on future fertility,” Stone says. “If you want to become pregnant, simply stop using it.”
Not sure which birth control method is right for you?
We're here to help!
Book with an OB-GYN
on Maven anytime to chat through your options.
Sources
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services

title.en-US: The most common causes of irregular periods

content.value: If your period is more cuckoo than clockwork, you may be wondering what’s up. Irregular periods aren’t always a cause for concern, but sometimes they can be a sign of an underlying issue. Maven OB-GYN Carol Russell, DO, explains the most common causes and when it’s best to talk to a doctor.
What is an “irregular” period?

An irregular period is when your menstrual cycle occurs outside of the “normal” range. “The average menstrual cycle is 28 days long, meaning you get your period every 28 days,” Russell says. “But it’s rare that someone is exactly on time every month, so anything that falls within a week of that in either direction is considered normal. A cycle that’s shorter than 21 days or longer than 35 days or that varies by more than 7-9 days every month is what we would define as “irregular.”’
How do I know if my period is irregular?

The best way to know if your period is irregular is to track it and then calculate your average cycle length. Follow the steps below to get started. This can also help you see if you’ve missed months, had multiple periods in a month, or have especially short or long cycles. “If you’re going on memory alone it can be hard to know how long your cycle usually is,” Russell says. “For this reason, it’s helpful to track your period for 6-12 months and share this information with your OB-GYN. The longer you track, the more you’ll learn. ”
How do I track my period?
Mark your calendar on the first day your period starts each month for 6-12 months
Count the days between those marks
Find the average by adding them together and then dividing by how many months you tracked
What are the most common causes of an irregular period?
Irregular periods can be caused by many things, from diet to changing to a new birth control, to an underlying health issue. Here are some common reasons your period might be irregular:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Can stress affect my period?

“Certain life events can be stressful enough to cause changes in your period, usually on a short-term basis,” Russell says. “Losing a spouse or child, going through a divorce, or being laid off, for example, could be stressful enough to alter your period for a time. Everyday causes of stress, like a fight with your mother or starting a new project at work, usually won’t have any affect on your period. The main thing to remember: don’t assume “it’s just stress.” If you notice changes in your period for longer than 3 months, it’s best to have all the other causes ruled out with an exam by your OB-GYN and some blood work.”
Are there signs I should talk to a doctor right away?
Our periods can be a litmus test for our overall health. Be sure to talk to your doctor or a
Maven OB-GYN
if you notice any of the following:
Your period is much heavier than usual (soaking through more than one pad or tampon in 1 hour) or much lighter
You are bleeding or spotting between periods
Your periods are very painful
You’ve missed three periods in a row
Your periods suddenly become irregular when they’re usually regular
Your period lasts longer than 7 days
You have a fever or feel sick while using tampons during your period
Can I do anything to regulate my periods?
“The safest thing to do if your period is irregular is to have a conversation with your OB-GYN or an
OB-GYN on Maven

,” Russell says. “They can help you get to the root cause and devise a plan from there. For some, irregular periods are just what our bodies do and there’s no cause for concern. But you definitely want to rule out more serious medical conditions first.”
Should I get treatment for my irregular period?

“If you want a period that’s more predictable, taking hormonal birth control can help” Russell says. “Additionally, if you want to become pregnant, your doctor may want to work with you on regulating your period as this can increase your odds. Speak with your doctor or a
Maven OB-GYN
to learn about all of your available options.”
Sources
Mayo Clinic
Medical News Today
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services

items.header: Eating disorder, extreme exercising or weight loss

content.value: Anorexia and extreme weight loss can both cause your period to become irregular or disappear entirely. Excessive exercising can also cause your period to stop. “If you aren’t sure if your exercise regimen is extreme or you’re struggling with how you feel about your body, please talk to your doctor or an
OB-GYN on Maven
,” Russell says. “We’re here to help.”

“If you just started the pill, the Depo shot, had an IUD implanted, or any other form of birth control that contains hormones, your period may not be regular for about 3-6 months while your body adjusts,” Russell says. “Depending on the type of birth control, your period may also become lighter, heavier, or go away altogether as a side effect.” If you have any questions about how your birth control may be affecting your period, be sure to ask your OB-GYN or a
Maven provider
One of the first signs of pregnancy is a missed period. If your period doesn’t come when expected, take an at-home pregnancy test or visit your OB-GYN.

“Sometimes miscarriages can happen so early that we’re unaware of it, resulting in a change in our usual menstrual cycle,” says Russell. “If it’s a known miscarriage, your body may take a month or two to return to your normal menstrual cycle.”

PCOS is a fairly common disorder of the endocrine system where the ovaries make large amounts of the androgen hormone. This can cause follicles to grow in the ovaries, preventing eggs from maturing and leading to inconsistent ovulation. The result is often an irregular period or no period at all.

Because your thyroid, a gland at the base of your neck, helps control your menstrual cycle, having a thyroid disease can result in changes to your period. Hyperthyroidism (increased hormone production) or hypothyroidism (decreased hormone production) can cause your periods to become light, heavy, or irregular. They can also make your period stop altogether.

“This is when your ovaries stop functioning the way they normally would before the age of 40,” Russell says. “So instead of ovulating once a month, you may stop ovulating or ovulate on occasion and this leads to an irregular period.”

title.en-US: How to lower your risk of diabetes

content.value: Approximately 463 million adults have diabetes worldwide—and 1 in 2 don’t know it, according to the International Diabetes Federation. If left unchecked, type 2 diabetes (the most common form) can have damaging long term effects on your health, increasing your risk for stroke and heart disease. But the great news is that for many people, diabetes is a preventable condition. Maven Diabetes Coach and Registered Dietitian Erin Davis shares common risk factors you should be aware of and her top tips for how you can lower your risk.
Biggest risk factors for diabetes
These are the biggest risk factors for developing type 2 diabetes, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention:
Being overweight
Being 45 years of age or older
Having a parent or sibling with type 2 diabetes
Being physically active fewer than 3 times a week
Having had gestational diabetes (diabetes that developed while pregnant)
African Americans, Hispanic/Latino Americans, American Indians, Pacific Islanders, and some Asian Americans are at higher risk for type 2 diabetes
Tips for lowering your risk of diabetes
Some risk factors for diabetes are beyond your control, but some are very much within your power. Start by making these three changes.
Get tested

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf you’re concerned about developing diabetes, ask your doctor for a blood glucose test. “A glucose test can help determine if your body is using insulin properly,” Davis says. “Glucose (aka blood sugar) levels that are above the normal range can be an indicator of prediabetes or diabetes.”REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Get sweaty

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKExercise 30 minutes a day to help maintain normal blood sugar levels. Try working a brisk walk, bike ride, or a quick workout into your daily life. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“Exercising at the same time every day can help it become part of your routine,” Davis says. “You may also want to share your daily exercise goals with someone you trust so they can help motivate you (and hold you accountable!). This can be a close friend or a supportive online community.”
Get cooking!

Eating a nutrient-rich diet can help lower your risk of diabetes—think plenty of fruits and veggies, lean protein, and whole grains. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“A helpful first step would be to set a limit for how many times a month you eat out or get takeout,” Davis says. “Even ‘healthier’ options off the menu can be high in saturated fats, salt, and sugar. If you can, try to make the majority of meals you eat homemade. It helps to meal prep on weekends so they’re ready to go on busy work days. And be sure to have plenty of healthy snacks around like apples, oranges, bananas, nuts and seeds. When we’re hungry we tend to reach for the most convenient foods, which aren’t always the best for us."
Sources
International Diabetes Federation
Mayo Clinic
American Diabetes Association

title.en-US: Endometriosis: Everything you've ever wanted to know

content.value: Some experts believe that endometriosis affects approximately 10% of women worldwide, while others believe this number to be much smaller at 1-2%. Why such a wide range? Because the symptoms of endometriosis can be hard to spot and a definitive diagnosis typically requires surgery. But endometriosis is a serious condition that can become worse if left untreated. Maven OB-GYN Scott Osmun, MD, explains everything you need to know so you can recognize the symptoms and get care.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
The bottom line:

Endometriosis can be a painful condition with long term side effects. If you think you may be suffering from endometriosis, talk to a doctor and share your symptoms right away. The sooner you have a diagnosis, the sooner you can start a treatment plan.
Sources
Mayo Clinic
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
US National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health

Your period is made up of endometrial tissue—the lining of your uterus that thickens each month as it prepares for pregnancy. This tissue breaks apart and is shed when a pregnancy doesn’t occur. Endometriosis is a condition where this tissue grows outside of the uterus and it can be found on the ovaries, fallopian tubes, in the pelvis or in other locations. It can cause painful periods or pain with intercourse. The pain can be severe, especially during your period. It may also show up as an ovarian cyst, which is called an endometrioma. In a study of 1,000 individuals with endometriosis, approximately 80% presented with pain, 25% with infertility, and 20% with an endometrioma.

“Unlike the tissue that grows, breaks down, and comes out as menstrual blood during your period, with endometriosis the tissue growing outside of the uterus has nowhere to go,” Osmun says. “So instead of leaving your body it has the ability to grow and spread. This can lead to abnormal growths like ovarian cysts, scar tissue, and bands of tissue that can form in the pelvic area or, in rare cases, between organs, which can be very painful.”
The cause of endometriosis isn’t completely known, but experts believe some possible causes may include:
- Retrograde menstruation:
This is when menstrual fluid flows backwards into the fallopian tubes and pelvis. The endometrial cells in this fluid then begin to grow on the pelvic lining or other organs.
- Cell transformation:
Endometriosis may be the result of hormones transforming other cells into endometrial-like cells.
- Scar tissue from surgery:
Having a hysterectomy or a C-section can increase the risk of endometriosis if endometrial cells attach themselves to the location of an incision.
- Cell movement:
It’s possible that endometrial cells can move outside of the uterus to other parts of the body by way of blood vessels or tissue fluids.
- Immune system disorders:

If a person has an immune system disorder—such as chronic fatigue syndrome or an underactive thyroid—this may prevent the body from being able to notice and destroy endometrial-like tissue growing outside of the uterus, leaving it unchecked.

Some women have no symptoms or they’re so mild that they’re mistaken for normal period pain. Sometimes the symptoms are varied or not very specific and thought to be due to something totally different, like digestive disorders. “The symptoms of endometriosis are often felt during your period and can range from mild to very painful,” Osmun says. “But the severity of your pain isn’t necessarily related to the severity of your condition—you can have no symptoms with advanced endometriosis and very painful symptoms with mild endometriosis. So if you have any of the following symptoms to any degree, it’s best to tell your doctor. You may also see symptoms temporarily improve during pregnancy and disappear altogether after menopause.”
These are the most common symptoms of endometriosis. You may have one or several of these symptoms:
- Painful periods:
One of the telltale signs of endometriosis is very painful periods. Endometriosis can cause severe cramping and pelvic pain. In some cases, it can also cause stomach and lower back pain.
- Painful sex:
This includes pain during sex, as well as afterward.
- Painful urination or bowel movements:
This is most common during your period.
- Abnormal menstrual bleeding:
You may have heavy periods or spotting between periods.

According to a 2011 study conducted in France, it's estimated that there’s an average of 6.7 years between when the symptoms of endometriosis first appear and when it’s diagnosed. “Endometriosis can be difficult to diagnose because it’s sometimes mistaken for other conditions that can cause pelvic or abdominal pain, such as ovarian cysts or irritable bowel syndrome—or because patients assume that pain is just a normal part of having a period,” Osmun says. “To find out if you have endometriosis, your doctor will first ask about your symptoms, including where you feel them and when they occur. So it’s helpful to keep track of your symptoms and share this information with your doctor.”
Based on your symptoms, your doctor may perform the following exams:
- Pelvic examination:
Your doctor will manually feel for abnormalities in your pelvis, like cysts or scars. However, it’s difficult to feel small spots of endometriosis so an ultrasound is often performed as well.
- Ultrasound:

To get a better view of the reproductive organs, your doctor may perform an ultrasound. Using a wand inserted into the vagina or a device pressed against your abdomen, sound waves will create an image of your reproductive organs so your doctor can look for abnormal growths such as cysts, which can be a sign of endometriosis.
- Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):

Your doctor may also suggest an MRI exam. Using magnetic fields and radio waves, the MRI will create a more detailed image of your organs and tissues. This can help your doctor find the exact location and size of any growths. MRIs are commonly used before surgery.

items.header: Are there health conditions that increase my risk?

content.value: You may be more likely to develop endometriosis if:
You got your period at an early age (11 years or younger)
You have short menstrual cycles (less than 27 days between periods)
You have heavy periods lasting longer than a week
You have a low BMI
You have a close relative with endometriosis (mother, sister, or aunt)
You have reproductive tract abnormalities like an abnormally shaped uterus
You’ve never given birth

items.header: Does having endometriosis put me at risk for other issues?

content.value: Endometriosis can increase the risk of two types of cancer, ovarian and endometriosis-associated adenocarcinoma, although the risk is low. Recurring pain and infertility issues caused by endometriosis can also affect mental wellbeing and lead to depression.

As many as 50% of women with endometriosis will have trouble becoming pregnant, according to the Mayo Clinic, but many with mild or moderate cases have gone on to have healthy pregnancies and treatment can help improve your fertility. “Because endometriosis can cause tissue to grow in the fallopian tube, it can block sperm from meeting and fertilizing an egg,” Osmun says. “It’s not uncommon for individuals to first learn that they have endometriosis when they have trouble conceiving. If this is the case, your doctor will likely recommend that you speak with a fertility specialist. They can help you decide on the best treatment options, including stimulating ovulation through medication or hormone treatment, or pursuing in vitro fertilization (IVF).”
To learn more about fertility treatment, video chat with a
Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist

“How your doctor treats endometriosis depends on the severity,” Osmun says. “For mild cases, medication can help relieve the symptoms and help you manage pain. For more advanced cases, surgery may be needed.”
Your treatment options could include:
- Short-term pain relief:
For short-term pain relief, it can help to take warm baths, use a heating pad, and take ibuprofen to ease cramping caused by endometriosis, which commonly occurs during your period.
- Birth control:

“Hormonal birth control, like birth control pills, the ring or the patch can help regulate hormone levels including, potentially, the hormones that trigger endometrial tissue growth,” Osmun says. “They can also cause shorter and lighter periods which can help reduce pain. Birth control with progestin, like IUDs and the Nexplanon birth control implant can cause periods to end altogether, which can provide relief from endometriosis.”
- Medication:

Your doctor may prescribe hormone-blocking medications that lower your estrogen levels and stop menstruation, which can cause the endometrial tissue to shrink. Medication is sometimes prescribed in combination with birth control.
- Surgery:

“In cases where the pain is severe, your doctor may recommend surgery to remove the endometriosis tissue,” Osmun says. “Surgery has been shown to improve the chances of becoming pregnant. It is also the only way to confirm a diagnosis of endometriosis.”

Endometriosis surgery is commonly performed using laparoscopy. Small incisions are made near your navel and in your lower abdomen. A laparoscope or camera is inserted to view your pelvis and reproductive organs and to look for endometrial tissue. Another thin instrument is inserted through the other small incisions to remove the tissue. Though you may have heard of women with endometriosis having surgery to remove the uterus and ovaries, it’s uncommon and usually reserved for individuals who don't want to become pregnant.

title.en-US: Should you do genetic screening before becoming pregnant?

content.value: Everyone wants to have a healthy pregnancy and a healthy baby. Genetic testing can offer some peace of mind about this by screening for genetic conditions you may pass on to your child. But it’s also possible for the results to sometimes cause more worry than relief. Maven Genetic Counselor Ushta Davar Canteenwalla explains everything you need to know if you’re considering genetic screening before and during pregnancy and how to decide if it’s something you want to pursue.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
The bottom line:

There is no right answer when deciding what testing to take before or during your pregnancy—but it is important to figure out what information is meaningful for you to have. A chat with a genetic counselor can often help you work through some of the key questions you should be asking yourself as you consider genetic testing. Want to talk to one from the comfort of your home?
Book a video appointment
with a Genetic Counselor on Maven.
Sources
Canadian Family Physician Journal
U.S. Library of Medicine
Mayo Clinic
Canteenwalla:

“Genetic carrier screening is one of the tests that you can take prior to becoming pregnant that can help identify if you or the baby's father are a carrier of a genetic condition that can be passed on to your child. Because the testing is looking at genetic changes in you, not your developing baby, it can be done prior to becoming pregnant. Children inherit genes from both of their parents and our genes are linked to certain traits—If both mom and dad are a carrier of the same condition, then there’s an increased risk for a child to have that condition.”
Canteenwalla:

“We each have 2 copies of our genes: one that we inherit from our mom and the other copy from our dad. Genetic carrier screening helps identify if you have a change in your genes that would increase the chance for your future children to be affected by one of the conditions on the testing panel. Genetic carrier screening panels can vary in regards to the number of conditions they screen for. They can include more commonly occuring conditions such as cystic fibrosis, sickle cell anemia, Fragile X, and Tay-Sachs disease, as well as some rarer conditions. The conditions that are on carrier screening panels are those that significantly impact childhood health and do not include adult onset conditions like breast cancer, for example.”

items.header: Does my partner have to be screened as well?

content.value: Canteenwalla:

“Typically we start with carrier screening on the partner that intends to get pregnant. If they are a carrier for any condition, then we go ahead and screen their reproductive partner to further assess the risk. However, carrier screening can be done at the same time on both partners if there’s a time crunch to get this information.”

items.header: Can anyone get a pre-pregnancy genetic screening?

content.value: Canteenwalla:

“Yes. Anyone can request genetic carrier screening, either before pregnancy or during. Although less likely these days, some doctors may only offer carrier screening if you or your partner are considered ‘high-risk,’ meaning you have a family history of hereditary disease or you are part of certain ethnic groups with a higher risk of specific genetic disorders. Also, some insurance plans may not cover carrier screening prior to pregnancy.”

items.header: If I’m healthy, why should I consider getting screened?

content.value: Canteenwalla:

“Even if you and your partner are healthy and show no signs of disease, and even if neither of you have a family member with a disease, it’s still possible for you to be a carrier of a genetic mutation that can affect your children. In fact, most people who are found to be carriers are typically healthy, have no health symptoms or manifestations, and do not have a family history of that condition. Your doctor or genetic counselor can help you decide if information from genetic screening is a good choice for you.”
