items.header: Do I have to do genetic screening?

content.value: Canteenwalla:

“No. Genetic screening is completely optional and not required. Based on your personal health and family history, your doctor or genetic counselor may advise that you consider genetic screening and help you decide by going over the pros and cons of screening, but the choice is always entirely yours to make.”
Canteenwalla:

“Your doctor or genetic counselor will ask you about your health and your family’s health history. Based on the information that's gathered, they’ll offer you tests accordingly. Genetic carrier screening can be done either by a cheek swab or blood test.”

items.header: When is the best time to do genetic screening?

content.value: Canteenwalla:

“Genetic carrier screening can be done at any time before pregnancy or in early pregnancy. Since the conditions and genetic variants that are on carrier screening panels can change over time, we typically recommend that the test be done closer to when you are hoping to get pregnant.”
Canteenwalla:
“Screening for genetic diseases before becoming pregnant gives you the option to choose other methods of growing your family if you’re found to be at a high risk for passing on a genetic disease.”
Canteenwalla:

“There’s little physical risk in choosing to do genetic carrier screening before becoming pregnant (after all, it’s just a blood test). But the emotional, and sometimes financial, toll can be great. Before agreeing to genetic screening, your doctor or genetic counselor should explain it to you in full, including the benefits and risks, possible results, and it’s limitations.”
Canteenwalla:

“It’s not unusual to be told that you’re a carrier of a genetic condition. In fact, most people who are tested on one of the larger screening panels (~200+ conditions) come back as a carrier for about 2-3 conditions. If your carrier screening test results indicate that you’re a carrier, a genetic counselor can review what the risks would be to have a child with that condition and talk a bit about the physical characteristics or symptoms of that condition.

It’s important to remember that the greatest chance is that your baby will not be affected with the condition, but in order to understand more about the risk, we would need to see if your reproductive partner is also a carrier for the same condition. For most conditions that are screened for, being a carrier has no health implications for you—however, for some conditions, people who are carriers may have some clinical impact. This is something your genetic counselor would be able to review with you. If results from carrier screening come back as negative, or indicate that you’re not a carrier for any of the conditions screened for, that's great news. However, note that a negative result simply means that the risk for being a carrier for any of these conditions is significantly reduced, but not eliminated.”

items.header: What does it mean if my partner and I are carriers of the same condition?

content.value: Canteenwalla:
“If both partners are found to be a carrier of the same condition, then there is a 25% chance that a future pregnancy could be affected with that condition.”

items.header: What are my options if we're carriers of a condition?

content.value: Canteenwalla:
“If you find out that your future pregnancy is at an increased risk of being affected with one of the conditions on the carrier screening panel, there are a couple of options to consider:

You may choose to become pregnant with medical assistance and undergo a process called preimplantation genetic testing (PGT-M). This testing is done with the assistance of in vitro fertilization (IVF) where a biopsy from the embryo is sent to a genetic testing lab that will test for the genetic change in question. The goal here is that only the embryos that are not affected with the condition will be transferred for implantation.
You may choose to get pregnant without medical assistance and then be tested for the condition via a CVS or amniocentesis procedure that’s done early in pregnancy.
Or you may choose to become pregnant without medical assistance and not to do any testing on the pregnancy itself and instead wait to do testing on the baby at birth or shortly thereafter.”

items.header: Is pre-pregnancy genetic screening covered by health insurance?

content.value: Canteenwalla:

“Health insurance providers have different policies about covering pre-pregnancy genetic carrier screening so it’s best to call them directly before undergoing screening and ask what they will cover. Some may require proof that this screening was recommended by your doctor before they’ll cover all or part of the cost.”

items.header: If I don't do genetic screening before conceiving can I do it when I'm pregnant?

content.value: Canteenwalla:

“You can always do genetic carrier screening once you are pregnant. There are also many genetic screenings and tests that are only offered once pregnant to help assess the risk of common chromosome conditions. In the first trimester, you may be offered a test that looks at proteins made by the baby (called “first trimester screening”) or a test for fetal DNA that is circulating in your blood (called “cell-free fetal DNA testing”). These are all done via a blood test on you and look at the chance for the pregnancy to have some of the more common chromosome conditions such as Trisomy 21, 18 or 13.

If the results show an “increased risk,” this means that there is a higher than expected chance that a pregnancy may be affected with that condition. However, this is not a definitive result and further testing needs to be done via diagnostic testing like a CVS or amniocentesis to confirm the results.”

items.header: How can I prepare for screening?

content.value: Canteenwalla:

“Speak to your family about their medical history. If there is a family history of anyone with a genetic condition or unexpected early death, talk to a genetic counselor who can guide you towards the most appropriate testing for you to better understand your risk. Make a list of questions about how the screening works, what the results could mean, and what options you would have if you receive a positive test result.

Keep in mind that your results can also have an affect on your family. If you test positive for a genetic mutation, it’s possible for other family members to have this mutation as well and you may feel obligated to share the results with them.“Finding out that you have a genetic disorder that runs in the family may be a welcome head’s up or information your family members would rather not know.”

title.en-US: How endometriosis affects your health

content.value: Endometriosis is more than painful periods—it’s a serious condition that can impact your overall health. According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, as many as 10% of women have endometriosis and many more may go undiagnosed. Read on to learn how endometriosis can affect your health and what you can do about it.
Let’s start with the basics—what is endometriosis?

Your period is made up of endometrial tissue—the lining of your uterus that thickens each month as it prepares for pregnancy. This tissue breaks apart and is shed when a pregnancy doesn’t occur. Endometriosis is a condition where this tissue grows outside of the uterus and it can be found on the ovaries, fallopian tubes, in the pelvis or in other locations within your body. It can cause painful periods or pain with intercourse. The pain can be severe, especially during your period. It may also show up as an ovarian cyst, which is called an endometrioma. In a study of 1,000 women with endometriosis, approximately 80% presented with pain, 25% with infertility, and 20% with an endometrioma.
Learn more about endometriosis
How does endometriosis affect my health?
Some common symptoms of endometriosis that can affect your health include:
Painful periods

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKPain is the most common symptom associated with endometriosis and typically occurs during a menstrual cycle. This is called dysmenorrhea. This pain can vary from mild to severe and usually is described as cramping and low pelvic pain. In some cases, it can also cause upper abdominal pain and lower back pain. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Painful sex
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThis includes pain during sex, as well as afterward.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Painful urination or bowel movements
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKMost common during your period.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Abnormal menstrual bleeding
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYou may have heavy periods or bleeding between periods.
Can it cause other long-term health problems?
Even if your symptoms are mild, endometriosis can spread and get worse over time if left untreated. Some long-term health problems include:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
The bottom line:

There isn’t a cure for endometriosis, but there are steps you can take to reduce your symptoms such as managing your weight, exercising, and avoiding alcohol and caffeine. Get started today by talking to your doctor or an
OB-GYN on Maven
who can help.
Sources
Mayo Clinic
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology
Endometriosis can cause abnormal growths like ovarian cysts, scar tissue, and bands of tissue in the pelvic area and other parts of the body.

Endometriosis can start off as very small lesions in a single location and it can spread over time, leading to larger lesions. It can also form scar tissue and adhere to organs such as the uterus, bladder, intestines, and fallopian tubes. This can lead to pain and organ dysfunction.

Endometrial tissue growth can block your fallopian tube and prevent fertilization or, if fertilization occurs, increase your risk for an ectopic pregnancy (a pregnancy that forms in your fallopian tube, which can be potentially life-threatening).

The pain caused by endometriosis can affect mental wellbeing. In an analysis of 24 studies including 99,614 participants, those with endometriosis had higher levels of depression, especially those who experienced chronic pain from endometriosis.

Endometriosis can increase the risk of two types of cancer: ovarian and endometriosis-associated adenocarcinoma, although the risk is very low. A study of 50,000 Finnish women with ovarian endometriosis found an increased risk for certain ovarian cancers. However, for those with pelvic endometriosis, there was no increased risk.

One study, as reported by the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services, showed that autoimmune disorders like allergies, asthma, and hypothyroidism were more common in individuals with endometriosis.

title.en-US: Read this if you’re using drugs and want to become pregnant

content.value: The desire to have a baby can be an important reason to stop any unhealthy habit, especially drug use. Using drugs can not only reduce your chances of becoming pregnant but it can also impact the health of you and your baby once you are pregnant. According to the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA), using drugs while pregnant—including smoking marijuana, misusing opioid pain relievers or anti-anxiety medications, or using illegal drugs—can triple the risk of stillbirth. Maven OB-GYN Danielle Frock-Welnak, MD, explains why getting help with drug use now is the best way to ensure the overall health of you and your future baby.
How drugs affect your chances of becoming pregnant

“Using drugs can impact many aspects of female health, especially hormones that are needed to regulate your menstrual cycle and stimulate ovulation,” Frock-Welnak says. “Without ovulation, pregnancy isn’t possible.” In male partners, drug use has a negative impact on the quality, quantity, and mobility of sperm. It can also lead to erectile dysfunction and low sex drive, all of which lower the odds of becoming pregnant. Here’s how drug use can affect your fertility:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
How drug use in pregnancy can impact your baby before and after birth

Some drugs can easily pass through the placenta—that means that the drugs you take also reach your baby with the potential to affect their heart, brain, and other developing organs. “If you use certain drugs during your pregnancy, namely opioids or benzodiazepines, your baby may be born with these drugs in their system,” Frock-Welnak says. “Shortly after birth, your baby may begin to experience withdrawal symptoms. Some babies will have mild symptoms like irritability, trouble sleeping, or issues feeding, while others will have more severe symptoms like tremors, seizures, or severe pain. Some babies will require treatment and may need to stay in the hospital for a long period of time.”
Studies have shown that using drugs while pregnant can cause serious health consequences, including:
Miscarriage
Low birth weight
Premature labor
Placental abruption (when the placenta separates from the uterus causing the baby to be deprived of oxygen)
Development and behavioral issues as your child grows
Smaller-than-normal head size (microcephaly)
Infections passed from mother to baby (including hepatitis C and HIV)
Increased risk of birth defects (including heart defects)
Premature birth
Stillbirth or fetal death
Maternal death
Increased need for neonatal intensive care following birth (admission to the NICU)
Neonatal abstinence syndrome (when the baby goes through withdrawal upon birth, with symptoms ranging from mild to severe or even life-threatening)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Even if your baby is born without immediate health issues, babies born to mothers who use drugs often have problems later in life. According to the March of Dimes they can include:
Learning and behavior problems
Slower-than-normal growth
Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) (the unexplained death of a child while sleeping)
The effects of specific drugs on your fertility and pregnancy
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Why you shouldn’t wait until you’re pregnant to quit

If you’d like to become pregnant, it’s safest to stop illegal drug use or misuse of prescription medications before conceiving. “For many people, they may not learn they’re pregnant until they are already 4 or more weeks along as most standard pregnancy tests will not detect a pregnancy until this time,” Frock-Welnak says. “If you’re abusing drugs during this time, you may be exposing your baby to harmful chemicals when your baby is in a vital development stage, including developing their heart, brain, and spinal cord. This may lead to birth defects or miscarriage.”
How to get help

“Abusing drugs doesn’t make you a bad person and there is no shame in asking for help to quit—that’s what we’re here for, ” Frock-Welnak says. “I cannot promise that the road to recovery will be easy, but as a doctor, I can promise you that it is the absolute best thing you can do for your health and that of your child’s.”

There are many options for treatment including outpatient and inpatient rehabilitation. For opioid addiction, medications like methadone, suboxone, and subutex are safe for use both prior to, during, and after pregnancy. These medications can be prescribed by a certified provider and require regular followup to assess dosing and compliance. There is still the possibility of withdrawal for your child after delivery; however, it tends to be less severe when in treatment. And with some drugs, like opioids and benzos, stopping suddenly during pregnancy can also pose risks for your baby, so always talk to your healthcare provider to get advice on how to quit.

“It’s important to keep in mind that asking for help is the first and most important step,” Frock-Welnak says. “Pregnancy is the perfect excuse for making healthy lifestyle changes—because a healthy baby starts with a healthy mom.”
We're here for you
Book a video appointment
or message with a Maven provider for judgment-free care from the comfort of your own home. If you're not sure who to talk to, just message your Maven Care Advocate for a personal recommendation.
Sources
March of Dimes
National Library of Medicine
American Pregnancy Association
National Institute on Drug Abuse
Reuters
Drug use can change your menstrual cycle, making it lighter, heavier, irregular or nonexistent which can interfere with the ability to ovulate and become pregnant.

items.header: Increased risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs)

content.value: Abusing drugs can impair your judgment and lead to risky behaviors like unprotected sex, which increases the risk of sexually transmitted infections. Infections like gonorrhea or chlamydia, although treatable with antibiotics, can lead to a condition called pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). This condition causes scarring of the female reproductive tract leading to chronic pain and infertility. Untreated chlamydia at the time of birth can also negatively impact your baby’s health.

HIV is another infection that can be acquired through unprotected sex or intravenous drug use. Injection drug use is linked to 1 in 10 cases of HIV according to the National Institute of Drug Abuse. HIV can be treated but has no cure and is associated with many negative health outcomes including infertility.

In addition to HIV / AIDS, intravenous drug use greatly increases the risk of contracting other serious infectious diseases that impact fertility or impair maternal health before and during pregnancy, including hepatitis. “If a mother has HIV or hepatitis, these conditions can be passed to your unborn child if pregnancy occurs,” Frock-Welnak. “HIV is also present in breastmilk and therefore, mothers with HIV cannot safely breastfeed their infant.”

“Drug use can lead to changes in weight and poor nutrition, both of which can affect your overall health and fertility,” Frock-Welnak says. If critical nutrients are missing when you conceive, the baby may develop congenital defects, such as malformation of the spinal cord (neural tube defects). In pregnancy, poor weight gain and inadequate nutrition can negatively impact the growth and development of your baby.
Effects on fertility:
Men:
Low testosterone
Issues with sperm motility and viability
Decreased sperm count and quality
Women:
Menstrual cycle disruption
Decreased ovulation in women
Effects on pregnancy and newborn:
Developmental issues
Premature birth (birth before 37 weeks) when combined with tobacco use
Low birth weight
Neural tube defects
Anemia
Issues with breathing and feeding as well as increased risk of NICU admission
Transmitted in breast milk (in some states, it's illegal to breastfeed while using marijuana)
Effects on fertility:
Decreased ovulation in women
Decreased sperm count and quality in men
Effects on pregnancy and newborn:
High rate of miscarriage
Developmental issues
Placental abruption
Low birth weight
Premature birth
Neonatal death
Neonatal irritability and other neurologic and behavioral abnormalities linked to cocaine exposure during pregnancy
Neonatal abstinence syndrome, or withdrawal after birth
Increased risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)
Increased blood pressure and risk of stroke in mothers
Effects on fertility:
Decreased ovulation in women
Decreased sperm count and quality in men
Effects on pregnancy and newborn:
Developmental issues
Placental abruption
Low birth weight
Birth defects
Premature birth
Stillbirth or neonatal death
Increased need for neonatal intensive care following birth (admission to the NICU)
Increased risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)
Neonatal abstinence syndrome, or withdrawal after birth (including irritability, jerky movements, and neurologic abnormalities)
Increased risk of gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, and stroke in mother

items.header: Heroin, fentanyl, codeine, morphine, oxycodone and other opioids

content.value: Effects on fertility:
Women:
Hormone and menstrual cycle disruption
Decreased ovulation
Men:
Decreased sperm count and quality in men
Erectile dysfunction
Effects on pregnancy and newborn:
Placental abruption
Miscarriage
Developmental issues
Low birth weight
Premature birth
Stillbirth
Much like adults, babies may suffer from withdrawal following birth, ranging from mild to life-threatening
Increased risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)

items.header: Benzodiazepines (abusing prescription drugs such as Valium or Xanax)

content.value: Effects on fertility:
Unknown
Effects on pregnancy and newborn:
Miscarriage
Developmental issues
Low birth weight
Preterm birth
Stillbirth
Respiratory issues
Birth defects
Baby may suffer from life-threatening withdrawal upon birth
