title.en-US: The basics of baby sign language and how to teach it to your baby

content.value: You probably spend a fair amount of time wondering what your baby is thinking or trying to tell you. With baby sign language, you just may find out. After all, sign language gives your baby an effective way to communicate with you months earlier than if you waited for them to verbally develop those same words, says Maven Pediatric Occupational Therapist Victoria Peake.

She explains that you can start to introduce sign language to your baby when they’re as young as two to three months, with most babies being able to initiate some signs between 6 to 12 months. (Conversely, many babies develop their first word around 10 to 14 months.)

As a result, teaching your baby sign language can help you more effectively recognize their needs, and potentially ease frustrations for your child. Between the ages of eight months and two years, many children tend to know what they want and need, but don’t have the ability to verbally communicate those desires, according to the Mayo Clinic.

And for children who experience verbal delays, sign language can be an even more important tool to improve communication, reduce frustrations, and lower the risk of behavioral issues, according to research from the University of Kansas.

Plus, the benefits of baby sign language extend far past early communication skills. Learning sign language promotes fine motor coordination, imitation, and cognitive development, Peake says. As your baby learns the words and motions, you engage their full senses: They get to watch the signs, hear the words, and feel the movements with their hands. As you touch and help them move their hands, you bond that much more.
Best beginner signs for babies

When starting with sign language, Peake recommends putting these words at the top of your list. They use simple motions that make them easy beginner signs, from a motor-skills and imitation perspective. And, among the frequently used (or need-to-use) words, they’re incredibly useful and easy to repeat multiple times throughout the day. (When it comes to learning, repetition is key.)
“More”

“This is very easy to incorporate into mealtimes when your baby wants ‘more food,’ or during social games such as ‘more tickling,’ or at the playground when they want ‘more swinging,’” Peake says. It’s often one of the first signs babies pick up.
To sign “more” –
Take both hands and place your fingers against your thumbs like you’re pinching something with lobster claws. From here, tap the tips of your fingers together, draw them apart, and repeat.
“All done

“When you identify when a baby wants more of an experience or object, you can read their cues to identify when they’re also ‘all done,’” Peake says. Then show them the sign for it. Keep in mind that this sign technically means “finish” or “finished,” but this version keeps things simple for both you and your baby.
To sign “all done” –

Hold both hands in front of your chest/shoulders, with your fingers extended and palms facing your body. From here, rotate your hands to face your palms away from you. For emphasis, you can repeat this motion a few times back and forth.
“Eat”

“This will happen at least one to three times in a day, so you’ll have lots of opportunity to practice,” Peake says. Also make sure to use this word and sign to ask your child if they’re hungry. Note: This sign comes with a bonus. It’s also the sign for “food.”
To sign “eat” –
Place the fingers of your dominant hand against your thumb like you are pinching something with lobster claws. From here, tap the tips of your fingers to your lips a few times.
“Mommy” and/or “Daddy”

What parent doesn’t want to hear (or see!) these words? Take note that the signs for mom and dad are 90 percent the same. The only difference is whether you bring your thumb to your chin or to your forehead.
To sign “mommy” –

Spread the fingers of your dominant hand and hold it several inches in front of your face with your thumb facing you and your pinkie facing away from you. From here, tap your thumb to your chin. Repeat if needed to reinforce.
To sign “daddy” –

Spread the fingers of your dominant hand and hold it several inches in front of your face with your thumb facing you and your pinkie facing away from you. From here, tap your thumb to your forehead. Repeat if needed to reinforce.
“Milk”
“This will come into use at least three to six times per day, depending upon feeding schedule and age,” Peake says. To sign “ milk,” make the sign for “milk” near your breast or the bottle.
To sign “milk” –
Hold out your dominant hand, squeeze it into a fist, let go, and repeat. It’s just like squeezing an udder, without the downward motion.
How to teach your baby sign language

The best way to teach your baby sign language is during routine tasks (where there’s consistency around the words you use) and during play when your baby is fully engaged, Peake says. For example, using “eat” and “all done” during mealtimes. Making sure you have your baby’s attention will help get the message across and, in time, encourage your baby to mimic your signs and use them on their own. Also, ensure your baby can easily see your mouth, hands, and, when applicable, the item you’re referencing.
Then, follow these steps:
Perform the sign while simultaneously saying the word. If you’re referencing a person or object, gesture to them after saying the word.
Repeat two to four times.
Guide your baby to mimic the sign by gently putting your hands over theirs and going through the motions with them. Repeat the word aloud as you sign together.
Reinforce the action by praising your baby.
If you want one-on-one support or have more questions about baby sign language, Maven Pediatric Occupational Therapists are here to help!
Book a video appointment today

title.en-US: Domestic infant adoption 101 in the U.S.

content.value: Adoption is a wonderful way to create a family, but the process can also feel overwhelming at first. What are your options? How much does it really cost? Is it best to work with an agency or law firm? As an adoptive mother herself, Maven Adoption Coach Amy Twombly knows firsthand how intense all of these decisions can feel. “Many adoptive families begin by searching online, where they can become overwhelmed by too much information, and, unfortunately a lot of misinformation,” Twombly says. If you’ve just begun your search, or you’re feeling a bit lost, read on to learn all about the key steps to helping you bring your child home.
Step #1: Understanding state-specific laws

First, it’s important to know that you don’t have to adopt from the state in which you live if you live within the United States—your adoption search can be nationwide. However, every state has different laws and every agency and attorney will have different processes and procedures. There are states that are considered more “adoption friendly” (for example, some states have a shorter time frame for the birth mother to consent to the adoption), so it may be worth looking beyond your home state.
Learn more about state-specific adoption laws
Step #2: Weighing the costs of domestic adoption

Fees vary between agencies and law firms, from case to case, and even based on the age of the child. But if you’re looking for a ballpark figure, according to the Child Welfare Information Gate, the average costs of domestic adoption are:
Public agency adoption (aka adopting a child out of foster care):
Approximately $2,000 which is often completely subsidized and may include additional benefits such as covered health care and college tuition for the adopted child
Domestic infant adoption through an agency or law firm:
$20,000 to more than $45,000
Independent adoption (also known as identified adoption or self match):
$15,000 to more than $45,000
Learn more about how to afford adoption
Step #3: Deciding who to work with

There are a few different ways to go about domestic adoption. Here’s a brief summary of each approach to help you decide which route is best for you. Keep in mind, in many cases you can work with more than one agency at a time for more opportunities to see potential cases but some agencies require that you exclusively work with them. Need help finding an agency? Message your Maven Care Advocate for a customized list.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Step #4: Getting ready for your home study

No matter what route you decide to take to adopt a child, you’ll need an approved home study to move forward. “This is a very deep look into every aspect of your family’s life,” Twombly says. “It can feel quite invasive but basically, home studies help make sure that the adoptive family is able to offer a child a loving, safe, and financially secure environment.”

A licensed social worker who works with a child-placing agency in your state must perform the home study even if you’re adopting from a different agency in a different state. A home study can’t be performed by a social worker from a hospital or school. When choosing an agency to perform your home study, you’ll want to confirm that they’ll be able to transfer the study to the agency you’re working with to adopt.

You’ll be asked to compile many documents (proof of citizenship, proof of income, medical records, marriage license if applicable, etc.), have a series of interviews, and a home visit. Generally, a home study costs anywhere from $1,000 to over $4,000 on the very high end, depending on your state. If you’re adopting through foster care, there is often no fee. It takes between eight and 12 weeks (sometimes longer) to complete this step.
Learn more about how to prepare for a home study
Step #5: Preparing your profile book

Putting together a profile book is a critical step on your adoption journey if you’re hoping to adopt a baby through a domestic infant adoption agency or adoption attorney. Families create a profile book using a combination of photos and text which showcases their family to expectant mothers, and these books are shared with expectant parents. The profile book can be in PDF form, printable form, or video form. Please check with your chosen adoption provider to find out which format is preferred.

“The expectant mother wants to be able to visualize what their baby’s life will be like with the adoptive family,” Twombly says. “She wants to see how families will incorporate her child into every aspect of their life—their community, family, friends, hobbies, traditions, etc. So it’s an important piece of the adoption journey.”

You should research what the book should include and how it should be written. You can create a book yourself using different online platforms or hire a professional to create the book for you, which Twombly often recommends to clients.
Learn how to create a profile book that stands out
Step #6: Becoming a waiting family

If families go through an adoption agency or an attorney, they’ll fill out an application, pay an upfront fee, and complete a home study in order to be approved. Next, families become a waiting family. This means that their agency or attorney can now present them to expectant mothers. In order to become a waiting family, your application must be approved, all required payments submitted, all paperwork completed, home study approved, and profile book completed.

“There’s a big misconception in the adoption world that expectant moms are teenagers or college-aged women,” Twombly says. “In reality, most expectant mothers are in their late 20s or early 30s and many have other children. They are most always in crisis. Many struggle with substance abuse or mental health. They may be homeless or victims of sexual assault. Many don’t want to be in the position of placing their baby or child for adoption, but they want to be able to give the child the best life possible, which they can’t provide at that time.”

Adoption professionals will usually ask an adoptive family about their preferences for the child they’d like to bring into their family. There are five main preferences to consider and research when thinking about adoption: race, gender, substance abuse during the pregnancy and mental health history of the birth parent, and the ongoing contact you’re willing to have with the birth parent. “It’s really important for families to understand the realities of the cases they're going to see and educate themselves about what they’re comfortable with,” Twombly says.
The more flexible you are in your preferences, the more cases you’re going to see, and the more chances you’ll have to be chosen, she says.
Step #7: The match

“You’re matched from the time an expectant mother chooses you until she delivers,” Twombly says. “During this time, it's important for the adoptive family to establish and navigate a relationship with the expectant parent(s).”

If you’re working with an agency or law firm, they’ll help facilitate this relationship. The expectant parents may want to have a first-time phone call, an in-person visit before birth, or have ongoing communication during the pregnancy. “It’s crucial for families to understand that the expectant mother is making one of the most difficult decisions of her life,” Twombly says. “This relationship is about her as well as the baby or child. I also stress to adoptive parents that this is her child until she decides to terminate her parental rights and it becomes irrevocable. When you’re at the hospital and during labor and delivery, be flexible and open to whatever the expectant mother’s wishes are, knowing that her wishes can change at any moment.”
Step #8: Placement

Every state has a different time frame as to when a mother can consent to terminating her parental rights and when it becomes irrevocable. Once that happens, it cannot be revoked unless she can prove she signed under duress, coercion, or fraud (depending on state law). “After the signing, the agency becomes the legal guardian of the child,” Twombly says. “They then allow the adoptive family to take placement of the child with the goal of permanent adoption.”

If a family adopts a child out of their home state, they’ll need to get approval from the Interstate Compact for the Placement of Children (ICPC) office. This is an agreement that all 50 states abide by when a child is being placed for adoption from one state to another (meaning, from the child’s birth state to the adoptive family’s state). Both states have to approve the placement. In general, ICPC approval can take about 7-10 business days. Families must stay in the state of the child’s birth and cannot cross state lines until approval.

“It’s a stressful waiting period for many adoptive families,” Twombly says. “I remind my clients that this is a unique time, when everything stands still. You’re likely not working and you’re not at home so there’s no housework! So try your best to enjoy this time and bond with your new little one.”
Step #9: Post-placement period

After the adoptive family takes a placement, every state requires a post-placement period before they’ll allow the adoption to be legally finalized. This period of time is different in every state but it’s usually between 3-6 months. During this time, each state also requires a certain number of post-placement visits with the adoptive family and child. These are performed by the social worker who completed the family’s home study. Again, each state requires a different number of visits, but there are usually between 3-5.

“The post-placement period is the time when the adoption agency or the attorney and the state want to make sure that the adoptive family is doing everything they said they would do for the child—giving them a loving, stable, financially secure home, feeding them, taking them to the doctor, things like that,” Twombly says. “It's also a time to make sure that the adoptive family is comfortable with the placement before everything is legally finalized and permanent.”
Step #10: Becoming legal guardians of the child

Once the post-placement period has passed, the attorney will send all of the adoption documents to the court, a court date will be scheduled, and the judge will sign an adoption decree which will transfer all legal rights to the adoptive family. “And finally, you become the legal guardians of the child and they become a permanent part of your family,” says Twombly.
The bottom line:

There are many steps in the adoption process. It can be long and very complex. According to Twombly, this one thing above all else will set you up for success: “Align yourself with adoption professionals that you feel comfortable with and that you feel you can trust. Then be open and honest with them as you make your way through this journey with them by your side.”
To get started, message your Maven Care Advocate who can help make personalized recommendations on agencies and consultants to work with.
Sources
Child Welfare Information Gateway: Planning for Adoption: Knowing the Costs and Resources
Child Welfare Information Gateway: Children’s Bureau: Adoption Options
Child Welfare Information Gateway: Children’s Bureau: State Laws on Domestic Infant Adoption
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Children's Bureau: Adoption and Foster Care Analysis and Reporting System 2020
Building Your Family: The Infertility & Adoption Guide
Resolve: The National infertility Association: Financing Adoption
American Public Human Services Association: ICPC FAQ

items.header: Public agency (aka foster care) or agencies contracted by the state:

content.value: Children from infancy to 21 years of age are waiting for homes of their own within the foster care system. In fact, as of 2019 there were more than 420,000 children in the foster care system, according to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Infants are rarely adopted out of foster care as they tend to be reunited with their birth parents, but it can be a great option if you’re interested in adopting a toddler, older child, or sibling group.

The foster care system is held to state-specific standards and regulations. It is most common to adopt through foster care in the state in which you live (in rare occasions you can adopt from foster care in another state). You can also start out as a foster parent before adopting a baby or older child permanently and this is often encouraged.

Keep in mind that the primary goal of the foster care system is to reunite children with their parents or other family members and you’ll be expected to work with the agency’s social workers to help facilitate this first and foremost. However, if the child is unable to be reunited safely with the birth parent or another relative, officials will work to find the child a new adoptive family and foster parents are often offered the first opportunity to adopt. You’ll then need to hire an adoption attorney to finalize the adoption legally. These and other fees associated with finalizing a foster care adoption may be reimbursed.

It’s important to know that children in foster care are usually removed from their families due to abuse or neglect and have likely experienced trauma in their lives. A social worker will play a big part in helping to select a family to ensure that they’re aware of and able to meet a child’s specific needs.
To find a child to foster or adopt, visit
The National Foster Care & Adoption Directory
or message your Maven Care Advocate for help.

A licensed adoption agency is a private organization that helps match adoptable children with prospective families. Most adoption agencies focus primarily on finding homes for infants, with the vast majority of toddler and older child adoptions going through the foster care system. Expectant mothers come directly to a domestic infant adoption agency for help finding a family for their unborn child and adoptive parents come directly looking to be matched with an expectant mother. Domestic infant adoption agencies are required to meet state standards so there is oversight—which is a good thing!

“Adoption agencies are full-service organizations,” Twombly says. “They provide outreach to expectant mothers making their services easier to find, they have social workers on staff to support and counsel the expectant mothers, and they walk families through the entire process.”

Prospective adoptive parents create pictorial profiles for expectant mothers to look at for help choosing a family to place their baby with once they’re born. Keep in mind that the birth parent has until after the birth to decide if they consent to the adoption and sign their legal parental rights away, and different states have different laws about how long they have after birth to decide, as well as how long they have to revoke it if they ultimately choose to parent.

When working with a domestic infant adoption agency, they’ll often have in-house legal counsel to review documents, field legal questions, and terminate the birth parent’s parental rights. “Usually the attorney’s services will be part of the overall adoption fee you pay the agency and you won’t have to hire an attorney on your own,” Twombly says. However, some agencies may require you to hire your own attorney to finalize the adoption.
To find a domestic infant adoption agency, visit
The National Foster Care & Adoption Directory
or message your Maven Care Advocate for help.

items.header: Independent adoption (also known as identified or self match):

content.value: An independent adoption is one that doesn’t use an adoption agency. Expectant mothers and adoptive families must find each other and work together directly. Unlike working with an agency, you’ll need to independently hire assistance such as an adoption attorney for the legal aspects and a social worker to complete the home study.

“Self-match adoption is kind of like trying to sell your house on your own without a realtor,” Twombly says. “There is no outside guidance or support for you or the birth parent. You’re responsible for marketing yourself to expectant mothers, navigating your relationship with them, and ensuring all legal aspects of the adoption are in place which can make it especially risky and emotionally draining.”

Just like with working with an adoption agency, independent adoptions must follow individual state adoption laws, including how long a birth parent has to consent to sign their legal parental rights away and/or revoke that consent which is why it’s recommended that you hire an adoption attorney.
To find an adoption attorney to help facilitate an independent adoption, visit the
Academy of Adoption & Assisted Reproduction Attorneys.

In some states, adopting through a law firm is another way to go about adopting a child. Adoption attorneys may provide matching services, contracting social workers to serve as case workers for expectant parents looking to find an adoptive family. Some law firms have all of the attorneys needed to handle the entire adoption process in-house, others require that you hire an additional outside attorney (be sure to ask about this when contacting a law firm). Also of note, potential adoptive parents usually need to hire an adoption attorney in their home state.
To find an adoption attorney, visit the
Academy of Adoption & Assisted Reproduction Attorneys

An adoption consultant does not perform adoptions, but you can hire one privately to help you through the many steps of adoption. “Adoption consultants can help families understand the entire adoption process and know what to expect so they’re able to make educated decisions,” Twombly says. “This includes finding licensed adoption providers (agencies and attorneys) to work with based on your preferences and budget.”

Think of an adoption consultant as a personal concierge who holds your hand and can help you make difficult decisions and potentially avoid pitfalls. Working with an adoption consultant is an additional and optional service to consider if you’d like extra help. You can expect this service to cost $3,500 to $4,000.

A matching service or facilitator is a group that facilitates matches but in many states is unlicensed, not required to meet any state standards, has no legal oversight, and may be risky to work with as a result. These matching or facilitator services connect expectant mothers and potential adoptive families directly and may or may not be regulated by their state. Some states prohibit them altogether. Please check with your state adoption regulations to see if you can work with a matching service or adoption facilitator.

title.en-US: How to find an adoption attorney for domestic infant adoption

content.value: An adoption attorney can be a great person to have in your corner should your adoption journey get into legal questions you aren’t prepared for. We spoke with Maven Adoption Coach Amy Twombly to learn about the role an adoption attorney may play in your domestic infant adoption and how to find the right attorney for you.
How adoption attorneys help

Technically, you’re not required to have an adoption attorney to complete an adoption but most adoptive families usually see them as a much-needed partner in helping them through the often legally complex aspects of adoption.

For example, every state has different adoption laws. These laws include which state the adoption must be finalized in (the child’s state or the adoptive family’s state) or whether or not out-of-state families can adopt at all. There are also state-specific regulations around how long a birth mother has to sign away her parental rights after birth, and how long she has to revoke it should she change her mind.

It’s also possible to encounter what’s known as a “contested adoption.” In this scenario, a birth father may try to contest the adoption so they can take custody of the child. “This doesn’t happen often, but it can become a complex legal battle,” Twombly says. “As you can see, things can get complicated in a number of ways and an attorney can help.”

If you choose not to hire an adoption attorney, just keep in mind that you’ll have to accurately understand and adhere to state-specific adoption laws, file all of the paperwork needed to legally complete the adoption, and possibly represent yourself in court should there be legal complications with the birth parents.
The role of an attorney in adoption
There are a few different ways to go about a domestic infant adoption and the role an adoption attorney plays will differ slightly in each case:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
How to vet adoption attorneys to find the best one for you
Not sure where to start when it comes to finding an adoption attorney? Follow these steps:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
The bottom line:

An adoption attorney can be a huge help when navigating the legal complexities of adoption and finding one you can trust is key. Look to reputable sources and ask for recommendations from people you know who’ve been there. Your relationship with your adoption attorney may be long, so it’s important to find a good match.
Sources
Child Welfare Information Gateway: Find an Adoption Agency or Lawyer

When a family chooses to self match (meaning you find an expectant mother on your own), you and the expectant mother will have to hire your own attorneys independently to complete all of the legal aspects of the adoption.

Some families choose to hire an adoption attorney to facilitate the entire adoption. They’ll primarily be an expert in the legal aspects of adoption, but some may be able to help connect families with expectant mothers and offer other services.
To find an adoption attorney, visit the
Academy of Adoption & Assisted Reproduction Attorneys

items.header: Working with a private adoption agency

content.value: “If you’re adopting through an agency, some will have in-house legal counsel to review documents, field legal questions, and finalize the adoption,” Twombly says. “Usually the attorney’s services will be part of the overall adoption fee you pay the agency and you won’t have to hire an attorney on your own.” However, agencies may not always have in-house legal counsel and you may be required to hire your own attorney to finalize the adoption.
Twombly recommends that families find what’s called a “Quad A” attorney. These attorneys are adoption experts who have been admitted to the
A
cademy of
A
doption
A
doption
A

ttorneys (the 4 “As” = the term Quad A) and also include Assisted Reproduction Attorneys (which is invitation-only). As of this writing, there are only 470 legal professionals, including attorneys, professors, and judges, who have this designation within the United States.

Quad A attorneys have deep experience in adoption practice and attend continuing education classes to ensure that they’re up to date on any changes in legal issues surrounding adoption. They also have other Quad A attorneys in their networks that they can tap for advice if need be. If you visit the Academy of Adoption and Assisted Reproduction Attorneys website, you can search by state for a Quad A attorney. (Just make sure you filter for an adoption attorney, since they have reproductive lawyers listed as well.) A current list can be found at
adoptionart.org.

items.header: Use word-of-mouth recommendations if you can

content.value: If you have people in your life who’ve adopted children and used an attorney, ask about their experiences and if they have any recommendations. Sites like adoption.com also have community forums where adoptive families can ask for advice from those who’ve been through the process before.

items.header: If choosing an attorney for the entire process, ask them how they operate

content.value: These are a few particularly important issues to get clear on before deciding to work with an attorney for more than just the finalization process. Twombly suggests asking the following questions to avoid potential scammers (unfortunately, they’re out there):
How many waiting families do they have?
What is your process?
What kind of support is my family going to get?
What kind of support is the expectant mother going to get?
Do you market to expectant mothers?
How do you confirm the expectant mothers pregnancy and that she wants to place her child up for adoption?

items.header: Align yourself with people you feel comfortable with

content.value: Call the attorney you’re considering and chat with them, Twombly advises. “Tell them about your situation,” she says. “Get a vibe and ask yourself if you feel connected to them. A Quad A attorney will likely have plenty of experience with adoption placements and the legal intricacies around them. You can ask them questions about their experience, but also you should be looking for a connection, if your personalities match and you feel you’ll work well together.”

title.en-US: How to find and vet an adoption agency

content.value: Adopting a child can be complex, so working with an adoption agency is a great way to ensure you’ll have support along your journey. Adoption agencies can help navigate the tricky terrain of both domestic and international adoptions. Compared to working with a private attorney or doing a self-match on your own, adoption agencies are often able to offer more dedicated support throughout the process (both to your family and the birth parents). But with roughly 3,000 adoption agencies in the U.S. alone—all with their own rules and processes—where do you begin? Maven Adoption Coach Caitlin Phillips gives her top tips for how to find the right adoption agency for you.
Some common misconceptions

According to Phillips, an adoption consultant who helps families navigate the adoption process, adoptive parents often assume that they can only work with one adoption agency at a time. “There are some agencies that do require you to work with only them, but many are open to families working with a handful of agencies at a time,” Phillips says. “And working with multiple agencies can actually be a smart move, because you’ll have more opportunities to match.”

Families also don’t realize that they can ask questions or don’t know the most helpful questions to ask when vetting an adoption agency. “Parents often just sign up with their local adoption agency and pay a large sum of money only to learn later that the agency only does a few adoptions per year and has many waiting families,” Phillips says. Asking these questions up front can help manage expectations and minimize frustrations later on.
To help you avoid potential pitfalls, follow these steps to find and vet an adoption agency.
Step #1: Choose the state(s) that you’d like to adopt from

Before you start your search for an adoption agency, it’s important to know that adoption laws vary significantly by state, making some more adoption-friendly than others. One of the main differences is the waiting period that the birth mother has to sign paperwork relinquishing her rights after the baby is born. In Texas, for instance, birth mothers have 48 hours after the birth to sign. But in Connecticut, they have well over a month. When choosing which state you’d like to adopt from, start by investigating your state’s specific adoption laws. If you find that they’re not the most adoption-friendly (for example, they don’t allow out-of-state adopters, they have long revocation periods, etc.), you may decide you want to adopt from another state.
Once you know the states you’re interested in adopting from, look for adoption agencies that are either licensed in that state or in multiple states if you’d like to expand your search.
For an extensive overview of the adoption laws in different states, visit the Child Welfare Information Gateway
State Laws on Domestic Adoption
. To see the most up-to-date adoption laws for an individual state, visit the
state’s government website
. A licensed adoption agency or adoption attorney can also help you navigate this.
Learn more about infant adoption laws in the U.S.
Step #2: Ask about fee structure

While the total fee for adopting a child through an adoption agency will be in the same general range ($20,000 to $45,000 for domestic infant adoption), when these fees are due may differ between agencies. Some agencies charge a lower upfront fee to work with them, usually between $100 and $3,000, and others charge a higher upfront fee, between $14,000 and $18,000, with the remainder due at a later step in the adoption process. Some agencies may space the fees out over a few different steps in the adoption process. For example, they may collect a portion of the total fee when you first apply, then after your home study, and the final payment once the child has been placed with you.

Once you’ve found an agency you’re interested in, give them a call to ask about their fee structure upfront. If an adoption agency charges a high upfront fee, it isn’t necessarily a bad thing, but you’re then financially obligated to work with that agency or walk away from the money. “Usually, the fees that you pay up front are nonrefundable,” Phillips says. “One upside of working with agencies with lower upfront fees is that you may be able to afford to work with multiple agencies, which could give you more opportunities to connect with expectant mothers.”
Step #3: Ask for numbers
Once you’ve narrowed down your options by state and fee structure, you’ll want to know two numbers:
How many placements the agency does each year
How many waiting families they have

“These numbers are important because if an agency is doing 10 placements a year and they have 40 waiting families, for example, you could be waiting a long time for a child if you choose to work with them,” Phillips says. “But if they’re doing 70 placements per year and have 100 waiting families, the odds are good that you could match relatively soon.”
You can also ask what the average wait time for a placement is, Phillips says. “It’s always approximate, but they should be able to give you a range.”
Step #4: Ask about the support the birth mother receives

It’s unpleasant to think about, but Phillips advises that potential adoptive families make sure that the expectant mother isn’t being coerced in any way and that they’re being supported by the adoption agency. “It’s important that agencies do good and ethical work and that they’re treating the expectant mothers they’re working with respectfully and providing options for counseling and support,” Phillips says. Be sure to ask exactly what kind of support the agency is offering to expectant mothers. For example: Do you offer birth mothers counseling before and after the adoption? Do you assist birth mothers with finding housing, getting prenatal care, etc?
Step #5: Learn about each agency’s internal policies

Beyond state rules, individual agencies also have their own unique policies—and some are more strict than others. “Every agency is different and they set their own policies because they are independent (ie, not run by the state),” Phillips says. “For example, not all agencies will work with same-sex couples or single parents. Some are faith-based and require you to associate with a certain religion or even require regular church attendance.” Others won’t work with families that are too specific about the child they want to adopt, like a particular gender and race combination, she says. Many have age limits for adoptive parents as well. Ask about their policies upfront when interviewing agencies to work with.
Step #6: Iron out the financials

Most adoptions through an agency will cost a total of between $20,000 and more than $45,000, according to the Child Welfare Information Gateway. “If you're on a budget as a family, you’ll definitely want to ask them what their average overall cost is upfront,” Phillips says.
In terms of fees, you’ll also want to figure out what happens if the expectant mother decides not to proceed with the adoption. Ask the agency in what specific circumstances the fees can be refunded.
The bottom line:

It all comes down to understanding what you want and need out of the adoption experience and doing your research. “Before you financially invest in an adoption agency, you really want to know that you will be working with an agency that will come through for you,” Phillips says. Need help getting started? Message your Maven Care Advocate today! They can help create a list of agencies reputable agencies to reach out to.
Sources
Child Welfare Information Gateway: Planning for Adoption: Knowing the Costs and Resources
Resolve: The National infertility Association: Financing Adoption

title.en-US: The basics of buying donated breast milk

content.value: A hundred years ago, “wet nurses,” someone who nurses a child they didn’t give birth to, were common. Today, this is no longer the norm, but milk sharing still goes on in its own way. If you want to give your baby breastmilk but cannot or choose not to breastfeed or pump, your two main options are to purchase donated milk from a milk bank or directly from a lactating mother. Maven Lactation Consultant & Nutritionist Lauren Olofsson, IBCLC, explains everything you need to know to help you decide what’s best for your baby.
Option A: Purchase breast milk from a milk bank
How to find a milk bank

In order to purchase breast milk, you’ll need to get a prescription from your doctor. After that, the Human Milk Banking Association of North America (HMBANA) is the best place to begin your search for safe donor breast milk in the United States. The HMBANA sets safety guidelines and accredits milk banks who follow these guidelines. Keep in mind that there are only 30 HMBANA-accredited breast milk banks across the U.S. and Canada, so the one closest to you may still be a drive.

Once you locate your nearest location, call them up to learn about their supply and if you qualify to have breast milk sent to you instead of having to pick it up. “You’ll want to find out how much milk they have available and who has priority to that milk, as they may also serve hospitals,” Olofsson says. “Usually neonates—or the youngest babies born prematurely—tend to get priority because breast milk is most essential for their health compared to say, a healthy 6-month-old baby who was born full term.”
Each milk bank has its own process, but you will likely have to fill out an application and you can work with several milk banks at once.
To find your nearest milk bank, start here:
North America:
hmbana.org
International:
internationalmilkbanking.org
European:
europeanmilkbanking.com
How much it costs

According to the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), the cost of donor milk can vary by milk bank but is usually in the range of $3-5 per ounce. These costs cover screening of the donor, milk pasteurization and testing, and shipping of the milk. So how much might it cost to feed your newborn solely donor milk for one month? As a rough estimate, if your newborn drinks an average of 20 ounces a day at an average of $4 per ounce, it could cost $80 a day, $560 a week, or $2400 a month to solely feed your baby donor milk.
About the screening process
According to Olofsson, here are the typical steps a potential milk donor will go through:

A potential milk donor is prescreened to make sure they’re a good candidate. They will answer many (many) questions about their health history, her partner’s health history, and her own baby’s health history. The criteria is very detailed. For example, the candidate cannot have ever travelled to certain countries, ever injected drugs or had sex with someone who has injected drugs, taken certain medications while pumping (including progestin-only birth control pills), or regularly consume excess caffeine—to name a few.
Waivers must be signed by the donor’s doctor and her baby’s pediatrician.
Once the donor has been approved, blood work is taken to rule out any diseases that could affect the breast milk (such as HIV, HTLV syphilis, or hepatitis).
If the donor passes all of these steps, she can then send in her breast milk.
The breast milk is received, pasteurized, and bottled—which involves it’s own extensive sterilization process—before it makes its way to you and your baby’s bottle.
How much milk you can get

Unfortunately, milk banks aren’t like Amazon—you can’t usually reorder as you go week after week. Olofsson says the amount you can get really varies from one milk bank to another and will depend on how much milk they have to offer. Some won’t have enough available to fill your order, while others may be able to provide you with a one-time, one-week supply, or more. What’s important to know is that most banks will not be able to provide you with enough to solely rely on donor breast milk to feed your baby so be sure to speak to your baby’s pediatrician about a supplementation plan.
Option B: Purchase breast milk directly from a lactating mother

Getting breast milk directly from a lactating mother may be another option. For example, your sister may have just weaned her child and has an extra freezer stash to share. Or a mother in your neighborhood Facebook group may have some she’d love to donate to another mom in need. There are also sites that sell breast milk online. But it’s important to consider the safety of this option. “Black market” breast milk isn’t screened or regulated by the HMBANA or any other agency. Olofsson cautions against milk from unregulated sources because it’s hard to know if you’re getting the safest milk for your baby. “Unlike getting donated milk from HMBANA, there is no screening process,” Olofsson says. “Online sellers could quite literally be selling you cow’s milk and you’d be none the wiser.”

While friends and family members may be well meaning in sharing their extra breast milk, you still need to be careful. “I always encourage people going this route to speak with their child’s pediatrician first so they know the right questions to ask before giving someone else’s breast milk to their baby,” Olofsson says. “The biggest concern is assuming that the person donating it doesn’t have any blood-borne illnesses or diseases that can be transmitted through breast milk, like HIV, syphilis, or hepatitis B.” But that’s not the only thing. Beyond those serious health risks are also concerns around cleanliness. “Even if there are no known health issues, you don’t know if they sanitized their pump parts to decrease the risk of bacteria, if they stored the milk properly or it sat out too long...all of these little factors can become a serious issue for your baby’s health,” Oloffson says.
The bottom line:

Wanting to feed your baby breast milk is great! Just make sure you can do it safely. Regardless of which route you choose to secure donor milk, always talk to your child’s pediatrician or a pediatrician on Maven first for help deciding what’s truly best for your baby.
Sources
Human Milk Banking Association of North America
La Leche League International

title.en-US: Week 18: Your baby is the size of a sweet potato

content.value: This week, your baby is around 5 1/2 inches and starting to feel a little sensitive. That's because their nerves are forming complex connections that will eventually become their five senses.
What your baby is up to

Sight, sound, smell, taste and touch. Right about now your little one is starting to form the complex nerve connections that make their five amazing senses possible, so when they’re born they’ll be able to experience them all (especially when it comes to you, their favorite person). They’re also able to yawn and are forming myelin—a protective layer around their nerves that will keep forming after they’re born.

If you’re having a girl, her fallopian tubes and uterus are now in place and you may be able to see her external genitalia if you have an ultrasound. (Random fact: The labia may be visible and basically looks like two parallel lines.) If you’re having a boy, his external genitalia may be visible at your next ultrasound as well. Just keep in mind that while it’s super exciting to find out or see your baby’s sex, babies don’t always cooperate during ultrasounds so it can be tough to spot even for your doctor, and they won’t tell you the sex unless they’re absolutely certain. As you can imagine it doesn’t go over well if they guess wrong!
You may also be getting closer to feeling your baby move for the first time. Did you ever think you’d be this excited to get punched in the gut?
What’s new with you

Feeling a little lightheaded? This is the trimester when your blood pressure will be lower than normal. Blood pressure actually drops throughout the beginning of pregnancy and reaches its lowest point around 18-19 weeks. Why? Hormones strike again! Hormonal changes cause your blood vessels to dilate which makes your blood pressure drop. As a result, you may have dizzy spells if you stand up too quickly after sitting or lying down. Take your time rising to avoid it. Another great idea if it happens to you frequently is to have a cold glass of water nearby. Drinking 12-16 oz of water will help normalize your blood pressure and make those floating stars disappear.

Speaking of being horizontal, it’s also a good time to start sticking to lying on your side as much as you can. More specifically, it’s good to sleep on your left side because it rolls the uterus off the vena cava, a major vein, and can increase blood flow to your heart and brain and also to the placenta (that’s a good thing). But don't panic if you roll over onto your back in the middle of the night, because, you know, sleep is important too! If you’re a strict back sleeper or finding it increasingly difficult to get comfy, give a body pillow a shot. They really can help as your belly grows by supporting your back, hips, and stomach.
If your lack of sleep is less about your bump and more about your heartburn, we hear you. Heartburn is very common in pregnancy. Here are some tips:
Eat four to six small meals a day instead of three large ones
Avoid tight-fitting clothing
Finish eating at least three hours before bedtime
Skip foods that make your symptoms worse like coffee, cola, tea, citrus foods, chocolate, and fatty foods
Try raising the head of your bed by six to eight inches or use a styrofoam wedge under your pillow
TUMS and Pepcid are generally safe over the counter heartburn relievers. Just double-check with your doctor or a
Maven OB-GYN
first.
Stay hydrated with plenty of water!
We’re here to help

Around this week, you may be having an anatomy scan, an ultrasound that looks in detail at your baby’s anatomy and development. Wondering what your doctor will be looking for or have follow-up questions? We can explain! Book a video chat with a
Maven OB-GYN
and ask away.

title.en-US: Week 20: Your baby is the size of an artichoke

content.value: Your baby is measuring at about 6 1/2 inches and—exciting update—you may learn their sex! If the angle is just right, you may be able to see their genitals at your ultrasound.
What your baby is up to

This week, your baby is about 6 1/2 inches long and you’re due for another look at their adorableness. Around now you’ll likely have a midterm ultrasound (aka anatomy scan) and depending on your baby's position, you may even be able to find out their sex if you haven’t gotten the results from a blood test. Though they haven’t fully developed yet, your baby’s genitals have grown enough to be spotted by your provider’s well-trained eye. If your baby is a girl, her uterus is fully formed and her vaginal canal is taking shape. She also has in the neighborhood of over six million eggs already in her ovaries, one of which might someday become your grandchild (!!!)...but let’s not get ahead of ourselves here.

Another fun fact: Around this week your baby is also beginning to produce meconium, the black or dark green and tarry stool substance you’ll (be shocked to) see in their first diaper. What’s it made of? A healthy, if unpleasant, combination of the amniotic fluid your baby has swallowed, digestive acids, and dead skin cells. Most babies will pass it in the first few hours or days after being born so prepare yourself.
What’s new with you

You know how every road trip comes with an “are we there yet?” moment, no matter how scenic the view? Consider pregnancy your own very epic (and at times, impossibly long) road trip. The great news is that week 20 marks the unofficial halfway point (woohoo!).

Now, for the not-as-great news: There’s nothing quite like the realization that sleep gets harder even before motherhood officially starts. We don’t have a cure for the occasionally bumpy nights you might be experiencing at this stage in your pregnancy, but we have rounded up a few tricks from our Maven providers.
Leg cramp cures:

Increase your potassium (bananas, oranges, melons, grapefruit, apricots and vitamin K (kale, mustard greens, collard greens, Swiss chard, spinach, broccoli) if you’re experiencing leg cramps at night. If they’re waking you, gently stretch the bottom of the heel up and out, while reaching your toes towards your shins. Walking helps to relieve the cramping, too. Not working? Talk to your doctor or a Maven OB-GYN about taking over the counter magnesium supplements.
Fluff it up:
Placing a body pillow or extra supportive pillow between your legs and underneath your belly as you sleep on your side can help you find a more restful sleep.
Keep your cool:
Light, breathable fabrics help to keep moisture off your body as you combat hormonal night sweats and a fan circulating cool air near you might help as well.

For the working moms out there, now is a great time to start preparing for maternity leave. Start by thinking about and documenting your workload to help your team prep and make the transition as smooth as possible. Not sure where to get started? Start by answering questions like these:
What is your most important project, account, or client and what are some things only you know about them?
Which projects need to be taken over and what will need to happen within the next business quarter?
Who should take over which projects in your absence?
We’re here to help
Prepping for maternity leave can feel overwhelming at first. Chat with a
Maven Career Coach
for tips on how to take it one step at a time so you can go on leave with peace of mind.

title.en-US: Maven’s Fertility Clinic Network

content.value: Selecting a fertility clinic can feel overwhelming. Between success rates, pricing, and patient testimonials, there’s a ton of information to consider. That’s why we’ve done the legwork for you. Maven partners with top fertility clinics in the U.S. and internationally to help you get high-quality care and the best chance at a successful, healthy pregnancy.
How we select fertility clinics
We only partner with fertility clinics that meet or exceed our criteria, like:
Averaging less than 2 embryos transferred per cycle
Greater than 35% of new patients under age 35 achieve a singleton birth
High patient satisfaction ratings
How to get started
Message your Maven Care Advocate

to receive a list of carefully vetted fertility clinics in your area, including success rate stats, and details about any perks available for Maven members. Feel free to mention specific criteria you’re looking for in a clinic or provider!
If you choose to work with one of our Fertility Clinic Partners,
ask your Maven Care Advocate to make an appointment
for you to unlock your perks as a Maven member.
If you choose a top fertility clinic that isn’t one of our partners, rest assured that we vetted them carefully.
Contact them directly to make an appointment.
Remember, as a Maven member you also receive free and unlimited access to our services, including:
24/7 dedicated Care Advocate
Unlimited video chat appointments and messaging with Maven fertility specialists
Live group classes with fertility experts
Evidence-backed resources that answer your questions
If you'd like to discuss your fertility clinic options, message your Care Advocate  today.

title.en-US: Week 29: Your baby is the size of a butternut squash

content.value: At over 15 inches long, your baby is starting to get quite snug in their living quarters. In addition to the gentle kicks you've gotten used to, you may start to feel some sharp elbows as they make space.
What your baby is up to

At 29 weeks, your baby is around 15 inches long and weighs about 2 3⁄4 lbs—that’s about as big as a butternut squash! Their muscles and lungs are maturing and their head is growing too thanks to all of the brain development going on now.

At this stage, the weight gain is real and your baby is growing rapidly, so much so that your little tenant is probably starting to get pretty cramped in there. Don’t be surprised if you start to feel elbow jabs, punches, and full-on tumbles that take your breath away in addition to the gentle kicks you've gotten used to.

Your midwife or OB-GYN might ask you to start counting these little love jabs now, too. Basically, kick counting is a way to get familiar with your baby’s movement patterns so you’re better able to spot if your baby has become less active. We recommend using the "count to 10" method:
Lie down

and be still so you can pay attention to the baby’s movements. Picking a time that they tend to be active (like right after a meal or as you’re trying to go to sleep) can help. Also recommended: a tall glass of cold water, or a meal or snack if you haven’t eaten in 4 or more hours.
Record
how long it takes to get to 10 movements (every punch, kick, roll, hiccup, flutter or any other movement counts!). You can do this on paper or download a kick counting app.
Look over

the results. In general, it should take about the same amount of time every day. If you notice that it takes significantly longer to get to 10 than usual, let your provider know. If you don’t feel 10 movements in 2 hours, go to the hospital to have the baby monitored.
What’s new with you

If you've sailed through your pregnancy so far, consider yourself one of the lucky ones. But right about now even the most peaceful of pregnancies can start to reveal new symptoms as your baby crowds your internal organs. For one, you may get lightheaded when you stand up quickly or change positions. Seeing spots or “stars” is your body’s reaction to sudden changes in position and the abrupt changes in blood pressure that come with it. Try to avoid sitting up suddenly and have a tall glass of cold water if you’re feeling spacey. Staying hydrated helps with so many things in pregnancy and lightheadedness can be a sign of dehydration. If you see “stars” in your vision for more than a few minutes contact your provider to make sure it’s not something more serious like preeclampsia.

You might also experience leg cramps, back pain, indigestion, heartburn, constipation, or even hemorrhoids (are you glowing yet?). Talk to a physical therapist on Maven for back pain tips. Sometimes a few key exercises and/or using a band to support your belly can help. Warm baths are a good idea and can help relieve some of the back pain and other discomforts of pregnancy, but steer clear of saunas and hot tubs. Electric heating pads are also great for getting those back muscles that have been working overtime to relax. As for the rest, keeping up with a balanced diet and staying hydrated can help with some of the digestive issues, and ensure that your baby, who's munching along with you, is eating well, too.
We’re here to help
Need help with kick counting or how to deal with third trimester aches and pains? Book a quick chat with a
Maven OB-GYN
or
Midwife
for help right away!

title.en-US: Everything you need to know about Maven birth plan appointments

content.value: Creating a birth plan is the one of the best things you can do to prepare for labor and delivery. And you don’t have to do it alone! Maven offers free birth plan appointments with trained providers who’ll walk you through the process, step by step. Here’s what you need to know.
What is a birth plan?

A birth plan is a document you create that lays out your preferences for labor and delivery. And it’s much more than just “epidural or no epidural”. It covers who you want with you, how bright or dim you want the lights in the room, what type of monitoring you want while you labor, your pain management preferences, and more. Think of it as a blueprint for your preferred birth experience that you share with your provider. It gets you both on the same page about how the process will ideally go. It’s important to note though that labor rarely goes as planned, so you need to be flexible.
How can a birth plan affect my labor and delivery?

There are a couple of ways creating a birth plan can improve your labor and delivery experience. First, knowing your preferences helps you advocate for what you do and do not want during labor and delivery, and also helps you feel as prepared as possible going in. Second, there’s research that shows having a birth plan in place can improve outcomes. For example, women who complete birth plans are less likely to undergo induction to begin labor, and some studies have shown a significant reduction in C-section rates for women who engage with the birth planning process.
How do I create one?
Maven offers free birth plan appointments where you’ll meet a trained provider and create your birth plan together.
What happens during a birth plan appointment?
You and a Maven provider will walk through
Maven’s birth plan guide
to help you understand important decisions you may need to make and preferences you may have for your labor and delivery.You will then fill out your
Birth preferences checklist
together to make sure no question or preference is left undecided. After, you can share your preferences document with your in-person provider.
Here are a few key topics you’ll cover during your Maven birth plan appointment:
Questions to bring up with your in-person provider before you go into labor, like whether your partner will be allowed to stay with you during recovery
Common reasons for cesareans
Your birth preferences during labor, from pain management to monitoring
Positions you’d like to push in when the time comes
How quickly you’d like your baby placed on your chest for skin-to-skin time after delivery
How you’d like to feed your baby
And much more
What Maven members have to say

We met with an OB-GYN on Maven to learn about creating a birth plan or preferences guide, and also had two 90 minute 1-1 sessions with trained labor and postpartum doulas. Most people would pay hundreds of dollars for that kind of 1-1 time! Their wealth of information and practical experience was helpful, timely, and exactly what we needed. We couldn't believe we had access to their services and knowledge for FREE!
- Maven member

I was pretty lost and overwhelmed by the birth plan as I had no idea what some of those concepts meant. My Maven practitioner was a huge help, and now I feel a lot better and more empowered to advocate for myself and my baby during labor and delivery. -
Maven member
How do I book a birth plan appointment?

Birth plan appointments are available to Maven members starting at week 28 of pregnancy. You can book directly through your dashboard or message your Care Advocate to let them know you’d like to schedule a birth plan appointment and they’ll take it from there. It’s as simple as that!
Are there any materials I should read to help me prepare for my birth planning appointment?
Check out
My Maven birth plan guide
before your appointment to get an idea of the information you’ll go over with your provider during your session.
Explore your
My birth preferences checklist
. Your provider will help you fill this out during your session.
Sources
Reproductive Health
Birth

title.en-US: Food allergy prevention 101

content.value: There’ve been a lot of exciting new developments recently when it comes to food allergies in babies. The old and now outdated way of thinking about food allergy prevention was avoiding peanuts for the first three years of life. We now know that, in fact, the opposite is true: Introducing allergens like peanuts early and often is the best way to help prevent a food allergy for your baby. Dr. Anthony Fauci, the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) Director, further explains, “as it turns out, that [avoiding peanuts] works against the child.” These new recommendations come after recent landmark research found a significant reduction in food allergy risk when parents fed their baby allergens starting at 4-6 months of age.
The landmark research on food allergy prevention

The breakthrough Learning Early About Peanut (LEAP) study showed that introducing peanut significantly lowered a child’s risk of developing a peanut allergy. Other clinical studies, including the Enquiring about Tolerance (EAT) trial and Two-step egg introduction for prevention of egg allergy in high-risk infants with eczema (PETIT) trial, reinforced and expanded on these findings, showing that other allergens (like egg) could also be introduced with a significant reduction in food allergy risk. The key takeaways from these studies for parents include:
Introduce allergens early
- New guidelines recommend introducing allergens at 4-12 months of age. Delaying allergen introduction can put your baby at a higher risk of developing food allergies so don’t delay!
Consistently feed allergens

- In the studies, children were regularly fed allergens for up to 5 years so it’s important to consistently feed allergens—it’s not a one and done situation. “Recent studies show us that oral tolerance requires repeated exposure. In fact, there is no evidence that introducing allergenic foods only once is effective,” explains Board Certified Allergist Katie Marks-Cogan, M.D.
Early allergen introduction is safe

- In the three clinical trials that started early introduction as young as 4 months with over 2,000 babies (including those at a higher risk of developing food allergies with risk factors such as eczema), there weren’t any cases of anaphylaxis or hospitalizations. Furthermore, new research shows introducing allergens in infancy is the safest time, when reactions are these least likely to occur and if they do occur, tend to be mild.
Recipes to introduce peanut to your baby

Peanut is one of the most common food allergies in children and is also most often associated with severe reactions. But it also has the most evidence in favor of early introduction to reduce allergies. Here are some ways to safely introduce peanut to your baby, according to the new NIAID Addendum Guidelines on Peanut Introduction.
Thinned peanut butter
Ingredients:
2 tsp of smooth, all-natural peanut butter
Instructions:
Add 2-3 teaspoons of hot water to the peanut butter
Stir until combined
Let mixture cool
Peanut flour puree
Ingredients:
2 tsp of peanut flour or peanut butter powder
Baby’s favorite puree
Instructions:
Add 2 teaspoons of peanut flour or peanut butter powder to 2 tablespoons of pureed fruit and/or vegetables. Adjust amount of puree to achieve desired consistency.
Find more recipes to introduce peanut to your baby here.
Introduce the most common allergens

Many parents find it difficult to introduce allergens to their baby, especially with new USDA Dietary Guidelines that recommend introducing all of the most common allergens (including peanuts, egg, cow milk products, tree nuts, wheat, crustacean shellfish, fish, and soy) one at a time when your baby starts solids. It’s a lot to tackle!
Sources
The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology
National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
Dietary Guidelines for Americans 2020-2025

title.en-US: Will I have postpartum depression or anxiety if I had it before?

content.value: If you suffered from postpartum depression or anxiety after a previous birth, you may be wondering, and worrying, about whether you’ll feel this way again after this birth. Maven experts explain the risks, how to get support, and the steps you can take today to have a better postpartum experience.
What is PPD and PPA?

Postpartum depression (PPD) and postpartum anxiety (PPA) are perinatal mood and anxiety disorders (or PMADs). PMADs can occur during pregnancy or up to a year after birth. One in seven mothers will experience a PMAD according to the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG)—though some estimates put that number as high as 1 in 5 considering how many mothers never report it. This makes PMADs one of the most common, if not the #1, complication of birth according to the US Preventive Services Task Force.
What do PPD and PPA feel like?

Symptoms of PPD and PPA can feel different to different people and it’s also possible to experience both conditions at once. “Some common symptoms of PPD are a lack of interest or pleasure in activities, persistent irritability, feeling ‘sad’ or ‘empty’, difficulty concentrating or making decisions, changes in appetite and feeling a disconnect from bonding with your baby,” says Maven Mental Health Provider Cynthia Coffelt, LCSW. “PPA may look very similar but with the addition of intrusive thoughts, constant worry about something ‘bad’ happening to your baby or persistent doubts about your ability to safely care for your baby.”
How are PPD and PPA different from the “baby blues”?

Many women experience changes to their mood after birth (as many as 85% of women according to some studies). For some, these “normal” mood disturbances are short-lived, lasting about two weeks after birth. But for many women, these feelings can linger and become intense, affecting their daily lives and their ability to care for themselves and their children.

“Baby blues are usually caused by rapid hormonal shifts in the days following delivery, and sleep deprivation with a newborn probably has an impact as well,” says Maven Midwife Ericka Quezada-York, CNM. “But depression and anxiety are longer-lasting and more pervasive. The timing of PPD and PPA are also different from the baby blues, which usually start when the baby is a few days old and fade away within a couple of weeks. But depression and anxiety can start from pregnancy to any time in the first 12 months after birth.
If I had it before, will I have it again?

The exact causes of PPD or PPA aren’t known but according to the American Psychiatric Association, they’re likely caused by a combination of hormones and “social” factors, like the kind of pregnancy and birth experience you had, or the support around you during the postpartum period. “Sleep deprivation and not having a support network you can turn to are often two of the strongest social risk factors for PPD/PPA,” Coffelt says. “However, experiencing depression during pregnancy or as a result of a traumatic birth experience can also impact the risk of developing a perinatal mood disorder,” Coffelt says. According to some studies, having a history of depression or anxiety or having had PPD or PPA in a previous pregnancy is actually the greatest risk of experiencing it again.
The following factors can increase your risk:
A history of depression or anxiety
PPD or PPA with a previous pregnancy
Difficulty breastfeeding
A high-needs infant or older child
Lacking a support system or having relationship issues
Financial stressors
Having multiples (twins, triplets, etc.)
Stressful events—like pregnancy or birth complications, an illness, or a job loss

“It's important to remember that every pregnancy is unique and just because you experienced PPD/PPA with a previous child, that doesn’t necessarily mean you'll experience it again,” Coffelt says. “Also, those with a previous history of anxiety and depression don't necessarily experience PPD or PPA.”
What can I do about it?

“If you have a history of depression or anxiety, or if you’ve had a perinatal mood disorder in the past, your providers always want to know that information about you,” Quezada-York says. “It helps your providers look out for this as a risk factor. It can be hard to get treatment because when you have depression or anxiety, those symptoms make it difficult to reach out to others. It’s good to know that you have someone on your team in case you need them—whether that’s a therapist or counselor you already know, someone on your health care team like your OB provider or primary care provider, or a provider on Maven.”

Having suffered from a PPD or PPA before doesn’t have to be a sentence for suffering from it again. In fact, studies have found an increased risk of developing mood disorders in the postpartum period if they start during pregnancy and are left untreated.

“Consider the things you found most challenging during your first pregnancy and create an action plan for this pregnancy to help alleviate some of these symptoms,” Coffelt says. “For example, sharing your mental health history with your health care team so they can make recommendations should you need additional care, engaging in therapy proactively prior to delivery and arranging for more social support or help with certain tasks—like helping care for your older children or doing light housework—in the postpartum period can all help,” Coffelt says.
Follow these steps today to make a plan for your mental health:
Tell your provider today
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThe best thing you can do for your mental health, and the health of your baby, is to talk to your doctor or a
mental health provider on Maven

. By informing your doctor about your concerns and risk factors right away, they can help you take extra care of your mental health now and keep an extra eye on how you’re feeling after birth.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Make a treatment plan together
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKTalk to your provider or a
Maven Mental Health Provider

who specializes in maternal mental health. They may recommend talk therapy now and after birth as a first line of defense, or talk therapy combined with medication for more severe cases. Always speak to your doctor before taking medication while pregnant (including prescriptions and over-the-counter) or breastfeeding.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Know the signs

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKKeep a list of common PPA and PPD symptoms and check in with yourself. Sometimes it helps to mark your mood on a daily calendar. You could use a word or an emoji to capture your feelings for the day then look for patterns over time. Adjusting to life with multiple children is definitely trying but if you’ve been feeling more down than up for several weeks, it may be a sign it’s time to ask for help.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Tell loved ones

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKHave a talk with your partner, if you have one, close family members or friends about your experiences with PPD and PPA in the past and your concerns. Describe how you felt and ask them to watch out for signs of trouble so you can get help early. There’s no shame in sharing your experience—in fact, it’s highly likely that someone you tell may have experienced it themselves or know someone who has. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Get help right away

It’s common for mothers to brush off their feelings, especially when their hands are full caring for a newborn and older children or you just don’t want to make a big deal out of it. But PPD and PPA are a big deal and if untreated they can have a lasting impact on you and your family. These are treatable conditions that deserve help. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKMany women won’t see their provider until six weeks after birth but your mental health shouldn’t wait. Call your provider in advance, talk to your child’s pediatrician (who you likely will see very often after birth), or a
mental health provider on Maven
right away. The sooner you get help, the sooner you can get back to feeling more like yourself and enjoying motherhood.
Sources
American Academy of Pediatrics: Depression During & After Pregnancy
US Preventive Services Task Force: Interventions to Prevent Perinatal Depression
Mother To Baby: Depression
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists: Screening for Perinatal Depression
American Psychiatric Association: What is Postpartum Depression?
U.S. National Library of Medicine: Interventions to Prevent Perinatal Depression: A Systematic Evidence Review for the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force
U.S. National Library of Medicine: The long-term psychiatric and medical prognosis of perinatal mental illness
U.S. National Library of Medicine: A Review of Postpartum Depression
The Journal of Midwifery & Women’s Health: Postpartum Depression and Anxiety

title.en-US: How to get twins on the same feeding schedule

content.value: Whether you’re feeding your adorable duo by breast or bottle, you’re team Boppy or My Brest Friend, twins parents everywhere all agree on this one feeding must: Get your twins on a synchronized feeding schedule—STAT. Easier said than done when you’re wrangling two babes with their own (very particular) dining preferences, but according to Maven Pediatrician and Lactation Consultant Amy Brandon, MD, IBCLC, it’s worth the extra effort. Here’s your step-by-step guide to get your twins feeding like clockwork (at least most of the time).
Why synchronizing feeding schedules is a good move

Picture this: You begin your journey by feeding your twins on demand—the only thing is they demand to eat at different times so the moment you’ve finished feeding one, the other starts crying for their meal. The result? Your 30-minute feeding session just turned into a back-to-back feeding hour. Multiply this by 10-12 feedings a day in their first month of life and you’ve become a short-order chef working an all-day shift. See where this is going? Synching feeding schedules can save a lot of precious time and your sanity.
Synced feeding leads to synced sleeping

“Twins who feed at the same time are more likely to learn to sleep at the same time, which is the holy grail for parents of multiples,” Brandon says. That’s because a belly full of breast milk or formula is the baby version of falling into a tryptophan-induced slumber after Thanksgiving dinner. Feeding makes babies feel satiated, secure, and oh so sleepy. So much so that getting their feeding schedule synchronized is the number one tip before even attempting to get their naps and bedtime aligned.
Convinced? Here’s how to make synchronized sipping happen
Take these steps to get both of your babes in the mood for a sip (and then a snooze!) at the same time:
Start from day one

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“As overwhelming as it might seem, see if you can try to nurse or bottle-feed your twins simultaneously from the very first feeding,” Brandon says. “A little too late for that? No worries. The sooner you start, the more quickly they’ll sync so just go ahead and start today.” Setting this schedule at a few weeks or months old will be much easier than waiting until they’re older and more set in their (opposite) ways.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Follow a schedule

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“Though we often encourage singletons to feed ‘on demand’, with multiples it does make sense to try to find and follow a schedule,” Brandon says. “Your nurses will help you figure out a plan starting in the hospital that you can continue once you take your babies home.” Having trouble remembering in the blur that is postpartum recovery? Book a one-on-one video chat with a
lactation consultant
or
pediatrician
on Maven to help you set a schedule.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Enlist help

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“Simultaneous feedings take a lot of practice to master—you’re not an octopus after all,” Brandon says. “Ask the hospital staff to help you get into position and take note of their tips—they have
a lot
of wisdom and experience to share.
Often the hospital will have a lactation consultant visit you as well. If they don’t, ask if one is available or
book a chat with one on Maven

. If you have a partner, make sure they watch and practice so they can help replicate your favorite positions once you’re home. If you’re bottle feeding and have a partner, take one baby each—just make sure they’re feeding at the same time. Purchasing a pillow made specifically for tandem feeding and bringing it with you to the hospital can also help immensely. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
When one baby cries, feed both

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThis part is key to synchronizing. Even if just one twin asks to eat, feed them both. If the other refuses to feed, don’t force it but keep offering to both at the same time. “Newborn babies will often feed at least a little bit whenever offered which is why you’re most likely to find success starting from the first sips,” Brandon says.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Wake a sleeping baby (shudder, but hear us out)

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKWe know, this one is tough to hear when newborn slumber is so hard to come by but it’s a must for getting your duo synched as soon as possible. “If one twin is giving you hunger cues but the other is snoozing away, take a deep breath and wake the other for a feeding as well,” Brandon says. “Luckily babies often don’t fully wake to feed and before long they’ll both be hungry at the same time, so you won’t have to commit heinous sleep crimes for long.”
Remember, you will get through this

Synching twin feeding schedules will take time and (a lot of) patience, but you will get through it and it’ll be worth it. “If you’re more structured about their feeding routine, you’ll hopefully see your twins’ schedules start to sync within a few weeks to a month,” Brandon says. By being consistent from the beginning, you’re more likely to reap the rewards in the end.

Some research indicates that identical twins may have an easier time matching up feeding schedules than fraternal twins, in part because they have the same DNA. That said, as babies grow and their personalities are influenced by environmental factors, any twin types can fall out of sync.
