Same goes for if you’re traveling, your twins are sick, Mercury is in retrograde, it’s a Wednesday—you get the idea. Hiccups will happen, just try your best to ride them out and keep it as consistent as possible.

“If your babies just won’t cooperate for simultaneous feedings, try back to back,” Brandon says. “This can help free up extra hands and keep your twins on a similar, if not identical, schedule.” If your duo is made up of two true individuals who are having none of it, take heart that they will find a rhythm eventually—even if it ends up being to the beat of their own drums.
We’re here to help
Having a tough go? You’re not alone. Getting to a good nursing or bottle feeding routine is hard in general and even harder when you have multiple mouths to feed. Talk to a
pediatrician
or a
lactation consultant
on Maven for one-on-one help at any time, day or night. They can help you find comfortable positioning, troubleshoot latching or supply issues, and advise on formula needs for your babies.

title.en-US: How to synchronize your twins’ sleep schedule

content.value: Once upon a time, after 45 minutes of rocking and shushing, your second twin finally drifts off to slumberland. You tiptoe out of the room, click the nursery door shut, and let out a sigh of sweet, sleep-deprived relief. Then it happens—the first twin who fell asleep an hour earlier lets out a five-alarm wail that wakes the whole house. If we just described every night this week, or you’re planning ahead, fear not. Maven Pediatric Sleep Coach Tracie Kesatie explains how to avoid this waking nightmare by getting your twins on a synchronized sleep schedule.
Why syncing your twins’ sleep is so worth it

There are many (many) sleep philosophies out there and ultimately, it’s your choice which one works best for your family. That said, sleep deprivation can be multiplied by twins if they’re on different sleep schedules—when one is up, the other is down and that means you never catch a break. How’s a twin mom supposed to “sleep when the baby sleeps”? By synchronizing your twins’ sleep schedule as soon as possible.

“Having twins on the same (or similar) sleep schedule can make life so much easier for parents,” Kesatie says. “Otherwise you can end up in a situation where you feel like there’s always a baby awake and you never get the rest that you need, too.”

Remember, taking care of your wellbeing is just as important as taking care of your babies, and getting rest is a big part of that. You’re recovering from pregnancy and childbirth and your body needs downtime in order to heal. Prolonged sleep deprivation not only slows this physical recovery down, but it can also have a big impact on your mental health.
When to attempt it

The sooner the better. Because newborns can sleep upwards of 18 hours a day, you’ll have a lot of opportunities to try to get them down at the same time. If you gave birth in a hospital or birth center, or you hired a postpartum doula, take full advantage of years of infant sleep wisdom at your disposal. Your nurse or postpartum doula can help you set a sleep schedule from day one. Often, you’ll be asked to record your babies’ sleep, feedings, and diaper changing times while in the hospital. Bring this sheet home with you so you can keep it going or use a baby tracker app like
Baby Connect
or
Sprout
Even if your twins are a bit older, it’s never too late! Start following these tips today and talk to a
pediatric sleep coach
on Maven for more personalized advice based on how old your babies are and your family’s schedule.
Should twins sleep together or alone?

Your little duo has spent the past nine-ish months snug as bugs together in the womb. But now that they’re on the outside, you might be wondering if they should stick together or sleep alone. Although multiples are often kept in the same bed in hospitals, there simply hasn’t been enough research to say whether it’s safe or beneficial. As a result, the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends that twin parents follow the same safety recommendations as singleton parents and keep their twins in separate cribs or bassinets.

What we do know is that infants who sleep with other children or parents are at four times the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) according to the AAP. What’s more, multiples are at an already increased risk of SIDS if they’re born preterm and a bed buddy may increase this risk due to overheating, rebreathing each others’ carbon dioxide, or accidental suffocation (particularly if one twin is bigger than the other).

And before you start searching for a bigger place, “for safety reasons, I recommend twins sleeping in their own separate sleep space (crib, bassinet, Snoo, etc.),” Kesatie says. “However, since twins typically learn to sleep through each other’s noises, sharing a room is fine.”
How to sync your twins’ sleep schedules
Now that you’ve got all the background info, it’s time to give sleep syncing a try! Follow these tips to get started:
Sync feeding first

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKEating and sleeping are closely linked, so sync your twins’ feeding schedule first. Whether you’re feeding by breast or bottle, feed both babies around the same time to increase the odds they’ll get sleepy around the same time, too. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“I recommend feeding twins within 15 minutes of each other so that their schedules stay fairly synced,” Kesatie says. “So if one newborn twin wakes up to eat, then wake the other to eat within 15 minutes so that you don’t end up with the other baby waking to eat an hour later.” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn how to sync your twins’ feedings
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Ask for a hand

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKGetting two babies down at once is going to take a few extra hands. After a feeding, enlist your partner, support person, hired help, or a baby rocker to help soothe as much as it takes to get both babies sleepy simultaneously.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Put them to bed at the same time

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKAfter you’ve fed and soothed them, put both babies down in their own crib or bassinet at the same(ish) time. Even if they don’t both fall instantly asleep (or at all), this will start the signal that after feeding, comes sleeping. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Keep it up

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKSet the schedule and keep it going: Feed, sleep, repeat (again, an online tracker can really help with this). As they get a little older you can add new activities, just keep it the same every day: Play, feed, sleep, repeat. Even if one twin isn’t showing hunger cues or one lies awake while the other snoozes, so long as you’re consistent, both will start to get
Z
message.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Next steps

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKAround 4-6 months old, your twins may be ready for self-soothing. Once you get your pediatrician’s okay, work on putting your babies down drowsy, but not fully asleep so they can practice falling asleep on their own. This will help with getting your twins to sleep through the night (the dream!).
What if it doesn’t work?

It can take several weeks or months to get twins on the same schedule—but when it works, it’s so worth it (like, several-hours-to-yourself-a-day worth it). “While it can take some time for twins to get on the same schedule, the more consistent you are with trying to sync their feeding and sleeping routines, the faster things will settle into place and the easier it should become,” Kesatie says.

But keep in mind that if your twins were born preterm or at a lower birth weight, it may take longer for them to reach certain milestones, including sleep schedules. And fraternal twins may also have a harder time syncing than identical twins who share the same DNA.

That said, babies in general have a mind of their own, even if they did share a womb. Some days even the most steadfast schedule will go right out the window. If your babies are teething, are sleeping in an unfamiliar place, or they just won’t sync, it’s OK. Try your best to get their schedules as close together as you can and celebrate the upshot of getting a little quality time with each of them. And while QT time doesn’t help your bleary eyes, rest assured that one day you’ll be knocking on their doors to get up at noon.
We’re here to help
Baby sleep is exhausting. Talk to a
Maven Pediatric Sleep Coach
anytime for one-on-one advice, including how to sync your twins’ sleep schedules, when to sleep train, and how to get everyone back to bed.
Sources
American Academy of Pediatrics: SIDS and Other Sleep-Related Infant Deaths
American Academy of Pediatrics: Cobedding Twins and Higher-Order Multiples in a Hospital Setting

title.en-US: How to plan ahead for postpartum with twins

content.value: Soon you’ll finally get to meet the dynamic duo that’s been kicking up a storm in your belly. And while many moms-to-be spend their final pregnancy weeks focused on birth, it’s just as important to make a postpartum plan—especially with twins. You’ll have two newborns who need lots of care, but you’ll need plenty of TLC, too. Maven Nurse Practitioner and twin mom Rebecca Callahan, MSN, WHNP-BC, shares her top ten tips to help you start preparing for double duty during recovery.
How to plan ahead for postpartum with twins

Soon you’ll finally get to meet the dynamic duo that’s been kicking up a storm in your belly. And while many moms-to-be spend their final pregnancy weeks focused on birth, it’s just as important to make a postpartum plan—especially with twins. You’ll have two newborns who need lots of care, but you’ll need plenty of TLC, too. Maven Nurse Practitioner and twin mom Rebecca Callahan, MSN, WHNP-BC, shares her top ten tips to help you start preparing for double duty during recovery.
1. Make a milk plan (and a backup plan)

As soon as your twins are born, it’s go-time. The World Health Organization (WHO) encourages feeding within the first hour after birth. If you delivered in a hospital, your nurse will usually help but there are steps you can take now to make this first foray into tandem feeding a little easier.
Breastfeeding and pumping

It can take a few days for your breast milk to come in so your twins will nurse on colostrum at first. During this time, babies tend to lose weight and your pediatrician will be looking for them to get back to their birth weight within the first two weeks. This combination of waiting for your milk, learning how to tandem feed, and watching your babies’ weight drop can be stressful. Here’s how to plan ahead to ease undue anxiety:
Book an appointment with a
lactation consultant on Maven
. Learn twin-specific breastfeeding tips like how to tandem feed and how to determine if both babies are eating enough.
Cozy up with your breast pump.

If your twins are born early or need to spend time in the NICU, or you're having trouble nursing, a breast pump can become essential. If you’ve been avoiding unboxing, or haven’t gotten a pump, now’s a great time to get familiar.
Have a backup plan.

“Many mothers of twins breastfeed and supplement with formula or donated breast milk,” Callahan says. This isn’t to say exclusively breastfeeding twins isn’t possible, but that having a Plan B can help you relax (and relaxing can help you breastfeed!). Talk to your pediatrician or a
pediatrician on Maven
now for help choosing a breast milk bank or formula to have on-hand.
Formula
If you plan to formula feed exclusively or in combination with breast milk, talk to a
pediatrician on Maven

for recommendations and pack some in your hospital bag. There are many formulas to choose from, but rest assured that within the U.S., any formula on the shelves has been approved by the F.D.A. for safety and will provide all of your twins’ essential nutrients.
Learn how to pick a formula
Donated breast milk

If you want your twins to have breast milk but aren’t able to breastfeed or need to supplement, donated breast milk is another option. Talk to your pediatrician or hospital to get a recommendation for an accredited milk bank and make a plan early. “Milk banks often have long waiting lists and babies born prematurely or with health conditions usually take priority,” Callahan says.
Learn more about donated breast milk
2. Give yourself (ample) time to recover

In addition to getting the hang of double everything, you’ll be recovering from carrying and delivering two babies. No matter how you delivered, give your body time to heal. For a vaginal delivery, expect 3 to 6 weeks or longer. For a cesarean delivery, expect 4 to 8 weeks or longer. A C-section is a major abdominal surgery and your body will need extra care.

“I had a vaginal delivery and tear with my daughter and then a C-section with my twins two years later,” Callahan says. “Neither recovery was easy. Be patient with yourself and give yourself enough time to heal.” And always follow your provider’s restrictions after birth. Avoid lifting anything heavier than one of your babies at a time for the first 4 weeks after surgery (double car seats included!). Pushing yourself too fast, too soon can cause serious issues. Increased bleeding, increased pain, split stitches—these are all signs that you’re overdoing it.

In addition to the more obvious recovery aches and pains, many mothers (and twin moms especially) can experience issues that they don’t share. “All women should see a pelvic floor physical therapist after delivery to help with everything your body has been through, and to avoid or fix issues like diastasis recti (the separation of your abdominal muscles) and incontinence,” Callahan says. Make a plan to talk to a
physical therapist
in person or on Maven in addition to meeting with your OB-GYN for your six-week checkup.
3. Plan ahead for your mental health
Even if your physical recovery takes 6 weeks,
feeling

like yourself again may take longer. Adjusting to being a twin mom while strapped to a postpartum hormone roller coaster can be really hard on your mental health. According to several studies, mothers of multiples are at higher risk for postpartum mood disorders such as depression or anxiety. Because you likely won’t see your OB-GYN for 3 to 6 weeks after delivery, make a plan now to talk about your mental health before that.
Postpartum mood disorders are common (some estimates put the number of moms affected by them as high as 1 in 5) and treatable. Before your due date, book an appointment with a
mental health provider on Maven

to talk through how you’re feeling about birth, becoming a twin parent, your relationship, financial stressors or anything else on your mind. By starting this relationship now, you’ll have someone (literally) in your back pocket to check in with postpartum.
4. Don’t just accept help, ask for it ahead of time

A great way to protect your mental health is to make a plan to have help. For the first few weeks postpartum, assume that you’ll only have time to care for your twins and rest. List out all the other tasks like cleaning, cooking, laundry, dog walking, etc. and ask your support system to pitch in or hire a pro. When everyone knows the drill ahead of time you can focus on your twins and your recovery. If you already have a child at home, make a plan for them to get extra attention, too, like scheduled trips to the park with a family member or your partner.
5. Consider hiring a postpartum doula or nanny

An adoring grandparent is great, but even they have limits—like helping with twin feedings at 12am, 2am, and 4am. To ensure that you have plenty of baby care help and get much-needed rest, consider hiring a professional. Even if it’s just for the first week or two, the temporary added expense may be worth it (or make a great group registry gift!):
A postpartum doula

is an excellent support person for right after birth. Their main focus is on mom’s physical and emotional recovery and helping your family transition into twin parenthood. A postpartum doula can provide information and support on everything from how your body is healing to helping you learn how to feed and care for your babies. Many postpartum doulas also do overnight shifts to help feed and soothe your babies back to sleep so you can get some shut-eye. They can also help you establish good feeding and sleeping routines.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn more about postpartum doulas
A nanny
can offer daytime help with the twins, freeing you up to do other tasks or just have a minute to yourself. They can be especially helpful as you or your partner transition back to work.
6. Make frozen meals your friend

You may not be able to survive solely on takeout and foodie friends when juggling twins so cook up some hearty, healthy meals now and freeze them (think: bean soups, veggie-loaded lasagna, or cauliflower rice). Stock up on healthy snacks, too, for late night cravings (think: Greek yogurt, hummus, baby carrots, and mixed nuts). “Good nutrition is absolutely key to recovery of your body and also for your state of mind,” Callahan says. “Being sleep-deprived and hangry can make this recovery period harder for everyone. And if you’re breastfeeding twins, be prepared to eat like a teenage boy.”
7. Invest in a few extras

Two hands for two babies. That math works, right? Not exactly. Even if you have a partner or support person, having twins means that both of your hands are always full and no one has a free hand for all the other things that need doing. Before your babes arrive, invest in a few extra places to safely plant them:
(2) infant pillows (like Dock-a-Tot or Boppy newborn lounger) where your little ones can lay before they’re able to sit up
(1) tandem feeding pillow for feeding both twins at once by bottle or breast
(1) glider or swing your twins can alternate out of (can be great for soothing)
(1) playmat they can share for tummy time
(1) exersaucer they can alternate out of when they’re starting to stand
When in doubt, remember: Your babies can’t fall off the floor and it’s OK to plant them there when you really need to use the bathroom.
8. Know that logistics will be tough at first

Maybe you envisioned dropping into mommy and me yoga while baby-wearing, but getting a hang of twin-wrangling will take time. Make sure you’re able to get out and connect with others (when you’re ready) by setting expectations beforehand.
Tell well-meaning friends and family now that they’re welcome to come visit when you give the go-ahead. They can expect to rock, feed, burp, or change a newborn diaper (
and

they should bring lunch). When you’re ready to venture out, skip the sing-a-longs at first and plan on simply bringing your kiddos outside for fresh air at a park. “A double snap-n-go style stroller is all you’ll really need for the first few months,” Callahan says. “Basically, it’s a foldable base with wheels you can snap two car seats into so it functions as a double stroller for getting around.”
9. Accept that this is a learning experience

Knowing how to be a mom to twins isn’t something you’re born with—it’s something that you learn how to do a little more each day. After all, this is probably your first time caring for two babies at once and neither comes with an instructional manual! “During my identical twins' first year, so many people asked me how the boys' personalities differed,” Callahan says. “At first it made me feel really inadequate. Finally I realized that it's okay if I couldn't perceive huge differences in their baby styles just yet. I was doing my best and that is enough.”
So when there are days—and, oh, there will be days—when it feels like you can’t get anything right, make a plan to give yourself some grace. Write this down and put it where you’ll see it:
I learned a lot today
. And as each month goes by, take a moment to give yourself credit for how far you’ve already come in becoming a really great twin mom.
10. And remember, we’re here to help

Anytime you need to speak to a pediatrician without hauling two car seats around, have concerns about your recovery, or you’re just feeling overwhelmed—we’re here for you. Talk to pediatricians, OB-GYNs, mental health providers, nurse practitioners, lactation consultants, pediatric sleep coaches and more anytime on Maven.
Sources
World Health Organization
National Health Service

title.en-US: Is exclusively breastfeeding twins realistic?

content.value: The short answer is: Yes! If your goal is to exclusively breastfeed your twins, it is possible and we’re here to help you achieve it. Maven Midwife and Lactation Consultant Nina Wilson answers the most common questions moms-to-be of multiples have, including how twin breastfeeding works, what to expect, and how a backup plan can help ease stress (even if you never need to use it).
Will I be able to make enough milk?

“This is a very common concern for new parents of twins,” Wilson says. “In most cases the answer is yes, you will be able to make enough milk. Focusing on your babies latching well in the beginning and feeding them often is very important with twins and will help you establish and maintain your milk supply.”

Simply put, breastfeeding is a supply and demand system. Every time you breastfeed, milk is removed from your breasts and this sends a signal to your body to produce more. When you breastfeed twins, more milk is removed so your body gets the message to make
more
milk in response. “Meeting with a lactation consultant before your babies are born and soon after delivery to help establish a plan for feeding your babies is also a great idea,” Wilson says.
How will I know if my babies are eating enough?
Unlike bottles, breasts don’t come with conveniently marked fluid ounce labels. So how do you know how much your twins are getting, and if it’s enough?
Weight gain

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“There are several ways to make sure your babies are eating enough,” Wilson says. “The most obvious reassuring sign is adequate weight gain. After your more mature milk comes in—usually between days 2-4 after birth—your babies should gain around an ounce a day and regain their birth weight by around 2 weeks of age (for full-term twins; preterm twins may take longer to regain their birth weight).” Make sure to bring your twins to all of their pediatric appointments so their doctor can weigh them.
Breast changes

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKWhile you’re breastfeeding, “you should be able to see active sucking and swallowing and your breasts should feel significantly softer after your babies feed,” Wilson says. “These are both signs of good milk transfer.”
Dirty diapers

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKAnother great indicator is soiled diapers. Pay attention to how much urine and stool your babies make. “In the first 4 days of life your babies’ wet and dirty diapers should be the same as the day of life,” Wilson says. “For example, on day 1 each baby should have at least 1 wet (urine) and at least one dirty (stool) diaper. By day 4 your babies should have at least 4 wet and 4 dirty diapers. From day 5 on, your babies should have at least 6-8 wet diapers and at least 4-6 dirty diapers per day for at least the first month.”

In the first foggy month of twin life, it helps to track all of this information through an app or jot it down in a notebook so you can look for patterns, keep track of each baby individually, and share this information with your pediatrician. You’ll have several pediatric appointments soon after your babies are born where they’ll be weighed to make sure they’re eating enough. But if you ever have any doubts, don’t wait for these appointments. Reach out to your pediatrician or a
pediatrician
or
lactation consultant
on Maven right away.
How often will I need to breastfeed?

Feeding your babies on demand means looking for signs that they’re hungry and responding by offering them the opportunity to nurse. In their first month, aim for about every 2-3 hours, or 8-10 times a day. Look for signs that they’re hungry including opening their mouths, rooting around in search of your breast, or crying.
What are some challenges of twin feeding?
Breastfeeding can be challenging for any parent, but a parent of twins has a few extra hurdles to keep in mind.
Early birth

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKMany twins are born before preterm (before 37 weeks of gestation). The upside is that twins born preterm can especially benefit from breastfeeding because your milk will adjust to their unique nutritional needs. However, if your twins are born very preterm (before 32 weeks) and haven’t developed the ability to suck and swallow, you may not be able to breastfeed directly from the breast. In these cases, you’ll need to pump your breastmilk so that it can be fed to them by tube or a special cup. Ask your hospital about using a hospital grade breast pump to help you do this.
Low birth weight

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKBabies tend to lose weight after birth while they’re learning how to feed and your breast milk supply is building up. If either twin is born at a low birth weight, you may feel pressure to make sure they’re eating enough and gaining weight which can cause added stress. Work closely with your
pediatrician
and
lactation consultant
for help making sure your babies are latching well and gaining weight.
Latching issues

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKAs with singletons, it’s always possible that one or both babies won’t latch well. A good latch is essential to breastfeeding and ensuring that your babies get enough milk—and that breastfeeding isn’t painful beyond the usual soreness as your nipples adjust to being worked around-the-clock. “Sometimes if one baby is latching better than the other it’s helpful to tandem feed because the less efficient nursing baby will benefit from the letdown (aka faster milk flow) stimulated by the more vigorous feeder,” Wilson says. Ask if there’s a lactation consultant on staff where you deliver your twins or book an appointment with a
lactation consultant on Maven
anytime for latching tips.
Mismatched schedules

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKAt first, your baby’s meal times may not be aligned which can leave you feeling like an all-night Dairy Queen. Try your best to synchronize your twin’s feeding schedules from day one. Even if one is crying for milk while the other is snoozing away, wake the other twin and feed both at the same time. Getting your duo on the same dining schedule will not only give you a break between feedings, but also help establish your supply. Plus (and this is a big one), it’s the first step to synchronizing their sleep. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn how to synchronize your twins’ feeding schedules
Logistics

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKWhile the math of having two breasts and two babies makes sense, getting each baby to each breast is something else entirely. After you deliver your babies in the hospital, ask your nurse to help you get into position to tandem feed and have your partner or support person take notes so they can repeat it. It will take an extra hand and getting a twin breastfeeding pillow can help.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf either baby is struggling to latch or trying to feed them simultaneously is causing more stress than milk drunk bliss, start with one after the other. This can still help build supply and begin to get your babies on a similar schedule while allowing you to focus on helping one baby get a solid latch at a time. As your babies grow they’ll be able to control their heads a little more and find their own way into position, making tandem feeding more doable.
How can I prepare in advance?
“Breastfeeding twins definitely adds some unique challenges to your breastfeeding journey,” Wilson says. “Being as prepared as possible by meeting with a
lactation consultant on Maven

or in person prior to delivery and attending a twin breastfeeding class will help you have the best start possible. There are many different ways to breastfeed twins. A lactation consultant can help you customize your breastfeeding plan to your babies and your unique circumstances.”

Be sure to also share your wishes to exclusively breastfeed with your care team before your delivery date. This is a great point to have written out in your birth plan so your hospital care team can help you achieve your goal.
What if my milk doesn’t come in or doesn’t come in fast enough?

In the first days after your twins are born, they’ll nurse on colostrum (or “first milk”). This thick, nutrient-rich substance produced by your body provides everything your babies need. In about 2-4 days after birth, your milk will start to “come in.” It takes some time, and a lot of breastfeeding, to trigger breast milk production and for some, breast milk may not come in despite every effort.

“Under normal circumstances colostrum is the perfect first food for babies in the early days and contains all of the nutrients they need as well as beneficial antibodies for a healthy immune system,” Wilson says. “Unless there are medical reasons for formula supplementation, colostrum is all your babies need. Remember that it’s normal for babies to lose up to 10% of their birth weight during this time and the weight begins to increase after your mature milk comes in.”

This time period can be nerve-wracking as you’re trying to keep up with the demands of your twins and trying to help them gain back their birth weight. Work closely with your hospital nurses, pediatrician, and lactation consultant or speak with a
pediatrician
or a
lactation consultant
on Maven to ensure your babies are eating enough during this important stage and have a backup plan in place just in case (more on that next!).
What kind of backup plan should I have?

Committing to exclusively breastfeeding your twins is half the battle and can help keep you motivated to achieve your goal. That said, breastfeeding can be very challenging with a lot of factors at play—some of which may be out of your control. Having support at your fingertips and “just in case” sustenance as a backup can help put your mind at ease and ensure that your babies get the nutrition they need should there be any breastfeeding hurdles.

Before heading to the hospital, make sure to have your backup feeding plan in place. This may include bringing infant formula with you and having a stash at home, lining up donated breast milk, or both. Remember, having a Plan B in place doesn’t mean you can’t exclusively breastfeed! It means you’re fully prepared to help your babies thrive, and that’s the most important thing of all.
“Having a good support system is crucial during the early days of breastfeeding, especially with twins,” Wilson says. “Reach out for help from a
Maven lactation consultant
with any questions or concerns. We’re here to help you navigate this often overwhelming time and to help you reach your breastfeeding goals.”
Learn how to choose the best infant formula
Learn more about donated breast milk
Sources
Mayo Clinic
La Leche League

title.en-US: The best way to breastfeed twins

content.value: At first, breastfeeding twins can make you feel like an octopus trying to pole vault. There’s a lot of wiggling and suckers, but nothing quite seems to land. The truth is that it’s going to take practice and that the best way to breastfeed twins is whatever way works for you. That said, it can definitely help to show up to the twin mom Olympics with a bit of training. Maven Midwife and Lactation Consultant Nina Wilson shares her tried-and-true tips for tackling twin nursing.
1. Sync to save time

Even if they’re identical or were born mere minutes apart, twins don’t necessarily do everything the same way. It’s not uncommon for Twin A and Twin B to be hungry at entirely different times of the day which can turn nursing into a full-time job. Try your best to get both babies on the same nursing schedule so you can catch a break in-between feeds. If they’re just not cooperating (and babies are known for this) or one twin is having trouble latching, try feeding them back-to-back instead. This will give you some one-on-one time with each twin while you all get the hang of this breastfeeding thing. Remember, this is all new to them, too!

Bonus: “Tandem feeding is extra helpful when one twin is a stronger feeder than the other,” Wilson says. “The baby who is having more difficulty feeding will benefit from the letdown (aka your faster milk flow) stimulated by the other twin.”
Learn how to sync twin feeding schedules
2. Get a lift from a twin breastfeeding pillow

Does a breastfeeding pillow seem like more unnecessary baby “stuff”? You can make twin feeding work with pillows you already own but you may not want to be struggling to perfectly stack lumpy throw pillows when you have two crying babies at 3 a.m. A made-for-twins breastfeeding pillow like the Twin Z or My Brest Friend Twin Nursing Pillow can make breastfeeding more efficient (so you can get back to bed!). They provide an even lift to help get your babies to your breasts and give your tired arms and back a rest.
Pro tip: Put two twin breastfeeding pillows on your registry and have ready-to-go nursing stations set up in key areas, like the nursery and living room.
3. Find your favorite position

Some breastfeeding positions will just feel more comfortable to you than others and some will help your babies get a better latch. It’ll be a bit of trial and error once your twins arrive but here are some breastfeeding positions that tend to work well when you’re wrangling two:
REPLACEWITHASSET
Best for tandem nursing:
The double football hold where you have one baby tucked under your arm like a football on each side, their feet towards your back.
Best for preemies:
Preemies are more likely to have difficulty nursing so the double football hold is also a great option for babies who need a little more help latching.
Best for picky eaters:

The football/cradle combination is a great way to meet the needs of each of your babies, especially if one latches better than the other. Hold the twin who nurses like a champ in the cradle position, supported by your arm with their body running along your waist. And hold the twin in need of a little more help forming a good latch in the football hold.
Best for bleary-eyed mornings:

Once you’ve gotten the hang of breastfeeding, try the side-lying or reclined positions. If you’re feeding one at a time, you can lie on your side facing Twin A lying on their side as well. For two, you create a kind of in-bed recliner with pillows so your back is slightly propped up. Then lean back and have your support person place your babies on either side of you. Your babies spoon your waist and you get to relax.
If trying to visualize, let alone pull these off, feels like a cruel form of origami, talk to the hospital staff or jump on a quick video chat with a
Maven Lactation Consultant
. They can help walk you through how to get your little ones into position and find what works best for you and your babies.
4. Take it one latch at a time

“A good latch is crucial to successful breastfeeding,” Wilson says. “It’s important to unlatch your baby (insert your finger between your nipple and baby’s mouth) and then readjust a painful latch every time to prevent nipple damage and to make sure there’s good milk transfer. Pain is always a sign that a baby's latch is not quite right and should be evaluated by a lactation consultant if you’re not able to adjust for a comfortable latch on your own.”

That said, getting two babies to form a good latch simultaneously is tough. Start by latching one baby at a time, even if you’re tandem feeding. When Twin A is successfully latched, then get Twin B into position with help from your support person. “As your babies develop better head control, it’s sometimes helpful to latch one baby with the help of a sling carrier which can often give you two hands to latch the second baby,” Wilson says.
5. Remember to switch sides

Babies can quickly develop favorite breasts and one baby may be better at breastfeeding than another. To keep your supply evened out (and avoid lopsided breasts), switch it up at each feeding. So if Twin A nursed on the left breast at the last feeding and Twin B nursed on the right, have them switch spots for the next feeding. You can assign a colored hair band or teething bracelet to each baby and keep them on your wrists to help you remember who fed on which side last.

“Switching sides and babies each feed is helpful to keep your supply even in both breasts,” Wilson says. “But don't stress if you get confused at times about who was where at the last nursing session. It’s not likely to cause a problem if it’s only happening occasionally.”
6. Practice, practice, practice

You don’t have to wait for your duo to arrive to start getting the hang of double breastfeeding. Give the above positions a simulated test drive with a couple of baby dolls or plush animals. True, your babies will be wigglier, but practicing in advance can help getting into position come more naturally. It also really helps to practice with your partner or support person so they know how they can assist you.
7. Mother yourself

Constantly creating breastmilk is a huge undertaking, especially on limited sleep. To help your body stay up to the task, be sure to take care of yourself too. Eat healthy foods (you’ll be ravenous and will need the extra calories!) and drink plenty of water. This is also a great job for your support person. They can help you make sure you have a nice tall glass of water and some healthy snacks when you’re nursing.

“Hydrating is important so drink to thirst, but know that drinking extra fluids won't increase your supply,” Wilson says. “Frequent and effective milk removal is the best way to keep supply up. However, make sure you’re eating extra healthy snacks because restricting calories while breastfeeding can negatively impact supply.”
8. Ask for help!
Breastfeeding in general, and tandem feeding especially, takes time to master. Take a
breastfeeding class on Maven

or a twin-specific class before your twins arrive. Once your babies are born, take full advantage of the highly experienced nurses and lactation consultants at your hospital or book a video chat with a
lactation consultant on Maven
for expert tips and help with positioning. Getting support quickly can help you overcome breastfeeding challenges and make the experience better for all three of you.

With all the setup and coordination, twin nursing sessions may take up a lot of time at first. But with help and plenty of practice, it will begin to feel like a choreographed dance and the day you pull off a tandem feed while scrolling your phone will feel like winning the Olympics indeed.
** Sources**
Mayo Clinic
La Leche League

title.en-US: What's the link between race and preterm birth?

content.value: Around 1 in 10 infants in the U.S. arrive preterm, meaning they’re born before 37 weeks of gestation. Many preterm babies are completely healthy, but the earlier they’re born, the higher the risk of health complications.
There are a few things you can do to prevent the likelihood of preterm labor.
If you smoke tobacco or use drugs, you can get help to stop those habits
Focus on eating a nutritious diet—a lack of nutrients is linked to preterm birth
Stay active—regular exercise can decrease your risk of preterm birth
Physicians can monitor you for infections that make preterm birth more likely and help you manage your stress levels
But there are some factors putting you at a higher risk for preterm birth that you really can’t control, and one of those is race.
Who’s at risk of having a preterm birth?
Risk factors for preterm birth include:
Being a teenager or over the age of 35
Prior preterm delivery
Experiencing first trimester bleeding
IVF pregnancy
Uterine malformations
Being a preterm baby yourself
Pregnancy with multiples
Infection
Tobacco use
Substance use
Stress
Being Black

That last point may be surprising, but Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) data says that Black moms in the U.S. have a preterm birth rate of 14.4%, compared to 9.3% for white moms and 10% for Hispanic moms.
Why are Black moms at a higher risk?

“We don't really know why it happens,” says Maven OB-GYN Kathleen Green, MD. Research suggests there are some factors linked to genetics or the immune system, but there isn’t conclusive evidence. “It could be access to care. It could be due to social determinants of health. And stress has been shown to be a contributing factor.”
Access to care

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKBlack and Hispanic women are more likely to have late access or no access to prenatal care. The March of Dimes explains that having prenatal care lowers your risk of preterm birth because you miss out on tests and physical exams that can identify potential problems, plus recommendations from your doctor on how to have a healthy pregnancy. According to CDC data from 2019, 82.8% of white women received prenatal care during their first trimester, compared to 72.1% of Hispanic women and 67.6% of Black women. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKOne possible reason for this is a lack of health insurance coverage. According to the Kaiser Family Foundation, 7.8% of non-elderly white American adults are uninsured, compared to 11.4% of Black adults and 20% of Hispanic adults. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKLiving in a “maternity care desert” will also affect someone’s access to care. An estimated 2.2 million women of childbearing age in the U.S. live in a county with no hospital that offers obstetric care, no birth center, and no OB-GYNs or Certified Nurse Midwives. Research suggests that counties with fewer obstetric services often have a lower average household income and a higher level of Black residents in the community. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Social determinants of health

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKGreen explains that your social determinants of health are the places you live, work, and grow, and says that they have a huge affect on our health. “For example, imagine you live in a city that has no green space, no safe place for you to walk outside, that has tons of pollution, that has no grocery store near you, that has no public transportation,” she says.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKSomeone living there will have a different pregnancy experience from a mom who lives in a safe, walkable city close to a maternity care provider, with plentiful options for fresh, nutritious food. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKOther social determinants of health include having a support system, getting access to education and job opportunities, how fluently you speak the local language and how comfortable you are with medical terms, literacy, exposure to violence, and access to technology. All of these things affect your stress levels, which can also affect your health. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Unknown factors

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKWhile socioeconomic status may play a part, it’s not the full story. One study examined birth certificates from over two million singleton pregnancies in 2015 to 2017. They collected data from moms who had a college education, held private health insurance, and did not receive government benefits. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKEach mom self-reported her race as Black, white, or mixed Black and white. The study found that 9.9% of Black women and 6% of mixed-race women had a preterm birth, compared to delivered preterm as compared to 5% percent of white women. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKAll this suggests that there are factors in play we just don’t know enough about. “Studies show genetic, bacterial, infectious, and immune differences that could have some effect,” says Maven OB-GYN Jackie Stone.
What can you do to prevent preterm birth?

Experts say you should always attend your recommended prenatal care appointments and manage any preexisting health conditions. It’s also important to know what preterm labor looks like, so you can seek help right away. Signs can include:
Lower back pain
Lower abdominal cramping
Contractions
Pressure in the pelvis or vagina
Flu-like symptoms
Fluid leaking from the vagina

If you do go into preterm labor, Green says that the recommended course of action depends how far along you are. “If it truly is preterm labor, we can do our best to try to delay it and try to get medications on board that will make sure to increase the chances that the baby will do well on the outside,” she says. “We’ll want to get antibiotics on board and to get steroids on board to help the baby's brain and lungs mature.”

If you’re at a high risk for preterm birth, your doctor or a Maven OB-GYN can always recommend helpful changes to your diet, activity levels, or general lifestyle. If you have a history of previous preterm birth due to preterm labor or early rupture of membranes, you can talk to your doctor about progesterone treatment.

“At your 20 week anatomy scan, the length of your cervix can be checked,” Stone explains. “Women with super short cervix are at increased risk of preterm birth. This can be treated with progesterone to reduce the risk.”
And if you’re Black and concerned about preterm labor, it’s always a good idea to speak with your provider about your worries.
Sources:
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): Preterm Birth
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG): Preterm Labor and Birth
American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology: "Racial disparities in prematurity persist among women of high socioeconomic status,” February 2020
Obstetrics & Gynecology: "Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Perinatal Insurance Coverage", April 2020
March of Dimes: Nowhere to Go: Maternity Care Deserts Across the US
March of Dimes: Preterm Labor and Premature Birth: Are You At Risk?
Health Affairs: “Access To Obstetric Services In Rural Counties Still Declining, With 9 Percent Losing Services, 2004–14,” 2017

https://www.healthaffairs.org/doi/full/10.1377/hlthaff.2017.0338#:~:text=9%3A%20Market%20Concentration-,Access%20To%20Obstetric%20Services%20In%20Rural%20Counties%20Still%20Declining%2C%20With,Percent%20Losing%20Services%2C%202004%E2%80%9314&text=Peiyin%20Hung%20(%20hungx068%40umn.,of%20Public%20Health%2C%20in%20Minneapolis

title.en-US: What treatment for postpartum depression or anxiety really looks like

content.value: Going through postpartum depression and anxiety is difficult to say the least, and asking for help can seem impossible. Once you’ve recognized that what you’re going through is more than “just the baby blues,” the next step is locating a good mental health provider and making a treatment plan. But what will that actually look like? Maven Mental Health Provider Nicole Woodcox Bolden shares what you should know.
The first step is to recognize the symptoms

Postpartum depression is much more common than you may think—the Anxiety and Depression Association of America (ADAA) estimates that 1 in 7 moms will experience it. Symptoms usually begin within the first month after delivery, and can include:
Depressed mood
Severe mood swings
Trouble bonding with the baby
Loss of appetite
Lack of pleasure in things you used to enjoy
Trouble concentrating or making decisions
Severe anxiety
Panic attacks
Thoughts about harming yourself or your baby
Postpartum anxiety is also very common. Symptoms include:
Feeling like you can’t relax
Feeling constant worry or dread that something bad will happen
Decreased appetite
Trouble sleeping
Trouble sitting still
Racing thoughts
Heart palpitations
Sweating, shaking, or trembling

If you’re having thoughts about hurting yourself or someone else, you should contact a hotline right away: the phone number for the National Suicide Prevention Hotline is 1-800-273-8255, and you can contact the National Crisis Text Line (text HOME to 741741) to get help with any type of crisis. If you’re at an immediate risk of harming yourself or someone else, call 911.
The next step is to seek out professional treatment
Locate an experienced, competent provider who can help you through your postpartum and depression or anxiety. Step by step, the process will go something like this:
Find a provider who can help you make a plan
. Ask your OB-GYN for a referral, or speak to a
Maven Mental Health Provider

. Woodcox Bolden recommends someone who has experience and specialized education in postpartum mood disorders. “You don’t want to just talk to someone who says ‘Oh, I have kids too,” she says. “You want someone with training in perinatal mental health.”
Your provider will probably have you take an assessment like the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS).
The EPDS has 10 short questions about your mood over the past 7 days, and asks you to select an answer for each one that comes closest to your experience.
Share what’s going on

. Your provider will also want to have a conversation about what you’re going through, and that means getting specific. While it can feel embarrassing or even shameful to open up, medical professionals have truly seen it all. Knowing the full extent of what you’re thinking and feeling will help them make the best possible recommendations.
Add any relevant history.

Do you have a family history of anxiety or depression? Or a personal history? If you were treated for anxiety and depression prior to pregnancy and delivery, you’ll know what has and hasn’t worked for you. That’s information your provider can use to inform their treatment plan.
Next up, you’ll talk through all your options

Your provider should be able to talk you through various treatment options, then explain what they’d recommend for you and why. They should answer any questions you have about the treatment timeline, any upsides or downsides to their approach, side effects you could experience, and alternative possibilities.

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) explains that talk therapy is an excellent tool for postpartum depression and anxiety, and that some people may also benefit from medication. Woodcox Bolden stresses that medication should be prescribed in addition to therapy, not just as a solo measure.
Some common treatment options include:
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
CBT can help you identify and change unhelpful thinking patterns that are contributing to your condition. At a high level, CBT can be broken down into four different steps:
Identifying the situations or conditions that you’re struggling with'
Identifying your thoughts and feelings about these issues
Identifying ways of thinking that are inaccurate or distorted
Reshaping that thinking
Research from 2015 analyzed 40 different studies about CBT and postpartum depression. They found that CBT could help treat
and
prevent PPD, and that one-on-one sessions were more helpful than CBT in a group setting.
Antidepressant medications

Antidepressant medications like selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are commonly used to treat anxiety and depression, and they may be helpful for PPD and PPA, too. Research published in 2014 reviewed available studies on medication for PPD and concluded that SSRIs should be the first-line medication recommended for postpartum depression.

If you’re breastfeeding or pumping, you can still safely take medication. According to the MGH Center for Women’s Mental Health, there’s robust data on the safety of breastfeeding while taking SSRIs like sertraline, paroxetine, fluoxetine, as well as tricyclic antidepressants. If you have any concerns about taking medication while breastfeeding, your provider should be able to talk you through what the research shows.
PPD-specific medication

In 2019, the FDA approved a new drug called brexanolone (brand name ZulressoTM) specifically to treat postpartum depression. The Cleveland Clinic says that brexanolone is chemically identical to a hormone called endogenous allopregnanolone, which decreases in the body after birth and may be linked to postpartum depression.

Brexanolone is an IV drug that has to be administered by a medical professional over a 60-hour period, and there are some reported side effects like dizziness, a dry mouth, and excessive sedation. You need to be fully monitored by medical staff during the IV infusion. Because the drug is quite new and it does require special care to administer, it may or may not be easily available in your area, plus your health insurance may not cover it and it can be very expensive. You can ask your OB-GYN or mental health care provider if it’s a good option for you.
The bottom line

Ultimately, the right treatment for postpartum depression or postpartum anxiety really depends on you. And you can reach out for help any time—whether you’re pregnant now, in the postpartum trenches, or celebrating your child’s first birthday. Seeking help isn’t a sign of weakness, and the right treatment can help you feel like yourself again.
“We just want to give you a larger toolbox to help you cope,” Woodcox Bolden says. Remember,
Maven Mental Health Providers
are here for you at any time. Book an appointment today.
Sources:
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG): Postpartum Depression
Anxiety and Depression Association of America (ADAA): Postpartum Depression
American Psychological Association (APA): What Is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy?
Mayo Clinic: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
Journal of Affective Disorders: “A systematic review of the efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapy for treating and preventing perinatal depression,” 2015
National Institute of Mental Health: Perinatal Depression
The Massachusetts General Hospital Center for Women’s Mental Health: Breastfeeding and Psychiatric Medications
Cleveland Clinic: What to Know About the New Postpartum Depression Drug
Expert Opinion on Pharmacotherapy: “Pharmacotherapy of postpartum depression: an update,” 2014
Cleveland Clinic: Postpartum Depression
Texas Childrens’ Hospital: Recognizing signs of postpartum anxiety

title.en-US: The ins and outs of buying donated breast milk

content.value: A hundred years ago, “wet nurses” who would nurse a child they didn’t give birth to were the norm. Today, milk sharing still goes on in its own way. If you’re unable or don’t want to breastfeed, but still want to give your baby the benefits of breast milk, you have options! Maven Lactation Consultant & Nutritionist Lauren Olofsson, IBCLC, explains how to go about buying breast milk and how to do it safely.
Option A: Purchase breast milk from a milk bank
How much milk you can get

Unfortunately, milk banks aren’t like Amazon—you usually can’t reorder as you go week after week. Olofsson says the amount you can get really varies from one milk bank to another and will depend on how much milk they have to offer. Some won’t have enough available to fill your order, while others may be able to provide you with a one-time, one-week supply, or more. What’s important to know is that most banks will not be able to provide you with enough to solely rely on donor breast milk to feed your baby so be sure to speak to your baby’s pediatrician about a supplementation plan.
How to find a milk bank

To purchase breast milk, you’ll need to get a prescription from your doctor. After that, the Human Milk Banking Association of North America (HMBANA) is the best place to start your search for safe donor breast milk in the United States. The HMBANA sets safety guidelines and accredits milk banks who follow these guidelines. Keep in mind that there are only 30 HMBANA-accredited breast milk banks across the U.S. and Canada, so the one closest to you may still be a drive.

Once you locate your nearest location, call them up to learn about their supply and if you qualify to have breast milk sent to you instead of having to pick it up. “You’ll want to find out how much milk they have available and who has priority to that milk, as they may also serve hospitals,” Olofsson says. “Usually neonates—or the youngest babies born prematurely—tend to get priority because breast milk is most essential for their health compared to say, a healthy 6-month-old baby who was born full term.”
Each milk bank has its own process, but you’ll likely have to fill out an application and you can work with several milk banks at once.
To find your nearest milk bank, start here:
North America:
hmbana.org
International:
internationalmilkbanking.org
European:
europeanmilkbanking.com
How much it costs

According to the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), the cost of donor milk can vary by milk bank but it’s usually in the range of $3-5 per ounce. These costs cover screening of the donor, milk pasteurization and testing, and shipping of the milk. So how much might it cost to solely feed your newborn donor milk for one month? As a rough estimate, if your newborn drinks an average of 20 ounces a day at an average of $4 per ounce, it could cost $80 a day, $560 a week, or $2400 a month to solely feed your baby donor milk.
How breast milk donors are screened
Here are the typical steps a potential milk donor will go through to ensure that the breast milk they’re donating is safe for your baby:

A potential milk donor is prescreened to make sure they’re a good candidate. They’ll answer many (many) questions about their health history, their partner’s health history, and their own baby’s health history. The criteria is very detailed. For example, the candidate cannot have ever travelled to certain countries, ever injected drugs or had sex with someone who has injected drugs, taken certain medications while pumping (including progestin-only birth control pills), or regularly consume excess caffeine—to name a few.
Waivers must be signed by the donor’s doctor and her baby’s pediatrician.
Once the donor has been approved, blood work is taken to rule out any diseases that could affect the breast milk (such as HIV, HTLV syphilis, or hepatitis).
If the donor passes all of these steps, she can then send in her breast milk.
The breast milk is received, pasteurized, and bottled—which involves it’s own extensive sterilization process—before it makes its way to you and your baby’s bottle.
Option B: Purchase breast milk directly from a lactating mother

Getting breast milk directly from a lactating mother may be another option. For example, your sister may have just weaned her child and has an extra freezer stash to share. Or a mother in your neighborhood Facebook group may have some she’d love to donate to another mom in need. There are also sites that sell breast milk online. But it’s important to consider the safety of this option.

Olofsson cautions against milk from unregulated sources because it’s hard to know if you’re getting the safest milk for your baby. “Unlike getting donated milk from HMBANA, ‘black market’ breast milk isn’t screened or regulated by HMBANA or any other agency,” Olofsson says. “Online sellers could quite literally be selling you cow’s milk and you’d be none the wiser.”

While friends and family members may be well meaning in sharing their extra breast milk, you still need to be careful. “I always encourage people going this route to speak with their child’s pediatrician first so they know the right questions to ask before giving someone else’s breast milk to their baby,” Olofsson says. “The biggest concern is assuming that the person donating it doesn’t have any blood-borne illnesses or diseases that can be transmitted through breast milk, like HIV, syphilis, or hepatitis B.” But that’s not the only thing. Beyond those serious health risks are also concerns around cleanliness. “Even if there are no known health issues, you don’t know if they sanitized their pump parts to decrease the risk of bacteria, if they stored the milk properly or it sat out too long...all of these little factors can become a serious issue for your baby’s health,” Oloffson says.
The bottom line:

Wanting to feed your baby breast milk is great! Just make sure you can do it safely. Regardless of which route you choose to secure donor milk, always talk to your child’s pediatrician or a pediatrician on Maven first for help deciding what’s best for your baby.
Sources
Human Milk Banking Association of North America
La Leche League International

title.en-US: What to expect during labor and delivery

content.value: What you need to know:
Every birth is different, but all birthing people experience 3 stages of labor and delivery: labor, pushing and delivering baby, and then delivering the placenta.
If a vaginal delivery becomes unsafe for you or baby, you might need a Cesarean (C-section) delivery.
It can take anywhere from a few hours to a few days for your baby to be born.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Your due date is soon! Whether you are feeling excited, nervous, or a little bit of both, knowing what to expect during labor and delivery can help you feel more prepared.
Here is everything you need to know about the different stages of labor and delivery.
What are the stages of labor and delivery?
The 3 main stages of labor and delivery are:
Labor:
This stage is made up of 3 phases called early labor, active labor, and transitional labor.
Pushing and delivery:
This stage starts with pushing and ends with the arrival of your baby!
Delivering the placenta:
During this stage, you will push out your placenta or it will be removed by your OB-GYN.
What happens during stage 1 (labor)?

The first stage of labor and delivery starts when you begin to feel regular contractions. They will become stronger, last longer, and get closer together over time. These contractions cause your cervix to dilate (open) and efface (thin), so your baby can move into the birth canal.
This first labor stage usually lasts longer than the other two stages, and is made up of 3 separate phases. The 3 phases of labor are:
1. Early labor
During early labor, you will probably feel light contractions as your cervix opens to 4 to 6 centimeters. Contractions might feel like period cramps.

How long early labor lasts is different for everyone. It can take a few hours to a few days. If this is your first baby, labor may take longer—because it is the first time your body is doing this! If you’ve given birth before, it may be quicker.

If you do not have a high-risk pregnancy, your OB-GYN or midwife might recommend laboring at home until your contractions are closer together. When your contractions come every 4 minutes and last for 1 minute for 1 full hour, head to your hospital or birthing center. (An easy way to remember this is 4-1-1.)
Learn more about timing labor contractions here.

Call your OB-GYN or midwife, or go to the hospital or birthing center right away if you have a high-risk pregnancy, heavy vaginal bleeding, or your water breaks and you tested positive for group B strep (GBS).
2. Active labor

During active labor, your contractions will become stronger, last longer, and get closer together as your cervix opens from about 6 centimeters to 10 centimeters. If your water has not broken yet, it might break during active labor and make contractions come faster and stronger.
If your water does not break on its own, your OB-GYN or midwife might ask if you want them to help break it to speed up labor.
Breathing exercises, changing your positions, bouncing on a ball, or soaking in a tub (if your hospital or birthing center offers it) can help you through the pain of contractions. If you want an
epidural
to help with the pain, this is the time to ask for it.
Learn more about all of your pain management tools.
If you have questions about managing pain during labor and delivery, be sure to ask your OB-GYN or midwife. Or make a free, online appointment with a
Maven OB-GYN
or a
Maven Doula
for advice.
Active labor can last from 20 minutes to several hours depending on if you have given birth before.
3. Transitional labor
Transitional labor is usually the hardest, but fastest phase of labor and delivery. Your cervix will open from about 8 centimeters to 10 centimeters (at 10, you are fully dilated).
Contractions will feel like they are back-to-back and can be very painful. If you have an epidural, you will feel the pressure of contractions, but less pain.
You might feel overwhelmed, tired, or irritable, but remember—you are close to meeting your baby!
What happens during stage 2 (pushing and delivery)?

It is time to push! In stage 2, your cervix is fully dilated at 10 centimeters for baby to come down into the birth canal. You will feel waves of contractions and pressure pushing your baby through the birth canal. Many people say this stage feels like having a big bowel movement.
Your support team will coach you through pushing with each contraction. Pushing too quickly can cause
vaginal tearing
, so they will help you slow down if baby is coming through the birth canal too quickly.

When your baby’s head comes through the opening of your vagina (called crowning), you may feel a burning sensation even if you have an epidural. This is the skin around your vagina stretching to let baby’s head pass through. Once their head is out (the biggest part of the baby), the rest of their body will come out more easily.
How long pushing and delivery takes depends on a lot of factors, like:
If you have given birth before
The size of your baby
Baby’s position in the birth canal
The shape of your body REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If a vaginal delivery becomes unsafe for you or baby, you might need a Cesarean delivery (C-section) where an incision is made and baby is taken out by an OB-GYN. If you need a C-section, you will be given medication that numbs you completely from the waist down. Then you will be taken to the operating room (OR) for a C-section delivery.
Learn more about C-sections.
What happens during stage 3 (delivering the placenta)?
You did it! Time to cut the umbilical cord and meet your baby. (Your support person can cut the cord if OK by your doctor.)

While you or your support person are holding your baby, your uterus will keep contracting until the placenta detaches and is pushed out. This usually takes 5 to 40 minutes. Your OB-GYN or midwife might help push out the placenta by putting pressure on your belly. If you have a C-section, your placenta will be removed during surgery and you will be stitched up. You may be able to hold baby at this time or they will be brought to you in recovery.

This is also the time your OB-GYN or midwife will repair any vaginal tearing with stitches. You will not feel the stitches if you had an epidural. If you did not have an epidural, your OB-GYN will numb you with an injection before starting your stitches.

Your baby will have a quick exam to make sure they are healthy. Then it is back to cuddling with you or your support person. If your baby needs extra care, your birthing team will let you know what is going on, then take baby for treatment. In some cases, your support person may be able to go with baby while you are in recovery.
What happens next?
Congratulations! You made it through all 3 stages of labor.

Now is a good time to do skin-to-skin contact with your baby. You or your support person can put baby on your bare chest. Skin-to-skin contact can help strengthen the bond you have with your baby and soothe them. If you want to breastfeed, it also tells your body it is time to start producing milk.

It is recommended that you feed your baby within the first hour after birth. If you want to breastfeed, the nursing staff or your midwife will help you get started. If you want to formula feed, it will be given to you.
You and your baby will spend at least 24 hours in the hospital or birthing center to make sure you are both OK. If you had a C-section you may spend 2-4 days in the hospital to recover.
It can be tough with a newborn, but try to get some rest while you have nursing staff to support you. Your body needs lots of rest to heal from pregnancy, labor, and delivery.

Recovering from birth usually takes at least 6 weeks. During this time, it is important to pay close attention to your body as it heals. Certain complications, like infection or postpartum preeclampsia, can be dangerous. Learn more about recovering from birth, and when to call your doctor, here.
Learn more about recovering from birth, and when to call your doctor, here.
Have questions about labor and delivery?
Ask us! You can schedule an appointment online at any time with a
Maven OB-GYN
or
Maven Doula
Sources
Maven Clinic

title.en-US: What is an external cephalic version (and does it hurt)?

content.value: Our bodies are amazing. Somehow they just know how to grow a baby and then, when the time is just right, push that baby out into the world. And babies are equally impressive partners in this, knowing just when to flip over into the ideal head-down position in preparation for birth. Except when they don’t. If you’re nearing your due date with a little one who didn’t seem to get the head-down memo, consider this your first lesson in raising a true individual. While a Cesarean delivery is sometimes necessary, you may have another option: External cephalic version. Maven OB-GYN Radhika Sharma, MD, explains how it works, what it feels like, and how to know if it’s the right move for you.
What it is

An external cephalic version (ECV) is a procedure performed by a trained OB-GYN, midwife, or family physician to manually rotate your baby into the ideal head-down (aka cephalic) position from the outside. That’s right. And while it may sound hard to believe that this is even possible, ECV has been around since the time of Aristotle (384 to 322 B.C.) and is taught in most obstetric residency programs today.

“Most OB-GYN providers are trained and comfortable with performing ECV,” Sharma says. “It’s usually a two-person procedure. Your provider will usually be the one directing the procedure, and have an assistant in order to ensure everything goes smoothly.”
Why it’s done

Ideally, your baby will make their way to the ideal position—head down, chin tucked, facing your back—on their own. And most babies do! But sometimes they settle sideways (transverse) or breech (feet or butt first). This can make vaginal delivery more difficult and unsafe, and in some cases, impossible.
According to the
American Family Physician

, approximately 12% of Cesarean deliveries in the U.S. are performed because a baby is in the breech position. If your doctor decides that you’re a good candidate for an ECV and is trained in the procedure, a successful ECV could possibly prevent you from needing a Cesarean (and avoiding a major surgery is a win!).

“The majority of babies will be cephalic (head down) at term, which is past 37 weeks of pregnancy,” Sharma says. “According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 3-4% of babies will be in a breech presentation. In this case, an ECV is an excellent option to assist in turning the baby to the cephalic presentation. If babies persist in a breech presentation, your health care provider may suggest a Cesarean delivery. There are risks associated with a breech vaginal delivery and a Cesarean delivery, but the risks associated with a vaginal breech delivery are higher than for a primary Cesarean delivery. In certain situations, it’s not safe to perform an external cephalic version, and your doctor will be able to help you determine if you’re a candidate for the procedure.”
How it’s done

Wondering what to expect when you have an ECV? Your ECV may be performed by your main provider alone or two providers who’ve been trained in this technique. It may be performed by a midwife or family physician, but only if there’s an OB-GYN available to perform surgery if needed. An ECV will always be performed in a hospital that’s equipped to perform an emergency Cesarean delivery and one that has an ultrasound machine and technician.
The procedure usually takes a few hours from the time your appointment begins to when you head home. Here’s how it goes step by step:

You’ll arrive for your scheduled ECV appointment and have an ultrasound to confirm the position of your baby, your amniotic fluid index, the location of the placenta and to rule out any abnormalities that may interfere with the procedure.
You’ll be asked to empty your bladder.
Your doctor will then perform a nonstress test. This tracks your baby’s heart rate to ensure there aren’t any issues.
You’ll have your blood drawn and IV access will be placed in case of an emergency.

You may be given medication to help relax your uterus or offered an epidural to manage discomfort*—*more on that later. But no anesthesia should be given (this can increase the risk of complications).
You’ll lay flat on your back and may be tilted back (with your feet slightly higher than your head) and your belly will be coated in ultrasound gel.

Your doctor will press their hands on the outside of your belly to locate your baby. They’ll place one hand on baby’s bottom and one on their head. Your baby’s bottom is the part that will be maneuvered, while the head is very gently guided toward the pelvis. They’ll guide your baby up and over into a forward roll or backflip (depending on their position) ending in the head-down position. If the procedure is unsuccessful, your doctor may attempt it again in the opposite direction.
After the procedure, your doctor will perform another nonstress test and ultrasound examination to ensure your baby’s heart rate is normal and they’ve been successfully flipped.
Success rates

“Over half of ECV’s are successful,” Sharma says. “But in those babies that have been moved to the cephalic position, there’s still a chance they can flip back to a breech presentation.” According to studies, ECVs successfully turn a baby into the head-down position approximately 65% of the time. If the procedure isn’t successful, it can be tried again in a few days to a week. It’s also possible for your baby to flip back but this only happens about 7% of the time.
When ECV is recommended

If you’re not experiencing a hisk-risk pregnancy, you’re nearing or past 36 weeks pregnant and your baby is in any type of breech position (frank, complete, or footling) or lying sideways (transverse), you may be a good candidate for ECV. Talk to your provider or a
Maven OB-GYN
about it.
According to the
American Family Physician

, the ideal time to perform an ECV is 37 weeks and before your baby has dropped into your pelvis. Performing an ECV before 37 weeks isn’t considered safe because it can increase the risk of complications. There’s also a high likelihood that the baby will turn back into the breech position if performed too early, because there’s more room for baby to move about earlier in pregnancy.
When ECV isn’t recommended
Your provider will not recommend ECV if you’re experiencing a high-risk pregnancy or any of the following apply:
Your provider has not been trained in ECV
There are placenta issues (such as placenta previa)
You’ve experienced third trimester bleeding
Your baby isn’t growing as expected (too large or too small)
There are any amniotic fluid abnormalities (too low or too high)
There are malformations of the uterus
You have cardiac disease or pregnancy-induced hypertension
Your baby has an abnormal heartbeat
Your baby has a major congenital anomaly (such as a heart defect, neural tube defect, or Down syndrome)
Your water has broken
Your baby’s head isn’t bent forward
You’re having multiples (though ECV may be used after birthing the first twin if the first is head-down but the second isn’t)
Risks vs. benefits
In a low-risk pregnancy, the risk of complications from having an ECV is approximately 1-2% according to a study published in
Obstetrics & Gynecology
. But the risks can be serious so be sure to discuss them in full with your doctor or an
OB-GYN on Maven

“Some of the risks associated with an ECV are prelabor rupture of membranes (when your water breaks before labor), changes in the babies heart rate pattern during or after the procedure, premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, and preterm or early labor before 37 weeks,” Sharma says. “The overall benefit of having an external cephalic version is to have a spontaneous vaginal delivery, which prevents a Cesarean section. And this usually allows for a faster recovery time.”
Your doctor will explain what to keep an eye out for after your ECV and to contact them right away if you experience any bleeding, contractions, or less movement than usual from your baby.
And finally, what it feels like

Flipping a baby from the outside is no small feat. It’ll take a certain amount of firm pressure and will cause a certain amount of discomfort. Everyone’s experience of pain is different*—*that said, it shouldn’t feel extremely painful. If you’re experiencing excessive pain or discomfort, your doctor detects any fetal distress or the turn just isn’t working, the procedure will be stopped. You can choose to try again in a few days if you wish. You may experience light bruising after an ECV from hand pressure.

“External cephalic version, and the attempt to put the baby in a head-down position, can be associated with increased levels of cramping as well as preterm contractions,” Sharma says. “Often, a conversation is had between you and your provider about the option of using medication to relax the uterus as well as use of an epidural to prevent major discomfort. Many women will opt for an epidural even for the short period of time needed for less discomfort during and after the ECV procedure.”
If all of this makes you feel squeamish, we completely understand. Talk it through with your doctor and get a second opinion from an
OB-GYN
or
midwife on Maven
. If you’re a good candidate for an ECV and it can help you avoid a Cesarean delivery, you may decide that the temporary discomfort is worth it.
Sources
American Family Physician
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
StatPearls
Obstetrics and Gynecology
British Medical Journal
Cochrane Library
International Journal of Gynecology & Obstetrics

title.en-US: Having a baby while being in a larger body

content.value: Obesity isn’t something you are; it’s something you have. It’s a complex health condition and just as with any preexisting health condition, it’s important to know how it may affect your pregnancy. While the risk factors of being in a larger body while pregnant may be worrisome to hear about, the great news is that when you’re armed with information and support, you can be in a larger body and have a healthy pregnancy and baby. Maven OB-GYN Radhika Sharma, MD, and Maven Doula and Care Advocate Kaeleigh Terrill explain what you need to know, how to create a supportive care team, and the steps you can start taking today to have a healthy pregnancy.
Body weight and pregnancy
Being “overweight” is defined as having a
body mass index

(BMI) of 25–29.9 and “obesity” is defined as a BMI of 30 or greater. A high BMI is connected to certain health conditions including developing coronary artery disease, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, diabetes, and metabolic syndrome. That said, BMI is far from the perfect marker of health and even people with low BMI can develop these and other health conditions. However, it can be a helpful reference point for you and your provider to start a discussion about your health and how to have a healthy pregnancy.

People in larger bodies can have uncomplicated pregnancies—and getting support is key. “We’re here to help you advocate for your healthy pregnancy and tailor your care to support you where you are,” Terrill says.
How body weight can affect pregnancy
Many complications can arise during pregnancy—you’re growing a human, after all. But when you’re pregnant in a larger body, it can increase the risk of specific complications including:
Gestational hypertension (high blood pressure)
Preeclampsia (a serious condition where blood pressure rises rapidly and can lead to organ failure)
Gestational diabetes (high blood glucose levels)
Heart failure
