Obstructive sleep apnea (when a person stops breathing for short periods while sleeping)
Complications with labor
Need for Cesarean delivery and Cesarean complications (such as infection)
Miscarriage
Being in a larger body can also increase the risk of certain health conditions in babies. Studies have found links between mothers with obesity and the increased risk of the following:
Difficulty performing ultrasound exams and fetal heart monitoring (which can make it difficult to determine anatomical issues while in the womb or increased distress during birth)
Birth defects (such as heart or neural tube defects)
Macrosomia (larger than average baby which can increase birth injury and need for a Cesarean delivery)
Preterm birth (being born before 37 weeks)
Stillbirth
Asthma and respiratory issues
Childhood obesity
Specialized care you may receive

If you have a high BMI, your pregnancy will be considered “high-risk.” This simply means that because there’s a higher risk of certain complications, your doctor will schedule additional appointments and testing to ensure that you and your baby are safe including:
Earlier gestational diabetes screening

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYou’ll likely be screened for gestational diabetes early in your pregnancy, at one of your first prenatal visits, rather than waiting until the standard 24-28 weeks. This glucose screening checks for abnormal glucose (sugar) levels in your blood. Know that any sized body can develop gestational diabetes, but it’s important to catch it early to reduce complications.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf the results are normal, you’ll be screened again at the standard time. If the levels are abnormal, your doctor will advise you on dietary changes you can make to manage gestational diabetes.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn more about gestational diabetes
Sleep apnea screening

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKSleep apnea is when your breathing temporarily stops during sleep. It’s more common in people in larger bodies and can increase the risk of pregnancy complications, including preeclampsia. Your doctor will likely complete a sleep apnea screening at an early prenatal appointment. If you’re diagnosed with sleep apnea, they may recommend that you meet with a sleep medicine specialist for treatment.
Additional ultrasounds and testing

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“In patients in larger bodies, an anatomy ultrasound will be completed at the standard time but because body fat can make imaging more difficult, additional imaging may be needed to completely view the baby’s heart and other organs,” Sharma says. “You may also have growth ultrasounds more frequently to ensure your baby’s healthy growth and development.” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYou may also have more testing in the third trimester. “Testing usually consists of a non-stress test where a monitor with a small ultrasound is placed on your abdomen to monitor your baby’s heart rate,” Sharma says. “Or you may have a biophysical profile, a mini ultrasound that helps determine baby’s well-being.” If any of these tests are abnormal, your provider will discuss next steps with you which may include scheduling an induction or Cesarean delivery for your safety and that of your baby.
Referrals to specialists

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf you’re in a larger body, your doctor will recommend that you gain less weight during pregnancy than someone who’s not. Your doctor may refer you to a prenatal nutritionist or registered dietician for help managing pregnancy weight gain.
Steps you can take to have a healthy pregnancy

“Start by giving yourself grace, and knowing that you’re not alone,” Sharma says. “Educating yourself by reading and creating questions to bring to your OB-GYN is a great first step that can equip you with the information, and in turn, the confidence to have a healthy pregnancy.” Here are some steps you can start taking today:
Make your pregnancy provider your #1 ally

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYour pregnancy providers will play a very important role in your pregnancy. “I recommend working with size-friendly doctors,” Terrill says. “Providers who adhere to Health at Every Size principles practice evidence-based care while exercising compassion, treating patients with dignity, being aware of personal biases, and avoiding assumptions about nutrition or physical activity levels.” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKLearn more about how to find a size-friendly provider at
haescommunity.com

. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKOnce you find a provider you like, make sure to attend all of your prenatal appointments—they’re an important time to ask questions and seek guidance on how to lower the risk of complications, as well as for your doctor to monitor your health and catch any signs of complications early. If you have other health conditions, always share that information with your provider so they can provide complete care and guidance. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf your provider makes you feel uncomfortable, judged, or unheard in any way, find a new one if you’re able to. This person will be your guide for nine long months, so it’s essential that you feel safe and supported by them. (Need help finding a new pregnancy provider in your area? Message your Care Advocate  for help!)
Rely on Maven in-between visits
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf you forgot to ask something at your last in-person prenatal appointment or don’t feel comfortable with your primary provider, remember that Maven is here for you anytime. Our
OB-GYNs
midwives
prenatal nutritionists
mental health providers

and more are available for same-day virtual appointments or messaging so you can always get a second opinion or more specialized care throughout your pregnancy and postpartum. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“Virtual appointments are proven to be extremely helpful to patients along their pregnancy journey,” Sharma says. “It’s nice to have the resource of a trained OB-GYN on demand to answer any question or concern at times of day where you’re unable to reach your provider. They’re a great way to put your mind at ease quickly.” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKNot sure who to talk to? Message your Care Advocate . They’re your go-to support person and can even create a personal list of providers based on your needs, including those who specialize in high-risk pregnancies.
Make a weight management plan
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKWork with your OB-GYN or an
OB-GYN on Maven

to make a plan for how much weight it would be best to gain throughout your pregnancy. For people with a BMI of 30 or higher, the generally recommended weight gain is 11 to 20 pounds; for higher BMIs, recommended weight gain is lower. That said, fixating on specific numbers can be anxiety-inducing. Talk about it with your provider or a provider on Maven so they can help support you. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“Often when patients with obesity become pregnant they’re afraid it will be detrimental to their pregnancy,” Sharma says. “But by following recommended weight gain and caloric regulation and having ongoing support, many women with obesity can have a healthy pregnancy. I always recommend staying healthy in body and mind; this includes exercise but also behavioral management and therapy options. I always talk to my patients about their history and factors that may have played a role in developing obesity.” Talking to a
mental health provider
can be extremely helpful throughout your pregnancy.
Get to know the best pregnancy foods

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKAccording to a study of pregnant women who were overweight or had obesity in the British Medical Journal, making changes to the foods you eat had the greatest impact on maintaining healthy pregnancy weight and significantly lowers the risk of developing preeclampsia and may also reduce the risk of gestational diabetes, gestational hypertension, preterm birth, and stillbirth—even more so than exercise. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThat said, it’s important to safely balance weight management with making sure you’re getting enough healthy calories and nutrients for your growing baby. A pregnant person needs about 300 extra calories a day. From avocados to salmon, leafy greens to whole grains, work with a
nutritionist on Maven

to learn which foods have the healthiest (and tastiest!) extra calories. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKNot sure where to begin? Our nutritionists can help you make a weekly meal plan and provide healthy snack ideas when cravings kick in. “Working with a nutritionist can help promote a better relationship with food and your body,” Terrill says.
MyPlate

is another great resource for creating custom meal plans that are ideal for pregnancy, as well as apps that can help you keep a food diary and learn which foods are healthiest. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKOne more important note—fad diets, weight loss supplements, or weight loss medication are dangerous while pregnant. Always speak with your provider or a provider on Maven before trying them.
Learn about low-impact exercises
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKBeing in a larger body while carrying a baby can make physical activity more difficult, but it’s important to a healthy pregnancy. Work with a
physical therapist on Maven

to learn some low-impact exercises that can be more comfortable, like swimming or walking. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf you’re not used to exercising, break it down to make it more manageable. “I recommend moderate exercise for a total of 30 minutes 5 times per week but if this is too difficult at first, break it up into 10-minute increments and then work up to 30 minutes over time,” Sharma says. Studies show that having a friend who’s willing to exercise with you can help you stick to it. This can be in-person, or jumping on a call with a long-distance friend whenever you head out for a walk. (A good catchup is a great exercise distraction!) “A fun fact is that working up a sweat can actually really help alleviate morning sickness, as unpleasant as that may sound,” Terrill says. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKPrefer to connect online? There are tons of apps with livestream classes that are actually fun (think: dancing to 90s pop hits) with really active, diverse, and welcoming online communities (#sweatyselfie anyone?) that can help you stay motivated. (Check out
Obé Fitness
or
Daily Burn
for starters).
Plus Size Birth
is also a great resource for information.
Focus on feeling good

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKNumbers, diets, exercise—all of these are a means to an end, but your real focus should be on getting to a place in your pregnancy where you feel good. “Pregnancy comes with a lot of different emotions for everyone, especially as your body changes in the coming months,” Terrill says. “Work with a
wellness coach
or a
mental health provider on Maven
to help you get to a place where you feel good in the body you’re in.”
The bottom line:

Pregnancy in a larger body can present extra challenges and anxiety, but it doesn’t mean that you can’t have a healthy pregnancy and a perfect bundle of joy after. Try your best to focus on this as your goal, rather than fixate on numbers, and then create a circle of supporters—both medical and personal—who’ll be there to help you achieve it. “By discussing your anxiety and concerns with your provider or a provider on Maven, you can work through any challenge related to obesity,” Sharma says. “A team of physicians, nurses, and counselors can help you have a safe and successful pregnancy.” “I’d also try to remember everything your body is doing right now to grow a baby,” Terrill says. “Try to focus on treating your body well and honoring all of the amazing work it’s doing.”
Sources
Mayo Clinic
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
U.S. Department of Agriculture: MyPlate
British Medical Journal

title.en-US: The most common breastfeeding questions, answered

content.value: If all the ins and outs of breastfeeding are making your head spin, you’re not alone. Here are the most common questions Maven members ask in our virtual Breastfeeding 101 class with answers from Maven Midwife and Lactation Consultant Nina Wilson. Have a question we didn’t cover? Talk to a
Maven lactation consultant
anytime for personal advice,
watch past Breastfeeding 101 classes
, or
join us for our next one
Colostrum
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Baby health
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Timing
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Alternating breasts
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Hand expression
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Bottle feeding
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Diet and breastfeeding
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Medications and alcohol safety
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Mastitis
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Haakaa
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Have a breastfeeding question we didn’t cover?
Maven lactation consultants
are here to help at every step of your breastfeeding journey—day or night, at home or at work. Book a quick video appointment or send them a message anytime.

items.header: How long does colostrum last and when does regular milk come in?

content.value: NW: “In the first few days after delivery, your baby will feed on colostrum, which your body starts producing between weeks 16-20 of pregnancy (you often don’t notice it until after delivery). Colostrum is sometimes called “early milk” and is very small in quantity, just tiny drops (about a teaspoon per feeding), but it’s power-packed with nutrients and antibodies for your baby.

Many women get concerned that their baby is hungry or isn’t getting enough to eat because they may not notice changes in their breasts in those first few days after birth. This is normal—you won’t usually notice leaking milk or fullness until days 2 to 4 postpartum when your mature milk comes in. Rest assured that under normal circumstances, if your baby has no additional supplementation needs and they’re latching well, colostrum provides all the proteins, carbs, fats, vitamins and immune factors your baby needs.”

items.header: If I’m leaking during my pregnancy, will there be any colostrum left when the baby is born?

content.value: NW: “If you leak colostrum during pregnancy or after delivery, there’s no need to worry that you’ll run out. Your body will keep making colostrum and you should have plenty when the baby is born. Then your breasts will begin making mature milk a few days after that. If you want to collect colostrum that’s leaking during pregnancy, you can collect it using a syringe (as they’re just tiny drops) and store it in a breast milk storage bag or a small medicine cup if you’re at the hospital. You certainly don’t need to, but it can be nice to have if, for example, your baby is at risk of being born preterm or you know that they’ll need to spend time in the NICU—you’d feed them using a syringe or cup-feeding. But collecting colostrum in advance is usually not necessary.”

items.header: How do you know if the baby is getting enough milk during each feeding?

content.value: NW: “Always speak with a
lactation consultant

right away if you’re worried that your baby isn’t getting enough milk, especially in the early days when weight gain is most important. Here are a few ways you can check to make sure that your baby is getting enough milk during each feeding:
Weight gain

Weight gain is the most obvious way to know that your baby is getting enough milk while breastfeeding. They should be back up to their birth weight by two weeks old. That said, you’re probably not weighing them daily and there may be weeks between appointments at the pediatrician. So the next indicator is to watch them feeding.
Active sucking and swallowing

Once your mature milk has come in, usually 2-4 days after birth, you’ll want to make sure that your baby is actively sucking and swallowing during feedings. They’ll start with a fluttery suck to trigger your milk letdown. As your breast milk starts flowing, they’ll start a more rhythmic sucking—usually 3-4 sucks and then a swallow. You may see their chin lift or hear a gulp or notice a pause as they swallow. This is a great indicator that they’re having a good feed. If they’re only flutter-sucking and don’t seem to be actively sucking and swallowing, they may not be getting enough milk. You can do some breast compressions to speed up the flow of milk by compressing and massaging the breast they’re nursing on or try a
new position
to help your baby get a better latch. A
lactation consultant on Maven
can help you with this.
Breast changes
You can also feel your breasts before and after a feeding. They should feel full before a feeding and softer after if your baby has done a good job of emptying your breast and getting milk.
Satisfied baby

You can also watch your baby’s reaction after a feeding. If they had a good feeding they’ll seem satisfied, relaxed, and “milk drunk” after. They look content and may even be zonked out after a feeding. If they seem irritated or continue to root for your breast after feeding, this may be an indicator that they aren’t getting enough milk.
Dirty diapers

And finally, diapers are a telltale sign that feedings are going well. In baby’s first days of life their wet and dirty diapers should mimic the day of life. For example, 1 dirty diaper and 1 wet diaper on their first day of life. Two dirty and 2 wet diapers on their second day of life, and so on. After 5+ days, they should have 2-4 dirty and 6-8 wet diapers. (These are minimums; there could be more.)

You should also notice their stools transition in color—going from thick, tarry black meconium stools to greenish brown as their GI system clears and they get more breast milk, then to yellowish seedy breast milk bowel movements. Transitioning to yellow bowel movements means that the meconium has been cleared out by plenty of breast milk consumption.”

items.header: Does the baby get all the nutrients they need through breast milk? Should we supplement on top of breast milk?

content.value: NW: “Breast milk has all of the nutrients your baby needs except Vitamin D. Talk to your pediatrician or a
pediatrician on Maven
about giving your baby Vitamin D supplements via drops.”

items.header: What are the feeding cues I should look out for?

content.value: NW: “Babies give feeding cues to show hunger. Early feeding cues are rooting around, turning their head from side to side and moving their mouth in a sucking motion. They may even start sucking on your skin, neck, or shoulder if you’re holding them as they look for a breast. Your baby may also put their fists or thumbs to their mouth to suck on if they’re hungry.

Crying is a late feeding cue. You want to try your best to look for the early cues before your baby gets to crying because once they’re crying (or screaming) they’re not as patient and this can make latching and successfully breastfeeding more difficult. During the night you’re not likely to catch those early cues though, because hopefully you’re sleeping! That’s why your baby will use crying to get your attention in the night.”

items.header: What causes a baby to spit up after a feeding?

content.value: NW: “If you have a baby who spits up frequently after eating, especially after a night feeding, it can make you feel anxious, but keeping them upright and burping them after feedings can help. After feeding your baby, you’ll just want to keep them upright for 15-20 minutes to help prevent them from spitting up the milk immediately upon lying down.

It can be worrisome, but rest assured that it’s very unusual for a baby to choke on their spit up. They usually turn their heads to the side and the spit will then fall out. Holding them up for a bit after feeding is the best thing you can do.

Keep in mind that in many instances, breastfed babies spit up because they’re getting more milk than they need. If you have a good supply or fast letdown, your baby may simply be getting too much breast milk. If they’re spitting up, gaining weight well, and don't seem bothered by the spit up, then this is usually the case and will most likely resolve on its own as your baby gets bigger. However, if your baby seems in pain and is spitting up, they may have reflux and you’ll want to talk to your child’s pediatrician or a
pediatrician on Maven
for more support.”

items.header: When should I start pumping and how often should I be pumping in between feedings?

content.value: NW: “You don’t want to start pumping too early in your breastfeeding journey. In the early weeks the most important thing is to work on establishing a good latch and a good breastfeeding rhythm to establish your supply. In the early weeks removing milk regularly is key. If you’re returning to work or would like someone else to help with bottle feeding or need to pump for any other reason, waiting until your baby is around 6-8 weeks is a good idea if you can to not interfere with establishing breastfeeding and your milk supply. At first, start by pumping once a day for about 15 minutes. I recommend doing it right after your first feeding of the day because this is when you tend to have the most milk. You can do this over a few days to get the hang of pumping and you can collect whatever ounces you get across those few first days to make a bottle. Once you get the hang of pumping, and your baby begins to take a bottle in place of a nursing session (both processes can take a few weeks), you’ll pump each day when your baby is bottle feeding to replace that feeding for the next day, so you don’t need a huge stash in advance.

As your supply gets established and your body gets used to pumping, expect to pump both breasts for 15-20 minutes each during a pumping session to make up a bottle of milk for your baby. Massaging your breasts before pumping can help with letdown. Just know that what you pump doesn’t necessarily equate to what your baby is getting when they nurse. A baby is much better at extracting milk than any pump is. So if you’re only able to get an ounce of breast milk out sometimes when using your pump, this doesn’t mean that your baby is only eating an ounce when they’re breastfeeding.

If you’re pumping for the next day’s milk or you’re exclusively pumping, you’ll want to pump on the same schedule that your baby feeds, so every 2-3 hours, in order to keep your supply up. For example, if you sleep or work for 8 hrs but your baby normally feeds 2-3 times in that 8 hours, your supply will drop if you don’t pump at about the same times during that 8-hour stretch. Instead, you would need to pump as many times as you would normally be nursing, even if someone else is giving them a bottle. You could stretch it to every 4 hours overnight in the early weeks if your baby is sleeping 4-hour stretches, but I wouldn’t go longer than that in the early weeks where their weight gain and establishing your milk supply is most important.”

items.header: How long should you breastfeed to give the baby the most benefits?

content.value: NW: “The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and The World Health Organization (WHO) recommend exclusively breastfeeding your baby until 6 months of age and then continuing to breastfeed until 2 years or longer for health benefits (while also offering complimentary foods).

Those are the official recommendations but know that any amount of breastfeeding or breast milk is wonderful for your baby. Two years is a great goal, but two days, two weeks, two months is great, too. It’s all personal and a lot depends on how well things are going for you. If you’re stressed and it’s not the best for you and baby, rest assured that your baby will still benefit from any time spent breastfeeding. And on the other end, if you’re still breastfeeding your baby at two or three years old, know that it’s still beneficial and has immune factors.”

items.header: How many weeks do you feed the baby on the every 3 hours schedule?

content.value: NW: “You can expect to feed your baby about every 3 hours for at least the first two weeks. And this schedule is from the beginning of one feed to the beginning of the next. Once baby is feeding and gaining weight well, if your baby wants to sleep 4-6 hours overnight and your pediatrician doesn’t have any concerns, it’s okay to extend this time, especially if they’re eating well during the day. Once your baby reaches 2 weeks old,has regained their birth weight and is otherwise healthy, you can begin to follow their lead regarding a feeding schedule.

Know that it’s normal for babies to eat very frequently at first. I would not, for example, recommend a sleep training method that doesn’t allow for any overnight feedings or an 8-12 hours stretch if the baby is only a few weeks old. This isn’t healthy for your baby or your milk supply. In this early phase, babies are waking in the night because they need to eat.”

items.header: Should you always feed the baby at both breasts, even in the beginning? And how long at each breast?

content.value: NW: “During the first few days of breastfeeding, when baby is feeding on colostrum, nursing duration can vary anywhere from about 5-15 minutes at each breast. When your milk comes in, baby may nurse anywhere from 15-40 minutes total or about 20 minutes per breast, and this time tends to get shorter as they become more efficient at feeding. You want to alternate breasts, if not at every single session then between sessions to make sure you establish a good supply and avoid clogged milk ducts.

It’s also always a good idea to offer the other breast at each feeding. That said, if you have a great supply and your baby seems full, you don’t have to offer the second one every time. But if your baby doesn’t seem full, offer the second breast even if it’s for a few minutes. If your baby falls asleep mid-feed and burping doesn’t stimulate them, there’s no need to rouse them for the second breast every time. Just try to make it a general habit to offer both.”

items.header: If the baby only takes one breast, should I pump the other one?

content.value: NW: “If your baby doesn’t nurse at both breasts at a feeding, just start at the side they didn’t nurse from next time. There’s no need to pump (this can lead to engorgement or oversupply). Your body figures out how to balance your milk supply. Your other breast may get a little full, but your body will slow production and balance out supply. The less you interfere with your supply and production and just try to keep feeding even between your breasts, the better your body will be able to intuitively balance everything out on its own.”

items.header: How do you know when to switch breasts/sides during a feed?

content.value: NW: “If your baby is actively sucking, let them keep going on that breast. Once your mature milk comes in you’ll be able to more easily notice this sucking and swallowing and should feed the baby on one side for as long as that’s happening. If they seem to have a good feed with lots of sucking and swallowing and then start fluttering their tongue and stay there, stop sucking altogether or become sleepy, this is a good indicator that it’s time to switch to the other breast. You can burp your baby before switching them to the other breast to help stimulate them enough to nurse on the other side (even if they don’t actually let out a burp). Babies won’t always take the second breast, but always offer it even if they only nurse for a few minutes.

The breast that got the least attention in the last feed should then be the breast you start with on the next feed. It will usually be physically obvious and feel fuller or denser but you can also use a hairband on your wrist to remind you.”

NW: “Hand expression is a way of using your hand to empty milk from your breasts. You make a C-shape with your hand on your breast and squeeze behind your nipple in a rhythmic way to encourage letdown. (You can see this technique demonstrated in this
Stanford University video

Hand expression is a helpful thing to know how to do if you’re in a pinch and don’t have access to a pump. It’s also one of the best ways to alleviate engorgement (when your breasts become uncomfortably full), because pumping can make engorgement worse.”

items.header: Do you need to hand express colostrum during the first few days?

content.value: NW: “There’s no need to hand express colostrum in the first few days. You can just let your baby feed on it directly by nursing. If there’s a medical reason or your baby is in the NICU and you need to hand express colostrum then you can hand express into a metal medicine cup or spoon provided by the hospital—the hospital staff can show you how to do this.”

items.header: How do you save hand expressed colostrum and feed it to baby?

content.value: NW: “If you need to hand express colostrum, the hospital can provide a tubing system, metal medicine cup, or a syringe to help you collect hand-expressed colostrum to then feed to your baby. Hospital staff can show you how to cup feed because the amounts are so small.”

items.header: When should I start introducing bottle feedings?

content.value: NW: “Once your supply is established and your baby is latching well, at about 6-8 weeks, you can try introducing a bottle. Five weeks at the earliest. It’s tough to mix in bottle feedings before this time and I generally advise against it unless you have to for health or work reasons because breast stimulation and removal of milk in early weeks is so important to establishing your supply. If you start giving a bottle in the early weeks it will affect your supply but you have to find what works for you.

As for nipple preference concerns, I think babies can develop less of a nipple preference and more of a flow preference when bottles are introduced. Breast milk comes out of a bottle quickly. It’s easy and doesn’t take much work and babies tend to like that. Breastfeeding takes work. It may take a minute or more for baby to suck enough to start your milk flow. As a result, having bottles too soon may make them more easily frustrated at the breast. For this reason, I recommend paced feeding when introducing a bottle. Try to mimic breastfeeding by slowly tipping the bottle back, allowing baby to get a little milk, then take a break. This can help with the transition from breast to bottle and back.”

items.header: What are your recommendations for transitioning babies from breast-only to bottle/breastfeeding when mom has to go back to work?

content.value: NW: “At about 6-8 weeks ideally is the ideal time to introduce a bottle. For breastfeeding to go well, those first few weeks are important to be breastfeeding only if possible. Then you can work on adding bottles.

I recommend that you offer baby a bottle around 6-8 weeks as the sweet spot. You don’t want to do it too early because it can interfere with breastfeeding, but you also don’t want to wait too long because their sucking reflex diminishes between 8-12 weeks. Try offering a bottle a few weeks in advance of returning to work to get your baby used to it. Pump for 15-20 minutes and then offer the bottle to baby. See how much baby takes during the day and then you can schedule out your at-work pumping sessions based on this. For example, if your baby has 3 feeding sessions of 3-5 ounces each during the hours you’ll be away at work, you’ll need to plan to pump about the same amount at the same times baby usually feeds while you’re at work (so 9am, 12pm, 3pm for example).
What you pump one day you will feed your baby the next so don’t feel like you need a freezer full. I highly recommend talking to a
lactation consultant
to work on a specific plan for your situation.”

items.header: If we bottle and breastfeed, should we be changing the nipple size as the child grows? If so, how do we know when to change them?

content.value: NW: “I recommend keeping your baby on a slow flow nipple for a while so as not to make it too easy for them as this can cause issues with breastfeeding. A little work is okay as it mimics the work your baby puts into breastfeeding. If your baby is really struggling with the bottle and seems frustrated, that’s a good time to size up the nipple opening.”

items.header: Are there any foods/drinks to avoid while breastfeeding?

content.value: NW: “When it comes to foods to avoid while breastfeeding it’s not as restrictive as pregnancy as food-borne illnesses aren’t passed through breast milk. You don’t have to worry about eating sushi or raw fish or deli meats; those things are not off-limits while breastfeeding. You can drink caffeine but if you notice your baby is jittery, you may want to back off though most babies tolerate coffee just fine.

That said, anything with peppermint such as peppermint tea or Altoids can decrease milk supply. Also avoid decongestants such as Sudafed. Anything that decreases secretions can decrease breast milk supply.

On the same note, eliminating a bunch of foods from your diet or worrying about what you’re eating is misguided and based on misinformation. It’s very unusual that your diet will affect your baby. For example, things that cause gas in adults don’t cause gas in babies. Cruciferous foods cause gas in adult stomachs because they’re so hard to digest but your baby isn’t eating a whole head of broccoli like you are. If you eat a gassy food, it goes into your bloodstream and is digested. Your baby then receives it in a totally different form that isn’t difficult to digest because it’s already all broken down for them.

Acidic foods like tomatoes or orange juice can cause light skin irritation in your baby. If your baby is spitting up a lot and it’s not a result of oversupply of breast milk or fast letdown, and if your baby also has rashes and bowel issues, this grouping of symptoms may be connected to dairy. Babies can have a cow’s milk protein intolerance; they may also have responses to soy, eggs, or gluten and your pediatrician may recommend cutting these out if a sensitivity is seen.

But unless there is a known issue, I wouldn’t recommend eliminating foods. Talk to your pediatrician or a lactation consultant first. We want to make sure you’re getting the extra calories needed to produce breast milk and eliminating a lot of things from your diet can make this very difficult.”

items.header: Are there any foods/drinks that will help with milk supply before the baby is born?

content.value: NW: “There’s nothing you need to do to prep before or after baby comes in terms of breast milk supply. Frequent and effective removal of milk is the best way to make breast milk. Skin-to-skin time with your baby can also help. Beyond that, there are no magic foods or drinks that will help you make more breast milk. Lactation teas, cookies, or drinks don’t have a therapeutic dose high enough to have any benefit. If you’re having supply issues, talk to your provider or a lactation consultant about herbal supplements in pill form. They won’t work for everyone and should only be used with the guidance of a provider in certain amounts if you truly need it.

On the topic of drinks, you don’t have to drink extra water but you should drink to thirst while breastfeeding. Being dehydrated can negatively affect your milk supply, but drinking a gallon of water won’t increase your supply. Focus on simply staying hydrated and eating enough calories (more on that below).”

items.header: How many extra calories should you eat while breastfeeding?

content.value: NW: “Eating extra calories doesn’t make you make more milk but not eating enough calories does have a negative impact on your milk supply. You want to make sure you’re getting enough calories—an extra 300-500 a day to make adequate amounts of breast milk. And you definitely don’t want to restrict your calories while breastfeeding.

Some women lose weight quickly while breastfeeding, while some hold onto weight while breastfeeding because their bodies are worried they need to hold on to extra fat cells. Either way, avoid restricting your calories and extreme exercise, especially in the first few months where your milk supply is being established. Just make sure you’re getting good healthy extra calories and good fats and protein. That’s most important. You don’t have to eat an all organic diet to make healthy breast milk. Your milk will still provide your baby with all of the nutrients and components your baby needs.”

items.header: Do you need to continue to take prenatal vitamins while breastfeeding?

content.value: NW: “Taking prenatal or postnatal vitamins while breastfeeding can be a good way to get extra iron if your iron is low from blood loss after delivery, or from anemia for example, as this can affect breast milk supply. It’s best to get your nutrients in your diet but it’s a good idea to continue taking vitamins as an extra precaution.

This is less for your baby or your milk, but for your own health. If your diet doesn’t have the nutrients you need when breastfeeding, your body will leach calcium out of your bones and break down things from your body to make sure the baby gets what they need. As a result calcium supplements may be needed. Always talk to your provider first before taking any supplements or vitamins.”

items.header: Are there products or medications to avoid using while breastfeeding?

content.value: NW: “Anything that’s absorbed into your skin can get into your breast milk in tiny quantities. Things that are in your bloodstream may or may not pass into breast milk depending on the size of the particles. We don’t know for certain how many toxins get into our breast milk. Medications usually only get into breast milk in tiny amounts, depending on the medication and how it’s metabolized. Even the COVID-19 vaccine may only get into breast milk in tiny amounts if at all. Every part of the vaccine would most likely be broken down before it got into the milk supply. It may even confer some passive immunity to your baby. We don’t have enough studies to know for sure but the most current research seems promising that it’s safe for breastfeeding women.*

It’ll depend on the medication but most medications show up in very small amounts in breast milk. There are very few medications that can’t be used while breastfeeding and as a result, it’s much less restrictive than while pregnant.

It’s rare that a lactating parent would need to “pump and dump” while taking a short term course of a prescribed medication. Most supplements and pain medication after a C-section are also considered safe. But if you ever have a question about the safety of a medication or product while breastfeeding, always ask your OB or a lactation consultant. I also highly recommend the
University of Texas Infant Risk Center
. It’s run by a team of pharmacists and you can call their hotline and ask them Ask your OB or a lactation consultant about any medications before taking them.

*(According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, clinical trials for the COVID-19 vaccine have not included people who are breastfeeding but state that “based on how these vaccines work in the body, COVID-19 vaccines are thought not to be a risk to lactating people or their breastfeeding babies.” You can
find more information here

items.header: What’s the current science on drinking alcohol and breastfeeding?

content.value: NW: “If your blood alcohol content is low enough to be legally able to drive, then your breast milk alcohol content would be safe for the baby. The amount of alcohol in your blood is the same as that in your breast milk. So if you had one small glass of wine or one beer, you are likely safe to breastfeed. If you have a whole bottle of wine, that’s different and would be unsafe.”

items.header: Do you have to dump milk if you decide to have more than 1 drink?

content.value: NW: “It takes about 3 hrs for your body to metabolize a glass of wine or a beer. So if you have a small glass or a bottle of beer, you’re likely fine to breastfeed after. If you’ve had a bottle of wine that’s another story; you would not want to give your baby that milk by breast or pumped bottle. You can wait until you don’t feel intoxicated anymore then pump and dump that milk.”

items.header: Are there any tricks to prevent mastitis?

content.value: NW: “Mastitis is an infection that can happen while breastfeeding. It may happen if you have nipple damage that doesn’t heal and bacteria gets in, from clogged milk ducts from infrequent breastfeeding or an incorrect latch that doesn’t allow your breast to be fully drained during feedings, it may be caused by underwire bras that cause pressure, or the cause can be completely unknown.

You can sometimes resolve clogged ducts with cool and warm compresses and ibuprofen but if you experience fever or sudden, flu-like symptoms and find warm and tender lumps in your breast you need to reach out to your OB or an
OB-GYN on Maven
as you most likely need antibiotics.

Mastitis can’t necessarily be avoided completely, but emptying breasts completely and frequently is the best way to help avoid it. If your breast stays full for too long, milk can become clogged in a duct which can lead to mastitis.
Here are some additional tips to help avoid mastitis:

Empty breasts frequently - if you’re pumping, empty completely; if you’re nursing, you usually don’t need to worry about pumping after baby eats, just make sure they’re feeding well and emptying the breast
Don’t go too long between feeds (every 2-3 hours recommended in the early weeks of life, stretching to every 4-5 as your baby gets older)
Don’t wear underwire bras
Avoid nipple damage and skin breakage (as bacteria can enter and lead to mastitis)
If you have any broken skin, use nipple cream to speed healing and check with a provider if you need guidance
Anytime you feel a clogged duct (a lump that’s painful and swollen) apply warm compress lightly massage before feeding; after feeding, apply cold compress and take ibuprofen

Be very careful with massaging: Use very light pressure, as though you were applying lotion to your skin. Do not dig at a lump as though it was a muscle knot—massaging too intensely can make things worse and even lead to abscess formation

items.header: What are your thoughts on the Haakaa?

content.value: NW: “The Haakaa is a great passive suction pump for collecting milk. It’s good for catching leaking milk from the side baby isn’t nursing on but I would not use it to remove milk that the baby should be getting—just for catching any excess that may be leaking out. Just be aware that if you exert too much suction you can develop an oversupply issue.

If you’re leaking a lot of excess milk ( more than 4 ounces in a day) that you’re collecting with the Haakaa in addition to nursing your baby, your Haakaa use may be causing or contributing to the creation of an oversupply of breast milk. Over time, your supply should regulate to baby’s intake so that you’re leaking less and less, but continued daily use of the Haakaa can send mixed messages to your body so that it thinks that extra milk is still desired. If you need guidance on how to break this cycle, check in with a
Maven lactation consultant

items.header: Can a Haakaa help with engorgement?

content.value: NW: “The Haakaa is a great way to help with engorgement. Do some massaging and then put the Haakaa on for a minute just until your breast softens up. You just don’t want too much suction. Electric pumps, by comparison, can be too much suction which can cause more engorgement and tissue inflammation. The Haakaa is definitely the way to go if you need to soften engorgement.”

items.header: Should we be using Haakaa for letdown right from the beginning or wait for several weeks?

content.value: NW: “You don’t need to use the Haakaa at all but if you’re leaking a little and want to collect that, you can use the Haakaa, just exercise caution and use the slightest amount of suction. I recommend the Milkies Milk Saver for collection without suction. Haakaa is more ideal for engorgement or clogged milk ducts.”

title.en-US: What is neonatal abstinence syndrome, and how long will my baby be in the hospital?

content.value: What you need to know:

Neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) happens when a baby becomes addicted to a drug or other substance while in the womb. After they are born, they go through withdrawal from the drug or substance (just like an adult).
Most babies have symptoms of NAS a few days after they are born. Symptoms can last several weeks in serious cases
Babies with NAS need extra love, patience, and care while they get better.
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

When someone uses drugs or certain medications during pregnancy, those drugs or substances can reach their baby before they are born. This can be bad for the baby’s health and it can affect how they grow and develop. It can also lead to the baby going through withdrawal after they are born.
Read on for everything you need to know if you are using drugs while pregnant and what you can do today to help your baby.
What is neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS)?

A baby who has been exposed to drugs or substances during pregnancy can become dependent on them. After the baby is born, and not getting those drugs or substances from their mother anymore, the baby can go through withdrawal just like an adult. This is called “neonatal abstinence syndrome,” or NAS. (If it’s caused by opioid use, it’s sometimes called neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome or NOWS.)
What kinds of drugs can cause NAS?
If a pregnant person uses any of these drugs, their baby can have NAS when they’re born:
opioids
heroin
hydrocodone (Vicodin)
codeine
oxycodone (OxyContin, Percocet)
tramadol
methadone
fentanyl
morphine (Kadian, Avinza)
benzodiazepines (like Valium or Xanax)
Buprenorphine (Subutex, Suboxone)
barbiturates
certain antidepressants/anti-anxiety meds (like selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or SSRIs)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Using alcohol, nicotine, marijuana, cocaine, or amphetamines while pregnant can make a baby’s NAS symptoms worse and often cause additional health issues for babies.
What are the symptoms of NAS?

The symptoms of NAS will depend on a lot of things, like the type of drug(s) used during pregnancy, how much was used, for how long, when the last use was, and when the baby is born (if they’re born early, before 37 weeks of pregnancy, symptoms can be worse).
Symptoms of NAS usually start in the first few days after the baby is born, but they can take up to a week to show.
Some babies with NAS may only have mild or moderate symptoms, like:
Crankiness
Trouble sleeping
Trouble eating
Excessive weight loss
Skin irritation
A lot of crying or very high-pitched crying
Stuffy nose, sneezing
Yawning more than usualREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Some babies with NAS may have stronger, more severe symptoms, like:
Diarrhea
Jerky movement
Sweating
Fast breathing
Fever
Shaking or tremors
Seizures
Vomiting
Severe painREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
In very serious cases, NAS can cause death in babies.
How is my baby tested for NAS?

Your baby’s health care team won’t know if your baby has NAS until after they’re born. After your baby is born, they will take the following steps to find out if your baby has NAS, how severe it is, and what treatment will help your baby feel better.
Your baby will have an NAS scoring test.
Your baby’s health care team will monitor your baby’s symptoms, and score them according to the NAS scoring system (which evaluates symptoms and how severe they are).
Their urine and stool (or poop) may also be tested for drugs and other substances.
Your care team will ask you some questions.

They will ask about the types of drugs you used during pregnancy, how much, and when they were taken. Remember, the goal isn't to make you feel bad. This information helps your care team know how to best treat your baby. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“Different drugs stay in the body for different amounts of time,” says Maven Maternal-Fetal Medicine specialist, Kathryn Berryman, MD. “NAS will develop anywhere from the first day of life to up to one week of life. It will depend on the types of exposures that the baby had in pregnancy. That is why it’s important to share this information.”
You may also be asked to take a urine test.

Please know that your care team’s first priority is to take care of you and your baby. There is a possibility that what you share with a care provider may be reported, if legally required in your state.
Learn about the reporting laws in your state (scroll down to see a state chart)
What kind of treatment will my baby get?
Depending on how severe your baby’s NAS symptoms are and their NAS score, they may need treatment and they may need to stay in the hospital.
If your baby’s NAS symptoms are mild,

their treatment may just be love, care, and patience from you while the drugs leave their system. “We try to create a quiet, soothing environment for them without lots of extra stimulation,” says Maven Pediatrician Amy Brandon, MD. “You can help a lot with soothing! You can hold your baby skin to skin, quietly rock them, and help the care team with swaddling and feeding.”
If your baby’s symptoms are severe,

they may need medicine (usually liquid morphine or methadone) in addition to your love and care. These medicines will help your baby be more comfortable and the dose will be slowly lowered to help your baby adjust to life without it. Then the medicines will be stopped. If your baby needs treatment, they will stay in the neonatal intensive care unit (or NICU) in the hospital so they can be closely watched.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Your baby may also get fluids through an IV, a small needle placed in their arm, to make sure they don’t become dehydrated.

Your care team will continue to evaluate your baby’s symptoms and how severe they are and score them with the NAS scoring system every few hours to monitor how they’re doing. They will check that your baby is eating OK and gaining weight. Your care team will talk to you about the best way to feed your baby based on how they’re feeling and their treatment. If your baby is having trouble eating, they may suggest a special high-calorie formula to help your baby gain weight. In the beginning, some babies may need to be fed through a small tube inserted from their mouth into their stomach.
How long will my baby be in the hospital?

This depends on how severe your baby’s symptoms are, and how they respond to treatment. They may be in the hospital for a week or several weeks. If your baby’s withdrawal symptoms are more severe and they need continued treatment, they may be in the hospital for a month or more so they can be closely monitored until they’re better.
Once your baby can come home with you, they will still need extra attention and patience.
Here are some tips to help you care for a baby with NAS.
What can I do to help my baby today?
Getting support to stop drug use and starting treatment as soon as possible is the best thing you can do for yourself and your baby. Don’t wait until after birth to get help.
Do not stop using drugs suddenly.
Always talk to a doctor first because stopping drug use on your own can be dangerous for you and your baby.
Tell your doctor or a
pregnancy provider on Maven
right away if you’re using drugs while pregnant.

They can help you find support and treatment that’s safe while pregnant. Remember, it is free to talk to any provider on the Maven app, anytime.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKKeep in mind that reporting laws vary per state. If you need help finding a doctor who will support you, message your Care Advocate .REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Start treatment.

Starting treatment now can make the symptoms of NAS less severe for your baby. Search for a treatment center near you through your insurance company's website or state’s Medicaid website or by calling the helpline on your insurance card.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn more about treatment options that are safe while pregnant.
We’re here to help

Using drugs does not make you a bad person and there is no shame in asking a doctor for help. “You deserve to get the support you need,” Maven Mental Health Provider Nashay Lorick, LCSW, says. “There are many treatment options available for you. A mental health provider can help you find the right treatment and connect you to any other resources that might be helpful . You are not alone! Take full advantage of the care that is available. You are worth it. Your baby is worth it.”
If your doctor isn’t supporting you or you’re nervous about asking for help, talk to a
doctor on Maven
or message your Maven Care Advocate  for free help anytime.
Sources
March of Dimes
National Library of Medicine: MedlinePlus
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title.en-US: What are safe treatments for opioid use during pregnancy?

content.value: What are safe treatments for opioid use during pregnancy?
Using opioids (like heroin, fentanyl, codeine, morphine, OxyContin or Vicodin) during pregnancy can be very dangerous for your health and your baby’s health.

If you use opioids during pregnancy, it is important to tell your pregnancy provider right away. They are there to support you and can help you stop using opioids with medication and other treatments.
Your healthcare team can help you decide what kind of opioid use treatment is best for you and your baby. Maven providers are always here to help if you have questions or need advice.

You do not have to wait until your baby is born to start getting help for opioid use. In fact, the sooner you get help, the better off you and your baby will be. “There are many treatment options available to you. Some are inpatient treatment centers, outpatient therapy, or treatment in the comfort of your own home,” says Maven Mental Health Provider Nashay Lorick, LCSW. “It is best to
speak with a provider

who can support you and recommend the best treatment for you because stopping opioids on your own can be dangerous for you and your child. Remember that getting treatment is a hard, but important decision that will improve your life and your baby’s life.”
Here are the best treatment options that are safe to do while pregnant and how to find a treatment center near you.
How opioids affect your pregnancy and baby

Using opioids while pregnant can be very dangerous for your health and your baby’s health. Opioids like heroin, fentanyl, codeine, morphine, OxyContin or Vicodin and others can increase the risk of having a miscarriage, early birth, issues with baby’s growth and development and low birth weight. It can also increase the risk of stillbirth, sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS), and neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS), where a baby experiences withdrawal symptoms after birth.
Learn more about neonatal abstinence syndrome.
How treatment can help your baby

The great news is that OUD (opioid use disorder) is treatable and can be safely managed while you are pregnant. Starting treatment while pregnant can lower health risks for you and your baby. It can also make the symptoms of NAS less severe for your baby after they are born.

You will also be less exposed to diseases that can spread through needle use like HIV or hepatitis when getting medication through a provider, you are less likely to overdose, and you may be more likely to go to your prenatal care appointments when you are stable. This means an overall healthier life for you, and a healthier start to life for your baby.

“We recommend treatment with methadone or buprenorphine for pregnant people who are trying to stop using opioids,” says Maven Pediatrician Amy Brandon, MD. “These medications can prevent withdrawal for you, and can also help your care team and baby’s care team when it is time for delivery. Together with prenatal care, these medications can really make a difference and give your growing family its best start.”
How to find a treatment center
Tell your doctor that you want to learn about treatment for opioid use
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThey can tell you where to find help. Keep in mind that there is a chance that what you share with a care provider may be reported,
if legally required in your state
. If you do not feel supported by your doctor, or do not have a doctor, message your Maven Care Advocate  for help finding a doctor who will support you.
Find a treatment center in your area
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKGo to your insurance website or state’s Medicaid website or call the number on your insurance card for help finding a treatment center near you.
Get free online help on Maven
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKMessage your Care Advocate  who can connect you to a care provider on Maven for free counseling or help you find a treatment center.
Safe treatment options
Talk to your doctor or a
pregnancy provider on Maven
for free to learn more about these treatment options, and find a treatment center near you.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Methadone vs. buprenorphine in treatment

If you choose to start MOUD treatment, you may be offered methadone or buprenorphine medication. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and the American Society of Addiction Medicine recommends methadone or buprenorphine as the best treatment options for opioid use disorder during pregnancy. But, what is the difference?
REPLACEWITHACCORDION

Keep in mind that if you have already started treatment with methadone, you cannot switch to buprenorphine. It can cause very strong withdrawal symptoms. But it is safe to switch from buprenorphine to methadone.
The risks

Your baby may experience NAS after birth if you go through MOUD treatment while pregnant. This is a known effect and it is treatable. It is usually much easier to treat than NAS from opioid use outside of treatment. “MOUD treatment (with methadone or buprenorphine) is absolutely much healthier and safer for you and your baby than using street drugs,” Berryman says.
Your doctor will work closely with your baby’s care team to slowly taper your baby off of the medication used for your treatment if they show
symptoms of NAS
. Your doctor or a
provider on Maven
can help explain any risks of opioid treatment on your baby’s health. They can also help you weigh these risks against the much higher risks of not seeking treatment and using opioids while pregnant.
After your baby is born

When your baby is born is the most important time to keep up with your treatment and rely on your support network. Stopping treatment at this time can do more harm than good. Especially with the increased stress of taking care of a newborn. The risk of relapse and accidental overdose can be higher at this time, so make a plan to keep working with your doctors to get the help you need.

Know that you can continue to get treatment as long as you need to. Just check with your doctor to talk about whether it is safe to breastfeed based on the medication you are taking. “Breastfeeding is usually encouraged for women who are stable in an opioid maintenance treatment program,” says Berryman.
You can continue MOUD treatment for as long as needed. If you feel stable and ready to stop treatment, work with your provider and treatment center to do this slowly, and safely.
How to get help

Message your Care Advocate  for a personal recommendation on who to talk to for more treatment information. They can help you find a supportive doctor on Maven to explain your treatment options and answer any questions you may have. “You are taking very important first steps in making a healthier life for yourself,” Lorick says. “This is not easy but you have what it takes to take these steps. We are ready and waiting to support you on your journey.”
Sources
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
National Institute on Drug Abuse
National Institutes of Health
The New England Journal of Medicine

MOUD is the most effective and highly recommended treatment for opioid use disorder in pregnant people. It is covered by Medicaid programs and some insurances. It is sometimes called opioid agonist pharmacotherapy, medication-assisted treatment, or simply MAT.

MOUD uses a combination of daily medication, counseling, and peer groups. You will receive a dose of methadone (or buprenorphine) every day from a licensed opioid treatment program. This medication prevents withdrawal symptoms and reduces or stops your cravings.

It is usually an outpatient program, meaning you do not stay overnight at a facility and it is up to you to show up to your daily appointment for treatment success. Some MOUD programs may be inpatient if you want more support sticking to treatment.

“MOUD treatment is preferred because medically supervised withdrawal and quit programs have a high rate of relapse,” says Maven Maternal-Fetal Medicine doctor Kathryn Berryman, MD. “Pregnancy is a time to focus on getting stable, which is what MOUD offers. Quitting opioids completely can be safer to do after pregnancy.”

Mental health issues like depression, anxiety, past trauma, and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) are often connected to drug use so behavioral therapy, addiction counseling, and peer support groups are usually part of MOUD treatment. “It is important to get counseling while you are being treated with medications. It is a way to look at all the issues in your life that can lead to opioid use,” Lorick says. “ Studies have shown that recovery from substances is more effective when we can take care of mental health and substance use disorders at the same time.
”You can continue MOUD treatment for as long as you need to and it is safe to do while pregnant and after your baby is born.

items.header: If MOUD is not available in your area

content.value: You can consider treatment that uses combination medication (such as Suboxone) or medically supervised withdrawal where you are given methadone or buprenorphine in doses that are slowly lowered and then stopped. There are also treatment programs where you gradually stop opioid use without medication.
Unfortunately, these programs have high relapse rates (so they also run the risk of higher rates of overdose)—so they are not recommended for pregnant women.
Talk to your doctor or a
pregnancy provider on Maven
to weigh the risks of these other treatment types if MOUD treatment is not available to you.
Methadone has been used as a treatment since the 1970s with many studies done on how effective and safe it is.

It is currently illegal for a physician to prescribe opioids, including methadone, to treat OUD outside of a licensed opioid treatment program or hospital setting—so you will only be able to get methadone treatment through these facilities.

The pros of working with a treatment center to take methadone are that you have extra support to help you stay on track and it lowers your risk of overdose. But it does mean you have to show up to the center every day if you are an outpatient.
Some studies show that methadone may be more effective than buprenorphine.
Buprenorphine is a newer medication that has been around since 2002 so there is not as much long-term information about how it can affect you or your child.
This medication can be prescribed by a doctor’s office and self-administered—meaning, you could take it yourself at home.

The pro of giving yourself buprenorphine treatment medication at home is that you do not have to get to a center every day. But it does put more pressure on you to remember to take your medication daily and at the right dosage.
Some studies

have found that babies born to women who took buprenorphine while pregnant seemed to have less severe NAS withdrawal symptoms than those who took methadone. This could mean less time in the hospital and less medication needed for your baby.
It also has weaker opioid effects than methadone, so overdose is less likely, and you may have fewer withdrawal symptoms when you stop taking it.

title.en-US: How to time contractions and when to go to the hospital

content.value: What you need to know:
Sometimes it is hard to tell if you are in early labor or feeling something else, like Braxton Hicks (practice contractions) or gas.
Timing contractions can help you figure out if you are in labor.

If you are less than 37 weeks pregnant, go to your hospital or birthing center if you have contractions that come every 10 minutes or less, bleeding, strong cramping, severe back pain, or your water breaks. These could be signs of preterm birth.
If you are 37 weeks pregnant or more, go to your hospital or birthing center when your contractions come every 4 minutes and last for 1 minute for 1 hour.
Timing contractions can help you figure out if you are in early labor or if you are feeling something else. Here is what you need to know.
How do I know if I’m in labor?
The strength and timing of your contractions can tell you if you are having labor contractions.
Contractions

During early labor, contractions feel like very strong period cramps. You will feel a tight squeeze in your back and belly. At first, contractions do not last long and do not come in a pattern. As time goes on, contractions will feel stronger and longer, and come more regularly.
Braxton Hicks

Braxton Hicks are contractions that many people feel during pregnancy. But unlike labor contractions, Braxton Hicks are not very strong, do not come in a pattern, and usually go away if you change your position (like lying down instead of sitting up), drink water, or go to the bathroom. Braxton Hicks contractions are your body’s way of practicing for labor.
Gas pain

Having gas is very common during pregnancy. But unlike achy labor contractions, gas pains usually feel like a sharp pain. Gas pains also do not come in a regular pattern like labor contractions. For relief, try walking in place or doing some light stretches.
How to time contractions
If you think you are in early labor, it is important to figure out how often you are having contractions.

You will need a timer (a watch, a kitchen timer, or your phone’s timer will work), a pen, and a piece of paper (or use the notes on your phone). There are also apps you can download to track contractions on your smartphone.
How to time your contractions:
Use your timer to see how long each contraction lasts. Start timing from the beginning of the contraction until it goes away. Write it down.
Use your timer to see how often you are having contractions. You want to time it from the beginning of one contraction to the beginning of the next contraction. Write it down.
Repeat steps 1 and 2 for an hour.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Answer these questions to figure out if you are in early labor:
Do your contractions last at least 30 seconds?
Are your contractions getting longer and longer?
Are contractions coming on more often? REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
These are all good signs that you are in labor. It is a major sign if your water breaks, too.
Have questions about timing contractions? Ask us!
Maven OB-GYNs
are here to help for free at any time.
When to go to the hospital
Most people can stay at home during early labor, but it is a good idea to call your OB-GYN and let them know you are in early labor.
Go to the hospital right away if:
You have a high-risk pregnancy
You are bleeding
Your water broke and you tested positive for group B strep (GBS)
You have contractions that come every 4 minutes and last for 1 minute for 1 hour
You cannot talk or eat during a contractionREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you do not have any of the above, you can rest at home until your contractions become stronger and closer together.
If you think you are in labor, but are not sure, call your doctor or midwife, or you can video chat with a
Maven OB-GYN
online for free for advice.
We are here to help
It can be tough to tell if you are in early labor or if you are experiencing something else. But timing the length and how often contractions come on can help you figure it out.
If you have questions about timing contractions, be sure to ask your OB-GYN, or make a free, online appointment with a
Maven OB-GYN
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
Maven Clinic

title.en-US: This is how babies experience the birthing process

content.value: A step-by-step unfolding of how things go down from your little one’s perspective.

It’s wild to think that the most incredible trip you’ve ever taken is one that you can’t even remember. But that’s the case with all of us, who’ve undergone the journey from womb to the outside world.
Labor is the first thing that you and your baby will experience together, and although it’s impossible to know exactly what your baby is feeling, we can make an educated guess.

To start, babies are bound to feel a dropping and squeezing sensation. The head, the biggest part of your baby’s body, leads the way through this curious cul-de-sac that’s your birth canal. First the cervix; your baby’s one smart cookie, knowing to keep his chin tucked so it’s easier to move through. A baby’s body typically stays in one position with one shoulder toward your spine (that’s where he’s typically facing, too) and the other toward your belly. Then his malleable head squeezes through your vagina, sliding against your pubic bone. The shoulders and the rest of the body are a piece of cake, given the smaller diameter.

As for the temps: It gets cold. From your womb to the birthing room, there’s a 20-degree temperature drop. But don’t worry. Your baby’s got a nice supply of brown fat that’ll burn to keep him warm and help him adjust.
Babies typically open their eyes soon after birth (some immediately; others within minutes). It’s so bright! Things look fuzzy, since they’re nearsighted at birth.

As the umbilical cord is clamped, the oxygen that was once streamed into his system so seamlessly is cut off. He gasps—is it from emotional shock? Or a purely physical response? Likely the latter. The rest happens like clockwork. The fluid in his lungs drains or gets absorbed. The respiratory organs kick in, blood starts flowing, and the lungs inflate. Your baby is breathing on his own!
He cries and misses that cozy feeling in the womb. Let him snuggle up with you as soon as your doctor or midwife okays it—and welcome your baby to the world.

title.en-US: Understanding your partner’s morning sickness

content.value: Around 80 percent of women, by some estimates, have morning sickness during pregnancy. It usually starts in the first trimester, and usually improves by 16 - 20 weeks, although some women do suffer from morning sickness throughout their entire pregnancy. Interestingly, one large study actually found a possible link between nausea and a lower risk of miscarriage—which has fueled the myth that morning sickness is a surefire sign of a healthy pregnancy.

No one can say for certain what causes morning sickness. But one thing that’s for sure: It can be hard to see your partner in a daily hug-fest with the porcelain bowl. One dad-to-be put it this way: “Before watching my partner suffer through morning sickness, I thought a pregnant woman woke up feeling queasy, threw up and then went back to feeling fine for the rest of the day. Morning sickness is a total misnomer, since it can persist throughout the day.”
It’s normal to feel helpless at many stages during your partner’s pregnancy. But in this case, there are actually a few things you can do to ease her discomfort:
Keep her triggers away

It may seem obvious, but if you notice that your eau-de-breakfast triggers your partner’s gag reflexes in a major way, it’s a good idea to have your eggs or sausage (or whatever the offending food) in another room—or switch to a meal she can tolerate.
Feed her cravings

She’ll likely have a very good sense of her own aversions—and cravings—for food. Make sure you’re stocked up on her “yes” list, and encourage her to eat frequent smaller meals instead of three large ones. Experts say snacking can help keep morning sickness symptoms from getting worse.
Invest in a reusable water bottle
Hydration is key. Some women say ice chips and ice pops are also life-savers in this phase of pregnancy.
Keep an eye out for things getting worse

If your partner is vomiting so much that she can’t keep any food down, definitely encourage her to see her OB-GYN or consult with a Maven practitioner to talk about different treatment options for nausea. A doctor might prescribe an anti-nausea medication, recommend IV fluids for dehydration, or suggest a supplement like Vitamin B6.

title.en-US: An in-depth guide to fertility treatments in India

content.value: If you’ve been wading through a sea of fertility treatment information that leaves you feeling more confused than confident, don’t stress. Maven’s fertility guide will explain all the basics in one place, including the most common fertility treatments, average costs, and what to expect while going through treatment in India. Read on for clarity and the start of a better fertility journey.
Fast facts
1 in 5
Couples in India struggle with infertility
Infertility is 40% male factor, 40% female factor, 20% a combination of factors

Average cost for IVF treatment (per cycle). Medication alone can cost INR 80,000. When adding medications and procedures such as intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and frozen embryo transfer cycles (FET’s), the cost may be closer to INR 1,00,000 to 3,500,000. Average cost is between INR 1,00,000 to 3,50,000.
Who might need fertility treatment?

According to the World Health Organization, the prevalence of primary infertility in India is between 3.9-16.8% and varies from state to state. There are lots of reasons people need help conceiving, and the best treatment option for each person and couple depends largely on the cause of infertility. So what are some of the most common causes of infertility and who’s a good candidate for fertility treatment?
Common causes of infertility:
Age related fertility decline or diminished ovarian reserve (low egg count)
Blocked fallopian tubes (this may be genetic or caused by pelvic inflammatory disease or other infections)

Sexually transmitted infections (STI’s). STI’s are generally considered the leading preventable cause of infertility worldwide, causing approximately 70% of all pelvic inflammatory disease cases. STI prevalence is high in India.
Male factor (such as structural abnormalities or sperm production problems)
Ovulation issues (irregular or no ovulation)
Hormonal imbalances (such as thyroid disorders)
Abnormalities of the uterus (from birth or due to fibroids, polyps, etc)
Endometriosis
Combination of male and female factors
Unexplained factors
What to expect at your initial consultation

Once you’ve made the decision to explore or undergo fertility treatments, you’ll start with an initial consultation. In this first consultation, your clinical team will evaluate your fertility and medical history*—* this is a key part of planning your treatment. During this meeting they’ll discuss their reasons for recommending fertility treatment (intrauterine insemination or in-vitro fertilization) and explain the process step by step. The doctor will require several test results to plan the IUI/IVF cycle in detail.
Common tests

For female patients, a vaginal ultrasound is one of the most important diagnostic tests used to assess fertility. It will assess the structural anatomy of the uterus and ovaries, identifying any problems, and look at antral follicle count (AFC). The AFC looks at the amount of premature follicles (resting eggs) in the ovaries, allowing the physician to assess the patients’ egg reserve. Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is another marker of egg reserve that your physician will measure. The AFC and AMH results are used to guide the clinical team as to the type of protocol you need, and how they anticipate you’ll respond to the medications they prescribe.
Treatment options
Intrauterine insemination

Intrauterine insemination (IUI) involves injecting sperm directly into a woman's uterus. This bypasses the cervix, reducing the distance sperm has to travel to meet the egg and increasing the chances of pregnancy.
There are two options when it comes to IUI cycles: a stimulated or a natural approach.
Stimulated IUI

In stimulated IUI, your doctor will prescribe hormonal medications to stimulate the growth of more than one follicle in your ovaries and increase the chances of ovulation. These may be oral medications such as Clomiphene Citrate (Clomid), Letrozole tablets or hormonal injections known as gonadotropins. These hormonal injections are typically self-administered at home.

Stimulated IUI cycles usually require 4 to 6 clinic visits per treatment cycle so your doctor can closely monitor the growth of your follicles. The first visit is typically on day 2-3 of your menstrual cycle (to rule out any ovarian cysts), again on day 6 and more regularly depending on your response to the medication. During each visit, a pelvic ultrasound is performed to measure the size of the follicles and the thickness of the endometrial lining. After approximately 10-12 days of hormonal injections and once the follicle size reaches 20-22 mm in diameter, a HCG "trigger" shot is given to start ovulation. The IUI is then scheduled approximately 36-40 hours later.
Natural IUI

In a natural IUI cycle, no medication will be given. Your doctor will track the growth of the dominant follicle (egg) in your ovary by transvaginal ultrasound and when it’s big enough (18-20 mm), they’ll wait for the natural ovulation process to occur. This will be detected by a blood or urine test. The IUI will then be scheduled.

If a couple decides to do IUI using their own sperm, the man will be asked to provide a sperm sample at the fertility clinic by masturbating into a specimen cup. This usually happens on the same day that the IUI treatment takes place. The sperm sample will be "washed" and filtered to produce a concentrated sample of healthy sperm. If donated sperm is used, the sperm will be thawed and prepared in time for the IUI treatment to take place.
The cost of an IUI cycle is approximately INR 10,000 - 12,000 (excluding medication costs).
In-vitro fertilization

In-vitro fertilization (IVF) is a technique where a woman’s eggs and man’s sperm are combined in a special laboratory in order to create an embryo(s). Depending on the diagnosis and age of the woman, an embryo or, in some cases, embryos, are transferred to the woman’s uterus through her cervix to increase the chances of pregnancy. When this technology was first introduced in the 1970s, IVF was only recommended to women with blocked fallopian tubes. Currently, IVF success rates have improved dramatically, and in India, IVF is used for those experiencing a range of infertility causes and for single women pursuing parenthood. So what does it involve?
Step 1. Superovulation to boost egg production

Superovulation is a process to boost egg production. It begins with self-injection of medication containing follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), which causes egg growth in your ovaries. The more eggs produced, the higher chances of successful fertilization later in the treatment.

You’ll also receive blood tests and transvaginal ultrasounds regularly to monitor your hormone levels and check on your ovaries. You might experience bruising, tenderness, or pain at the injection sites. Hormonal medication might also cause emotional changes like mood swings, restlessness, irritability, or generally feeling down, as well as nausea, bloating, fatigue, and possible hot flashes.
Step 2. Egg retrieval

A day or two before your eggs are scheduled to be retrieved, you’ll self-administer a hormone injection that will help the eggs mature more quickly, known as a trigger shot. Roughly 36 hours later, you’ll undergo a minor outpatient surgical procedure called follicular aspiration to extract mature eggs.
