Most egg collection procedures are performed under conscious intravenous sedation, meaning you’ll be asleep and won’t feel or remember anything. You’ll likely experience some mild to moderate abdominal cramping and/or pelvic pain afterwards, but this pain is usually mild enough to be treated with over-the-counter pain medicine and disappears within a day or two after the procedure.
Step 3. Sperm production from partner or donor

During the egg removal process, the patient's partner will provide a sperm sample or a sample from donated sperm will be thawed. The sperm are then sorted through a high-speed wash and spin cycle to find the healthiest ones. Normally men will produce a fresh ejaculated sperm sample on the day of egg collection to fertilize the eggs however some men may need to freeze sperm in advance of the egg collection to ensure sperm is available on the day. This occurs when men have reduced sperm volume or quality or may have performance anxiety about producing a sample on the day.
Step 4. Fertilization of eggs

About an hour or so after the eggs have been retrieved and after the sperm has been prepared and assessed, sperm and egg are combined in a process known as insemination. Insemination involves placing a fixed amount of sperm around each egg in a petri dish in an incubator. It typically takes a few hours for a sperm to fertilize an egg, which is evaluated and reported on the following day.

If the sperm performance doesn’t meet the strict criteria for traditional insemination, then a technique called intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is performed. An embryologist injects the sperm directly into the egg under high magnification and checks to see whether fertilization occurred the next day.
Step 5. Blastocyst culture

Embryos (fertilized eggs) are grown in a special incubator that monitors the development of each individual embryo. The embryos are assessed the morning after the egg collection to confirm fertilization into a 2-cell embryo. The embryos, if normally fertilized, should go on to become rapidly expanding balls of cells (blastocysts). Blastocysts are formed by day 5 or 6 of their development. The outer layer of the embryo goes on to become the placenta and the inner cell mass goes on to form the baby. It’s common practice in IVF clinics to extend embryo culture for 5 days and until the embryos reach the blastocyst stage.
Embryo development and grading

You may have heard about embryo grading, where an embryologist makes an educated guess about an embryo’s potential based on certain characteristics like the number and size of cells and how quickly certain stages of development are reached. What does the grade of your embryo tell you about the chances of becoming pregnant? The honest answer is: not much. All embryo grading systems are subjective. A high grade doesn’t guarantee that an embryo will successfully implant and carry to term. Many embryos with “poor” grades will become healthy babies, while others graded as top quality will not. In some cases the reason for this will be genetic, which is something that cannot be assessed just by looking at the embryo. Preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) is the only way to assess embryo genetics.
Key milestones to focus on after your egg collection are:
By 16-18 hours post egg collection, fertilisation into a zygote should occur. If an embryo has not reached 2 cells within 24 hours, the process will be stopped.
By 48 hours (“day 2”), the embryos should be at least at the 2 to 4 cell stage.
By 72 hours (“day 3”), the embryos should have about 8-10 cells, also known as cleavage stage.
By ”day 5”, the embryos should reach 120 cells, also known as the blastocyst stage.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Connect with a
Maven Reproductive Endocrinologis
t to understand more about IVF versus ICSI and about embryo development.
Step 6. Embryo transfer
Reaching embryo transfer day is a huge milestone. There are two types of embryo transfers: Fresh and frozen.
Fresh embryo transfer

Once your eggs are collected, you’ll be prescribed luteal support in the form of either vaginal creams/pessaries or self-injectables. These are progesterone-based medications that prepare the lining of your uterus to receive the embryos that will be transferred back.

In a fresh embryo transfer cycle, the embryo transfer is done 5 days after your egg collection. Current recommendations in Western countries are to transfer a single embryo back into the uterus as opposed to two, to reduce the chance of a twin pregnancy. The embryo transfer is done while you’re awake, under ultrasound guidance using a very narrow catheter. It’s pain-free but a full bladder is required prior to the procedure to help with positioning of the uterus and to allow the smooth transfer of the catheter inside. Some women find this slightly uncomfortable, but manageable. The bladder can be emptied right away, after the embryo transfer. The progesterone medication will be continued until the first beta hCG pregnancy test is done, about 2 weeks later. If your cycle resulted in more than one viable embryo, they can be frozen for use in future IVF cycles.
Frozen embryo transfer (FET)

During a frozen embryo transfer cycle (FET), you’ll be given medications to build the endometrial thickness of your uterus to increase the odds that an embryo will implant. Since an FET cycle uses an embryo that’s already been created, you won’t need to undergo egg retrieval. There are a few ways to prep for a FET cycle:
Natural cycle:
A natural cycle follows the body’s dominant follicle where the mature follicle produces oestrogen and leads to the thickening of the endometrial lining.
Modified natural cycle:

This cycle is similar to a natural cycle except that an injection of hCG is given to trigger ovulation. You’ll use progesterone pessaries/injectables/oral tablets to prep your uterus for implantation.
Stimulated cycle:
In a stimulated cycle, ovulation is induced with medications (clomid, letrozole or gonadotropins).
Programmed cycle:

Oestrogen and progesterone medications are given to prep your uterus and the ovary is suppressed, so ovulation does not occur. The embryo transfer is planned a set number of days after progesterone support starts, usually for 3-6 days later. Estrogen and progesterone are continued and a pregnancy test is done 9-14 days after the transfer. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

There are a number of reasons why you might undergo a FET rather than a fresh transfer. For example, if you’re using embryos created from a previous treatment cycle, they’ll be transferred from frozen. Or, if your endometrial lining doesn’t reach desired thickness for a fresh transfer, your doctor may decide to postpone the embryo transfer, and you’ll need to do a FET transfer in the future instead.

Another common reason to do FET is when PGT-A genetic testing is being performed on the embryos to rule out chromosomal abnormalities. This process involves taking several cells from the outer layer of the fresh embryos then freezing the embryos while awaiting the results of the genetic test. Once the results are received and if a genetically normal embryo has been identified, a FET cycle will be planned.

If you’re at risk for Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS), your doctor may also decide to freeze all of your embryos for future use. Transferring an embryo back into the uterus while you’re at risk of OHSS is not recommended*—* if you became pregnant, the resulting increasing hCG levels would make OHSS worse. This can be potentially life threatening.
Frozen embryo transfer cycles offer:
Reduced risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
Optimization of endometrial receptivity
Time for PGT testing
Prioritisation of embryos for single embryo transfer (SET)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Pregnancy rates after FET have significantly increased over the years mainly due to advances in embryo freezing. This has led to many clinics encouraging elective “freeze-all”: freezing
all
suitable embryos for future use. A large 2020 review however, showed that there is no significant difference between birth rates in fresh ETs versus FETs for most patients.
So, who should consider freeze-all? Your physician may recommend it if any of the below apply to you:
You’re at risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
You have high progesterone on trigger day
You want to do PGT-A genetic testing
You have slow growth embryos
You have uterine abnormalities
Side effects of IVF
Side effects of IVF may include:
Nausea
Mood swings
Bloating
Fatigue
Bruising at the injection site
Vaginal discharge
Pelvic pain or abdominal pain REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Are there any risks?

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a possible complication of IVF where the ovaries swell and fluid leaks into the body. The condition is more common in women with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). After gonadotropin stimulation for IVF, the reported rate of moderate OHSS is 3% to 6%, and for severe OHSS it’s 0.1% to 2%. A milder form of OHSS occurs in about 20% to 33% of IVF cycles but isn’t a cause for concern. With close monitoring and the use of lower doses of gonadotropins to trigger ovulation, the risk of severe OHSS can be greatly reduced. (The risk of developing OHSS during medicated IUI cycles is much lower because the medication doses are lower.)
Are there any restrictions on who can access treatment in India?

In India, fertility treatment is legislated under The Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART Regulation Bill), 2021. The Act permits IUI and IVF treatments, surrogacy, egg donation, embryo donation and sperm donation within the country for heterosexual, married couples.

Surrogacy is regulated under The Surrogacy Regulation Bill (2019), which prohibits commercial surrogacy but allows altruistic surrogacy, where no monetary compensation is provided to the surrogate mother other than the medical expenses and insurance coverage during pregnancy. A certificate of eligibility is required from a District Medical Board with conditions that a couple pursuing surrogacy must have Indian citizenship, be a heterosexual couple married for at least five years, be between 23-50 years old (wife) and 26-55 years old (husband), without children of their own.

The ART Bill permits surrogacy, elective fertility preservation, egg donation, embryo donation and sperm donation within the country however single men, same-sex couples and LGBTQ people are not legally allowed to access fertility services.
Sex selection is prohibited, except under certain circumstances when it’s used to screen for genetic diseases.
LGBTQ family building

India decrimilinalised homosexuality in 2018 but because same-sex marriage remains illegal in India, same-sex couples cannot pursue fertility treatments, surrogacy or adoption. Single men, same-sex couples and LGBTQ people remain banned from accessing these services.
Single parenthood

The right of single mothers has been recognised by the Supreme Court since 2015 and more and more clinics are offering sperm donation and fertility treatments for single women wishing to start a family. Prospective single mothers are required to go through psychological counseling and screening where they’re asked about their reasons for pursuing single parenthood. An evaluation on factors like family support is also performed. Unlike other countries, Indian sperm banks don’t share images of sperm donors, but do share details on height, weight, education and complexion.
How much does IVF really cost?
As anyone who has undergone fertility treatments will tell you, the emotional and physical challenges can be immense. And the financial toll can be, too.
India’s public health insurance does not generally cover fertility treatments.
Out-of-pocket costs

The average out of pocket cost for an IVF cycle is between Rs 2.5 lakhs and Rs 4 lakhs, with medication costing anywhere from an additional 1 lakh. Costs also vary between clinics so requesting this information early on can be useful for comparing clinics.
What can impact the costs?

The number of cycles required. IVF isn’t always successful after the first cycle, which is why clinics quote their “cumulative success rate”, i.e. their results from one fresh IVF cycle and subsequent frozen embryo transfer (FET) cycles. Any subsequent FET cycle will incur additional costs ranging from 80,000 - 90,000 INR. and varies from clinic to clinic.
Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), a technique used to treat male factor infertility can cost INR 1,50,000.
Storage costs for any surplus eggs/embryos you store for future use. This can cost approximately INR 30,000 per year.
Medication dose and brand (generic v non-generic), ranging from INR 80,000 per cycle.
Genetic testing of embryos (PGT-A and PGT-M). The added cost of a PGT cycle is approximately INR 2,00,000 in addition to a standard IVF + ICSI cycle.
How to find a high quality fertility clinic
The process of finding the right clinic can feel overwhelming. Between factors like success rates, reviews and location, there’s a lot to consider.

There’s a lot about the fertility sector in India that’s not known; for example, how many fertility clinics and egg or sperm banks are actually operating in the country. It’s reported that approximately 80% of Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) clinics are
not

officially registered in India. The Assisted Reproductive Technology Bill passed in 2021 seeks to regulate and supervise ART clinics and banks, prevent misuse, and push for the adoption of safe and ethical practices.

Based on the number of applications received by the National ART Registry, The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) puts the number of fertility clinics in the capital, New Delhi, at 125. Officials however believe that the actual figure is around 250-300. While there’s no definitive data, it’s been reported that at least 3,000 clinics and egg/sperm banks are known to offer fertility treatments across the country (but not all of them are registered with the ICMR).

Unlike many other countries, India doesn’t have a country-wide mandate that IVF clinics must publish their success rates. That makes it hard to properly compare one clinic to another. And while there are no standard protocols for fertility centers to follow and currently reporting remains inadequate in the country, choosing a clinic with comparable or above national average success rates is a good starting point. Keep in mind though that in India, this can be difficult to navigate alone as clinics can still manipulate the data.
Here are a few key rates to focus on:
Cumulative live birth rate

This rate is arguably the most important rate to focus on and refers to the birth rate resulting from all of the eggs collected in one IVF cycle. Translation? The live birth rate after a fresh IVF cycle, including live births from any associated frozen embryos from that cycle within one year. This information provides those considering IVF with a better understanding of their chances of delivering a child when undertaking one egg retrieval procedure.
The Indian National Average IVF Live Birth Rate (Cumulative) is 35.7% for women of all ages (ICMART 2013, Fertility Sterility 2021).
REPLACEWITHASSET
Clinical pregnancy rate
Another important rate, this refers to a pregnancy that reaches the point where it can be seen on ultrasound (around 6-7 weeks gestational age and beyond).
The Indian national average IVF clinical pregnancy rate (fresh IVF) is 34.8% for women of all ages.
REPLACEWITHASSET
Multiple birth rate

Another important rate to consider is the multiple birth rate. India has seen a tenfold increase in twinning rates over the past two decades, owing mostly to assisted reproductive technology. Why does this matter? Twin pregnancies are much higher risk for both mother and babies, and babies born prematurely (as twins often are) are at greater risk for serious short term and long-term health problems.

Several countries outside of India have strict rules on promoting single embryo transfer practices, reducing the multiple birth rate. However, given the lack of strict laws in India, policies vary from clinic to clinic. When considering a clinic, look for a clinic with a multiple pregnancy rate as low as possible, ideally less than 10%.
Other important things to consider:
Responsive staff
You shouldn’t feel rushed. You should be able to ask all of your questions and get helpful answers in return.
Excellent reviews
Other patients should seem highly satisfied with the quality of the staff and services provided.
High-quality laboratory

The quality of the IVF lab is instrumental in ensuring the best possible embryos are created and the best possible outcome is achieved. What happens in the lab between your egg collection and embryo transfer could determine whether you deliver a healthy baby. Even if your embryos were top quality, a substandard lab could negatively impact embryos growth and ultimately affect your treatment outcome. This is why it’s important to ask for your IVF lab’s Performance Indicators (PI’s). Ask your clinic what their PIs are and compare them to those of other clinics in your area.

In 2017, the European Society for Human Reproduction and Embryology (ESHRE) and Alpha Scientists in Reproductive Medicine, an expert panel of fertility specialists, created goal PIs for IVF labs. If these numbers are not readily available from your clinic, they should be provided when asked for:
Number of eggs collected: 80-95% of follicles
Number of mature eggs: 75-90% of eggs collected
Normal fertilisation: 75-80% of eggs
Number of fertilised eggs that cleave (divide): 96-99%
Number of embryos that become blastocysts: 40-60%
Implantation rate (blastocyst): 35-60%REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

A great IVF lab can make a big difference in your chances of bringing home a baby. If you need help choosing a fertility clinic, Maven can support you by building a list of high quality fertility clinics in your area, including information on the clinic’s success rates (if available). Remember, Maven is here to support you at every step of your fertility journey. Reach out to your Care Advocate  for help today.
Resources
Indian Society for Assisted Reproduction (ISAR) Website

ISAR was formed 25 years ago and is an organization dedicated to providing educational information to the public about infertility and ART services, as well as to healthcare professions; promoting clinical advancement in the field of Assisted Reproduction.
Sources
Assisted Human Reproduction Act
National, Regional, and Global Trends in Infertility Prevalence since 1990: A Systematic Analysis of 277 Surveys
National Health Portal India
Indian Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology
The Surrogacy Regulation Bill (2019)

title.en-US: Navigating the financial side of abortion

content.value: When you’re deciding whether or not to continue with a pregnancy, one consideration is your financial situation. No matter what option you choose to move forward with, there’s a financial component involved.

Depending on where you live, your options for accessing an abortion may be limited by legislation and a lack of clinics—and another potential barrier to access is cost. How can you figure out how much an abortion will cost, and what are your options if you can’t afford the full amount? We spoke to Maven Care Advocates to get their advice.
How much does it cost to get an abortion?
The price of an abortion depends on:
Whether or not you have health insurance that covers part or all of an abortion
How far along in pregnancy you are when you have an abortion
Whether you have an abortion procedure or a medication abortion
Abortion costs range from
$0 out of pocket to up to over $3,000
but many clinics provide a sliding scale where you pay less depending on your income.
According to the
Guttmacher Institute
, the average cost people pay for an early medication abortion (before about 9 weeks of pregnancy) is
Planned Parenthood
estimates that for an early second-trimester abortion procedure you may pay somewhere between
The later you are in your pregnancy, the more expensive an abortion will be

There may also be non-medical costs associated with getting an abortion. These can include travel costs to get to a provider, staying overnight in another state to comply with waiting period requirements, childcare, lost wages, and more.

You can price out what different options will cost you by calling around to clinics in your area—making sure to ask them about waiting periods and required appointments to get the full picture. The upfront prices of an abortion are high, but there are options available for getting financial help.
Will health insurance cover my abortion?

It depends on what kind of insurance you have, where you live, and the circumstances behind your pregnancy. To be clear, abortion is a completely valid choice regardless of how you got pregnant. However, some plans will only cover abortion care in cases of rape, incest, or your life being in mortal danger, but not in other situations.
Affordable Care Act:

Under the Affordable Care Act, abortion services are not considered “essential health benefits.” This means that health insurance plans are not legally required to cover abortion care, but they can choose to do so, which is why some plans do and some don’t. To find out if your insurance plan covers abortion care, look through your coverage documents or call the number on your insurance card or website to speak to someone directly about your coverage.
Public employees or those insured through an exchange plan:

A number of states in the U.S. restrict abortion coverage for public employees or people insured through an exchange plan (another term for the Health Insurance Marketplace). You can contact your Maven Care Advocate  for help understanding your coverage.
Medicaid:

Due to a federal law stating that federal funds can only be used for abortion in cases of rape, incest, or life endangerment, those circumstances are covered by Medicaid. Some other states use state-specific funds to ensure that Medicaid covers abortion in other circumstances. Ask your treating medical provider where you can find reputable information on what’s available in your state. Your Maven Care Advocate  may also be able to help.
What are my options if I can’t afford an abortion?
If you’re worried about the financial side of an abortion, there are various places you can turn to for help.
Call abortion providers to learn what their services cost.

They can give you specific prices based on your situation. Also ask them about any travel requirements or waiting periods, so you can factor in costs for transportation or lodging. Some abortion providers offer sliding scale services or payment plans. Ask an administrator at the clinic or doctor’s office if they offer financial assistance.
Look through your insurance coverage documents
or call the number on your insurance card or website to see if your insurance plan fully or partially covers abortion services.
Contact
abortion fund networks

that provide financial help to people who need abortions. This can include assistance for traveling out of state, paying for somewhere to stay, covering childcare, and more. Two places to start: REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK- The
National Abortion Federation
hotline, 1-800-772-9100REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK- The
National Network of Abortion Funds
, which has an ongoing list of funds by state

Contact your Maven Care Advocate . They can help with the above, and may also know about specific benefits that apply to you—for example, some companies will offer financial assistance for employees seeking abortion care.
The bottom line

Getting an abortion can require some out-of-pocket costs, with a wide range depending on where you are, what your insurance covers, and what kind of care you need. Reach out to your Maven Care Advocate  for free help finding options and resources available to you.
Sources:
Guttmacher Institute
Planned Parenthood

title.en-US: What is preeclampsia and eclampsia?

content.value: Pregnancy comes with lots of new words to learn, and the words “preeclampsia” and “eclampsia” can feel scary if you aren’t familiar with them. Maven OB-GYN Ban Al-Karaghouli, MD, explains why a preeclampsia or eclampsia diagnosis should be taken seriously, but it can be managed and treated with the right care.
What is the difference between preeclampsia and eclampsia?
Preeclampsia

is a condition that causes sudden high blood pressure during pregnancy. It usually happens after 20 weeks of pregnancy, but can also happen several weeks or months after giving birth. You may not see or feel any symptoms of preeclampsia but it is often associated with proteinuria. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKProteinuria means there’s protein in your urine (or pee). This is a sign that you might have an issue with your kidneys. This is why your doctor tests your urine at every prenatal appointment and why it’s really important to go to these appointments or reschedule if you can’t make one. Preeclampsia is serious and can become dangerous to you and your baby if it is not treated fast.
Eclampsia

is severe preeclampsia. Al-Karaghouli says that preeclampsia can lead to eclampsia, where a pregnant person has seizures and can fall into a coma. This is a rare but very serious condition that could lead to death if untreated.
Symptoms of preeclampsia
Just as with other conditions, you are a unique person so you may have some, none, or all of these symptoms. It’s important to pay close attention to your body and what feels normal or not to you.
Some symptoms of preeclampsia include:
Sudden high blood pressure
Protein in your urine (this would be found in your urine sample at your doctor’s office)
Migraines or worse-than-usual headaches
Changes in your vision (blurry, seeing spots, or loss of vision)
Shortness of breath and trouble breathing (due to fluid in the lungs)
Pain in the upper belly, usually under your ribs on the right side
New feelings of needing to throw up
Vomiting
If you have any of these symptoms, call your provider right away or go to the ER. Preeclampsia can become dangerous to you and your baby fast.
Spotting eclampsia
Eclampsia is rare, but it’s always good to know symptoms to watch out for. These include:
Being unable to use the bathroom (either not peeing much or having trouble peeing)
Gaining a lot of weight fast (an important reason you’re weighed at every prenatal appointment)
Sudden swelling, especially in the face or hands
Trouble with your vision (things looking blurry or fuzzy, for example)
If you have any of these symptoms, call 911 or go to the ER right away. Getting help immediately can be life-saving to you and your baby.
Causes of preeclampsia

Preeclampsia isn’t something you have done wrong. It’s a condition that many experts believe has more to do with your placenta (the organ that gives oxygen and nutrients to your baby) not working the way it should, which can lead to a lack of blood flow. It can also be caused by high blood pressure or your genes.

Most cases of preeclampsia are random, but there have been a lot of studies that show that it could be genetic. It’s difficult to say what causes it in most cases, but preeclampsia is most likely NOT caused by habits like not eating healthy, smoking, or alcohol use.
Risk factors
Anyone can get unexpected news that they have preeclampsia. But it can be more likely if you have these risk factors:
Having preeclampsia before
Having diabetes before pregnancy
Having kidney disease
Having chronic high blood pressure
Having kidney disease
Having obesity
Having certain autoimmune disorders
Female partner who is over the age of 35
Being African American
A short time (less than two years ) between pregnancies
Having a long time (think more than 10 years) between pregnancies
Pregnant with more than one baby
Are preeclampsia and eclampsia avoidable?
If you’re worried about getting preeclampsia or eclampsia during pregnancy, Al Karaghouli shares these four ways you may be able to lower your risk:
Talk to your doctor or a
doctor on Maven
about taking a “low dose of aspirin (think 81 milligrams per day)
Keep a healthy weight for your body
Eat nutritious foods with a lower salt content
And
exercise in a way that feels good to you
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Avoiding preeclampsia is the best way to avoid eclampsia. The aspirin is a good tip for lowering your risk, since it’s been studied and shown to help with preeclampsia prevention. Talk to your doctor about it today. If you need help choosing healthy foods, talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
for free. For fun exercise ideas, talk to a
Maven Physical Therapist
for free.
How is preeclampsia treated?

Remember this about a preeclampsia diagnosis: it’s common, it can be managed, and it is not your fault. Your health care team will help you through this time. It should not mean you have to stop enjoying your pregnancy or that you won’t have a healthy baby. It does mean a few things might have to change for now, though.

Often, your doctor will make a plan with you to safely deliver your baby as far beyond 37 weeks as possible. You might be given medicine to help control your blood pressure if you’re admitted to the hospital. If it is needed, you might be induced (or given medicine to help kick start labor). This decision with your health care provider will depend on how severe the preeclampsia is, how far along you are in pregnancy, and the health of you and your baby.

If your preeclampsia isn't severe, you may have more provider visits to monitor your blood pressure, any changes in signs or symptoms, and the health of your baby. You'll likely also be asked to check your blood pressure daily at home using a blood pressure cuff.

Even though symptoms of preeclampsia go away within 6 weeks of having your baby, there are still risks. Sometimes, high blood pressure gets worse the first few days after delivery or several months after delivery. Your doctor will keep monitoring you closely after having the baby. Remain on high alert for any new or worse symptoms like those above and let your doctor know right away.
Learn how to check your blood pressure.
How will these conditions affect my pregnancy?

Preeclampsia can affect baby's growth and can also lead to preterm birth. Preterm birth is when you deliveryour baby before the 37th week of pregnancy. Though preeclampsia is the cause for approximately 15% of premature births according to the March of Dimes, it doesn’t mean that it will happen in your case.
Stay in tune with your body and speak to your doctor when you feel something is wrong. You are your best judge, doctor, and advocate: and sometimes you have to be all of those things in one!
HELLP syndrome

Preeclampsia can also cause HELLP syndrome. According to the March of Dimes, HELLP syndrome is a pregnancy complication that affects your blood and liver (HELLP stands for Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes and Low Platelets).
HELLP is a rare medical emergency that needs fast treatment. Signs and symptoms of HELLP include:
Blurry vision
Chest pain
Pain in the upper right or middle part of the belly
Swelling
Throwing up
Call 911 or go to your nearest ER if you have any of these symptoms.
What is postpartum preeclampsia?
Postpartum preeclampsia is when you get preeclampsia after you have given birth. It’s quite rare, but it can happen and it can be dangerous.
Symptoms of postpartum preeclampsia include:
High blood pressure
Severe headaches
Blurry vision
Swelling in your hands, feet, or face
Protein in your pee (this would be found during a urine sample screening at a doctor’s office)
Nausea
Vomiting
Quick weight gainREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Postpartum preeclampsia can get worse when it’s not treated, causing seizures, strokes, blood clots, and organ damage. If you notice any of the above symptoms after giving birth, call your doctor right away.
There are different ways to treat postpartum preeclampsia, including:
Medication to lower your blood pressure
Medication to stop you from getting seizures
Medication to stop you from getting blood clots, another common complicationREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have postpartum preeclampsia, you may have to stay at the hospital until the condition is under control. Once you have been treated, most people recover fully from the condition.
The bottom line

It can be frustrating to get a diagnosis like preeclampsia. It isn’t what you want to hear during this exciting time, but when it is managed you can still have the pregnancy you want, even if you have a complication you don’t want. Most women with preeclampsia will deliver healthy babies and fully recover, and can go on to have more babies if they choose to. Work closely with your provider and
providers on Maven
for support along the way.
Sources
Mayo Clinic: Preeclampsia
March of Dimes: HELLP Syndrome
Preeclampsia Foundation: What is preeclampsia?
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists: Gestational Hypertension and Preeclampsia

title.en-US: High blood pressure during pregnancy 101

content.value: When you’re pregnant, your health care providers should check your blood pressure levels at every appointment. That’s because high blood pressure (or hypertension) is linked to some health problems that can be harmful to you and your baby. Luckily, there are plenty of ways to manage high blood pressure to help both of you stay healthy.
What is high blood pressure?

Your blood travels around your body through your blood vessels (veins and arteries), bringing oxygen to your muscles and organs so they can work properly. Your blood pushes against the walls of your blood vessels as it travels. That’s your blood pressure level: How much force your blood pushes against those walls.
Over time, this increased force can cause health problems. Your heart has to work harder to pump blood around your body, and constant pressure on the blood vessel walls can damage them.
How is blood pressure measured?

Your blood pressure is measured by two different numbers. The first number (systolic pressure) is the force of your heartbeat pumping blood out of the heart and into your arteries. The second number (diastolic pressure) is the force when your heart is resting between heart beats.
According to the American Heart Association, there are five different blood pressure categories:
Normal:
under 120 / under 80
Elevated:
High blood pressure (hypertension) stage 1:
High blood pressure (hypertension) stage 2:
140 or higher / or 90 or higher
Hypertensive crisis:
Higher than 180, and/or a number higher than 120
REPLACEWITHIMGWCAPTION
What is the difference between chronic high blood pressure, gestational high blood pressure, and preeclampsia?
If you have
chronic high blood pressure

, you were diagnosed before you got pregnant, and you will likely still have high blood pressure after you give birth. You might already take medication to lower your blood pressure, or manage it through diet and activity.
If you have
gestational high blood pressure
, you were diagnosed during your pregnancy, and your high blood pressure might go away after you give birth. Your doctor will give you tips for how to manage the condition during pregnancy.
If you have
preeclampsia

, you have a specific pregnancy condition characterized by sudden high blood pressure usually after the 20th week of pregnancy. Preeclampsia is a serious condition that can be harmful to you and your baby and needs attention right away. Preeclampsia only goes away after your baby is born. Because of this, people with preeclampsia are more likely to give birth early, to be induced (
learn more about what that means here
) or to need a cesarean birth (C-section).
Learn more about preeclampsia.
What causes high blood pressure during pregnancy?
Some things increase your risk of high blood pressure during pregnancy, like if you:
Are over 40 years old
Are carrying more than one baby
Are African-American
Have obesity (meaning a Body Mass Index of 30 or higher)
Had preeclampsia or high blood pressure in a past pregnancy
Used in vitro fertilization (IVF), donor eggs, or donor sperm to get pregnant
Have a family history of preeclampsia
Have been diagnosed with
gestational diabetes
, or have chronic diabetes
How do I know if I have high blood pressure?

Maven OB-GYN Patricia Convery, MD, says that most people with high blood pressure don’t have any symptoms. That means you’ll only know your blood pressure is high by having it tested using a blood pressure cuff. Your provider will check your blood pressure readings at every appointment throughout your pregnancy, and you might also be given a
blood pressure cuff to use at home
Preeclampsia,
a sudden increase in high blood pressure during pregnancy, can cause some symptoms, like:
Swelling in your face and hands
A headache that won’t go away
Blurry vision, seeing spots, or other problems seeing properly
Pain in your upper right stomach area
Trouble breathing
Protein in your pee (this would be found in a urine sample taken at your doctor’s office)
New feelings of nausea or vomitingREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you notice any of these symptoms during pregnancy, you should contact your health care provider right away. If you can’t reach them, go to the emergency room to get checked out.

Preeclampsia can be dangerous because it can affect the blood supply to your placenta (the organ that gives oxygen and nutrients to your baby), prevent your liver and kidneys from working properly, and cause fluid buildup in your lungs. If you have preeclampsia, your doctor will work with you to make a plan to keep you and your baby safe.
How do I treat high blood pressure during pregnancy?
Your doctor can talk you through tools for treating and managing high blood pressure, such as:
Taking medication
Staying active
Eating a low-sodium dietREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have preeclampsia, there is only one way to treat the condition—delivering your baby.
Learn more about that here.
Does having high blood pressure change my pregnancy tests and appointments?
Your doctor might schedule more appointments to check on you and the baby. They may also give you a blood pressure cuff so you can check your own blood pressure at home.
If your blood pressure remains high or you are diagnosed with
preeclampsia

, you might deliver your baby early through an induction or a cesarean birth (C-section). This will only happen if your providers feel that you or your baby are in danger, and that giving birth immediately is the best option for keeping both of you healthy.
Can I avoid getting high blood pressure or preeclampsia during pregnancy?
High blood pressure is a tricky condition. The most important things you can do are attend your prenatal appointments and let your doctor know if you start experiencing symptoms.
Some other things you can do to lower the risks of high blood pressure during pregnancy:
Stop smoking and consuming alcohol
Take blood pressure medication, if that has been prescribed to you
Stay active when possible
Ask your provider or a
Maven Nutritionist
about food choices that might helpREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
We don’t know why some people get
preeclampsia

and other people don’t. It’s possible that preeclampsia is genetic, or related to how your placenta works. According to the Cleveland Clinic, preeclampsia is not caused by stress or too much activity. If you do have it, it’s not because of anything you did wrong.
What happens with my high blood pressure after I give birth?
You can learn more about
what happens here
, but there are a few options:
If you had chronic high blood pressure before pregnancy, you will likely still have it after pregnancy.
For some people,
gestational high blood pressure
will go away when the baby is born. It might come back during future pregnancies.
Sometimes your blood pressure will improve after giving birth, but get worse again 6-12 weeks after delivery so it’s important to keep in touch with your provider and go to your postpartum checkup
Sometimes your blood pressure will remain high after you give birth, and you will be diagnosed with
chronic high blood pressure (or hypertension)
Will having high blood pressure during pregnancy affect my baby’s health?
High blood pressure during pregnancy can be serious, and there are some risks to your baby’s health if the condition is untreated. For example, untreated high blood pressure increases your risks of:
Intrauterine growth restriction (where your baby is extremely small)

A placental abruption, where your placenta moves away from the wall of the uterus before birth. This can prevent oxygen from getting to your baby, and cause heavy bleeding. Placental abruption is quite rare, but it is an emergency.

Stillbirth is rare, but it can happen when high blood pressure or preeclampsia goes untreated. It’s important to go to your pregnancy appointments so your doctor can keep a close eye on you, and do everything they can to keep you and your baby safe.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Your doctor will talk to you about the risks of high blood pressure, and work with you to make a plan for treatment. The condition is confusing and scary, but there are plenty of tools available to manage it.
I still have questions!
We’re here for you. Contact a
Maven OB-GYN
any time for a free, confidential video appointment. Your Maven Care Advocate  can also provide personalized recommendations for in-person support.
Sources:
MedLine Plus
Cleveland Clinic
American Heart Association
Mayo Clinic
March of Dimes
Source: Adapted from the American Heart Association

title.en-US: When should I call my doctor about high blood pressure during pregnancy?

content.value: If you’re dealing with high blood pressure during pregnancy, you will probably check your blood pressure (BP) every day to make sure everything looks okay. But what are the risks of your blood pressure getting higher, and what should you do if you notice that?

If you’re not sure what to do, it’s always best to call your doctor, speak to a provider on Maven, or go get checked out just in case there’s an issue. Maven OB-GYN Patricia Convery, MD, shares more advice on what to look out for.
What is a high blood pressure reading?

If you are taking your blood pressure measurements at home, make sure to keep a record of the readings so you can see any patterns or changes over time. You can write down the readings in a notebook, use a notes feature on your phone, or use a specialized app.
Blood pressure readings fall into five different groups:
REPLACEWITHIMGWCAPTION
What should I do if I get a high blood pressure reading?
If your blood pressure is elevated:
Call your doctor’s office or after-hours line to see what they recommend.
If your blood pressure is high:
Call your doctor’s office or after-hours line to see what they recommend.
If you are in a “hypertensive crisis”:
Go to the emergency room, or call 911 if you can’t get yourself there safely. Call your OB-GYNs office when you can, just to let them know what’s going on.
What if I get a blood pressure reading that’s higher than usual, but not in the “elevated” category or above?
If you have noticed your blood pressure is higher than usual
for you
, it never hurts to get checked out—even if it’s not in the “elevated” category or higher. Call your doctor if you notice this happening or
speak to a provider on Maven.
What can happen if my blood pressure gets too high during pregnancy?

Everyone’s body responds differently to high blood pressure. If it’s not treated, high blood pressure during pregnancy can become a serious problem—that’s why it’s important to stay on top of your readings and go to your pregnancy appointments.
Some of the risks linked to high blood pressure in pregnancy are:
Having a stroke

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), which is when your baby is extremely small. This can happen if your baby is not getting the oxygen or nutrients they need to grow. If your baby has IUGR, your doctors might suggest you have an induction or a cesarean birth (C-section) earlier than your due date, so your baby can get special care to grow.

A placental abruption, where your placenta moves away from the wall of the uterus before birth. This can prevent oxygen from getting to your baby, and cause heavy bleeding. Placental abruption is quite rare, but is an emergency.

Stillbirth. This is rare, but it’s linked to untreated high blood pressure or preeclampsia. It’s important to go to your pregnancy appointments so your doctor can keep a close eye on you, and do everything they can to keep you and your baby safe.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
High blood pressure after 20 weeks of pregnancy can also be a sign of preeclampsia, which is a serious condition.
Learn more about preeclampsia here.
What else can I do about high blood pressure during pregnancy?
It can be very worrying and confusing to have high blood pressure when you’re pregnant. However, there are lots of different ways to manage it that you and your doctor can try together.
Attend all your prenatal appointments
, so your doctor can check that you and your baby are healthy.
Track your blood pressure at home
, if your doctor suggests it. It might be confusing at first, but you’ll get the hang of it in no time and can
speak to a provider on Maven
for free help anytime
Avoid using alcohol or drugs
during pregnancy. They can affect your blood pressure and the health of your baby. If you need support, we’re here for you.
Talk to a Maven provider for help
Take your medication,

if your doctor prescribed it to treat high blood pressure during pregnancy. Ask any questions you have about the medicine. If you have trouble remembering to take medication every day, try setting an alarm on your phone or using a pill box labeled with days of the week. Keep the box somewhere you’ll see it every day, like on your bedside table or next to your phone charger.
I have more questions!
Reach out to a
Maven OB-GYN
any time for free, confidential advice about high blood pressure during pregnancy and the warning signs to look out for. The condition can be confusing, but we’re here to help.
Sources:
Mayo Clinic
MedLine Plus
American Academy of Family Physicians
Source: Adapted from the American Heart Association

title.en-US: An in-depth guide to fertility treatments in the UK

content.value: If you’ve been wading through fertility treatment information that leaves you feeling more confused than confident, Maven has your back. Our fertility guide explains all the basics in one place, including the most common fertility treatments, average costs, and what to expect while going through treatment in the UK. Read on for clarity and the start of a better fertility journey.
Fast facts
1 in 7
Heterosexual couples in the UK experience infertility
In the UK, infertility is attributed to 40% male factor, 40% female factor, 20% a combination of factors

Average cost for IVF treatment (per cycle, excluding medications). Medication alone can cost £900 - £1,200. When adding medications and procedures such as intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and frozen embryo transfer cycles (FET’s), the cost may be closer to between £6,900 - £8,500 per cycle.
Who might need fertility treatment?

There are lots of reasons people need help conceiving, and the best treatment option for each person and couple depends largely on the cause of infertility. In other cases, same sex couple require a sperm or egg donor and assisted reproductive technology to start their family. So what are some of the most common causes of infertility and who’s a good candidate for fertility treatment?
Common causes of infertility
According to The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE), the main causes of infertility in the UK are:
Unexplained infertility, meaning there’s no identified male or female cause
Irregular or no ovulation
Tubal damage (this may be genetic or caused by pelvic inflammatory disease or other infections)
Male factors causing infertility such as structural abnormalities or sperm production problems
Age-related fertility decline or diminished ovarian reserve (low egg count)
Hormonal imbalances, like thyroid disorders
Abnormalities of the uterus (from birth or due to fibroids, polyps, etc.)
Endometriosis
Combination of male and female factors
What to expect at your initial consultation

Once you’ve made the decision to explore or undergo fertility treatments, you’ll start with an initial consultation. Your clinical team will evaluate your fertility and medical history—this is a key part of determining next steps. After your initial consultation, you’ll likely be asked to complete a number of tests. Once the test results are in and reviewed by your doctor, your clinical team will discuss their recommended approach. If a treatment like intrauterine insemination (IUI) or in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) is required, your doctor will explain the process step by step.
Common tests

For female patients, a vaginal ultrasound is one of the most important diagnostic tests to assess fertility. It will give your doctor a close look at your uterus and ovaries so they can identify any problems, and look at antral follicle count (AFC). The AFC measures the number of premature follicles (resting eggs) in the ovaries, allowing your doctor to assess your egg reserve. Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is another marker of egg reserve that your doctor will measure. Your clinical team will use the AFC and AMH results to decide what type of protocol you need, and to anticipate how you’ll respond to the medications they prescribe.

If the ultrasound suggests possible blockage of the fallopian tubes, you’ll be referred for a test called an HyCoSy or an X-ray (HSG). Chlamydia testing is usually performed too, as chlamydia can negatively affect your reproductive system. Additional tests that may be ordered include progesterone, follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinising hormone (LH), thyroid function, Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) profile, and miscarriage or genetic screening, if clinically indicated.

For heterosexual or same-sex male couples seeking fertility treatment, a basic semen analysis (SA) will also be done to look at sperm criteria including semen volume, sperm count, morphology (shape) and motility. Semen analysis is performed on an ejaculated sample and evaluated based on standards created by the World Health Organisation (WHO). The reference ranges below are the range of values considered “normal” when assessing semen.
REPLACEWITHASSET

Sperm “quality” refers to the sperm’s ability to fertilise an egg, and sperm DNA integrity is very important for normal fertilisation and embryo development. “Good” quality sperm is functional, can achieve fertilisation and has the correct genetics. Assessments of sperm quality shouldn’t serve to define a male as fertile or infertile, but rather to determine further evaluation and treatments.
Sperm motility:
Sperm should be moving forward, not in tight circles or along erratic paths. Low motility is also called asthenozoospermia.
Sperm morphology:
A morphologically normal sperm should have a:
Long tail
made of protein fibers which helps it “swim” to the egg
Mid-piece
that contains mitochondria to power the sperm’s movement
Nicely shaped head
that stores genetic information and helps the sperm get into the egg. Abnormal morphology is also called teratozoospermia.
Total sperm count:

This refers to the total number of sperm within the ejaculate. A high sperm count isn’t helpful if most sperm have abnormal morphology or can’t swim properly. Similarly, sperm with great morphology may carry abnormal DNA.
Sperm concentration:

The total number of sperm per millilitre (ml) of ejaculate. Low sperm concentration is also called oligospermia. If very few sperm are seen after a special preparation, it’s classified as cryptozoospermia. If no sperm are seen, this is called azoospermia.
Some important points:
Sperm are continuously produced and take 76 days to mature, so the effect of lifestyle improvements made today could be seen in 2-3 months
Sperm counts fluctuate, so it’s crucial that 2 or more samples are tested over time to ensure consistency
Seasonal variations in sperm parameters have been reported, with highest counts in late winter/early spring and lowest in late summer
Abstinence length impacts quality; it’s recommended to abstain from ejaculation for 2-7 days before semen analysis
Routine SA’s can’t measure DNA integrity REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Sperm DNA fragmentation is an additional test that may be performed to look for fragmentation or “damage” to the genetic material inside the sperm head. DNA integrity of the sperm is important as half of the genetic material required to make a baby comes from the sperm and the other half comes from the egg. DNA damage to either the egg or sperm affects fertility.
Treatment options
Intrauterine insemination

Intrauterine insemination (IUI) involves injecting sperm directly into a woman's uterus. This bypasses the cervix, reducing the distance sperm has to travel to meet the egg and increasing the chances of pregnancy.

The success rates of IUI vary in the UK. For heterosexual couples where the female is 35 years old or younger, the success rate per cycle is between 10-15%. For those ages 36-39, the success rate is 10% and for those over 40, it’s around 6-7%. For IUI using donor sperm, success rates are 17% under 38 years of age and 7% for those older than 38.
The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA) recommends IUI for:
Couples who are unable (or would find it very difficult) to have vaginal intercourse, for example because of a physical disability or other challenges
Those who need donated sperm but have no female fertility problems, including
single women
and
same sex couples

Those who have a condition where they need specific help to achieve a pregnancy safely (for example, men who are HIV positive and have had sperm washing to reduce the risk of passing on the disease to their partner and potential child)

Unexplained infertility. Note that NICE does not recommend IUI for unexplained infertility. Additionally, NICE does not recommend IUI for cases of mild endometriosis or low sperm count. In these cases, you’ll be advised to keep trying to conceive through regular unprotected sexual intercourse for a total of 2 years (this can include 1 year of trying before you had your fertility tests). After that, you may be offered IVF.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Because NICE doesn’t recommend IUI for unexplained infertility, mild endometriosis, or low sperm count, IUI is generally not funded by the NHS in these cases. If you have unexplained infertility and would prefer IUI instead of IVF, you’ll likely have to pay privately.

According to guidelines from NICE, If you don’t become pregnant after 6 cycles of IUI, you should be offered additional fertility tests. If your test results are normal, you should be offered another 6 cycles of IUI before other treatments, such as IVF, are considered.

Based on the most recent review of research, the World Health Organisation recommends that at least three consecutive IUI cycles should be performed in couples with an indication for IUI. There is no official recommendation on the maximum number of IUI treatment cycles people should pursue. It’s a decision you’ll need to make with your treatment team.
There are two options when it comes to IUI cycles: stimulated or natural.
Stimulated IUI

Your doctor will prescribe hormonal medications to help grow more than one follicle in your ovaries and increase the chances of ovulation. These may be oral medications such as Clomiphene Citrate (Clomid), Letrozole tablets or hormonal injections known as Gonadotropins. These hormonal injections are typically self-administered at home.

Stimulated IUI cycles usually require 4 to 6 clinic visits per treatment cycle so your doctor can closely monitor the growth of your follicles. The first visit is typically on day 2-3 of your menstrual cycle (to rule out any ovarian cysts), again on day 6 and more regularly depending on your response to the medication. During each visit, a pelvic ultrasound is performed to measure the size of the follicles and the thickness of the endometrial lining. After approximately 10-12 days of medication and once the lead follicle is large enough, a HCG "trigger" shot is given to start ovulation. The IUI is then scheduled approximately 24-40 hours later.
Natural IUI

In a natural IUI cycle, no medication will be given. Your doctor will track the growth of the dominant follicle (egg) in your ovary by transvaginal ultrasound and when it’s big enough, they’ll wait for the natural ovulation process to occur. This will be detected by a blood or urine test. The IUI will then be scheduled the next day. In couples with unexplained infertility, it’s not recommended to try natural IUI.
The cost of an IUI cycle is approximately £1,200 (excluding medication costs).
In-vitro fertilisation

While intrauterine insemination is a cost-effective, noninvasive first-line therapy for certain patients (same-sex female couples, those with functioning fallopian tubes, cervical issues, anovulation, moderate male factor and unexplained infertility), it has limited success in patients with endometriosis, severe male factor infertility, tubal factor infertility and advanced maternal age (female over 35 years old). After several rounds of unsuccessful IUI treatment or if the causes of infertility aren’t suitable for IUI, in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) may be recommended.

IVF is a technique where a woman’s eggs and man’s sperm are combined in a laboratory in order to create an embryo(s). Depending on the diagnosis and age of the woman, an embryo or, in some cases, embryos, are transferred to the woman’s uterus through her cervix to increase the chances of pregnancy. IVF is used for heterosexual couples experiencing a range of infertility causes, same sex couples and for single women pursuing parenthood. So, what does it involve?
Step 1. Superovulation to boost egg production

Superovulation is a stimulation process to boost egg production. The process begins with self-injection of drugs containing Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH), which causes egg growth in your ovaries. The more eggs produced, the higher chances of successful fertilisation later in the treatment.

You’ll also receive blood tests and transvaginal ultrasounds regularly to monitor your hormone levels and check on your ovaries. You might experience bruising, tenderness, or pain at the injection sites. Hormonal medication might also cause emotional changes like mood swings, restlessness, irritability, or generally feeling down, as well as nausea, bloating, fatigue, and possible hot flashes.
Step 2. Egg retrieval

A day or two before your eggs are scheduled to be retrieved, you’ll self-administer a hormone injection that will help the eggs mature more quickly, known as a trigger shot. Roughly 36 hours later, you’ll undergo a minor outpatient surgical procedure called follicular aspiration to extract mature eggs. Most egg collection procedures are performed under conscious intravenous sedation, meaning you’ll be conscious with reduced pain sensitivity. You’ll likely experience some mild to moderate abdominal cramping and/or pelvic pain following the procedure, but this pain is usually mild enough to be treated with over-the-counter pain medicine and disappears within a day or two after the procedure.
Step 3. Sperm production from partner or donor

During the egg retrieval process, the patient's partner will provide a sperm sample or a sample from donated sperm will be thawed. The sperm are then sorted through a high-speed wash and spin cycle to find the healthiest ones. Normally men will produce a fresh ejaculated sperm sample on the day of egg collection to fertilise the eggs, however some men may need to freeze sperm in advance of the egg collection to ensure sperm is available on the day of fertilisation. This occurs when men have reduced sperm volume or quality or may have performance anxiety about producing a sample on the day of the procedure.
Step 4. Fertilisation of eggs

About an hour or so after the eggs have been retrieved and after the sperm has been prepared and assessed, sperm and egg are combined in a process known as insemination. Insemination involves placing a fixed amount of sperm around each egg in a petri dish in an incubator. It typically takes a few hours for a sperm to fertilise an egg. Your clinical team will check to see if fertilisation occured the following day.

If the sperm don’t meet the criteria for traditional insemination, then a technique called intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is performed. The key difference between routine IVF and ICSI is the way the sperm enters the egg. With ICSI, an embryologist will select the “best” sperm and inject each one directly into each mature egg. ICSI is suggested for the majority of patients, not because they need it, but due to higher fertilisation rates. The trend for this is so great that in some countries almost 100% of patients are only offered ICSI, despite many studies showing that patients with advanced maternal age, low egg numbers and unexplained infertility, can have success with routine IVF. Interestingly, pregnancy rates after traditional insemination and after ICSI are very similar.
Step 5. Blastocyst culture

Embryos (fertilised eggs) are grown in a special incubator that monitors the development of each individual embryo. The embryos are assessed the morning after the egg collection to confirm fertilisation into a 2-cell embryo. The embryos, if normally fertilised, should go on to become rapidly expanding balls of cells called blastocysts. Blastocysts are formed by day 5 or 6 of their development. The outer layer of the embryo goes on to become the placenta and the inner cell mass goes on to form the baby. It’s common practice in IVF clinics to extend embryo culture for 5 days until the embryos reach the blastocyst stage.
Embryo development and grading

You may have heard about embryo grading, where an embryologist makes an educated guess about an embryo’s potential based on certain embryo characteristics like the number and size of cells and how quickly certain stages of development are reached. What does the grade of your embryo tell you about the chances of becoming pregnant? The honest answer is: not much. All embryo grading systems are subjective. A high grade doesn’t guarantee that an embryo will successfully implant and carry to term. Many embryos with “poor” grades will become healthy babies, while others graded as top quality will not. In some cases the reason for this will be genetic, which is something that cannot be assessed just by looking at the embryo. Preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) is the only way to assess embryo genetics.
Key milestones to focus on after your egg collection are:
By 16-18 hours post egg collection, fertilisation into a zygote should occur. If an embryo has not reached 2 cells within 24 hours, the process will be stopped.
By 48 hours (“day 2”), the embryos should be at least at the 2 to 4 cell stage.
By 72 hours (“day 3”), the embryos should have about 8-10 cells, also known as cleavage stage.
By ”day 5”, the embryos should reach 120 cells, also known as the blastocyst stage.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Connect with a
Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist
to understand more about IVF versus ICSI and about embryo development.
Step 6. Embryo transfer
Reaching embryo transfer day is a huge milestone. There are two types of embryo transfers to know about: Fresh and frozen.
Fresh embryo transfer

Once your eggs are collected, you’ll be prescribed progesterone-based medications that prepare the lining of your uterus to receive the embryo(s) that will be transferred back. In a fresh embryo transfer cycle, the embryo transfer is done 3-5 days after your egg collection.

Current recommendations are to transfer a single embryo back into the uterus as opposed to two, to reduce the chance of a twin pregnancy. The embryo transfer is done while you’re awake, under ultrasound guidance using a very narrow catheter. It’s pain-free but a full bladder is required prior to the procedure to help with positioning of the uterus and to allow the smooth transfer of the catheter inside. Some people find this slightly uncomfortable, but manageable. (You can empty your bladder right away after the embryo transfer.) The progesterone medication will be continued until the first beta hCG pregnancy test is done, about 2 weeks later. If your cycle resulted in more than one viable embryo, they can be frozen for use in future FET cycles. If the pregnancy test is positive, the progesterone support is usually continued until the end of the first trimester.
Frozen embryo transfer (FET)

During a frozen embryo transfer cycle (FET), you’ll be given medications to build the endometrial thickness of your uterus to increase the odds that an embryo will implant. Since an FET cycle uses an embryo that’s already been created, you won’t need to undergo egg retrieval. There are a few ways to prep for a FET cycle:
Natural cycle:
A natural cycle follows the body’s dominant follicle where the mature follicle produces oestrogen and leads to the thickening of the endometrial lining.
Modified natural cycle:

This cycle is similar to a natural cycle except that an injection of hCG is given to trigger ovulation. You’ll use progesterone pessaries/injectables/oral tablets to prep your uterus for implantation.
Stimulated cycle:
In a stimulated cycle, ovulation is induced with medications (clomid, letrozole or gonadotropins).
Programmed cycle:

Oestrogen and progesterone medications are given to prep your uterus and the ovary is suppressed, so ovulation does not occur. The embryo transfer is planned a set number of days after progesterone support starts, usually for 3-6 days later. Estrogen and progesterone are continued and a pregnancy test is done 9-14 days after the transfer. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

There are a number of reasons why you might undergo a FET rather than a fresh transfer. For example, if you’re using embryos created from a previous treatment cycle, they’ll be transferred from frozen. Or, if your endometrial lining doesn’t reach desired thickness for a fresh transfer, your doctor may decide to postpone the embryo transfer, and you’ll need to do a FET transfer in the future instead.

Another common reason to do FET is when PGT-A genetic testing is being performed on the embryos to rule out chromosomal abnormalities. This process involves taking several cells from the outer layer of the fresh embryos then freezing the embryos while awaiting the results of the genetic test. Once the results are received and if a genetically normal embryo has been identified, a FET cycle will be planned.

If you’re at risk for Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS), your doctor may also decide to freeze all of your embryos for future use. Transferring an embryo back into the uterus while you’re at risk of OHSS is not recommended*—* if you became pregnant, the resulting increasing hCG levels would make OHSS worse. This can be potentially life threatening.
Frozen embryo transfer cycles offer:
Reduced risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
Optimization of endometrial receptivity
Time for PGT testing
Prioritisation of embryos for single embryo transfer (SET)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Pregnancy rates after FET have significantly increased over the years mainly due to advances in embryo freezing. This has led to many clinics encouraging elective “freeze-all”: freezing
all
suitable embryos for future use. A large 2020 review however, showed that there is no significant difference between birth rates in fresh ETs versus FETs for most patients.
So, who should consider freeze-all? Your physician may recommend it if any of the below apply to you:
You’re at risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
You have high progesterone on trigger day
You want to do PGT-A genetic testing
You have slow growth embryos
You have uterine abnormalities
Side effects of IVF
Side effects of IVF may include:
Nausea
Mood swings
Bloating
Fatigue
Bruising at the injection site
Vaginal discharge
Pelvic pain or abdominal pain
Are there any risks?

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a possible complication of IVF where the ovaries swell and fluid leaks into the body. The condition is more common in women with polycystic ovarian syndrome. The rates of moderate OHSS are 3% to 6%, and for severe OHSS it’s 0.1% to 2%. A milder form of OHSS occurs in up to one-third of IVF cycles but isn’t a cause for concern. With close monitoring and the use of lower doses of gonadotropins to trigger ovulation, the risk of severe OHSS can be greatly reduced. (The risk of developing OHSS during medicated IUI cycles is much lower because the medication doses are lower.)
Are there any restrictions on who can access treatment in the UK?

There are no restrictions when accessing fertility treatments in the UK and the number of LGBTQIA+ and single people becoming parents is increasing. Adoption, altruistic surrogacy and third party reproductive treatments such as egg, sperm and embryo donation are available throughout the UK. Non-anonymous or “known” sperm and egg donation is required within the UK and all children born through donation have the right to access non-identifying information about their donor at age 16 and identifying information from age 18. Genetic testing for sex selection is prohibited unless there is a genetic condition in the family.
LGBTQIA+ family building
At the national level, there are no restriction on services for same-sex couples.
Same-sex female couples

Same-sex female couples can build their families using donor sperm and IUI or IVF treatment at a clinic or by private arrangement at home. There is one important difference in terms of legal parentage depending on the route chosen. Lesbian couples who conceive their child through a
fertility clinic

using donor sperm are both treated as their child’s legal parents regardless of whether they are in a civil partnership or not. When civil partners conceive through donor insemination at home, they are both considered legal parents; however, when non-civil partners conceive through donor insemination at home by private arrangement, the non-birth mother has no legal parenthood and will have to obtain parental rights by adopting the child. When it comes to funding fertility treatment, unfortunately most NHS clinical commissioning groups (CCGs) consider same-sex female couples ineligible for fertility treatment.
Same-sex male couples

For same-sex male couples wishing to start their family, surrogacy is the main treatment option. Commercial surrogacy is illegal in the UK however altruistic surrogacy is allowed, covering reasonable expenses. Surrogacy agreements are not protected by law. However, people can enter into surrogacy arrangements which outline the legal transfer of parental rights to the same-sex male parents after birth. Surrogacy is facilitated by non-for-profit surrogacy organisations in the UK, and the HFEA recommends four agencies to use. Canada and the U.S. are popular destinations for couples seeking surrogacy outside of the UK.
Trans and non-binary
Trans and non-binary people seeking fertility treatment can access information on fertility preservation and their family building options
here.
How much does IVF really cost?
As anyone who has undergone fertility treatments will tell you, the emotional and physical challenges can be immense. And the financial toll can be, too.

NICE recommends who should have access to fertility treatment on the NHS in England and Wales. Despite these recommendations, individual CCGs make the final decision about who can receive NHS-funded IVF in their local area. They often set stricter criteria than those recommended by NICE, creating unequal access to NHS funded treatment across the country, described by many as the “postcode lottery.”

Across the 106 CCGs in England, funding can vary quite a bit. Some CCG’s will take age into consideration and factors like having a child from a previous relationship. Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales have separate funding. In 2019, there was significantly more NHS-funded treatment of IVF cycles in Scotland compared to Wales, Northern Ireland, and England. NICE guidelines recommend that if you’re a woman under 40 years old you should be offered 3 full cycles of IVF. In some clinics, 1 fresh IVF cycle and 2 frozen embryo transfer cycles could count towards the 3 cycles. Your GP will be able to guide you on the relevant forms to be filled when being referred to your local CCG. Your Maven Care Advocate can also provide support with navigating this often confusing process.
Out-of-pocket costs

If you’re not eligible for NHS funding, you’ll need to factor in treatment costs. The average out of pocket cost for an IVF cycle is between £3,200 and £4,500, with medication costing anywhere from an additional £900 - £1,200. Costs also vary between clinics, particularly in central London, so requesting this information early on can be useful for comparing clinics.
Insurance coverage

Many UK health insurance providers don’t pay out for fertility treatments. Those that do often have specific terms and conditions about what treatments they’re willing to cover. You may be able to include IVF as part of your health insurance package and we recommend that you do some research into this before choosing the right insurance provider.
What can impact the costs?

The number of cycles required. IVF isn’t always successful after the first cycle, which is why clinics quote their “cumulative success rate”, i.e. their results from one fresh IVF cycle and subsequent FET cycles. Any subsequent FET cycle will incur additional costs of approximately £1,600 per cycle and varies from clinic to clinic.
Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI), a technique used to treat male factor infertility can cost up to £1,200 per cycle.
Storage costs for any surplus eggs/embryos you store for future use. This can cost approximately £250 - £300 per year.
Medication dose and brand (generic v non-generic), ranging from £900 - £1,200.

Genetic testing of embryos (PGT-A and PGT-M). The added cost of a PGT cycle is approximately £800 - £1200 in addition to the standard IVF + ICSI cycle cost. The price varies depending on the number of embryos requiring genetic testing.
Fertility grants

The Fertility Foundation, a charity set up to support those going through fertility treatments, offers one-time grants of up to £5,000. Their fertility grants applications are open twice a year (fertilityfoundation.org).
How to find a high quality fertility clinic
Finding the right clinic can feel overwhelming. Between factors like success rates, reviews and location, there’s a lot to consider.
The UK fertility sector is well regulated by the HFEA and comparing the success metrics of different clinics is easy to do. You can find out information about each clinic from the HFEA
website

The HFEA focuses on several important metrics for choosing a fertility clinic: inspection rate, patient satisfaction rating, the clinic’s live birth rate, and multiple pregnancy rate (the HFEA has set a target for all clinics to have multiple birth rate of 10% or lower).

The HFEA reports success rates in several ways. The “IVF birth rate” refers to the “birth rate per embryo transferred” in women under 38 years old. This is the number of births divided by the total number of embryos transferred. Measuring this rate promotes embryo transfer practices that minimise the chances of twins, which carry health risks for the babies and the mother.
HFEA inspection rating: rated out of 5
HFEA patient rating: rated out of 5
IVF birth rate per embryo transferred for women under 38 years old: national average is 31%
Multiple birth rate: national average is 8%REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
When you think about a clinic’s success rates, here are a few key ones to focus on.
Births per embryo transferred

This rate is arguably the most important one UK fertility clinics focus on. It’s the number of births divided by the total number of embryos transferred. Measuring this rate promotes embryo transfer practices that minimises the chances of twins.
The HFEA live birth rate per embryo transferred is 31% for women under the age of 38.
REPLACEWITHASSET
Births per egg collection

This rate refers to the birth rate resulting from all of the eggs collected in one IVF cycle. This means the live birth rate after a fresh IVF cycle, including live births from any associated frozen embryos from that cycle within two years of the egg collection. This information provides those considering IVF with a better understanding of their chances of delivering a child when undertaking one egg retrieval procedure.
The HFEA live birth per egg collection rate (cumulative) is 45% for women under 38 years of age.
REPLACEWITHASSET
Multiple birth rate

Another important rate to consider is the multiple birth rate. For some people, having twins may seem like a wonderful thing, but multiple pregnancies are less safe for mother and babies. The national average for 2018 was 8%, showing the UK’s focus on promoting single embryo transfer practices. Look for clinics with a multiple pregnancy rate of less than 10%.
For greater details on the overall clinic performance in various age groups, you can review their detailed statistics page per clinic
here
Other important things to consider:
Responsive staff
You shouldn’t feel rushed. You should be able to ask all of your questions and get helpful answers in return.
Excellent reviews
Other patients should seem highly satisfied with the quality of the staff and services provided.
High-quality laboratory

The quality of the IVF lab is instrumental in ensuring the best possible embryos are created and the best possible outcome is achieved. What happens in the lab between your egg collection and embryo transfer could determine whether you deliver a healthy baby. Even if your embryos were top quality, a substandard lab could negatively impact embryos growth and ultimately affect your treatment outcome. This is why it’s important to ask for your IVF lab’s Performance Indicators (PI’s). Ask your clinic what their PIs are and compare them to those of other clinics in your area.

In 2017, the European Society for Human Reproduction and Embryology (ESHRE) and Alpha Scientists in Reproductive Medicine, an expert panel of fertility specialists, created goal PIs for IVF labs. If these numbers are not readily available from your clinic, they should be provided when asked for:
Number of eggs collected: 80-95% of follicles
Number of mature eggs: 75-90% of eggs collected
Normal fertilisation: 75-80% of eggs
Number of fertilised eggs that cleave (divide): 96-99%
Number of embryos that become blastocysts: 40-60%
Implantation rate (blastocyst): 35-60%REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

A great IVF lab can make a big difference in your chances of bringing home a baby. If you need help choosing a fertility clinic, Maven can support you by building a list of high quality fertility clinics in your area, including information on the clinic’s success rates (if available).

As a Maven member located in the UK, you get access to exclusive perks at IVI London, one of the UK’s leading fertility clinics. We’ve carefully selected IVI London based on their high clinical quality standards, strong success rates, and patient satisfaction. IVI offers a full range of fertility services for both couples and individuals, including IUI, IVF, egg freezing, and more.
