At IVI, Maven members receive exclusive perks like discounts on the initial consultation, egg freezing, and fertility treatment, including pre-implantation genetic testing. You can message your Care Advocate  to learn more about this partnership, and get connected with IVI London for in-person care.
No matter what questions you have or type of support you need on your fertility journey, Maven has your back.
Check out our
“Guide to Maven’s Fertility Providers”
to see the provider types available to you, and common topics they can help you with or reach out to your Care Advocate today for help.
Resources
Fertility Network UK

Fertility Network UK is the nation’s leading patient-focused fertility charity, providing free and impartial support, advice, information and understanding for anyone experiencing fertility issues. Support line: 0121 323 5025 or e-mail
support@fertilitynetworkuk.org
Donor Conception Network (DCN)

The Donor Conception Network is a charity network of over 2,200 families with children conceived with donated eggs, sperm or embryos and those thinking about or undergoing donor conception procedures and donor conceived people.
HFEA Resources
Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA): costs and funding
Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA): fertility treatment abroad
Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA): choose a fertility clinic
Sources
ESHRE
The Vienna consensus: report of an expert meeting on the development of ART laboratory performance indicators
Reprod BioMed Online
Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority Website
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines
WHO 6th Edition Lab Manual for the Examination and Processing of Human Semen
WHO IUI: Review and Systematic Assessment of the Evidence that Supports Global Recommendations

title.en-US: Every step of the IVF process, explained

content.value: A woman with a regular menstrual cycle releases one mature egg every month. If a healthy sperm is around and able to reach that egg and penetrate it, it can become fertilized and then become an embryo that becomes your baby. With in vitro fertilization (IVF), this process just gets a bit of assistance and the meeting between sperm and egg happens in a lab. Romantic? Not exactly. Effective? Yes! Kind of intimidating? It can be. We’re here to break down every step of the process with help from Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist Ellen H. Goldstein, MD.
What it is

In vitro fertilization (IVF) is a fertility treatment where a sperm and an egg are put together in a petri dish in a laboratory to form an embryo. That embryo is then transferred into the uterus where it (hopefully) implants itself and grows from an embryo into a fetus.
When it’s recommended

IVF can be a good fertility treatment option for people with certain conditions that make it difficult to become pregnant through timed intercourse or intrauterine insemination (IUI) treatment, including:
Female partner with blocked fallopian tubes
Female partner with endometriosis
Male partner with infertility caused by low sperm count or blockage
Unexplained infertility that hasn’t been successfully treated with non-IVF treatment
You’re building your family through surrogacy
You’re building your family using an egg donor
You’re using eggs that have been frozen (cryopreservation)
You're trying to screen out a genetic condition that you or your partner carry

Depending on your situation, IVF may be the first course of action recommended to you by your doctor, but for many, IVF is one of the later treatment recommendations as it’s more involved, invasive, and can be quite expensive if your insurance doesn’t cover it.
What to expect: The TLDR

IVF involves many steps, self-injections, and sometimes disappointment—but it can also be quite effective. When choosing to pursue IVF, it helps to keep this last part in mind to help you through what can be a long and complex process.

“If a patient has been through many treatments before, I try to frame IVF as a source of relief,” Goldstein says. “They can now move on to the most effective treatment, one that has an excellent chance of working. IVF aims to overcome as many fertility issues as we possibly can: By growing as many eggs as possible, we give ourselves the best chance that there will be one (or more than one) genetically viable egg in the group. Then, by getting the eggs out of the body, we make sure that if there’s a normal egg there, we don’t lose it to the random inefficiency of human reproduction. We actually force fertilization to happen, which effectively treats almost all male factor fertility and unexplained infertility cases. Finally, we take over for all the ‘transport issues’ by growing the embryos in the lab and gently placing them back in the uterus.”

That said, there are many emotions involved in undergoing IVF treatment. Everyone is different and you may experience highs and lows along your journey. “I think that having your emotions run high during IVF is actually a very normal response to the stress of this process,” Goldstein says. “You may be upset that you have to do this. You’re worried that it may not work. You’re likely stressed about the finances. The best thing is to allow yourself to acknowledge that. Some people are more or less sensitive, and you should feel what
you
feel. Just listen to your body and take care of yourself along the way.”
How it works: The details

The total timeline of IVF treatment will vary based on your fertility clinic, when your cycle starts, the protocols used in your treatment, whether or not you’re pursuing genetic testing, and a number of other factors. That said, from day one of your period to checking for a positive pregnancy test, one cycle of IVF treatment may take anywhere from 1-4 months.
Keep in mind that your fertility clinic may do things a
little
differently but these are the general steps you can expect to go through if you pursue IVF treatment:
Pre-ovarian stimulation
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: Usually 1 to 3 weeks prior to starting ovarian stimulation medications

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYour doctor may have you take pre-IVF medications, typically birth control pills, estrogen pills or patches, or Lupron (a type of hormone medication). “The goal of these medications is two-fold,” Goldstein says. “One goal is to synchronize all of the eggs (or follicles) to the same stage of development so that when you start your IVF medications, all of the eggs wake up together and you have a higher yield of mature eggs. The other goal is so that you (and your doctor’s office) have some control and a rough estimate of expected dates for your appointments and procedures.”REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Ultrasound
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: Usually 10-21 days after starting the pre-treatment medication

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKWhen the female partner’s period is expected—either according to your cycle schedule or, more often, controlled with the help of birth control pills—you’ll go into your doctor’s office for an ultrasound and blood test. “Your doctor will check labs and inspect your ovaries to make sure that everything looks exactly as it should to start treatment,” Goldstein says. “This is called your ‘baseline.’”REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Ovarian stimulation
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: You’ll usually begin ovarian stimulation on the same day as your ultrasound. The stimulation phase lasts 9-11 days.

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKFirst, the female partner will receive ovarian stimulating injections (1-4 self-injected shots daily for 9-11 days) that will cause multiple eggs to grow (instead of the usual one per month). Another self-injected medication you’ll be given will also prevent the eggs from being released into the fallopian tubes so that as many eggs as possible can reach maturity. During this time, you’ll receive transvaginal ultrasounds and blood tests daily, or every few days, to make sure your hormone levels are good and the follicles are developing as they should. Your medication dosage may be adjusted based on these results. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“I always clarify with patients that the injected medications used for IVF are technically ‘hormones,’ because the definition of hormone is a signal from one part of the body to another, but they are not estrogen, progesterone, testosterone, etc,” Goldstein says. “These injections are simply the same small signaling molecules your brain usually makes to talk to your ovaries, and they have very few side effects. Your ovaries will naturally make their own estrogen and progesterone for the month.” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn how to make self-injection less stressful.
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Egg maturation (aka “trigger shot”)
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Timeframe: Based on apparent maturity level of the eggs, which is determined by follicle size and estradiol level (usually 9-11 days from ovarian stimulation, but may be 7-8 days or 12-13 days depending on individual).

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKBefore they can be retrieved, the eggs need to mature. The female partner will receive what’s known as a “trigger shot” that will cause the egg follicles to reach the final stage of maturation. The trigger shot is usually self-administered and it’s often human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which mimics your body’s natural ovulation surge. But for some patients, especially high-responders, it may be just Lupron, which causes a natural, but well timed, LH surge. The timing on this shot is exact, to the hour, to make sure that the eggs are perfectly matured, not too little and not too much, which will increase the odds of treatment being successful. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYou’ll likely have daily ultrasounds to make sure this timing is spot-on based on the size of the follicles. If the follicles aren't growing as expected, your doctor may increase your medication or cancel the cycle.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Egg retrieval
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: Usually 35 or 36 hours after the trigger shot (depending on your provider). The egg retrieval procedure itself only takes about 15 minutes.

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKMature eggs will be retrieved from the female partner usually within 36 hours after receiving the trigger shot. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKEggs are retrieved using a minor, out-patient surgical procedure called follicular aspiration. “You’ll receive medication intravenously so you won’t feel pain and to help you relax (usually this produces a ‘twilight’ anesthesia, similar to when you have your wisdom teeth removed),” Goldstein says. “Know that injury and infection during this procedure are rare and you should be asleep the whole time if you’ve chosen to have anesthesia.” Be sure to schedule a ride home since you’ll have had anesthesia and it will not be safe for you to drive. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKUsing a transvaginal ultrasound, your doctor will insert a thin needle through your vagina and up into each ovary to retrieve follicles. (Remember, you won’t feel this during the procedure, but may have cramping for a day or two after). At the end of the needle is a small device that sucks or “aspirates” the follicular fluid out of the follicles, including eggs (aka oocytes) and other cells. “Your doctor will attempt to aspirate every follicle to get as many eggs as possible,” Goldstein says. “Many patients want to know if we ‘aspirate both sides’ or ‘how many eggs we are trying to get.’ The answer is always, the more the better!” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThe procedure only takes about 15 minutes, and then you’ll stay at the clinic for a few hours after to make sure that you’re feeling well and any medication you received wears off. It’s common to experience some cramping or light spotting for 1-2 days after. Your doctor will also explain the signs of OHSS (more on this below). REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThe retrieved eggs will then be examined by an embryologist to choose those that are the right maturation to be fertilized or to possibly stimulate those that haven’t matured fully. After retrieval, if you’re doing a fresh transfer, your doctor will prescribe progesterone supplements, which may be intramuscular injections or vaginal suppositories. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn more about fresh vs. frozen embryo transfer.
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Sperm collection
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: Usually takes place the same day as the egg retrieval. After the sample is given by the male partner, sperm preparation takes about an hour.

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKWhile the female partner is having her eggs retrieved, the male partner provides a sperm sample or donor sperm is used if you’ve chosen to use a donor (often at the same appointment). The male partner provides the sperm sample by masturbating into a sterile container in a private room at the clinic. Some clinics may offer an at-home collection option if you live nearby but most prefer in-office to lower the risk of the sperm not surviving due to temperature extremes during transport (they also need to be processed within about 45 minutes after ejaculation). You’ll receive very specific instructions about cleaning your hands, avoiding lubricants that can affect the semen sample, etc. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKOnce collected, the sperm is then “washed.” This means that healthy and motile (aka moving) sperm are removed from dead or non-moving sperm by an embryologist, as well as separated from the other fluids or chemicals that make up semen to help increase the odds of successful fertilization. This is done with a centrifuge machine. Some clinics will freeze some sperm in case another cycle is needed. If you’re using donor sperm or frozen sperm, it’ll be thawed at this time.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Fertilization
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: Eggs are fertilized 2-4 hours after retrieval. Then a fertilization check is performed by the embryologist about 18 hours after fertilization.

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThe healthiest eggs retrieved from the female partner will be placed in a special fluid-filled dish and then into a temperature-controlled incubator until it’s time to unite them with the sperm. When the sperm is ready, each individual egg is then placed in a dish with a high concentration of the healthiest sperm from the male partner or donor (several thousand sperm are placed with a single egg). From there, the two are left to do what they do best in a special incubator. If it’s successful the sperm will penetrate the eggs and fertilize them within 12-24 hours. They’ll be checked the next day (or about 18 hours later) to look for signs of fertilization. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIn some cases, your doctor may directly inject the eggs with sperm (this process is called intracytoplasmic sperm injection or ICSI) to try to create embryos. “This was developed (and is a crucial part of treatment) for severe sperm abnormalities, however it’s also used in a majority of IVF cycles in the United States because it can also be helpful for unexplained infertility, low egg yield, and if you’re doing any genetic testing of your embryos,” Goldstein says.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Embryo transfer
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Timeframe: Embryos are transferred 3 or 5 days after fertilization. The transfer takes about 5 minutes, though you usually have to be at the office for about an hour. If you choose to do PGT-A genetic screening, you will have your embryos frozen and await screening results, which can add about 3 weeks to the timeline.

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf your embryos are growing well in the lab and you and your doctor have discussed and chosen to do a fresh embryo transfer, then you’ll move forward with an embryo transfer. The female partner will receive medication that will help prepare her uterine lining and then either 3 or 5 days after egg retrieval, the healthiest looking fertilized embryo(s) will be transferred into the uterus in the hopes that it implants itself into the uterine lining and begins to grow into a fetus. The highest quality embryo may be chosen using only a microscope. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKPreimplantation genetic testing for aneuploidy (PGT-A) may also be an option if you choose to go with a frozen embryo transfer. “PGT-A is a genetic screening that can determine which embryos have a normal chromosome number and thus the highest chance of success per transfer,” Goldstein says. “If you choose to do PGT-A, you actually won’t have your fresh embryos transferred right away. Instead, the embryos will be frozen and you’ll come back later to do a frozen embryo transfer.” You and your doctor should have a detailed conversation about fresh untested embryo transfer vs frozen embryo transfer with PGT-A, and which is the best option for your particular case. In terms of timeline, PGT-A adds just a few weeks to the process. “The embryos are biopsied and frozen 5-6 days after retrieval, and you’ll recover from the egg retrieval with no more treatment,” Goldstein says. “The biopsies are sent off for genetic testing which usually takes 7-10 days and the results usually come back right around the time you get a period (2 weeks after retrieval) so you can start a frozen embryo transfer cycle (which is roughly three weeks from start to transfer).” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKFor the fresh or the frozen transfer, your doctor will deposit the embryo using a thin catheter inserted into the vagina, through the cervix and into the uterus. Again, you may have some cramping during this step, but it shouldn’t feel painful and generally doesn’t require anesthesia. You’ll be asked to remain lying down for a few minutes to a few hours afterwards. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKUsually, one embryo is transferred back to the uterus (aka “single embryo transfer”). In some cases, you may choose to have more than one embryo transferred to potentially increase the odds that at least one successfully implants itself. However, this can increase the odds of becoming pregnant with multiples. According to Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology (SART), transferring more than one embryo at a time does not significantly increase the chance of a live birth, but does increase the risk of a multiple pregnancy and risks associated with that. You’ll discuss how many to transfer with your doctor beforehand and likely be able to freeze the rest for use in another cycle if this one is unsuccessful, or for another baby down the road.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
The two-week wait
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Timeframe: If pregnant, a pregnancy test will turn positive about 14 days after ovulation. This is calculated based on the developmental stage of the embryos when transferred. (For example, after a day-3 transfer your provider will check 11 days later, after a day-5 transfer they would check 9 days later. The timing is the same for a fresh or frozen embryo transfer.)

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKAfter embryo transfer comes the waiting period. To encourage the embryo(s) to attach the uterine lining, a certain level of hormones are needed to prep the lining. If doing a fresh embryo transfer, the female partner will receive progesterone supplements either vaginally or by injection (or a combination). You’ll start these injections on the day of, or the day after, egg retrieval and will continue through until you take a pregnancy test (and possibly a few more weeks after depending on your levels). “If you’re doing a frozen embryo transfer, your doctor will prepare the lining of your uterus similarly, either by inducing ovulation or giving a specific sequence of estrogen and progesterone prior to transfer,” Goldstein says. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThis can be a difficult time as you anticipate whether or not the embryo transfer was successful and you’ve become pregnant. Schedule plenty to do during this time to take your mind off of it.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn more about how to cope with the two-week wait.
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
The pregnancy test
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: Approximately 9-12 days after transferring the embryo(s)

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYour fertility provider may advise you not to use an at-home pregnancy test because medication you’ve taken during your treatment may lead to false results, but to wait to have your hCG levels tested at the clinic. However, if you can’t stand the wait and you are pregnant, an at-home test might turn positive 1-2 days before this appointment. (Again, timing varies because it’s calculated from ovulation.) REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKApproximately 9-12 days after transferring the embryo(s), you’ll go back to your fertility doctor’s office for a pregnancy test. You may have this test repeated 2 days later. Your fertility doctor will also continue to monitor your progesterone levels and you may need to keep self-administering progesterone shots at this time. If the test is positive and stays positive, you may be on your way to having a baby! Your fertility doctor will keep having you come in so they can watch the development closely via blood work and ultrasounds to watch for signs of miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy, or multiples. If all looks well around 8-10 weeks pregnant, you’ll start seeing your OB-GYN or midwife for prenatal care. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf the pregnancy test is negative, you’ll be asked to stop the progesterone shots. Once your period starts again, your doctor will talk to you and your partner, if you have one, about whether you’d like to try another IVF cycle. While it can be disheartening, it often takes multiple cycles to become pregnant through IVF.
Success rates

When it comes to fertility treatment, success rates should always be taken with a large grain of salt. Everyone is different and many factors can affect whether or not someone can successfully become pregnant through fertility treatment—including the reason for infertility, maternal age, personal health history and even unknown factors. That said, according to SART, this is the approximate percentage of egg retrievals started that eventually lead to a live birth (the key word here is “eventually;” keep in mind that these rates are not necessarily after a single embryo transfer):
REPLACEWITHASSET

You’ll notice that the approximate live birth rates are tied to maternal age, not because fertility is solely a “woman’s problem” but because the female partner’s age does have a strong influence on how successful IVF is.

There are a few steps in the IVF process where your cycle may be cancelled if things aren’t developing as needed. It can feel discouraging, but try to remember that cancellations are for your safety and to increase the odds of having a successful cycle. And if these success rates seem low, remember also that couples who don’t have fertility issues only have a 20% chance of becoming pregnant and carrying to term in any given month that they try, and that 1 in every 100 babies in the U.S. is born with the help of fertility treatment (according to SART).

“It’s definitely helpful to remember that fertility treatment can feel like a marathon, not a sprint,” Goldstein says. “It’s crucial that you trust your doctor and have a good rapport with your fertility clinic. It’s our job to make sure that not only do we give you the best chance of success, but also that we make sure our care is individualized to your particular situation and that nothing is ever missed. You should also discuss preimplantation genetic testing for aneuploidy (PGT-A) with your doctor. Even though we can’t ‘make’ an embryo be genetically normal, when a couple has multiple embryos created in an IVF cycle only some will be viable on a cellular level, but the PGT-A gives us a window into which ones and allows us to choose the embryos most likely to implant. A PGT-A normal embryo actually has a 70% chance of live birth, regardless of the age of the woman.”
Your individual success rate should always be discussed with your provider and know that each clinic has their own success rates.
Risks

IVF is considered safe for most, but there are risks involved that should always be discussed with your doctor before undergoing IVF treatment. One risk is that the female partner can experience ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) from the injections used to stimulate the production of eggs for retrieval. OHSS happens when injections (and sometimes oral medication, though less likely) cause a woman’s ovaries to swell and leak fluid. This can cause abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. According to the Cleveland Clinic, most cases of OHSS are mild and temporary, occurring in less than 5% of women undergoing IVF treatment. In severe cases (less than 0.5% according to SART) OHSS can cause severe nausea and vomiting, severe abdominal swelling and pain, blood clots, difficulty breathing and difficulty urinating.

OHSS can happen in women who have high egg numbers (ovarian reserve), typically those who have 25 or more eggs (oocytes) retrieved. Among those with high egg numbers, women who are thin and have PCOS also have a higher predisposition for OHSS. Your doctor will continue to monitor you via ultrasounds and blood tests to look for any signs of OHSS. “There are also evidence-based treatments to reduce the risk, including freezing all the embryos, using Lupron to trigger, and medications including Metformin and Cabergoline,” Goldstein says. “So be sure to ask your doctor about this.”

The egg retrieval and embryo transfer processes can cause some cramping during and after. In very rare cases, they may cause bleeding or pelvic infection which can be treated with antibiotics. There’s also an increased risk of multiples and transferring more than one embryo can increase this risk. While twins may sound fun, being pregnant with multiples can put the mother and the babies at a higher risk of complications.

There’s also a 2-4% risk of ectopic pregnancy, where the pregnancy develops outside of the uterus, in the fallopian tubes. This type of pregnancy can be very dangerous and would need to be terminated.

“The rate of miscarrying a baby conceived with help from IVF is about the same as the rate of unassisted pregnancy, at 30-50% depending on the age of the woman, if the embryos have not been genetically tested,” Goldstein says. “However, because most miscarriages are caused by chromosomal abnormalities, the miscarriage rate of PGT-A tested embryos is actually only 5%.”

“IVF is overall an extremely safe process,” Goldstein says. “The rate of major complications including bleeding, infection, or ovarian torsion is about 1 in 3,000. OHSS should be very rare these days with careful attention by your physician and judicious deployment of a freeze-all strategy and Lupron trigger.”
Additionally, IVF doesn’t increase the risk of having a baby with birth defects. According to SART, the chance of birth defects in all children is 2% to 4% whether conceived naturally or from IVF.
Costs

IVF costs can vary by clinic and depends on how many cycles it takes to have a successful pregnancy. For many people, IVF can take multiple cycles but as a rough estimate, you can expect IVF treatment to cost between $12,000-$25,000 per cycle. Many couples go through multiple cycles with the first being in this price range and the subsequent cycles averaging about $4,000-7,000 each (often using embryos that were frozen from previous IVF cycles). If you’re using advanced techniques like ICSI, a surrogate or egg donor, costs will be higher.

Be sure to also talk to your doctor about the medication costs involved in IVF treatment as this can be an added expense (ranging from $1,500-$5,000 per cycle). You can also speak to a few fertility clinics to compare their costs, though it can be hard to actually get an “apples to apples comparison” for this complicated process with many line items.

Always contact your health insurance company directly to learn what costs they’ll cover and ask your fertility clinic directly about whether or not they accept insurance. Even if your clinic doesn’t accept insurance, you may be able to contact your insurance company to be reimbursed after treatment. You may also be able to use a flexible spending account (FSA) or a health savings plan (HSA) to save on taxes related to health spending.
If you need help navigating your insurance or finding a high quality fertility clinic, remember that your Maven Care Advocate  is always here to help.
(Learn about
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies to offer you discounts on your medications and more.)
How to get support

Between figuring out how to afford IVF to navigating treatment to learning how to self-inject medication and riding the rollercoaster of hormones and stress, IVF can be a lot to go through on your own—both physically and emotionally. Remember that Maven is here for you at every step. Don’t hesitate to message your Care Advocate  anytime for help finding a high quality fertility clinic, understanding your benefits, and even navigating the cost of IVF treatment. If you ever have questions about IVF treatment, our
Reproductive Endocrinologists
are here to help answer them or provide a second opinion. And for emotional support, reach out to our
Mental Health Providers
alone or with your partner for help getting through the highs and lows of your fertility journey.
Sources
Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology: ART: Step-by-Step Guide
Penn Medicine
Cleveland Clinic
The American Society for Reproductive Medicine
Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology: FAQ
Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology: Live births per intended egg retrieval

title.en-US: Every step of the IUI process, explained

content.value: To become pregnant, a sperm and an egg need to meet it. Sounds simple right? While essential, it’s also a very long journey and a lot of things can get in the way of sperm making it to their final destination. That’s where intrauterine insemination (IUI) can be helpful. With IUI, sperm take the fast train to an egg, which can increase the odds of becoming pregnant. Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist Ellen H. Goldstein, MD explains exactly how it works step by step.
What it is

Intrauterine insemination (IUI, and formerly artificial insemination) is a fertility treatment where the male partner’s sperm or sperm from a donor is put directly inside the female partner’s uterus, upping the amount of healthy sperm that make it to an egg and the odds that one of them will successfully fertilize it.
When it’s recommended

IUI can be a good fertility treatment option for people with mild fertility issues that have made it difficult to become pregnant through timed intercourse. It’s most commonly recommended in the following cases:
Male partner with low sperm count
Male partner with low sperm motility (ability to swim and swim forward)
Male partner with low sperm morphology (percentage of normally shaped sperm)
Donor or frozen sperm is being used
Unexplained infertility
In some situations, IUI may also be recommended if:
Female partner has cervical mucus issues, cervical scar tissue, or an abnormally shaped cervix
Female partner has mild endometriosis
Male partner has trouble ejaculating

If your fertility issues are mild or you’re using donor sperm, IUI may be the first treatment your doctor recommends. It’s less invasive and less expensive than in vitro fertilization (IVF). If either partner has severe infertility factors or has gone through several rounds of IUI without becoming pregnant, your doctor may advise moving straight to IVF.
What to expect: The TLDR

“The goal of IUI is to use multiple interventions in synergy—including more sperm, intrauterine insemination, and the help of your reproductive endocrinologist—to improve the efficiency of becoming pregnant inside your own body,” Goldstein says. With IUI, a concentrated sperm sample is placed high in the uterus (about 2⁄3 of the way closer to an egg than where it’s deposited during intercourse), which can increase the odds of fertilization.

IUI can be done with or without medication used to stimulate the ovaries to make more than one egg. You’ll discuss with your doctor whether adding this step is right for you. “Medication can increase the chances that there will be a genetically viable egg in a given month, as well as give the sperm more targets to hit,” Goldstein says. If you choose to add this step, your fertility doctor will closely monitor how you respond to the medication and make changes as needed to avoid growing too many follicles.

IUI is a fairly straight-forward procedure and only takes a few minutes to perform. However, it’s common to undergo several cycles of IUI. “In any given month of trying, human reproduction is an inefficient process (with only a 20% chance of conceiving even for couples without fertility issues), and therefore IUI may be something that does work for you at some point even if it doesn’t happen to work the first time, Goldstein says.”
How it works: The details

Depending on your unique situation, the efficiency of the fertility clinic, and timing of your menstrual cycle, one cycle of IUI takes about a month from day one of your period to checking for a positive pregnancy test. Every fertility clinic does things slightly differently, but these are the typical, more specific, steps you’ll go through when pursuing IUI treatment. Keep in mind that the steps and time frames below will also vary based on whether or not you’re using medication to stimulate egg production.
Ultrasound
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: On day 2-4 of your menstrual cycle, counted from first day of period

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIn some cases, an ultrasound will be the first step of your IUI treatment, though this is usually only done if you’re also using medications to stimulate egg production. “With some exceptions, starting IUI treatment involves calling your provider on the first day of your period and then going in for a baseline ultrasound on cycle day 2-4,” Goldstein says. Occasionally, your doctor may prescribe a short course of birth control pills and schedule your treatment that way, but this is less common.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Ovarian stimulation or natural ovulation tracking
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: You’ll usually begin ovarian stimulation on the same day as your ultrasound. The stimulation phase lasts 9-11 days.

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“If you’re doing IUI with medication, typical oral medications used for IUI are clomiphene (clomid) or letrozole (femara),” Goldstein says. “You’ll usually take these for 5 days and return for one to three follow up ultrasounds in the second week of your cycle to see how the follicles are growing and to help time the insemination. Alternatively, you might be prescribed self-injected medication. These are typically taken for 7-10 nights and require closer monitoring, roughly every 2-3 days, to make sure you’re not over- or under-responding and to allow for medication changes.”REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn how to make self-injection less stressful.

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf you’re not using medication for egg production, your doctor may ask that you use an at-home ovulation predictor kit to track your natural ovulation and/or come in for an ultrasound and blood work to help predict when you’ll ovulate. Your provider will typically schedule your IUI treatment within 24-36 hours of predicted ovulation. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn how to use an ovulation predictor kit.
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Egg maturation (aka “trigger shot”)
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: Based on apparent maturity level of the eggs, which is determined by follicle size and estradiol level (usually 9-11 days, but may be 7-8 days or 12-13 days depending on individual).

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf you’re undergoing IUI with medication, a trigger shot will be administered that causes egg follicles to reach the last stage of maturation. This is usually a self-administered dose of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which mimics your body’s natural ovulation surge. The timing on this shot is very important, down to the hour. It’s typically done 36-40 hours before insemination to ensure (though some doctors may give a broader range of 24-40 hours) that your eggs are perfectly matured, which will increase the odds that your treatment is successful. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYour doctor will likely perform daily or near-daily ultrasounds to track the size of the follicles in order to time the trigger shot. If the follicles aren’t growing as expected (too many or too few), they may increase medication or cancel the cycle. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf you’re not using medication for egg production, you’ll skip this step and head to sperm collection then insemination.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Sperm collection
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: Usually takes place the same day as the IUI procedure (aka insemination). After the sample is given by the male partner, sperm preparation takes about an hour.

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThe male partner provides a sperm sample, or donor sperm will be used for insemination. The male partner provides sperm by masturbating into a sterile container. Most often, this is done in a private collection room at your fertility clinic, but some offer the option to collect sperm at home if you live nearby (though this can increase the risk that the sperm won't survive due to temperature extremes during transport—they also need to be processed within about 45 minutes after ejaculation). Your fertility nurse or doctor will give you detailed instructions on how to make sure you get a good semen sample, including how to clean your hands and avoiding lubricants that can affect the semen sample. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThe sperm will then go through a “washing” process at the clinic. You may be picturing a mini laundromat, but this just means that an embryologist will separate out the healthy and motile (aka moving) sperm from the dead or non-moving sperm and other fluids and chemicals that make up semen. This is done with a centrifuge machine. Inserting only the healthiest-looking sperm increases your odds of fertilization. Your clinic may also freeze some sperm in case another IUI cycle is needed. If you’re using donor sperm or frozen sperm, it’ll be thawed before insemination.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Insemination
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Timeframe: Typically 24-40 hours after the trigger shot and within 1 to 4 hours after the sperm has been washed (if fresh) or thawed (if frozen/donated). The actual insemination only takes only a few minutes.

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThe female partner will be asked to lie on their back with their legs held up by stirrups (the same way you might receive a Pap smear). Your doctor or nurse will insert a speculum into the vagina in order to see the cervix and then they’ll insert a catheter. The catheter is a thin, soft tube that will go into the vagina, through the cervix, and finally into the uterus. Your nurse or doctor will then use a syringe to slowly push through a high concentration of the healthiest and most active sperm from the male partner or donor directly into the uterus. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThe process is quick and may be only mildly uncomfortable with no pain relievers or anesthesia needed. Your doctor will ask you to remain on your back for about 10 minutes (roughly the time it takes for sperm to reach an egg) and you may experience some spotting or light cramping that day or the day after.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
The two-week wait
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: If pregnant, a pregnancy test will turn positive about 13-14 days after insemination, which is why this period is commonly known as the two-week wait.

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKAfter your IUI treatment, you’ll wait about two weeks to find out if any of the sperm were able to fertilize an egg and become an embryo. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK“If you’ve been injecting gonadotropins as part of your IUI treatment, at this stage your provider may prescribe supplemental progesterone in the form of a vaginal suppository,” Goldstein says. “The reason for this is that gonadotropins ‘take over’ for your brain hormones FSH and LH, so your brain might also ‘forget’ to stimulate the ovaries to make progesterone after ovulation and progesterone is needed to prep the lining of the uterus. Progesterone may not be necessary after a clomid or letrozole or natural cycle.” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKThe two-week wait can be an emotional time, full of anticipation and anxiety about whether or not the IUI treatment was successful. Try to focus on taking care of yourself and doing things that bring you joy while you wait. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn more about how to cope with the two-week wait.
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
The pregnancy test
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Timeframe: Approximately 13-14 days after insemination

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYour fertility doctor may ask you to avoid taking an at-home pregnancy test. They’re not trying to torture you; they’re just trying to help you avoid disappointment because medication you’ve taken during your treatment may lead to false positives. Instead, try your best to wait to have your hCG levels tested at the clinic. (But if you are pregnant, you might be able to see a positive on an at-home test 1-2 days before this appointment depending on when you ovulated.)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKOn day 13-14 after your IUI treatment, your fertility doctor will either schedule a blood test at the clinic to see if you have a positive hCG or tell you when to take an at-home pregnancy test. If your results are positive you’ll come back or retest at home in 2 days. Your fertility doctor will also keep a close eye for signs of miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy, or multiples via blood work and ultrasounds. If everything looks good that means your baby is on the way! Your fertility doctor will then give you the green light to start getting prenatal care from your OB-GYN or midwife. If you’ve been taking progesterone, your fertility doctor will usually ask you to continue progesterone through 9-12 weeks of pregnancy.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf the pregnancy test is negative, you’ll discuss this with your fertility doctor and partner. You may want to try another round of IUI or your doctor may advise moving on to IVF. It can be heart-breaking to hear this news, but it often takes multiple rounds to become pregnant through any fertility treatment, including IUI. According to the Mayo Clinic, undergoing the same fertility treatment for 3-6 months maximizes your chances of becoming pregnant.
Success rates

While less invasive and less expensive, IUI is considered significantly less effective than IVF treatment, according to both the Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology (SART) and the American Pregnancy Association (APA). However, you should always discuss your individual success rate with your provider because they can vary widely based on the reason you’re seeking treatment and by fertility clinic as well.

According to SART, IUI is most effective if you have unexplained infertility (success rates are more than double the success rates of not using any fertility treatment), and if you don’t have severe fertility issues in either the male or female partner—for example, women with cervical issues that prevent sperm from entering the cervix and men with ejaculation issues.

IUI success rates are not broken down per age because they depend on the reason why you're doing IUI. If the reason you’re seeking IUI treatment is due solely to male factor infertility (for example, a low total motile sperm count), then the goal of doing IUI treatment on a natural cycle would be to correct this issue and get you back to non-treatment pregnancy success rates, which are based on the age of the female partner: females in their 20s have 20-30% success rate per try, 10-15% in their 30s, and 5% chance in their 40s.

Success rates can also depend on whether you took medication during the IUI procedure. Studies show that going the medication route may increase success and the rate of success can increase with each cycle. In the largest study of patients with unexplained infertility (women ages 28 to 42, with a mean age of 34) the chance of pregnancy without treatment or medication was approximately 3% per attempt versus 7% with oral medication or about 9% with injectable medications.
Risks

IUI is considered safe for most people and has a low risk of serious complications, in part because it’s a relatively simple procedure. However, all risks should always be discussed with your doctor before undergoing IUI or any fertility treatment.

Some low risks you should discuss with your doctor include the risk that the female partner experiences an infection and/or spotting from the use of a catheter. The risk of miscarrying a baby conceived with help from IUI is about the same as the rate of unassisted pregnancy, or 30-50% depending on the age of the woman. IUI doesn’t increase the risk of having a baby with birth defects. According to SART, the chance of birth defects in all children is 2% to 4% whether conceived with or without fertility treatment.

If you’re taking medications to increase the number of eggs ovulated, there are some increased risks to be aware of and discuss with your doctor. If taking medication, there is a 2-4% risk of ectopic pregnancy, where the pregnancy develops outside of the uterus, in the fallopian tubes. This type of pregnancy can be very dangerous and would need to be terminated.

There's also an increased risk of becoming pregnant with multiples if ovulation-stimulating medications are used and the risk of multiples from IUI treatment is higher than with IVF treatment. Becoming pregnant with multiples can increase the risk of complications for mother and children. The IUI procedure itself doesn’t increase this risk; it’s simply associated with being pregnant with multiple babies.

If you took injectable gonadotropins to stimulate egg production during IUI treatment and have a high ovarian reserve or polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), there is a risk of experiencing ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS). OHSS happens when injections (and sometimes oral medication, though less likely) cause the ovaries to swell and leak fluid leading to abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Most cases of OHSS are mild and temporary. Studies show an overall incidence of about 1% if injectibles were taken. In severe cases OHSS can cause severe nausea and vomiting, severe abdominal swelling and pain, blood clots, difficulty breathing and difficulty urinating.
Costs

The costs of any fertility treatment can vary by fertility clinic and by insurance coverage. Costs will also depend on how many IUI cycles you go through, and for many, it may take several rounds of IUI to conceive. Even still, IUI tends to be significantly more affordable than IVF in part because there are fewer steps than there are with IVF (with IVF eggs needing to be retrieved and then fertilized with sperm in a laboratory).

For a rough estimate, you can expect IUI treatment to cost between $300-$2,000 per cycle and it’s common to undergo 3-4 cycles to become pregnant. If you’re using a sperm donor, this would be an added cost. According to SART, because multiple rounds are often needed, the overall cost of several rounds of IUI may come to about half the cost of one cycle of IVF (or about $6000).

Always talk to your doctor about the cost of medication involved in IUI treatment as well because this can significantly increase the price. For a rough estimate, oral medications used during IUI may cost $5-$30 per dose. An hCG trigger shot may cost $100-$200. If prescribed, injectable gonadotropins may cost $1,000-$3,000. “The cost of injectable gonadotropins is one reason that they often aren’t used for IUI cycles,” Goldstein says. “If you’re going to pay for injectable gonadotropins, you may want to consider doing IVF instead of IUI, as it has a higher success rate.” You can speak to several fertility clinics to compare pricing and you should always contact your health insurance company directly to learn what costs they’ll cover and if your fertility clinic accepts insurance.

Always contact your health insurance company directly to learn what costs they’ll cover and ask your fertility clinic directly about whether or not they accept insurance. If your clinic doesn’t accept insurance, you may be able to be reimbursed by your insurance after treatment but always ask your insurance company about this directly before proceeding. You may also be able to use a flexible spending account (FSA) or a health savings plan (HSA) to save on taxes related to health spending.
If you need help navigating your insurance or finding a high quality fertility clinic, remember that your Maven Care Advocate  is always here to help.
(Learn about
MavenRx
, Maven's partnership with leading fertility pharmacies to offer you discounts on your medications and more.)
A note on DIY insemination (typically for non-intimate partner donors)

Perhaps you know someone who took matters into their own hands, ordered an insemination kit online (or used less sanitary household utensils) and did it themselves at home. While this option may sound appealing (and cost-saving), there are inefficiencies and risks to going this route.

If you’re wondering about DIY insemination using your partner’s sperm, “there aren’t any additional benefits over intercourse,” Goldstein says. “Studies have shown that in situations of unexplained infertility, intravaginal or intracervical insemination (which is what insemination kits offer) doesn’t increase pregnancy rates. Intrauterine insemination in trained hands does.”

If you’re working with donated sperm, “there are dangers of using a sperm donor who may have infectious diseases,” Goldstein says. “Sperm is also highly temperature and time sensitive. It can’t be put in a home freezer or shipped safely. You may also open yourself up to an unforeseen custody battle, as he might have paternal rights.” For these reasons, DIY insemination is not recommended.
How to get support

Whether you’re deciding between treatments or on your third round of IUI, this process can be stressful and isolating. Remember, you don’t have to go through it alone and that you can access every kind of care on Maven, at any time of day, and at no cost.

Message your Care Advocate  for help finding a high quality fertility clinic, understanding your benefits, and navigating the costs of IUI treatment. If you have specific questions about IUI treatment or want a second opinion, book a video appointment with a
Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist
. And when you just need a listening ear, our
Mental Health Providers
are always here for you at every step of your fertility journey.
Sources
Mayo Clinic: IUI
American Society for Reproductive Medicine
Society for Assisted Reproductive Technology
American Pregnancy Association
Northwestern Medicine: Center for Fertility & Reproductive Medicine
Mayo Clinic: OHSS

title.en-US: An in-depth guide to fertility treatments in Australia

content.value: If you’ve been wading through fertility advice that leaves you feeling more confused than confident, Maven has your back. Our fertility guide will explain all the basics in one place, including the most common fertility treatments, average costs, and what to expect while going through treatment in Australia. Read on for clarity and the start of a better fertility journey.
Fast facts
1 in 6
Heterosexual couples in Australia experience infertility
In Australia, infertility is attributed to 40% male factor, 40% female factor, 20% a combination of factors or unknown

Average cost for IVF treatment (per cycle, excluding medications). When adding procedures such as intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and frozen embryo transfer cycles (FETs), the cost may be closer to $7,000 to $8,000 per cycle.
Who might need fertility treatment?

There are lots of reasons people need help conceiving, and the best treatment option for each person and couple depends largely on the cause of infertility. In other cases, same sex couple require a sperm or egg donor and assisted reproductive technology to start their family. So what are some of the most common causes of infertility and who’s a good candidate for fertility treatment?
Common causes of infertility
According to The Fertility Society of Australia and New Zealand, the main causes of infertility in Australia are:
Ovulatory disorders like irregular or no ovulation (these are the most common cause of female infertility)
Age-related fertility decline or diminished ovarian reserve (low egg count)
Endometriosis
Tubal damage–this may be genetic or caused by pelvic inflammatory disease or other infections
Abnormalities of the uterus (from birth or due to fibroids, polyps, etc.)
Autoimmune disorders
Unexplained infertility, meaning there’s no identified male or female cause
Male factors causing infertility such as structural abnormalities or sperm production problems
Hormonal imbalances (such as thyroid disorders)
Lifestyle factors
Combination of male and female factors
What to expect at your initial consultation

In Australia, you’ll need a referral for fertility treatment if you want to claim a Medicare rebate, and your clinic will request this before your first appointment. Once you have that referral, you’ll start with an initial consultation. Your clinical team will evaluate your fertility and medical history*—*this is a key part of determining next steps. After your initial consultation, you’ll likely be asked to complete a number of tests. Once the test results are in and reviewed by your doctor, your clinical team will discuss their recommended approach. If a treatment like intrauterine insemination (IUI) or in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) is required, your doctor will explain the process step by step.
Common tests

For female patients, a vaginal ultrasound is one of the most important diagnostic tests to assess fertility. It will give your doctor a close look at your uterus and ovaries so they can identify any problems, and look at antral follicle count (AFC). The AFC measures the number of premature follicles (resting eggs) in the ovaries, allowing your doctor to assess your egg reserve. Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is another marker of egg reserve that your doctor will measure. Your clinical team will use the AFC and AMH results to decide what type of protocol you need, and to anticipate how you’ll respond to the medications they prescribe.

If the ultrasound suggests possible blockage of the fallopian tubes, you’ll be referred for a test called an HyCoSy or an X-ray (HSG). Chlamydia testing is usually performed too, as chlamydia can negatively affect your reproductive system. Additional tests that may be ordered include progesterone, follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinising hormone (LH), thyroid function, polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) profile, and miscarriage or genetic screening, if clinically indicated.

For heterosexual or same-sex male couples seeking fertility treatment, a basic semen analysis (SA) will also be done to look at sperm criteria including semen volume, sperm count, morphology (shape) and motility. Semen analysis is performed on an ejaculated sample and evaluated based on standards created by the World Health Organisation (WHO).

Sperm “quality” refers to the sperm’s ability to fertilise an egg, and sperm DNA integrity is very important for normal fertilisation and embryo development. “Good” quality sperm is functional, can achieve fertilisation and has the correct genetics. Assessments of sperm quality shouldn’t serve to define a male as fertile or infertile, but rather to determine further evaluation and treatments.
Sperm motility:
Sperm should be moving forward, not in tight circles or along erratic paths. Low motility is also called asthenozoospermia.
Sperm morphology:
A morphologically normal sperm should have a:
Long tail
made of protein fibers which helps it “swim” to the egg
Mid-piece
that contains mitochondria to power the sperm’s movement
Nicely shaped head
that stores genetic information and helps the sperm get into the egg. Abnormal morphology is also called teratozoospermia.
Total sperm count:

This refers to the total number of sperm within the ejaculate. A high sperm count isn’t helpful if most sperm have abnormal morphology or can’t swim properly. Similarly, sperm with great morphology may carry abnormal DNA.
Sperm concentration:

The total number of sperm per millilitre (ml) of ejaculate. Low sperm concentration is also called oligospermia. If very few sperm are seen after a special preparation, it’s classified as cryptozoospermia. If no sperm are seen, this is called azoospermia.
Some important points:
Sperm are continuously produced and take 76 days to mature, so the effect of lifestyle improvements made today could be seen in 2-3 months
Sperm counts fluctuate, so it’s crucial that 2 or more samples are tested over time to ensure consistency
Seasonal variations in sperm parameters have been reported, with highest counts in late winter/early spring and lowest in late summer
Abstinence length impacts quality; it’s recommended to abstain from ejaculation for 2-5 days before semen analysis
Routine SA’s can’t measure DNA integrity REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Sperm DNA fragmentation is an additional test that may be performed to look for fragmentation or “damage” to the genetic material inside the sperm head. DNA integrity of the sperm is important as half of the genetic material required to make a baby comes from the sperm and the other half comes from the egg. DNA damage to either the egg or sperm affects fertility.
Treatment options
Intrauterine insemination

Intrauterine insemination (IUI) involves injecting sperm directly into a woman's uterus to bypass the cervix, reducing the distance sperm has to travel to meet the egg and increasing the chances of pregnancy.

The success rates of IUI vary and generally fall between 15-20% per cycle depending on factors like age and underlying fertility challenges. The Fertility Society of Australia has reported that 60% of IUI patients conceive within 6 cycles of IUI, but it’s a good idea to speak to your fertility clinic to understand their IUI success rates.

Based on the most recent review of research, the WHO recommends that at least three consecutive IUI cycles should be performed in couples with an indication for IUI, though doing four to six cycles is generally recommended before considering alternative treatments such as IVF. There is no official recommendation on the maximum number of IUI treatment cycles people should pursue. It’s a decision you’ll need to make with your treatment team.
There are two options when it comes to IUI cycles: stimulated or natural.
Stimulated IUI

Your doctor will prescribe hormonal medications to help grow more than one follicle in your ovaries and increase the chances of ovulation. These may be oral medications such as Clomiphene Citrate (Clomid), Letrozole tablets or hormonal injections known as Gonadotropins. These hormonal injections are typically self-administered at home.

Stimulated IUI cycles usually require 4 to 6 clinic visits per treatment cycle so your doctor can closely monitor the growth of your follicles. The first visit is typically on day 2-3 of your menstrual cycle (to rule out any ovarian cysts), again on day 6 and more regularly depending on your response to the medication. During each visit, a pelvic ultrasound is performed to measure the size of the follicles and the thickness of the endometrial lining. After approximately 10-12 days of medication and once the lead follicle is large enough, a HCG "trigger" shot is given to start ovulation. The IUI is then scheduled approximately 24-40 hours later.
Natural IUI

In a natural IUI cycle, no medication will be given. Your doctor will track the growth of the dominant follicle (egg) in your ovary by transvaginal ultrasound and when it’s big enough, they’ll wait for the natural ovulation process to occur. This will be detected by a blood or urine test. The IUI will then be scheduled the next day. Natural IUI isn’t recommended for couples with unexplained infertility.

The cost of an IUI cycle is approximately $2,600 before any rebates are considered (excluding medication costs). The estimated out of pocket costs for an initial cycle in a calendar year is approximately $2,000.
In-vitro fertilization

While intrauterine insemination is a cost-effective, noninvasive first-line therapy for certain patients (same-sex female couples, those with functioning fallopian tubes, cervical issues, anovulation, moderate male factor and unexplained infertility), it has limited success in patients with endometriosis, severe male factor infertility, tubal factor infertility and advanced maternal age (female over 35 years old). After several rounds of unsuccessful IUI treatment or if the causes of infertility aren’t suitable for IUI, in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) may be recommended.

IVF is a technique where a woman’s eggs and a man’s sperm are combined in a laboratory in order to create an embryo(s). Depending on the diagnosis and age of the woman, an embryo or, in some cases, embryos, are transferred to the woman’s uterus through her cervix to increase the chances of pregnancy. IVF is used for heterosexual couples experiencing a range of infertility causes, same sex couples and for single women pursuing parenthood. So, what does it involve?
Step 1. Superovulation to boost egg production

Superovulation is a stimulation process to boost egg production. The process begins with self-injection of drugs containing Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH), which causes egg growth in your ovaries. The more eggs produced, the higher chances of successful fertilisation later in the treatment. |

You’ll also receive blood tests and transvaginal ultrasounds regularly to monitor your hormone levels and check on your ovaries. You might experience bruising, tenderness, or pain at the injection sites. Hormonal medication might also cause emotional changes like mood swings, restlessness, irritability, or generally feeling down, as well as nausea, bloating, fatigue, and possible hot flashes.
Step 2. Egg retrieval

A day or two before your eggs are scheduled to be retrieved, you’ll self-administer a hormone injection that will help the eggs mature more quickly, known as a trigger shot. Roughly 36 hours later, you’ll undergo a minor outpatient surgical procedure called follicular aspiration to extract mature eggs. Most egg collection procedures are performed under conscious intravenous sedation, meaning you’ll be conscious with reduced pain sensitivity. You’ll likely experience some mild to moderate abdominal cramping and/or pelvic pain following the procedure, but this pain is usually mild enough to be treated with over-the-counter pain medicine and disappears within a day or two after the procedure.
Step 3. Sperm production from partner or donor

During the egg retrieval process, the patient's partner will provide a sperm sample or a sample from donated sperm will be thawed. The sperm are then sorted through a high-speed wash and spin cycle to find the healthiest ones. Normally men will produce a fresh ejaculated sperm sample on the day of egg collection to fertilise the eggs, however some men may need to freeze sperm in advance of the egg collection to ensure sperm is available on the day of fertilisation. This occurs when men have reduced sperm volume or quality or may have performance anxiety about producing a sample on the day of the procedure.
Step 4. Fertilisation of eggs

About an hour or so after the eggs have been retrieved and after the sperm has been prepared and assessed, sperm and egg are combined in a process known as insemination. Insemination involves placing a fixed amount of sperm around each egg in a petri dish in an incubator. It typically takes a few hours for a sperm to fertilise an egg. Your clinical team will check to see if fertilisation occurred the following day.

If the sperm don’t meet the criteria for traditional insemination, then a technique called intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is performed. The key difference between routine IVF and ICSI is the way the sperm enters the egg. With ICSI, an embryologist will select the “best” sperm and inject each one directly into each mature egg. ICSI is suggested for the majority of patients, not because they need it, but due to higher fertilisation rates. The trend for this is so great that in some countries almost 100% of patients are only offered ICSI, despite many studies showing that patients with advanced maternal age, low egg numbers and unexplained infertility can have success with routine IVF. Interestingly, pregnancy rates after traditional insemination and after ICSI are very similar.
Step 5. Blastocyst culture

Embryos (fertilised eggs) are grown in a special incubator that monitors the development of each individual embryo. The embryos are assessed the morning after the egg collection to confirm fertilisation into a 2-cell embryo. The embryos, if normally fertilised, should go on to become rapidly expanding balls of cells called blastocysts. Blastocysts are formed by day 5 or 6 of their development. The outer layer of the embryo goes on to become the placenta and the inner cell mass goes on to form the baby. It’s common practice in IVF clinics to extend embryo culture for 5 days until the embryos reach the blastocyst stage.
Embryo development and grading

You may have heard about embryo grading, where an embryologist makes an educated guess about an embryo’s potential based on certain characteristics like the number and size of cells and how quickly certain stages of development are reached. What does the grade of your embryo tell you about the chances of becoming pregnant? The honest answer is: not much. All embryo grading systems are subjective. A high grade doesn’t guarantee that an embryo will successfully implant and carry to term. Many embryos with “poor” grades will become healthy babies, while others graded as top quality will not. In some cases the reason for this will be genetic, which is something that cannot be assessed just by looking at the embryo. Preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) is the only way to assess embryo genetics.
Key milestones to focus on after your egg collection are:
By 16-18 hours post egg collection, fertilisation into a zygote should occur. If an embryo has not reached 2 cells within 24 hours, the process will be stopped.
By 48 hours (“day 2”), the embryos should be at least at the 2 to 4 cell stage.
By 72 hours (“day 3”), the embryos should have about 8-10 cells, also known as cleavage stage.
By ”day 5”, the embryos should reach 120 cells, also known as the blastocyst stage.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Connect with a
Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist
to understand more about IVF versus ICSI and about embryo development.
Step 6. Embryo transfer
Reaching embryo transfer day is a huge milestone. There are two types of embryo transfers to know about: Fresh and frozen.
Fresh embryo transfer

Once your eggs are collected, you’ll be prescribed progesterone-based medications that prepare the lining of your uterus to receive the embryo(s) that will be transferred back. In a fresh embryo transfer cycle, the embryo transfer is done 3-5 days after your egg collection.

Current recommendations are to transfer a single embryo back into the uterus as opposed to two, to reduce the chance of a twin pregnancy. The embryo transfer is done while you’re awake, under ultrasound guidance using a very narrow catheter. It’s pain-free but a full bladder is required prior to the procedure to help with positioning of the uterus and to allow the smooth transfer of the catheter inside. Some people find this slightly uncomfortable, but manageable. (You can empty your bladder right away after the embryo transfer.) The progesterone medication will be continued until the first beta hCG pregnancy test is done, about 2 weeks later. If your cycle resulted in more than one viable embryo, they can be frozen for use in future FET cycles. If the pregnancy test is positive, the progesterone support is usually continued until the end of the first trimester.
Frozen embryo transfer (FET)

During a frozen embryo transfer cycle (FET), you’ll be given medications to build the endometrial thickness of your uterus to increase the odds that an embryo will implant. Since an FET cycle uses an embryo that’s already been created, you won’t need to undergo egg retrieval. There are a few ways to prep for a FET cycle:
Natural cycle:
A natural cycle follows the body’s dominant follicle where the mature follicle produces oestrogen and leads to the thickening of the endometrial lining.
Modified natural cycle:

This cycle is similar to a natural cycle except that an injection of hCG is given to trigger ovulation. You’ll use progesterone pessaries/injectables/oral tablets to prep your uterus for implantation.
Stimulated cycle:
In a stimulated cycle, ovulation is induced with medications (clomid, letrozole or gonadotropins).
Programmed cycle:

Estrogen and progesterone medications are given to prep your uterus and the ovary is suppressed, so ovulation does not occur. The embryo transfer is planned a set number of days after progesterone support starts, usually for 3-6 days later. Estrogen and progesterone are continued and a pregnancy test is done 9-14 days after the transfer. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

There are a number of reasons why you might undergo a FET rather than a fresh transfer. For example, if you’re using embryos created from a previous treatment cycle, they’ll be transferred from frozen. Or, if your endometrial lining doesn’t reach desired thickness for a fresh transfer, your doctor may decide to postpone the embryo transfer, and you’ll need to do a FET transfer in the future instead.

Another common reason to do FET is when PGT-A genetic testing is being performed on the embryos to rule out chromosomal abnormalities. This process involves taking several cells from the outer layer of the fresh embryos then freezing the embryos while awaiting the results of the genetic test. Once the results are received and if a genetically normal embryo has been identified, a FET cycle will be planned.

If you’re at risk for Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS), your doctor may also decide to freeze all of your embryos for future use. Transferring an embryo back into the uterus while you’re at risk of OHSS is not recommended*—* if you became pregnant, the resulting increasing hCG levels would make OHSS worse. This can be potentially life threatening.
Frozen embryo transfer cycles offer:
Reduced risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
Optimization of endometrial receptivity
Time for PGT testing
Prioritisation of embryos for single embryo transfer (SET)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Pregnancy rates after FET have significantly increased over the years mainly due to advances in embryo freezing. This has led to many clinics encouraging elective “freeze-all”: freezing
all
suitable embryos for future use. A large 2020 review however, showed that there is no significant difference between birth rates in fresh ETs versus FETs for most patients.
So, who should consider freeze-all? Your physician may recommend it if any of the below apply to you:
You’re at risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
You have high progesterone on trigger day
You want to do PGT-A genetic testing
You have slow growth embryos
You have uterine abnormalities
Side effects of IVF
Side effects of IVF medication may include:
Nausea
Mood swings
Bloating
Fatigue
Bruising at the injection site
Vaginal discharge
Pelvic pain or abdominal pain
Are there any risks?

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a possible complication of IVF where the ovaries swell and fluid leaks into the body. The condition is more common in women with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). After gonadotropin stimulation for IVF, the reported rate of moderate OHSS is 3% to 6%, and for severe OHSS it’s 0.1% to 2%. A milder form of OHSS occurs in about 20% to 33% of IVF cycles but isn’t a cause for concern. With close monitoring and the use of lower doses of gonadotropins to trigger ovulation, the risk of severe OHSS can be greatly reduced. (The risk of developing OHSS during medicated IUI cycles is much lower because the medication doses are lower.)
Are there any restrictions on who can access treatment in Australia?
LGBTQIA+ family building

LGBTQIA+ are legally guaranteed access to fertility treatments in Australia. However, you’re only eligible for a Medicare rebate if you’re "medically infertile" which is often not the case for LGBTQIA+ people seeking to start a family. Because of this, the costs of fertility treatment are often a barrier for LGBTQIA+ couples seeking treatments.
Same-sex female couples

Same-sex female couples wishing to start a family will need to use donor sperm. According to the Victoria Assisted Reproductive Treatment Authority, single women are still the largest group using donor sperm (53%), followed by women in same-sex relationships (34%). Anonymous sperm donation is not allowed in Australia and identifying information about the donor will be released to any person born as a result of their donation if requested (the same goes for donor eggs or embryos as well).
Same-sex male couples
For same-sex male couples wishing to start their family through assisted reproductive technology, surrogacy is the main treatment option. Surrogacy is heavily regulated and laws vary by region.

Commercial surrogacy is outlawed in all states of Australia except for the Northern Territory, which has no laws governing surrogacy. Three jurisdictions impose extra-territorial criminal sanctions for those who engage in commercial surrogacy overseas and return with a child. Altruistic surrogacy arrangements are privately organised and legal in all Australian states (although there are no laws in the Northern Territory which deal specifically with surrogacy). There is a restriction in the Australian Capital Territory that the intending parents to an altruistic surrogacy arrangement must be a couple and at least one of the intended parents must be genetically related to the child. Sex selection is prohibited except when it is used to screen for genetic diseases. In April 2022, a new law was passed allowing people with hereditary mitochondrial disease to use a third person's egg in IVF treatment.

Donor egg treatment is available throughout Australia with regulation differing significantly from state to state. Anonymous donation is not allowed in Australia. In Victoria, eggs can only be “gifted” meaning commercial donation is prohibited. Although it is illegal to be paid for donating an egg(s), a donor may be reimbursed for reasonable expenses like medical costs, counselling expenses, and travel expenses.
How much does IVF cost in Australia?
As anyone who has undergone fertility treatments will tell you, the emotional and physical challenges can be immense. And the financial toll can be, too.
Out-of-pocket costs

The average out of pocket cost for an IVF cycle is between $5,000 - $6,000 excluding medication costs. Costs also vary between clinics so requesting this information early on can be useful for comparing clinics.
Private insurance coverage

Many private insurers offer plans that partially cover the cost of care, reimbursing patients for a portion of the expenses involved in fertility treatment. Private health plans that cover IVF treatments will generally apply a 12-month waiting period to assisted reproductive services. Get clarification on this from the outset to avoid any delays. If you have private health insurance and your egg collection procedure is performed in a hospital, you may be fully or partially covered for the expenses. It’s recommended to contact your private health fund and specifically ask about item 13212 (egg collection procedure) to confirm your level of coverage. Anaesthetic fees are often eligible for rebate from private health insurance if the egg collection is performed under general anaesthesia. If the egg collection is performed under conscious sedation, then the cost of the medication utilised will be charged directly to you by the dispensing pharmacy.
Public Medicare coverage

Medicare is Australia’s universal health care system. It offers rebates that partially cover the cost of care and can provide reimbursement for a portion of the expenses involved in fertility treatment. The Extended Medicare Safety Net (EMSN) provides an additional capped rebate for individuals and families whose costs go over an annual threshold.

There is no Medicare rebate available for Specialist Day Hospital procedures, although there are some rebates for anaesthetic services. Anaesthetic fees are often eligible for rebate from both Medicare and private health insurance. That means the total amount for which a patient is covered for fertility treatment day hospital procedures is dependent on the level of private insurance coverage. Most fertility medications are listed and covered on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) with a co-payment required for each type of fertility medication prescribed. It's estimated that medications cost around $200. Medicare ineligible patients and those cycles ineligible for rebate cannot use the PBS copay and could pay out-of-pocket medication costs in the range of $2,500 - $4,000.
What can impact the costs?

The number of cycles required. IVF isn’t always successful after the first cycle, which is why clinics quote their “cumulative success rate”, i.e. their results from one fresh IVF cycle and subsequent FET cycles. Any subsequent FET cycle will incur additional costs of approximately $2,000 per cycle (excluding medication costs) and varies from clinic to clinic.
ICSI can cost an additional $900 - $1,000 per cycle.
Storage costs for any surplus eggs/embryos you store for future use. This can cost approximately $600 per year.

Genetic testing of embryos (PGT-A and PGT-M). PGT- with Array CGH (advanced embryo selection for chromosomal variations) and PGD (for single gene disorders) can cost approximately $700 per embryo biopsied. The price varies depending on the number of embryos requiring genetic testing and the individual clinic fees. Genetic testing is not covered under the Medicare rebate.
How can you save money?
Medicare rebates
Many fertility treatments are eligible for Medicare rebates. Register for
Medicare Safety Net

to lower your out of pocket medical costs for out of hospital services. Once you meet a certain threshold, some fertility treatment costs can be covered. A referral from a specialist with a diagnosis of “infertility” is required for Medicare eligibility and there is no limit on the number of treatment rounds you can have.
