It’s important to speak to your doctor, your clinic and your insurer to find out what your insurance coverage is, Medicare coverage is, what the different treatment costs are and what you’ll have to pay so you can make an informed decision. Most clinics will have a patient services team who can offer a detailed individual financial estimate of expected expenses.
Release of superannuation

Superannuation (generally for retirement) is accessible to those seeking assistance with fertility treatment costs. People can apply to the Australian Tax Office to legally access their super funds early on compassionate grounds for a range of medical procedures, including IVF.
Maven Partner Clinic perks

As a Maven member located in Australia, you get access to exclusive perks at Australia’s leading network of fertility clinics, Virtus Group. We’ve carefully selected Virtus Group’s clinics based on their high clinical quality standards, strong success rates, and patient satisfaction. The clinics we have partnered with offer a full range of fertility services for both couples and individuals, including IUI, IVF, egg freezing, and more. Virtus Group clinics—including IVFAustralia, Melbourne IVF, Queensland Fertility Group, TasIVF, and The Fertility Centre—offer Maven members exclusive perks like discounts on fertility services and complementary egg/embryo storage for the first year. You can message your Care Advocate  to learn more about this partnership, and get connected with a Maven partner fertility clinic.
How to find a high quality fertility clinic
Finding the right clinic can feel overwhelming. Between factors like success rates, reviews and location, there’s a lot to consider.

In Australia, fertility treatments are regulated by The Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee (RTAC), a professional group of the Board of the Fertility Society of Australia. All fertility clinics throughout Australia are required to submit their data to the National Perinatal Epidemiology and Statistics Unit (NPESU) each year as part of the licensing requirement. That data is then made available to the public through the Australian & New Zealand Assisted Reproduction Database (ANZARD). ANZARD data is used for benchmarking the performance of clinics both nationally and internationally and makes it possible to compare individual clinic success rates against the national rates.
ANZARD focuses on several important metrics for choosing a fertility clinic:
Live birth rate (cumulative)
Live birth rate (per embryo transferred)
Multiple pregnancy rate
National average success rates
When you think about a clinic’s success rate, compare the clinic’s results to the national average rates. Here are a few key rates to focus on.
Births per complete egg retrieval cycle (cumulative live birth rate)

This rate refers to the birth rate resulting from all of the eggs collected in one IVF cycle. That means the live birth rate after a fresh IVF cycle, including live births from any associated frozen embryos from that cycle. This information provides those considering IVF with a better understanding of their chances of delivering a child when undertaking one egg retrieval procedure.
The ANZARD live birth rate (cumulative) is 44% for women younger than 35 years of age.
REPLACEWITHASSET
Births per embryo transferred

This rate is arguably the most important rate Australian clinics focus on. It’s the number of births divided by the total number of embryos transferred. This measure shows the chance of a live birth from each individual fresh or frozen embryo that was transferred in one year at this clinic. Measuring this rate promotes embryo transfer practices that minimises the chances of twins, which carry health risks for the babies and the mother.
The ANZARD live birth rate per embryo transferred is 31% for women younger than 38 years of age.
REPLACEWITHASSET
Multiple birth rate

Another important rate to consider is the multiple birth rate. For some people, having twins may seem like a wonderful thing, but multiple pregnancies are less safe for mother and babies. Look for clinics with a multiple pregnancy rate of less than 10%.
The national average multiple birth rate in Australia is 3.2%.
Outcomes of donor insemination (DI) Cycles

ANZARD also gathers data from donor insemination (DI) cycles using donor sperm. Of the DI cycles in women under 35 years old, 16.4% resulted in a live birth, compared with 2.8% of DI cycles in women aged 40 or older.
REPLACEWITHASSET
Other important things to consider:
Responsive staff
You shouldn’t feel rushed. You should be able to ask all of your questions and get helpful answers in return.
Excellent reviews
Other patients should seem highly satisfied with the quality of the staff and services provided.
High-quality laboratory

The quality of the IVF lab is instrumental in ensuring the best possible embryos are created and the best possible outcome is achieved. What happens in the lab between your egg collection and embryo transfer could determine whether you deliver a healthy baby. Even if your embryos were top quality, a substandard lab could negatively impact embryos growth and ultimately affect your treatment outcome. This is why it’s important to ask for your IVF lab’s Performance Indicators (PI’s). Ask your clinic what their PIs are and compare them to those of other clinics in your area.

In 2017, the European Society for Human Reproduction and Embryology (ESHRE) and Alpha Scientists in Reproductive Medicine, an expert panel of fertility specialists, created goal PIs for IVF labs. If these numbers are not readily available from your clinic, they should be provided when asked for:
Number of eggs collected: 80-95% of follicles
Number of mature eggs: 75-90% of eggs collected
Normal fertilisation: 75-80% of eggs
Number of fertilised eggs that cleave (divide): 96-99%
Number of embryos that become blastocysts: 40-60%
Implantation rate (blastocyst): 35-60%REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

A great IVF lab can make a big difference in your chances of bringing home a baby. If you need help choosing a fertility clinic, Maven can support you by building a list of high quality fertility clinics in your area, including information on the clinic’s success rates (if available). Remember, Maven is here to support you at every step of your fertility journey. Reach out to your Care Advocate  for help today.
Resources
Fertility counsellors
The Fertility Society of Australia and New Zealand provides a list of private practice fertility counsellors. A list can be found
here.
Professional bodies
Fertility Society of Australia and New Zealand
the peak professional body representing scientists, doctors, researchers, nurses, consumers and counsellors in reproductive medicine in Australia & New Zealand.
ANZICA

the Australian and New Zealand Infertility Counsellors Association is a professional association for infertility counsellors that promotes a high standard of counselling for individuals affected by infertility issues.
Australia surrogacy resources
Surrogacy Australia
is a national organisation that aims to enhance the understanding of, and access to, best practice surrogacy arrangements through education, support and advocacy.
Sources
Australian and New Zealand Assisted Reproduction Database (ANZARD)
Australian Government: Services Australia - Medicare
Victoria Assisted Reproductive Treatment Authority (VARTA)
The Fertility Society of Australia and New Zealand
The Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee (RTAC)
WHO IUI: Review and Systematic Assessment of the Evidence that Supports Global Recommendations

title.en-US: An in-depth guide to fertility treatments in Canada

content.value: If you’ve been wading through a sea of fertility treatment information that leaves you feeling more confused than confident, Maven has your back. Our fertility guide explains all the basics in one place, including the most common fertility treatments, average costs, and what to expect while going through treatment in Canada. Read on for clarity and the start of a better fertility journey.
Fast facts
1 in 6
Couples experience infertility in Canada
Infertility is 30% male factor, 40% female factor, 20% a combination of factors, 10% unexplained
Average cost for IVF treatment (per cycle). Medication alone can cost anywhere from $2,500 to $7,000+.
Who might need fertility treatment?

There are lots of reasons people need help conceiving, and the best treatment option for each person and couple depends largely on the cause of infertility. In other cases, same sex couple require a sperm or egg donor and assisted reproductive technology to start their family. So what are some of the most common causes of infertility and who’s a good candidate for fertility treatment?
Common causes of infertility

Age related fertility decline or diminished ovarian reserve (low egg count). According to the Canadian Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, age is a primary reason for infertility challenges. Female fertility naturally declines with age, particularly after age 35, and for that reason, it’s recommended that women over 35 seek an infertility work-up after 6 months of trying to conceive.
Blocked fallopian tubes (this may be genetic or caused by pelvic inflammatory disease or other infections)
Male factor (such as structural abnormalities or sperm production problems)
Ovulation issues (irregular or no ovulation)
Hormonal imbalances (such as thyroid disorders)
Abnormalities of the uterus (from birth or due to fibroids, polyps, etc)
Endometriosis
Combination of male and female factors
Unexplained factors
What to expect at your initial consultation

Once you’ve made the decision to explore or undergo fertility treatments, you’ll start with an initial consultation. Your clinical team will evaluate your fertility and medical history*—*this is a key part of determining next steps. After your initial consultation, you’ll likely be asked to complete a number of tests. Once the results of the tests are in and reviewed by your doctor, your clinical team will discuss their recommended approach. If a treatment like IUI or IVF (intrauterine insemination or in-vitro fertilization) is required, your doctor will explain the process step by step.
Common tests

For female patients, a vaginal ultrasound is one of the most important diagnostic tests to assess fertility. It will give your doctor a close look at your uterus and ovaries so they can identify any problems, and look at antral follicle count (AFC). The AFC measures the number of premature follicles (resting eggs) in the ovaries, allowing your doctor to assess your egg reserve. Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is another marker of egg reserve that your doctor will measure. Your clinical team will use the AFC and AMH results to decide what type of protocol you need, and to anticipate how you’ll respond to the medications they prescribe.

If the ultrasound suggests possible blockage of the fallopian tubes, you’ll be referred for a test called an HyCoSy or an X-ray (HSG). Chlamydia testing is usually performed too, as chlamydia can negatively affect your reproductive system. Additional tests that may be ordered include progesterone, follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinising hormone (LH), thyroid function, polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) profile, and miscarriage or genetic screening, if clinically indicated.

For heterosexual or same-sex male couples seeking fertility treatment, a basic semen analysis (SA) will also be done to look at sperm criteria including semen volume, sperm count, morphology (shape) and motility. Semen analysis is performed on an ejaculated sample and evaluated based on standards created by the World Health Organisation (WHO).

Sperm “quality” refers to the sperm’s ability to fertilise an egg, and sperm DNA integrity is very important for normal fertilisation and embryo development. “Good” quality sperm is functional, can achieve fertilisation and has the correct genetics. Assessments of sperm quality shouldn’t serve to define a male as fertile or infertile, but rather to determine further evaluation and treatments.
Sperm motility:
Sperm should be moving forward, not in tight circles or along erratic paths. Low motility is also called asthenozoospermia.
Sperm morphology:
A morphologically normal sperm should have a:
Long tail
made of protein fibers which helps it “swim” to the egg
Mid-piece
that contains mitochondria to power the sperm’s movement
Nicely shaped head
that stores genetic information and helps the sperm get into the egg. Abnormal morphology is also called teratozoospermia.
Total sperm count:

This refers to the total number of sperm within the ejaculate. A high sperm count isn’t helpful if most sperm have abnormal morphology or can’t swim properly. Similarly, sperm with great morphology may carry abnormal DNA.
Sperm concentration:

The total number of sperm per millilitre (ml) of ejaculate. Low sperm concentration is also called oligospermia. If very few sperm are seen after a special preparation, it’s classified as cryptozoospermia. If no sperm are seen, this is called azoospermia.
Some important points:
Sperm are continuously produced and take 76 days to mature, so the effect of lifestyle improvements made today could be seen in 2-3 months
Sperm counts fluctuate, so it’s crucial that 2 or more samples are tested over time to ensure consistency
Seasonal variations in sperm parameters have been reported, with highest counts in late winter/early spring and lowest in late summer
Abstinence length impacts quality; it’s recommended to abstain from ejaculation for 2-5 days before semen analysis
Routine SA’s can’t measure DNA integrity REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Sperm DNA fragmentation is an additional test that may be performed to look for fragmentation or “damage” to the genetic material inside the sperm head. DNA integrity of the sperm is important as half of the genetic material required to make a baby comes from the sperm and the other half comes from the egg. DNA damage to either the egg or sperm affects fertility.
Treatment options
Intrauterine insemination

Intrauterine insemination (IUI) involves injecting sperm directly into a woman's uterus to bypass the cervix, reducing the distance sperm has to travel to meet the egg and increasing the chances of pregnancy.

If a couple decides to do IUI using their own sperm, the male will be asked to provide a sperm sample at the fertility clinic by masturbating into a specimen cup. This usually happens on the same day that the IUI treatment takes place. The sperm sample will be "washed" and filtered to produce a concentrated sample of healthy sperm. If donated sperm is used, the sperm will be thawed and prepared in time for the IUI treatment to take place.

“The recommended number of IUI cycles really depends on the clinical scenario,” says Dan Nayot, MD, Reproductive Endocrinologist and Medical Director at The Fertility Partners, Maven’s fertility clinic partner network in Canada. If a patient that doesn’t have access to sperm (eg single woman or same-sex female couple), but would otherwise be considered fertile, several IUI cycles might be attempted before considering another approach. Generally in “unexplained” infertility, 3 cycles of IUI are commonly recommended as first line treatment. The clinical approach must be personalized, and the patient is encouraged to understand their chances of success with each proposed intervention and to be actively involved in their decision making.
Indications for IUI:

In couples with unexplained infertility where the male has a total motile sperm count (TMSC) above 10 million and the likelihood of spontaneous pregnancy within a year is less than 30% (as determined by your clinical team), IUI plus ovarian stimulation is the first line of treatment.
In couples with just poor sperm quality in the male, there is no official recommendation for or against IUI.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
There are two options when it comes to IUI cycles: a stimulated or a natural approach.
Stimulated IUI

Your doctor will prescribe hormonal medications to help grow more than one follicle in your ovaries and increase the chances of ovulation. These may be oral medications such as Clomiphene Citrate (Clomid), Letrozole tablets or hormonal injections known as Gonadotropins. These hormonal injections are typically self-administered at home.

Stimulated IUI cycles usually require 4 to 6 clinic visits per treatment cycle so your doctor can closely monitor the growth of your follicles. The first visit is typically on day 2-3 of your menstrual cycle (to rule out any ovarian cysts), again on day 6 and more regularly depending on your response to the medication. During each visit, a pelvic ultrasound is performed to measure the size of the follicles and the thickness of the endometrial lining. After approximately 10-12 days of medication and once the lead follicle is large enough, a HCG "trigger" shot is given to start ovulation. The IUI is then scheduled approximately 24-40 hours later.
Natural IUI

In a natural IUI cycle, no medication will be given. Your doctor will track the growth of the dominant follicle (egg) in your ovary by transvaginal ultrasound and when it’s big enough, they’ll wait for the natural ovulation process to occur. This will be detected by a blood or urine test. The IUI will then be scheduled the next day. In couples with unexplained infertility, it’s not recommended to try natural IUI.
The cost of an IUI cycle can range from $400-1500 CAD.
In-vitro fertilization

While intrauterine insemination is a cost-effective, noninvasive first-line therapy for certain patients (same-sex female couples, those with functioning fallopian tubes, cervical issues, anovulation, moderate male factor and unexplained infertility), it has limited success in patients with endometriosis, severe male factor infertility, tubal factor infertility and advanced maternal age (female over 35 years old). After several rounds of unsuccessful IUI treatment or if the causes of infertility aren’t suitable for IUI, in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) may be recommended.

IVF is a technique where a woman’s eggs and a man’s sperm are combined in a laboratory in order to create an embryo(s). Depending on the diagnosis and age of the woman, an embryo or, in some cases, embryos, are transferred to the woman’s uterus through her cervix to increase the chances of pregnancy. IVF is used for heterosexual couples experiencing a range of infertility causes, same sex couples and for single women pursuing parenthood. So, what does it involve?
Step 1. Superovulation to boost egg production

Superovulation is a stimulation process to boost egg production. The process begins with self-injection of drugs containing Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH), which causes egg growth in your ovaries. The more eggs produced, the higher chances of successful fertilisation later in the treatment. |

You’ll also receive blood tests and transvaginal ultrasounds regularly to monitor your hormone levels and check on your ovaries. You might experience bruising, tenderness, or pain at the injection sites. Hormonal medication might also cause emotional changes like mood swings, restlessness, irritability, or generally feeling down, as well as nausea, bloating, fatigue, and possible hot flashes.
Step 2. Egg retrieval

A day or two before your eggs are scheduled to be retrieved, you’ll self-administer a hormone injection that will help the eggs mature more quickly, known as a trigger shot. Roughly 36 hours later, you’ll undergo a minor outpatient surgical procedure called follicular aspiration to extract mature eggs. Most egg collection procedures are performed under conscious intravenous sedation, meaning you’ll be conscious with reduced pain sensitivity. You’ll likely experience some mild to moderate abdominal cramping and/or pelvic pain following the procedure, but this pain is usually mild enough to be treated with over-the-counter pain medicine and disappears within a day or two after the procedure.
Step 3. Sperm production from partner or donor

During the egg retrieval process, the patient's partner will provide a sperm sample or a sample from donated sperm will be thawed. The sperm are then sorted through a high-speed wash and spin cycle to find the healthiest ones. Normally men will produce a fresh ejaculated sperm sample on the day of egg collection to fertilise the eggs, however some men may need to freeze sperm in advance of the egg collection to ensure sperm is available on the day of fertilisation. This occurs when men have reduced sperm volume or quality or may have performance anxiety about producing a sample on the day of the procedure.
Step 4. Fertilisation of eggs

About an hour or so after the eggs have been retrieved and after the sperm has been prepared and assessed, sperm and egg are combined in a process known as insemination. Insemination involves placing a fixed amount of sperm around each egg in a petri dish in an incubator. It typically takes a few hours for a sperm to fertilise an egg. Your clinical team will check to see if fertilisation occurred the following day.

If the sperm don’t meet the criteria for traditional insemination, then a technique called intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is performed. The key difference between routine IVF and ICSI is the way the sperm enters the egg. With ICSI, an embryologist will select the “best” sperm and inject each one directly into each mature egg. ICSI is suggested for the majority of patients, not because they need it, but due to higher fertilisation rates. The trend for this is so great that in some countries almost 100% of patients are only offered ICSI, despite many studies showing that patients with advanced maternal age, low egg numbers and unexplained infertility can have success with routine IVF. Interestingly, pregnancy rates after traditional insemination and after ICSI are very similar.
Step 5. Blastocyst culture

Embryos (fertilised eggs) are grown in a special incubator that monitors the development of each individual embryo. The embryos are assessed the morning after the egg collection to confirm fertilisation into a 2-cell embryo. The embryos, if normally fertilised, should go on to become rapidly expanding balls of cells called blastocysts. Blastocysts are formed by day 5 or 6 of their development. The outer layer of the embryo goes on to become the placenta and the inner cell mass goes on to form the baby. It’s common practice in IVF clinics to extend embryo culture for 5 days until the embryos reach the blastocyst stage.
Embryo development and grading

You may have heard about embryo grading, where an embryologist makes an educated guess about an embryo’s potential based on certain characteristics like the number and size of cells and how quickly certain stages of development are reached. What does the grade of your embryo tell you about the chances of becoming pregnant? The honest answer is: not much. All embryo grading systems are subjective. A high grade doesn’t guarantee that an embryo will successfully implant and carry to term. Many embryos with “poor” grades will become healthy babies, while others graded as top quality will not. In some cases the reason for this will be genetic, which is something that cannot be assessed just by looking at the embryo. Preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) is the only way to assess embryo genetics.
Key milestones to focus on after your egg collection are:
By 16-18 hours post egg collection, fertilisation into a zygote should occur. If an embryo has not reached 2 cells within 24 hours, the process will be stopped.
By 48 hours (“day 2”), the embryos should be at least at the 2 to 4 cell stage.
By 72 hours (“day 3”), the embryos should have about 8-10 cells, also known as cleavage stage.
By ”day 5”, the embryos should reach 120 cells, also known as the blastocyst stage.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Connect with a
Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist
to understand more about IVF versus ICSI and about embryo development.
Step 6. Embryo transfer
Reaching embryo transfer day is a huge milestone. There are two types of embryo transfers to know about: Fresh and frozen.
Fresh embryo transfer

Once your eggs are collected, you’ll be prescribed progesterone-based medications that prepare the lining of your uterus to receive the embryo(s) that will be transferred back. In a fresh embryo transfer cycle, the embryo transfer is done 3-5 days after your egg collection.

Current recommendations are to transfer a single embryo back into the uterus as opposed to two, to reduce the chance of a twin pregnancy. The embryo transfer is done while you’re awake, under ultrasound guidance using a very narrow catheter. It’s pain-free but a full bladder is required prior to the procedure to help with positioning of the uterus and to allow the smooth transfer of the catheter inside. Some people find this slightly uncomfortable, but manageable. (You can empty your bladder right away after the embryo transfer.) The progesterone medication will be continued until the first beta hCG pregnancy test is done, about 2 weeks later. If your cycle resulted in more than one viable embryo, they can be frozen for use in future FET cycles. If the pregnancy test is positive, the progesterone support is usually continued until the end of the first trimester.
Frozen embryo transfer (FET)

During a frozen embryo transfer cycle (FET), you’ll be given medications to build the endometrial thickness of your uterus to increase the odds that an embryo will implant. Since an FET cycle uses an embryo that’s already been created, you won’t need to undergo egg retrieval. There are a few ways to prep for a FET cycle:
Natural cycle:
A natural cycle follows the body’s dominant follicle where the mature follicle produces oestrogen and leads to the thickening of the endometrial lining.
Modified natural cycle:

This cycle is similar to a natural cycle except that an injection of hCG is given to trigger ovulation. You’ll use progesterone pessaries/injectables/oral tablets to prep your uterus for implantation.
Stimulated cycle:
In a stimulated cycle, ovulation is induced with medications (clomid, letrozole or gonadotropins).
Programmed cycle:

Estrogen and progesterone medications are given to prep your uterus and the ovary is suppressed, so ovulation does not occur. The embryo transfer is planned a set number of days after progesterone support starts, usually for 3-6 days later. Estrogen and progesterone are continued and a pregnancy test is done 9-14 days after the transfer. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

There are a number of reasons why you might undergo a FET rather than a fresh transfer. For example, if you’re using embryos created from a previous treatment cycle, they’ll be transferred from frozen. Or, if your endometrial lining doesn’t reach desired thickness for a fresh transfer, your doctor may decide to postpone the embryo transfer, and you’ll need to do a FET transfer in the future instead.

Another common reason to do FET is when PGT-A genetic testing is being performed on the embryos to rule out chromosomal abnormalities. This process involves taking several cells from the outer layer of the fresh embryos then freezing the embryos while awaiting the results of the genetic test. Once the results are received and if a genetically normal embryo has been identified, a FET cycle will be planned.

If you’re at risk for Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS), your doctor may also decide to freeze all of your embryos for future use. Transferring an embryo back into the uterus while you’re at risk of OHSS is not recommended*—* if you became pregnant, the resulting increasing hCG levels would make OHSS worse. This can be potentially life threatening.
Frozen embryo transfer cycles offer:
Reduced risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
Optimization of endometrial receptivity
Time for PGT testing
Prioritisation of embryos for single embryo transfer (SET)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Pregnancy rates after FET have significantly increased over the years mainly due to advances in embryo freezing. This has led to many clinics encouraging elective “freeze-all”: freezing
all
suitable embryos for future use. A large 2020 review however, showed that there is no significant difference between birth rates in fresh ETs versus FETs for most patients.
So, who should consider freeze-all? Your physician may recommend it if any of the below apply to you:
You’re at risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
You have high progesterone on trigger day
You want to do PGT-A genetic testing
You have slow growth embryos
You have uterine abnormalities
Side effects of IVF
Side effects of IVF medication may include:
Nausea
Mood swings
Bloating
Fatigue
Bruising at the injection site
Vaginal discharge
Pelvic pain or abdominal pain
Are there any risks?

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a possible complication of IVF where the ovaries swell and fluid leaks into the body. The condition is more common in women with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). After gonadotropin stimulation for IVF, the reported rate of moderate OHSS is 3% to 6%, and for severe OHSS it’s 0.1% to 2%. A milder form of OHSS occurs in about 20% to 33% of IVF cycles but isn’t a cause for concern. With close monitoring and the use of lower doses of gonadotropins to trigger ovulation, the risk of severe OHSS can be greatly reduced. (The risk of developing OHSS during medicated IUI cycles is much lower because the medication doses are lower.)
Are there any restrictions on who can access treatment in Canada?

In Canada, fertility treatment is legislated under The Assisted Human Reproduction Act (AHRA). The Act permits surrogacy, egg donation, embryo donation, and sperm donation within the country. If you’re a same sex couple, single, or already have children, there are no restrictions to accessing fertility treatments. Sex selection however is prohibited, except under certain circumstances when it’s used to screen for genetic diseases.
LGBTQIA+ family building

Most provinces and territories in Canada support LGBTQIA+ family building and discriminating based on sexual orientation and expression is illegal. Non-commercial surrogacy is legal and it’s also legal to reimburse a surrogate mother for her reasonable expenses incurred as a result of the surrogacy.
Same sex male couples

For same sex male couples or single men wishing to grow their families, gestational surrogacy is very common. While traditional surrogacy (the process of having the surrogate mother donate her own eggs and also carry the pregnancy) is technically legal, it can have unintended emotional and legal consequences for everyone involved. That’s why gestational surrogacy is the most common route to parenthood. The couple or person using a surrogate will need to enlist the help of both an
egg donor
(known or anonymous) and a
gestational carrier
(a surrogate who does not have a genetic connection to the fetus they are carrying).
Anonymous donors
choose to remain unknown and have no contact with the Intended Parent(s).
Known donors
donate their eggs and choose to reveal their identities and possibly have contact with their egg recipient, the Intended Parent(s). REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Seeking legal advice before starting this journey is necessary as both an egg donor agreement and a surrogacy agreement will need to be prepared. Once the baby is born, the father(s) will need to
apply for a declaration of parentage
Same sex female couples

Same sex female couples wanting to grow their families will need to use a sperm donor. Sperm donation is legal but can be complex, so seeking legal advice is recommended. The most notable restriction is that it’s illegal to purchase sperm directly from a donor or a person acting on behalf of a donor. Sperm donation treatment usually takes place at a fertility clinic using sperm from a sperm bank or from a known sperm donor. Donor sperm must be screened, frozen, and quarantined for six months before it can be used through a fertility clinic.
Same sex female couples have options on the type of assistance they want when trying to achieve a pregnancy. IVF, IUI and home insemination are all options available to those living in Canada.

The carrying mother is automatically the legal parent of the child while her non-carrying partner is not. Equal legal parentage for both mothers can be achieved through a second parent adoption process or a declaration of parentage process. It’s recommended to seek legal advice before pursuing treatment with donor sperm. Before any treatment, a sperm donation agreement will be recommended for all parties.

There’s no definitive law in Canada regarding the legal rights and obligations of a sperm donor, so it’s important to seek legal advice specific to the province you live in. In Ontario and Alberta for example, there’s legislation in place specifying that a sperm donor is not a parent simply because of their genetic connection to the child. In other provinces, legislation is silent as to the rights and obligations of a sperm donor, which may be more concerning. Having a sperm donation agreement is in everyone’s best interest.

Ontario is the only province in Canada to recognize sperm donation through sex in such a way as to make the donor not a legal parent. In this case, a written agreement between the parties must be in place prior to the conception of the child.
How much does IVF cost in Canada?
As anyone who has undergone fertility treatments will tell you, the emotional and physical challenges can be immense. And the financial toll can be, too.

Despite having a universal healthcare system, healthcare coverage for infertility treatment varies between each province in Canada, with only five provinces currently providing financial assistance for IVF.
Provincial coverage
Ontario

In Ontario, the Ontario Health Insurance Plan (OHIP) currently offers coverage for one cycle of IVF per person, per lifetime. The Ontario fertility program also covers unlimited rounds of IUI. For more information about funding eligibility, visit
health.gov.on.ca/en/public/programs/ivf/
Clinics
are required to be officially approved by the Ontario Ministry of Health to provide OHIP-funded fertility treatments.
Here

is a complete list of OHIP-funded fertility treatments in Ontario. Coverage is limited to those under 43 years of age seeking treatment and medications are not currently covered under this provincial plan. The cost of medications can range from $5,000 - $7,000 CAD per IVF cycle.
Manitoba

Manitoba offers a tax credit of 40 percent of the cost of fertility treatments provided by a Manitoba licensed medical practitioner or infertility treatment clinic, including medication costs. There’s no limit on the number of treatments you can claim, however you can only claim $20,000 in annual eligible costs for a maximum yearly fertility treatment tax credit of $8,000. More information on eligibility and how to access this tax credit can be found
here
New Brunswick
Those living in New Brunswick receive a one-time grant to claim 50 percent of incurred costs related to IVF, capped at a maximum of $5,000.
Quebec

As of November 2021, Quebec offers one free IVF treatment cycle for single women, women in heterosexual relationships, and same-sex couples. To be eligible, people must have a medical note stating that they can’t conceive as a couple or on their own and must be between 18 and 41 years old.
Prince Edward Island
Those living in P.E.I receive $5,000 - $10,000 annually for fertility treatment coverage when seeking care in out of province clinics. This can be accessed for up to three 12-month terms and an
application
needs to be made to the department of health.
The remaining provinces and territories have no coverage.
Out-of-pocket costs

The average out of pocket cost for an IVF cycle is between $7,750 – 12,250 CAD with medication costing anywhere from an additional $2,500 to $7,000+. Costs also vary between clinics so requesting this information early on can be useful for comparing clinics.
Medical expense tax credits (METC)

You may be able to claim expenses relating to fertility treatments on your personal income taxes as a medical expense tax credit. You can submit medical expenses from IVF under the Medical Expense Tax Credit (METC) through your income tax and can claim for costs you’ve paid yourself, for your spouse, common law partner, or anyone marked as a dependent on your income tax return.
More information about who’s eligible to claim the
medical expense tax credit
, expenses that qualify for the credit, and specific requirements for claiming the credit can be found at the
Canada Revenue Agency website
. Some private insurances may cover parts of the cost of IVF treatment and/or medications and it’s always recommended to contact your insurer directly.
What can impact the costs?

The number of cycles required. IVF isn’t always successful after the first cycle, which is why clinics quote their “cumulative success rate”, i.e. their results from one fresh IVF cycle and subsequent frozen embryo transfer (FET) cycles. Any subsequent FET cycle will incur additional costs ranging from $1,900 to $4,500 CAD and varies from clinic to clinic.
Storage costs for any surplus eggs/embryos you store for future use. This can cost approximately $300+ per year.
Medication dose and brand (generic v non-generic), ranging from $2,500 - $7,000 per cycle.
Genetic testing of embryos (PGT-A and PGT-M). The added cost of a PGT cycle can range from $3,000 – $7,000+ in addition to a standard IVF + ICSI cycle.
How to find a high quality fertility clinic

The process of finding the right clinic can feel overwhelming. Between factors like success rates and reviews and location, there’s a lot to consider. Canada has 37 fertility clinics across the country; choosing a clinic with comparable or above national average success rates is a good starting point. Thirty-six out of 37 IVF clinics in Canada report their data to the
Canadian Assisted Reproductive Technologies Register

(CARTR), providing a benchmark to compare individual clinics to. When you think about a clinic’s success rates, compare the clinic’s results to the national average found on this registry. Here are a few key rates to focus on.
Cumulative live birth rate

This rate is arguably the most important rate to focus on and refers to the birth rate resulting from all of the eggs collected in one IVF cycle. Translation? The live birth rate after a fresh IVF cycle, including live births from any associated frozen embryos from that cycle within one year. This information provides those contemplating IVF with a better understanding of their chances of delivering a child when undertaking one egg retrieval procedure.
The Canadian National Average IVF Live Birth Rate (Cumulative) is 39.9% for women <38 years of age (2013-2019).
REPLACEWITHASSET
Clinical pregnancy rate

Another important measure of success in an IVF cycle is clinical pregnancy rate after one embryo transfer cycle. This refers to a pregnancy that reaches the point it can be seen on ultrasound (i.e. 6-7 weeks gestational age and beyond). Clinical pregnancy rate is the number of gestational sacs seen on ultrasound divided by the number of embryos transferred.
The Canadian National Average IVF Clinical Pregnancy Rate (Fresh IVF) is 32.3% for women <38 years of age (2020).
REPLACEWITHASSET
Cumulative clinical pregnancy rate

This refers to the pregnancy rate resulting from all of the eggs collected in one IVF cycle. This is defined as the clinical pregnancy rate after a fresh IVF cycle, including clinical pregnancies from any associated frozen embryos from that cycle within one year.
The Canadian National Average IVF Clinical Pregnancy Rate (Cumulative) is 52.2% for women <38 years of age (2013-2020).
REPLACEWITHASSET
Multiple birth rate

Another important rate to consider is the multiple birth rate. The national average for 2020 was 5.9% indicating Canada’s focus on promoting single embryo transfer practices. Twin pregnancies are much higher risk for both mother and baby, and babies born prematurely are at greater risk for serious short term and long-term health problems. Look for clinics with a multiple pregnancy rate of less than 10%.
Other important things to consider:
Responsive staff
You shouldn’t feel rushed. You should be able to ask all of your questions and get helpful answers in return.
Excellent reviews
Other patients should seem highly satisfied with the quality of the staff and services provided.
High-quality laboratory

The quality of the IVF lab is instrumental in ensuring the best possible embryos are created and the best possible outcome is achieved. What happens in the lab between your egg collection and embryo transfer could determine whether you deliver a healthy baby. Even if your embryos were top quality, a substandard lab has the capacity to negatively impact embryos growth and ultimately jeopardize your treatment outcome. This is why it’s important to ask for your IVF lab’s Performance Indicators (PI’s). Ask your clinic what their PIs are and compare them to those of other clinics in your area.
If these numbers are not readily available, they should be provided when asked for. The ranges here are what you’d expect to see in a high quality laboratory.
Number of eggs collected: 80-95% of follicles
Number of mature eggs: 75-90% of eggs collected
Normal fertilization: 75-80% of eggs
Number of fertilized eggs that cleave (divide): 96-99%
Number of embryos that become blastocysts: 40-60%
Implantation rate (blastocyst): 35-60%REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

A great IVF lab can potentially double your chances of bringing home a baby. If you need help choosing a fertility clinic, Maven can support you by building a list of high quality fertility clinics in your area, including information on the clinic’s success rates (if available).

As a Maven member located in Canada, you get access to exclusive perks at Canada’s leading fertility clinics. We’ve carefully selected a network of fertility clinics based on their high clinical quality standards, strong success rates, and patient satisfaction. The clinic network we have partnered with offers a full range of fertility services for both couples and individuals, including IUI, IVF, egg freezing, and more. There are ten fertility clinics across Canada that offer Maven members exclusive perks like discounts on fertility services and complementary egg/embryo storage for the first year. You can message your Care Advocate  to learn more about this partnership, and get connected with a Maven partner fertility clinic.
No matter what questions you have or type of support you need on your fertility journey, Maven has your back.
Check out our
“Guide to Maven’s Fertility Providers”
to see the provider types available to you, and common topics they can help you with.
Resources
Fertility Matters Canada (FMC)
: Fertility Matters Canada (FMC) is a national organization that provides support, awareness, information and education around reproductive health, and promotes equal access to fertility treatments.
Find support groups by province
here
Sources
Assisted Human Reproduction Act
American Society for Reproductive Medicine ASRM
Canadian Fertility and Andrology Society 2018 Success Rates
Government of Canada
JOGC Article (Age related fertility decline)
Canadian Fertility and Andrology Society Press Release
JOGC Article (OHSS)
WHO 6th Edition Lab Manual for the Examination and Processing of Human Semen
WHO IUI: Review and Systematic Assessment of the Evidence that Supports Global Recommendations

title.en-US: An in-depth guide to fertility treatments in Ireland

content.value: If you’ve been wading through a sea of fertility treatment information that leaves you feeling more confused than confident, Maven has your back. Our fertility guide explains all the basics in one place, including the most common fertility treatments, average costs, and what to expect while going through treatment in Ireland. Read on for clarity and the start of a better fertility journey.
Fast facts
1 in 6
Heterosexual couples in the Ireland experience infertility.
In Ireland, infertility is attributed to 30% male factor, 30% female factor, 30% a combination of factors or 10% unknown reasons.

Average cost for IVF treatment (per cycle, excluding medications). Medication costs vary depending on the type of drug prescribed but is generally capped at €80 per treatment cycle when using the Drug Payment Scheme. When adding procedures such as intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and frozen embryo transfer cycles (FETs), the cost may be closer to between €7,000 - €11,000 per IVF cycle.
Who might need fertility treatment?

There are lots of reasons people need help conceiving, and the best treatment option for each person and couple depends largely on the cause of infertility. In other cases, same sex couple require a sperm or egg donor and assisted reproductive technology to start their family. So what are some of the most common causes of infertility and who’s a good candidate for fertility treatment?
Common causes of infertility
According Ireland’s Health Service Executive (HSE), the main causes of infertility in Ireland are:
Damaged or blocked fallopian tubes
Conditions affecting the womb - these include large fibroids or large polyps in the womb (benign growths)
Endometriosis
Ovulation disorders
Polycystic ovarian syndrome
Early menopause
Sexually transmitted infections (STI’s)
What to expect at your initial consultation

Once you’ve made the decision to explore or undergo fertility treatments, you’ll start with an initial consultation. Your clinical team will evaluate your fertility and medical history*—*this is a key part of determining next steps. After your initial consultation, you’ll likely be asked to complete a number of tests. Once the results of the tests are in and reviewed by your doctor, your clinical team will discuss their recommended approach. If a treatment like IUI or IVF (intrauterine insemination or in-vitro fertilization) is required, your doctor will explain the process step by step.
Common tests

For female patients, a vaginal ultrasound is one of the most important diagnostic tests to assess fertility. It will give your doctor a close look at your uterus and ovaries so they can identify any problems, and look at antral follicle count (AFC). The AFC measures the number of premature follicles (resting eggs) in the ovaries, allowing your doctor to assess your egg reserve. Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is another marker of egg reserve that your doctor will measure. Your clinical team will use the AFC and AMH results to decide what type of protocol you need, and to anticipate how you’ll respond to the medications they prescribe.

If the ultrasound suggests possible blockage of the fallopian tubes, you’ll be referred for a test called an HyCoSy or an X-ray (HSG). Chlamydia testing is usually performed too, as chlamydia can negatively affect your reproductive system. Additional tests that may be ordered include progesterone, follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinising hormone (LH), thyroid function, polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) profile, and miscarriage or genetic screening, if clinically indicated.

For heterosexual or same-sex male couples seeking fertility treatment, a basic semen analysis (SA) will also be done to look at sperm criteria including semen volume, sperm count, morphology (shape) and motility. Semen analysis is performed on an ejaculated sample and evaluated based on standards created by the World Health Organisation (WHO).

Sperm “quality” refers to the sperm’s ability to fertilise an egg, and sperm DNA integrity is very important for normal fertilisation and embryo development. “Good” quality sperm is functional, can achieve fertilisation and has the correct genetics. Assessments of sperm quality shouldn’t serve to define a male as fertile or infertile, but rather to determine further evaluation and treatments.
Sperm motility:
Sperm should be moving forward, not in tight circles or along erratic paths. Low motility is also called asthenozoospermia.
Sperm morphology:
A morphologically normal sperm should have a:
Long tail
made of protein fibers which helps it “swim” to the egg
Mid-piece
that contains mitochondria to power the sperm’s movement
Nicely shaped head
that stores genetic information and helps the sperm get into the egg. Abnormal morphology is also called teratozoospermia.
Total sperm count:

This refers to the total number of sperm within the ejaculate. A high sperm count isn’t helpful if most sperm have abnormal morphology or can’t swim properly. Similarly, sperm with great morphology may carry abnormal DNA.
Sperm concentration:

The total number of sperm per millilitre (ml) of ejaculate. Low sperm concentration is also called oligospermia. If very few sperm are seen after a special preparation, it’s classified as cryptozoospermia. If no sperm are seen, this is called azoospermia.
Some important points:
Sperm are continuously produced and take 76 days to mature, so the effect of lifestyle improvements made today could be seen in 2-3 months
Sperm counts fluctuate, so it’s crucial that 2 or more samples are tested over time to ensure consistency
Seasonal variations in sperm parameters have been reported, with highest counts in late winter/early spring and lowest in late summer
Abstinence length impacts quality; it’s recommended to abstain from ejaculation for 2-5 days before semen analysis
Routine SA’s can’t measure DNA integrity REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Sperm DNA fragmentation is an additional test that may be performed to look for fragmentation or “damage” to the genetic material inside the sperm head. DNA integrity of the sperm is important as half of the genetic material required to make a baby comes from the sperm and the other half comes from the egg. DNA damage to either the egg or sperm affects fertility.
Treatment options
Intrauterine insemination

Intrauterine insemination (IUI) involves injecting sperm directly into a woman's uterus to bypass the cervix, reducing the distance sperm has to travel to meet the egg and increasing the chances of pregnancy.

The success rates of IUI vary and generally fall between 15-20% per cycle depending on factors like age and underlying fertility challenges. Based on the most recent review of research, the WHO recommends that at least three consecutive IUI cycles should be performed in couples with an indication for IUI, though doing four to six cycles is generally recommended before considering alternative treatments such as IVF. There is no official recommendation on the maximum number of IUI treatment cycles people should pursue. It’s a decision you’ll need to make with your treatment team.
There are two options when it comes to IUI cycles: stimulated or natural.
Stimulated IUI

Your doctor will prescribe hormonal medications to help grow more than one follicle in your ovaries and increase the chances of ovulation. These may be oral medications such as Clomiphene Citrate (Clomid), Letrozole tablets or hormonal injections known as Gonadotropins. These hormonal injections are typically self-administered at home.

Stimulated IUI cycles usually require 4 to 6 clinic visits per treatment cycle so your doctor can closely monitor the growth of your follicles. The first visit is typically on day 2-3 of your menstrual cycle (to rule out any ovarian cysts), again on day 6 and more regularly depending on your response to the medication. During each visit, a pelvic ultrasound is performed to measure the size of the follicles and the thickness of the endometrial lining. After approximately 10-12 days of medication and once the lead follicle is large enough, a HCG "trigger" shot is given to start ovulation. The IUI is then scheduled approximately 24-40 hours later.
Natural IUI

In a natural IUI cycle, no medication will be given. Your doctor will track the growth of the dominant follicle (egg) in your ovary by transvaginal ultrasound and when it’s big enough, they’ll wait for the natural ovulation process to occur. This will be detected by a blood or urine test. The IUI will then be scheduled the next day. In couples with unexplained infertility, it’s not recommended to try natural IUI.
The cost of an IUI cycle can range from €400-800.
In-vitro fertilization

While intrauterine insemination is a cost-effective, noninvasive first-line therapy for certain patients (same-sex female couples, those with functioning fallopian tubes, cervical issues, anovulation, moderate male factor and unexplained infertility), it has limited success in patients with endometriosis, severe male factor infertility, tubal factor infertility and advanced maternal age (female over 35 years old). After several rounds of unsuccessful IUI treatment or if the causes of infertility aren’t suitable for IUI, in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) may be recommended.

IVF is a technique where a woman’s eggs and a man’s sperm are combined in a laboratory in order to create an embryo(s). Depending on the diagnosis and age of the woman, an embryo or, in some cases, embryos, are transferred to the woman’s uterus through her cervix to increase the chances of pregnancy. IVF is used for heterosexual couples experiencing a range of infertility causes, same sex couples and for single women pursuing parenthood. So, what does it involve?
Step 1. Superovulation to boost egg production

Superovulation is a stimulation process to boost egg production. The process begins with self-injection of drugs containing Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH), which causes egg growth in your ovaries. The more eggs produced, the higher chances of successful fertilisation later in the treatment. |

You’ll also receive blood tests and transvaginal ultrasounds regularly to monitor your hormone levels and check on your ovaries. You might experience bruising, tenderness, or pain at the injection sites. Hormonal medication might also cause emotional changes like mood swings, restlessness, irritability, or generally feeling down, as well as nausea, bloating, fatigue, and possible hot flashes.
Step 2. Egg retrieval

A day or two before your eggs are scheduled to be retrieved, you’ll self-administer a hormone injection that will help the eggs mature more quickly, known as a trigger shot. Roughly 36 hours later, you’ll undergo a minor outpatient surgical procedure called follicular aspiration to extract mature eggs. Most egg collection procedures are performed under conscious intravenous sedation, meaning you’ll be conscious with reduced pain sensitivity. You’ll likely experience some mild to moderate abdominal cramping and/or pelvic pain following the procedure, but this pain is usually mild enough to be treated with over-the-counter pain medicine and disappears within a day or two after the procedure.
Step 3. Sperm production from partner or donor

During the egg retrieval process, the patient's partner will provide a sperm sample or a sample from donated sperm will be thawed. The sperm are then sorted through a high-speed wash and spin cycle to find the healthiest ones. Normally men will produce a fresh ejaculated sperm sample on the day of egg collection to fertilise the eggs, however some men may need to freeze sperm in advance of the egg collection to ensure sperm is available on the day of fertilisation. This occurs when men have reduced sperm volume or quality or may have performance anxiety about producing a sample on the day of the procedure.
Step 4. Fertilisation of eggs

About an hour or so after the eggs have been retrieved and after the sperm has been prepared and assessed, sperm and egg are combined in a process known as insemination. Insemination involves placing a fixed amount of sperm around each egg in a petri dish in an incubator. It typically takes a few hours for a sperm to fertilise an egg. Your clinical team will check to see if fertilisation occurred the following day.

If the sperm don’t meet the criteria for traditional insemination, then a technique called intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) is performed. The key difference between routine IVF and ICSI is the way the sperm enters the egg. With ICSI, an embryologist will select the “best” sperm and inject each one directly into each mature egg. ICSI is suggested for the majority of patients, not because they need it, but due to higher fertilisation rates. The trend for this is so great that in some countries almost 100% of patients are only offered ICSI, despite many studies showing that patients with advanced maternal age, low egg numbers and unexplained infertility can have success with routine IVF. Interestingly, pregnancy rates after traditional insemination and after ICSI are very similar.
Step 5. Blastocyst culture

Embryos (fertilised eggs) are grown in a special incubator that monitors the development of each individual embryo. The embryos are assessed the morning after the egg collection to confirm fertilisation into a 2-cell embryo. The embryos, if normally fertilised, should go on to become rapidly expanding balls of cells called blastocysts. Blastocysts are formed by day 5 or 6 of their development. The outer layer of the embryo goes on to become the placenta and the inner cell mass goes on to form the baby. It’s common practice in IVF clinics to extend embryo culture for 5 days until the embryos reach the blastocyst stage.
Embryo development and grading

You may have heard about embryo grading, where an embryologist makes an educated guess about an embryo’s potential based on certain characteristics like the number and size of cells and how quickly certain stages of development are reached. What does the grade of your embryo tell you about the chances of becoming pregnant? The honest answer is: not much. All embryo grading systems are subjective. A high grade doesn’t guarantee that an embryo will successfully implant and carry to term. Many embryos with “poor” grades will become healthy babies, while others graded as top quality will not. In some cases the reason for this will be genetic, which is something that cannot be assessed just by looking at the embryo. Preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) is the only way to assess embryo genetics.
Key milestones to focus on after your egg collection are:
By 16-18 hours post egg collection, fertilisation into a zygote should occur. If an embryo has not reached 2 cells within 24 hours, the process will be stopped.
By 48 hours (“day 2”), the embryos should be at least at the 2 to 4 cell stage.
By 72 hours (“day 3”), the embryos should have about 8-10 cells, also known as cleavage stage.
By ”day 5”, the embryos should reach 120 cells, also known as the blastocyst stage.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Connect with a
Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist
to understand more about IVF versus ICSI and about embryo development.
Step 6. Embryo transfer
Reaching embryo transfer day is a huge milestone. There are two types of embryo transfers to know about: Fresh and frozen.
Fresh embryo transfer

Once your eggs are collected, you’ll be prescribed progesterone-based medications that prepare the lining of your uterus to receive the embryo(s) that will be transferred back. In a fresh embryo transfer cycle, the embryo transfer is done 3-5 days after your egg collection.

Current recommendations are to transfer a single embryo back into the uterus as opposed to two, to reduce the chance of a twin pregnancy. The embryo transfer is done while you’re awake, under ultrasound guidance using a very narrow catheter. It’s pain-free but a full bladder is required prior to the procedure to help with positioning of the uterus and to allow the smooth transfer of the catheter inside. Some people find this slightly uncomfortable, but manageable. (You can empty your bladder right away after the embryo transfer.) The progesterone medication will be continued until the first beta hCG pregnancy test is done, about 2 weeks later. If your cycle resulted in more than one viable embryo, they can be frozen for use in future FET cycles. If the pregnancy test is positive, the progesterone support is usually continued until the end of the first trimester.
Frozen embryo transfer (FET)

During a frozen embryo transfer cycle (FET), you’ll be given medications to build the endometrial thickness of your uterus to increase the odds that an embryo will implant. Since an FET cycle uses an embryo that’s already been created, you won’t need to undergo egg retrieval. There are a few ways to prep for a FET cycle:
Natural cycle:
A natural cycle follows the body’s dominant follicle where the mature follicle produces oestrogen and leads to the thickening of the endometrial lining.
Modified natural cycle:

This cycle is similar to a natural cycle except that an injection of hCG is given to trigger ovulation. You’ll use progesterone pessaries/injectables/oral tablets to prep your uterus for implantation.
Stimulated cycle:
In a stimulated cycle, ovulation is induced with medications (clomid, letrozole or gonadotropins).
Programmed cycle:

Estrogen and progesterone medications are given to prep your uterus and the ovary is suppressed, so ovulation does not occur. The embryo transfer is planned a set number of days after progesterone support starts, usually for 3-6 days later. Estrogen and progesterone are continued and a pregnancy test is done 9-14 days after the transfer. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

There are a number of reasons why you might undergo a FET rather than a fresh transfer. For example, if you’re using embryos created from a previous treatment cycle, they’ll be transferred from frozen. Or, if your endometrial lining doesn’t reach desired thickness for a fresh transfer, your doctor may decide to postpone the embryo transfer, and you’ll need to do a FET transfer in the future instead.

Another common reason to do FET is when PGT-A genetic testing is being performed on the embryos to rule out chromosomal abnormalities. This process involves taking several cells from the outer layer of the fresh embryos then freezing the embryos while awaiting the results of the genetic test. Once the results are received and if a genetically normal embryo has been identified, a FET cycle will be planned.

If you’re at risk for Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS), your doctor may also decide to freeze all of your embryos for future use. Transferring an embryo back into the uterus while you’re at risk of OHSS is not recommended*—* if you became pregnant, the resulting increasing hCG levels would make OHSS worse. This can be potentially life threatening.
Frozen embryo transfer cycles offer:
Reduced risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
Optimization of endometrial receptivity
Time for PGT testing
Prioritisation of embryos for single embryo transfer (SET)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Pregnancy rates after FET have significantly increased over the years mainly due to advances in embryo freezing. This has led to many clinics encouraging elective “freeze-all”: freezing
all
suitable embryos for future use. A large 2020 review however, showed that there is no significant difference between birth rates in fresh ETs versus FETs for most patients.
So, who should consider freeze-all? Your physician may recommend it if any of the below apply to you:
You’re at risk of Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
You have high progesterone on trigger day
You want to do PGT-A genetic testing
You have slow growth embryos
You have uterine abnormalities
Side effects of IVF
Side effects of IVF medication may include:
Nausea
Mood swings
Bloating
Fatigue
Bruising at the injection site
Vaginal discharge
Pelvic pain or abdominal pain
Are there any risks?

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a possible complication of IVF where the ovaries swell and fluid leaks into the body. The condition is more common in women with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). After gonadotropin stimulation for IVF, the reported rate of moderate OHSS is 3% to 6%, and for severe OHSS it’s 0.1% to 2%. A milder form of OHSS occurs in about 20% to 33% of IVF cycles but isn’t a cause for concern. With close monitoring and the use of lower doses of gonadotropins to trigger ovulation, the risk of severe OHSS can be greatly reduced. (The risk of developing OHSS during medicated IUI cycles is much lower because the medication doses are lower.)
Are there any restrictions on who can access treatment in Ireland?

There are no restrictions to accessing fertility treatments in Ireland and the number of LGBTQIA+ and single people becoming parents is increasing. Altruistic surrogacy and third party reproductive treatments such as egg, sperm and embryo donation are available throughout the country. Non-anonymous or “known” sperm donation is legally required within Ireland and all children born through donation are registered on the National Donor-Conceived Person Register and have access to identifying information about their donor once they turn 18. Genetic testing for sex selection is prohibited unless there is an x-linked genetic condition in the family.
LGBTQIA+ family building
Same-sex female couples

Same-sex female couples can build their families using donor sperm and IUI or IVF treatment at a fertility clinic. Shared Motherhood or Reciprocal Donation is becoming more common, where eggs from one partner are used in an IVF cycle (using donor sperm) to create embryos that are then transferred into the other partner’s uterus. This allows one partner to be the birth mother and the other partner to be the genetic mother. Since 2020, the Irish state recognises same-sex female couples as parents on birth certificates. There are two different scenarios for this, depending on when a donor-conceived child was conceived.

For children conceived after the 4th of May 2020: The Donor Assisted Human Reproduction (DAHR) procedure must have been undertaken in a DAHR facility in Ireland using a traceable sperm donor. Both parents can be registered in these cases through the Registrar with a certificate from the clinic.

For children conceived prior to the 4th of May 2020: The DAHR procedure may have been undertaken in a DAHR facility in Ireland or abroad using an anonymous or traceable sperm donor. However, in these cases a Declaration of Parentage is required from the Court, to enable both parents to be registered on the child’s birth certificate at re-registration.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Same-sex male couples

For same-sex male couples wishing to start their family through assisted reproductive technology, surrogacy is the main treatment option. It’s very complex in Ireland though, because the law says that once a child is born, the surrogate is considered the legal parent. Currently, there is no process for surrogate parents to easily transfer parental rights to the intended parents. The genetic father can apply for a declaration of parentage to the Circuit Court as well as apply for guardianship. The intending mother can then apply for parentage after 2 years which, if approved, expires when the child turns 18. This makes it difficult for people in Ireland to access surrogates domestically, forcing many to go abroad.
Trans and non-binary people

Trans and non-binary people seeking fertility treatment can initially access information on fertility preservation and their family forming options through their GP. The process of treatment involves first being diagnosed by a GP and referred to see a specialist, e.g. a gender identity psychiatrist. If necessary, they will refer to a gender identity clinic, where a “full assessment” will be provided that could take 3 months. This assessment is necessary to receive any further treatment (hormone therapy) and fertility preservation (egg/sperm freezing) if recommended.
How much does IVF cost in Ireland?

As anyone who has undergone fertility treatments will tell you, the emotional and physical challenges can be immense. And the financial toll can be, too. Ireland is the only EU country that doesn’t offer state funding for assisted reproduction.
Out-of-pocket costs

The average out of pocket cost for an IVF cycle is between €5,000 - €10,000 with medication costs capped at €124 under the Drugs Payment Scheme (DPS). Costs also vary between clinics so requesting this information early on can be useful for comparing clinics.
Insurance coverage

Generally, only the most expensive private health insurance packages offer broad coverage for infertility treatment. Most Irish health insurance companies have added fertility benefits to a number of private health insurance plans however they will only cover a small portion of the costs associated with fertility treatment. VHI, Irish Life Healthcare and Laya Healthcare introduced fertility benefits on a selection of their plans with coverage ranging from a €1000 lifetime max up to 50pc cover for IVF, IUI and ICSI, up to a maximum of €2,000.
What can impact the costs?

The number of cycles required. IVF isn’t always successful after the first cycle, which is why clinics quote their “cumulative success rate”, i.e. their results from one fresh IVF cycle and subsequent FET cycles. Any subsequent FET cycle will incur additional costs of approximately €1450 per cycle and varies from clinic to clinic.
ICSI can cost an additional €400-500 per cycle.
Storage costs for any surplus eggs/embryos you store for future use. This can cost approximately €300 per year.
Most fertility medications are covered under the Drug Payment Scheme however prescribed supplements are not covered.

Genetic testing of embryos. The total cost of an IVF cycle with PGT-A (biopsy of up to 4 embryos) can be approximately €8,900. The price varies depending on the number of embryos requiring genetic testing. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
How can you save money?
Claiming tax back

Tax relief can be claimed on any fees relating to IVF treatment through the tax relief for medical expenses scheme. The tax relief is given at a rate of 20%. Only expenses not already claimed for elsewhere, i.e. through your insurance policy or another public or local authority, are eligible. You can find a guide to claiming your tab rebate
here
The Drug Payment Scheme

Fertility medications are expensive, but under the Drugs Payment Scheme (DPS) an individual or family will pay no more than €80 per treatment cycle. Anyone who is 'ordinarily resident' in the Republic of Ireland can apply. 'Ordinarily resident' means that you’re living in Ireland and intend to live there for at least one year. There is no means test for a DPS card. You can apply for your DPS card using the application form
here
Maven Partner Clinic Perks

As a Maven member located in Ireland, you get access to exclusive perks at SIMS IVF, Ireland. We’ve carefully selected SIMS IVF as our fertility clinic partner based on their high clinical quality standards, strong success rates, and patient satisfaction. SIMS IVF offers a variety of fertility services for couples and individuals, including IUI, IVF, egg freezing, and more. The clinics throughout Ireland offer Maven members exclusive perks like discounts on fertility services and complementary egg/embryo storage for the first year.
Regional Fertility Hubs

In late 2019 the Department of Health and HSEs National Women & Infants Health Programme announced a plan to publicly fund infertility services. So far, six Regional Fertility Hubs have been established throughout Ireland, one in each of the country’s six maternity networks. Four Hubs are currently in operation and accepting GP referrals; The Coombe Hospital Fertility Service, The National Maternity Hospital “Holles Street”, The Rotunda Hospital Fertility Service and Cork University Maternity Hospital. The Hub process was set up to allow GPs to refer patients for initial fertility work-ups, such as diagnostic ultrasound scanning, Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS), blood testing (AMH, TFT’s, Rubella) and semen analysis testing. Once performed, a patient is then referred to the public clinic. These Hubs can offer follicle tracking and ovulation induction (OI cycles)but there is currently no public funding in place for patients requiring IUI, IVF or ICSI cycles. Patients who need these services will be referred over to a private fertility clinic for treatment.
How to find a high quality fertility clinic
Finding the right clinic can feel overwhelming. Between factors like success rates, reviews and location, there’s a lot to consider.
In Ireland, fertility clinics are regulated and monitored by the
Health Products Regulatory Authority

(HPRA) but there is no regulatory body that specifically oversees the fertility industry. Each clinic self-reports their results using different criteria, making it hard for patients to compare “like-for-like” rates between different clinics. The most reliable results come from International bodies such as The European Society for Human Reproduction and Embryology (ESHRE) and The International Committee for Monitoring Assisted Reproductive Technologies (ICMART). Some, but not all, Irish clinics contribute to this data.
National average success rates

The success rates below are reported by the European IVF-Monitoring Consortium from clinics in Ireland. Clinics are not required to report their success rates and so not all clinics do. The latest data from 2018 represents success rates from fresh, non-donor IVF cycles from participating clinics.
Clinical pregnancy rate per egg collection

The clinical pregnancy rate (i.e. the number of pregnancies confirmed by ultrasound) per egg collection looks at the pregnancy rate relative to all the IVF cycles that follow one egg collection. Some clinics report results per embryo transfer rather than per egg collection, which removes results for cycles that may not have reached egg collection or never made it to an embryo transfer, and therefore those results will be higher.
*This rate does not include any subsequent embryo transfer (FET) cycles.
The clinical pregnancy rate per egg collection is 13.9% for women 35 to 39 years of age.
REPLACEWITHASSET
Live birth per egg collection

The live birth rate is the “take home baby” rate and is the ultimate measure of success. It looks at the number of females who deliver a baby after going through one full IVF cycle with a fresh embryo transfer..
*This rate does not include any subsequent embryo transfer (FET) cycles.
The live birth per egg collection rate is 11.9% for women between 35 to 39 years of age.
REPLACEWITHASSET
Multiple birth rate

The multiple birth rate is also important to know. For some people, having twins may seem like a wonderful thing, but multiple pregnancies are less safe for mother and babies. Look for clinics with a multiple pregnancy rate of less than 10%.
REPLACEWITHASSET
Other important things to consider:
Responsive staff
You shouldn’t feel rushed. You should be able to ask all of your questions and get helpful answers in return.
Excellent reviews
Other patients should seem highly satisfied with the quality of the staff and services provided.
High-quality laboratory

The quality of the IVF lab is instrumental in ensuring the best possible embryos are created and the best possible outcome is achieved. What happens in the lab between your egg collection and embryo transfer could determine whether you deliver a healthy baby. Even if your embryos were top quality, a substandard lab has the capacity to negatively impact embryos growth and ultimately jeopardize your treatment outcome. This is why it’s important to ask for your IVF lab’s Performance Indicators (PI’s). Ask your clinic what their PIs are and compare them to those of other clinics in your area.

In 2017, the European Society for Human Reproduction and Embryology (ESHRE) and Alpha Scientists in Reproductive Medicine, an expert panel of fertility specialists, created goal PIs for IVF labs. If these numbers are not readily available from your clinic, they should be provided when asked for:
Number of eggs collected: 80-95% of follicles
Number of mature eggs: 75-90% of eggs collected
Normal fertilisation: 75-80% of eggs
Number of fertilised eggs that cleave (divide): 96-99%
Number of embryos that become blastocysts: 40-60%
Implantation rate (blastocyst): 35-60%REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

A great IVF lab can make a big difference in your chances of bringing home a baby. If you need help choosing a fertility clinic, Maven can support you by building a list of high quality fertility clinics in your area, including information on the clinic’s success rates (if available). Remember, Maven is here to support you at every step of your fertility journey. Reach out to your Care Advocate  for help today.

As a Maven member located in Ireland, you get access to exclusive perks at Ireland’s leading fertility clinic, Sims IVF. We’ve carefully selected Sims IVF based on their high clinical quality standards, strong success rates, and patient satisfaction. Sims IVF offers a full range of fertility services for both couples and individuals, including IUI, IVF, egg freezing and more. Their locations in Clonskeagh, Swords, Cork, Carlow, Dundalk, and Limerick offer Maven members exclusive perks like a free Advanced Fertility Package and discounts on IVF, ICSI and egg freezing. You can message your Care Advocate  to learn more about this partnership, and get connected with a Maven partner fertility clinic in Ireland.
Resources
The National Infertility Support and Network Group (NISIG)

NISIG offers support meetings and facilitated peer-to-peer support for people experiencing infertility issues. They also offer phone support and have a LiveChat line on Monday & Thursday from 7pm to 9:30pm.
LGBT Ireland

LGBT Ireland is a National organisation providing support, training and advocacy which aims to improve the lives of LGBT+ people across Ireland. The National LGBT Helpline - Lo-Call 1890 929 539 or chat online at
lgbt.ie
Sources

ESHRE Special Interest Group of Embryology and Alpha Scientists in Reproductive Medicine, The Vienna consensus: report of an expert meeting on the development of ART laboratory performance indicators. Reprod BioMed Online
Joint Commission on International Surrogacy Debate: Oireachtas 2022
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines
Parts 2 & 3 of the Children and Family Relationships Act, 2015 (CFRA)
The Health Service Executive (HSE) Website
WHO 6th Edition Lab Manual for the Examination and Processing of Human Semen
WHO IUI: Review and Systematic Assessment of the Evidence that Supports Global Recommendations

items.header: When should I get my fertility evaluated?

content.value: KG: “We usually see patients who have not been able to conceive in the following situations:
After 1 year of consistent, unprotected intercourse if the female partner is under 35 years of age.
After 6 months of consistent, unprotected intercourse if the female partner is 35 years of age or above.

Sooner if the female partner has an irregular menstrual cycle or known risk factors for infertility, including: endometriosis, a history of pelvic inflammatory disease, or a history of reproductive tract malformations.
Or the male partner has a history of risk factors (chemotherapy, chronic medical illness, trouble conceiving in a prior relationship).
Same sex couples, as soon as they want to start trying with donated sperm or reciprocal IVF.

items.header: Is age really a factor in fertility?

content.value: KG: “Yes. Female age is the biggest predictor of fertility. Females are born with all of the eggs they will ever have. Their number of eggs declines over time because every month only one egg ovulates, and the others die off. The quality of the eggs also declines with age.
