As the energy in our bodies decreases, the egg cell energy decreases, making it harder for the egg cell to divide correctly as we age. This makes it more difficult to become pregnant and increases the risk of miscarriage, as well as the risk of trisomy-21 (Down syndrome).

Men, on the other hand, make new sperm every day, so the quantity doesn’t decrease over time. The lifecycle of a sperm cell is about 90 days from beginning of growth to ejaculation. So, the sperm cell is about 90 days old versus the female egg cell which could be 20, 30, or 40+ years old. The sperm cell can still divide incorrectly but that chance is sporadic, and it does not increase with male age.

items.header: Does taking the pill impact how long it will take to become pregnant?

content.value: KG: “Not usually. If you stop taking birth control pills, it should be out of your system within a few weeks. Some people may be able to get pregnant within the same month of stopping birth control pills. Others may take a bit longer if their bodies are more sensitive. But it should leave your system pretty soon and there’s no reason to wait to try to conceive after stopping the pill.”

items.header: Do you recommend eating a certain diet or avoiding certain foods (ie: dairy, gluten, sugar) while trying to conceive?

content.value: KG: “While trying to conceive or undergoing fertility treatment I generally recommend a diet that’s clean, low in processed foods and high in whole foods, more plant-based than animal-based, more organic than not. I also recommend diets high in omega-3 fatty acids (things like salmon, avocado, walnuts, flax seeds, etc.). But I don’t recommend avoiding certain foods per se. Gluten, sugar, and processed foods are probably not great in general but people going through fertility treatment are already stressed, so I don’t like to exacerbate their stress with a highly restrictive diet. I just generally recommend healthy eating.”

items.header: Are there any supplements you recommend to help increase fertility?

content.value: KG: “It’s always best to get nutrients from your diet rather than supplements. But I don’t see the harm in taking certain supplements that may benefit your fertility, if you don’t experience any side effects like gastrointestinal issues.

The most important nutrient for females undergoing fertility treatment or trying to conceive is folic acid because it supports the formation of the baby's neural tube. By the time you take a pregnancy test, the neural tube is already formed so folic acid is important in advance. I recommend taking up to 4 mg of folic acid a day for all female patients regardless of diet. And I recommend 1,000 mg of fish oil if they’re not eating a diet that’s high in omega-3 fatty acids.

I also recommend taking coenzyme Q10, a fat-soluble antioxidant vitamin which has been shown in female mice (not female humans, mind you) to help with pregnancy rates. Based on these studies we theorize that it’s potentially involved with energy production in the cell, and can possibly help with egg quality, to help the egg divide properly. We don’t know for sure, but I generally recommend 200 mg of coenzyme Q10 three times a day, taken with food (because it’s fat-soluble it’s better absorbed with food).

For male partners, I recommend the same three supplements (folic acid, fish oil, and coenzyme Q10) as well as 1000 mg vitamin C and 400 mg of vitamin E a day. Sperm are made in the testicles and stored in the epididymis. The longer they're stored there, the longer they’re exposed to oxidative stressors and free radicals and vitamin C and vitamin E may help combat this.”

items.header: How much does alcohol affect sperm?

content.value: KG: “If a male partner has an abnormal semen analysis, I recommend that they stop drinking alcohol, smoking tobacco or marijuana, consuming too much caffeine and that they get to a normal body mass index, as all of these things may be impacting their sperm. However, we cannot say with certainty the exact number of alcoholic beverages that are OK or not OK to consume in relation to male fertility.

Studies of patients undergoing IVF while consuming alcohol have found that generally, none is better than any as far as pregnancy rates go. But we don’t know the exact number. Within reason, we want both male and female patients to be moderate in their alcohol consumption, mostly so they don’t have the additional worry that something they’re doing is impacting their ability to conceive. For this reason, in my practice I generally recommend under 4 drinks a week.”

items.header: Any thoughts on the benefits of fertility-specific acupuncture?

content.value: KG: “According to the American Society of Reproductive Medicine, based on all of the studies that have been done on the fertility benefits of acupuncture, nothing more than a placebo effect has been found. That said, a placebo effect is still an effect. So, if acupuncture relaxes you and you enjoy it, that can only help you, especially when it comes to easing the stress of going through fertility treatment. But if you don’t enjoy it, don’t do it for the benefit of your fertility.”

items.header: How do ovarian cysts affect fertility and IVF treatment? Should they be removed before treatment?

content.value: KG: “The short answer is, it depends. The female body makes physiologic cysts (aka functional cysts) every month in the form of egg follicles, fluid-filled structures that serve a purpose in reproduction. After a follicle releases an egg, sometimes that cyst gets reabsorbed by the body and sometimes it doesn’t. If it doesn’t, it can cause problems. If you have a leftover physiologic cyst, it may not be the ideal time to start fertility treatment, but they generally go away on their own in time.

If it doesn’t go away in time, then it’s another type of cyst. But we won’t know what type unless we remove it. Most cysts are benign, but we also don’t know that unless we remove them. We would remove a cyst if there was rapid growth or certain features on ultrasound that made us think there may be a chance it is not benign, but that’s not common. If the cyst is endometriosis, we also don’t know that until we remove it.

Most of the time we leave cysts alone. If you aren’t in pain and you have a good ovarian reserve and good follicles around the cysts, we don’t touch the cysts because ovarian surgery can compromise good ovarian tissue and we don’t want to do that. If the cysts are very large and rapidly growing, you’re in pain, and/or they aren’t going away, then they may need to be removed.”

items.header: Can you help me understand how fibroids might affect fertility and IVF treatment?

content.value: KG: “Fibroids can affect pregnancy rates depending on where they are and how big they are. There are four different types of fibroids:Subserosal fibroids are on the outside of the uterus and have no impact on fertility unless they’re of a certain size or location.
Transmural (or intramuscular) fibroids

are in the muscle of the uterus, but don’t push in on the uterine cavity. If they’re more than 4cm across or larger, they’re associated with lower pregnancy rates and higher miscarriage rates. However, we don’t know that removing them will necessarily improve rates so your doctor may or may not recommend removal depending on your situation.
Submucosal fibroids

are when some of the fibroid is in the uterine cavity, and some is in the muscle. We believe this type of fibroid can decrease the chance of pregnancy and increase the risk of miscarriage, so we recommend removing them before getting pregnant or undergoing an embryo transfer if someone is doing IVF.
Intracavitary fibroids

are inside the uterine cavity, and we recommend removal prior to pregnancy or embryo transfer if someone is doing IVF because they can decrease the chance of pregnancy and increase the risk of miscarriage.

Fibroids can also impact the process of IVF treatment, depending on size and location. For example, if a fibroid blocks our ability to get to the ovaries to suction out eggs during IVF treatment, we may recommend removal beforehand. If we can get to the ovaries, but the female is older and has lower ovarian reserve, we may recommend optimizing the uterine cavity by removing fibroids prior to transferring an embryo to give them the best possible chance of becoming pregnant.”

items.header: Is there anything you can do to minimize the chance of getting ovarian cysts as a side effect from Clomid?

content.value: KG: “There’s no way to minimize the chance of getting ovarian cysts as a side effect of Clomid because the goal of Clomid is to help your body make cysts. We either use Clomid to get patients to grow a follicle, which is a cyst, or we use Clomid to increase the number of follicles/cysts that a patient grows each month. A follicle, by definition, is a cyst. It's a fluid-filled structure. Each follicle houses one egg. Clomid helps you grow a follicle (if you don’t normally ovulate) or increases the number of eggs that you ovulate if you’re already ovulating on your own.

With Clomid, instead of growing one, you may grow three, four, or five follicles/cysts. Your body is used to reabsorbing one cyst each month if you don’t become pregnant, but not four or five. It’s possible that on your next cycle, if you're not pregnant, that all of the follicles will be reabsorbed but a lot of times they aren’t. It depends on the person and your ovaries may just need more time. There is not a way of minimizing the chance of cysts with Clomid use because it is, in essence, the goal of this medication.”

items.header: How many times should you try IUI before moving to IVF?

content.value: KG: “The majority of my patients move on to IVF if they’ve had three unsuccessful rounds of IUI with Clomid but it really depends on your fertility diagnosis.

For example, if you’re a female who is under 35 and have tried for 12 months to conceive and your male partner’s total motile sperm count is low, it’s probably male factor so doing IUI may take several tries. If you have unexplained infertility, we generally start with IUI with oral medication. After three unsuccessful IUI treatments with oral medication, the pregnancy rates drop off, statistically speaking. So at that point we generally recommend moving on to IVF. Again, it will all depend on your individual diagnosis.”

items.header: What’s the total timeline for IUI treatment?

content.value: KG: “The total process for one cycle of IUI treatment is about a month long. After initial workup and consultation, the timeline for IUI treatment with a natural cycle starts from day one of your menstrual cycle. You’ll check for a positive ovulation kit result (using an at-home kit) which typically occurs around day 14 of your cycle. You would then come into the fertility clinic the day after your positive at-home ovulation kit for an insemination and then come back for a pregnancy test two weeks later. Keep in mind that if your cycle is already underway, we would have to wait until the next cycle which could add time.”

items.header: Can IUI treatment cycles be done back to back? What is the suggested time frame between cycles?

content.value: KG: “One properly timed IUI is as good as doing two back to back (as in, one day after the other), so we don’t typically do IUI treatments this close together. If two weeks after insemination you aren’t pregnant, that’s when we would consider starting a new cycle.”

items.header: What are the success rates by age for IUI?

content.value: KG: “We don't really break IUI success rates down per age because they depend on the reason why you're doing IUI. For example, if the reason is only male factor infertility, say a low total motile sperm count (where the sperm is having difficulty swimming to the egg), then doing IUI treatment on a natural cycle, without medication, would hopefully simply correct the sperm motility issue and get you back to the normal, non-treatment pregnancy success rates, which are based on the age of the female partner: females in their 20s have 20-30% success rate per try, 10-15% in their 30s, and 5% chance in their 40s.

If patients have unexplained infertility, the largest prospective study (of women ages 28 to 42, with a mean age of 34) showed that the chance of pregnancy without treatment or medication is about a 3% per attempt. With oral medication and IUI, the pregnancy rate increases to about 7%. After three attempts of IUI, this 7% success rate decreases. So, I would say with unexplained fertility the rates are between 3-7%. If you choose to do injectable medications with IUI and have unexplained infertility, it's probably about a 9% chance of pregnancy per try.”

items.header: What’s the timeline of each step of IVF, and the total timeline from first appointment to possible pregnancy?

content.value: KG: “This would vary by a number of factors, including if the patient has had any workup done before, when their cycle starts, if they’re pursuing any genetic testing, the protocols used in your treatment, and the efficiency of your fertility clinic. If you haven’t already, we would start with an initial workup and follow-up consultation to review recommended treatment options based on the results found in your workup. Once you decide to pursue treatment, most treatment options start with someone's period. If you’re already having your period, we would have to wait until the next menstrual cycle and ask that you call us on day one of your period. Generally speaking, from day one of your period to checking for a positive pregnancy test, IVF treatment could take anywhere from 1-4 months, start to finish.

items.header: What’s the process for acquiring donated sperm or donated eggs?

content.value: KG: “Getting donated sperm is easy, even if choosing it is not always easy! Sperm banks have been around a long time and sperm are robust—they do well with freezing. It’s also much easier to get sperm and freeze them than it is to get eggs and freeze them. It’s also less expensive. As a result, there are a lot more sperm banks than there are egg banks.

To get sperm, a male undergoes a screening process and then ejaculates into a sterile container. The sperm is then “washed” and frozen. To get eggs, a female would need to undergo screening and then undergo an egg retrieval, an invasive and expensive procedure to remove the eggs, after which they’re frozen. Before vitrification (a fast-freezing technique) was used there wasn’t a lot of success using frozen eggs, in part because they have a higher water content than sperm and didn’t survive the freezing process as well. Now we’re seeing better egg warming success and egg banks have become more common in the last five years or so, making donated frozen eggs easier to acquire. Keep in mind that some fertility clinics work only with donor egg agencies, and you get to choose a donor. Some work only with donor egg banks where they use frozen eggs.”

items.header: What are the success rates by age for IVF?

content.value: KG: “IVF offers the highest chance of pregnancy of any assisted reproductive treatment. The IVF success rates are broken down based on the age of the female partner, as that's the biggest predictor of fertility. Based on Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) data in 2018, the rates of an IVF embryo transfer resulting in a live birth where the female used her own eggs were as follow:
Female under 35 years of age = 48.8%
Female 35-37 years of age = 44%
Female 38-40 years of age = 38%
Female 41-42 years of age = 27%
Female 43 years of age = 12%
By their mid 40s, most patients using their own eggs will miscarry because the egg doesn’t divide correctly and they only have about a 5% chance of a live birth.”

items.header: What is PGT-A and does it affect the embryo or the outcome of embryo transfer?

content.value: KG: “PGT-A stands for pre-implantation genetic screening for aneuploidy. It’s a genetic screening performed to determine whether or not an embryo has a normal number of chromosomes before implantation. In a blastocyst one part becomes the fetus and one part becomes the placenta. With PGT-A we use a laser to take a nick of the shell, removing about 6-8 cells from the part of the embryo that becomes the placenta and look to see if there are 46 chromosomes in those cells. If we see that approximately 71-81% or more show 46 chromosomes we say that’s ~95% accurate, meaning 95 out of 100 times it’s an accurate assessment. But this doesn’t mean these biopsied cells are representative of all the other cells in the embryo. If say, 31-50% of the cells do not have 46 chromosomes, we could not call it normal or abnormal. Then we call it a mosaic result.

A mosaic result is when the vast majority of cells (~>=70%), are not showing normal or abnormal in terms of the number of cells, but a mix of both. Some may be mostly normal with some abnormal, or mostly abnormal with some normal. Mosaic embryos are not usually transferred because of the risk of miscarriage or genetic abnormalities, but you can discuss the risk with your provider or genetic counselor.

Can a PGT-A biopsy affect the embryo? Yes. A biopsy is a nick of the shell and cells are removed so there’s a potential risk that this process can negatively impact the embryo. However, if the PGT-A shows 46 chromosomes in the cells tested, you’re looking at an approximately 60-70% chance of pregnancy regardless of the female partner’s age. If you’re 35 and above this does impact pregnancy rates as chromosomal abnormalities are a main reason why patients are not able to become pregnant or have a miscarriage. You should always discuss the risk of PGT-A versus the potential benefit with your fertility provider.”

items.header: What is ICSI and does it affect the embryo or the outcome of embryo transfer?

content.value: KG: “ICSI, or intracytoplasmic sperm injection, is when instead of putting an egg and a high concentration of sperm together in a dish and letting fertilization happen, a single sperm is injected directly into the egg. This is most often used in the case of severe male infertility but may also be used if previous rounds of IVF have been unsuccessful, PGT-A has been used, or frozen eggs are being used.

In terms of effect on the embryo, ICSI has been associated with an increased risk of certain birth defects. According to the CDC, some (but not all) studies of ICSI have found an increased risk for ‘chromosomal abnormalities, autism, intellectual disabilities, and birth defects compared with conventional IVF.’ However, this increased risk may not be a result of the procedure itself, but of the integrity of the eggs and sperm used. Always discuss these risks with your fertility provider before pursuing ICSI.”

items.header: Will I have pregnancy symptoms during the 2-week wait after treatment?

content.value: KG: “Sometimes you will, and sometimes you won’t. You may have literally no symptoms and be pregnant or you may have symptoms of high progesterone which happens post-ovulation (breast tenderness, bloating, mood changes) and not be pregnant. So there can be symptoms but if you don’t have any it doesn’t necessarily mean that you’re not pregnant.”

title.en-US: How to manage high blood pressure when trying to conceive

content.value: Trying to get pregnant while also managing a health condition like high blood pressure? That’s a lot to take on. You may have just found out you (or your partner) have high blood pressure while visiting your doctor’s office—or you may have been managing this condition for a while now. Either way, keeping your blood pressure under control is so important for both your health and the health of your future baby. Maven OB-GYN Kathleen Green, MD, and Maven Reproductive Nurse Hailey Baker, ARNP, WHNP-BC, walk us through medication options that are safe should you become pregnant and some ideas for lifestyle changes that can help keep high blood pressure in check while trying to conceive and when you’re expecting.
What is considered high blood pressure (aka hypertension)?
First up, you may be wondering what caused your high blood pressure. You also may wonder what those elevated numbers that come up on the machine mean.
High blood pressure is when your blood pressure, or the force of blood flowing through your blood arteries, is continuously too high.
Blood pressure is measured in millimeters of mercury (mmHg). When your doctor takes your blood pressure, they record two levels that appear like a fraction (ex. 125/80):
Top number:
Systolic pressure—the pressure of blood in your arteries when your heart contracts (or beats)
Bottom number:
Diastolic pressure—the pressure of blood in your arteries when your heart relaxes (between beats)
REPLACEWITHIMGWCAPTION
How does high blood pressure affect female fertility?

So if you’re living with chronic high blood pressure, you may wonder if it can affect your ability to get pregnant. The answer is: Maybe. The relationship between the two is complex because of some of the secondary conditions or effects hypertension can cause.

“It’s hard to clearly state or understand the exact relationship between hypertension and infertility,” Baker says. “For women, it’s hard to know if it’s the hypertension itself causing issues with becoming pregnant. That’s because hypertension is often accompanied by other metabolic diseases such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, or high cholesterol. These conditions can lead to menstrual cycle irregularities, hormone imbalances, anovulation (not ovulating), and overall reproductive dysfunction which can impact fertility.” You may be on medications to manage these conditions. These can affect fertility, too.

That’s not to say that the conditions causing high blood pressure or the side effects of it mean you can’t get pregnant. You may just need a bit more support to get there. Talk to your doctor or book an appointment with a
Maven OB-GYN
to create a care management plan.

It’s also important to note that poorly treated or long-standing high blood pressure can cause damage to the heart and kidneys. Prior to pregnancy, you may need additional tests to make sure these organs are functioning well. Talk to your doctor to see which (if any) tests they recommend when trying to conceive.
How does high blood affect male fertility?

A male partner’s fertility may be negatively affected by high blood pressure or medications to manage it, too. “There’s growing evidence that hypertension in males is related to problems in sperm quality,” Baker says. “Plus some antihypertensive medications can have a negative impact on sperm and sexual function.”
A 2017 study published in
The
World Journal of Men’s Health
found that beta blockers specifically were associated with lower sperm volume, concentration, motility, total sperm count, and motile (moving) sperm count.
For that reason, if you’re a man living with hypertension and trying to conceive, it’s important to work with your doctor or a
Maven provider
to successfully manage high blood pressure. You may need to adjust your medications and follow a program that includes a healthy diet, exercise, no smoking, and possibly weight loss, if recommended.
Medications for high blood pressure while trying to conceive

It’s important to talk to your doctor about any current medications you’re taking before you try to get pregnant. “If you have high blood pressure and are on medication, talk to your doctor first to see if your medication is safe for pregnancy and to make any adjustments to your medication regimen,” Green says. “It’s also good to talk to your OB-GYN about the risk of having high blood pressure in your specific situation prior to getting pregnant.” The goal should be to achieve normal blood pressure prior to trying to conceive.
Make sure your partner also sets up an appointment to talk to a
Maven provider
about their high blood pressure and if any changes are needed to their medications.
Lifestyle changes

In addition to working with your doctor to manage the medications you’re taking and monitoring your blood pressure carefully, there are some healthy lifestyle changes that may help keep your blood pressure in check. “Diet and exercise are the first-line treatments for early onset high blood pressure,” Baker says. “Many individuals are able to control high blood pressure with these lifestyle changes alone.”
Empower yourself to take charge of your health and try some of the following ideas:
Add whole foods to your diet including fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fish, poultry, and low-sodium nuts
Eat plenty of high-fiber foods like beans, lentils, broccoli, lentils
Make time to exercise each week—even just 10-30 minutes per day of light exercise like brisk walking, cycling, yoga, or swimming can make a difference
Try to take more steps each day by parking farther away, getting off a bus stop early, and taking the stairs instead of the elevator REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Need help coming up with nutritious meal ideas that satisfy your taste buds? Talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
. For exercise ideas that excite you, chat with a
Maven Wellness Coach
The bottom line
You may have a lot of questions about how to safely manage your or your partner’s high blood pressure when you’re trying to conceive.
Maven providers
are here to support you—from changing up your medication regimen to healthy diet recommendations—and get you on your way to having a healthy pregnancy and baby.
Sources
Hypertension and Male Fertility.
World Journal of Men’s Health.
Source: Adapted from the American Heart Association

title.en-US: How a routine male-body checkup can boost fertility

content.value: Between a busy work and home schedule, going to the doctor may be pretty low on your to-do list—not to mention the inconvenient appointment times or feeling embarrassed about certain health problems. If you haven’t had a checkup lately, you’re in the majority. But if you’re trying to start a family, it’s a smart move to get an appointment on the books.

Seeing your healthcare provider at least once a year is important for your health, wellness, and, in many cases, fertility. If you’re trying to conceive, getting a handle on your overall health is key—especially since male-body wellness and male fertility go hand-in-hand. Here’s what to expect from a routine check-up and areas that can be most important to focus on for your fertility.
Have questions about your health or fertility? Book a virtual appointment with a
Maven Family Physician
for free. To find an in-person doctor for a checkup, reach out to your Maven Care Advocate  for a list of in-network providers in your area.
Who to see for a check-up

Seeing your primary care provider (like a primary care physician, physician’s assistant, or nurse practitioner) is a good first step. Primary care providers can diagnose a massive range of conditions—from a common cold, to diabetes, to heart disease—and will conduct a number of screenings that can offer insight into your health
and
fertility.
How often you should have a check-up

Providers generally recommend having a physical every year if you’re healthy and don’t have any risk factors. Maven Family Physician Shelly Sethi, DO, recommends seeing your primary care physician more frequently if you’ve been diagnosed with a condition or have risk factors, like a family history of health issues.
What to expect at your appointment
Here are the tests and screenings your healthcare provider may conduct at your appointment:
1. Your medical history and your family’s health history

Your provider will ask you about your medical history and your family’s health history to see if you’re at risk for certain conditions, like heart disease, diabetes, autoimmune diseases, and other conditions that can be passed down. They’ll also review your vaccination history, any allergies you may have, and medications you’re currently taking.

It’s important to be completely honest about your medical history, lifestyle choices, and any relevant risk factors even if it feels awkward. Knowing your complete health history can better help your provider treat or prevent certain health conditions.
2. A physical exam and basic screenings

After checking your health history, your healthcare provider will likely conduct a complete physical exam. In addition to checking your height, weight, and vitals (like your temperature and pulse) you’ll be screened for:
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
3. A blood test to determine hormone levels

Your hormone levels—like testosterone—may be screened during your physical. Some providers, including Sethi, check all patients’ hormone levels, regardless of their age or family status. Low testosterone can affect your fertility, but it can also have other serious effects, like severe fatigue, loss of muscle mass, loss of bone mass, and hair loss.
If you’re trying to conceive, Sethi recommends letting your provider know, so they can test your:
Testosterone
DHEA, a hormone that helps your body produce testosterone
SHBG, a hormone that controls how much testosterone your body tissue can useREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If your hormone levels are low—whether you’re trying to conceive or not—your healthcare provider may recommend lifestyle changes or medications to bring them back to normal levels. There are a number of hormonal treatments available online and in wellness stores, but it’s important to never take a medication or
supplement
without consulting your healthcare provider first.
4. A prostate exam
if you’re at risk
Although prostate cancer is the second most common cancer among males and affects 1 in 8 during their lifetime, it has a very high survival rate.

Depending on your age and family history, routine screenings for prostate cancer may not be necessary. It’s generally recommended to make a plan with your provider once you turn 50, but recommendations can vary based on your family history. It’s also important to know prostate cancer is very rare in males under 40. The average age at diagnosis is 66.
5. Testicular exams

Unless you have certain risk factors, like a family history of testicular cancer, self-exams are no longer recommended and most healthcare providers don’t conduct testicular exams during physicals. Sethi explains why: “The American Academy of Family Practice says there's no benefit to screening for testicular cancer due to the low incidence of disease and high cure rates. Even in patients who have advanced disease, there are potential harms associated with screening, like false positive results, anxiety and harm from diagnostic tests or procedures.”
The American Cancer Society (ACS) has slightly different guidelines, but doesn’t recommend frequent self-exams either, explains Sethi. Rather, the ACS says male patients should be
aware
of the possibility of testicular cancer (0.004% or about 1 in every 250 males) and should report changes to their testes to their healthcare provider ASAP.
The bottom line

Male health and wellness goes hand-in-hand with male fertility, so it’s important to stay up-to-date on routine screenings and physical exams. Preventive care can diagnose and treat health problems before they worsen or become chronic, and boost your overall fertility which can help you achieve your goals of starting a family.
If you need help finding a primary care physician in your area, contact your Maven Care Advocate  for help. We’re here to assist you 24/7.
Sources
American Psychiatric Association
Asian Journal of Andrology
BMJ Open
Cancer.org
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention - Adult Obesity Causes and Consequences
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention - Facts About Hypertension
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention - Tobacco Use
Cleveland Clinic
European Urology
Johns Hopkins Medicine
Johns Hopkins Medicine
The World Journal of Men’s Health

High blood pressure (hypertension) is a very common condition—it’s estimated that nearly half of adults in the United States have high blood pressure. Untreated high blood pressure can put you at risk for heart disease, stroke, and sexual dysfunction, among other issues. When it comes to fertility, studies have found that males with high blood pressure are more likely to have reduced semen volume (the amount of semen produced), lower sperm count, and poorer sperm motility (how sperm move) than males without hypertension.

High blood pressure can impact many of your body’s systems and functions, so it’s important to get screened at least every 2 years—or more often if you have elevated or high blood pressure. Practicing healthy habits like eating a balanced diet, exercising regularly, maintaining a healthy weight, and keeping your alcohol intake low to moderate can improve or reverse high blood pressure. If lifestyle changes aren’t effective, your healthcare provider may recommend starting medication. There are a number of medications available, but some, like beta-blockers, can affect sperm count and motility. Always talk to your healthcare provider about the right treatment options for your condition and your family plans.
Having obesity, or a
body mass index (BMI)

of 30 or higher is linked to certain health issues—including high blood pressure, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. Several studies have also linked obesity to reduced male fertility. Sethi explains: “The main issue with obesity is low testosterone, which can decrease sperm production. Males who are over their recommended weight or have obesity are 11% more likely to have low sperm count and 40% more likely to have no sperm at all (
azoospermia
) compared to males who are in the recommended weight range.”
If you have obesity, work with your healthcare provider or a
nutritionist on Maven
to develop a weight management plan. Losing excess weight and better managing blood sugar levels can reduce the risks of obesity and, in some cases, reverse fertility issues, Sethi says.
A simple blood test will show if you have prediabetes (also known as
insulin resistance

) or type 2 diabetes, a long-term condition that can cause body-wide damage. There are two types of diabetes—type 1 and type 2—but type 1 typically develops in childhood and is considered an autoimmune condition. Type 2 diabetes usually develops in adulthood and is related to family history, lifestyle choices, and other things related to health, like access to nutritious food, education, and safe housing (also called social determinants of health).

Unmanaged type 2 diabetes can harm your heart, nerves, vision, and dental health, as well as fertility. Studies have found that males diagnosed with type 2 diabetes often have issues with their sperm health, motility, and count. According to Sethi, type 2 diabetes can also impact your testosterone levels, which impact sperm production, sperm health, and sex drive.

Type 2 diabetes can often be managed by eating a balanced diet, exercising regularly, and avoiding tobacco and alcohol products. Your healthcare provider may also prescribe injectable insulin or an oral medication if you need extra help controlling your blood sugar. For ongoing help, talk to a
Diabetes Coach
on Maven for free.

Depression is a common, but serious mental health condition that can affect your mood and ability to function in everyday life. If you have depression, know you’re not alone. According to the American Psychiatric Association, 1 in 6 people will experience depression at some point in their lifetime.

Depression can take a serious mental and physical toll. Some physical effects of depression include severe fatigue, difficulty sleeping or sleeping too much, changes in appetite, and sexual dysfunction, like
erectile dysfunction
or difficulty ejaculating. In terms of fertility, it’s also believed that untreated depression can impact sex hormone levels, sperm quality and sperm concentration.

Your healthcare provider will ask a series of questions to screen for depression. If you’re experiencing ongoing feelings of sadness, hopelessness, or anxiety, there are steps you can take to feel better. In fact, 80% to 90% of people diagnosed with depression eventually respond to treatment—whether it be therapy, medication, lifestyle changes, or a combination of these. Be honest with your healthcare provider, so they can help you start a treatment plan.
If you have feelings of anxiety or depression, you don’t have to go it alone. Contact a
Maven Mental Health Provider
to talk about your counseling options. If you have severe feelings of depression or harming yourself or others, please call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 800-273-8255.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), tobacco use is the leading cause of preventable disease and death in the United States, so if you use tobacco products, it’s important to let your healthcare provider know. Quitting can be a
huge
challenge, but the long-term effects of tobacco use can be devastating—it’s been linked to cancer, heart disease, type 2 diabetes, stroke, and other serious health issues.
Plus, it’s been proven to damage virtually every organ in the body, including the reproductive organs.
No level of tobacco use is safe for
your fertility

. It’s been found that tobacco products can damage sperm concentration, morphology (how sperm are shaped), motility, and DNA, and contribute to sexual dysfunction, like erectile dysfunction. Researchers have also found in heterosexual couples, male partner tobacco use can impact female partner’s fertility due to secondhand smoke exposure.
Quitting tobacco use can be tough, but it is possible with the right tools and support. If you want to make a plan to quit, talk to your healthcare provider or get free advice from a
Maven Family Physician

Excessive alcohol use can cause a number of health issues—from high blood pressure, to cancer, to liver disease and cirrhosis. But what, exactly, is considered excessive drinking? The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) defines excessive alcohol use as 15 drinks or more per week for males.
Keep in mind: a standard drink contains 0.6 ounces of pure alcohol, or roughly:
12 ounces of beer
5 ounces of wine
8 ounces of malt liquor
1.5 ounces of spirits
Research has shown that excessive alcohol use can affect your fertility, too. Researchers haven’t determined the
exact
amount of alcohol it takes to impact fertility, but heavy drinking has been shown to reduce semen volume and sperm count, affect sperm motility, and lower testosterone levels.
It’s OK to enjoy a drink, but if you feel you’re drinking too much, your healthcare provider can help come up with a plan to cut back. You can also discuss your options with a
Maven Family Physician
or
Mental Health Provider.

title.en-US: How hormone imbalances can affect male fertility

content.value: Hormones are responsible for hundreds of functions in the human body, including your sleep-wake cycle, mood regulation, and sexual function and fertility. So even small changes in hormone levels can have a major effect on your health. And if you’re trying to conceive, these changes can make getting pregnant more challenging.
Read on to learn about male hormones and hormonal imbalances, so you can achieve your fertility goals.
Who should get their hormone levels checked?

If you’re planning on getting pregnant, it’s a good idea to mention it to your healthcare provider. A primary care provider (PCP) can do a simple blood test to make sure your hormones are balanced. Plus, they can recommend ways to improve your overall health since wellness and male fertility are closely related.

If you and your partner have been trying to conceive for at least a year (6 months if the female partner is over 35), Mary Samplaski, MD, Urologist and Associate Professor of Clinical Urology at Keck School of Medicine at USC recommends seeking care from a specialist rather than your PCP. She recommends making an appointment ASAP with a reproductive urologist. “​​They will conduct a medical history, physical exam, and morning blood draw to check your hormones—testosterone is highest between 8 and 10 AM. If abnormalities are discovered, your provider may want to do more bloodwork to determine the underlying cause.”
Male hormones and how they impact fertility

When it comes to male fertility, there are three key hormones: testosterone (T), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH). These hormones are vital to a male’s sperm production, sperm quality, and sexual function. Hormones like estrogen, prolactin, and thyroid-stimulating hormone can also impact male fertility, but play a smaller role.
Here’s what you need to know about each of these hormones.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
The bottom line

“The good news is that many of these imbalances are manageable with medications. If you're trying to conceive, it's best that any hormonal imbalances are managed by a reproductive urologist—some medications can lower sperm count, so you need to be treated by a provider that specializes in these issues,” says Samplaski. Certain imbalances can also be improved by making lifestyle changes, like eating a more balanced diet or stopping tobacco use.

Several different hormonal imbalances can affect male fertility, and it can be confusing, so if you have concerns, be sure to talk to your healthcare provider or your Maven Care Advocate  about scheduling a hormone workup. Your Maven Care Advocate can help you find in-person providers in your network.
Sources
Arab Journal of Urology
Cleveland Clinic - Low Testosterone
Cleveland Clinic - Luteinizing Hormone
Frontiers in Endocrinology - Clinical Use of FSH in Male Infertility
Frontiers in Endocrinology - Thyroid Function in Male Infertility
International Journal of Molecular Sciences
Medical News Today - Estrogen
Medical News Today - Prolactin
Medline Plus
Sexual Medicine Reviews
What it is:

Testosterone is the most well-known male hormone (although it’s present in female bodies at lower levels, too). It’s vital to muscle development, growth, mood regulation, sperm production, sex drive, and sexual function.
What happens if it’s imbalanced:
The effects of low testosterone can impact your fertility and make conceiving challenging. A side effect like
erectile dysfunction
doesn’t
directly
impact fertility, but it can make it difficult to orgasm—so can reduced sex drive, depression, and fatigue. Low testosterone can also harm your body’s ability to produce sperm.
Symptoms to look for:
If someone has
low testosterone
—blood levels lower than 300 nanograms per deciliter (ng/dL), according to the American Urology Association (AUA)—they may experience symptoms, like:
Decreased sex drive
Problems achieving or maintaining an erection (erectile dysfunction)
Less seminal fluid
Smaller testicles (where testosterone is produced)
Mood swings, irritability, anxiety, and depression
Trouble concentrating or sleeping
Causes:
Testosterone levels naturally start to decline around age 30, but low testosterone can impact males of any age. Some common causes of low testosterone are:
Injury or infection in the testicles
Chronic conditions, like type 2 diabetes or obesity
Congenital defects and genetic conditions
Tobacco use

Certain causes of low testosterone—like genetic conditions or congenital defects—can’t be prevented and will likely need medical treatment. But some can. Eating a healthy diet, staying active, avoiding smoking/vaping, and limiting alcohol can all help keep testosterone levels balanced.
How it’s diagnosed:
If you’re experiencing symptoms of low testosterone, talk to your healthcare provider or a
Maven Reproductive Endocrinologist
about testing. A simple blood test can provide answers.
What it is:

Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) is a hormone that’s produced by the pituitary gland (a small gland located underneath the brain). Proper levels of FSH are important for sexual development and function, and sperm development in males; in females, FSH stimulates the growth of eggs and helps regulate the menstrual cycle.
What happens if it’s imbalanced:
In most cases, FSH levels remain pretty stable in males, but having too much or too little FSH can cause a variety of health issues, including reduced fertility and sexual function.
Symptoms to look for:
Someone with an imbalance of FSH can experience things like:
Difficulty getting a female partner pregnant
Low sex drive
Fatigue
Decreased appetite and weight loss

FSH plays a major role in sperm development and quality, so unbalanced levels can affect sperm count, motility (how sperm move) and morphology (how sperm are shaped), which can make conceiving more challenging.
Causes:
Some causes of high FSH include:
Testicular exposure to chemotherapy or radiation
Damage from an infection in the testicles
Genetic disorders that affect sexual development, like Klinefelter’s syndrome
Causes of low FSH include conditions affecting the pituitary gland or the hypothalamus (a region of the brain).
How it’s diagnosed:

An imbalance of FSH can be diagnosed with a blood test at your healthcare provider’s office. In addition to testing, a thorough health, sexual, and fertility history can help your healthcare provider determine the cause of the imbalance.
Treatment:

Treatment will vary based on the cause of an FSH imbalance and certain treatments are still considered experimental in many countries. More research is needed, but studies have had some promising results: one determined that FSH therapy can significantly improve sperm count, motility, and morphology after a few months of treatment. Another found a significantly increased rate of pregnancy in female partners of males undergoing FSH treatment.
If you’re concerned about your levels of FSH, be sure to talk to your healthcare provider or a
Maven Reproductive Nurse
. And remember: never start any kind of hormone therapy without consulting your healthcare team first.
What it is:

Luteinizing hormone (LH) is a hormone that’s produced in the pituitary gland. It’s responsible for the production of the testosterone that helps produce sperm. Closely related to follicle-stimulating hormone, LH and FSH work together to trigger sperm production in the testicles.
What happens if it’s imbalanced:
Since LH is responsible for testosterone production, having too little can create imbalances in testosterone levels. This, in turn, can affect sperm production and quality,
and
lead to problems with sexual function, like low sex drive or erectile dysfunction.
Causes:
Some causes of low LH levels include:
Kallmann syndrome, a genetic condition that causes low testosterone and estrogen
Conditions that affect the pituitary gland
Some causes of high LH levels include:
Klinefelter syndrome, a genetic condition that is often linked to fertility problems
Conditions that affect the pituitary gland
Injury or damage to the testicles
Testicular failure (when the testicles stop producing testosterone and sperm)
How it’s diagnosed:

LH levels can vary, but a typical range for a male is 1.42 to 15.4 UI/L of blood. Knowing your LH levels can help your healthcare provider figure out if you have low testosterone, a pituitary gland disorder, or another condition.
Treatment:

The treatment of LH imbalances depends on the cause. Although hormone therapy—like testosterone replacement therapy (TRT)—can help bring levels back to normal, several studies have found that TRT has a significant impact on male fertility. So if you’re trying to conceive, your healthcare provider may recommend other treatments, like
lifestyle changes
that can help improve LH and testosterone levels.
What it is:
Estrogen is often called the “female hormone,” but it’s present in both male and female bodies, just at different levels.
What happens if it’s imbalanced:
In a male body, estrogen has to remain balanced with testosterone for proper sexual function and sperm production.
Symptoms to look for:

Testosterone naturally starts to decline and estrogen increases as males age, but it usually doesn’t cause issues unless estrogen levels are very high. Someone with high estrogen levels might experience symptoms like:
Low sperm count or quality
Erectile dysfunction or low sex drive
Development of breast tissue (a condition called gynecomastia)
Reduced muscle mass
Hair loss
Causes:
Some causes of excess estrogen in a male body include:
Having obesity
Chronic stress
Certain medications, including some psychiatric medications and antibiotics
Hormonal imbalances
In most males, lower levels of estrogen won’t have an effect on their health or fertility. Males with extremely low levels may have a hormonal imbalance that’s affecting their entire body.
Treatment:

There isn’t a ton of evidence that supports medical treatment for high estrogen in males, so your healthcare provider may recommend focusing on lifestyle changes, like eating a healthy diet, exercising when you can, and losing any excess weight.
What it is:

Prolactin is the hormone that triggers breast milk production in pregnant or breastfeeding females, but it’s also in male bodies in lower levels. In a male body, prolactin plays important roles in the function of the testicles and sperm production.
What happens if it’s imbalanced:
High levels of prolactin can harm a males’ sperm production and sexual function—both of which can make conceiving difficult.
Symptoms to look for:
A male with higher prolactin may also experience symptoms like:
The inability to get their female partner pregnant
Erectile dysfunction
Headaches or issues with vision
Nipple discharge called galactorrhea
Causes:
A number of medical conditions and other factors can cause high levels of prolactin in males. If you’re experiencing symptoms, your healthcare provider may screen for:
Conditions that affect the pituitary gland
Hypothyroidism (a condition in which the thyroid doesn’t produce enough
thyroid hormone)
Liver, kidney, or lung disease
Herpes zoster infections, which cause chickenpox and shingles
High levels of prolactin have also been linked to medications like antidepressants and drugs that control high blood pressure, and
marijuana use
. If you’re taking medication that raises prolactin levels, be sure to talk to your provider before stopping use.
How it’s diagnosed:
If your healthcare provider suspects you have high prolactin, they’ll conduct a blood test to measure your levels.
Treatment:
High prolactin levels are usually treated with medication, but you’ll work with your healthcare team to figure out the best course of treatment.
What it is:

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is made in the pituitary gland and produces thyroid hormones that are responsible for tons of processes in the body—from brain development, to digestive function, to metabolism. Very high or low levels of TSH can signal an
issue with the thyroid
, like hyperthyroidism (an overactive thyroid) or hypothyroidism (an underactive thyroid).
What happens if it’s imbalanced:
Although an imbalance of TSH doesn’t
directly

impact male fertility, there’s evidence that hyperthyroidism can affect male sexual function and cause issues like erectile dysfunction, low sex drive, or premature ejaculation. Hypothyroidism can harm sperm count, motility, and morphology.
Treatment:

Treatment for hyper- or hypothyroidism is usually medication that can bring thyroid hormone levels back to normal. Once the underlying cause is treated, males with thyroid-related infertility may experience an improvement in their sexual function or sperm characteristics.
If you have a thyroid condition and have questions about your fertility, schedule an appointment with one of
Maven’s Reproductive Endocrinologists

title.en-US: Strengthening the pelvic floor muscles: Why it’s important for menopause

content.value: While head-heavy menopause symptoms like hot flashes and brain fog tend to get all the buzz, there’s a lot going on down below to talk about, too.
Menopause can weaken your pelvic floor—causing painful sex, making it difficult to control your bladder, and even upping your risk for bacterial infections like urinary tract infections (ugh!).
Maven Physical Therapist Heather Brooks explains how menopause changes the pelvic floor and how to strengthen it if needed.
What are some pelvic floor concerns to be aware of during the menopause years?

You can thank hormonal changes for some of the pelvic floor shifts you may notice during the menopause years. “During menopause, your vaginal area may unfortunately suffer from decreased estrogen,” Brooks explains. “With the decreased estrogen comes decreased strength and function of the pelvic floor muscles.” These important muscles and nerves help support your bladder, uterus, small intestine, and bowel.
This decrease in estrogen can also cause:
Urinary incontinence
Vaginal dryness
Itching
Pain during sex without the use of lubrication
More frequent UTIs or vaginal infections (if your vaginal flora or pH gets unbalanced)
How to tell if you’re experiencing pelvic floor discomfort
Some of the symptoms will be obvious (hello, painful sex) but others might be less so.
You might be experiencing problems with your pelvic floor if:
You have urinary or fecal incontinence (leaking urine or stool) at any time
You feel vaginal or pelvic pain
You have difficulty emptying your bowel or bladder
Sex is painful
You feel a bulge or pressure in your pelvic floorREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
These are all concerns you should talk about with your primary care provider (could be your family physician, OB-GYN, or nurse practitioner). You can also book an appointment to speak to a
Maven Physical Therapist
for free online anytime.
Will strengthening exercises help me with my pelvic floor discomfort?

Kegels aren’t a cure-all. As it turns out, strengthening exercises aren’t actually safe or effective for everyone, Brooks explains. “Not everyone is a candidate for pelvic floor exercises,” she says. “Some people need relaxation instead, like learning how to breathe from the diaphragm or stretching.”
That’s why it’s so important to be evaluated in-person or speak to a
Maven Physical Therapist

online to determine if they’re a good fit for you before performing any exercises, Kegels included. To find an in-person pelvic floor specialist near you, message your Maven Care Advocate  for help getting a referral list.

“The important part is knowing if you are a Kegel candidate and would benefit from performing pelvic floor muscle contractions, or Kegels,” Brooks says. “Not everyone is a Kegel candidate. This is why having a physical therapist (PT) perform an internal and external vaginal assessment is very important. They will evaluate your ability to perform a Kegel correctly and if you actually need to perform these exercises. Some people have more tension in their pelvic floors, and need more relaxation exercises instead.”
Exercises to strengthen the pelvic floor
If a PT does recommend you perform Kegels, or pelvic floor contractions, you can follow the steps below.

Start by performing these lying down—which is the easiest position. “Eventually, as you get stronger and can hold for up to 10 seconds, you can perform it sitting or standing, which are harder positions,” Brooks notes.
How to perform a Kegel:
Imagine a blueberry is at the base of your vaginal opening and you are trying to suck the blueberry into the vagina.
Hold for 5 seconds, then relax and let the blueberry go.

Allow at least 10 seconds for relaxation, then suck the blueberry up again. (Important note: Don’t hold your breath and try to isolate your pelvic muscles. Don’t use other muscles like your glutes, or butt, abdominal, or thigh muscles.)
Repeat steps 1-3. As you start to feel stronger, you can increase the length and try to hold for 10 seconds, then relax for 10 seconds. Do 10 repetitions about 3 times per day.
The bottom line

Menopausal pelvic floor changes can feel disheartening and start to really impact your life. But help is available and you can perform strengthening exercises like Kegels, if recommended. Strengthening exercises can make a big difference, but remember, they’re not right for everyone and always check with your doctor or a PT first.
Wondering what’s best for you? Make an appointment to talk to a
Maven Physical Therapist
anytime. If needed, your Maven Care Advocate  can also recommend a pelvic floor specialist near you that you can see in-person for an evaluation.

title.en-US: Exactly what questions to ask your insurance provider about your fertility benefits

content.value: Insurance is complicated (to say the least). So it’s no surprise that trying to understand your coverage for fertility treatments can feel overwhelming. One of the best ways to understand your benefits is through a conversation with your insurance provider. (Keep in mind that your fertility clinic can help you understand your benefits and coverage, too.) If you’d like to talk to your insurance provider before going to a fertility clinic, here’s a list of essential questions to help you get what you need out of the call.
Read these tips before you pick up the phone:

Whenever you talk to your insurance company, note the time, date, name of the customer service rep, their ID # (if they have one), and their call center location. If you’re told that you have coverage for a procedure, service, or medication and then your insurance provider denies the claims, you can have the insurance company look up the conversation and replay it. (So don’t forget to get this info!)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Take detailed notes during any calls you have with your insurance company.
Words to know
These are terms your insurance provider may use. Knowing what they mean can help you make heads or tails of what’s covered and what’s not.
In-network vs out-of-network:

Providers or health care facilities that are part of a health plan's network of providers with which it has negotiated rates. If a doctor or facility has no contract with your health plan, they're considered out-of-network and the costs to see them may be higher.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Out of pocket (OOP):
Your expenses for medical care that aren't reimbursed by insurance.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Annual or lifetime cap:
A cap on the benefits your insurance company will pay in a year or over your lifetime while you're enrolled in a particular health insurance plan.
Diagnosis of infertility:

An infertility diagnosis may be required to access your fertility benefits. Example infertility diagnoses include trying to conceive for 6-12 months (depending on age) and not becoming pregnant, ovulation disorders, blocked fallopian tubes, and low sperm count. Learn more about infertility
here
Primary vs. secondary infertility:
If you’re trying to have your first child, the diagnosis given is primary infertility. If you’re trying to have another child, the diagnosis will be secondary infertility.
Pre-authorization, also known as prior authorization:
A decision by your health insurer or plan that a health care service, treatment plan, prescription drug or durable medical equipment is medically necessary.
Questions to ask your insurance provider
Now that you have a better handle on insurance-speak, here are the key questions to ask.
1. What are the basics of my health insurance plan?
Although each insurance plan is unique, there’s a baseline structure to every policy. Start your call by confirming these policy basics:
Deductible:
A deductible is an amount of money that you’re responsible for paying toward your medical expenses before your insurance kicks in.
Co-pays:
A fixed amount you pay for a covered health service after you’ve paid your deductible. (For example, a $20 co-pay.)
Co-insurance:
The percentage of costs of a covered health care service you pay after you've paid your deductible. (For example, a 20% co-insurance.)
Out of pocket max:
The most you have to pay for covered services in a plan year.
Premium:
The amount you pay for your health insurance provider every month.
2. Does my plan cover fertility treatment? If it does, does that include:
Consultations at a fertility clinic
Diagnostic testing (examples: hormone testing, HSG, sperm analysis)
Artificial insemination and intrauterine insemination (IUI)
In vitro fertilization (IVF)
Preimplantation genetic testing (PGT-A and/or PGT-M) testing on embryos
Cryopreservation/storage (of egg/sperm/embryo)
Medications
Surgical procedures related to fertility (examples: fibroid or polyp removal)
3. Is there a separate cap for medical bills and pharmacy bills?

Medical bills include treatments and procedures like diagnostic tests, IUI, or IVF. Pharmacy bills are for medications associated with fertility treatments. Sometimes, benefits are structured such that the annual/lifetime cap is split out between medical and pharmacy. For example, $10,000 toward medical and $5,000 toward pharmacy, for a combined lifetime benefit of $15,000.
4. Is there a separate deductible for fertility care?
This isn’t very common, but it’s worth knowing if your plan may have a separate deductible.
5. Do my co-pays or co-insurance differ if I see an in-network or out-of-network fertility provider?

Higher co-pays and co-insurance at out-of-network fertility providers are very common. Make sure you understand the differences in cost that you might incur if you go to an in-network or out-of-network provider.
6. Are there any requirements I have to meet before my fertility benefits become effective?
If the answer is yes, follow up with these questions to make you have a complete understanding of what’s required for you to access your benefits:
Does my fertility coverage require a diagnosis of infertility?
Does egg/sperm/embryo freezing and cryopreservation/storage require a diagnosis of infertility?
How is the diagnosis defined?
What is required for me and/or my partner to prove a diagnosis of infertility?

Do I/we need to prove that I/we have been trying to conceive for 6-12 months (depending on age) to qualify for fertility coverage? (If the answer is yes, your primary care provider, OBGYN, or fertility specialist can guide you through this.)
Is there a differing policy for secondary infertility?
Are there any exclusions to qualifying for coverage?
Are there certain treatments that must be tried before pursuing IVF?
7. Is pre-authorization required at any point in my fertility treatment? If it is, how do I get pre-authorization?

“Pre-authorization” may be required before you can get fertility treatments covered. This authorization may be a referral from a primary care doctor or an OBGYN prior to seeing a fertility specialist. Or, your fertility specialist (a Reproductive Endocrinologist) may be required to submit your treatment plan to your insurance provider for approval before beginning treatment.

Make sure you know whether pre-authorization is required before any treatment (including infertility diagnostic testing) begins. Some insurers won’t pay for visits unless the pre-authorization paperwork is in place at the time of your visit, even if coverage for this visit would’ve been included in your insurance policy.
Extra questions to ask about specific services

Once you understand the basics of your coverage, you may want to ask your insurance provider if certain services are covered. Your fertility clinic will also provide you with this information in most cases, since they call your insurance provider to confirm your benefits and coverage, too. Some specific questions that may be helpful to ask your insurance provider yourself are:
Are genetic disease carrier screening tests for me and my partner covered?
Am I restricted on what lab I can use for carrier screening tests or any other diagnostic testing?
Is genetic counseling covered?
Am I restricted to a specific lab for preimplantation genetic testing (PGT-A and/or PGT-M) on embryos?
Are third party services covered by my insurance? (e.g., donor egg/sperm/embryo, gestational carrier)
Are certain fertility medications covered, but not others? (Your insurance provider may be able to send you a list of fertility medications that are covered under your plan)
If medications are covered, do I need to get my medications from a specific pharmacy? REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Starting your fertility journey can feel overwhelming, but remember that Maven has your back every step of the way. Check out
Maven’s Fertility Program Providers
available to you, from Mental Health providers to Reproductive Endocrinologists and Reproductive Nurses, and schedule a free video call any time you could use some support.

title.en-US: How to take care of your mental health during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know:
Many people have feelings of sadness, anxiety, panic, or anger during pregnancy.
These can be signs of perinatal mood and anxiety disorders (PMADs). PMADs are mental health conditions that can happen during pregnancy or after your baby is born.
Talking to a mental health provider is very important for recovery from PMADs.
Breathing exercises, support groups, and other ways to cope can also help.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Having a hard time with your mental health while you are pregnant can be scary. Very strong feelings may make it hard to live your everyday life or take care of yourself while pregnant.
Know that you are not alone—many pregnant people have these feelings. And there are ways to get help. Take these steps to start to feel better.
1. Talk to a mental health provider
If you are having very strong emotions, not feeling like yourself, or think you have a perinatal mood and anxiety disorder (PMAD), get help from a mental health provider right away.
A mental health provider can teach you coping skills. These are activities or ways of thinking that can ease depression, anxiety, and other side effects of mental health conditions.
To find a provider who takes Medicaid insurance, visit your state site or call the number on your insurance card. You can also speak to a
Maven Mental Health Provider
any time online for free.

If you are having a mental health emergency or are thinking about hurting yourself or someone else, call the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline at 988 right away. Or go to the emergency room and tell them you are pregnant and need help.
Learn more about PMADs and how to find a provider
2. Try these easy exercises that can help you feel better
If you are feeling anxious, panicked, sad, or angry, these coping skills can help you feel better quickly. Plus, they can be done anywhere, like your home, car, or workplace.
If you want more ideas, schedule a free appointment with one of
Maven’s Mental Health Providers
Box breathing:
If you are feeling nervous or panicked, breathing exercises can help you calm down. Here is what to do:
Breathe out for 4 seconds
Hold your breath for 4 seconds
Breathe in for 4 seconds
Hold your breath for 4 seconds
Keep breathing in this pattern until you feel better
T.I.P.P.:
If you feel extremely upset, anxious, or panicked, T.I.P.P. can calm your mind and body down right away. Here is what to do:
Temperature:
Drink a glass of very cold water or hold an ice cube against your skin
Intense exercise
: Do push-ups against a wall, seated leg lifts, or stretch (only do this if your doctor has given you the OK to exercise during pregnancy)
Paced breathing:
Do the above box breathing exercise
Paired muscle relaxation:
Squeeze all of your muscles while you breathe in for 5 seconds. Then release your muscles when you breathe out.
Count backwards from 9 to 0:
Doing this exercise can distract you from feelings of stress and anxiety. Here is what to do:
Count backwards from 9 to 0.
Then, count backwards from 8 to 0.
Then, count backwards from 7 to 0, 6 to 0, 5 to 0, and so on.
Repeat this counting pattern until you start to feel better.
Imagine your favorite place:
Thinking about your favorite place can bring up the good feelings you have when you are there. Here is what to do:
Close your eyes
Try to create a very detailed mental picture of your favorite place
Think about how it looks, smells, and sounds
Think about how you feel when you are there
3. Find your support system
Many people who have anxiety, depression, panic, or anger during pregnancy can feel lonely. But it is important to remember that you are
not
alone and there are ways to find the support you need.
Here are some ways to find support from your family, friends, and community:
Ask loved ones for help:
If friends or family members live close to you, do not be afraid to ask them for help. For example, you might ask a trusted loved one to watch your kids while you rest.
Find a support group:
Talking to people who are going through the same thing might make you feel better. You can find many support groups online or on Facebook.
Postpartum Support International
has a lot of free support groups for pregnant people.
Talk to a Maven Mental Health Provider:
You can contact a
Maven Mental Health Provider
for support and a safe space to talk about how you are feeling for free.
4. Take care of yourself
Having feelings of sadness, anxiety, panic, or anger during pregnancy is a very hard thing to go through. But it is important to take care of your mind and body, so you can have a healthy pregnancy.
Get some rest:
It is hard to get enough sleep when you are pregnant. But not getting enough sleep can make symptoms of PMADs worse. Try to rest whenever you can. Even a short nap can make a big difference.
Eat a mostly healthy diet:
Your mind and body need vitamins and nutrients to work their best. Especially when you are pregnant. Eating a mostly healthy diet and taking your
prenatal vitamin
every day can give your body the nutrients it needs
and
help you feel better.
Learn how to eat healthy on a budget.
Try to be kind to yourself:
It may feel hard, but try to be nice to yourself. Having a PMAD during pregnancy does not make you a bad parent. You did nothing to cause this condition.
We’re here for you
Having struggling with your mental health during pregnancy is a very hard thing to go through. But you do not have to do it alone. There are ways to feel better. And remember:
Maven Mental Health Providers
and Maven Care Advocates  are always here to help you at no cost.
Sources
Postpartum Support International

title.en-US: 4 ways to help your mental health after pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know:
Many new parents feel sad, anxious, nervous, or angry after their baby is born.
These feelings can last 2-3 weeks after baby is born and are called “the baby blues.”
Longer-lasting feelings of sadness, anxiety, panic, or anger could be signs of a perinatal mood and anxiety disorder (PMAD).
Talk to a mental health provider to help you feel better. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Struggling with your mental health after you give birth can feel scary and lonely. Feelings of depression, anxiety, or anger can make it hard to take care of yourself and your baby. You may even feel ashamed or like you are not a good parent.
It is important to know that having these feelings is
not

your fault and you are not alone. Many new moms have the baby blues for 2 to 3 weeks after they give birth. And about 15% of new moms experience longer-lasting or very strong feelings within the first year after birth. This may be a sign of a perinatal mood and anxiety disorder (PMAD).
With the right treatment, you will get better. Here is how to get started.
1. Talk to a mental health provider
Talk to a mental health provider right away if you are not feeling like yourself or you think you have a PMAD. They will give you a safe space to talk about how you are feeling.
Your mental health provider will also teach you coping skills. Coping skills are exercises (like deep breathing) that can ease depression, nervousness, and other intense feelings.
Here’s how to find a mental health provider who takes Medicaid insurance:
▢ Visit your
state’s Medicaid site
or call the number on your insurance card to find out if your Medicaid coverage is still active.
Many state plans stop coverage soon after you have given birth.
▢ If active, ask for help finding a mental health provider who accepts Medicaid, or search providers on your state’s site.
▢ Message your Maven Care Advocate  if you are having trouble finding a provider
▢ You can also speak to a
Mental Health Provider
online for free on Maven.
Learn more about PMADs and how to find a provider

If you are having a mental health emergency or are thinking about hurting yourself or your baby, or someone else, call the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline at 988 right away. Or go to the emergency room and tell them you need help.
2. Do mental exercises that can help you feel better

If you have very strong feelings of sadness, nervousness, or anger, these coping skills can calm down your mind and body quickly. They only take a few minutes and can be done anywhere, like your home, car, or workplace.
Box breathing:
Breathe out for 4 seconds
Hold your breath for 4 seconds
Breathe in for 4 seconds
Hold your breath for 4 seconds
Keep breathing in this pattern until you feel better
5-4-3-2-1 exercise:
Look at your surroundings and:
Notice 5 things you can see (like a tree, furniture, or another person)
Notice 4 things you can hear (like cars honking, music, or people talking)
Notice 3 things you can smell (like coffee or your shampoo)
Notice 2 things you can touch (like yourself or your chair)
Notice 1 thing you can taste (like your toothpaste or the last thing you ate)
Count backwards from 9 to 0:
Count backwards from 9 to 0.
Then, count backwards from 8 to 0.
Then, count backwards from 7 to 0, 6 to 0, 5 to 0, and so on.
Repeat this counting pattern until you start to feel better.
Imagine your favorite place:
Thinking about your favorite place can bring up the good feelings you have when you are there.
First, close your eyes
Try to create a very detailed mental picture of your favorite place
Think about how it looks, smells, and sounds
Think about how you feel when you are there REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you want to learn more quick coping skills, schedule a free video appointment with one of
Maven’s Mental Health Providers
3. Get the support you need
Not feeling like yourself or having a PMAD after your baby is born can feel very lonely. You might feel like you are the only parent having these feelings. But remember: you are
not
alone and many other people feel the same way.
The right support can help you feel better. Here are some things you might want to try:
Find a support group:
Talking to other parents who are going through the same thing can help. It is also a good reminder that you are not in this alone. Find free support groups online, like
Postpartum Support International
or on Facebook.
Ask friends and family for help:
Do not be afraid to ask your loved ones to help you with childcare, chores, or other things. For example, you might ask a trusted loved one to watch baby while you take a nap or shower.
Talk to a Maven Mental Health Provider for free:
You can video chat or message with a
Maven Mental Health Provider
at any time for a safe space to talk about how you are feeling.
4. Take care of yourself

It is very hard to take care of yourself when you have a newborn. Many new parents cannot even find time to shower! But taking care of your mind and your body are important when you are struggling with your mental health.
Do something you enjoy:

It is hard to get a break, especially when you have a new baby. Spend a few minutes doing something for yourself every day. Watch an episode of your favorite show, paint your nails, or talk to a friend.
Sleep whenever you can:

It is not easy to get a lot of sleep when you have a new baby. But not getting enough rest can make mental health issues worse. Rest whenever you can. Ask a loved one to watch baby while you take a nap.
Try to eat a healthy diet:
Your mind and body need nutrients and hydration to work their best, especially if you are breastfeeding. Eating a mostly healthy diet and drinking water can give you the energy you need.
Learn how to eat healthy on a budget
Be nice to yourself:
It might not be easy, but try to be kind to yourself. Having a PMAD is not your fault and does not make you a bad parent. Showing yourself love and compassion can help your recovery.
We are here for you
Struggling emotionally or having a PMAD after you give birth can be scary. But you are not alone and you will feel better with the right treatment. If you need help or a safe space to talk,
Maven Mental Health Providers
are always here to help at no cost.
Sources
Postpartum Support International

title.en-US: How to take care of your mental health as a new parent

content.value: What you need to know:
It is important to take care of your mental health when you have a new baby.
Changes to hormones, not sleeping, and stress can hurt your mental health.
Asking for help, joining a parents’ group, and doing something you enjoy are good for your mental health.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Parenting is a hard job. That is why it is so important to take care of your mental health.
Here are some common worries that can weigh on a parent’s mental health, and how to feel better if you are stressed, anxious, or overwhelmed.

If you have long-lasting feelings of sadness, anxiety, or anger, it is important to talk to a mental health provider right away. These can be signs of a perinatal mood and anxiety disorder (PMAD). Many mental health providers accept insurance or you can talk to a Maven Mental Health Provider for free.
Learn more about PMADs and how to find a provider who accepts Medicaid
How do I know if my baby is OK?

It is normal to feel unsure or nervous when you bring your baby home. Many new parents are not sure what to expect, especially with their first baby. And even if you are already a parent, every birth and every baby is different.
It is scary at first, but after a few weeks with your baby, you will become more confident in your parenting skills.
If you are worried, here are a few signs that your baby is healthy and developing:
▢ They have 6-10 wet diapers per day
▢ Their poop is yellow or brown and a watery or peanut butter consistency
▢ They are gaining weight (your pediatrician will weigh your baby at checkups, so they can track their growth and development)
▢ They calm down when you hold them and talk to them
▢ They are quiet and alert a few times per day (newborns cry a lot, so even a few minutes of quiet is a good sign)
▢ They turn towards sounds
Remember, newborns go to the pediatrician a lot in the first few months of life. They will keep track of baby’s growth and development, and can answer any questions you have.
Maven Pediatricians
are always here to answer your questions online for free in-between appointments with your regular pediatrician.
If you are constantly worried about your baby’s health, talk to a mental health provider or a
Maven Mental Health Provider
for help. Feeling worried about your baby all of the time may be a sign of a mental health condition like postpartum anxiety.
What if I don’t feel close to my baby?

It may seem like all parents bond with their newborns right away, but that is not true for everyone. Many new parents need time to connect with their baby. It is normal if you do not feel intense love for your baby right away. Do not feel bad or ashamed.
The bond between parent and baby grows over the first year of baby’s life. Here are some things you can do to help build that bond:
Skin-to-skin contact:

Put baby’s skin against your skin (you can have them in just a diaper and a blanket on top). This can help calm baby when they are upset. Studies have shown that it can also help strengthen your bond.
Make eye contact with your baby:
Look into your baby’s eyes to help their development and the bond you share.
Cuddle with your baby:
Cuddle, rock, and soothe your baby when they are upset to strengthen your bond. (Remember, you cannot spoil a newborn.)
