Many new moms have the “baby blues” for 2 to 3 weeks after their baby is born. The baby blues can cause feelings of sadness, anger, or anxiety. It can also make it hard to bond with baby. If you have the baby blues, you may feel more connected to baby after it ends.

If you have longer-lasting or very strong feelings of sadness, anger, or anxiety, talk to your OB-GYN or a mental health provider. They will want to screen you for a perinatal mood or anxiety disorder (PMAD). A PMAD is a mental health condition that can happen during pregnancy or the first year of your baby’s life. PMADs like postpartum depression and anxiety can make it very hard to connect to your baby.
Maven OB-GYNs
and
Mental Health Providers
are also available to chat with you online anytime for free.
What should I do if I feel overwhelmed?

It is normal to feel overwhelmed or stressed out sometimes. Parenting is not easy! Plus, changes to your hormones after pregnancy, poor sleep, and taking care of a new baby (and older kids) can hurt your mood.
Babies—especially newborns—cry a lot. And not being able to calm your baby when they are crying can also feel very hard.

If you feel like you are getting overwhelmed or angry with your baby, put them somewhere safe (like in their sleeping area without blankets, pillows, or toys) and take a few minutes to calm down. You might try a deep breathing exercise, listening to your favorite song, or calling a friend for support.

Never shake your baby, swing them by their arms or legs, or try to quiet them by putting a blanket, pillow, or something else over their face. It is OK to step away for a few minutes if baby is in a safe space, so you can calm down.
If you are feeling overwhelmed, stressed, or angry a lot of the time, talk to a mental health provider in person or a
Maven Mental Health Provider
for free.
I am so busy—how am I supposed to take care of myself?

A lot of the time, parents do not take care of themselves because they are busy taking care of their kids. Caring for a new baby, older kids, your home, and your job is a lot of work. But it is important to take care of yourself, too. Giving your mind and body a break is good for your mental health and happiness, and for your family, too.
Here are some ways to care of yourself as a parent:
Try to get out at least once every day:

It can be very hard to leave home with a new baby. Some new parents even feel like they are trapped at home. This can lead to feelings of loneliness. But a short trip to the grocery store or a walk around your block can help your mental health.
Eat healthy foods and drink water:
Your body needs nutrients and water to work its best. Eating mostly healthy foods and drinking a few glasses of water every day can give you energy, especially if you are breastfeeding.
Do something you like every day:

It feels hard to find the time, but it is important to take a few minutes to yourself every day. You might chat with a friend, do some stretching and gentle exercises (with your doctor’s permission), or watch your favorite show.
Take care of your mental health:

It is normal to feel nervous, anxious, or stressed sometimes. But if these feelings are making it hard to live your life (or hard to take care of your kids and yourself), get help from a mental health provider right away.
Maven Mental Health Providers
are available at any time for free. Message them or book a video chat.
How can I find the right support?
Again, it takes a village to raise kids. Do not be afraid to ask your friends, family, and community for support when you need it.
Get help with childcare:
Taking care of a newborn
and

older kids can be hard. It is OK to ask for help. If you have friends or family that live close to you, you might ask them to drop-off or pick-up your older kids at daycare or school, have them over for a playdate, or watch them while you rest.
Join a parents’ group:
Staying home with your kids can feel lonely sometimes. Join a local parents’ group to meet other parents and get out of your home. You can find local groups online or on Facebook.
Find a support group:
There are also many mental health support groups online and on Facebook. If you have a PMAD, Postpartum Support International has a lot of free support groups for parents with PMADs.
Talk to a Maven Provider for free:
If you need a safe space to talk about how you are feeling, message or video chat with a
Maven Mental Health Provider
. If you have questions about your kids’ health, schedule an appointment with a
Maven Pediatrician

title.en-US: What therapy is really like and how to find a therapist

content.value: What you need to know:
A mental health provider (or therapist) can help you with mental health conditions (like anxiety or depression), trauma, managing everyday stress, or just creating a safe space to talk.
It is OK if you do not feel comfortable opening up to a therapist right away. It might take time to feel ready to share.
Medicaid will cover most types of mental health care, including online and in-person appointments.
You can video chat or message with a
Maven Mental Health Provider
for free at any time on the website or app. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you are struggling with your mental health during pregnancy or the postpartum period, you are not alone. Talking to a therapist is a great first step toward feeling like yourself again.
Here is what you can expect from a therapy appointment, and how to find a mental health provider who takes your insurance.
If you are thinking about hurting yourself or someone else, call or text the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline at 988 right away. Or go to the emergency room and tell them you need help.
You might feel guilty or ashamed, but try to let go of those feelings
Seeing a therapist for the first time might feel overwhelming, scary, or uncomfortable. But it is important to know that:
What you are going through can be treated
It is not your fault and does not make you a bad parentREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
It is very common for pregnant and postpartum people to struggle with their mental health. In fact, 10% to 20% of pregnant or postpartum women have depression and 4% to almost 11% have anxiety.
Some people think going to see a therapist makes them weak or a failure. This is not true. It takes a lot of strength to get the help you need to take care of yourself and your family.

It can also be hard to open up to a stranger. In the beginning, it is OK to share as much or as little information with your therapist as you want. Over time, you might get more comfortable talking about your feelings and experiences. This can help your therapist understand what you are going through and recommend next steps for treatment.
You do not have to know exactly “what is wrong” to get help

Everyone’s emotions and experiences are different. So it might be hard to explain exactly what you are going through or what you are feeling. It is OK to feel unsure—your therapist will help you figure it out.
Here are some things you can do that might help your provider get a better understanding of what is going on:
Write down your symptoms.

Do you feel very sad? Is it hard to take care of yourself, your baby, or your older kids? Do you have trouble sleeping? Do you have a fast heartbeat? Write down any mental or physical symptoms you have.
Write down when you have symptoms.
This can be a certain time of day (like nighttime) or after you are exposed to a trigger. A trigger is something that is very upsetting to you.
Think about things you do to feel better.

Is there something you do to feel better when you are very upset? If so, this is called a coping skill. Coping skills are things you do (like going for a walk or doing deep breathing) that calm you down when you are in distress. Book an appointment with a
Maven Mental Health Provider
to learn more about healthy coping skills. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Writing down what you are experiencing might make it easier for you to open up to a therapist, too.
Learn about common mental health conditions during and after pregnancy
You will be asked to share a lot during your first appointment

When you meet with a therapist for the first time, they will ask a lot of questions to get a better understanding of what you are going through. If you have signs of depression, they might have you fill out a questionnaire that can help screen for perinatal depression (depression during pregnancy or after birth).
Some things your therapist will probably ask about are:
How you are feeling mentally, physically, and emotionally
If you have any mental or physical symptoms
If you use any coping skills regularly
Your past experiences or past trauma
Your medical and mental health history REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

It is OK to tell your therapist if you are not comfortable answering these questions right away. They can work with you to get more comfortable over a few appointments. But know that being open with them is important for finding the right treatment.

If you feel awkward or embarrassed about sharing, remember that mental health conditions are common during pregnancy and the postpartum period, and your therapist has most likely helped many other people going through the same things you are. They will not judge you for your thoughts, feelings, or experiences.
Maven Mental Health Providers
can also give you a safe space to talk about how you are feeling through a video chat or messaging. Schedule a free online appointment through the Maven app or website.
It should feel like your therapist is supporting you
Here are some important qualities to look for in a therapist:
They are supportive
They are kind and compassionate
They listen closely
They communicate clearlyREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
You should never feel judged by a therapist. If a provider makes you feel this way, it is a good idea to find someone else.
Your therapist will recommend next steps
Everyone is different, so there are a lot of options for next steps:
Some people will need more therapy sessions
Some people will need medication prescribed by a psychiatrist (a mental health provider who can prescribe medications)
Some people may learn coping skills and not need to continue therapyREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
No matter what your next step is, your therapist should be very clear about their recommendation and why, and be open to you asking questions about it.
It is OK to change providers if you are unhappy with your therapist

Going to therapy is a very personal thing. It is important to feel comfortable and get along with your provider. You might need to meet with a few different mental health providers before you find the right one for you.
Scheduling online appointments or short phone calls might make it easier to narrow down the right person.
Does insurance cover therapy?

Your insurance company may cover all or part of mental health therapy, including online or in-person therapy. Contact your health insurance company (or Medicaid) directly to learn more about coverage by visiting their website or calling the number on your insurance card. (In some cases, you might need a prescription from your doctor or OB-GYN.)
Note:
If you are on Medicaid and have already had your baby, make sure your Medicaid coverage is still active. Many state plans stop coverage soon after you have given birth. You can
find your state’s Medicaid website here.
Where can I find a therapist?
To find a licensed therapist or mental health provider, follow these steps:
To find a provider that accepts your insurance
Visit your insurance company or state’s Medicaid website
Or call the phone number on your insurance card
Contact your Maven Care Advocate  for help finding a providerREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
To talk to a provider online for free on Maven:
Message your Maven Care Advocate  for advice on who to meet with
Or look through
Maven’s Mental Health Providers
to find a provider you would like to talk to. Remember all appointments on Maven are free to you.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you are thinking about hurting yourself or someone else, call or text the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline at 988 right away. Or go to the emergency room and tell them you need help.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic Journal of Medicine
[Journal of Women’s Health](
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4589308/#:~:text=Perinatal%20generalized%20anxiety%20disorder%20(GAD,health%20condition%20is%20often%20underdiagnosed)

title.en-US: How to get help finding a better job

content.value: What you need to know
Free clothing closets (places where you can find free or cheap clothing!) are in most towns and cities to help you get professional clothing so you are interview ready
You can do many jobs from home now, and your job might even be able to give you a computer for work
You can (and should) ask lots of questions about pay, benefits, and flexible schedules during the interview process

Feeling like you don’t have enough time in the day or paycheck in a month can be stressful. Your job shouldn’t completely take over your life, and it shouldn’t feel as though you have to work all of the time just to get by, either.
If you’re looking for work, or a better job, we’re here to help. We’ll break down some of the steps you can take to start your job hunt and feel prepared for interviews.
If you want help talking about job options, practicing for an interview, or having tough conversations with your boss, reach out to our
Maven Career Coaches
for free professional advice anytime.
What are some steps to get started on your job hunt?
Think about your reason:
Ask yourself these questions:
Why do you want or need a new job?
What are some things that would make a job ideal for you?
What are your “deal breakers?” These could be things like hours, benefits, or salary.
Make time to look:
Job searching can take awhile. Spend some time on websites like
Indeed

to look at different jobs in your area (or remote if that would work for you). It can help to set a schedule and hold yourself to it—like making a plan to job search for one every night, or applying to 3-5 new jobs a week.
Ask family and friends:
Do they know of anyone hiring? Maybe their workplace has openings or they have heard about a job opening somewhere else.
Where else can I look for a job?
Looking online is a great place to start, but local resources can be helpful too. Try going to your local library, coffee shops, or grocery stores that have bulletin boards to find out about:
Job fairs
Job postings
Free or low cost ways to take classes or get into a field you’re interested in
How to make a resume
Your resume is a one-page sheet that tells about your work history. It needs to be updated after each new job you get.
Maven has Career Coaches who can help you:
Update your resume
Practice interviewing
Offer tips and tricks on feeling comfortable applying and interviewing for jobs
Book free virtual appointments with our
Career Coaches
to get started and anytime you need help along the way.
You can also get in-person help from
Goodwill
to prepare a resume and practice interviewing.
What if I need clothes for an interview?

Feeling like you don’t have anything you want to wear for an interview can be stressful. There are clothing closets in most towns and communities that can help you get ready. Clothing closets are free (or really cheap) places to find professional clothes for an interview. Find local options through
Dress for Success
, or by searching on Facebook or Google.
You can also find affordable interview clothes at:
Goodwill
Consignment sales
Facebook groups
Have a friend who’s the same size as you? You can also ask to borrow an outfit.
What else can I do to get ready?
Read up on the job you want and to learn about which skills are most in demand. You can do this by Googling it or by finding out more about the company you’d like to work for.
Talk to people who do the kind of work you want to do. What are some of the requirements for entering and succeeding in that career?

If you don’t personally know anyone in the field you’re interested in, search around for people who are active on LinkedIn, a social media site for professionals and message them. Many times, people are happy to tell you how they made it in their careers and provide tips.

If you want to change fields or jobs completely, it can be tough to get the role you want right away. If that's one of the career hurdles you have to jump, there are several possible workarounds. You can:
Volunteer for an organization in the field you’re interested in to learn more about it
Do freelance work on sites like
UpWork
or
Fiverr
to get practice
Start doing a side business that’s geared towards your dream role
Practice interviewing with a friend or family member
Talk to people in the field or industry you’d like to be in to make connections and ask them about the skills you might need
Talk to a
Career Coach
for free on Maven for more tips
What questions should you ask during an interview?
The questions you ask might depend on the kind of job you want. But some questions are smart to ask no matter what, and include things like:
Skills:
What skills are helpful for me to succeed in this job? What about character traits that would be helpful for me in this job?
Team:
How much will I work with others and how much will I work by myself?
Turnover:
How long has this role been open and why? Do people usually stick around at this company?
Pay:
Find out what the job pays and how often they pay (biweekly/weekly/monthly)
Benefits:
These include health, retirement, and paid leave options
Childcare:
Some jobs give a childcare allowance. It never hurts to ask!
Remote:
Can the job be done remotely to save money on gas?
Flexibility in schedule:
Do they have other people to help cover if you need it?
Here are some examples of ways to ask these questions in an interview.
Pay:
Could you provide more information on the pay schedule? What is the compensation for this role?
Benefits:
What’s included in the benefits package here? Do you offer health/dental/vision/retirement/paid time off?
Flexibility in schedule:
What is coverage like when an employee needs time off here?
Need more help?
FindHelp.org
is a great resource to use to find more employment help in your area. Just put in your zip code and searching for local help under their “work” tab.
A
Maven Career Coach
can also help with more questions or concerns you may have before setting off on the job hunt, too. Book a free online appointment or message them anytime.

title.en-US: Mental health conditions to watch for during and after pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know:
Mental health conditions that happen when a person is pregnant or after they give birth are called perinatal mood and anxiety disorders (PMADs).
Feelings of sadness, numbness, nervousness, or anger are common in people who have a PMAD.
Talking to a mental health provider is the best way to get help. Some people may also need to take medication to feel better.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
It is normal to feel a lot of emotions when you are pregnant or after you have your baby. Highs and lows are common—you are going through a lot.
But if you feel sad, anxious, numb, or angry for long periods of time, it is a good idea to get checked for a
perinatal mood and anxiety disorder (PMAD)
Keep reading to learn more about PMADs and what to look out for when you are pregnant or postpartum.
What is a perinatal mood and anxiety disorder (PMAD)?

You may have heard about postpartum depression, but there are many different mental health conditions that can happen during pregnancy or any time during the first year of your baby’s life. These are called
perinatal mood and anxiety disorders or PMADs
“Perinatal” means the time before and after birth.
Types of PMADs and what to look for
There are many kinds of PMADs. Some of them share signs, like crying a lot or having trouble sleeping. Some people can have more than one PMAD at the same time, like depression and anxiety.

Your OB-GYN or midwife should screen you for PMADs at least once during the postpartum period. If they do not offer a screening, be sure to ask for one. It is important to take care of your mental health after your baby is born.
Maven’s Mental Health Providers
can give you a safe space to talk about how you are feeling. Video chat or message with our providers for free anytime you need to.
If you are thinking about hurting yourself, your baby, or someone else, call the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline at 988 right away. Or go to the emergency room and tell them you need help.
REPLACEWITHASSET
How common are perinatal mood disorders?
About 15% to 20% of new moms can have a PMAD.

People of every culture, age, race, ethnicity, gender, education, and income level can develop a PMAD. Even male partners can have a PMAD—about 10% of new dads have problems with depression and 18% have anxiety.
What causes PMADs?
It is believed that the changes your body is going through during pregnancy and after giving birth can cause PMADs. Changes to your hormones can have a big impact on your mental health and emotions.
Some other things that can cause PMADs include:
Stress
A family or personal history of depression or anxiety
Alcohol or drug abuse
Little or no support from loved ones
A hard childbirth
Having a baby that needs a lot of medical treatment
Not getting enough sleep REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Remember: having a PMAD is not your fault and does not make you a bad parent. A PMAD is like any other serious illness and needs treatment from a doctor or mental health provider. These feelings do not have to last forever. You will get better with the right help.
How to get help
If you think you have a PMAD, it is important to get help right away from a mental health provider. They can diagnose you and provide treatment to help you feel better.

Talking to a mental health provider is the main treatment for PMADs. You can talk to a mental health provider in their office or online. Certain clinical social workers can diagnose and treat PMADs, too.
Medicaid has many mental health benefits, including online or in-person therapy. You might need a prescription from your doctor or OB-GYN. But Medicaid will cover most types of mental health therapy.
If you have already had your baby, make sure your Medicaid coverage is still active. Many state plans stop coverage soon after you have given birth. You can
find your state’s Medicaid website here.
How to find a mental health provider
To find a provider that accepts Medicaid insurance:
Visit your state’s Medicaid website
Or call the phone number on your Medicaid insurance card
If you’re having trouble, message your Maven Care Advocate  for help
To talk to a provider online for free on Maven:
Message your Maven Care Advocate  for advice on who to meet with
Or look through
Maven’s Mental Health Providers
to find a provider you would like to talk to on video chat or by message on your phone or computer
Medical treatments for PMADs
Some people with PMADs have to take medication to get better. This always requires a prescription from a doctor or psychiatrist (a doctor who can treat mental health problems with medicine).
If you are pregnant, talk to your psychiatrist and your OB-GYN to make sure it is safe before you take any medications.

Some state Medicaid programs cover prescription medication and some do not. Make sure you check your benefits or talk to your Maven Care Advocate  to learn more about what is included in your Medicaid plan.
We are here for you
PMADs are difficult, but you do not have to go through it alone. It is important to get the help you need, so you can start to feel better.
If you need a safe space to talk or have questions about PMADs,
Maven’s Mental Health Providers
are here to help for free anytime.
If you are thinking about hurting yourself, your baby, or someone else, call or text the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline at 988 right away. Or go to the emergency room and tell them you need help.
Sources
Postpartum Support International

title.en-US: 20 ways to keep your sleeping baby safe

content.value: What you need to know:
Safe sleep protects your baby from danger, like sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) and choking.
Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is when a baby under 1 year old dies for an unknown reason. It usually happens when a baby is sleeping.
Always put your baby to sleep on their back on a firm, flat surface with nothing but a tightly-fitting bottom sheet.
Never put blankets, pillows, stuffed animals, or bumpers in your baby’s crib.
Your baby should sleep by themselves in a crib or bassinet. Sleeping with baby in your bed is dangerous. Do not let other kids sleep with your baby in their crib or playard. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Congratulations on bringing your baby home! Making sure your baby has a safe place to sleep is one of the most important things you can do to protect them.
Use these steps to make sure your baby has a safe place to sleep, so you can both get some more shut-eye.
Have questions about your baby’s sleeping area? Video chat or message with a
Maven Infant Sleep Coach
any time for free advice.
Make sure your baby’s sleep area is safe.
If you buy a used crib or get one from a family member or friend, check
cpsc.gov
to make sure it meets today’s safety standards.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Always put baby to sleep on a firm, flat surface.
A crib, playard, or bassinet are safe, firm surfaces for baby to sleep on. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Always put baby to sleep on their back.
If your baby can eventually turn onto their tummy or side by themselves, it is OK to leave them in that position. But you should never put them on their tummy or side for sleep. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Make sure baby’s sleep area is completely empty.

Use only a tightly-fitted bottom sheet. Do not put pillows, blankets, toys, bumpers, or any other items besides a pacifier in your baby’s sleeping area. They can cause your baby to suffocate. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Dress baby in close-fitting pajamas.

Babies can get tangled or suffocate in loose-fitting clothing. If it’s cold, dress baby in warm, close-fitting pajamas or in a sleep sack (a special blanket babies wear). If it’s warm, put baby to sleep in a diaper, onesie, or short-sleeved fitted pajamas. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Do not use weighted blankets or swaddles.
If you swaddle your baby, use a lightweight swaddle that is snug at the chest and loose around baby’s hips and legs. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Stop using swaddles when baby starts to roll.
Do not use swaddles after baby starts to roll (usually around 3 or 4 months, but earlier for some babies). If a swaddled baby rolls over they can suffocate. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Do not use pillows, soft bedding, or wedges that prop baby up or keep them in one position.
These are sometimes called anti-roll pillows, loungers, or nests. They can be very dangerous and lead to suffocation. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Keep baby’s crib in your room for at least 6 months, but up to 1 year is best.
Having baby in their own sleep area in your bedroom helps reduce the risk of SIDS and other dangers. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Do not bring your baby in your bed to sleep.

This can raise the risk of SIDS, choking, and suffocation. You could accidentally roll on top of your baby or push them off the bed. Being over-tired as a new parent can make this more common. Babies can also easily get tangled in bedding and suffocate without you realizing it. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKSome people like to sleep with their baby to bond, but can be dangerous. Some other ways to bond are cuddling with baby, singing to them, or looking into their eyes. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Keep baby away from cigarette smoke.
Babies who are exposed to cigarette smoke have a higher risk of SIDS even if you or someone else are smoking in a different room. Try to keep your home and car free of smoke. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Breastfeed if you can (and if you want to).
Breastfeeding can help protect your baby from SIDS. If you are nursing your baby in your bed, put them back in their crib or bassinet when they are finished eating. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Give baby a pacifier.
Letting your baby sleep with a pacifier can help protect them from SIDS. Never hang the pacifier around baby’s neck or attach it to their clothes. This can cause strangulation.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Do not let baby get too hot.
The best temperature for a baby’s sleep is cooler than you think—
between 68 and 72 degrees F
. If the room is very warm, dress baby in a onesie or diaper. It can be dangerous for babies to get too hot. If the back of your baby’s neck feels sweaty, they are too hot.
Get your baby vaccinated.
Studies show that babies who are vaccinated are less likely to have SIDS. Make sure your baby has
all of the recommended vaccines for their age

. If you are not sure if your baby is vaccinated, talk to their pediatrician. If you need help finding a pediatrician who takes your insurance, talk to your Maven Care Advocate . They can help you find a pediatrician in your area.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Try not to fall asleep while holding baby.

It is dangerous to sleep with baby on an armchair, couch, or in your bed. If you do accidentally fall asleep, make sure you put your baby in their crib or bassinet as soon as you wake up. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Clear the space around baby’s sleeping area.

Cords from window blinds and electronics (like your TV or a charging phone), blankets, pillows, clothing, and other soft items can hurt your baby. Babies can get tangled in these things and suffocate or choke.
Do not use heart rate or breathing monitors.
Do not use monitors your baby wears to track their heartbeat or breathing while they sleep. There is no proof that these monitors stop SIDS from happening.
Give your baby tummy time.

Tummy time helps baby’s neck, shoulder, back, and arm muscles grow stronger. Only do tummy time when baby is awake. Never leave them alone during tummy time—even for a few seconds. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKLearn more about tummy time and why it is important
here
. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Use a cardboard box as a safe sleep space during emergencies.
If you do not have a sleep space that meets CPSC rules, baby can sleep in a flat cardboard box on the floor until you can find a safe crib, bassinet, or playard.
We are here to help
Remember the ABCs of sleep to keep your baby safe: Alone, back, crib.
If you have questions about baby’s sleep safety—or any questions about your baby’s sleep—you can chat with a
Maven Sleep Consultant
for free.
Sources
March of Dimes

title.en-US: How to recover from giving birth

content.value: What you need to know
The time after you give birth is called postpartum.
During the postpartum period, your body needs to heal and recover from pregnancy, labor, and delivery.
It is important to take care of your body, mind, and emotions during the postpartum period. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
When you have a new baby, it is normal to want to put all of your energy into taking care of them. But after you give birth, it is very important to take care of yourself, too.
Here is everything you need to know about how to recover from birth.
Get postpartum care
Your body went through a lot during pregnancy, labor, and delivery. Now that you are in the postpartum period, you need special care to recover.
Make sure your insurance coverage is still active
If you are on Medicaid, many state plans stop coverage soon after you have given birth. You can
find your state’s Medicaid website here.
Schedule your postpartum checkup
Call your OB-GYN or midwife to make a postpartum appointment. Most providers recommend that you see them 6 weeks after you give birth or sooner. Call your provider to ask.
Talk to Maven providers
If you have any questions or worries before seeing your in-person doctor, make a free online appointment on Maven. You can video chat or message with:
OB-GYNs
Mental Health Providers
Pediatricians
Lactation Consultants
Physical Therapists
Career Coaches
How to recover from labor and delivery
Here is what to expect if you had a vaginal delivery:
Vaginal discharge

Your body will flush mucus and blood from your uterus for a few weeks after birth. Discharge will be red and heavy for the first few days. Over time, the color will turn pink, then brown, then yellow-white.
Vaginal soreness
It is normal to feel sore after a vaginal delivery. If you had a vaginal tear or an episiotomy (a cut between the vagina and anus), it might hurt for a few weeks. Here are some things that can help:
Take a pain reliever, like Advil or Tylenol (always check with your doctor first)
Use a squirt bottle to pour warm water over the area while you pee
Freeze a maxi pad in your freezer, then put it in your underwear
Ask your doctor about taking a stool softener or laxative if it is painful to go to the bathroomREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Leaking pee (incontinence)

Pregnancy, labor, and delivery can stretch out or hurt the muscles that support your uterus, bladder, and rectum (these are called the pelvic floor muscles). That means you might leak a few drops of pee when you cough, sneeze, or laugh. A maxi pad or panty liner can help keep you dry. Incontinence usually goes away on its own, but tell your OB-GYN if it does not.
Contractions

Some people have contractions (also called afterpains) after they give birth. They are very common in people who are breastfeeding. These contractions usually feel like period cramps and can be treated with Advil or Tylenol (ask your doctor first).
Hemorrhoids
Some people get hemorrhoids (swollen blood vessels in the anus) from pushing during labor. They can be painful, itchy, and bleed. Here are some things that can help ease pain and itchiness:
Use an over-the-counter cream for hemorrhoids
Sit in warm water for a few minutes every day
Eat food that has a lot of fiber, like vegetables, fruit, and whole grain bread or cereal (this will make it easier to go to the bathroom)
Here is what to expect if you had a Cesarean (C-section) delivery
Vaginal discharge

Your body will flush mucus and blood from your uterus for a few weeks after birth. Discharge will be red and heavy for the first few days. Some people may have lighter discharge. Over time, the color will turn pink, then brown, then yellow-white.
Soreness around your incision
It is normal to feel sore in the place where you were cut after a C-section. Here are some things that can help:
Take a pain reliever, like Advil or Tylenol (talk to your doctor first, they might recommend a prescription pain reliever)
Wear loose dresses or pants with a loose, high, or elastic waistband, so they do not put pressure on your incision
Try to avoid lifting anything heavier than your baby for a few weeks (including groceries, laundry, and older kids.)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Keep your incision clean and dry

Gently wash the area around your incision and pat it dry with a clean towel. Remember to look out for signs of infection. If your incision is red, swollen, painful, or leaking fluid or pus, call your OB-GYN right away.
Contractions

Some people have contractions (also called afterpains) after they give birth. They are very common in people who are breastfeeding. These contractions usually feel like period cramps and can be treated with Advil or Tylenol (ask your doctor first).
Symptoms to look out for after birth
It is normal to feel very tired and sore after you have a baby. But some people can have serious complications. Be on the lookout for these signs and symptoms of a problem.
If you have any of these symptoms, call your OB-GYN or talk to a
Maven OB-GYN
for advice:
A fever that is 100.4 degrees F or higher
Pain, redness, swelling, or discharge around a vaginal tear, episiotomy, or C-section incision
Pain or burning when you pee or having to pee more often than usual
Pain in your lower back or side
Very bad pain in the lower belly
Vaginal discharge that smells bad
Red streaks on your breast(s) or lumps in your breast(s) that hurtREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have any of these symptoms, call your OB-GYN or go to the emergency room right away:
Vaginal bleeding that fills a maxi pad in 1 hour or bleeding that gets heavier over time
Pain, redness, swelling, and heat in your legs (especially around your calves)
Sudden swelling in your legs, hands, or face
Blurry vision, dizziness, and a very bad headache
Pain in the upper-right part of your belly or your shoulder
Bad chest pain or feeling like you cannot breathe
Feeling very sick to your stomach or throwing up REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have signs of an infection (like fever, redness, swelling, and discharge) with the below symptoms, call your OB-GYN or go to the emergency room right away:
Feeling very cold (chills)
Fast breathing
Fast heartbeat
Feeling confused or dizzy
How to take care of your postpartum body
Your body has gone through some major changes over the last 9 months. It might be hard, but it is important to rest when you can and let your body heal.
Get some rest

It is hard to rest when you are taking care of a new baby (and older kids, if you have them). But even short naps can help you recover. Ask a trusted loved one to watch your kids if you can while you rest.
Check for diastasis recti

Diastasis recti happens when the muscles around your belly button separate to make room for your growing baby. Most pregnant people have some separation. But if there is a lot of separation, it can cause back or pelvic pain after you give birth.
Here is how to tell if you have diastasis recti:
Lie flat on your back with your knees upREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Put one hand above your belly button and one below your belly buttonREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Lift your head and shouldersREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Use your fingers to feel for any separation between your muscles REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If the separation is 3 fingers-wide (or wider), ask your doctor about things you can do to help close the space. Or talk to a
Maven Physical Therapist
online for free advice.
Try gentle exercise (with your OB-GYN’s OK)
Light stretching, gentle yoga (try Maven’s free prenatal yoga classes here), and walking can help keep you healthy. Plus, exercise is great when you are feeling stressed, anxious, or overwhelmed.
Slow postpartum hair loss
Many new mothers lose some hair after they give birth. But it can be scary to see a lot of hair in the shower drain or on your brush. Here are some ways to keep your hair healthy:
Try to avoid using hot styling tools (like a blow dryer or curling iron)
If you have natural hair, try to use protective styles
Use a volumizing shampoo
Try to avoid very tight ponytails or braids
Try to eat mostly healthy foods
Your body needs lots of vitamins, nutrients, and water to heal from labor and delivery. Plus, eating healthy foods when you can will give you more energy.
Eat healthy foods when you can
. Fresh, canned, or frozen veggies and fruits, cereal with milk, brown rice, beans, eggs, whole wheat bread, peanut butter, tortillas, cheese, and yogurt are all good options.
Drink plenty of water
to stay hydrated, especially if you are breastfeeding.
Sign up for W.I.C. benefits
here
. These benefits can help lower the cost of healthy foods.
Take care of your mental health
Changes to your hormones, poor sleep, and stress can have a big impact on your mood after you give birth. Here are some ways to take care of your mental health.
Talk about it.
Feeling anxious, depressed, or angry? You are not alone. A lot of people have these feelings after they give birth.
Maven Mental Health Providers
can give you a safe space to talk about it. Make an online appointment at any time for free.
Try to get out at least once every day.
Being home with your kids can feel lonely sometimes. A short trip to the grocery store or a walk around your block can help.
Learn how to manage everyday stress.
Some easy ways are breathing exercises, talking to a loved one, or listening to your favorite song.
Look for the signs of postpartum mental health conditions.
Long-lasting, strong feelings of sadness, anxiety, or anger could be a sign of a postpartum mental health condition, like depression or anxiety.
Here are the symptoms
to look out for and how to find a mental health provider. You can talk to a
Mental Health Provider on Maven
anytime at no cost.
Your sex life after giving birth
Having sex after you give birth is a personal decision. Only you can decide when you are ready. But doctors do have some recommendations when you are recovering from birth.
Talk to your doctor about birth control.
It is possible to get pregnant right away after giving birth. If you do not want to get pregnant (or want to
space out your pregnancies

), ask your doctor about birth control options like the pill, an IUD, or condoms.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKHow many kids you want and how close in age you want them to be is a personal choice. But pregnancies and births that are very close together have some health risks for you and baby, like problems with your blood or early birth. If you want kids that are close in age, talk to your OB-GYN about ways to reduce these risks.
Ask your doctor how long you should wait to have sex.
Most providers say you should avoid vaginal sex for 4 to 6 weeks after giving birth. This also applies to people who had C-sections.
Go at your own pace.
Do not feel pressured to have sex right away. If you are not ready to have sex, tell your partner. There are a lot of other things you can do to be intimate (if you are ready).
Maven Sex Coaches
are here to help with any worries you have.
Know sex might feel different after giving birth.

It is common for sex to feel different or even painful right after you have a baby. Especially if you have a vaginal tear or episiotomy. Using lubricant and taking a pain reliever (like Advil or Tylenol) can help. If sex is painful for several months after giving birth, tell your doctor.
Free classes you can take on Maven
Maven has free, on-demand classes that can help you recover after birth. Visit the Library for classes like:
Postpartum recovery 101
Newborn care 101
Breastfeeding 101
Newborn and infant sleep 101
Spotting the signs of postpartum depression and anxiety
We are here to help
The postpartum period is not easy. But remember, Maven Providers are here to help you any day, any time, at no cost.
Explore our providers now
Sources
Mayo Clinic: C-section recovery
Mayo Clinic: Postpartum care

title.en-US: Signs of depression and anxiety during pregnancy, and how to get help

content.value: What you need to know:
Perinatal depression or anxiety can happen during pregnancy or after your baby is born.
Some people have both depression and anxiety.
Talking to a mental health provider is the most helpful treatmentREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
When you are pregnant, changes to your hormones, poor sleep, and stressful things in your daily life can all affect your mood and mental health. You might feel happy one day and sad the next.

Some pregnant people have very strong, long-lasting feelings of sadness, emptiness, or nervousness. Their feelings can change the way they think and act. These can be signs of a mental health condition, like
perinatal depression or anxiety
Keep reading to learn more and how to get help.
Remember:
Maven Mental Health Providers
can give you a safe space to talk about how you are feeling. Schedule a free appointment or message our providers now.
If you are thinking about hurting yourself or someone else, call the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline at 988 right away. Or go to the emergency room and tell them you are pregnant and need help.
What are perinatal depression and anxiety?

Perinatal depression and anxiety are mental health conditions that can happen when someone is pregnant or after their baby is born. “Perinatal” means during pregnancy or during the first year of your baby’s life.
Perinatal depression and anxiety share many signs and causes. Some people have both conditions at the same time.
Learn about other perinatal mood disorders
What are the signs of depression or anxiety?
Here are some important facts to know:
REPLACEWITHASSET
How can I get help?
If you think you have perinatal depression or anxiety, it is important to get help right away. Getting support while you are pregnant can help ease these feelings after baby is born, too.

A mental health provider can diagnose you and provide treatment. You can talk to a mental health provider in their office or online. Certain clinical social workers can diagnose and treat perinatal depression and anxiety, too.

Many health insurance plans and Medicaid have mental health benefits, including online or in-person therapy that is either fully covered or with a low co-pay. You might need a prescription from your doctor or OB-GYN. But insurance and Medicaid will cover most types of mental health therapy.
How do I find a mental health provider?
To find a provider that accepts your health insurance
Visit your insurance website or state’s Medicaid website
Or call the phone number on your health insurance card
If you’re having trouble, contact your Maven Care Advocate  for helpREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
To talk to a provider online for free on Maven:
Message your Maven Care Advocate  for advice on who to meet with
Or look through
Maven’s Mental Health Providers
to find a provider you would like to talk to on video chat or by message on your phone or computer at no cost
Medical treatment for perinatal depression and anxiety

Some people with perinatal depression or anxiety have to take medication to feel better. This always requires a prescription from a doctor or psychiatrist (a doctor who can treat mental health problems with medicine).
If you are given medication, talk to your psychiatrist
and
your OB-GYN to make sure it is safe to take during pregnancy.

Some health insurance plans and some state Medicaid programs cover prescription medication and some do not. Make sure you check your benefits by calling your health insurance directly, or talk to your Maven Care Advocate  for help understanding what is included in your plan.
We are here for you
Perinatal depression and perinatal anxiety can feel very scary, but you are not alone. There are ways to get better. Talk to your OB-GYN or a
Maven Mental Health Provider
to get started.
Sources
Mayo Clinic
Postpartum International

title.en-US: Baby sleep: What to expect from birth to 2 years

content.value: What you need to know:
Practice safe sleep to protect baby from danger, like sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) and choking.
Newborns sleep a lot, but for short amounts of time. As baby grows, they will sleep less during the day and more at night.
Newborns cannot tell when it is daytime or nighttime, so they wake up a lot at night.
If you need help, talk to a
Maven Sleep Coach
for free! REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Figuring out baby sleep is hard (and tiring). If you are up all night, you are not alone. But there are things you can do to help your little one get some zzz’s.
Here is everything you need to know about baby sleep, so everyone in the family can feel happy, healthy, and rested.
Where should my baby sleep?
Giving your baby a safe place to sleep is one of the most important things you can do to protect them.
Here are some things you need to do to make sure your sleeping baby is safe:
Make sure your crib, playard, or bassinet meets safety standards by checking
cpsc.gov
Always put baby to sleep on a firm, flat surface in a crib, playard, or bassinet.
Always put baby to sleep on their back, not their tummy or side.

Make sure baby’s sleep area is completely empty, with only a tightly-fitted bottom sheet. Blankets, bumpers, toys, or any other item can cause suffocation. Do not let other kids sleep in baby’s crib or playard with them.
Do not bring your baby in your bed to sleep. This can raise the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS), choking, and suffocation.
Read more important sleep safety tips for baby
here.
If you are not sure if your baby’s sleep area is safe, video chat or message a
Maven Pediatric Sleep Coach
or a
Maven Pediatrician
for help.
How do I know if my baby is tired?
Not every baby will show the same signs of sleepiness. But some common signs baby is tired are:
Looking away from you
Acting cranky or fussy
Yawning
Rubbing their eyes
Their eyes turn red or pinkREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If your baby starts to show these signs, it is a good idea to get them ready for their nap or bedtime. If you wait too long, your baby might become overtired (which means too tired). When a baby is overtired, they can be very fussy. They might also have a hard time falling asleep or staying asleep. And as babies become toddlers, they may become hyperactive when overtired.
How much sleep does my baby need?

Remember: every baby is different. Some need more or less sleep than others. It will also depend on their age and their naps. For example, babies who take longer or more naps will need less sleep at night. Babies who take shorter or fewer naps will need more sleep at night.
Here is how much average sleep a baby needs in a 24-hour period:
REPLACEWITHASSET
Remember, these are averages. Your baby may naturally need more or less sleep.
If you are worried your baby is getting too much sleep or not enough sleep, contact a
Maven Pediatric Sleep Coach
for free advice.
How do I know if my baby is getting enough sleep?
Not every baby will follow the same sleep schedule. The most important thing is that your baby seems happy and rested when they are awake.
How can I get my baby ready for sleep?
Having a bedtime routine you or another caregiver do every night can help your baby sleep better. Some things you can do to help baby get ready for sleep are:
Lower the lights
Turn off screens or loud sounds a few hours before bedtime
Take a warm bath (remember to never leave baby alone in the tub)
Sing songs or lullabies
Read a book
Rock or cuddle with themREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Babies and toddlers cannot tell time. But having a bedtime routine you do every night can give them signs that it is time for sleep. Try to do your routine at the same time, in the same order if you can.
Doing a shorter version of your bedtime routine can also help babies nap during the day. For example, you might skip the bath, but sing lullabies and read a book.
How can I help my baby fall asleep?
Babies usually do not know how to put themselves to sleep. And when they wake up in the middle of the night, they might not know how to put themselves back to sleep.
Many parents like to help their baby fall asleep by rocking them, breastfeeding, or giving them a bottle.
How many times do babies eat at night?
When your baby is a newborn, they need to eat every 2 to 3 hours, including at night. You can expect to breastfeed or bottle feed your newborn 8 to 12 times in a 24 hour period.
As your baby grows, they will need fewer feedings at night. For example, by 2 months old, many babies eat every 3 to 4 hours.

Over time, some babies will naturally stop waking to eat at night. Other babies will have to be night weaned. Night weaning is when you slowly stop feeding your baby overnight, so they stop waking up as often. Night weaning is
not
recommended until baby is at least 6 months old. Be sure to check with your pediatrician before you start to drop meals.
What is sleep training? Do I have to sleep train my baby?
Some parents also use sleep training to teach their babies to fall asleep on their own.
Most pediatricians say babies
should not
be sleep trained until they are at least 4 months old. Before you try to sleep train, make sure your baby is:
Safe in their sleep space
Fed (from breastfeeding or a bottle)
In a clean, dry diaper
Not too hot and not too coldREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Some common sleep training methods are:
Cry It Out:
Put baby to bed when they are tired, but not asleep. Then you leave the room until morning, even if baby cries.
Ferber Method:

Put baby to bed when they are tired, but not asleep. You return to the room to check on them after 10 minutes, then 20 minutes, then 30 minutes if they cry. You can check on them more often or less if you want. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Sleep training will not work for every baby. And some parents choose to avoid sleep training. The important thing is that your baby seems rested and is not fussy when they are awake.
If you have questions about sleep training or need help doing it, you can chat with a
Maven Pediatric Sleep Coach
for free.
What if my baby will not go to sleep?
Newborns cannot tell the difference between daytime and nighttime. They wake up a lot during the night because they need to eat every few hours.
But if your baby has been sleeping through the night and is waking up a lot, there could be a few reasons. Some things that make a baby wake up at night include:
A sleep regression:

As your baby gets older, they might go through sleep regressions. A sleep regression is when baby’s sleep habits change and they wake up a lot at night. It is common for babies to have sleep regressions. Many babies have sleep regressions at 4 months, 6 months, 8 months, 12 months, 18 months, 2 years, and 3 years.
Baby is learning a new skill:
If your baby is learning how to roll, sit, stand, crawl, or walk, they might sleep less at night because they want to practice.
Separation anxiety:

Separation anxiety is when your baby is nervous or worried to be away from you. Many babies get separation anxiety starting around 6 months. Having separation anxiety can make it hard for your baby to go to sleep or to fall back asleep on their own if they wake up at night.
Teething:
If your baby is teething, they might feel uncomfortable and wake up at night. Talk to your baby’s doctor or a
Maven Pediatrician
about things you can do to help your baby feel better if they are teething.
Being sick:
If your baby is sick with a cold or other illness, they might wake up a lot. A
Maven Pediatrician
can give you free advice on how to help your baby feel better if they are sick. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Remember, a tired baby can cry a lot. If you feel like you are getting overwhelmed or angry with your baby, put them somewhere safe (like in their sleeping area without blankets, pillows, or toys) and step away for a few minutes to calm down.

Never shake your baby, swing them by their arms or legs, or try to quiet them by putting a blanket, pillow, or something else over their face. It is OK to step away for a few minutes if baby is in a safe space, so you can calm down.
Have questions about your baby’s sleep?

Remember that every baby is different. Some babies have long naps and less sleep at night. Some babies have short naps and more sleep at night. If your baby seems rested and happy, and their sleep schedule works for your family, you are on the right track.
If you’re having trouble,
Maven Pediatric Sleep Coaches
are here to help. Make an appointment online for free baby sleep advice anytime.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
Stanford Children’s Health

title.en-US: Miscarriage: Everything you need to know

content.value: What you need to know:
A miscarriage is a pregnancy that ends before 20 weeks.
Doctors often don’t know what causes a miscarriage.
Many people who have a miscarriage have healthy pregnancies later.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Miscarriages are sadly very common, but it can still be a very hard thing to go through.
Keep reading to learn about miscarriages and what to do if you think you are having a miscarriage.
Having a miscarriage can be very emotional.
Maven Mental Health Providers
are available through message or video chat for free anytime you need to talk.
What is a miscarriage?
A miscarriage is when a pregnancy ends before 20 weeks. A miscarriage is also called an early pregnancy loss.
About 25% of pregnancies may end in miscarriage. There isn’t an exact number because many people do not realize they are pregnant when they have a miscarriage.
When do miscarriages happen?
Most miscarriages happen during the first trimester (the first 12 weeks of pregnancy). Miscarriages can also happen during the second trimester (weeks 13 to 19 of pregnancy), but it is not as common.
What causes a miscarriage?

Doctors usually don’t know why a person had a miscarriage. But about 50% of miscarriages are caused by problems with the baby’s chromosomes and are completely out of your control. Chromosomes carry genes (genes give a person their unique traits). If a baby has too many or not enough chromosomes, there can be problems and a pregnancy may end.
Some other causes of miscarriages are:
Problems with the uterus (the womb) or cervix (the opening to the uterus)
Infections, like STIs/STDs (tell your doctor right away if you think you have a sexually transmitted infection)
Health conditions, like thyroid disease or diabetes
What doesn’t cause a miscarriage?
Miscarriages are not caused by having sex, exercising, falling, or working. Remember: nothing you did caused a miscarriage. It is
not
your fault.
How do I know if I’m having a miscarriage?
The signs of a miscarriage are different for everyone. But the main things to look for are
cramping like you have your period
and
bleeding from your vagina

. Many people have both. Some people don’t have any signs of a miscarriage. They don’t learn they have miscarried until later. This is called a missed or silent miscarriage because the normal signs are not there.
Look for these signs:
Cramping
They might feel like your period, then get stronger
They can go away and come back
You might feel cramps in your belly and lower back
Bleeding
It can be very light or very heavy
It can be brown, red, or pink
It might go away and come back
You might pass large blood clots (clumps or small balls of sticky blood). Blood clots are scary, but a common sign of a miscarriage. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you’re pregnant and have painful cramping or bleeding, call your doctor right away.
If you have heavy, fast bleeding that does not stop (bleeding through 2 pads in 2 hours) go to the emergency room (ER) right away.
Bleeding during pregnancy can be very scary, but you are not alone. Don’t be afraid to contact your doctor or a
Maven OB-GYN
, even if you are not sure if you are having a miscarriage.
What if I don’t have a doctor?

If you think you are having a miscarriage and can’t find a doctor to see you, message your Maven Care Advocate . They can try to help you find an in-person provider who takes your insurance. They can also connect you with a
Maven provider
online for free who can give you advice.
Remember: if you’re bleeding through 2 pads in 2 hours, go to the emergency room (ER) right away. Do not wait to speak to a doctor. Heavy bleeding can be very dangerous.
How will a doctor know if I had a miscarriage?

If you have the signs of a miscarriage, try to see your doctor right away. They need to do tests to make sure you are OK. They might do a blood test, pelvic exam, or ultrasound (a test that looks inside your womb). These tests will tell them if you have had a miscarriage.
Some people have cramps and light bleeding (called spotting) early in pregnancy and don’t have a miscarriage. Seeing a doctor can tell you for sure. Contact your doctor or a
Maven provider
if you have questions or if something is worrying you.
What is the treatment for a miscarriage?

When you have a miscarriage, it is important for your body to pass tissue. If any tissue stays inside, you can get an infection. Sometimes your body can pass the tissue naturally at home. But if your body doesn’t pass the tissue, you might need to take medicine or have surgery to remove it.
Treatment for a miscarriage depends on how far into pregnancy you are.
If you had a miscarriage in the first trimester:
You may be able to pass the tissue naturally at home.

This option does not require medical treatment. But it will take the longest time. It’s important to call your doctor right away if you have heavy bleeding, bad pain, or a fever. These can be signs of an infection.
Your doctor may give you medicine to help your body pass the tissue.
This medication can help you pass the tissue quickly. It takes 24 to 48 hours for most people. But if your body does not pass all of the tissue, you might have to take a few doses of medication.
Your doctor may recommend surgery to remove the tissue if you do not want to wait and do not want to take medicine.
This surgery is called dilation and curettage (D&C). During the surgery, your doctor will open your cervix (the opening to the uterus) and use a small vacuum to remove the tissue.
If you had a miscarriage in the second trimester:
Your doctor may give you medicine to help your body pass the tissue.
Your doctor may recommend surgery to remove the tissue. There are two kinds of surgery:
Dilation and curettage (D&C):
During this surgery, your doctor will open your cervix (the opening to the uterus) and use a small vacuum to remove the tissue.
Dilation and evacuation (D&E):

This surgery is usually used for second trimester miscarriages. During this surgery, your doctor will open your cervix and use medical tools to remove the tissue. Your doctor might offer to put you to sleep during this surgery.
Is it normal to feel emotional after a miscarriage?

There’s no one way you should feel after a miscarriage. Some people feel sad, worried, angry, or guilty. It’s normal to feel a lot of emotions after a pregnancy loss. Losing a pregnancy is a very hard thing to go through. But talking to a family member, friend, or loved one can help. So can talking to a mental health provider.
Remember you are not alone. You can text or video chat with a
Maven Mental Health Provider
for free support.
How long does it take to recover from a miscarriage?

Depending on how long you were pregnant, it can take a few weeks to a few months to get better. You might have pregnancy hormones in your body for 1 to 2 months after a loss. But most people get their periods again 4 to 6 weeks after a miscarriage.

Many people feel emotional after they have a miscarriage. It’s OK to feel sad, angry, confused, or worried. It’s also normal to feel like you lost a loved one or to feel numb. It can take some time to feel better emotionally. Don’t be afraid to ask your family members or friends for support.
You can also talk to a
Maven Mental Health Provider
at any time for free. We are here for you.
Can I get pregnant again after a miscarriage?
Most people who have a miscarriage have healthy pregnancies later. But everyone is different. If you want to get pregnant again, talk to your doctor about when is a good time to try.
Most people can try to get pregnant after having a period. Check with your doctor or a
doctor on Maven
. If you need medical tests to figure out why you miscarried, you might have to wait longer.

If you don’t feel ready to try to get pregnant again, that’s OK. It might take some time to feel ready after having a miscarriage. You might want to use birth control or condoms because some people can get pregnant right after a miscarriage. If you want to talk about it,
Maven Mental Health Providers
can help.
Is it possible to have more than one miscarriage?

Sadly, some people can have more than one miscarriage. About 1% of people have two or more miscarriages. They are called repeat miscarriages or recurrent miscarriages. But take comfort that about 65% of people who have repeat miscarriages go on to have healthy pregnancies.
Need help?
If you have any questions during your pregnancy,
ask us
. You can video chat or message any question to any Maven provider for free.
Sources
March of Dimes
Planned Parenthood

title.en-US: Formula feeding 101

content.value: What you need to know:
You can get formula at grocery stores, drugstores, online, and through your local Women, Infants, and Children program (WIC).
All formulas made in the United States are safe and have all the nutrition your baby needs.
Your pediatrician can help you choose the formula that is just right for your baby.
You will be able to bond with your baby while formula feeding, just as you would with breastfeeding.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Feeding your baby formula is a personal decision, and one that you can make (along with your baby’s
pediatrician
) with peace of mind. Formula feeding is a great way to give your baby all the good nutrition they need to grow. And we’re here to help you do it confidently!
There are a few steps to formula feeding, and if you have any questions after reading you can reach out to a
Maven Pediatrician
online for free at any time.
How do I let the hospital know I want my baby to have formula?
Make sure you let your care team know if you plan to give your baby formula—either along with breast milk, or only formula.
Let your pediatrician know this before you deliver if you can, so they can help you choose a formula that’s right for your baby.
Benefits of formula feeding
Besides having the vitamins and calories your baby needs to grow, formula feeding has other perks, too. These include:
Other trusted loved ones can help feed baby
You have an idea of how much baby is eating
You don’t have to change anything about your own diet if baby has allergies
What kinds of formulas are there?
Formula can come in powder form, which needs to be mixed with water according to the steps below.

It comes in liquid form as well, and this kind is ready to be fed to baby and does not need to be mixed with water. Just shake and serve. Liquid formula is usually more expensive and might not be covered by your local Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) program, though, so be sure to check.
How do I choose a formula for my baby?
You can get help picking the right kind of formula for your baby from your baby’s pediatrician, or with help from a
Maven Pediatrician
There are several kinds of formula. They are:
REPLACEWITHASSET
Where do I buy formula?

Formula is sold at almost all drugstores, grocery stores, and places like Walmart or Target. Many different kinds of formula are covered by WIC–though you might need a prescription or doctor’s note if your baby has a very specific need. Find out by calling the number on the back of your WIC card, or by looking
here
if you need a special formula for baby’s diet.
How do I know if a formula is right for my baby?
If your baby has any allergies or a sensitive tummy from their formula, you’ll see that pretty quickly with:
How they act:
Is baby fussy and cranky or do they seem to get full and happy after a feeding?
How their diapers look:
Does their poop seem hard and dark? This could be a sign of constipation.
Is there blood in their stool?
Sounds scary, but usually switching formulas is a simple fix. Talk to baby’s pediatrician if you notice this.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

When starting a formula, it might be helpful to watch baby’s behavior pretty closely for a few days. This is important to see if you notice any of the signs below that the formula might not be right for them.
How do I make a bottle of formula?
If you’ve never made a bottle of formula before, it can seem a bit overwhelming. Here are 7 easy steps you can follow, and you’ll be a bottle-making pro before you know it!
1. Wash your hands
Scrub your hands with soap and hot water for 20 seconds before handling any formula or bottles (tip: sing your A, B, C’s and that will be about the recommended time).
2. Use clean bottles and nipples

Only use bottles, nipples, and other parts that have been properly cleaned. You can run them through a hot-water and heat drying cycle in your dishwasher, or hand wash with hot water and soap and then allow to air dry.
You can also buy a bottle sterilizer (or put one on your registry).
3. Wipe down your work area

Clean the surface you’ll put everything together on. Don’t want to wipe the counters every time? Consider buying a silicone mat you could use just to do bottle prep, and then give the mat a rinse or run in the dishwasher after.
4. Measure the formula and water
Follow the instructions on the package to measure out the water first, then add the powder.
Always put in the exact amounts outlined
. If the formula is too weak, your baby won’t get the nutrition they need. If it’s too strong, it can make your baby’s belly go into overtime (and lead to a cranky/gassy baby).
5. Use clean water

Most babies can have formula made with whatever water is safe enough for you to drink yourself. For babies under 3 months, it’s recommended to boil the water first and then mix it with the formula to sterilize it—then let it cool before giving it to baby.

To save time, you can do this boiling method once in the morning and prepare all of the day’s bottles, then put them in the fridge until needed. Once your baby isn’t a newborn anymore, it’s fine to use water straight from a bottle or tap.
6. Check the temperature

Room temperature formula suits baby just fine. If your baby likes it a little warmer or if it has been in the fridge, run the bottle under warm (not hot) water from the faucet for a minute or so (taking care not to get water in the bottle’s nipple).
Never use a microwave to warm a bottle, as it can heat unevenly and burn baby’s mouth.
7. Serve or store
Once the formula is made, you have the following options:
Use it up

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKA prepped bottle of formula should be eaten within two hours. If baby has already started drinking from it, it should be used within 1 hour to avoid bacteria growth (yep, even if it’s refrigerated).
Stick it in the fridge
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKFor bottles you’re not going to use right away, you can store them in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours.
When in doubt, throw it out

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKGet rid of any remaining liquid in the bottle after baby’s done eating if it’s been more than 1 hour. The leftover spit from baby’s mouth could lead to bacteria growth in the milk.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
How to hold baby while feeding with a bottle

Hold baby in your arms with their head slightly raised in one elbow, while the other hand holds the bottle. Never give a bottle to baby while they’re lying flat on their back. This makes it hard for them to swallow and could cause baby to choke.
Burping

Burping helps your baby get rid of gas after eating. A gassy baby isn’t usually a happy one, so burping them after every feeding is important. You can do this by holding baby upright against your chest and lightly patting their upper back until they burp.
Still have questions about formula feeding?
Formula feeding might seem like a big task to take on if you’re just getting started. Your
Maven Pediatrician
is on team “help baby grow” with you, and is available to you for free anytime.

title.en-US: Pumping 101

content.value: What you need to know:
Lactation consultants are here to help you on Maven.
You can still pump and breastfeed your baby (or formula feed!).
Cleaning your hands and pump parts is very important to protect baby from bacteria and illness!REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Pumping, or getting milk from your breasts, might sound intimidating at first. How does it even work? And what’s up with all those parts? Maybe you’ve heard friends talk about their difficulties.
While pumping breast milk may not be your favorite part of parenthood, it definitely has its pros.
Read on to learn everything you need to know to set yourself up for pumping success. After reading,
Maven Lactation Consultants
can help you figure out any other questions you have—everything from how to use your pump to storing milk and more. Book a free appointment or
message them
anytime.
What are the benefits of pumping?
There are many pros of being able to give baby breast milk in a bottle, including:
Other people can help feed your baby, whether that’s a partner, loved one, or a daycare provider.
It can also help you to know how much baby is eating every time.
You can help your baby continue to get the benefits of breast milk even when you return to work.
Having a small stash of breast milk stored in your fridge or freezer can give you peace of mind if you need to be away from baby longer than expected
Can I give baby breast milk and formula?
Breast milk isn’t all or nothing. You can feed your baby breast milk exclusively (meaning this is the only thing they eat) you can give baby breast milk and formula.
You can read more about feeding them together
here.
When should I start pumping?

You can begin pumping a few weeks after baby is born if you plan to breastfeed and pump. If you don’t plan on feeding directly from the breast, it’s good to start pumping within a few hours after your baby is born. This helps keep up supply and demand (more on this below), and can help you give your baby the rich first milk called colostrum.
What’s colostrum?
Colostrum is the first milk your body makes. You might hear it called “liquid gold”.

When you first give birth, your breasts may not feel full yet because you will make colostrum before you make milk. It may not look like much (it’s usually semi-clear or yellowish), but colostrum is full of nutrients and all your baby needs in those first few days.
If you are pumping and not feeding directly from the breast, ask your hospital nurse to help you pump colostrum to feed to baby.
What kind of pump should I buy?

You should be able to get a pump for free from your insurance. You can call the number on the back of your insurance card. Even though they don’t cover all the brands of pumps, they’ll help you figure out which ones you can get.
Here are a few pump options:
Electric (one you plug in or that uses a battery)
Manual (one you pump by hand)
Single or double pumps (for one breast or both)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Most people use a double electric pump to get the most breast milk and keep their supply up. Single manual pumps are a great just-in-case backup.
What is supply and demand?
Your body keeps up your breast milk supply based on how much you ask of it to create milk. You might hear this called supply and demand.
Having baby feed from the breast and pumping both “demand” milk from your body. This tells it to continue making more!
In order to maintain your milk supply, try to pump within one hour from when baby is fed a bottle.
How often should I pump?
This depends on your breastfeeding goals and how old your baby is. You can work with a
Lactation Consultant
on Maven for free to find the right schedule for you, but here is a general guide:
REPLACEWITHASSET
If you are pumping at work to have bottles available for childcare, then you likely will need to pump the same number of times a bottle is given while you are separated from your child.
You can also add in a pump session after the first feed of the day, and after the baby goes to bed at night. This might help you pump a little less while you are at work during the daytime hours.
Need help? Talk to a
Lactation Consultant at Maven
for free.
How should pumping be balanced with nursing?
This again depends on your breastfeeding goals. In general, pumping should replace any missed nursing sessions in order to keep your supply up and have breast milk available in a bottle for baby.
How should I clean a breast pump?
Your pump parts and bottles need to be washed sanitized (more on that below) after every use and sanitized once a day.
How to wash pump parts
You can wash your pump parts and bottles by hand or on the top rack of the dishwasher.
If washing by hand, don’t let pump parts touch the sink Use a clean bowl or wash basin.
Wash all parts with cool water first to rinseREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Let them soak for 5 minutes in warm soapy waterREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
After the soak, wash with a clean dish rag or scrub brush that is only used for pump partsREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Rinse with clear water before placing on a clean towel or dish rack to dry
How to sanitize pump parts
When you need to clean your parts with more than just soapy water, this is called sanitizing. You do this once a day, and can do this with either the boil or steam method.
Boil method
Separate all pump parts that have come in contact with breast milk or breastsREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Bring a pot of water to a boil (enough water to cover all the pump parts)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Once boiling, carefully place the pump parts in the boiling water and leave for 10 minutesREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
After 10 minutes of boiling, turn the water offREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Remove the sanitized parts with tongs (or another utensil that can grip) so you don’t burn yourself once the water REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKcools a bitREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Make sure to place sanitized parts on a clean towel or drying rack to air dryREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Once fully dry store in a clean, dry placeREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Steam method:
A microwave and a microwave steam product are needed for this. There are freestanding steam sanitizers as well!
Follow the directions listed on the microwave steam sterilizer or microwave steam bag. Typically, you’ll do something like:
Add water and pre-rinse separated pump parts REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Add pump parts to the steamer or bagREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Place in microwave for a few minutes depending on the directionsREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Let the parts cool and air dry if needed!REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Once fully dry store in a clean, dry place
What helps to increase breast milk supply?
Very few things raise or help you keep supply like pumping! The more often you breastfeed or pump, the more milk your body will produce (supply and demand again!).
If you want to get more breast milk, increase the number of times you pump in a 24 hour period.
Breast milk production hormones are highest in the early morning hours. If your goal is more breast milk for bottles, then add extra pumping sessions to those early morning times if you’re able.
Here are some other tips to try: Use the right flange size (the funnel-shaped piece that fits over your nipple–more on that below!)
Replace any worn down pump parts especially if you pump frequently
Drink lots of water (think 12 glasses a day!)
Give your body lots of nutritious foods every 3-4 hours if possible. Foods like almonds, melons, and oatmeal may help.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you want to create a stash of breast milk to have in the fridge or freezer, you can pump for a few minutes after nursing.
What’s a flange, and why does the size matter?

A flange is the funnel-shaped piece of a pump that fits around your nipple. It’s important that it fits well and can kind of suction around the nipple to help pull out milk. Your nipple should move freely inside of the flange without rubbing the sides of the tunnel-shaped part of it.
Most pumps come with a standard 21mm and 24mm size, but these don’t fit everyone. You might have to buy larger or smaller sizes if this is the case for you.
Your pump manual should come with a guide to help find out what flange size you need, or check out your brand of pump’s website.
Birth isn’t the only time they’ll change: your nipples can change sizes throughout your breastfeeding journey, too. It’s not uncommon for you to need to change flange sizes later.
What about pumping at work?

Your job is required to give you time and a private place to pump. You might be able to find an affordable cooler or small lunch box to store breast milk in from Facebook Marketplace, Walmart, or even through local second hand stores.
Before you return to work, ask for a private spot where you can pump. There are federal laws your workplace must follow, including providing you a private space and time to pump.
To keep a good milk supply, pump as often as you would feed your baby (usually every 2-3 hours).
Skipping pumping sessions can decrease your supply, meaning you start to make less breast milk.

Think about how often you will have to pump and how much time you will have for each session to help you figure out which is the best pump for you. For example, if you’ll be pumping at work, a double electric will be quicker than a single manual pump.
It’s important to know that your job is required by law to give you time to pump at work.
