Maven Career Coaches
are available to help you speak up for yourself and your needs when returning to work and pumping.
Find more details on pumping at work and what your rights are.
What other supplies will I need?
Even though it seems overwhelming, thankfully most of the supplies you need can be reused and bought secondhand. Besides a breast pump, you’ll need:
Milk storage bottles or bags (find them at Walmart, Target, or even some grocery stores)
A small cooler or lunchbox to keep milk cold when you’re out and about
Hands-free nursing bra (you can take a regular sports bra and cut out circles to fit the flanges for a cheaper hack)
Nipple cream with lanolin (this is safe for both you and baby)
Have more questions?
Help from a
Lactation Consultant
is available on Maven anytime, and you can read even more about feeding your baby in
this guide
Source
Centers for Disease Control

title.en-US: How to find childcare

content.value: What you need to know:
Popular options for childcare are a trusted family member or a childcare center. There are also private options, like sharing a nanny or babysitter.
Have a list of questions ready to help you decide if it’s a good fit for your family.
Even though all licensed childcare centers have to be inspected, you can still ask safety questions if you have concerns.
State and local governments might be able to help you with childcare vouchers or help you make payments. You can also call your
state’s Women, Infants, and Children
(WIC) program to learn about services and stipends.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Choosing a place for your child to be while you’re at work can feel hard. You have more options than you might realize, but this can also make it feel overwhelming. Here are some helpful ideas and tips to help you choose childcare for your little one.
You also have free support on Maven. Message your Maven Care Advocate  to help you make a plan.
What are my childcare options?
Even though it might feel like every daycare or preschool has a waitlist, there are options out there. You can find childcare:
In an in-home daycare
In a private daycare or childcare center
In a preschool setting for older children
Through a shared nanny with other families
Through friends or family
Where are some places to search for childcare?
There are lots of places to find care, but you’ll want to make sure it fits your schedule, lifestyle, and budget.
For personal or in-home daycare, search:
Care.com
Sittercity.com
Urbansitter.com
Each of the websites above offers different kinds of childcare. You can find things like:
Nanny-sharing (where you and another family or two split costs of childcare by paying the same nanny or babysitter)
Tutoring (or after school care for older children, in your home or theirs)
And more!REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
These websites do charge a monthly fee to use their services, but there are often free trial periods to try it out.
For government or childcare centers like daycare, search:
The United States General Services
website
Or a
Head Start
program that helps your little one get ready for school. Head Start programs are for ages 0-5.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
To ask local parents, try:
Social media (Facebook groups are great and might already offer childcare-related searches for free)
Asking your pediatrician
Chatting with other parents at the park or other kid-friendly placesREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Call your
state’s Women, Infants, and Children
(WIC) program for more childcare services and stipends offered. You can also check in with your Care Advocate for free at any time to be connected with more child and care experts.
What should I ask to make sure it’s a good fit for my child and our family’s needs?
Here’s a list of questions to ask a childcare provider you might be interested in.
Are you licensed?

This might sound like a silly question, but if you can’t find this information on a care center’s website or if it’s someone caring for children in their home, it’s a good thing to ask.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What are your rates?
Be sure to get this information upfront, and find out if they have any scholarships or if your local government office might help with payments. This can be through
Head Start
or other programs like it.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Are you CPR and First Aid Certified?
It’s important that you ask this question. Not all in-home centers require their employees to have these life-saving trainings.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What are your adult-to-child ratios?
In other words, how many children are being cared for by 1 adult at a time? Here’s a chart to consider when you’re going to visit a place you’re interested in for your child or children.
REPLACEWITHASSET
What food and drinks are provided?
Some daycare centers provide formula or snacks, so be sure to ask if this is something that they include in their fees.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What is the discipline policy?

As a parent, your child’s safety is something you’re always thinking about. Be sure to ask if the discipline policies they use feel good to you and if they are something you feel is acceptable for your child, too.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Is there a phone number I can call or text for child updates, if needed?

Some daycare centers can give an update during the day, and others can’t. It might be easier to find one that can in a smaller or in-home setting. Otherwise, they should let you know how your child was when you pick them up.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Are your staff all background checked?
Ask if all of the people who will be interacting with your child at a childcare center have been background checked.

If you are choosing in-home care with a nanny or other provider (in your own home or in someone else’s) they can still provide you with background check information. This will help you feel more peace of mind and comfort in choosing them.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What are your hours?
In bigger cities, you might even find 24/7 care centers! Make sure their hours fit with your needs for work or your other children’s schedules, too.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What if my child is sick?
Find out if the care option you’re looking at has had long periods of being closed in the past, how they handled them, and what their policies are for things like a COVID-19 outbreak.
Ask if they have specific fever or sickness rules you’d need to follow.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What are your COVID policies?

Speaking of COVID, it’s a good idea to find out if the center matches with your wishes for child safety. Find out if they require masking, testing, and if they enforce quarantine rules by the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention (CDC)—more on that
here
.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Are you open year-round?
Some places keep a “school year” schedule and might close during the summer. Ask about this now so there are no surprises later.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What am I expected to bring for my child each day?
If you have to send food, diapers, or additional clothing it’s good to know in advance before registering your child somewhere.
What should I look for when I tour a childcare center or home?
When you visit a daycare or an in-home daycare, it’s great to take a look around. For example, check if they have:
First-aid kits ready and visible
Smoke detectors
A clean environment (except for toys and children running around, of course!)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

You’ll always have more questions to consider if you have a child with different needs, allergies, or conditions. Ask if they have experience with these things, and a good caregiver will be glad to help ease your mind on these topics that matter to you.
No question or concern is off limits when it comes to your child and keeping them safe and cared for while you’re at work or away.
Sources
Childcare.gov: Ratios and group sizes

title.en-US: 7 steps to finding a great pregnancy provider and hospital

content.value: What you need to know:
Your safety and comfort are the most important things when choosing a doctor. Your pregnancy doctor should feel like someone you can trust.
Hospitals have different rules and C-section rates. Get to know them and know that you have options.
If you don’t feel comfortable, safe, or heard, you can switch doctors at any time during your pregnancy.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Choosing a provider and hospital might not feel like the most fun thing on your baby to-do list, but it’s probably the most important. Read on for tips on how to choose the right provider and hospital for you.
If you ever need help you can always reach out to your Maven Care Advocate  anytime.
1. Find a provider who accepts your health insurance

Some people choose the hospital they want to deliver at first. Some choose the provider. Either works, but if making sure your prenatal care is fully covered by your health insurance is important to you, it helps to start by finding a pregnancy provider who accepts your insurance. Here’s how:
Check your insurance’s website or your state’s Medicaid site. They often have the ability to search for doctors.
Call the number on your insurance card.
Choose a few providers you’re interested in so you can have options if they aren’t taking new patients.
Remember, you can switch doctors at any time during your pregnancy if it doesn’t feel like a good match so it helps to have a list.
2. Look for someone nearby
Look for a provider nearby to make it easier to get to appointments (you’ll have a lot!).

Doctors are affiliated with certain hospitals and can only deliver babies at these hospitals, so choosing a doctor near you can help you make sure they can deliver at a hospital near you. This is important so that you feel comfortable with the doctor, or group of doctors, who will help deliver your baby.
3. Choose between an OB-GYN or Midwife

Most pregnant people will work with an OB-GYN or a midwife as their primary care provider for pregnancy and birth. This is the person you will see for all of your prenatal appointments. You can also choose to work with both! We’ll explain the differences:
OB-GYN:
This is a provider who is medically trained in pregnancy, labor, delivery, and postpartum (or the time period after giving birth). They can also perform Cesareans (C-sections).
Midwife:

These providers are not doctors, but they do most of the things an OB-GYN can do except they cannot perform C-sections. Midwives may have a more holistic approach and support unmedicated or medicated birth.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you already have an OB-GYN you like, then it might make sense to stick with them while you’re pregnant. Switching to a new provider is also totally okay. The person you see just once a year for a quick health exam may not be the person you want helping with your pregnancy and delivery.
Find out more about midwives and insurance coverage by calling your health insurance company or visiting their website (or your state’s
Medicaid website
if covered by Medicaid). You can also call the number on the back of your card.
You may also want to have a doula during delivery, in addition to your main pregnancy provider.
Doula:
Think of a doula as a support person who can coach you through labor and delivery. They are not doctors. They are there to help you feel comfortable and to speak up for you.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Doulas are covered by some health insurance and by Medicaid in a few states. Contact your health insurance company or your state’s
Medicaid website
for more information.
Learn more about what doulas do
4. Read reviews and ask around

The best reviews (and the most honest ones) will usually come from someone you know. Be mindful to listen to people’s thoughts and experiences, but know that you and your baby are going to have your own experience.
When you find a few providers you’re interested in, search for provider reviews online
Ask other pregnant people or parents in your area if they have recommendations, too!
5. Call them up!
Once you have a list of providers you’re interested in, call up their offices with these questions:
Confirm that they take your health insuranceREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Ask if they’re accepting new patientsREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Ask which hospital or hospitals they deliver atREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Ask if you can have an initial consultation with themREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If they meet your needs, make an initial appointment. It might seem like a lot of legwork, but this will be a good chance to get to know if they’re a good match for you. Remember, if you don’t feel comfortable with your provider, you can try a new one at any time during your pregnancy.
6. Have an initial consultation appointment
At your first visit ask the provider these questions to help you decide if they’ll be a good partner:
Will you have all of your prenatal appointments during pregnancy with them? Or will you meet with other OB-GYNs and midwives as well?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Which hospital do they deliver at?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Will they be around during your due date? If not, who else may you work with?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

What are their thoughts on topics that are important to you? For example, do they support medicated and unmedicated birth, vaginal birth after C-section (VBAC), breastfeeding within the first hour after birth, mental health screenings during and after pregnancy, or any other topics that are important to you?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Do they have expertise in specific conditions you may have? (Obesity, diabetes, high blood pressure, twin pregnancy, etc.)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What are their Cesarean (C-section) rates?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What are their thoughts on episiotomies? (This is a surgical cut that might be made during childbirth to prevent vaginal tearing and is not generally recommended)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What is their policy for induction? (Do they use medicines to induce you if you’re at or past your due date? Will they induce early?)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Can they tell you about the hospital they work with? What are some policies you should know about?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
After your initial consultation, ask yourself:
Did I feel heard and supported?
Did they ask me open-ended questions (not just yes/no questions)?
Did they treat me like an individual and listen to my concerns?
Do I feel like they will be a good partner in my pregnancy?
Do I feel comfortable talking to them? REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Trust your gut. It’s important to find someone you feel comfortable with and feel heard by.
7. Call up your hospital

Once you’ve found the provider you want to work with, call up the hospital they are affiliated with and make sure they are a good fit for you, too. Because your provider may not be there on delivery day, you’ll want to feel comfortable with your hospital’s staff, policies, services, and reputation, too.
Do your own homework, too, before you call. Read up on hospital reviews and ratings online.
The hospital also plays one of the most important roles in terms of C-section rates. Some hospitals have very low C-section rates, some very high. Make this a part of your search on a site like
LeapFrog Ratings
if it’s important to you to try to avoid a C-section.
Some questions to ask:
Do you take my health insurance?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Are all services covered by my health insurance?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Are there any staff members who aren’t covered by my insurance (like the anesthesiologist)?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Do you have a NICU unit on site?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Do you have the ability to handle an emergency C-section, if needed?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What are your C-section rates? REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What is your policy on episiotomies, using a vacuum to help with delivery, etc.?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
What pain management tools will be available to me? Do you offer epidurals, laughing gas, a pool or tub, a birthing ball, etc? REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Ask for a list of OB-GYNs and midwives who can deliver babies there (in case you want to switch providers at any point but stay at the same hospital)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Who will answer if I call and think I’m in labor?
Need help?
We’re here for you. You can message your Maven Care Advocate  anytime for free with more questions or concerns you might have.

title.en-US: How to stop drinking, drug use, and smoking while pregnant

content.value: What you need to know:
Deciding to stop any habit that’s not good for baby is an important step, and one you shouldn’t take alone.
You can talk to people who care on Maven anytime for free to help you stop drinking, smoking, or doing drugs.
Quitting some substances cold turkey can be dangerous for you and baby so always work with a provider to make a plan and get support.
Feeling sick from withdrawal might be confused with some pregnancy symptoms, and you should talk to your
provider
as soon as you can to be sure which is which.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Pregnancy can be a time for lots of changes, including quitting things you’ve gotten used to doing that could harm your baby.
Smoking, drinking, and doing drugs are dangerous for both you and for baby while you’re pregnant. It can be tough to stop doing these things, but you should know that you are not alone.
When you finish reading here, message your Maven Care Advocate  to get all of the support you need to quit with confidence.
Remember, you can message or have video chats with any
provider on Maven
for free anytime you need to to help you through this.
Using marijuana or CBD
Why it’s unhealthy for baby
Even though many states are legalizing marijuana for recreational use, using marijuana is not safe during pregnancy.
Like tobacco smoke, being around second-hand smoke from marijuana can hurt you and your baby, too. Avoid being around smoke when you are pregnant and after your baby is born.
CBD is not safe to use during pregnancy, either. It can damage your baby’s developing brain. Remember, just because a product is “natural” does not mean it is safe to use when you are pregnant.
How it affects baby
Research has found that using marijuana or CBD during pregnancy can:
Cause preterm birth
Slow down baby’s growth and development
Raise the risk of baby needing special medical care in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) after they are born
Cause developmental problems in kids later in life
Raise the risk of having a stillbirth
Smoking
Why should I stop smoking while pregnant?
Using tobacco of any kind (including cigarettes or vaping) can be harmful to baby. It can lead to issues with your pregnancy, like:
Having your baby too early
Low birth weight
Chance of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)
What are the steps I should take to stop smoking?
Reach out to your Maven Care Advocate  to find out which provider can best help. Then make a free online appointment with them.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Make a plan. Write down why you want to stop, why you need to stop, and any tips a
provider on Maven
gives you.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Call a quit-line. There are also free telephone lines that can help. If you need help quitting tobacco products, call 1-800-QUIT-NOW (7848669).REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Think about replacing smoking with something else, like something that keeps your hands and mind busy.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If your doctor gives the OK, try a nicotine replacement treatment (NRT) like a chewing gum along with other therapies your doctor says are safe.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Don’t try to quit cold turkey–this can make it much harder to quit and stick to it.
Help is available
for you anytime, day or night on Maven.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Tell your loved ones that you’re quitting so they can help and encourage you, too.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Find a local support group. Many cities and towns have in-person support groups where you can talk to people who are going through the same things and this can really help!REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Find an online support group. If you do not feel comfortable going to a support group in-person or want to be able to reach out anytime, there are lots of online support groups and forums you can try, too.
What you should know about withdrawal

Nicotine is the addictive chemical that’s in tobacco. Nicotine withdrawal is one of the hardest parts of quitting smoking. You could have more success quitting if you can get ready for these symptoms and find ways to fight them before they start.
Some withdrawal symptoms might be:
Trouble sleeping (falling asleep or staying asleep)
Getting mad or frustrated easily
Feeling anxious or nervous
Feeling sad or depressed
Drinking
Why should I stop drinking while I’m pregnant?
Drinking alcohol while you’re pregnant can harm baby and their development. Issues caused by alcohol can be lifelong for your baby. Some things that could happen are:
Higher chance of having a miscarriage
Fetal Alcohol Syndrome Disorders (FASD) which can lead to birth defects, brain development, and mental health issues
Having your baby too early
Low birth weight
Chance of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)
What are the steps I should take to stop drinking?
Reach out to your Maven Care Advocate  to find out which provider can best help.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Make a plan. Write down why you want to stop, why you need to stop, and any tips your
provider on Maven
gives.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Call a quit-line. There are free telephone lines that can help. Call 1-800-662-HELP (4357) to chat with someone.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Think about replacing alcohol with something else, especially if drinking is a social activity for you. Think about finding a new seltzer water or drink a “mocktail” (mixed drink without alcohol) when you’re out.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Don’t try to quit cold turkey–this can make it harder to stick to your goal.
Help is available
for you anytime, day or night on Maven.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Tell your loved ones that you’re quitting so they can help and encourage you, too.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Find a local support group. Many cities and towns have in-person support groups where you can talk to people who are going through the same things and can be your support system.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Find an online support group. If you do not feel comfortable going to a support group in-person or want to be able to reach out anytime, there are lots of online support groups and forums you can try, too.
What you should know about withdrawal
Alcohol withdrawal comes with some difficult side effects, too. These might include:
Shakes
Not being able to sleep
Feeling sick to your stomach
Feeling nervous or anxiousREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
It won’t be easy, but you have support. Your Maven Care Advocate  is here to help you quit and encourage you along the way.
Drug use
Why should I stop using drugs while pregnant?

Different drugs can affect your baby differently, and every baby and pregnancy is also unique. Using any drugs not given to you by your doctor while you’re pregnant could really put you and baby in danger.
Harm could happen to baby, like:
Higher chance of having a miscarriage
Stillbirth
Withdrawal symptoms in the baby after birth (
neonatal abstinence syndrome, or NAS
Having your baby too early
Low birth weight
Chance of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)
Behavioral problems
What are the steps I should take to stop using drugs?
Reach out to your Maven Care Advocate  to find out which provider can best help.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Make a plan. Write down why you want to stop using,, why you need to stop, and any tips a
provider on Maven
gives.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Call a quit-line. There are free telephone lines that can help. Call 1-800-662-HELP (4357) to chat with someone.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Don’t be around people who might try to get you to use drugs if possible.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Don’t try to quit cold turkey –
help is available
for you anytime, day or night on Maven and stopping drug use suddenly can be very dangerous for you and baby.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Tell your loved ones you’re quitting so they can encourage and support you.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Find a local support group. Many cities and towns have in-person support groups where you can talk to people who are going through the same things.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Find an online support group. If you do not feel comfortable going to a support group in-person or want to be able to reach out anytime, there are lots of online support groups and forums you can try.
What you should know about withdrawal from using drugs
If you have used drugs for a while, you might find it really hard to stop. Once you do, you could experience symptoms of withdrawal. These might be things like:
Trembling and tremors
Muscle pain or aches
Hunger or loss of appetite
Feeling extra tired
Sweating
Being easily irritated
Depression
Anxiety
Feeling sick on your stomach
Confusion
Paranoia
SeizuresREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
All of these symptoms shouldn’t be handled alone and can be dangerous to you and baby.
The decision to stop or find treatment for addiction is a brave one. This choice could help you and baby in more ways than you realize, and the sooner you talk to someone, the better. You can talk to
providers on Maven
who are here to help you through this tough time and have as healthy a pregnancy (and baby) as possible.
Sources
Centers for Disease Control (CDC) - Substance Abuse During Pregnancy
American Addiction Centers - Drug Withdrawal Symptoms

title.en-US: Perineal massage: What it is and how to do it

content.value: What you need to know:
Perineal massage uses gentle pressure to stretch the perineum (the space between your vagina and anus).
Perineal massage has been linked to lower risk of vaginal tearing during delivery, and certain postpartum complications that are linked to tearing.
Ask your pregnancy provider if perineal massage is OK for you before you try it at home. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you’re approaching your due date, you may have heard about things you can do that are “supposed” to make labor easier—like eating lots of dates to soften your cervix or drinking red raspberry leaf tea to naturally induce labor. While the verdict is still out on many, there’s some scientific evidence that one way to prep, called perineal massage, might actually help by reducing vaginal tearing during delivery.
So, what is perineal massage and does it really work? Read on to see what the experts say and how you can try it at home.
What is perineal massage?
Perineal massage uses gentle massage to stretch your perineum (the space between your vagina and your anus).

During labor, the muscles and skin around your vagina stretch and thin to let your baby pass through the birth canal more easily. Although it does stretch, the perineum isn’t quite as flexible as your vagina, and can tear from the pressure of your baby moving through the birth canal.
What are the benefits of perineal massage?
We’re not going to sugarcoat it: some vaginal tearing is common if you give birth vaginally. But doing perineal massage may reduce the risk of:
Vaginal tearing
Severe tears that extend to the perineum and anus
Scarring around the vagina and perineum
Postpartum urinary and fecal incontinence (when you can’t hold your urine or feces in due to severe vaginal tearing)

Episiotomy (an incision an OB-GYN or midwife makes to the perineum to widen the birth canal if baby is stuck or needs to be born quickly. They used to be common, but now providers only try to use episiotomies in emergency situations.
Learn more
.)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Have questions about perineal massage? Make an online appointment with a
Maven provider
for advice.
Does perineal massage work?

Maven OB-GYN Yi-Lo Yu recommends perineal massage for her patients beginning around 34 weeks of pregnancy. “Studies have shown that perineal massage reduces [tearing] that requires stitches, and reduces the need for episiotomy,” she says.
One study from the
International Urogynecology Journal

found that people who did perineal massage during the last few weeks of pregnancy were significantly less likely to have severe vaginal tearing (called third and fourth degree tears) and less likely to experience postpartum complications related to tearing.
Several studies have shown promising results, but much more research is needed. Many studies have also linked perineal massage to lower rates of episiotomy.

It’s important to remember that anything can happen during labor and delivery, and there’s no guarantee that perineal massage will completely prevent tearing. But if you feel comfortable doing it, it may be worth a shot!
Are there any risks to perineal massage?
There are a few risks to perineal massage, including:
Infection:

“The main risk of perineal massage is infection, so always be sure to wash your hands and clip your fingernails, so you don’t injure or infect the area,” says Yu. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf you have a partner who is going to help you with perineal massage, make sure they wash their hands and clip their fingernails, too. If you prefer wearing gloves (or having your partner wear them), you can buy nitrile or latex exam gloves at your local drugstore.
Stretching or stinging:

As you push down on your perineum, you’ll likely feel some stretching and pressure in your pelvic floor. Some people also feel a stinging or burning sensation. This is normal, but if you feel pain during perineal massage, stop right away.
Feeling triggered:

If you’ve experienced trauma in your past, perineal massage could bring up difficult memories or emotions. If you don’t want to do perineal massage, don’t—it’s your body and your decision. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKKnow that some OB-GYNs and midwives use perineal massage during labor, so if you don’t feel comfortable with it, be sure to tell them when labor begins. You can also add it to your
birth plan
or let your support person know it’s upsetting, so they can advocate for you. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Not sure if perineal massage is right for you? Talk to a
Maven provider
about other ways you can prepare your body for labor and delivery.
How to do perineal massage at home
Here’s how to do perineal massage starting between 34 and 36 weeks of pregnancy:
Wash your hands and make sure your fingernails are clipped short. If your partner is helping, ask them to wash their hands and check their fingernails. (You can also wear nitrile or latex gloves.)
Sit back in a comfortable position on your bed or in a warm bathtub and insert two fingers into your vagina.
Move your fingers side to side, while gently pushing down toward your rectum. Yu recommends using coconut oil, olive oil, or vaginal lubricant to make this more comfortable.
Do this for five minutes, once or twice per week until you go into labor. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Important:

Perineal massage should only be done once or twice per week—overdoing it could injure the skin and tissues around your vagina and perineum. Plus, there’s no evidence that doing perineal massage more than once or twice per week lowers the risk of tearing any further.
The bottom line

Perineal massage isn’t guaranteed to prevent tearing, but it is a simple, low-risk way to prepare your body for labor and delivery. Just make sure you (or your partner, if they help you) have clean hands and short fingernails, so you can avoid injury or infection.
If you have questions about perineal massage or labor and delivery,
Maven providers
are here to help 24/7. Make a free, online appointment now.
Sources
International Urogynecology Journal
Journal of Midwifery & Women’s Health

title.en-US: Understanding newborn sleep patterns

content.value: What you need to know
Newborns sleep a lot, even if it doesn’t happen in long spurts at a time.
How much your baby sleeps depends on what they eat, how old they are, and if they’re sick or feeling well.
Babies don’t know the difference between night and day yet, and won’t for a while (so they may be up a lot at night).
Talk to a
Pediatrician
or
Sleep Coach
on Maven anytime you need help, day or night!REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Sleep: just talking about it feels like a dream, doesn’t it? Whether you’re in the newborn haze of sleeplessness or just learning about what to expect once your baby is born, figuring out a newborn’s sleep schedule can seem like too much to tackle.
You don’t have to do it alone, though: Maven has
Sleep Coaches
Pediatricians
, and even
Mental Health Providers
at the ready to support you through the tiring times ahead.

Babies sleep in short spurts and they’re usually only awake when they need something, like a feeding or a diaper change. Read on to find out more about newborns and their sleep (or lack thereof) patterns.
A few reminders about safe sleep
It’s important to always lay a baby to sleep on their back. Use a firm and flat sleep surface. Good examples of these include:
Crib
Bassinet
Pack and playREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Room sharing is recommended for the first six months. You can get a good idea of your baby’s sleep habits while also having the peace of mind that comes with sleeping nearby. Remember, it is never safe to co-sleep or sleep in the same bed as your baby.
Keep baby’s sleep empty except for a tightly-fitted bottom sheet. Baby’s sleep area should always be free of soft objects, such as:
Pillows
Blankets
Loose bedding
Toys
Crib bumpersREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Learn more about sleep safety
here.
How much should a newborn sleep, anyway?
The amount of sleep your newborn gets depends on a few things:
Their eating habits and schedule:
Breastfed babies might wake up more during the night than babies who are formula fed. This is because formula takes longer to digest than breast milk, so baby
might
think they’re hungry again more frequently.
Whether they’re sick or not:
Just like you, babies need their rest when they aren’t feeling well. An extra sleepy or hard-to-wake baby might mean they’re getting sick. Always talk to your baby’s pediatrician or a
Pediatrician
on Maven right away if they seem overly sleepy or unwell.
How old they are:
Babies are considered newborns until they’re about two months old and how much your baby sleeps in a 24-hour period can come down to this one simple thing—their age. More on this next!
Here are some average sleep times based on your baby’s age:
(Just remember these are rough averages meant to be used as a guide. All babies are different—some need more sleep, some need less!)
REPLACEWITHASSET

Even though some babies do sleep for a small stretch at night, it’s important to make sure you wake them up to feed them during these first two months of life. They shouldn’t go more than 3-4 hours without eating, even if they’re snoozing. Babies can start sleeping in longer stretches when they’re 3-6 months old.
If you have questions about your baby’s sleep habits, you can talk to a
Sleep Coach
on Maven for free anytime.
What are “wake windows?”
Maybe you’ve heard of these and maybe you haven’t, but it’s important to understand your baby’s wake windows. These are simply just the times your baby can handle being awake.

Wake windows start to get some rhythm or a pattern around month four for your baby. This can be a good time to get as consistent as you can (life happens, though!) with baby’s sleep environment and routine.
If baby starts to seem grumpy after a certain amount of time of being awake and active, it might be because they’ve passed their wake window. You can ask a
Pediatrician
if you’re concerned about baby’s wake window being too short or too long.
Read even more about what a wake window is (and what to do with it) here.
You know your baby best: even if this is your first time as a parent, you’ll begin to notice things about them that others don’t. Trust your intuition to care for your baby best.
We’re here to help
Learn even more about baby’s sleep
here
, and remember that you can talk to a
Sleep Coach
on Maven to ask any questions you may have.

title.en-US: Wake windows: What they are and how to use them

content.value: What you need to know:
A wake window is the amount of time a baby or toddler can stay awake between naps or before bedtime.
Following wake windows can help keep your child from getting too much or too little sleep.
Wake windows don’t work for every family, but they can help you figure out the best times for your child’s naps or bedtime. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Figuring out your baby’s sleep schedule can be a challenging part of parenting, and for many families, it can remain tough well into toddlerhood. But understanding your baby or toddler’s wake windows may be the secret you’ve been searching for to help everyone in the family catch some more zzz’s.
Here’s everything you need to know about wake windows, and how to use them for better baby sleep.
What is a wake window?

“A wake window is the maximum amount of time a baby or toddler is [happily] awake between sleeps,” says Tracie Kesatie, Maven Pediatric Sleep Coach. For example, if your baby can stay awake for 2 hours between naps, they have a wake window of 2 hours. This is their sleepy sweet spot and you should plan to settle them down for their next snooze about 2 hours from when they last woke up.

(Keep in mind that their wake windows between naps and bedtime may be different. For example, your child may have a wake window of 2 hours from morning to first nap, 3 hours from first nap to second, and 5 hours from third nap to bedtime.)
Wake windows may be helpful for two major reasons:
To make sure your baby or toddler has been awake for long enough to feel tired
To put your baby or toddler down for a nap or bedtime before they get too tired REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

The key to better baby sleep is giving your child enough awake time to get sleepy (so they’re not undertired) without letting them get too sleepy (or overtired). Why is this important? “When babies [or toddlers] go to sleep undertired or overtired, it can lead to poorer quality of sleep, like shorter naps, bedtime challenges, more wakeups at night,” says Kesatie.
Know that every child is different, and wake windows may not work for everyone, but they can be a useful guide for figuring out your child’s nap times and bedtime.
How do I figure out my child’s wake windows?

Using the recommended wake windows for your child’s age (chart below) and paying attention to your child’s sleepy cues—or physical signs that they’re getting tired—can help you figure out the right wake windows for them.
Not every child will have the same cues, but here are some common signs of sleepiness:
Looking away from you
Acting cranky or fussy
Yawning
Rubbing their eyes
Red or pink eyesREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Some signs that your child is overtired are:
They’re extremely cranky or fussy
They have major bursts of energy (this is more common in toddlers)
They have trouble falling asleep at naptime or bedtime
Wake windows by age

Wake windows are based on age, so the amount of time changes as your little one gets older. Allow about 30 minutes before naptime and bedtime to do your child’s wind-down routine (like reading books, cuddling, or singing songs).
According to Kesatie, the recommended wake windows by age are:
REPLACEWITHASSET

If you’re worried that your child isn’t following the recommended wake windows for their age, Kesatie says: don’t. Every baby is different and has different sleep needs. “If your child isn't napping exactly to the wake windows for their age, but they are sleeping well during the day and at night, then chances are you don’t need to be concerned,” she adds. Some children will sleep a little more, some a little less.

It’s a good idea to record your child’s sleep and wake times, so you can get a sense for their sleep schedule. You can write it down with a pen and paper, or use apps like Huckleberry or Sprout to log times.
If you need help figuring out your child’s wake windows—or have any questions about baby sleep—make an online appointment with a
Maven Pediatric Sleep Coach
How do wake windows work with bedtime?

Your child’s longest wake window should be before bedtime. So if you have a 9 month old, for example, you can expect them to be awake for closer to 4 hours after their last nap before they’re ready for bed.
Kesatie says it’s a good idea to start your child’s bedtime routine about 30 minutes before bed, so keep that in mind when you’re figuring out their final wake window of the day.
When should I adjust my child’s wake windows?

As your child grows, they’ll be able to stay awake for longer and longer periods of time. If your child is often overtired, having trouble falling asleep and staying asleep, or waking up frequently during the night, it might be time to adjust their wake windows. You can start by moving their wake windows earlier or later by 15 minutes per day.

It’s also important to keep in mind that babies’ sleep patterns and habits are constantly changing, especially during their first year. Learning new skills, teething, and sleep regressions can all make it very difficult to navigate your baby’s sleep and their wake windows—so don’t be too hard on yourself if you have a cranky kid every once in a while. The most important thing is that your child seems happy and rested most of the time (and you’ll get there eventually, too).
The bottom line

Following your child’s wake windows and sleepy cues can help them get more, higher quality sleep, including longer naps and nighttime sleep. But keep in mind that every baby is different and has different sleep needs—some need more sleep, some need less.

We say, if your baby is sleeping well during the day and night, and seems happy and rested, you’re on the right track. If you ever need advice on your baby or toddler’s sleep, don’t hesitate to make a free online appointment with one of
Maven’s Pediatric Sleep Coaches

title.en-US: How to prepare for your induction

content.value: What you need to know
Sometimes you’re induced (or given something to help you go into labor) for medical reasons, and sometimes you might be able to choose an induction.
There are several ways to be induced, and you might even try more than once to get labor started.

You can do a few things before getting to the hospital to feel like you’re more in control, relaxed, and ready (although you might not ever feel 100% ready – that’s okay and totally normal!).REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Being induced to have your baby means you have a scheduled time when you will be either given medicine or have a small procedure done to jumpstart labor instead of labor starting on its own. An induction can feel a little bit like showing up early to the airport to pick up someone you’ve never met before – the nervousness and anxiety around it all might seem daunting.
Preparing for an induction isn’t a small feat, but one you can go into with knowledge that can empower you: read on for more, and remember that
Maven is here for you
anytime.
What should I know about inductions?
There are several ways you might be induced, which you can read more about
here

. We’ve got some fast facts on the different types of induction, though, and your doctor may suggest one or more of the ones listed here. Since everyone is different, your body might respond differently to each method.
REPLACEWITHASSET
How do I prepare emotionally?

Pregnancy and birth come with lots of emotions. Whether you’re nervous, excited, or a mixture of both: anything you’re feeling is completely normal. Check in with yourself emotionally before checking into the hospital by:
▢ Speaking with a
counselor for free on Maven
They’re here to help you sort through and name what you’re feeling, and can offer advice on coping or preparing for labor and delivery.
▢ Ask questions:
Your
provider

expects you to have some questions about the whole process of induction, and knowledge is power when it comes to procedures like this so ask away! (Remember, you can also always get a second opinion on Maven.)
▢ Journal:
Write down how you’re feeling now, even if it’s just a sentence or two. If you aren’t the kind of person who enjoys talking about your emotions, writing it down might help you get it out.
▢ Bring distractions:

Inducing labor takes time, and it can still take awhile until you meet your baby. Bring a book, magazine, or fully-charged phone to distract yourself (but try not to spend too much time on Google–you want a healthy distraction, not added stress!)
How do I prepare physically?

Your care team will be able to take care of any physical needs once you’re at the hospital, but a little preparation can go a long way to helping you feel prepared (and more relaxed) before you get to that point.
▢ Treat yourself:
Take a long shower or bath (not too hot!) and soak in epsom salts or enjoy some bubbles. Not only is this soothing, but it might be a little while before you can enjoy a bath like this postpartum.
▢ Bring a support person:

Whether you have a partner, trusted loved one, or a doula, having a person you trust by your side can make a difference. Once you get induced, you might not be allowed to get up and walk around for a few hours for your safety. Your support system will be greatly appreciated when you’re waiting to go into labor (and give you someone to talk to during the wait)
▢ Pack your bags:

Once you get induced, you know the baby is on their way! A packed bag can feel like you’re prepared, and doing this before the induction may alleviate some of the stress of the unknown. Find out more about
the top things to pack in your hospital bag
We’re here to help
It’s totally normal to have lots of feelings around your induction, and Maven providers are here to talk you through all of those. From the
emotional
aspect of things to the important
physical
ones, you’re never alone with those lingering questions.

title.en-US: Bleeding after sex while pregnant: What’s normal, what’s not

content.value: What you need to know
Vaginal bleeding while pregnant isn’t super common after sex, and sometimes can be a result of dryness.
Any bleeding that worries you is worth speaking to your doctor about, especially if you have a pregnancy complication. No matter if it’s a little bit or a lot, it can help to get peace of mind.
Bleeding that’s heavy enough to fill one pad in one hour is an emergency when you’re pregnant, and you should go get checked out right away.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Seeing vaginal blood during pregnancy can feel scary, especially if you’re worried you caused it due to having sex. You might be wondering if this is harmful to baby. We’re here to let you know that you didn’t do anything wrong, and you shouldn’t be embarrassed to talk to your provider or ask a provider on Maven if you’re feeling concerned.
Here’s everything you need to know about bleeding after sex while pregnant.
Is there any chance my partner can hurt the baby during sex?

This is a very common question. But this should put your mind at ease: your cervix (the end part of your uterus) protects your baby, so there’s no chance of "poking" if your partner has a penis, or if you or your partner use your hands or sex toys.
When is bleeding after sex not normal?
If you’ve had sex and begin experiencing any of these symptoms, you should try to be seen by your doctor as soon as you can:
Heavy bleeding (enough that you can fill one pad in one hour)
Cramping in your stomach or backREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Some cramping after sex is normal. If it goes away within a few hours, there’s nothing to be worried about. If it gets stronger over time and doesn’t go away, call your doctor right away.
Any bleeding is worth getting checked out about. Never worry about overreacting: it’s important to listen to your intuition. You can speak to a
Nurse Practitioner
Midwife
, or
OB-GYN
on Maven anytime to talk about what’s going on.

Emotional check-ins are important, too. Seeing blood while pregnant can be really scary, and feeling stress or anxiety long after an incident is totally normal. This might even be particularly scary if you’ve ever experienced pregnancy loss.
You can talk to a
provider on Maven
about how you’re feeling anytime, and read more about pregnancy after loss
here
When is bleeding after sex normal?
A little bit of vaginal bleeding isn’t necessarily cause for alarm during pregnancy, especially during the first trimester (weeks 1-13 of pregnancy). You might notice:
Reddish brown mucus or blood streaks
Pink blood in small amounts (aka “spotting”)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Bleeding due to dryness usually happens in small amounts immediately after sex. Consider using water-based lubricant to make the experience less worrisome for the next time.
You could also see some very light bleeding after sex during the first few months since your cervix is extra sensitive during this phase of pregnancy.
If you have any concerns about the amount of blood or how you feel afterwards, you can reach out to your doctor or a
provider on Maven
to ask what’s normal and what isn’t.
What about other kinds of sex?

Oral sex is generally safe while pregnant. However, never let your partner blow into your vagina, since that could cause something called a fatal air embolism, which could give baby a stroke, heart attack, or could even be fatal for you both.

Anal sex is also generally considered safe during pregnancy. Just remember to not go from anal sex to vaginal sex without putting on a condom or changing to a new condom, as that can increase risk of infection.
If you have questions about other sexual activities, bleeding, or anything at all you can talk to a
provider on Maven
anytime.

title.en-US: Your guide to breastfeeding in the NICU

content.value: What you need to know:
Fed is best when it comes to your baby. You can breastfeed, pump and bottle-feed breast milk, use formula, or do a combination!
Breastfeeding can be hard, but it shouldn’t be painful. Get help from a
Maven Lactation Consultant
for free at any time. They’re here for any questions you have about breastfeeding.
If baby isn’t eating or if you feel like they aren’t gaining weight, reach out to their pediatrician, or a
Maven Pediatrician
, right away.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
When it comes to parenthood, everyone warns you about losing sleep. But you may be surprised to learn that feeding your baby can be one of the biggest challenges of all.

We’ve all seen happy pictures of breastfeeding on social media. The truth is that feeding can be really hard. Remember that this is a new skill for you and for your baby, too. It can take time (and a few changes) to find what works.
Whether you are bottle feeding or breastfeeding, here are all the basics you need to know.
If you ever have questions along the way, we’re here for you! You can video chat or message with a
Lactation Consultant
for help breastfeeding or a
Pediatrician
for help choosing a formula or feeding tips for free on Maven anytime—day or night.
Remember, fed is best

If baby is having a hard time with eating, reach out to get help right away. There’s more than one way to feed them. They can have breast milk, formula, or a combination of both, and your pediatrician can help you decide what’s best for your baby. Your milk might take 3-5 days to fully come in, and that’s okay: but it’s still great to have a trusted lactation consultant to chat with.
Breastfeeding:
Breastfeeding has so many benefits if it works for you and your family. Some of these include:
Lower risks of breast cancer for you
Lower risks of ovarian cancer for you
Lots of good immunity is passed from you to baby
You can do it anytime and anywhere, for free
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Pumping:

Once your breast milk supply is in and you and baby have a good feeding routine (around 4-6 weeks), you may want to start pumping to store some breast milk. Sometimes you need to pump sooner, like if baby isn’t latching and that is OK!
Storing milk makes it easier for others to help with feedings. This means you can be away from baby when you need to, and it can also help you get ready for going back to work.
(For tips on choosing a bottle and feeding positions, see the formula and bottle feeding section below.)
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Formula and bottle feeding:

Remember: fed is best. If you choose not to breastfeed or can’t breastfeed, that is OK and baby will still get the nutrients they need. The important steps for formula feeding are choosing the bottle and formula that your baby needs and likes. (Babies may be small, but they get picky about these things!) Here are some tips to help you along.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Sources
American Academy of Pediatrics: Infant Food and Feeding
Mayo Clinic
World Health Organization
American Academy of Pediatrics
Breastfeeding can be tough, but it should never be painful. If you’re having any trouble feeding your baby, reach out to a
Lactation Consultant on Maven
right away.
Help is here for you, for free.

It is best to feed baby soon after birth or within the first hour (if you are recovering after a C-section). This will give you and baby a chance to learn how to latch. “Latching” is when baby’s mouth is positioned on your nipple and feeding the right way to get milk out.

In the first couple of days, it is more important for your baby to feed often than it is for them to feed for long amounts of time. This will give baby the nutrition they need and help your milk to come in.

Colostrum is the first milk your body makes. You might hear it called “liquid gold”. When you first give birth, your breasts may not feel full yet because you will make colostrum before you make milk.
It may not look like much (it’s usually semi-clear or yellowish), but colostrum is full of nutrients and all your baby needs in those first few days.
It is common for babies to lose a little weight the first couple of days as they feed on colostrum, and then to gain it back in the next week or so as your breast milk comes in.

items.header: When your breast milk will come in

content.value: Often your milk will come in between 3-5 days after giving birth. You will know it is coming in because your breasts will feel engorged (very full and firm to the touch) and the milk that comes out will get a thinner, white appearance.

It’s totally normal for it to take a few days for your body to really start making milk. Until then, colostrum is all baby needs. Babies have tiny stomachs and won’t need more than you’re making unless you notice you aren’t making milk at all.
If you don’t see your milk coming in within 3-5 days after having baby, talk to your doctor or care team.
Breastfeed your baby “on-demand,” meaning as often as they show signs of hunger. This will be about 8-12 times in 24 hours during the first month of life. This means you will need to feed baby:
At least every 2-3 hours during the day
And go no longer than every 4 hours at night. This often means waking your baby up to get them to feed at night.
Your baby will show you signs that they are hungry, such as:
Smacking their lips
Rooting (or searching for your nipple by putting their face into you)
Sucking on their fist to let you know when they’re hungry
You can hold baby in lots of positions while breastfeeding. These might include:
Side lying:
Lay on your side and let baby feed from your breast. It’s usually easier to use the same side and breast.
Cradle hold:
Hold baby and breastfeed them at the same time, making sure to support their head and guide them to your breast.
Laid-back hold:
Lay back with a pillow behind you, and hold baby rest on your stomach to feed from either breast.

Keep your baby at the breast as long as they are suckling. This usually is 15-20 minutes at each breast or about 40 minutes total when they are newborns. You might have to wake your baby after feeding on the first breast to get them to actively latch and nurse on the second breast.

items.header: How to know if baby is getting enough milk

content.value: One way to tell if baby is latching properly and getting enough milk in the first couple days of life is to look at your baby’s poop. It should start to change in color over a few days, from:
Black to greenish
Then greenish to yellow and seedy
Baby’s poop will be yellow and seedy looking when your milk has fully come in. Your baby will often start pooping after every feeding for the first month of life.
By 5 days old, your baby should also have at least:
5-7 wet pee diapers in 24 hours
Pale, colorless pee (it shouldn’t be dark yellow or another color)
They should also seem satisfied for about 1-3 hours after nursing

Burping helps your baby get rid of gas after eating. A gassy baby isn’t usually a happy one, so burping them after every feeding is important. You can do this by holding baby upright against your chest and lightly patting their upper back until they burp.
If you are exclusively breastfeeding your baby, sometimes you will also need to give baby a vitamin D supplement or iron. Talk to your baby’s pediatrician or a
Pediatrician on Maven
anytime about which would be best. Formula-fed babies may not need supplements.
The
World Health Organization
and the
American Academy of Pediatrics

recommends breastfeeding exclusively for the first 6 months if possible, and up to 2 years or longer along with safe and nutritious foods. That said, feeding is a personal decision made by you, with help from your child’s pediatrician.

Breastfeeding your baby any amount until they are 6 months old is great for you and baby if it works for your family. And, you can continue to breastfeed longer if you and your baby want to or use formula in addition to breast milk.
Lactation Consultants
are here for you on Maven to use anytime for free.

In order to pump, you’ll need to get a breast pump. Contact your insurance company or WIC to get a pump. They can let you know if they cover the cost of a breast pump and you may have to choose from their list.
There are a few pump options:
Electric (one you plug in or that uses a battery)
Manual (one you pump by hand)
Single or double pumps (for one breast or both)
Other supplies you’ll need include:
Bottles that fit your breast pump
Milk storage bags
Cooler for keeping milk safe while you’re out or at work
Pump cleaning wipes
Pumping bra if you want to be hands-free
You can pump:
after feeding your baby
in the middle of the night when baby is sleeping a longer stretch
when you are away from your baby, at the times they would normally feed
You may find that you make the most milk during the night and in the morning.
Decide if you want to store your milk in bags or bottles (and make sure you have a lot!). Once you’ve pumped milk,
do not let it sit out at room temperature for longer than 4 hours
. This is to keep your milk safe for baby to eat!

You can put breast milk in the refrigerator for up to 4 days, or put it in the freezer. You can freeze milk in a refrigerator freezer for 3-6 months and in a deep freezer for up to 12 months. When freezing milk, it’s best to do so in small amounts (such as 2-3 ounces).
Always label the container with:
The date the milk was collected
How much milk it is
The name of your baby (if daycare will be thawing it)
To heat up breast milk from the refrigerator, you just need to put the bottle in a bowl of warm water. To unthaw from the freezer, you can:
Put it in a bowl of warm water
Put it in the refrigerator overnight
Put it under warm running water
Remember: Never use a microwave to heat breast milk or any bottle. It might not
heat all the way through or could burn baby’s mouth.
Once it’s thawed you can store it in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours. If you don’t use it by then it has to be thrown away. Thawed breast milk can’t be put back in the freezer.

To slow the spread of germs, always keep your pump parts and baby’s bottle parts clean. Wash them by hand with warm water and dish soap or in the dishwasher (according to the instructions provided on the packaging).
For extra protection, clean feeding items daily for:
Babies younger than 3 months
Babies who were born prematurely (or earlier than their due date; usually before 37 weeks)
Babies with weakened immune systems
Follow these instructions from the Centers for Disease Control
Before you return to work, ask for a private spot where you can pump. There are federal laws your workplace must follow, including providing you a private space and time to pump.

To keep a good milk supply, pump as often as you would feed your baby (usually every 2-3 hours) if you can. Skipping pumping sessions can decrease your supply, meaning you start to make less breast milk.

Think about how often you will have to pump at work and how much time you will have for each session to help you figure out which is the best pump to bring to work for you. For example, if you’ll be pumping at work, a double electric will be quicker than a single manual pump, but you may need access to an outlet.
It’s important to know that your job is required by law to give you time to pump at work.
Maven Career Coaches
are available to help you speak up for yourself and your needs when returning to work and pumping.
Find more details on pumping at work and what your rights are
Formula is sold at grocery stores and places like Walmart or Target. Programs like Women, Infants and Children (WIC) cover all kinds of formulas. Contact your local
WIC to learn more

The options can be overwhelming. Luckily, you can rest assured that all formulas in the United States are checked and all are Federal Drug Administration (FDA) –approved (yep, even the store-brand ones). This means they are safe for your baby and have the nutrition they need.
Ask your baby’s pediatrician what formula may be best for them or ask a
Pediatrician on Maven
It may take a few different nipples to find the one your baby likes. Look for the stage on the package to make sure the nipple is recommended for newborns (and size up as they grow).
These stages affect how fast the milk will flow out, starting with a small hole for a slow flow, and then a larger or additional holes for a faster flow as your baby learns how to eat.
Always sanitize nipples before first use following the instructions on the package.
You can find great deals on bottles and nipples at children’s consignment stores, too!

Glass or silicone bottles are great because they are easy to keep clean. Often, it’s best to choose one bottle type and one nipple type and stick with it so your baby is familiar with it. Don’t be surprised if it takes a few tries to find the right combination.

items.header: How much to feed during the first few days of life

content.value: You can also use this formula to figure out how much to feed your baby:
Baby’s current weight in pounds x 2.5 ounces = Total ounces to feed per day (Example: Baby weighs 8 lbs x 2.5 ounces = 20 ounces per day)
This formula can be used until they are approximately 15 pounds or 2-3 months of age. Check in with your
Pediatrician on Maven
anytime to make sure.

Formula can be liquid or powder. Liquid formula is ready to feed and doesn’t need to be mixed with any water.Powdered formula is mixed with water according to the directions on the back of the can. Follow these general steps:
1. Wash:
Wash your hands, bottles, nipples, and work area to protect your baby from germs or bacteria.
2. Measure:
Follow the instructions on the package of formula to measure out the water first, then add the powder.

Always put in the exact amounts on the formula can. If the formula is too weak, your baby won’t get the nutrition they need. If it’s too strong, it can make your baby’s digestion system go into overdrive (and lead to a cranky/gassy baby).
Be sure to use clean water. If you have any doubts about your water quality, boil and cool the water before mixing with formula, or use distilled bottled water.
3. Check the temperature:
Room temperature formula for baby is just fine.

If your baby prefers it a little warmer or it has been in the fridge, run the bottle under warm (not hot) water from the faucet for a minute or so (taking care not to get water in the bottle’s nipple).
Never use a microwave to warm a bottle. It can cause heat spots and burn baby’s mouth.

items.header: How to hold baby while feeding

content.value: A few tips:
Feed your baby in a semi-upright position
Have the formula fill the nipple completely so your baby does not get too much air
Don’t feed baby while they are lying down. They can choke and milk can come back up. This can cause an ear infection.

To prevent the spread of germs that can make your baby sick, always keep bottles and nipples clean. Wash them by hand with warm water and dish soap or in the dishwasher (according to the instructions provided on the packaging).

Burping helps your baby get rid of gas after eating. A gassy baby isn’t usually a happy one, so burping them after every feeding is important. You can do this by holding baby upright against your chest and lightly patting their upper back until they burp.

title.en-US: Your guide to breastfeeding after a C-section

content.value: What you need to know:
You should still be able to do skin-to-skin time with baby and breastfeed after a C-section, when your care team says it’s safe to do so.
Some positions are going to be more comfortable to breastfeed in than others, ask your nurse or a
Maven Lactation Consultant
for tips.
You might need help positioning baby at the breast from a support person, and you shouldn’t worry about speaking up for what you need.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Breastfeeding is no small feat, and can feel like another mountain to climb if you’re doing it after giving birth by Cesarean (or C-section). But the good news is that not only can breastfeeding help you heal, it has lots of health benefits for you and baby.
You might be wondering what’s different about breastfeeding after having a C-section surgery.
Maven Lactation Consultants
and
OB-GYNs
are available to answer all of your questions if you still have some after reading below.
Know the benefits of breastfeeding
There are many benefits of breastfeeding, like:
Breast milk is free and full of good nutrients for baby
Lowers the risk of sickness for baby, including serious diseases like asthma or type 1 diabetes
Lowers your risk of breast cancer
Lowers your risk of ovarian cancer
Helps lessen the bleeding after giving birth
Helps burn calories (up to 500 or more calories a day)
Speak up for yourself

If breastfeeding is a top priority for you that you really want to make happen, you can let your care team know before and after birth so everyone is on the same page. Tell your doctor and nurses that you plan to breastfeed after your Cesarean (C-section) delivery.

You may need to wait until you are in recovery to breastfeed safely. But you can usually breastfeed in the recovery area within the hour after your baby is born if there aren’t any complications or health issues for you or baby.
Best breastfeeding positions post-C-section

You can hold baby in lots of positions while breastfeeding, but there are only a handful that will feel comfortable after a C-section surgery. You will be experiencing some soreness and pain, so it’s best to do what you can to minimize putting pressure on your lower belly or holding anything heavier than your baby for at least the first two weeks after giving birth.
Breastfeeding positions that could work for you might include:
Side lying:
Lay on your side and let baby feed from your breast. It’s usually easier to use the same side and breast.
Cradle hold:

Hold baby in the crook of your arm, their head resting on your forearm and your other arm supporting their body, and breastfeed them at the same time, making sure to support their head and guide them to your breast.
Laid-back hold:
Lay back with a pillow behind you, and let baby rest on your stomach to feed from either breast.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have a support person or nursing staff, ask for help getting yourself into a comfortable position first and then ask them to bring baby to you.
Get support right away
Even though it has many benefits, it can be challenging to breastfeed. You can get support from a
Maven Lactation Consultant
for free.
Maven has video appointments with
Lactation Consultants
who can observe your baby latching and provide real-time tips. Getting support early can save you lots of stress and even physical pain.

title.en-US: Coping with pregnancy complications: Where to get help for your mental health

content.value: What you need to know:
Dealing with pregnancy complications isn’t something you have to do alone: you have support on
Maven anytime
It’s normal to be concerned if you’re anxious about a pregnancy-related issue
Your mental health and physical health are tied together, so it’s important to talk to someone if you’re feeling stressed or overwhelmed (and even if you’d like a second opinion)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Pregnancy isn’t as straightforward as everyone thinks. Things can happen along the way that you weren’t expecting, and the dream pregnancy you or your partner once envisioned may start to feel like a bad one. While that’s hopefully only a temporary feeling, it is a completely normal one: and you aren’t alone. Here’s how to find support to help you through it.
How to find support
Feeling out of control in your own body can happen when you find yourself dealing with pregnancy complications. These can be anything, like:
The general unknown of pregnancy, childbirth, or parenting
Miscarriage or pregnancy after miscarriage
Gestational diabetes (diabetes that happens during pregnancy–learn more
here
Preeclampsia (dangerously high blood pressure in pregnancy–learn more
here
Baby being diagnosed with a health condition
Relationship strains
Physical changes
Helping an older child adjust to becoming a sibling
Work changes
Pregnancy after fertility treatment or difficulties conceivingREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
No matter what you’re going through, remember that
help
is always available.
You can:
Speak to a provider online on Maven
for free, anytime you need to
2. Tell your OB-GYN or midwife:
Keeping your primary doctors in the loop is important, since they can usually help you find mental health support, including:
Referrals
Medication
Being there for you and helping to coordinate care
Think about your village

They say that “it takes a village” to raise a child, but it takes one to raise a parent, too. If you’re dealing with a pregnancy complication, (or are struggling at all emotionally) you might want to get more folks involved who can help you. These can be anyone, including:
A doula
who will be your personal advocate and cheerleader (learn more about what they do
here
Second opinions (or third!)
about your condition and how to manage it on Maven, including free virtual appointments with:
Genetic Counselors
OB-GYNs
Midwives
High-Risk Pregnancy Specialists
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
A therapist
to discuss how you feel and even more ways to process your emotions
A nutritionist
if you’re needing to make any dietary changes
Your loved ones are also great people to lean on if you can. Frequent texts, calls, or check-ins might feel helpful to you during this time.
What are some exercises or techniques I can use to process how I’m feeling?

Being able to talk to someone about how you feel is one of the most important steps to getting help, but there are a few things you can do anytime you feel overwhelmed with everything that’s going on.
You can try:
Any kind of relaxation exercises (meditation, deep breathing, muscle relaxation)
If you have a support system, rely on them to help with basic things like a meal or cleaning if it helps you to feel like there’s less on your “to-do list”
Going to therapy (individual or couples)
Physical exercise or just taking a walk in nature (always check with your doctor first for safety)
Doing things you enjoy as long as they’re safe
What else do I need to know?
You are not alone. Coping with pregnancy complications is common, and you don’t deserve any blame that you might be putting on yourself right now.

All emotional reactions are valid. And often there is a wide range of emotions that can hit at the same time, or over time. They are all valid. There is no right or wrong way to process the news of a pregnancy complication.
What about once baby is born?

Depending on the situation, things could improve or the condition you had might go away; and other times, you might have a lifelong journey in learning about yourself and your new little one. You’ll need people who are ready to support you: and you can message your Care Advocate on Maven anytime to find out who the best
providers
are for you to talk to.

title.en-US: Cramps and abdominal pain during pregnancy: What’s normal, what’s not

content.value: What you need to know
If you are bleeding or cramping while pregnant, reach out to your doctor or a
provider on Maven
right away just to make sure all is OK.
Some cramping and abdominal pain during pregnancy is usually normal if it’s mild. Cramping that doesn’t go away or gets worse is not. Call your doctor right away if this is the case.
Always talk to a doctor if you are bleeding at all during pregnancy—with or without cramping. Seek emergency help if you are soaking through more than one pad in one hour.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Nothing puts you on high alert or causes anxiety like bleeding or cramping during pregnancy. Depending on what trimester you’re in, it can be totally normal: but if you feel concerned or worried something is up, trust your intuition. Talk to your doctor right away to play it safe. You can also speak with a
provider on Maven
to get peace of mind anytime if you still have questions after reading.
What's normal in terms of cramps during pregnancy (by trimester)?
First trimester (weeks 1-13)

Mild menstrual-like cramps without bleeding in the first trimester is usually normal. This might be due to your body preparing for pregnancy, and you might feel these cramps before you even realize you’re pregnant. Cramps during this time could be due to the fertilized egg attaching to the lining of the uterus in a process called implantation.
Second trimester (weeks 14-27)
Again, mild cramping here is usually normal. It could be due to your uterus expanding to make more room for baby.
These kinds of cramps should get better with:
Rest (a nap or warm—not hot—bath) is best
8-12 cups of water a day (you’re more likely to cramp if you aren’t well hydrated)
A hot water bottle on your lower back or lower belly (but not too hot) for less than 10 minutes at a timeREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Third trimester (weeks 28-40)

Your body is smart: and it might begin doing “practice” contractions called Braxton Hicks contractions. These don’t mean you’re actually going into labor, but they can feel a little more intense than cramps during the first and second trimesters.
Braxton Hicks should just feel like your stomach muscles are tightening. However, if you have any of these signs, it’s a good idea to reach out to your doctor or a
provider on Maven
Extreme pain (that you can’t talk through)
More than eight of these “false contractions” in one hour
Doesn’t go away with drinking water
Cramps that are getting stronger or not going away
What is NOT normal, and when should I speak with my provider?
Call your doctor right away if you are experiencing any of the following:
Sharp, shooting pain that doesn’t go away:
Anything that lasts longer than 1-2 hours and gets worse over time
should mean a call to your doctor
Bleeding:
Vaginal bleeding in pregnancy is
rarely normal
and should always mean a call to your doctor.
Leaking fluid:
This could be amniotic fluid, and even if it looks like slightly colored or tinged discharge
it’s worth a call to your doctor to be on the safe side.
Can’t get in touch with your doctor or want a second opinion? Remember,
Maven providers
are here to help you get peace of mind 24/7 if you have any questions at all during pregnancy.

title.en-US: Pregnancy insomnia

content.value: What you need to know
Insomnia (or having trouble sleeping or staying asleep) is common during pregnancy and can happen in any trimester (hormones may be to thank).
Sometimes insomnia points to anxiety around parenthood or pregnancy, and it’s a great time to speak to a
Maven provider
about any concerns you may have.

Unisom or Benadryl are generally considered safe for you to try if you’re really struggling to get some good shut-eye. Just be sure to always ask your provider first before taking any medication during pregnancy.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Sleep is a lot of pregnant people’s favorite pastimes: but it doesn’t come easily for everyone. If you’re in the wide-awake club, you’re not alone: pregnancy insomnia is very common and can happen no matter what trimester you’re in.
If you’re having trouble getting the rest you (and baby!) need during pregnancy, read on: and get some peace of mind by speaking with a
Maven Midwife
or
OB-GYN
for more personal tips after you’re done.
What is pregnancy insomnia?
Pregnancy insomnia is when you have a hard time sleeping or falling asleep while you’re in any trimester of your pregnancy. It usually goes away once you’ve had baby, and can be due to many factors.
What causes pregnancy insomnia?

In general, you are likely to feel very tired in the first trimester. You may feel like you can nap for 2 hours even after a full night of sleep! By the third trimester, you may notice more difficulty getting to sleep and staying asleep. This can be due to:
Feeling uncomfortable
Not being able to get in a position that feels restful because of your belly
Pain or pressure in your legs and hipsREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
You may feel like you have to go to the bathroom constantly, and this doesn’t help you feel rested either. Hormones are also to blame for the frequent waking up at night.
Are there any cures for pregnancy insomnia?
The best thing you can try is setting up an environment that is helpful to sleep, as you would if you were not pregnant. You can try a few different nighttime routine changes, such as:
Staying off electronics for an hour before bed
Keeping a dark and cool room
Meditating
Drinking warm, decaf teaREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Some people like to have a sound machine on to avoid any wake ups from random sounds that are outside of your home. You can also try setting yourself up in a comfortable position, on your side, with a pillow between your legs (or a body pillow) to help you feel supported.
Can I take medicine to help me sleep?
None of those tips working? Unisom or Benadryl are generally considered safe for pregnant people to take in their intended doses. Always talk to your pregnancy provider or a
provider on Maven
before taking any medication during pregnancy.
The bottom line:

Pregnancy insomnia is normal and won’t last forever: even if the nights seem to stretch on and feel as though it will. If you need other tips or help, you can reach out to your Care Advocate on Maven anytime to learn
who to meet
with for more help on Maven.

title.en-US: Tips for meal planning during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know
Planning what you’ll eat in a week saves you time and money in the long run: even if it’s a bit more time spent upfront.
A lot of meals reheat well, or even taste better days after they’re first made!
Easy snacks that pack a big punch for pregnancy nutrition include healthy fats and proteins like nut butters, beef jerky, and trail mixes with nuts.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

It’s okay if the words “meal planning” don’t immediately give you lots of ideas: you’re not alone. Meal planning isn’t most people’s idea of an exciting way to spend their time, but it could be a great way to make sure you’re getting the nutrition you need during pregnancy. Maven also has
Nutritionists
ready to help you if you still feel stumped after reading the tips below.
What are helpful tips to plan meals for the week during pregnancy?
Start by thinking about building your plate with a variety of foods and food groups. You can plan to include:
Fruit and Vegetables
Leafy greens
(mustard, dandelion, and collard greens for example)
Berries
(strawberries, blueberries, and blackberries are great)
Citrus fruit
