(think oranges, lemons, and grapefruit)
Root vegetables
(potatoes, carrots, beets, and turnips)
Crunchy vegetables
(broccoli and cauliflower are good options!)
Melons
(watermelon, cantaloupe, and honeydew)
Gourds
(squash and pumpkins)
Whole grains
Brown rice
Barley
Oatmeal
Corn
Quinoa
Full-fat dairy products
Yogurt
Cheese
Milk
Nuts and seeds
Peanuts
Sunflower seeds
Almonds
Cashews
Pumpkin seeds
Nut butters (almond, peanut, or others are great!)
Lean meats
Chicken
Turkey
Ground beef (90% lean or so is ideal and is usually written on the package with “90% lean, 10% fat” as an example)
Steak (on occasion, and any cut will do)
Low-mercury cooked fish
Salmon
Sardines
Canned light tuna
Tilapia
ShrimpREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Make a list for each section of your plate and then mix and match.
Make it easier on yourself
It can be overwhelming to just pick meals if you don't have a strategy around how to build them. Start by thinking about how much effort you want to put in.

Can you meal prep grilled chicken and salad toppings on the weekend by cooking the chicken and slicing lots of veggies? Could you make some overnight oats for the whole week? Or would a rotisserie chicken with a salad mix from the store be easier?
Try yogurt with berries that you can just toss together, or even some pre-made frozen egg bites.
What are some food groups that reheat well?
A lot of things can reheat well if the right form of heat is used. Bready-products like pizza reheat better in the oven, while leftover veggies and proteins can probably be reheated in the microwave.

Soups and casseroles generally reheat well and can also be frozen into individual portions for later use. Try putting cooled-down soups into ziploc bags and freeze them laying down flat to get the most out of your freezer space.
What are some nutritious foods I should try to work in?

Protein is the name of the game when you’re pregnant. Between mixing and matching from all of the options above and taking your daily prenatal vitamins, you should be getting the nutrition you and baby both need.
Pregnancy is also one of the most exhausting things you can experience. Growing a person is a lot of work, and meal prep might seem like the last thing you want to do.
One of the best things you can do is keep lots of easy options on hand. Some options:
Beef jerky
Cheese sticks
Yogurt
Cottage cheese
Nuts
Trail mix
Nut butters
Hard-boiled eggs
Canned fishREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Don't be afraid to get pre-made meals or order delivery, just keep focusing on building the plate around protein, veggies, and healthy fats. Make big batches for the week, make extra for leftovers, and build in a day off for takeout.
We’re here to help
You have support people on Maven who understand what you’re going through, and are here for any questions you might have. Book a video chat or message with a
Nutritionist
anytime. Or reach out to your Care Advocate if you have questions on the best provider to talk to about nutrition, meal planning, and more.

title.en-US: Vaginal discharge during pregnancy: Why it happens and when to see your doctor

content.value: What you need to know:
Increased vaginal discharge is very common during pregnancy, and is often one of the earliest signs of pregnancy.
Vaginal discharge keeps bacteria and infections from entering your cervix and harming your baby.
If you have green, gray, brown, yellow, pink, or red vaginal discharge, call your pregnancy provider right away. This can be a sign of infection and might need treatment. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Increased vaginal discharge (also called leukorrhea) is a healthy part of pregnancy. But how do you know what’s normal discharge and what’s not? Here’s everything you need to know about vaginal discharge during pregnancy and when it’s important to call your pregnancy provider.
Having more discharge is totally normal—and beneficial to you and baby
It’s completely normal to have more discharge during pregnancy. In fact, one of the earliest signs of pregnancy for many people is increased vaginal discharge.
Here’s what healthy vaginal discharge is like:
Usually white or slightly yellow
Has a thin, watery consistency
May be odorless or have a very mild smellREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

But what actually causes increased vaginal discharge during pregnancy? The surge of hormones your body experiences during the early weeks of pregnancy and increased blood flow to the pelvic area both contribute to extra vaginal discharge.

Vaginal discharge serves an important purpose. It helps keep you and your baby safe throughout pregnancy by acting as a natural cleanser for your vagina, and it offers protection. “Increased discharge helps protect you and your baby from infections or bacteria moving through the birth canal and entering the uterus,” Maven OB-GYN Kathleen Green.
What blood-streaked vaginal discharge could mean
Some pregnant people may have vaginal discharge that’s streaked with brown, pink, or red blood. Common causes of discharge streaked with
brown
or
pink blood
include:
Implantation bleeding (when a fertilized egg attaches to the lining of the uterus)
Your body shedding old blood from the uterus or birth canal
Irritation to the cervix after having sex or a pelvic exam REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Light spotting of red blood during pregnancy may be normal, but Green says it’s a good idea to play it safe and call your pregnancy provider if you have any blood in your vaginal discharge. You can also make an online appointment with a
Maven OB-GYN
for advice.

If you have heavier bleeding (enough to fill a pantyliner) with pain or abdominal cramps, it’s important to call your pregnancy provider immediately. They’ll want to make sure you and your baby are OK.
When to call your pregnancy provider about vaginal discharge
Having extra vaginal discharge during pregnancy is extremely common, but some types might be a sign of a problem.
Call your pregnancy provider right away if your vaginal discharge has any of these characteristics:
It’s green, gray, brown, yellow, pink or red in color
The consistency is thick, lumpy, bubbly, or foamy
It smells bad or fishy
You feel an itchy or burning sensation around your vagina
You have a strong gush or steady trickle of watery fluid from your vaginaREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

A gush or trickle of watery, slightly sweet smelling discharge could actually be amniotic fluid (the fluid in your uterus that protects baby and helps them develop). Losing a little bit of amniotic fluid usually isn’t a major concern, but losing too much can be very dangerous for your baby.
Some infections that can happen during pregnancy and change the color, consistency, and smell of your vaginal discharge include:
Yeast infections.

Vaginal yeast infections happen when the fungus called Candida albicans yeast, grows in the vagina. It’s naturally present, but can sometimes overgrow, causing an infection. Yeast infections usually cause white, thick, lumpy discharge (think: cottage cheese), itching, and pain. Yeast infections are very common during pregnancy and can usually be treated with over-the-counter creams or suppositories. Just be sure to talk to your pregnancy provider before taking any kind of treatment for a yeast infection.
Bacterial vaginosis (BV).

Another common infection during pregnancy, bacterial vaginosis can cause white or gray discharge that smells bad or fishy. BV is typically treated with pregnancy-safe antibiotics that your provider can prescribe.
Sexually-transmitted infections (STIs).

Sexually-transmitted infections like gonorrhea, chlamydia, or trichinosis can cause green or yellow discharge. If left untreated, STIs can be very dangerous for you and your baby. If you think you had unprotected sex with someone who has an STI, it’s important to tell your pregnancy provider right away. Don’t be afraid to tell your OB-GYN—they’re not there to judge, but to help you. Being tested and getting the right treatment is the best way to protect yourself and your baby. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Be sure to call your pregnancy provider right away if you think you have any of these (or other) infections.
Have questions about vaginal discharge?
Maven OB-GYNs
are here to help. Make an online appointment for advice now.
How to stay dry and comfortable
Remember: vaginal discharge is a good thing! But feeling damp all day long can be bothersome. Some things you can do to stay dry and feel more comfortable are:
Wear an unscented pantyliner to absorb extra discharge. Using tampons during pregnancy isn’t recommended—they might introduce new bacteria to your vagina.
Wear cotton underwear and loose clothing that allows air flow.

Avoid wipes and douching. Wipes can change the pH balance of your vagina and lead to discomfort or even vaginal infections. And douching isn’t considered safe for pregnancy, so it’s best to avoid it completely.
The bottom line

Increased vaginal discharge keeps you and your baby safe from infection and bacteria during pregnancy. White or slightly yellow, watery, odorless (or mildly odored) discharge is completely normal. But if you have thick or lumpy green, brown, gray, red, or yellow discharge that smells bad, call your pregnancy provider right away. These can be signs of a vaginal infection that need treatment.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic (Amniotic fluid)
Cleveland Clinic (Vaginal discharge)
Mayo Clinic

title.en-US: How to deal with headaches when you're pregnant

content.value: What you need to know:
Headaches are very common during pregnancy, and usually aren’t the sign of a health problem.
Changes to your hormones, blood volume, and diet during pregnancy can cause more headaches.
Drinking lots of water, getting enough rest, and taking acetaminophen (Tylenol) are all pregnancy-safe ways to get relief from a headache. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Pregnancy comes with a lot of aches and pains, and if you’re getting frequent headaches, you’re definitely not alone. “One-third of pregnant women who suffer from headaches will notice an increase of headaches and migraines during pregnancy,” says Maven OB-GYN Rana Daniel. “This is very normal, but can be really bothersome.”
Read on to find out why headaches are so common during pregnancy, and what you can do to get some relief.
Why you might get more headaches when you’re pregnant
There are a few factors that could up how often (and how bad!) your headaches are during pregnancy:
Hormonal changes
that happen throughout pregnancy, especially during the first trimester. (Headaches are sometimes a very early sign of pregnancy.)
Increased blood volume
that causes the blood vessels in your head to expand.
Congestion or runny nose
(also called rhinitis of pregnancy) caused by extra blood flow to your mucus membranes.
Dehydration
if morning sickness causes nausea or vomiting.
Caffeine withdrawal
if you suddenly stop drinking coffee or soda.
Hunger or low blood sugar
if you’re not eating enough
Types of headaches during pregnancy
When you’re pregnant, you can get the same types of headaches you had pre-pregnancy. The difference is, you may not be able to take the same medications for relief..
Some types of headaches that can happen during pregnancy include:
Tension headaches.

The most common type of headaches, tension headaches feel like a dull, achy pain in your head, neck, and shoulders. It can also feel like a tight band around your forehead. The exact causes of tension headaches aren’t fully understood, but many people get tension headaches from stress, hunger, or tightness in the muscles around the head, face, neck, and shoulders. Your changing body can contribute to tension in these muscle groups during pregnancy.
Migraine headaches.

Migraines can cause throbbing, moderate to severe pain that lasts anywhere from a few hours to a few days. Some people may also have nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and blurred vision with migraines. It’s believed that migraines are caused by changes in the blood flow to your brain, as well as certain genetic and lifestyle factors. Increased blood volume and blood flow during pregnancy may cause more frequent migraines.
Sinus headaches.

If you feel pressure around your cheeks, nose, or eyes, and have a stuffy nose, you might have a sinus headache. Sinus headaches are caused by swelling in your sinuses, and can be made worse by extra blood flow to your mucus membranes during pregnancy.
Cluster headaches.

Cluster headaches are very sharp, painful headaches that usually last less than an hour, but come back every day for some time. They usually happen around the same time every day, too. Fortunately, this type of headache is pretty rare.
What you can do to feel better
“Headache prevention is a great first step,” says Daniel. “Making sure you’re rested and sleeping well, staying hydrated, and eating healthy foods may help prevent headaches.”

When you have a headache, some of your go-to remedies may not be considered safe for pregnancy—like ibuprofen (Advil or Motrin), which shouldn’t be taken when you’re pregnant. But the good news is there are a few things you can do to feel better when your head is aching and your belly is growing.
Take acetaminophen (Tylenol).

The common pain reliever acetaminophen is considered safe for occasional use during pregnancy, but you should always check with your pregnancy provider before taking any medication. Daniel adds, “You may need a prescription for headache medication if it gets worse.” Again, ibuprofen (Advil or Motrin) are not considered safe to take while pregnant.
Get some rest.
Try to lay down in a dark, quiet room, especially if you have a migraine. Noise and light can make headaches worse. Try putting a cool, damp washcloth over your forehead and eyes.
Drink water.
Dehydration is a common cause of headaches, so be sure to drink a lot of water. Hydrating may give you some relief and is also good for your pregnancy!
Do gentle stretches.
If you have aches and pain in your neck or shoulders, gentle stretches might help ease the tension. You can try one of
Maven’s free prenatal yoga classes
to safely loosen up your muscles. Be sure that any exercise you do is pregnancy-safe by asking your provider or a
Maven provider
Wean yourself from caffeine slowly.

If you drink coffee or soda, suddenly stopping can cause headaches from caffeine withdrawal. Slowly cut down your caffeine intake for a few days instead of quitting cold turkey. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Talk to your doctor.
They may recommend a prescription medication to alleviate your headaches and any related symptoms.
When to call your doctor about a headache
Headaches usually aren’t considered dangerous during pregnancy, but if it’s accompanied by certain symptoms, Daniel recommends calling your provider right away.
Call your pregnancy provider ASAP if you have a headache and:
Your headaches are new and/or getting worse
You have swelling
You have abdominal pain
You have elevated blood pressure
You have spots in your vision
Your headaches affect your appetite, sleep, or ability to drink water REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
In rare cases, headaches can be a sign of preeclampsia, a dangerous condition that can develop after week 20 of pregnancy.
The bottom line

Headaches usually aren’t a cause for concern during pregnancy, but you may not be able to use your normal treatments, like ibuprofen. Resting, staying hydrated, and eating mostly healthy foods can help prevent headaches. But if you do get a bad headache, there are some pregnancy-safe remedies you can try.

Be sure to tell your pregnancy provider right away if you have a severe headache with swelling, pain in the abdomen, or spots in your vision, or if headaches affect your ability to eat, sleep, or drink water. You can also chat with a
Maven OB-GYN
or
Family Physician
for free advice at any time.
Sources
MedlinePlus
Stanford Children’s Hospital

title.en-US: Constipation during pregnancy: Why it happens and how to get relief

content.value: What you need to know:
Constipation happens when the waste in your digestive tract hardens, rather than leaving the body as stool.
Up to 40% of pregnancy people experience constipation at some point during their pregnancy.
Drinking a lot of water, eating foods that are high in fiber, and elevating your feet while you go to the bathroom can help ease pregnancy-related constipation.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

We all have tummy troubles from time-to-time, but if you haven’t had a bowel movement in a few days or are struggling to have one, you might be dealing with pregnancy-related constipation. The good news is, constipation isn’t usually a sign of something serious, but it can get
really
uncomfortable.
Keep reading to learn why constipation is so common during pregnancy, and what you can do for relief. Still have questions about pregnancy-related constipation? Make a free online appointment with a
Maven provider
for advice.
What is constipation?

Constipation happens when the waste in your digestive tract hardens, rather than becoming soft enough to leave the body as stool (or poop). This can make it difficult or even painful to have a bowel movement.
What are the symptoms of constipation?
Being constipated can feel really uncomfortable. Struggling to poop or not being able to poop are the hallmark symptoms of constipation, but you may also experience things like:
Bloating
Gassiness
Hard, lumpy, dry stools
Bowel movements that are painful REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Straining to go to the bathroom can also cause hemorrhoids, which are swollen veins in your anus or rectum. Hemorrhoids usually go away on their own, but can make going to the bathroom even more uncomfortable. (They’re also more likely to happen while pregnant.)
What causes constipation during pregnancy?
There are a few major things that can make constipation more likely during pregnancy. Maven OB-GYN Rana Daniel, explains:
Your hormones:
The hormone progesterone (which is especially high during the first trimester) slows down movement in the gut, causing waste to collect
Your hydration:
Fluids in your body are drawn to where they’re needed most, like the uterus. Other parts of the body, like your bowels, can become dried out.
Your changing body:
Pressure from your growing uterus puts pressure on the digestive tract, which can slow down digestion and make it hard for the body to pass waste.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Your diet and lifestyle can also have a big effect on your digestive tract. Not eating enough fiber or getting enough movement in your day can lead to constipation. And the iron in your prenatal vitamin—which is essential for a healthy pregnancy—can unfortunately make it tough for the bacteria in your bowels to break down food, so it can be passed.
How common is constipation during pregnancy?
According to the Cleveland Clinic, constipation affects 16% to 39% of pregnant people, but those numbers could be higher.

Constipation is most common during the third trimester when your growing uterus and baby are putting pressure on your bowels, but it can happen at any point during pregnancy. Some people may have constipation up to a few months after their baby is born, too.
What are some pregnancy-safe remedies for constipation?
The good news—there are lots of pregnancy-safe ways to get relief. If you’re struggling to poop—or can’t poop at all—be sure to try these tips:
Drink more water.

Aim for 8 to 12 8-ounce glasses of water (or other fluids) every day. Staying hydrated keeps waste moving through your digestive tract and makes stools softer and easier to pass. If you don’t like drinking water, you can also try low sodium broth, smoothies, milk, or pasteurized fruit juice (try to stick to those without added sugars).
Eat fiber-rich foods.

Daniel says a diet with lots of fiber is a great way to prevent or ease constipation. Eating 25 to 30 grams of fibrous foods makes stools softer, so they’re easier to pass. Plus, eating a mostly healthy diet with lots of fiber-rich foods, like fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes (beans, lentils, or peas) is good for you and your baby. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf you’re really constipated, Daniel recommends foods that act as natural laxatives: “Try prunes, dates, pears, and plums to get things moving.”
Add some movement to your day.

It can be hard to get regular exercise when you’re pregnant, but moving around a little bit every day has lots of benefits for you, your baby, and (ahem) your bowels. You don’t have to do an intense workout—just 20 to 30 minutes of moderate exercise (like walking or prenatal yoga) can help constipation. Just be sure to talk to your pregnancy provider before you start a new exercise routine.
Elevate your feet while you go to the bathroom.

It sounds strange, but changing the way you sit on the toilet can make it easier to have a bowel movement. Try using a footstool, small wastebasket, or a shoebox to elevate your knees to a 90-degree angle while you go (you can also buy a specific stool for this, known as “squatty potties”). One study actually found that this position made study participants strain less and poop more.
Avoid holding it.
When you feel the need to go, go! Holding your poop can make constipation worse. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have severe constipation, talk to your pregnancy provider about safe, over-the-counter supplements or medications you can take for relief. Remember to always talk to your provider or talk to a
Maven provider
before taking any medication or supplement during pregnancy.
When should I call my provider about constipation?

Daniel recommends calling your pregnancy provider if you’re severely constipated and need an over-the-counter supplement or medication to get relief. You should also call your doctor right away if having a bowel movement is very painful or causes bleeding.
The bottom line

Pregnancy-related constipation is rarely a sign of a serious health condition, but it can be very uncomfortable. Certain lifestyle habits, like exercising, drinking a lot of water, and eating fiber-rich foods can help. If you’re very constipated, your pregnancy provider might recommend certain supplements, medications, or suppositories to get your bowels moving—but always ask them before taking any kind of supplement or medication.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
Journal of Clinical Gastroenterology

title.en-US: Pregnancy itching and rashes explained

content.value: What you need to know:
Itchy, tight skin is very common during pregnancy, and isn’t usually the sign of a more serious health issue.
Certain skin conditions, like PUPPP (pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy) need to be treated by a healthcare provider.
Weaning loose clothing, avoiding hot showers or baths, and using gentle, fragrance-free lotion can give you some relief from itchy skin. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Your skin goes through a lot of changes when you’re pregnant. Think: stretching to make way for your growing belly, stretch marks, acne (or gorgeous, glowing skin!), melasma (darker patches of skin on your face), and more.

Itchy skin is super common, too. The good news is that many bouts of itchiness can be chalked up to harmless changes to your skin and hormones—but some pregnancy skin conditions, including itchy or painful rashes, need attention and treatment from your pregnancy provider.
Keep reading to learn about pregnancy-related itchiness and rashes, and when you need to call your pregnancy provider or
talk to a provider for free on Maven.
Common (and usually harmless) causes of itchiness during pregnancy
These causes of itchiness happen fairly often and usually aren’t anything to worry about. Call your doctor to make sure, and to get some tips on how to get relief.
Eczema.

“The most common cause of itchiness during pregnancy is a form of eczema that seems to be triggered by immune changes that happen during pregnancy,” says Maven Family Physician Megan Melo. “This may look like a dry, irritated, itchy, red rash on your chest or neck, or in the creases of your elbows or behind the knees.” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKDeveloping eczema during pregnancy is extremely common, but researchers aren’t 100% sure what causes it. Melo adds, “Pregnancy changes the number and function of your immune cells, so it’s possible that this change leads to a reaction that triggers skin inflammation.” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKFortunately, eczema can usually be managed well with over-the-counter creams, ointments, or lotions. If you think you have eczema, talk to your pregnancy provider or a
Maven Family Physician
. They can help you find the right treatment that’s safe during pregnancy.
Skin stretching.

Your skin stretches as your belly and breasts get bigger. This can make your skin feel itchy, tight, and dry, especially towards the end of your pregnancy when your belly is biggest. You might also feel itchy around stretch marks on other parts of your body.
Hormones.
The hormones that support pregnancy affect your entire body, including your skin. Fluctuations in these hormones can cause dry, flaky, itchy skin.
Dyes, fragrances, and other chemicals.

Your skin can become super sensitive to dyes and fragrances found in everyday household products, like laundry detergent, soap, and lotion. If your skin feels sensitive, try sticking to gentle, dye- and fragrance-free products during pregnancy.
Body temperature.

Pregnancy increases your body temperature, so you may be more likely to get heat rash—especially if you’re pregnant during the summer. Heat rash is caused by excessive sweating, and looks like small, red bumps that can be raised or swollen. Heat rash usually goes away on its own after a few days. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Need help figuring out the cause of your skin itchiness or rash? Make a free online appointment with one of
Maven’s Family Physicians
for help.
6 pregnancy skin conditions to look out for—and call your provider about

“There are a few conditions that can cause itching in pregnancy that need to be treated quickly by a provider,” says Melo. If you have signs of any of these pregnancy-related skin conditions—or any other itchy, painful rash—call your pregnancy provider right away.
REPLACEWITHACCORDION
Pregnancy-safe ways to get relief from itchy skin and rashes
“The best way to prevent itchy skin is moisture,” says Melo. “That includes drinking lots of hydrating fluids (mostly water) throughout the day and treating your skin with care.”
Here are a few other things you can do to get relief from itchy skin and rash:
Take warm oatmeal baths (Melo recommends avoiding hot water, “which can irritate dry skin, leading to more scratching and irritation.”)
Apply cold compresses to the itchy areas
Wear loose, breathable clothing that doesn’t cling to itchy areas or rash
Apply gentle, fragrance-free moisturizer to the affected areas
Take cool showers
Keep your body temperature comfortable and avoid a lot of sweatingREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you have any itchiness or rash during pregnancy, call your provider just to be safe. They might want to do some tests to identify the cause. They can also recommend over-the-counter treatments or give you a prescription for medication, if needed. You should never take any kind of treatment or medication without talking to your pregnancy provider or a
Maven OB-GYN
first; they’ll want to make sure it’s totally safe during pregnancy.
The bottom line

There are several causes of itchiness and rash during pregnancy. Some cases of itchiness are no cause for concern, like dry skin or sensitivity to dyes or perfumes in household products. But other cases can signal something more serious. If you develop a rash that’s extremely itchy or painful during pregnancy, call your pregnancy provider right away. They’ll want to make sure you and the baby are OK.
Sources
Brazilian Society of Dermatology (Pruritic folliculitis)
Cleveland Clinic (Prurigo of pregnancy)
Cleveland Clinic (PUPPP)
Dermatology Research and Practice
(Impetigo herpetiformis)
Mayo Clinic (Cholestasis of pregnancy)
StatPearls
(Pemphigoid gestationis)](
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470287/#:~:text=Pemphigoid%20gestationis%20(PG)%20(previously,pathogenetically%20similar%20to%20bullous%20pemphigoid

items.header: Pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy (PUPPP)

content.value: Pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy—or PUPPP—is an itchy rash that can develop in stretch marks around your belly, then spread to other parts of your body. PUPPP is annoying, but doesn’t pose any risk to you or your baby.
More research is needed to learn what causes PUPPP, but you’re more likely to develop it if:
You’re white
You’re pregnant with a male baby
You’re pregnant with multiples
This is your first pregnancy
PUPPP affects about 1 in every 160 pregnancies, making it the most common pregnancy-related skin condition.

PUPPP usually goes away after 4 to 6 weeks, or shortly after your baby is born. Most cases are treated with prescription steroid creams, but home remedies like oatmeal baths, cold compresses, and cool showers can offer some relief from itching.

PUPPP can easily be mistaken for another pregnancy skin condition called pemphigoid gestationis (PG), which can cause pregnancy complications in rare instances. So if you develop an itchy, hive-like rash on your belly, always call your pregnancy provider right away to make sure. They’ll want to run some tests to rule out PG.

Pemphigoid gestationis (PG) is a rare pregnancy skin condition that causes itchy, red, bumps or blisters to form on your skin, usually in the second or third trimester. The bumps typically develop on the belly, but can appear anywhere on your body, and turn into fluid-filled blisters after a few weeks. In very rare cases, PG can pass to your baby through the placenta.
You’re more likely to develop PG if:
You’re white or have fair skin
This is your second (or more) pregnancy

Fortunately, PG usually goes away on its own a few days to a few weeks after you give birth. Until then, you can manage the discomfort and itchiness by taking oatmeal baths and wearing loose, breathable clothing. In serious cases of PG, your pregnancy provider may prescribe an oral steroid and monitor you and baby for the remainder of your pregnancy.

Prurigo of pregnancy is a rash that causes itchy, red, purple, or pink bumps that can be crusty or scaly. The size of bumps can range from a pinpoint to the size of a pencil eraser. Prurigo of pregnancy is somewhat common—affecting every 1 in 300 pregnancies—but the good news is that it doesn’t have any negative effects on your growing baby.
More research is needed to learn the cause of prurigo of pregnancy, but it’s believed that it has links to:
Cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP)
Your body’s extra blood volume
Allergies
Changes to your immune system
Having other skin conditions, like eczema

If you’re very itchy, your pregnancy provider might recommend an over-the-counter allergy medication or lotion. You should never take any medication without talking to your pregnancy provider first. In the meantime, you might get relief from applying fragrance-free moisturizer or taking cool showers.
Impetigo herpetiformis is an extremely rare skin condition that can happen during pregnancy. It’s so rare that it has been reported in fewer than 100 pregnancies.
However, impetigo herpetiformis can be very dangerous for both parent and baby. It has been linked to:
Placental insufficiency (when your placenta doesn’t get oxygen and nutrients to your baby properly)
IUGR (intrauterine growth restriction, when baby doesn’t grow as expected)
Preterm premature rupture of membranes (when your water breaks too early)
Stillbirth (when a pregnancy ends after week 20)

Impetigo herpetiformis causes pus-filled bumps (called pustules) to form on the thighs and groin. These patches of pustules can combine to spread all over the body. Other symptoms are fever, nausea, vomiting, chills, and diarrhea.
Researchers aren’t sure what causes impetigo herpetiformis, but people with hypoparathyroidism (when the parathyroid glands don’t produce enough parathyroid hormone) are at an increased risk.

If you develop any pus-filled bumps or blisters during pregnancy, call your provider immediately. Impetigo herpetiformis is very rare, but it can cause serious complications and it’s always better to be safe.

Affecting about 1 in every 3,000 pregnancies, pruritic folliculitis of pregnancy is a rash that typically develops in the second or third trimester. It causes itchy, red bumps that may or may not contain pus to develop on the upper-half of your body. Pruritic folliculitis usually goes away on its own a few weeks to months after you deliver and there’s no evidence that it causes health problems in you or your baby.
Researchers aren’t sure what causes pruritic folliculitis, but some believe it’s caused by changes to your hormones during pregnancy.

Pruritic folliculitis is similar to acne, so it’s often treated with acne treatments, like benzoyl peroxide or UV light therapy. Remember, you should never start any treatment for a skin condition without talking to your pregnancy provider first.

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP)—known as cholestasis of pregnancy or cholestasis—is a condition that harms the way your liver works. Most cases of cholestasis develop during the third trimester of pregnancy.

Cholestasis causes bile (a substance your body produces to break down fat in the food you eat) to collect in the liver and bloodstream. When this build up reaches a certain level, it can cause extreme itchiness on your hands, feet, and other parts of the body, and can be very dangerous for your baby.

The tell-tale sign of cholestasis is feeling very itchy without a rash. It can affect any part of your body, but most people with cholestasis have very itchy palms of the hand and soles of the feet that get worse at night.
Some other symptoms of cholestasis are:
Dark urine
Light gray or pale brown poop
Extreme fatigue
Jaundice (when your skin and the white of your eyes turn yellow)
Loss of appetite
If you have any of these symptoms, call your pregnancy provider or chat with a
Maven OB-GYN

for advice ASAP. They’ll need to order bloodwork to see if you have cholestasis or something else. Cholestasis has been linked to dangerous health problems in babies, like preterm birth, lung problems, and stillbirth, so it’s important to get care right away.

Treatment for cholestasis includes medication to lower bile levels and relieve itching. In severe cases, your pregnancy provider might recommend inducing labor at week 37 or 38 of pregnancy to protect the baby from the effects of cholestasis. After you give birth, you’ll need bloodwork to make sure your liver function has returned to normal.

If you do develop cholestasis, know that your pregnancy provider will monitor you and your baby very closely for the rest of your pregnancy. Having cholestasis doesn’t mean your baby will be unhealthy—many people who have cholestasis have healthy babies without any long-lasting health problems—but getting treatment right away is key.

title.en-US: Pregnancy bloating and gas: What causes it and what to do about it

content.value: What you need to know:
Bloating and gas are very common during pregnancy due to hormonal changes and changes to the way your body digests food.
Eating foods high in fiber, adding more movement to your day, and sipping warm water with lemon can help alleviate bloating during pregnancy.
Call your pregnancy provider if you’re unable to pass gas, have painful bloating or gas, or have blood in your stool. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you’re dealing with some of the less-than-glamorous side effects of pregnancy (read: bloating and gas), you’re definitely not alone. In fact, bloating and gas are some of the most common side effects of pregnancy out there. The good news is that both are completely normal, but they can get pretty uncomfortable after 40 (or more!) weeks of pregnancy.
Keep reading to learn about what causes bloating and gas during pregnancy, and simple ways you can get some relief.
Your changing body can cause bloating and gas

Bloating and gas are early signs of pregnancy for many people thanks to the surge in the pregnancy hormone progesterone, says Maven OB-GYN Rana Daniel. She adds, “Often, the bloating is so significant in the first trimester, people often feel they’re showing.”

When you become pregnant, your body ups its production of progesterone to support your pregnancy. Among other things, progesterone relaxes the muscles in your body, including the muscles in your digestive tract. This can lead to slower digestion and uncomfortable bloating and gas.
On top of that, as your pregnancy progresses, your growing uterus puts more and more pressure on your digestive tract—which also slows digestion and leads to bloating.
These changes to your hormones and body can also cause constipation (or struggling to have a bowel movement) which—you guessed it!—worsens bloating and gas.
Learn more about pregnancy-related constipation and things you can do to feel better here.
Your diet could be causing bloating and gas, too

Eating a mostly balanced diet with lots of fruits, veggies, whole grains, dairy products, and proteins is an important part of a healthy pregnancy. It’s very common for people to feel bloated and gassy from things like fried food, soda, and sweets, but even super healthy foods, like beans, certain veggies (like broccoli, cauliflower, and Brussels sprouts), and dairy can cause bloating and gas. Daniel adds, “Raw vegetables and dairy products most commonly trigger bloating.”
Rather than skipping these good-for-you foods—and missing out on the important nutrients they provide for you and baby—you might consider:
Keeping a food diary to figure out which foods, exactly, make you feel bloated and gassy so you can avoid them
Cutting back on your serving sizes of foods that cause bloating and gas
Splitting your regular 3 meals per day into 6 small meals per day (this gives your digestive system a break, so it doesn’t become overloaded with larger meals)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Need help figuring out which foods are causing bloating and gas? Talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
for advice, and easy, healthy meal ideas that might help you avoid tummy troubles.
Pregnancy-safe remedies for bloating and gas
While some treatments for bloating and gas are off the table during pregnancy, there are lots of simple lifestyle changes you can make to get some relief. Here are some things you can try:
Drink a lot of water.

Staying hydrated will keep your digestive system moving, so you can avoid becoming constipated (which makes bloating and gas worse). The general recommendation is to drink 8 to 12 8-ounce glasses of water every day, but if you need a little variety, milk, pasteurized fruit juice with no added sugars, and broth can be hydrating, too.
Eat enough fiber.

Eating foods with fiber, like fruits, veggies, whole grains (like whole grain bread or pasta), and beans are a great way to curb constipation and the bloating it causes. Aim for 25 to 35 grams of fiber (about five servings of fruits and veggies) every day.
Move more.
According to Daniel, light exercises, like walking and prenatal yoga (if your pregnancy provider gives you the OK to exercise!), can gently release some of your belly bloating and gas.
Try a free prenatal yoga class from Maven.
Sip warm water with lemon or tea.
Drinking warm water or a pregnancy-safe tea can stimulate your bowels to get things moving again. Talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
to find out if your favorite tea is safe to drink during pregnancy.
Eat and drink slowly.

When you eat or drink too quickly, you can swallow a lot of air, which causes bloating and gas. It’s tough with a busy schedule, but try to eat your meals at a slower pace. You might also want to avoid drinking from straws, which make you swallow a lot of air.
Add probiotic foods to your diet.

Foods like yogurt, sourdough bread, pickles, kimchi, and sauerkraut contain naturally-occurring probiotics, which support the good bacteria in your gut. Not into fermented foods? Ask your pregnancy provider if it’s safe for you to take a probiotic supplement.
When to call your pregnancy provider

The good news is that bloating and gas are very common side effects of pregnancy, and don’t normally signal a serious problem. But Daniel recommends calling your pregnancy provider in a few scenarios.
Call your provider right away if:
Bloating is painful
You’re unable to pass gas and have nausea or vomiting
If you have blood in your stoolREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Your pregnancy provider can also prescribe or recommend pregnancy-safe treatments that can give you some relief. Just be sure to talk to your provider before you take any kind of medication or treatment—many are not considered safe for pregnancy.
The bottom line

Bloating and gas are extremely common during pregnancy and typically don’t go away until after baby is born. You can get some relief from that bloated, gassy feeling by making easy lifestyle changes, like drinking more water, doing gentle exercises (with your pregnancy provider’s OK), or eating foods that contain probiotics. If you’re severely bloated, your provider can prescribe or recommend a treatment that’s safe for pregnancy.
If you ever have any questions or concerns,
Maven providers
are here to help. Make a free online appointment for advice at any time.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
Gastroenterology Nursing

title.en-US: Cholestasis of pregnancy: Why severe itching can happen when you’re expecting

content.value: What you need to know:
Cholestasis of pregnancy is a rare, but serious condition that harms the way your liver works during pregnancy.
Cholestasis can be dangerous for your baby if left untreated.
Very itchy hands and feet are the main symptom of cholestasis. Call your pregnancy provider right away if your hands and feet are itchy. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Certain parts of pregnancy can be pretty uncomfortable. Think: having to pee all the time, swollen feet, a sore back, and itchy skin. But severe itchiness isn't just annoying—it might signal a serious health condition, too.
Here’s what you need to know about cholestasis of pregnancy, a rare, but serious condition that causes severe itching and can be dangerous during pregnancy.
What is cholestasis of pregnancy?

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP)—most often known as cholestasis of pregnancy or simply cholestasis—is a condition that harms the way your liver works in late pregnancy. Most cases of cholestasis develop during the third trimester or around week 28 of pregnancy.

Cholestasis causes bile (a substance your body produces to break down fat in the food you eat) to build up in the liver and bloodstream. When bile build up reaches a certain level, it can cause extreme itchiness on your hands, feet, and other parts of the body, and can be very dangerous for your baby.
What are the symptoms of cholestasis?

The major sign of cholestasis is feeling very itchy without a rash. It can affect any part of your body, but most people with cholestasis have very itchy hands and feet. The itchiness usually gets worse at night, too.
Some other symptoms of cholestasis are:
Dark urine
Light gray or pale brown poop
Extreme fatigue
Jaundice (when your skin and the white of your eyes turn yellow)
Loss of appetiteREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have any of these symptoms, call your pregnancy provider or chat with a
Maven OB-GYN
for advice ASAP.
How is cholestasis itchiness different from normal pregnancy itchiness?

“Normal pregnancy itching usually gets better with lotion or Vaseline, or may start with a rash on your belly,” says Maven OB-GYN Kathleen Green. “Cholestasis itching usually starts on the hands and feet with no rash present.”
If you’re having any itching while pregnant, always tell your doctor just to be safe.
How common is cholestasis?

Fortunately, cholestasis isn’t a super common condition. According to Cleveland Clinic, about 1 to 2 in every 1,000 pregnant people (0.001% to 0.002%) get it. Cleveland Clinic also says that being Hispanic or having a Swedish background also increases the risk of getting cholestasis.
Cholestasis is diagnosed more frequently in the winter, but more research is needed to figure out why.
What causes pregnant people to develop cholestasis?

When you’re pregnant, higher levels of estrogen and progesterone change the way your liver moves bile. Since bile doesn’t move through your body as well, it can build up in your liver and enter your bloodstream.
What are the risks of developing cholestasis during pregnancy?
Your liver is responsible for removing waste from your body and your baby’s body. If it’s not working the way it should, bile can build up to dangerous levels in your liver and baby’s liver.
In pregnant people

, cholestasis can make it hard for your body to absorb vitamin K from the foods you eat. This can increase your risk of severe bleeding. Cholestasis has also been linked to preeclampsia (a condition that causes dangerously high blood pressure) and gestational diabetes (a type of diabetes that develops during pregnancy).
In baby
, cholestasis can have very dangerous complications. Some of these complications include:
Preterm birth (being born before week 37 of pregnancy)
Problems with their lungs from breathing in meconium (baby’s poop can pass to your amniotic fluid if you have cholestasis)
Stillbirth (when a pregnancy ends after week 20)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have cholestasis, your pregnancy provider will watch you and your baby very closely. They might recommend inducing labor before your due date to protect your baby from serious complications.
Keep in mind: having cholestasis does
not
mean your baby will have health problems. Many people with cholestasis give birth to perfectly healthy babies. It’s important to get treatment right away, so you can keep yourself and your baby safe.
How is cholestasis diagnosed?

If you have symptoms of cholestasis, your pregnancy provider will do a physical exam and blood work to see how your liver is functioning. They’ll also use a blood test to measure the amount of bile acids in your bloodstream.
Depending on the results, your pregnancy provider might recommend doing blood work several times throughout your pregnancy to monitor the bile acids in your blood.
Remember: if you have symptoms of cholestasis, it’s important to call your pregnancy provider right away. The sooner you treat cholestasis, the better you and baby will be.
How is cholestasis treated?

“If you’re diagnosed with cholestasis, there are medications that can help the itching and help the liver clear bile acids. But the main treatment is monitoring and delivering the baby,” says Green. This is because cholestasis usually goes away on its own in the days after you give birth.

If medication doesn’t improve your liver function (based on blood test results), your pregnancy provider may recommend inducing labor around week 37 or 38 of pregnancy. Until labor begins or you’re induced, they’ll check on your baby using nonstress tests once or twice a week, Green says.
In addition to taking medication, here are some things you can do to ease the itchiness of cholestasis:
Use pregnancy-safe anti-itch cream (ask your pregnancy provider for their recommendation)
Take warm baths (not hot, as this can dry your skin out and lead to more itching)
Wear loose, comfortable clothing to allow your skin to breatheREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Once you have given birth and your bile acids have reached normal levels again, you can stop taking medication—but always check with your pregnancy provider first.
Are there ways to avoid cholestasis?
Unfortunately, there isn’t any way to prevent cholestasis of pregnancy. Many researchers think it may be genetic and that it runs in families.
Some risk factors for developing cholestasis are:
Having a family member who had cholestasis
Having cholestasis in a previous pregnancy
Being pregnant with multiples (twins, triplets, or more)
Having a history of liver problems, like hepatitis CREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you had cholestasis before and get pregnant again, Cleveland Clinic says there’s a 60% chance you’ll develop it again. In very severe cases of cholestasis, the risk of developing the condition in future pregnancies increases to 90%.
If you have any risk factors for cholestasis, talk to your pregnancy provider. They might want to monitor your bile acids as your pregnancy progresses.
The bottom line

Cholestasis of pregnancy is a fairly rare, but serious condition that happens later in pregnancy. It can cause extreme itchiness on your hands, feet, and other parts of the body, and can cause serious complications in your baby. If you develop any symptoms of cholestasis, tell your pregnancy provider right away. They will closely monitor you and your baby to keep you both safe until you give birth.
Have questions about cholestasis? Chat with a
Maven OB-GYN
for more information or advice.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
Mayo Clinic

title.en-US: Your guide to postpartum nutrition

content.value: What you need to know:
Eating a balanced diet and drinking plenty of water can help your body and mind recover from pregnancy, labor, and delivery.
Try to eat a wide variety of foods, especially foods that are high in protein, carbohydrates, and healthy fats (like avocados, peanut butter, or olive oil).
Don’t stress about “bouncing back”--it’s more important to nourish your postpartum body, so you can recover. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
When you’re newly postpartum, it may feel like all of your energy goes into taking care of your little one—but after going through 9 to 10 months of pregnancy
and

labor and delivery, it’s important to take care of yourself, too. One simple way to help your body and mind recover from pregnancy and birth is to eat a balanced diet and to drink enough water to stay hydrated.

Not sure what’s on the menu for your next meal? (Newborn life. We don’t blame you.) Here’s everything you need to know about eating a balanced diet during the postpartum period, plus some simple meal and snack ideas.
Why you need to focus on your postpartum nutrition

There are so many benefits to eating a balanced diet—it lowers your risk of certain health conditions (like heart disease or type 2 diabetes), and improves your mood and digestion. But eating well during the postpartum period is especially important. Here’s why:
A healthy diet helps your body heal.
Your body has been through
a lot

over the last several months. A nutritious diet provides the fuel your body needs to heal itself. Certain nutrients can even help you avoid postpartum complications. For example, iron-rich foods replenish your body’s iron supply and foods with a lot of fiber can help you avoid postpartum constipation.
A healthy diet boosts milk production (if you choose to breastfeed).
Eating a balanced diet and drinking plenty of water is important for increasing and maintaining your milk supply if you breastfeed or pump.
A healthy diet gives you the energy you need for the fourth trimester.
Taking care of a newborn is exhausting, but a balanced diet can give your body the energy to keep up with late-night feedings, never-ending laundry, and diaper blowouts.
What are the most important nutrients during the postpartum period?

“All nutrients play important roles in all bodies, in all stages of the life cycle,” says Maven Nutritionist Kendra Tolbert, MS, RDN, RYT. “Not getting enough of any one nutrient could be detrimental. But macronutrients are the nutrients we need in larger amounts. Think: protein, carbohydrates, and fat. These macronutrients provide the energy (calories) that fuels the important processes in our bodies.”
It’s important to eat a wide variety of foods, but you can find macronutrients in these:
Protein:
meats, fish, shellfish, eggs, beans, peas, lentils, and soy products
Carbohydrates:
fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and dairy products
Fat:
olive oil, nuts, nut butters, and avocadosREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

There’s no single postpartum diet you need to follow in order to be healthy, but it’s a good idea to eat a variety of healthy foods. And if you’re craving a not-so-healthy food, don’t feel like you need to deprive yourself. If you want a bacon cheeseburger or pizza, go for it! Just try to balance it out with healthier options at your next meal.
What to drink during the postpartum period

It’s also important to stay hydrated during the postpartum period, especially if you’re breastfeeding. Drink at least 8 cups of water per day to help your body heal itself in the early postpartum days, and maintain your milk supply if you choose to breastfeed or pump.
You don’t have to stick to plain ol’ water though. Fruit juice without added sugars, smoothies, broth, and milk can keep you hydrated, too.
Have questions about postpartum nutrition? Make a free online appointment with a
Maven Nutritionist
for advice.
What not to eat during the postpartum period

The good news is that many foods that were off-the-table during pregnancy—like sushi, raw shellfish, or undercooked meat or eggs—are finally safe to eat again now when you’re in the postpartum period.

But if you breastfeed or pump, there are still a few foods you shouldn’t eat until baby is weaned. Be sure to avoid high mercury fish, like big eye tuna, king mackerel, shark, swordfish, or tilefish; mercury can be passed from parent to baby through breast milk. And if you want to have the occasional
alcoholic drink
, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) says it’s OK as long as you wait at least 2 hours between drinking your last drink and nursing or pumping.
Easy-to-make meals for postpartum parents
For some parents of newborns, it can be tough to find the time to take a shower—let alone make an entire healthy meal
and

sit down to eat it. That’s why Tolbert recommends combining food groups at mealtimes: “Combining food groups gives you an interesting eating experience while providing a variety of foods. Eating a lot of different foods is one way to ensure you’re eating a wide variety of nutrients.”
Don’t know what to make? Here are some of Tolbert’s favorite snacks and meals for postpartum parents. Bonus: all of these foods can be prepared quickly and eaten with one hand!
Cheese and crackers
Sandwiches, wraps, or burritos
Quesadillas with cheese, veggies, and/or protein, like chicken, lean beef, or beans
Toast with toppings like avocado, hummus, cheese, nut butter, veggies, eggs, bean dip, or fruit
Smoothies with fruits, veggies, and nut butter
Fruit and nut barsREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Some other high-nutrient and low-prep foods you might want to pick up on your next grocery run are:
Light canned tuna, salmon, or low-sodium canned chunk chicken for sandwiches, wraps, or casseroles
Whole grain bread
Greek yogurt or low-sugar yogurt
Whole wheat pasta
Quick-cook brown rice
Oatmeal
Lentils
Eggs
String cheese
Your favorite fresh or frozen fruits and veggiesREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Chat with a
Maven Nutritionist
for other simple, but healthy meal and snack ideas you can try.
What about prenatal or postnatal vitamins?

Ask your pregnancy provider if they recommend continuing to take your prenatal vitamin or starting a postnatal vitamin after you give birth. Some people, especially those who follow a special diet like veganism, vegetarianism, or gluten-free, might benefit from additional supplements, too.
Don’t stress about “bouncing back”

It may be easier said than done, but focusing too much on trying to “bounce back” to your pre-pregnancy body—and too little on nourishing your postpartum body—can sometimes do more harm than good. Tolbert says, “With so much focus on caring for the baby, it’s easy to skip meals and not get enough energy from food. Couple that with the pressure to ‘lose the baby weight’ or ‘bounce back,’ and a lot of people end up not getting enough calories.”
If you restrict your calorie intake too much in the postpartum period, you can experience things like:
Very low energy and fatigue
Reduced milk production (your body needs calories to produce breast milk)
Weight loss that comes back once you stop cutting calories
Muscle loss REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you’re exclusively breastfeeding or pumping, it’s especially important to get enough calories every day—your body needs about 350 to 500 extra calories per day to produce breast milk.

Rather than restricting your calorie intake or dieting during the postpartum period, it’s a good idea to focus on eating wholesome, nutritious foods, and giving your body the energy it needs to take care of a newborn (and yourself). Tolbert adds, “See food as a tool to support recovery and a source of fuel, rather than something to control the size of your body. You grew a human, went through the marathon of labor and delivery, and now your body is healing—plus, you’re caring for that human. Your body needs a lot of energy and nutrients to support all of those things.”
The bottom line

The postpartum period can be completely exhausting, but taking care of yourself by eating a nutritious diet and drinking plenty of water can help your body and mind recover from pregnancy and birth, and give you the energy you need to take care of your newborn. There isn’t an exact postpartum diet to follow, but eating lots of fruits and veggies, whole grains, proteins, healthy fats, and low-fat dairy products is a great place to start.
Remember, if you ever have questions about your postpartum nutrition,
Maven Nutritionists
are here to help 24/7. Book a free appointment or message them anytime for advice!
Sources
ACOG
MedlinePlus

title.en-US: How to use a double electric breast pump

content.value: What you need to know:
The Affordable Care Act (ACA) requires all insurance providers, including Medicaid, to cover the cost of an electric breast pump.
Read your pump’s instruction manual to learn how to set up your pump for the first time, use the controls, and clean your pump parts.
If you need help using your pump, make an online appointment with a
Maven Lactation Consultant
for free advice.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
There’s no one right way to feed your baby, but using a double electric breast pump can be helpful if you need a break from nursing, you’re returning to work, or your baby is unable to breastfeed.

It may feel challenging at first, but over time, you’ll learn which pump settings work best for your body, whether you pump every once in a while, every few days, or every day. Here’s how to get started.
If you’re ever having trouble with your pump, remember we’re here for you. Talk to a
Lactation Consultant on Maven
anytime you need to for free.
How to choose a double electric breast pump

There are so many breast pumps on the market, having to choose one may feel overwhelming. But it’s a good idea to start with a phone call to your insurance provider. Thanks to the Affordable Care Act (ACA),
insurance providers, including Medicaid, are required to cover the cost of electric breast pumps
. Most plans will send you your pump within 30 days of your due date or after your baby is born.

Give yourself plenty of time and call your provider a few months before your due date. Ask them what they cover and the steps you need to take to get your pump at no cost. If you don’t like the models that are fully covered by your insurance provider, many insurance companies will let you upgrade to different models and pay part of the cost.

If you don’t want to go through your insurance provider for a pump, consider adding your preferred model to your baby registry. Your hospital or birthing center might also offer rentals on breast pumps that are safe for use by more than one person (these are called “hospital grade” pumps.)
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) doesn’t recommend reusing double electric breast pumps, so it’s best to avoid buying a used pump or taking a hand-me-down from a friend or family member.
Some other things you might want to consider when choosing a pump are:
How often you’ll need to pump (if you plan to combination feed or exclusively pump, you might want a more powerful pump that can handle several sessions per day)
If you’ll be pumping at work (a portable pump might work best for you while at work, and you may want a different kind at home)
Any brand preferences you may have REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you’re feeling totally lost, don’t worry—
Maven Lactation Consultants
are here to help. They can walk you through the pros and cons of pumps you’re interested in, so you can make the best decision for you and baby. Make an appointment for personalized advice anytime.
Breast pump parts, explained

Once you receive your pump, do an inventory of all the parts that come with it. You’ll want to make sure you’re not missing anything important. Plus, it can be helpful to get familiar with all of those parts ahead of time. You don’t want to wait to figure out how your pump works while you’re leaking milk and holding a hungry newborn!
Here’s are the parts that should come with your pump—and what they’re for:
Flanges
Flanges (sometimes called breast shields) are the plastic, trumpet-shaped parts that go against your breast while you’re pumping.

Many pumps come with standard-sized flanges (like 24 mm and 27 mm), but there’s a wide range of flange sizes; these measurements are based on the size of your nipple. Even though manufacturers include standard size pumps, it’s important to have the correct size flange for your body, says Maven Lactation Consultant Michelle Poole: “Having the correct flange size is critical to establishing and maintaining a milk supply. The wrong size flange not only tends to cause pain and nipple damage, but also can cause your milk supply to drop.”
In addition to lowering your milk supply, having a flange that’s
too
small
or
too
large
can cause:
Blisters that fill with breastmilk (called “blebs”)
Redness, swelling, and pain around your nipple
Clogged milk ducts (a major risk factor for mastitis)
Damage to your nipple and breast tissuesREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
It’s best to get measured for your flanges by a lactation consultant (you can ask a
Maven Lactation Consultant
to help!), but if you’re unable to, there are lots of free, printable tools you can use to measure yourself from breast pump brands like
Spectra
and
Medela
Know that your flange size can change, especially if your first measurements are taken during pregnancy or while your milk supply is being established.
Backflow protectors

If you have a closed pump system (meaning breastmilk is blocked from flowing into the mechanical base of the pump), it will come with backflow protectors. These are small, plastic shields with a silicone membrane that protect your pump’s tubing from milk overflow.
If you have an open pump system (which are less common), you will not need backflow protectors.
Duckbill valves

Duckbill valves are silicone valves that are shaped like a duck’s bill. They attach to the bottom of your flanges and help your milk flow from the flange into your collection bottles. They also help with suction that removes milk from your breasts.
Tubing

Tubing connects your flange to the mechanical base of your breast pump and provides suction to remove milk from your breasts. In a closed system, you should never see milk inside the tubing. If milk does enter the tubing, it’s best to throw it away and buy new tubing.
Milk collection bottles

Milk collection bottles are small bottles that screw onto the bottom of your flanges. Your milk will flow from the flanges to the milk collection bottles while you pump. You can store milk in these bottles or attach a nipple to the bottle to feed your baby.
Replacing your pump parts

Depending on how frequently you pump, you can expect to replace your pump parts every few weeks to every six months. If you exclusively pump, for example, you’ll likely need to replace your duckbill valves every few weeks. Flanges, backflow protectors, and tubing can usually be replaced every three to six months. If you notice a dip in your breast milk supply or your parts are looking worn out, it might be time to buy a new set.
Many insurance providers cover the cost of replacement parts. Be sure to contact your provider to see which parts are eligible for coverage.
How to prepare your breast pump for use
Every breast pump is a little bit different, so be sure to read your pump’s instruction manual before you start pumping.

Many pump manufacturers recommend sterilizing your pump parts before using them for the first time. This can be done in boiling water or a microwave sterilization bag. Not all parts should be sterilized, so pay close attention to the recommendations in the instruction manual.

If your manual doesn’t recommend sterilization, wash all of the removable parts (like flanges, duckbill valves, backflow protectors, and collection bottles) with warm, soapy water and put them in a clean place to dry. If you use a closed system pump, never wash your tubing. It’s very difficult to get your tubing fully dry, which can lead to mold.
You will need to wash these same pieces after each pumping session. Learn more about washing your pump parts
here
Understanding the controls on your pump
All breast pumps are slightly different, but most have three main settings:
Stimulation mode

, which mimics the quick sucking motion of infants starting to breastfeed. The quicker suction in stimulation mode stimulates your prolactin and oxytocin (milk-making hormones) and typically leads to let-down (when milk starts flowing from your breasts).
Expression mode
, which mimics the slower, stronger sucking patterns of infants when they’re actively breastfeeding (after your milk has started to flow).
Vacuum

buttons, so you can increase or decrease the strength of the pump’s suction. Poole recommends starting at a very low level of suction and working your way up, making sure it never feels painful: “Many pumping parents think that if they crank the suction all the way up, they’ll get more milk more quickly. However, this is not usually the case. Too high a suction causes pain, and pain can actually cause less milk to flow, as it blocks milk-making hormones.”REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Some pumps have a fourth control that allows you to increase or decrease the number of sucks per minute.

It may take some time to figure out the best suction and speed for you—but remember, pumping should never feel painful. If you’re having a hard time understanding how your pump works or need help finding the right levels make an appointment with a
Maven Lactation Consultant
How to pump breast milk with a double electric pump
Once your pump parts have been cleaned and assembled according to your pump’s instruction manual, it’s ready for use. Here’s how to get started:
Wash your hands
with soap and warm water.
Center your nipple
in the center opening or “horn” of the flange. You can hold the flanges against your breasts or wear a pumping bra that holds them in place for you.
Press the stimulation mode button

on your pump. You should feel a quick, but gentle sucking pattern. Consider looking at pictures or videos of your baby, or smelling an item of their clothing while you pump—this can stimulate let-down!
Move to expression mode.
Many pumps switch from stimulation mode to expression mode after two minutes, or you can change modes manually. Then, you can adjust the suction level and speed according to your comfort.
Pump for 15 minutes
, even if the milk stops flowing. Continuing to pump after the milk stops stimulates your breasts to keep making milk, which is good for your supply.
Use the milk or store in the refrigerator for later

. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), freshly pumped milk can stay out of the fridge for up to four hours. It will last in the fridge for up to four days, and in a freezer for up to 12 months.
Disassemble your pump and wash

all of the removable parts (flanges, duckbill valves, and backflow protectors) in warm, soapy water. Let them air dry on a bottle rack or a clean paper towel—drying them with a kitchen towel can introduce bacteria that could be harmful to your baby.
We’re here to help

Every person is different. You may find you need more or less time pumping to completely empty your breasts. Using a breast pump has a little bit of a learning curve, so don’t feel disappointed if it takes some time to figure out what works best for you, your body, and your baby.

Poole adds, “If you’re unsure about how the pump works, how often you should be using it, and how much milk you should be stashing in the freezer, I'd encourage you to work with a lactation consultant to come up with the perfect pumping plan for you.”
Maven Lactation Consultants
are always here to help if you have questions.
The bottom line

It may take a little while to learn how to use your breast pump to express the most breast milk, but over time, you’ll learn what works best for your body and your baby. Reading your pump’s instruction manual and talking to a
Maven Lactation Consultant
are two great places to start when you’re learning how to pump.

Whether you pump occasionally, often, or every day, remember: “The ‘best’ way to feed your baby is the way that works best for you! And as long as your baby is fed and loved, no matter what that looks like—you’re doing a great job,” says Poole.
Sources
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Spectra
U.S. Food and Drug Administration

title.en-US: The best foods to boost your breast milk

content.value: What you need to know:
Nursing or pumping frequently is the best way to boost your breast milk supply, but eating a balanced diet and staying hydrated are great ways to maintain it.
Your body needs an extra 350 to 500 calories per day to produce breast milk. Try to get these calories from nutritious foods that will give you energy.
Talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
if you need easy-to-make meals or snacks that are good for your milk supply. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Good news: There isn’t an exact diet you need to follow if you’re breastfeeding (which includes nursing and pumping), but giving your body plenty of nutrients and hydration IS important for keeping your supply up and running. Plus, a balanced diet will give you energy for all those middle-of-the-night nursing or pumping sessions.
Here are some foods and drinks to try to include in your daily meal rotation to best support your body during your breastfeeding journey.
Why a balanced diet is good for breastfeeding

There are so many benefits of a healthy diet, it reduces your risk of certain chronic conditions like heart disease or type 2 diabetes, helps you have better digestion, and it even ups your energy levels (a must for making it through the fourth trimester and beyond!).
Here’s why eating a balanced diet is so important for making breast milk, too:
You need extra calories while you’re breastfeeding.

Your body needs extra energy to produce breast milk and maintain your supply. In fact, most breastfeeding and pumping parents need an extra 350 to 500 calories per day to keep their supply up. As much as you can, try to get those extra calories from nutrient-dense foods that will fuel your body, like fruits and vegetables, whole grains, proteins, and low-fat dairy products ... with the occasional cheeseburger or ice cream for good measure.
Breastfeeding takes from your body’s nutrient reserves.

It’s true that you don’t need a perfectly healthy diet to give your baby perfect breast milk—your body will take what it needs from your nutrient stores to make sure baby gets the right balance of carbohydrates, fats, protein, vitamins, and minerals. But depleting your body’s nutrient stores on a regular basis isn’t good for your health. Try to replace what your body takes for baby by eating a wide variety of wholesome foods for you!
Breastfeeding and taking care of a newborn can make you feel exhausted.

Taking care of a new baby is beyond exhausting*.* That, plus work, child care for older kids, household responsibilities, and breastfeeding or pumping on top of it all? You may be left feeling like a zombie. Giving your body nutrient-dense foods can give you the energy you need to keep up with the demands of parenthood.
Do certain foods really increase breast milk supply?
Many people believe certain foods can increase your supply of breast milk. These foods, like oats, flaxseeds, fennel, and ginger are called galactagogues, says Maven Nutritionist Kendra Tolbert.

Unfortunately, it hasn’t been proven that galactagogues increase breast milk supply—more research is needed. “But there’s plenty of anecdotal evidence that they’re effective. Plus, there’s no harm in eating these foods,” she says.
Even if galactagogues aren’t proven to increase your supply, many are jam-packed with nutrients that will fuel your body. Some good-for-you galactagogues include:
Oatmeal, which is high in whole grains and fiber
Flaxseeds, which contain protein, fiber, and omega-3 fatty acids
Sweet potatoes, which are a good source of fiber, vitamins, and minerals
Chickpeas, which are high in protein, fiber, potassium, and iron
Lentils, which contain protein, fiber, and ironREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Remember: nursing or pumping often is the best way to increase your milk supply. If you need help boosting your supply, talk to a
Maven Lactation Consultant
for free, personalized advice.
Why eating a variety of foods is best
Rather than focusing on specific foods or food groups, it’s a good idea to eat a wide variety of foods when you’re making breast milk.

Tolbert says, “Foods from all food groups are important in their own way. I recommend focusing on eating a variety of foods from all food groups to optimize your chances of getting the various nutrients your body needs. Continuing to take a prenatal supplement will also help with meeting your nutrient needs.”
Quick meal ideas for milk-making parents

For many breastfeeding or pumping parents, the hunger is real. “Many people become absolutely ravenous,” says Tolbert. So, when breastfeeding hunger strikes—or you’re too sleep-deprived to even think about what to make for dinner—we recommend one of these easy, nutrient-dense meals or snacks:
Cold cut sandwiches on whole grain bread
Wraps or burritos with veggies and protein, like light canned tuna or canned salmon
Quesadillas with veggies and cheese, or proteins, like lean beef, chicken, or ground turkey
Smoothies with fruit, veggies, and nut butter
Greek yogurt with fruit, like berries or apple slices
Scrambled eggs or egg sandwiches with cheese and turkey bacon
Whole wheat pasta with veggies and mozzarella cheese
Quick-cook brown rice with canned black beans, salsa, sour cream, and guacamole
Cheese and crackers or string cheeseREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Remember: there’s no perfect diet for breastfeeding—just try to choose foods that nourish your body when you can. If you’re craving something that isn’t super healthy, go for it! You can balance it out with a healthier food at your next snack or mealtime.
Looking for more easy meals that support breastfeeding? Chat with a
Maven Nutritionist
for other ideas.
What to drink while you’re breastfeeding

Staying hydrated throughout the day is a good way to protect your milk supply. There’s no one-size-fits-all approach to hydration, so Tolbert recommends drinking according to your thirst. “Needs vary from person to person, and can change,” she says. “I often encourage people to keep fluids around their home and office as a reminder to drink throughout the day. Having a beverage after feeding or pumping can help make staying hydrated easier.”
In addition to water, fluids like fruit juice without added sugars, low-sodium broth, smoothies, and milk can help keep you hydrated, too.
Not sure if you’re drinking enough? Check the color of your urine during your next bathroom trip. Tolbert recommends aiming for light yellow to clear urine.
Foods and drinks to avoid while breastfeeding
Foods that were off-limits during pregnancy—like sushi, cold cuts, and soft cheeses—are back on the menu! But there are still a few things you should skip until you’re finished breastfeeding:
High mercury fish
Big eye tuna, king mackerel, shark, swordfish and tilefish are all considered high in mercury. Mercury can pass from parent to baby through breastmilk, so it’s best to totally avoid these fish.
Excessive alcohol

If you want the occasional alcoholic drink, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) says it’s OK as long as you stick to one drink and wait at least two hours between drinking and when you nurse or pump. It’s not recommended to have more than two alcoholic drinks per day while breastfeeding. As a reminder, one drink is equal to:
12 ounces of beer
5 ounces of wine
1.5 ounces of liquor
Excessive caffeine
Newborns can be sensitive to caffeine in amounts greater than 200 mg, so the ACOG recommends sticking to one or two cups of regular coffee (standard size, not jumbo!) per day.
The bottom line

Eating a wholesome diet with lots of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, proteins, healthy fats, and low-fat dairy products can increase and maintain your breast milk supply during your breastfeeding journey. There isn’t a single diet to follow, so just try to make healthy choices throughout the day. And remember to stay hydrated, whether you drink water, fruit juice without added sugar, smoothies, or milk—hydration is key for breast milk production.
Have questions about your nutrition while breastfeeding or pumping?
Maven Nutritionists
and
Lactation Consultants
are here to help. Make a free, online appointment now.
Sources
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
La Leche League

title.en-US: What you need to know about diastasis recti during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know:
Diastasis recti happens when the muscles in your abdomen stretch and separate during pregnancy, and don’t come back together completely during the postpartum period.
The majority of pregnant people have some abdominal separation during pregnancy and with postpartum.
Avoid straining your abdominal muscles, wear a belly support band that lifts your belly, and ask your doctor or a
Maven Physical Therapist
about gentle core exercises you can do to reduce the stress your muscles are under during pregnancy. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Having a six pack is probably far from your mind at the moment. But you may still be thinking about your abs during pregnancy if you’ve heard about diastasis recti—when your abdominal muscles separate to make room for baby during pregnancy. Even though diastasis recti is extremely common, there are ways to prevent a major separation and close the separation during the postpartum period.
Here’s everything you need to know about diastasis recti, and ways to lower the stress pregnancy puts on your abdominal muscles, so you can (hopefully) avoid postpartum complications.
What causes diastasis recti?

As your pregnant belly grows, it puts pressure on your abdominal muscles (or “abs”) and the tissues that connect them. Over time, the left and right sides of your abs separate to make more space for your growing baby.

After you’ve given birth, your abdominal muscles and connective tissues start to heal quickly. They’re like a rubber band that snaps back after it’s been stretched. But if these muscles and tissues lose their elasticity from being stretched too much, the space between your abdominal muscles won’t come back together completely. The gap left between the muscles is diastasis recti.
Pregnant people usually develop diastasis recti in the third trimester (after week 28 of pregnancy), when the baby is growing fastest.
How common is diastasis recti?
