Your body will go through a lot of changes during pregnancy—and it’s very likely that abdominal separation will be one of them. Maven Physical Therapist Karen Liberi, says, “More research is needed on diastasis recti during pregnancy, but some studies point to all pregnant people having some degree of it at week 35 of pregnancy.”
Even if the majority of pregnant people have some degree of abdominal separation, most people don’t notice it until they’re in the postpartum period.
Read more about diastasis recti during the postpartum period here
Are there risk factors for diastasis recti?
Even though most people have some abdominal separation during pregnancy, some are more likely to have greater abdominal separation. Some factors that might increase this risk are:
Being 35 years or older
Having multiple pregnancies (especially if they’re very close together)
Being pregnant with multiples (like twins or triplets)
Having a big baby
Having a vaginal delivery (pushing can put a lot of pressure on your abs)
Can I prevent diastasis recti?
Liberi says there’s no way to prevent diastasis recti during pregnancy. “Diastasis recti is a normal response from the pressure put on your tissue as your belly grows,” she explains.

While it’s normal and (expected) for you to have some abdominal separation during pregnancy, Liberi says there are a few things you can do to lower the stress placed on your abdominal muscles. Some steps you can take are:
Gain the recommended amount of weight
during pregnancy by eating a balanced diet and exercising regularly if your pregnancy provider gives the OK. Not sure how much to gain? Ask your provider or a provider on Maven for personal advice.
Avoid exercises that put a lot of pressure on your abs
, like sit-ups, planks, or twisting exercises, after week 12 of pregnancy.
Avoid straining your abs

if you lift your older child, groceries, or other heavy items. When you have to lift something, bend at your knees (not at the waist) and keep your back as straight as you can. Try to tighten your pelvic floor and pull your belly in as you lift for the best support. And be sure to use your leg muscles to stand—not your back or belly muscles.
Roll out of bed
instead of sitting straight up. Roll to one side, then push yourself up with your arms.
Do gentle core activations

if certain movements cause pain or discomfort in your abdomen. Activating your core while you move might offer some relief. Here’s how to do it: exhale and gently pull your core muscles (belly button) inwards towards your spine. Another way to think of this movement is to imagine that you’re “hugging baby with your belly,” says Liberi.
Use kinesio tape or a belly band to lift and support your belly
to give your abdominal muscles and tissues some extra support.
Ask your pregnancy provider or a
Maven Physical Therapist
if there are core exercises you can do to keep your strength while reducing the stress placed on your abdominal muscles.
How do I know if I have diastasis recti?

Most of the signs of diastasis recti are only noticeable during the postpartum period. If you’re pregnant or postpartum and you notice your belly makes a cone or dome shape when you sit up in bed, lean back in a chair, or do ab exercises (like sit-ups or planks), you might have some abdominal separation.

If you notice coning or rounding in your belly, consider talking to a physical therapist or a pelvic floor therapist before you give birth. They can teach you ways to lower the stress on your abdominal muscles, so you can avoid postpartum complications. You can also talk to a
Maven Physical Therapist
online for advice at any time for free.
Should I worry about diastasis recti?
Horror stories about diastasis recti are everywhere on social media. If you’ve come across these stories during your scrolling, and you’re super worried about diastasis recti, Liberi says: don’t be.

“Social media has definitely created a frenzy over this condition and there are many fearful claims out there that are simply unfounded,” she says. “As the body changes during pregnancy and the abdominal muscles lengthen over time, there will likely be separation. These muscles will need rehabilitation to help regain their strength and support, but there are lots of ways to do this and many wonderful resources.”

That being said, diastasis recti can affect your abdominal strength and in severe cases, cause postpartum complications, like discomfort during sex, incontinence, or pain in the pelvis, hips, or back. Even moderate cases of diastasis recti don’t heal on their own, and need attention from a pelvic floor therapist or physical therapist.

The best thing you can do is take steps to ease the stress pregnancy puts on your abdominal muscles, and have a game plan ready in case you have diastasis recti after you give birth. Your pregnancy provider, a pelvic floor therapist, or a
Maven Physical Therapist
can help you develop a rehabilitation plan.
The bottom line

The majority of people have some degree of abdominal separation during pregnancy and might not know they have diastasis recti until after their baby is born. There are steps you can take to reduce the pressure on your abdominal muscles during pregnancy, but there’s no way to totally avoid developing diastasis recti. If you do have diastasis recti, it’s a good idea to talk to a pelvic floor therapist or a
Maven Physical Therapist
to develop a rehabilitation plan you can use during the postpartum period.
Have questions about diastasis recti?
Maven Physical Therapists
are here to help. Make an online appointment today.

title.en-US: Diarrhea during pregnancy: What causes it and when should you see your doctor

content.value: What you need to know:
Having diarrhea (loose, watery stools) is a common side effect of pregnancy.
Diarrhea can be caused by pregnancy-related changes to your body (like your hormones) or certain viruses or bacteria.
Call your pregnancy provider if you have diarrhea for more than 48 hours or have severe abdominal pain. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Bloating, gas, and constipation are well-known side effects of pregnancy, but some people can experience bouts of diarrhea, too. Many times, diarrhea can be chalked up to pregnancy hormones, changes to your diet, or even your body preparing for labor. But some cases of diarrhea need attention from your pregnancy provider or
Family Physician
Here’s what you need to know about diarrhea during pregnancy, when you should call your provider, and pregnancy-safe ways to ease your symptoms.
Causes of diarrhea during pregnancy

There are many things that can cause diarrhea during pregnancy, ranging from your changing body, to a stomach virus or food poisoning. Some causes are generally harmless (but still bothersome), while others will need a call to your pregnancy provider and possibly treatment.
You might experience pregnancy-related diarrhea due to:
Pregnancy hormones:
The same hormones that support a healthy pregnancy can have major effects on your digestive system. Pregnancy hormones slow digestion, making diarrhea, bloating, or
constipation
common throughout all three trimesters.
Your changing body:
As your uterus and baby grow bigger, they put pressure on your digestive tract. This slows down digestion, which can cause diarrhea,
bloating
, or constipation (or all of these!).
Changes to your diet:

Eating a balanced diet and drinking a lot of water are important for a healthy pregnancy, but changes to your diet can cause temporary bouts of diarrhea. For example, it’s recommended that you eat 25 to 35 grams of fiber-rich foods every day during pregnancy, but eating
too much
fiber can cause diarrhea.
Your prenatal vitamins:
Constipation is a well-known side effect of the iron in prenatal vitamins, but some people can experience diarrhea from their prenatal vitamins, too. Ask your pregnancy provider or a
Maven provider
about changing prenatal vitamins if your current one upsets your stomach.
Your body preparing for labor:

Maven OB-GYN Rana Daniel advises, “Diarrhea can sometimes be an early sign of labor.” As your body preps for labor, an increase in hormones called prostaglandins—which help the muscles in your uterus, cervix, and rectum relax—can also make your digestive tract relax, leading to loose stool. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
There are also many causes of diarrhea that aren’t related to pregnancy. Some non-pregnancy causes of diarrhea are:
Stomach bugs or viruses:

Viruses like rotavirus (which is common in babies and young kids) can cause loose, watery bowel movements. If you have young kids, be sure to wash your hands well after diaper changes or helping them in the bathroom.
Food poisoning:
Cases of food poisoning from the
Salmonella
or
E. coli

bacteria (among others) can cause diarrhea, vomiting, and other uncomfortable gastrointestinal symptoms. You can avoid food poisoning by not eating food that has been sitting out for more than 2 hours (buffets included); thoroughly cleaning and cooking food; and washing your hands after handling unwashed or uncooked food. Read more about food poisoning during pregnancy here.
Certain medications, like antibiotics:

Diarrhea is a common side effect of medications like antibiotics. If your pregnancy provider or family physician prescribes antibiotics, you may have diarrhea until you finish treatment. Ask your provider if they recommend taking probiotics during the course of your treatment. Probiotics help the good bacteria in your digestive tract grow, which can sometimes alleviate diarrhea.
Symptoms of diarrhea during pregnancy and when to call your provider
Diarrhea is defined as having loose or watery stools and going to the bathroom more frequently than normal. Some other common signs of diarrhea include:
Stomach cramps or pain
Bloating
Nausea or vomiting
Fever
Needing to use the bathroom urgentlyREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Diarrhea typically goes away on its own within a few days, but if you’ve had symptoms for more than 48 hours, Daniel recommends calling your pregnancy provider. “If your symptoms are associated with bleeding or severe abdominal pain, let your provider know right away,’ she adds.

If you think you might be in early labor, call your pregnancy provider to see if you should head to the hospital or birthing center. Everyone has different signs of early labor, but some common indicators are:
Cramping or mild contractions that last longer and longer and come on more frequently
Pressure in your pelvis
Changes to your vaginal discharge or losing your mucus plug
How to feel better when you have diarrhea

In many cases, you can get relief from diarrhea by making a few changes to your daily diet and drinking lots of fluids. If you have longer-lasting diarrhea, or severe symptoms like bloody stool or abdominal pain, you might need medication to get better. Call your pregnancy provider right away or chat with a Maven provider if you have any of these symptoms.
Some things you can do to ease diarrhea and its symptoms are:
Drink plenty of water.

You can quickly become dehydrated if you have diarrhea—which can be very serious during pregnancy—so be sure to drink a lot of water. You can also ask your pregnancy provider if it’s a good idea to drink beverages with electrolytes, which will replenish lost fluids and minerals, such as potassium and sodium.
Try a plain diet.

“Try to eat foods that may be binding, like banana, bread, or toast,” says Daniel. Eating a bland diet will also give your digestive system a break. Try to avoid spicy, greasy, or fatty foods, or beans and cruciferous veggies (like broccoli, cauliflower, or Brussels sprouts) until you’re feeling better.
Ask your provider about safe medications.
If you need extra relief, ask your pregnancy provider or a
Maven provider
about pregnancy-safe over-the-counter treatments for diarrhea.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you have diarrhea caused by food poisoning or a parasite, your provider may recommend medication, like antibiotics, to treat the underlying infection and alleviate any symptoms it’s causing. Unfortunately, antibiotics won’t help if you have diarrhea caused by a stomach bug or a virus. Some over-the-counter medications may help, but again, always ask your provider or a
Maven provider
if it’s safe before you take any medication or treatment.
The bottom line

Diarrhea can be a common, but uncomfortable side effect of pregnancy. Many cases of diarrhea are caused by changes to your body, diet, or fluid intake, but others can be caused by viruses, bacteria, and other illnesses. If you have diarrhea that lasts longer than 48 hours or have symptoms like bloody stool or severe abdominal pain, call your pregnancy provider right away. Depending on the cause, they might recommend medication or other treatments. Remember: you should never take any medication or treatment without talking to your provider to make sure it’s safe for pregnancy first.
Maven OB-GYNs
and
Family Physicians
are here to help 24/7. Make an online appointment for advice about diarrhea during pregnancy, or any other questions you may have.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic (Period poops)
Cleveland Clinic (Early signs of labor)
Gastroenterology Clinics of North America
Mayo Clinic (Diarrhea)

title.en-US: A vegan's guide to prenatal nutrition

content.value: What you need to know:
You can keep up your vegan diet during pregnancy, it just requires some careful meal planning (and possibly supplements).
In addition to eating a wide variety of nutritious foods, taking a vegan prenatal vitamin every day is essential for your baby’s growth and development, and can help prevent certain birth defects.

Protein, DHA, choline, vitamin D, and preformed vitamin A (among other nutrients) are important during pregnancy, but it may be tough to get enough on a vegan diet. Talk to your pregnancy provider or a
Maven Nutritionist
if you need help finding vegan sources.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Vegan diets have become more and more common, and for good reason: Eating a plant-based diet has been linked to a whole host of health benefits, ranging from better digestion, to lower risk of type 2 diabetes and heart disease.

If you’re vegan, the good news is that it’s totally safe to stay that way during pregnancy—but it does require some careful meal planning to make sure you and your baby get the right amount of nutrients.
Learn more about the nutrients you need and where to get them from a vegan diet, so you can nourish your body and your baby.
Start with a vegan prenatal vitamin

When you’re pregnant, your body needs a lot of extra nutrients to support your changing body and your growing baby. It can be hard to get enough of these important nutrients (like folate, iron, and choline) from food alone, so it’s recommended that all pregnant people take a daily prenatal vitamin, regardless of their diet.

Heads up: many prenatal vitamins contain animal-derived ingredients, like gelatin or fish oil, so be sure to check the ingredients list before you buy. If you’re having a hard time finding a vegan prenatal vitamin, make an appointment with a
Maven Nutritionist
for a vegan-friendly recommendation.
Nutrients you need and where to find them in a vegan diet

“The nutrients needed for a healthy vegan pregnancy are the same as those of any other pregnancy, but often need a bit more intentional inclusion or supplementation,” says Maven Nutritionist Aubrey Phelps. “The nutrients to focus on in a vegan diet are
protein
DHA
choline
vitamin D
preformed vitamin A
vitamin B12
, and
iron
Some other important nutrients during pregnancy include
folate
iodine
, and
vitamin B6
In addition to looking for a prenatal vitamin that contains these nutrients, try to work the foods listed below into your daily rotation:
1. Nutrient: Protein
Why it’s important during pregnancy:
The amino acids that make up protein are vital to many functions in baby’s body, including cell growth and function, hormone production, and muscle development.
Where to find it:
Beans, lentils, quinoa, nuts, seeds, nut butters, soybeans and soy products, tofu, seitan, and tempeh
What to know about protein in a vegan diet:

How much protein you need in your daily diet depends on a few different factors, like your weight, your activity level, how far along you are in your pregnancy, and how many babies you’re carrying. Phelps recommends aiming for 20 to 30 grams of protein per meal and 10 to 15 grams of protein per snack, for a total of 80 to 100 grams per day.
2. Nutrient: DHA (docosahexaenoic acid)
Why it’s important during pregnancy:

DHA is an omega-3 fatty acid that’s vital for the development of baby’s central nervous system (their brain, spinal cord, and nerves), and vision. It’s also good for your brain function and heart health.
Where to find it:
Algae-based DHA supplements, some prenatal vitamins, fortified, plant-based milks, seaweed snacks
What to know about DHA in a vegan diet: “

DHA is found primarily in fish and seafood. The body can convert another omega-3 fatty acid called EPA into DHA, but the conversion is inadequate during pregnancy. I typically suggest an algae-based DHA supplement,” says Phelps. Certain prenatal vitamins also contain algae-based DHA.
If you want to take a DHA supplement, be sure to talk to your pregnancy provider or a
Maven provider
first. Never take any supplement or medication without making sure it’s safe for pregnancy.
3. Nutrient: Choline
Why it’s important during pregnancy:
Choline helps your baby’s brain develop. Some research has also shown that it can reduce the risk of neural tube defects (a birth defect that affects the brain and spinal cord).
Where to find it:
Soy products (like soy milk), tofu, peanuts, peanut butter, and supplements
What to know about choline in a vegan diet:

Your body makes its own choline, but not enough to meet the recommendation of 450 mg per day. It’s important to get enough from your diet. Some prenatal vitamins contain choline, but not all of them, so be sure to read the label closely. You can also ask a
Maven Nutritionist
for a recommendation.
4. Nutrient: Vitamin D
Why it’s important during pregnancy:
Vitamin D plays a major role in the development of your baby’s teeth, bones, eyesight, and skin.
Where to find it:
Fortified plant-based milks, fortified fruit juices, fortified breakfast cereals, mushrooms that are labeled as containing vitamin D, and your prenatal vitamin
What to know about vitamin D in a vegan diet:

According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), many people are low in vitamin D—especially vegans and vegetarians. If your pregnancy provider thinks you might be low in vitamin D, they can order a simple blood test to check your levels, and might recommend a vitamin D supplement.
5. Nutrient: Preformed vitamin A
Why it’s important during pregnancy:

Vitamin A (vitamin A that comes from animal products and fortified foods, and is better absorbed by your body) is needed for the development of your baby’s brain, immune system, and other body systems.
Where to find it:
Fortified milks, fortified cereals and breads, and your prenatal vitamin
What to know about vitamin A in a vegan diet:

Preformed vitamin A typically comes from animal products, like meat, fish, poultry, eggs, and dairy products, so you’ll have to pay close attention to how much you’re getting from plant-based sources and your prenatal vitamin.
6. Nutrient: Folate
Why it’s important during pregnancy:
It’s been proven that folate reduces the risk of neural tube defects. ACOG recommends getting 600 mg of folate per day to lower the risk of these birth defects.
Where to find it:
Dark leafy greens (like spinach, romaine lettuce, Brussels sprouts, and broccoli), beans, peanuts, fortified cereals, your prenatal vitamin (or listed as folic acid) or supplements
What to know about folate in a vegan diet:

It can be tough to get the recommended amount of folate from food alone, so be sure to take a prenatal vitamin with folate or folic acid (the manufactured version of folate) in it every day or a folic acid supplement in addition to your prenatal.
7. Nutrient: Vitamin B12
Why it’s important during pregnancy:
When combined with folate, vitamin B12 is thought to reduce the risk of neural tube defects, like spina bifida. B vitamins also help your placenta develop.
Where to find it:
Fortified cereals, fortified breads, fortified plant-based milks, and your prenatal vitamin
What to know about vitamin B12 in a vegan diet:

Vitamin B12 is also mostly found in animal products. Taking your prenatal vitamin and eating fortified breakfast cereals and fortified plant-based milks may help you reach the daily recommended amount. Talk to your pregnancy provider or a
Maven Nutritionist
if you need help finding additional sources of B12.
8. Nutrient: Iron
Why it’s important during pregnancy:

As the amount of blood in your body increases, you will need more iron to support your baby and deliver oxygen to them. Try to pair iron-rich foods with foods high in vitamin C, like oranges, strawberries, broccoli, or bell peppers. Vitamin C helps your body absorb iron better.
Where to find it:
Lentils, beans, dark leafy greens (like spinach or kale), fortified plant-based milks, fortified cereals, and your prenatal vitamin
What to know about iron in a vegan diet:

“Iron can be found in plants, but is significantly less bioavailable (meaning your body doesn’t absorb it as efficiently), so additional supplementation or careful and consistent meal planning that includes good plant-based sources is essential,” says Phelps.
9. Nutrient: Iodine
Why it’s important during pregnancy:
Iodine is important for the development of baby’s thyroid hormones and their brain.
Where to find it:
Iodized table salt (check the label on your salt) and your prenatal vitamin
What to know about iodine in a vegan diet:
Some prenatal vitamins contain the recommended amount of iodine, but some don’t. Check your vitamin’s label and talk to your pregnancy provider if your prenatal contains less than 220 mg of iodine.
10. Nutrient: Vitamin B6
Why it’s important during pregnancy:

In addition to boosting your baby’s growth and development, vitamin B6 supplements can help ease nausea from morning sickness. Just remember to talk to your pregnancy provider before taking any supplements.
Where to find it:
Chickpeas, fortified cereals and breads, bananas, sweet potatoes, and your prenatal vitamin
What to know about vitamin B6 in a vegan diet:

It’s sometimes thought that your body doesn’t absorb vitamin B6 as well if it’s from plant-based sources. But some research has shown that vegans and vegetarians aren’t at a higher risk of B6 deficiency (not having enough) than meat eaters. So the verdict is still out.

In general, Phelps says, “Focus on whole, real foods over processed foods as much as possible, with an emphasis on protein sources.” Certain vegan foods, like vegan cheeses, baked goods, or pre-made meals can be highly processed and contain a lot of fat and sodium—so try not to overdo it. If you’re craving a vegan grilled cheese, go for it! Just try to balance it out with a healthier, whole food during your next snack or mealtime.
The bottom line

It is possible to have a healthy pregnancy on a vegan diet—you just have to plan out your meals and supplement carefully. Start by taking a vegan prenatal vitamin every day, and try to incorporate foods that are high in protein, iron, vitamin D, and other important nutrients into your daily menu.
Looking for vegan-friendly meals that are high in these nutrients? Have questions about a vegan diet during pregnancy?
Maven Nutritionists
are here to help. Schedule a free online appointment now.
Sources
ACOG (Nutrition FAQs)
ACOG (Vitamin D)
Mount Sinai (DHA)
Nutrients

title.en-US: Baby movement in the womb: What's normal and what isn't

content.value: What you need to know:
Many people start to feel their baby move between 18 and 25 weeks of pregnancy.
Baby movement feels different for everyone. You may feel bubbles, taps, or flutters first, then rolls, somersaults, and kicks come later in pregnancy.
Being aware of your baby’s movement patterns will help you notice if there’s a big change in their movement, such as not moving as much. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

When you’re pregnant, feeling your baby move for the first time is so exciting! As they grow bigger, you’ll feel them move more and more, and you’ll probably even get to know their daily routine based on their movement (is that a future Olympian in there?).

But sometimes, it can be hard to tell what’s normal movement in the womb, and what isn’t. Read on to learn when it’s a good idea to call your pregnancy provider. (Spoiler: If you’re ever feeling concerned, call your provider or book a quick online chat with a
Maven provider
for free. It never hurts to be sure.)
All babies are different—and so are their patterns of movement

Every pregnancy and every baby are different, so movement will feel different for everyone—and it may even change day-to-day. But most people should start to feel some movement between 18 and 25 weeks of pregnancy. “Once you start feeling baby move regularly, you should feel them every day. It may be different each day, but after 28 weeks you should feel regular movement,” says Maven OB-GYN Kathleen Green.

Early on, you might not even realize you’re feeling your baby’s movements—they’re often confused with gas or indigestion. But as baby gets bigger, their movements will become much more noticeable, and you’ll become more familiar with their movement patterns throughout the day.
Baby’s first movements are often described as feeling like:
Bubbles or popcorn popping
Tapping or pulsing
Fluttering like a butterfly
Small rolls
Muscle spasmsREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
As your baby gets bigger, their movements will become stronger and more noticeable. Later in pregnancy it’s normal to feel:
Kicks
Jabs and punches
Rolls, swishes, and somersaults
Elbows, knees, and feet poking your belly
Babies switch between active and rest times

Once you get to know your baby’s movements, you’ll notice they’re usually active or inactive during different parts of the day. Although it’s believed that babies spend 90% to 95% of their time in the womb sleeping, being active—and getting those stretches, jabs, and rolls in—is important for the development of their muscles, joints, and bones.

There isn’t an exact time of day you can expect to feel your baby moving, but you may start to notice patterns after a few weeks. Many babies are very active after you’ve had a big meal or drink something cold or sweet (like ice water or orange juice). They also tend to be more active when you’re settling in for bed. On the other hand, you might find your baby is less active when you’re up and moving around during the day because the movement of your body rocks them to sleep.
When to start tracking baby’s movements

Many pregnancy providers recommend paying closer attention to your baby’s active and inactive times starting around the third trimester. It’s a good idea to be generally aware of baby’s habits in case there’s a major change in their movement, or they stop moving at all—both which can signal a problem.

If you notice a big change in your baby’s movement patterns or don’t feel them moving throughout the day, tell your pregnancy provider right away. They may ask you to come in for a check-up or recommend that you start to do daily
kick counts
. If you can’t get in touch with your doctor, remember you can talk to a
provider online on Maven
anytime.
Factors that can make it hard to feel your baby move
Some things that can affect when or how you feel your baby’s movements in the womb are:
This is your first pregnancy.

It can take a little bit longer for first-time parents to feel their baby moving in the womb—and realize it’s their baby moving, and not gas. “Most first-time parents start to feel baby move for the first time around 20 weeks,” says Green.
You have an anterior placenta.

Having an anterior placenta (a placenta that attaches to the front wall of the uterus, rather than the back wall) can sometimes make it difficult to feel your baby moving. It acts as a barrier between your baby and your belly, and absorbs the impact from baby’s movement so you may feel them less.
Your baby isn’t very active.

Some babies are simply less active than other babies. Plus, babies spend most of their time in the womb snoozing, so it can sometimes be tough to catch your little one during their wake time. If your baby was once very active and has slowed down a lot, tell your pregnancy provider right away. They’ll want to make sure you and your baby are OK. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you’re worried or have questions about your baby’s movement patterns, talk to your pregnancy provider or a
Maven provider

. Every pregnancy is different, but it’s always better to be safe and ask. “I always tell my patients, I would much rather you call me or come in than sit at home and worry. If you’re worried, I'm worried,” Green adds.
When to call your pregnancy provider about your baby’s movement
Call your pregnancy provider right away if:
You notice a big change
in your baby’s movement over a few days, like weaker movements or not moving as much
You don’t feel 10 movements in 2 hours
while you’re doing a
kick count
(if your pregnancy provider asks you to do kick counts)
You don’t feel your baby moving
at allREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
There’s a myth that babies stop moving just before and during labor. This is
not
true. You should still feel your baby’s movement before and during labor.
The bottom line

Over the course of your pregnancy, you’ll get to know your baby’s movement patterns throughout the day. There’s a wide range of what’s considered “normal” baby movement, but if you notice a big change in your baby’s movement or they stop moving at all, call your pregnancy provider immediately. They may ask you to come in for a check-up.
And remember,
Maven providers
are here to help 24/7 if you ever have any questions or concerns about your baby.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
Stanford Children’s Health

title.en-US: How to prepare for a VBAC

content.value: What you need to know:
Some people who have had a previous cesarean (C-section) delivery are good candidates for VBAC (vaginal birth after cesarean delivery).
About 70% of people who try for a VBAC are successful, but certain factors, like your health or birth history, can make VBAC unsafe.
You’ll work with your pregnancy provider to create the safest birth plan for you and your baby, but it’s a good idea to stay flexible in case your VBAC doesn’t go as planned.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you had a C-section delivery during a previous birth and you’re hoping for a
VBAC

this time around, some planning and preparation can help you have a positive experience—even if your labor and delivery don’t go exactly as planned. Here’s how to prep and up your chances of a successful VBAC.
1. Understand VBAC vocabulary
First, it’s important to understand the terminology pregnancy providers use to talk about VBACs. Here are the key terms you’ll need to know:
Cesarean (C-section) delivery:
a surgical cut (incision) made in your abdomen and uterus to deliver your baby.
TOLAC:
“trial of labor after cesarean delivery” or TOLAC is the
attempt
to have a VBAC. In order to have a successful VBAC, you have to have a successful TOLAC first.
VBAC:
“vaginal birth after cesarean delivery” or VBAC is when you’re able to give birth vaginally after having had a prior C-section.
2. Find out if you’re a good candidate for VBAC
Before you set your heart on a VBAC, it’s important to learn whether or not you’re a good candidate for a vaginal delivery.
You might be a good candidate for VBAC if:

You’re pregnant with one baby and have had one or two prior low transverse C-sections. That means your incision is horizontal (side-to-side) across the lower part of your uterus. This type of incision has the lowest risk for complications during a VBAC. Know that the incision on your abdomen doesn’t always look the same as the incision on your uterus, so your pregnancy provider will use your medical records to confirm which type you had.
You don’t have any conditions or complications that prevent vaginal delivery (like placenta previa) or make it dangerous (like having a very large baby)
You’ve had a vaginal delivery at least once before.
The reason you needed a C-section isn’t likely to happen again, such as fetal distress or baby being breechREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
You might NOT be a good candidate for VBAC if:

You had a prior “classical” vertical C-section (meaning your incision is up and down on the uterus). These incisions have a higher risk of uterine rupture, which happens when the uterus tears during labor. Uterine rupture is rare, but can be very dangerous for both you and baby.
You have a history of uterine surgery
You’ve had a uterine rupture during a previous birth
You’ve had three or more C-section deliveries before
You’ve had a labor that didn’t progress because you weren’t dilating or your baby didn’t drop into the birth canal (called arrest of descent)
You’ve had a baby (by vaginal or C-section delivery) in the last 18 months
You’re pregnant with multiples higher than twins (like triplets or quadruplets)
Your pregnancy lasts longer than 40 weeks
Your BMI (body mass index) is higher than 40
Your baby is measuring very large before birthREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
It’s true that VBACs have a fairly high success rate—around 70%, according to Mayo Clinic—but they may not be safe for everyone. Talk to your pregnancy provider or a
Maven OB-GYN
about whether or not a VBAC is right for you, and what your safest delivery method would be.
You can learn more about VBACs in Maven’s on-demand VBAC class. Watch it at any time (for free!) here.
3. Find a provider who is supportive of VBACs

Even though the American College of Gynecologists and Obstetricians (ACOG) encourages VBACs for people who are good candidates, not all pregnancy providers support them. This is often due to the risks linked to VBACs, like uterine rupture, or because their birthing facility isn’t equipped to handle VBACs or potential complications, says Maven OB-GYN Rana Daniel.

Choosing a VBAC-friendly pregnancy provider increases your chance of a successful VBAC, so it’s a good idea to find a provider who’s on the same page earlier in your pregnancy. That way, you have plenty of time to discuss the benefits, risks, and alternate delivery options, or find a new pregnancy provider if your current provider doesn’t do VBACs.
Having a tough time finding a pro-VBAC provider in your area? Message your Maven Care Advocate for help.
4. Don’t be afraid to ask your provider lots of questions

If your regular provider supports VBACs—or you’re interviewing new providers—it’s important to ask a lot of questions, says Daniel. You deserve to feel informed and confident in the decisions you make about your care.
Some questions Daniel recommends asking about VBACs are:
What are my chances of having a successful VBAC?

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYour pregnancy provider should be able to figure out your chances of a successful VBAC based on your health history, birth history, incision type from a prior C-section, and other factors.
What are the benefits of a VBAC? What are the risks? What are my alternate delivery options?

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKYour pregnancy provider should cover the benefits of VBACs (like shorter recovery time and less blood loss), as well as the risks (like uterine rupture or the need for an emergency C-section). They should also tell you if you have alternate delivery options, like a planned C-section.
Is your hospital equipped for TOLACs and VBACs?
REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKNot all birthing facilities can handle TOLACs and VBACs, or complications that can happen (like needing an emergency C-section). ACOG says that VBACs should
only
happen in facilities that have the equipment and the staff to handle emergency situations.
How many TOLACs have you attended in the last year? How many ended in a successful VBAC?

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf your provider supports VBACs, they should be able to tell you their rate of success. Be sure to ask them how many TOLACs they have overseen in the last year, and how many of them resulted in a successful VBAC.
If I have to be induced, will you be supportive of a TOLAC?

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKIf labor doesn’t start on its own, your pregnancy provider may need to use medication to induce you. Being induced raises the risk of uterine rupture during a TOLAC, so it’s important to find out where your provider stands on induction. Some providers will be supportive of a TOLAC after induction, but some will not.
If my pregnancy goes beyond 40 weeks, will you be supportive of a TOLAC?

REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKAccording to the ACOG, a pregnancy that lasts 40 weeks or longer doesn’t automatically mean you need another C-section. But many providers won’t support a TOLAC after 40 weeks because some research has shown it increases the risk of a failed VBAC.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have more questions about TOLAC or VBAC between appointments, you can chat with a
Maven OB-GYN
at any time for free.
5. Choose a birthing facility that’s prepared for TOLACs, VBACs, and emergency complications

Not all birthing facilities have the equipment or staff to support TOLACs or VBACs, or the complications that can happen. “A VBAC is a high-risk procedure,” says Daniel. “You should be in a hospital that’s comfortable doing them. If your hospital isn’t comfortable with VBACs, call around to find one that is.”

According to the ACOG, VBACs should only happen in hospitals that can manage life-threatening situations—which takes certain birthing centers and home births completely off the table. Since some people who go for a VBAC end up needing an emergency C-section, it’s vital that your hospital can support emergency C-sections, too. Home births are never recommended if attempting a VBAC.
You can get this information by asking your pregnancy provider about their preferred birthing facilities and what they’re equipped for, or by calling the facility directly.
6. Know that you’ll be considered a high-risk patient

“It’s important to mentally prepare yourself that you'll be considered high-risk, so you’ll be monitored closely and frequently,” says Daniel. Since TOLACs and VBACs can have some serious risks, your pregnancy provider will most likely recommend continuous monitoring of your baby’s heartbeat while you’re in labor.

Being continuously monitored can feel scary, especially if you’ve had a traumatic birth experience in the past. Daniel recommends being open and communicating with your provider if you’ve had a traumatic experience, so they can try to meet your needs. For example, continuous monitoring of your baby might be required, but they may be able to do fewer cervical checks while you labor.
Some other things that may help you mentally prepare for labor and delivery are:
Talk to a
Maven Mental Health Provider
about coping techniques you can use when you’re feeling scared, anxious, or stressed about labor.
Ask your pregnancy provider lots of questions about TOLACs and VBACs, so you can make an informed decision about your care.
Share your birth plan with your support person, so they know your wishes and can advocate for you if needed.
7. Try to be flexible with your birth plan—and don’t be hard on yourself if it doesn’t go as planned

Sometimes childbirth doesn’t go the exact way we want, and you may end up needing a repeat C-section to keep yourself and your baby safe. It may be disappointing—and you might even experience some feelings of guilt (parental guilt is
real
)—but the most important thing is that you and your baby are safe and healthy.
Daniel adds, “A C-section is not a failure of delivery. Although it may not be the plan, it’s never a reason to feel guilty.”
The bottom line

There are steps you can take to increase your chances of a successful VBAC. Finding out if you’re a good candidate, working with a pregnancy provider who supports VBACs, and choosing a birthing facility that’s equipped to handle VBACs are good places to start.
Choosing to attempt a VBAC is a big decision, but
Maven OB-GYNs
are here to answer your questions and concerns at any time. Make a free online appointment now.
Sources
American College of Gynecologists and Obstetricians
Kaiser Permanente
Maven Clinic
Mayo Clinic

title.en-US: How to handle heartburn and acid reflux during pregnancy

content.value: If you’re dealing with some of the not-so-fun symptoms of pregnancy, like heartburn and acid reflux, you’re definitely not alone—about 20% to a whopping 70% of pregnant women report heartburn at some point during their pregnancy. The good news is that heartburn is usually harmless, but can get pretty uncomfortable after three trimesters (plus, you know, the poor sleep, swollen feet, and gas).
Here’s why heartburn and reflux are so common during pregnancy, and what you can do to ease the burn.
What is heartburn?

Despite its name, heartburn doesn’t have anything to do with your heart. Heartburn happens when your stomach acids (which normally break down the food in your stomach) move into your esophagus and cause a burning feeling in your chest. You might also feel burning or a sour taste in your throat.
What is acid reflux?

Here’s a quick anatomy lesson: There’s a muscle between your esophagus and stomach called the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). The LES opens to allow food to enter your stomach and closes so stomach acid can’t enter the esophagus.
When the LES doesn’t close properly or completely, stomach acid can enter your esophagus and cause the burning sensation known as heartburn.
Are heartburn and acid reflux the same thing?

Nope! Lots of people use the terms “heartburn” and “acid reflux” to talk about the same thing, but heartburn is actually a symptom of acid reflux. Meaning, acid reflux is the main issue and causes the feeling of heartburn.
So, why are heartburn and acid reflux common during pregnancy?
Like most side effects of pregnancy, heartburn and acid reflux can usually be chalked up to pregnancy hormones and your changing body. Maven OB-GYN Felicia Wagman explains why:
Hormone changes during pregnancy affect the way your body digests food
. Specifically, they slow down your digestive system, which can lead to heartburn and other glamorous side effects, like
constipation
or
bloating and gas
Your body ups its levels of the hormones progesterone and relaxin, which cause your muscles to relax.
This helps your body prep for labor and delivery, but your LES also becomes relaxed and may not close completely, allowing stomach acid to enter the esophagus.
As your pregnancy progresses, your stomach gets squished.

As your growing baby and growing uterus start to squish your stomach, stomach acids get pushed into your esophagus**.** Heartburn tends to be the most common during the third trimester when your baby and uterus are biggest.
What are the symptoms of heartburn during pregnancy?
A burning, sour sensation in your chest and throat are the hallmark symptoms of heartburn, but some other common signs are:
Feeling very full or bloated
Burping a lot
Feeling nauseated or like you’re going to throw up
Tasting stomach acid in your throat or mouth
Throwing upREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Heartburn gets worse during the third trimester for many pregnant people. In fact, Cleveland Clinic says over half of pregnant women experience severe heartburn, especially later in pregnancy.
If you’re ever worried about heartburn during pregnancy, it’s always better to ask your provider.
Maven providers
are also here 24/7 to answer your questions.
Is heartburn ever a sign of something serious during pregnancy?
In most cases, heartburn and acid reflux are just unpleasant side effects of pregnancy. But if you have any of these symptoms, Wagman recommends calling your pregnancy provider right away:
Severe heartburn that makes it hard to sleep
Trouble swallowing
Bringing up or throwing up blood
Black or tar-like poop
Weight loss
CoughingREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
“If symptoms are severe or you develop chest pain, you should go to the emergency department right away,” Wagman says.

If you have these symptoms, your pregnancy provider may want to do some tests to make sure your heartburn isn’t a sign of a more serious health condition. Remember: heartburn is usually harmless, but it’s always better to be safe and get checked out.
How can I get relief from heartburn?
Preventing heartburn is a good first step when you’re pregnant. Some things you can do to avoid it are:
Skip or limit foods that trigger heartburn,
especially foods that are spicy, fatty, citrusy, or highly processed. Caffeine, carbonated drinks, and chocolate can cause heartburn in some people, too.
Eat smaller meals throughout the day
so your digestive system doesn’t have to work so hard digesting big meals.
Eat or drink slowly
to avoid swallowing a lot of air, which can worsen indigestion. Chewing your food completely also makes it easier for your digestive system to break it down.
Try to eat your last meal a few hours before bedtime,
so your body has time to digest before you lie down. Lying down with a full stomach makes it easier for stomach acids to come up. The same goes for meals and snacks before naps during the day.
Don’t smoke.
Smoking is dangerous for your baby and is a known cause of heartburn. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you’re already feeling the burn, there are some pregnancy-safe remedies that can give you relief. Drinking milk or eating yogurt can soothe the burning sensation heartburn causes (and give you an extra dose of calcium). If you’re
vegan
or lactose intolerant, non-dairy milk and yogurt can have the same effect.
Is it safe to take heartburn medication?

If you need relief right away, Wagman says you can also ask your pregnancy provider about pregnancy-friendly over-the-counter treatments. “A first-line, over-the-counter antacid that’s safe in pregnancy is TUMS. There are other antacids, such as Rolaids, Mylanta, and Maalox that can be used occasionally, but
always
check with your provider before you take them.” If over-the-counter treatments don’t work, Wagman says to ask your provider about pregnancy-safe prescription treatment options.
Remember to always ask your pregnancy provider or a
Maven provider
if it’s safe before you take any medication or supplement during pregnancy.
The bottom line

Heartburn and acid reflux are usually harmless and very common during pregnancy, but can become very uncomfortable over time. Drinking milk or eating yogurt are simple ways to get some relief at home, and you can ask your pregnancy provider or a
Maven provider

about pregnancy-safe antacids. But if you have severe heartburn that keeps you up at night, blood in your vomit, or black stool, call your pregnancy provider right away. They’ll want to rule out more serious health conditions that have severe heartburn as a symptom.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
Clinical Evidence

title.en-US: 5 ways your partner can help you prepare for labor

content.value: What you need to know:
Your partner can support you mentally, emotionally, and physically during labor and delivery. Try to be open and honest about the kind of support you think you’ll need.
Making a birth plan and telling your partner your wishes for labor and delivery will keep them informed, and prepared to be your advocate. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you’re getting close to your due date, you might be asking yourself a lot of questions, like:
Did I choose the right car seat? Where will I be when my water breaks?
And,
How the heck can my partner be involved in my labor?

It’s true that you’re the star of labor and delivery, but your partner has an important role to play, too: providing the support you need to have a positive birth experience. Here are five things your partner can do to help prepare for labor.
1. Attend a childbirth class

What happens during labor and delivery may seem a little obvious—um, you go into labor and then you deliver a baby? But there’s actually a lot more to it. Taking a birth class is a great way for your partner (and you!) to understand every single step of the birthing process, so you’ll both feel more informed and prepared when the big day arrives.

Your partner can also learn things they may not have known about otherwise, like physical and non-physical comforting techniques, positions they can help you labor in, and how they can best advocate for you during labor.

It’s usually recommended that you take a birthing class in the third trimester—so the information is fresh in your minds when you go into labor—but taking earlier classes isn’t a bad idea either. You can always take a refresher course closer to your due date, or watch
Maven’s free, on-demand childbirth class
at any time.
2. Understand the type of support you need

We all react to stress, pain, and exhaustion differently, and there’s no right or wrong way to act while you’re in labor. But if you have an idea of how you might react to these emotions—and the kind of support you’ll want when you’re feeling them—it’s a good idea to share that with your partner.

If you’re the type who likes physical comfort, your partner can hold you, rub your lower back, or squeeze your hips to help you through contractions. Don’t want to be touched? Your partner can keep track of your contractions, make sure you always have ice chips to chew or a cold cloth for your forehead, send updates to your loved ones, or take pictures (with your permission, of course!).
It’s hard to predict what will happen during labor and how you’ll react to it, but having a general idea of what brings you comfort can help your partner figure out how to best support you.
3. Know your birth plan and preferences
Everyone has different wishes about the way their birth experience will go. Writing a
birth plan
(a list of your wants and needs during and after labor and delivery) is a great way to keep your partner, your pregnancy provider, and your birthing staff informed of your wishes.
Some things you might want to include are:
Who you want in the room during labor and delivery
How you want to labor: Do you want to change positions often? Use a birthing ball? Walk around the room?
Whether or not you want to use
pain management medications
, like an epidural
How you feel about interventions, such as being induced, frequent cervical checks, assisted labor (when your provider uses forceps or a vacuum to help baby out), or Cesarean (C-section) delivery
Whether or not you want to breastfeed your babyREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you’re open to your partner’s input, you might want to consider writing your birth plan together. That way, they’ll be fully informed from the get-go and will have the opportunity to ask you any questions about your wants, or voice any potential concerns.

Whether or not they’re involved in writing the birth plan, your partner should know what your preferences are, so they can voice your needs if you’re too tired or in too much pain to communicate them.

You should also ask your partner to keep a copy of your birth plan on their phone, so it’s easy to find once you’re in labor. Keeping a digital copy means they’ll have one less thing to pack for the hospital, too. They can also print out your birth plan and keep it in their wallet if they want a physical copy.
Need help creating a birth plan? Message your Maven Care Advocate to book your free birth planning appointment today.
4. Take the lead on a few pre-labor tasks

As your due date approaches, there’s a good chance your mind will be occupied with all things new baby. One way to get some more mental space—and cross a few items off the neverending pre-baby to-do list—is to delegate some tasks to your partner. You might consider asking them to:
Pack snacks for the hospital.
Labor can take a long time, so having snacks on-hand is a good way to keep your energy levels up and avoid getting hangry.
Set up childcare for older kids
or petcare
while you’re going to be in the hospital.
Make sure the fridge is stocked with some basics
. That way, you don’t have to worry about groceries when you get home. Bonus points if they can prep a few easy, make-ahead meals, too.
Do a load of baby’s laundry,
so you have plenty of clean onesies and pajamas to pull from when the inevitable spit-up or poop happens. Having some fresh towels ready won’t hurt, either.
Arrange your first post-delivery meal.

This is very important! Labor and delivery might leave you feeling ravenous, especially if you opt for an epidural and can’t eat after it has been placed. So, if you’re craving sushi, a giant burrito, or a burger from your favorite fast food restaurant, let your partner deal with the logistics of getting it into the hospital and into your mouth ASAP.
5. Work on a caretaking plan before baby is born

Taking care of a newborn, yourself, and your home after going through labor and delivery is so much work—not to mention, absolutely exhausting. In order to get some recovery time (and try to avoid conflict that comes with being totally sleep-deprived!) Maven Mental Health Provider Heather Tahler advises making a caretaking plan before your baby is born.
She recommends addressing questions like:
How will we manage nights, so we can get some rest?
Who is our family's support system we can call when we need help?
If one partner is breastfeeding, how can the other pick up chores and tasks around the house?
How can we divide responsibilities? REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
“Obviously this plan may have to bend and shift, but it's very helpful to start thinking about these things ahead of time,” she says.
The bottom line

There are many ways your partner can help you prepare for labor mentally, emotionally, and physically. Being open and communicating your wants and needs is a great first step in having the birth experience you want, and ensuring that your partner is involved in it.

title.en-US: Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), explained

content.value: What you need to know:
Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), also known as fetal growth restriction (FGR), affects about 10% of pregnancies.
Your baby can measure smaller than average and
not
have IUGR.
IUGR can have many causes, from chronic conditions, to infections, placenta issues, or tobacco use during pregnancy.
There’s no cure for IUGR, but many babies born with IUGR are born healthy. Your provider will keep a close eye and might recommend early delivery (before week 37 of pregnancy). REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Being diagnosed with intrauterine uterine growth restriction (IUGR), when baby isn’t growing as expected, can feel scary. But the good news is that many babies with IUGR are born healthy and don’t have long-term health issues.
Here’s what you need to know about IUGR, and what to do if you’re at an increased risk of developing it.
What is intrauterine growth (IUGR) restriction?

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), also known as fetal growth restriction (FGR), is when a baby is not growing as expected during pregnancy, and is considered small for their gestational age (the number of weeks of pregnancy). Babies with IUGR are usually described as weighing under the 10th percentile. This means that they weigh less than 9 out of 10 babies who are the same age.
There are two types of IUGR:
Symmetric (or primary):
all of the baby’s body parts measure small in size. According to Cleveland Clinic, up to 30% of all IUGR cases are symmetric.
Asymmetric (or secondary):
only the baby’s abdomen is measuring small. Their brain and head measurements are normal. Up 70% to 80% of all IUGR cases are asymmetric. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Know that measuring small doesn’t necessarily mean your baby has IUGR. Some babies are just “constitutionally small” (meaning petite), but still healthy and do not have IUGR. This is especially true if the parents are smaller in stature. If your baby is measuring smaller than average, your pregnancy provider will order more tests to check for IUGR.
When can IUGR develop during pregnancy?
IUGR can happen at any point during pregnancy, but many cases are discovered around 20 weeks of pregnancy, when most providers perform these routine tests:
Your anatomy scan:

This is an ultrasound that most providers do between 18 and 22 weeks of pregnancy. During an anatomy scan, your ultrasound technician and pregnancy provider will look closely at how your baby is growing and developing, including baby’s size.
Your fundal height:

Beginning around 20 weeks of pregnancy, your provider will start measuring your fundal height (the distance between your pubic bone and the top of your uterus) at every prenatal appointment. If baby is growing as expected, your fundal height will usually match the number of weeks pregnant (give or take 1-2 centimeters). For example, if you’re 22 weeks pregnant, you can expect your fundal height to be about 22 centimeters. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have a shorter fundal height, your pregnancy provider will likely do more tests to check for IUGR.
What causes IUGR?

There are many possible causes of IUGR, but sometimes pregnancy providers can’t identify a single cause. If your pregnancy provider diagnoses you and baby with IUGR, they’ll work with you to try to discover the underlying cause, so it can be treated.
Some factors in the birthing parent that can cause IUGR are:
Problems with the placenta or umbilical cord that prevent baby from getting the right levels of nutrients, oxygen, or blood
High blood pressure or heart disease
Using tobacco, alcohol, or drugs
during pregnancy
Diabetes, kidney disease, or autoimmune conditions (like lupus)
Infections, like
cytomegalovirus (CMV)
, toxoplasmosis, or syphilis
Being pregnant with multiples (like twins or triplets)
Gaining significantly too much or too little weight during pregnancy REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
You may have heard that being smaller in stature puts your baby at risk of having IUGR. This is not a proven cause of IUGR.

Maven OB-GYN Rana Daniel adds, “Sometimes, IUGR has nothing to do with what the parent does, but there are certain things that can help decrease your risk, like not smoking, drinking, or doing recreational drugs. Things you can’t control include issues with the placenta, high blood pressure, or diabetes, but making sure your blood pressure and blood sugars are in the normal range will help.”
Some factors in baby that can cause IUGR are:
Genetic conditions, like Down syndrome
Certain birth defects
Infections REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have risk factors for IUGR, be sure to talk to your pregnancy provider if there are ways to lower your risk. You can also chat with a
Maven OB-GYN
for free advice at any time.
What are the signs and symptoms of IUGR?
Aside from a shorter fundal height, most pregnant people don’t have symptoms of IUGR.
In babies, the hallmark sign of IUGR is measuring smaller than the 10th percentile for their gestational age. When a baby with IUGR is born, they might have:
Low birth weight
Low temperature
Low blood sugar levels
Difficulty getting over infections
How is IUGR diagnosed?

First, your pregnancy provider will figure out your baby’s gestational age based on the first day of your last period and, in some cases, an ultrasound. Once they know this, they’ll use the methods below to see if baby is growing as expected for their gestational age and additional tests if they suspect IUGR.
Fundal height measurements:
Having a fundal height (the distance from your pubic bone to top of uterus) that’s 4 centimeters shorter than your expected fundal height could be a sign of IUGR.
Weight measurements:
Your pregnancy provider will check your weight at each prenatal appointment. Not gaining enough weight might suggest baby isn’t gaining as expected, either.
Ultrasounds:

Your pregnancy provider can use an ultrasound to check baby’s growth and measurements. They can also use an ultrasound to check your levels of amniotic fluid—having too little fluid can cause IUGR. If they suspect an issue with your umbilical cord, they’ll use a Doppler ultrasound to look at the blood flow through the placenta and umbilical cord. Poor blood flow can contribute to IUGR.
Fetal monitoring:
Your provider will strap a device to your belly that measures baby’s heartbeat and movements. Irregular heartbeat or movement may suggest IUGR.
Amniocentesis:

If your provider thinks your case of IUGR is caused by a genetic component, they might suggest an amniocentesis. During this procedure, your provider will insert a long, thin needle into your belly to collect amniotic fluid for testing. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

It’s tough to measure a baby while they’re still in the womb, so sometimes babies are born bigger or smaller than providers expect. Even so, since providers typically do several tests and measurements to see if a baby has IUGR, it’s not often misdiagnosed. Plus, if your provider suspects IUGR, they’ll want to err on the side of caution and make sure you and baby get the right care.

It’s important to keep in mind that many babies measure small during pregnancy and are born perfectly healthy. Plus, many babies who are diagnosed with IUGR are born without any long-term health issues. It’s always better to be safe and check, so try not to stress too much if your pregnancy provider recommends these or other tests.
Have questions about IUGR testing? Make a free online appointment with a
Maven OB-GYN
for advice.
Is IUGR dangerous for my baby or me?
Although most babies with IUGR are the same size of their peers by age 3, having IUGR does increase the risk of certain health problems at the time of birth, including:
Higher chance of needing a
Cesarean delivery (C-section)
because vaginal delivery can sometimes put too much stress on babies with IUGR
Higher chance of needing an early delivery (before 37 weeks of pregnancy)
Low oxygen levels and difficulty breathing at birth
Low blood sugar and difficulty eating
Difficulty regulating their body temperature
Difficulty fighting off infections
Higher risk of breathing in meconium (baby’s first poop)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Sadly, severe cases of IUGR have also been linked to stillbirth (when a pregnancy ends after week 20). This is often linked to problems with the placenta or umbilical cord. Your provider will talk to you about these risks and how you can work together to lower them, such as regularly checking the blood flow in your umbilical cord or planning to deliver baby early.
Some long-term health conditions like developmental and cognitive disabilities or heart problems can happen, too. These usually depend on what caused baby’s IUGR and how early they were born.
Are there ways to prevent IUGR?

Since IUGR can affect any pregnancy and sometimes has nothing to do with your own health, there isn’t a way to 100% guarantee you won’t develop it. However, certain lifestyle choices do up your risk. You can take these steps to potentially lower your odds:
Avoid alcohol, tobacco, or drug use during pregnancy
Eat regularly to try to gain the amount of pregnancy weight recommended by your provider
Eat a diet that’s high in important nutrients (
find tips here
!)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Certain health conditions in the pregnant parent can also increase the risk of IUGR. Be sure to talk to your pregnancy provider about steps you can take to lower your risk if you have:
Diabetes
Heart disease, including high blood pressure
Autoimmune conditions, like Lupus
Low red blood cell count (anemia) or sickle cell anemiaREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Know that having any of these chronic conditions doesn’t mean your baby will definitely have IUGR—there’s just an increased risk.
How is IUGR treated?

There isn’t a cure for IUGR, but your pregnancy providers will monitor your baby very closely for your entire pregnancy with ultrasounds, nonstress tests (monitoring baby’s heart rate and movements), and potentially other tests. Your regular provider might recommend seeing a provider who specializes in high-risk pregnancies, too.
Your pregnancy provider might recommend delivering baby early (before 37 weeks) if:
They believe baby is at-risk for certain health problems
There are problems with the placenta or umbilical cord
Baby has stopped growingREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

It may be confusing that babies with IUGR are sometimes delivered early (don’t they need more time in the uterus to grow?), but early delivery can actually help keep baby safe if there are issues with your placenta or umbilical cord. It can be dangerous for your baby if the placenta or umbilical cord stop working correctly before they’re born.

Remember: babies grow at different rates, so measuring small doesn’t always mean your baby has IUGR. And even if you are diagnosed, most babies born with IUGR are healthy and don’t have long-lasting health problems.
If you have questions about IUGR—or have been diagnosed with IUGR and want advice between your regular provider appointments—make a free online appointment with a
Maven provider specializing in maternal fetal medicine
. We’re here to help 24/7.
The bottom line

IUGR (also known as FGR) affects a baby’s growth and development in about 10% of pregnancies. Being diagnosed with IUGR can feel scary, but know that most babies with IUGR “catch up” with their peers by age 3.

If you have risk factors for IUGR, including certain chronic health conditions (like diabetes, heart disease, or anemia) or alcohol, tobacco, or drug use during pregnancy, talk to your pregnancy provider about steps you can take to reduce your risk.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
Mayo Clinic
Stanford Medicine
The World Health Organization

title.en-US: Vegetarian’s guide to prenatal nutrition

content.value: What you need to know:
If you’re a vegetarian, you should work closely with your care team during your pregnancy to make sure you’re getting all the important nutrients that you and baby need.
Pregnant people need around 60 to 100 grams of protein per day. (One egg contains around 6 grams.)
Eat lots of foods like lentils, tofu, whole grains, eggs, and dairy (if you eat these) to keep you and baby healthy and strong. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

As a vegetarian, tofu, broccoli, cauliflower wings, and veggie bacon are your jam. You’ve never considered it a big deal that meat wasn’t on the menu. But now that you’re pregnant, you might be questioning if it’s safe to continue with your plant-based diet. You, of course, want to make sure you’re getting all of the important nutrients you and your baby need.

Thankfully with a bit of prep, rest assured that you can continue to eat meat-free for the next 9 or so months, says Maven Nutritionist Kendra Tolbert. “It’s absolutely possible to have a healthy pregnancy as a vegetarian,” she says. “It just might require a bit more intentionality around food choices to make sure you’re getting enough of certain nutrients, but it’s very doable.”
Read on to learn more. Have more nutrition questions? Talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
for free anytime.
Vegetarianism and pregnancy 101

Nutrition is such a key part of making sure your baby is healthy and grows and develops on track. That’s why if you’re already a vegetarian, you should work closely with your care team to make sure you’re getting all the important nutrients that you and baby need.
Make sure to be up-front with your main provider (like your OB-GYN or midwife) and let them know you’re already a vegetarian and plan to continue to not eat meat throughout your pregnancy.

You should also be specific about what exactly being a vegetarian means to you. “It’s important to define what is meant by ‘vegetarian’ because I’ve worked with people who have described themselves as vegetarian, but upon further investigation, I discover that they regularly eat chicken and/or seafood,” Tolbert explains.
Let your provider know if you’re:
Vegan:
You don’t eat meat, chicken, eggs, dairy, seafood, or consume animal products of any kind
Lacto-vegetarian:
No meat, chicken, seafood, or eggs, but you do eat dairy
Ovo-vegetarian:
No meat, chicken, seafood, or dairy, but you do eat eggs
Lacto-Ovo vegetarian:
No meat, chicken, or seafood, but you do eat eggs and dairy
Pescatarian:
No meat or chicken, but you do eat eggs, dairy, fish, and possibly seafood
Flexitarian:
You eat meat sometimes or on certain days REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

By knowing exactly what your daily diet looks like, your provider can help you make a plan for a healthy pregnancy. They’ll let you know what you need to do to meet your and your baby’s nutritional needs. “Depending on which foods are restricted or limited, there may be cause for more or less concern,” Tolbert explains.
It’s also smart to work with a nutritionist throughout your pregnancy. They can help you meal plan and offer suggestions for supplements, if needed, and more. Make an appointment to speak with a
Maven Nutritionist
for free online anytime.
Starting a vegetarian diet during pregnancy

If you’re new to being a vegetarian during your pregnancy, be sure to let your provider know, too. They can let you know if they recommend any supplements (like extra iron or Vitamin B12) you might need. They can also suggest some foods you should include with your daily plate. You can also book a time to talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
if you want more nutrition advice or veggie-friendly meal ideas.
Will your prenatal vitamin be enough, or do you need other supplements?

Eating a (mostly) healthy diet with a wide variety of foods, plus taking your daily prenatal vitamin, is a great start when it comes to setting you and your baby up for nutritional success during your pregnancy.

But as a vegetarian, you might need some supplements like iron or vitamin B12 in addition to your daily prenatal vitamin. “A well-formulated prenatal vitamin is a great foundation,” Tolbert says. “They enhance or enrich your diet, but they don’t provide all of the nutrients you need.”
Your doctor during pregnancy will talk to you about what you eat and they can help you figure out if you need to take supplements. You’ll also get a blood test to check your iron levels and more.
Whether or not you might need additional supplements usually depends on:
Your overall eating habits
What your blood work reveals
Your health history
Medication use
What your prenatal vitamin contains REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have any questions about supplements, you can talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
for free online anytime. Never take a supplement during pregnancy without talking to your provider first.
Are you getting enough protein?

Protein, protein, protein. If you’ve been a vegetarian for a long time, you probably hear about the importance of protein all the time. During your pregnancy, it’s vital, as well. Protein not only keeps you strong, but also helps you feel full, and keeps your blood sugar levels steady. It’s so important for your baby’s growth and development, too.
Pregnant people need around 60 to 100 grams of protein per day, which is a lot! (One egg contains around 6 grams.)
Some smart vegetarian options for protein to include in your daily diet are:
Legumes, including soy products like tofu and edamame
Yogurt, cottage cheese, cheese (if you eat dairy)
Nuts, seeds
Grains like brown rice, quinoa, and whole wheat bread
Plant-based protein powders
Sea vegetables like seaweed and kelp
Eggs and dairy (if you eat these)
Fortified foods like cereal and pasta
Other nutrients to keep in mind
In addition to your daily prenatal vitamin, here are some other important nutrients you’ll need throughout your pregnancy and foods that have plenty of them:
Omega 3s:
Try flaxseeds, chia seeds, walnuts, hemp seeds, sea vegetables, and eggs
Iron:
Try fortified breakfast cereals, beans, peas, lentils, dark leafy greens, dark chocolate, canned stewed tomatoes, and dried fruit
Vitamin B12
: Try nutritional yeast, dairy, fortified breakfast cereal, and eggs
Zinc
: Try fortified breakfast cereal, seeds, nuts, beans, peas, lentils, and dairy
Choline
: Try eggs, beans, peas, lentils, potatoes, wheat germ, quinoa, broccoli, collard greens, and brussels sprouts
Calcium:
Try dairy, calcium-fortified orange juice, calcium-fortified soymilk, calcium-set tofu, fortified breakfast cereals, dark green leafy vegetables, beans, peas, and lentils
Iodine
: Sea vegetables, milk, iodized table salt, eggs, dairy
Vitamin D
: Try mushrooms, Vitamin-D fortified milk, Vitamin-D fortified soy milk, fortified cereal, and eggs
Vegetarian meals to try
If you’re lacking inspiration, try these healthy and delicious vegetarian meal ideas.
Breakfast:
Smoothie: Milk of choice, spinach, strawberries, chia seeds, protein powder, banana, or avocado
Breakfast Burrito: Tortilla, black beans, cheese, lettuce, stewed tomatoes
Breakfast Scramble: Quinoa, eggs, broccoli, and peppers
Cottage cheese or yogurt with granola and/or nuts
Lunch/Dinner:
Rice and bean bowl: Rice of choice, beans of choice, cheese or nutritional yeast, and veggie toppings of choice
Lentil and chickpea pasta: Lentil pasta, canned smoked clams (optional), tomato sauce, chickpeas
Curry over rice: Rice of choice with curried chickpeas
Vegetable stir fry and rice: Tofu, bok choy, carrots, onions, garlic, over rice
Chili: Bean or lentil-based
Soups/ stews: With beans and veggies
Snacks:
Orange and nuts
Apple or banana and nut butter
Yogurt, dried fruit, and seeds
Tortilla chips, bean dip, and cheese
Hard boiled eggs
The bottom line

It can feel a little overwhelming to make sure you’re getting all the important nutrition you and your baby need during your pregnancy. But Maven is here for you to make sure you’re up to date and have all the information you need. Make a free appointment to speak to a
Maven Nutritionist
anytime and get all your questions answered.
Sources
Mayo Clinic
Oregon State
UCSF Health

title.en-US: How to hand express your breast milk

content.value: What you need to know:
When you hand express breast milk, you use your hands (rather than your baby or a pump) to remove milk from your breasts.
Hand expression is a good way to relieve engorgement, remove milk from your breasts if you’re away from your baby or pump, and increase your milk supply.
If you need help with hand expression, make an online appointment with a
Maven Lactation Consultant
for free advice.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you choose to feed your baby breast milk (whether by nursing and pumping), knowing how to hand express your breast milk can come in ... handy (sorry, had to!). Here’s how to incorporate hand expression into your breastfeeding routine, and how it can maximize your milk production, with tips from Maven Lactation Consultant Michelle Poole.
When to hand express your breast milk
Here are a few scenarios where hand expression can be really helpful:
Baby isn’t latching
, but you want to give them colostrum (the thick, sticky milk that comes in before your mature milk). Hand expressing is usually more effective for removing colostrum than a pump.
Your breasts are too engorged
(full, hard, and swollen) for baby to latch. Hand expressing some milk can soften your areola enough for them to latch.
You’re away from baby
or your
breast pump
and need relief from engorgement
You’re without electricity
or water and can’t pump
You want to boost your breast milk supply
by hand expressing after a nursing or pumping sessionREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

The best part about hand expressing your breast milk is that you don’t need any special equipment, like a pump. So if you’re ever away from your baby or pump, or in an emergency situation without power or water, hand expression can be a great solution.
How hand expression can help your milk supply

“If a parent is trying to make more milk, hand expression after breastfeeding or pumping has been shown to increase supply over time,” says Poole. The more often you empty your breasts, the more milk your body will make, so tacking a few minutes of hand expression on right after a nursing or pumping session can help
boost your supply.

What’s more, if you don’t want to nurse or pump, but want to give your baby breast milk, you can use hand expression on its own to maintain your supply. Poole explains: “If milk is being removed from the breast—whether by baby, electric pump, or hand expression—in the same amount that the baby takes when nursing, the supply will be maintained.”
How to hand express breast milk
Learning how to hand express your breast milk might take some time and practice, but it’s a good skill to have if you plan to breastfeed your baby. Here’s how to get started:
1. Wash your hands

with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds (or the time it takes to sing “Happy Birthday” twice), or use hand sanitizer that’s at least 60% alcohol. Unwashed hands or collection containers can introduce bacteria to your breast milk, and to baby.
2. Find a clean container
to collect your breast milk in. It may be easier to express your milk into a container with a wide mouth, like a drinking glass, mason jar, or Haakaa manual breast pump.
3. Look at a picture of your baby,
think about them, or smell a piece of their clothing while you massage your breasts. This can stimulate your let-down (the reflex that makes your breast milk flow).
4. Place your hand in the right position.
Positioning your hand correctly will help maximize the milk you can express. Here’s what you need to do:
Position your thumb above your nipple and your fingers one to two inches below your nipple to
make a C-shape
with your hand.
Press
your thumb and fingers back towards your chest.
While pushing back, gently
compress
your thumb and fingers together. This should express your breast milk.
Release
your thumb and fingers, and repeat in a rhythmic pattern.
Press, compress,
and
release
until the milk stops flowing from your breast. Then, switch to the other breast.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you need a visual,
this video
from Stanford Medicine is a good example of the press, compress, release pattern that will give you the highest milk output.
5. Use the milk or store in the refrigerator for later.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), fresh milk can stay out of the fridge for up to four hours. It will last in the fridge for up to four days, and in a freezer for up to 12 months.
Some other things you can do to get your milk flowing
Sit in a comfortable position and lean slightly forward
Apply a warm compress, like a warm washcloth or heating pad, before you hand express
Try to relax with meditation or deep breathing. Feeling anxious or tense can actually block your milk-making hormones and lower the amount of breast milk you make.
How to avoid hurting your breasts while hand expressing

It’s important to know that it is possible to injure your breasts while hand expressing. Poole says, “If you drag your finger and thumb over your skin while applying pressure, this could cause friction burns and abrasions. And if you’re applying too much pressure, you could bruise the underlying breast tissue.”

Poole explains that many people also mistakenly think they need to squeeze their nipples during hand expression, but doing so can actually stop milk flow or even cause damage to the nipple tissue. “To avoid these problems, try to keep your finger and thumb in the same place while you press back into your chest and roll them together. The pressure you’re applying should be firm, but gentle,” she says.

Hand expressing your breast milk should never feel painful. If you feel any discomfort while you’re hand expressing, stop and try repositioning your hand or body. If hand expression continues to be painful, end the session and make an appointment with a
Maven Lactation Consultant
for advice.
We’re here to help
