Hand expressing breast milk is like any other new skill—it might take a few sessions to figure out what works best for your body. Poole says, “There is no one ‘right way’ to hand express. Experiment with different finger placements and techniques, and see what works best for you. Take your time, and be easy and gentle with yourself. The more you practice, the easier it will become!”
If you’re having a hard time understanding how to hand express your breast milk, feel pain when you hand express, or want more advice on breastfeeding, make an appointment with a
Maven Lactation Consultant
. They can walk you through it step by step in a quick video call.
Sources
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
La Leche League

title.en-US: UTIs during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know:
UTIs are common during pregnancy. But you should see your doctor right away for treatment if you think you have one.
Left untreated, UTIs can cause a kidney infection that can be dangerous for your baby.
To prevent future UTIs, stay hydrated and pee when you need to go. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Being pregnant comes with enough not-so-fun little challenges (first trimester nausea and having to pee
nonstop
, we’re looking at you). It doesn’t seem fair that you can also still get sick and experience uncomfortable urinary tract infections (UTIs), too.

Unfortunately, it turns out that UTIs are somewhat common during pregnancy. So if you think you have one, it’s important to see your doctor right away. Maven OB-GYN Kathleen Green explains why UTIs and pregnancy tend to go hand-in-hand. Plus the best pregnancy-safe ways to treat them.
UTIs and pregnancy: Why they happen

You aren’t alone if you’re pregnant and find yourself prone to UTIs. Up to 8 percent of pregnant people will experience a UTI at some point in their pregnancy, according to a study in the journal American Family Physician.

There are a few reasons for this. Mainly there’s a higher chance for bacteria to enter your urinary tract during pregnancy. That’s because your bladder might not empty completely as your body grows and uterus expands later in pregnancy. If you’re diagnosed with gestational diabetes (a type of diabetes that develops during pregnancy), you might be more likely to experience UTIs. (There may be more sugar in your urine where bacteria can grow).
UTI symptoms to watch for

The symptoms of a UTI during pregnancy are the same as when you’re not pregnant. So if you’ve experienced one before, it will probably feel similar. But it might be harder to tell if you do have a UTI because some of the symptoms overlap with pregnancy—such as having to pee more often.

If you experience any of the symptoms below and/or back pain, fever, or chills, see your doctor right away. They can test to see if you have a UTI. “Your symptoms can be a sign you may have a UTI, but the only way to be sure is to test your urine,” Green says.
Look out for:
Pain or a burning feeling when peeing
Peeing more often (hard to tell when you’re pregnant)
Feeling like your bladder isn’t emptying completely
Blood in your pee
Foul-smelling or cloudy urine
Will my OB-GYN test me for UTIs at every appointment?

You will likely be asked to give a urine sample at some (or all) of your prenatal appointments. So you might be wondering if your OB-GYN or midwife is testing for UTIs. The answer is, maybe. Your doctor might be looking for a UTI. Or they might only be testing for sugar or protein in your urine, which can be signs of gestational diabetes or preeclampsia later in your pregnancy.
If you have any symptoms of a UTI (listed above) or are concerned you might have one, talk to your provider. You can ask if more testing is needed.
Treatment and risks of untreated UTIs

It can be worrisome if you do get a UTI when you're pregnant. Thankfully, UTIs are easily treatable. “UTIs during pregnancy aren't dangerous if they are treated,” Green says “But if they go untreated, they can lead to more serious kidney infections. They can also cause preterm labor, early delivery, and even fetal death in some cases. You can become very sick as well.” So always tell your doctor, just to be safe.

Your doctor can prescribe pregnancy-safe antibiotics to help clear up your UTI. And it might sound obvious—but If you see a new provider for your UTI that’s not your usual OB-GYN, midwife, or family physician, be sure to let them know that you’re pregnant. That way, they can prescribe the right UTI treatment that’s safe for you and your baby.
How to prevent future UTIs
If you’re wondering how to
prevent future UTIs

for the rest of your pregnancy, your best bet is to stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water and other drinks such as non-caffeinated herbal tea. It’s also important to pee when you have the urge to go (we know, that’s going to be like all the time, which is not ideal). Try to empty your bladder completely each time, too.
If you have more questions about UTIs or how to prevent them in the future, you can speak to a
Maven Nurse Practitioner
for free online anytime.
Sources
ACOG
UT Southwestern Medical Center
American Family Physician

title.en-US: Iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy: What you need to know

content.value: What you need to know:
Having low iron during pregnancy can be very serious for you and your baby if left untreated.
Your prenatal vitamin might provide some of the iron you need during pregnancy. Your doctor will let you know if you need a supplement.
Follow your doctor’s recommendations for how much iron you need to take during your pregnancy. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Feeling like you need an afternoon cat nap is par for the course during pregnancy. Your body is hard at work growing life, after all! But if you feel so utterly exhausted or weak that you can’t get through the day, you might want to check in with your doctor about your iron levels.

Many pregnant people have low iron (iron deficiency anemia) during pregnancy, explains Maven OB-GYN Kathleen Green. If you do have low iron, or iron deficiency anemia, you might need to take a supplement. Read on to learn more.
Why your body needs iron

So why do you need iron, anyway? You need iron because your body uses it to make hemoglobin, the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. During pregnancy, you need even more iron. It helps bring oxygen to your baby.
Why your iron levels might be low during pregnancy

Your prenatal vitamin does give you some of the iron you need. (Make sure yours contains at least 27 milligrams of iron). But if you had low iron before you got pregnant, are pregnant with multiples, or are on a restrictive diet, for example, you might need more. And if you take gummy prenatal vitamins, be sure to check— some of them don’t have iron.

“As many as 30% of women have low iron before pregnancy, and then it gets worse during pregnancy as the demand for iron increases with the growing baby,” Green says. “Some people don't get enough iron in their diet or don't take a prenatal vitamin with iron. They go into pregnancy with low or no iron stores, and then have increased demand for iron but aren't increasing their intake of iron.”
If you are concerned about your iron levels, talk to your doctor or make an appointment with a
Maven OB-GYN
anytime.
Testing for low iron levels during pregnancy

You’ll probably get your blood drawn early on in your pregnancy. This test will let your OB-GYN or midwife know if you have low iron levels. You may have a second test later in your pregnancy, too.  “All pregnant people will get a CBC, or total blood count, at the start of pregnancy which will detect a low blood count,” Green explains. “If it’s low, your provider may order additional studies to see what is causing the blood count to be low. A second set of labs are also drawn at 28 weeks which check the blood count again to follow up on the anemia.”
Symptoms of low iron during pregnancy
As mentioned above, your doctor should recommend a blood test to check for low iron.
Also be on the lookout for these symptoms:
Lightheadedness
Extreme or more fatigue than usual
Headaches
Dizziness or weakness
Feeling short of breath REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you are experiencing these at any point in your pregnancy, be sure to let your doctor know. They might order additional testing to see what’s going on.
Is having low iron during pregnancy dangerous?
Unfortunately, having low iron during pregnancy can be very serious for you and your baby if left untreated.
Severe low iron can lead to:
Preterm birth (before 37 weeks)
Low birth weight
Increased risk of bleeding after delivery
Placenta abruption
Need for a blood transfusion and intensive care unit (ICU) admission for you
Increased risk of fetal distress and neonatal intensive care unit NICU admission for baby REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Because it can be so dangerous, if your doctor recommends that you take additional iron supplements, be sure to follow all their instructions carefully (more on that below).
Treatment for low iron

If your doctor does find your iron levels are low, taking your prenatal vitamins daily might be all that’s needed to bring them back up. However, if your iron is very low, you might need iron supplements or even receive iron transfusions. An iron transfusion is where you’ll receive iron through an IV inserted through a needle in your arm.
Your doctor may also recommend you eat a diet with plenty of iron-rich foods including:
Spinach
Kale
Beans
Red meat
Liver REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you are worried you aren’t getting enough iron in your diet or want to find out how to get more, you can book an appointment to speak with a
Maven Nutritionist
for free anytime.
The bottom line:

You aren’t alone if you find out your iron levels are low during your pregnancy—many pregnant people experience this. But be sure to continue taking your daily prenatal vitamin and follow your doctor’s recommendations carefully for how to get more iron if needed. Having very low iron levels can be dangerous for you and your baby if left untreated.
If you have any more questions or concerns when it comes to iron deficiency anemia, make an appointment to speak to a
Maven OB-GYN
for free online anytime.
Sources
Mayo Clinic
Mount Sinai
ACOG

title.en-US: Incontinence during pregnancy: Why it happens, what to try

content.value: What you need to know:
Incontinence, or leaking urine in-between bathroom breaks, is common during pregnancy.
It is likely caused by added pressure on your body from your baby and because your pelvic floor muscles are stretching.
You can work with your doctor and a pelvic floor therapist who can help. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Having to pee
all the time
when you’re pregnant is pretty standard. But when you also leak a little pee every time you sneeze, cough, or just take a step, you might be wondering...is this normal?

Incontinence, or leaking urine in-between bathroom breaks, is usually talked about in the postpartum period, after you have the baby. But it’s actually pretty common during pregnancy, too, especially in your second and third trimesters. That’s when baby is putting lots of extra pressure on your bladder.

It’s not the most fun thing to deal with—but know that if you’re experiencing this, there isn’t likely anything wrong with you or your baby, says Maven OB-GYN Kathleen Green. Here’s what you need to know and some things you can try to stop surprise leaks (or at least stay comfortable).
Why you might be leaking during pregnancy
There are a few reasons why you might be leaking urine during your pregnancy:
Added pressure on your body:

“Incontinence is very common in pregnancy because there’s added pressure from carrying a baby and the pelvic floor muscles stretch,” Green says. You might be dealing with something called “stress” incontinence. This leakage happens any time there’s pressure (or stress) put on your body. So you notice you leak urine when you sneeze, cough, laugh, or exercise.
Second or more pregnancy:
You may also be more likely to leak if this isn’t your first pregnancy. When you’ve been pregnant before, your pelvic floor muscles might already be stretched or weaker.
Urinary tract infections (UTIs):
UTIs can also cause leaking and can be more common during pregnancy. Your doctor might ask for a urine sample at your next prenatal appointment to check if you have a UTI.
Certain medications:
Some medications may also cause incontinence. Talk to your doctor if you’re on any medications and are concerned.
Is incontinence dangerous for you or your baby?

It’s not the most convenient thing to be dealing with, but a bit of leaking shouldn’t be dangerous for you or your baby. “Leaking small amounts of urine with coughing or sneezing can be normal, it doesn’t mean something is wrong,” Green says.
Still, it’s worth mentioning leaking to your provider at your next appointment. They’ll want to check to make sure your water hasn’t broken (more on that below) and that you don’t have a UTI.
Are you leaking pee—or is your water breaking?

If you feel a large gush of fluid or continue to leak fluid, this is more than incontinence and your water might have broken. If this happens, it’s important to call your doctor right away and head to the hospital.

If you’re having trouble telling the difference, know that if your water breaks, the amniotic fluid won’t smell like urine. It also will likely be clear, but might be white/murky and be mixed with mucus and/or blood.
How to cope with incontinence
Some good news is that incontinence may stop after you deliver your baby.
Until then, try these strategies to cope:
Wear ultra-absorbent panty liners
or pads in your underwear.
Keep extra pants or leggings in your car
(or work bag) so you’ll have something to change into if needed.
Keep a bladder journal.
Keep track of food or drinks that trigger incontinence. Try avoiding caffeine, citrus sugar, and spicy foods and note if you leak less when you avoid them.
Avoid getting constipated.
Drink water and eat fiber-rich foods like beans and leafy vegetables. Constipation can put extra pressure on your bladder and make you feel like you have to pee more.
Work with a pelvic floor physical therapist.

They can recommend exercises such as Kegels to strengthen your pelvic floor. It’s important to work with a professional (and talk to your doctor) because they can confirm that these exercises are safe for your pregnancy. You can also make an appointment to talk to a
Maven Pelvic Floor Physical Support Coach
anytime.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
National Association for Continence

title.en-US: Gluten-free guide to prenatal nutrition

content.value: What you need to know:
If you live with celiac disease and/or have already eliminated gluten from your diet before getting pregnant, you can continue eating (pretty much) like you normally do.
Work with your doctor and/or a nutritionist to make sure you aren’t missing anything important from your diet.
If you’re interested in cutting gluten from your diet during pregnancy, always talk to your doctor first. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you’re pregnant and follow a gluten-free diet, you might feel worried that you’re missing out on some key nutrients. Or you want to make sure that you’re eating enough healthy foods for you and your baby.

Know that if you live with celiac disease and/or have already eliminated gluten from your diet before getting pregnant, you can continue eating (pretty much) like you normally do. Just make sure you’re working together with your doctor and/or a nutritionist to make sure you’re getting all the nutrients and calories you need throughout your pregnancy, recommends Maven Nutritionist Lauren Olofsson.
If you’re considering going gluten-free for the first time while pregnant, definitely talk to your doctor first and get their help to do so safely.
Read this guide to learn more about a safe and healthy gluten-free prenatal diet.
I’m already gluten-free, should I continue while pregnant?
If you already follow a gluten-free diet
(meaning you don’t eat gluten, the protein found in wheat, barley, and rye) you can safely continue it throughout your pregnancy.

“If you’ve eliminated gluten from your diet prior to pregnancy and find that it works well for you because you have less inflammation or improved gut health, for example, then you may continue following a gluten-free diet throughout your pregnancy,” Olofsson says. “But do mention it to your doctor and be aware of some of the easy nutritional pitfalls found in many gluten-free alternatives or substitutes.” (More on that below.)
If you live with celiac disease

, continue to completely avoid gluten. It’s not safe for you to eat gluten anytime, including during your pregnancy. “If you have celiac it’s never safe for you to reintroduce gluten to your diet because it could trigger an immune response and you can get really sick,” Olofsson says. “Celiac disease is a chronic systemic autoimmune disorder. It’s caused by a permanent intolerance to gluten proteins.”
Is it safe to start a gluten-free diet during pregnancy?

If you’re interested in cutting gluten from your diet during pregnancy, always talk to your doctor first. You should also work with a nutritionist to make sure you’re changing your diet gradually and in a safe way.

“Know that a gluten-free diet is not healthier or necessary unless you have celiac disease or a significant inflammatory response (like bloating, pain, etc.) after consuming gluten-containing foods, such as gluten sensitivity or intolerance,” Olofsson explains. “If you’re still interested in starting a gluten-free diet during pregnancy, it can be safely done, but it’s best to work with a dietitian before starting and throughout the initial transition to gluten-free.”
You can talk to a
Maven Nutritionist
for free online anytime if you want to learn more.
How to eat gluten-free and healthy during your pregnancy
Take your prenatal vitamin:

This will give you many of the important vitamins and nutrients you need during your pregnancy that are hard to get just from food. They are so important for your baby’s development, too. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Eat a wide variety of foods:
During your pregnancy, it’s important to eat a wide variety of healthy foods to make sure you’re getting all the nutrients you and your growing baby need.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Eat gluten-free carbohydrates:
Even if you aren’t eating gluten, it’s still important to include healthy sources of gluten-free carbohydrates in your diet. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Pregnant people should aim to eat around 175 grams of carbohydrates each day, according to the U.S. Food & Drug Administration. (Unless you’re diagnosed with gestational diabetes. If that’s you, your diet will look different. Talk to your doctor or a
Nutritionist on Maven
to make a plan.)
Luckily many sources of carbohydrates are naturally gluten-free. Some healthy sources of naturally gluten-free carbs include:
Rice
Potatoes
Buckwheat
Gluten-free oats
Quinoa
Millet REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
“These carbohydrate sources alongside fruits, vegetables, dairy and meat can allow your pregnancy to easily stay nutritious and well-balanced,” Olofsson says.
Ask your doctor about supplements:

Unfortunately, even if you eat a lot of healthy foods, you might still need to supplement your diet in some ways. “When following a gluten-free diet, you’re more likely to consume less fiber (given grains are a naturally fiber-rich food) and lower amounts of Vitamin D, Vitamin B12, and folate,” says Olofsson.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKWork with your doctor or a
Nutritionist
and ask if you should take any supplements in addition to your daily prenatal vitamin. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Be careful with gluten-free substitutes:

They might not be as healthy as you think. “Many packaged/processed gluten-free foods are often lower in protein, higher in fat, salt, and sugar. This helps with the flavor when removing the gluten-containing item,” says Olofsson. “So keep in mind when you buy gluten-free packaged snack foods, it’s not necessarily healthier.” REPLACEWITHLINEBREAKREPLACEWITHLINEBREAKInstead, try to fill your plate with some of the gluten-free options listed above, along with plenty of lean protein, fresh fruits, and vegetables. Some more meal ideas are below.
Easy gluten-free meal ideas during pregnancy

Eating gluten-free during your pregnancy doesn’t have to be super complex. Try eating simple, healthy meals made from whole ingredients like fruits, vegetables, protein sources like eggs, and gluten-free grains.
Here are some meal ideas for a day of delicious gluten-free eats:
Breakfast

: Overnight oats with nut butter (make sure that your oats are marked as gluten-free to avoid cross contamination), 2 hard boiled eggs with fruit, cottage cheese with fruit (make sure the label says gluten-free), or a smoothie
Lunch:
Quinoa bowl with quinoa, sunflower seeds, cucumbers, tomatoes, bell peppers, hummus, oil, and vinegar, tuna salad over lettuce, or a gluten-free wrap with turkey and cheese
Dinner:

Stir fry chicken, tofu, rice and vegetables with Tamari or other gluten-free sauce (note some soy sauces contain gluten), chili or stew, or gluten-free pasta with sauce and veggies REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Want more gluten-free tips and meal ideas for your pregnancy? Book a free online appointment with a
Maven Nutritionist
anytime.
Sources
U.S. Food & Drug Administration
Mayo Clinic
Johns Hopkins Medicine

title.en-US: Supplements during pregnancy: Should you take anything besides your prenatal vitamin?

content.value: What you need to know:
Supplements aren’t usually needed during pregnancy.
The exception is if your provider says you need extra iron, folate, or other nutrients to help round out your daily diet.
Always let your doctor know which supplements you take. They’ll let you know if they’re safe to continue taking. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

During pregnancy, you want to do everything you can to keep you and your baby healthy and growing strong. Taking your prenatal vitamin every day is hopefully already on your daily to-do list, along with eating a wide variety of healthy foods when you can. (But hey, if you can’t manage to keep down a vegetable during the first trimester, you aren’t alone. Hang in there!)

Beyond that, you might be wondering if you need to take any extra vitamins or supplements to give your health a boost. But it turns out, they aren’t usually needed, says Maven OB-GYN Rana Daniel. The exception is if your provider says you need extra iron, folate, or other nutrients to help round out your daily diet.
Read on to learn more about supplements and you and your growing baby’s needs over the next nine or so months.
Do you need to take any supplements during pregnancy?

Supplements likely take up an entire aisle at your local pharmacy. They come in a bunch of different forms these days like vitamins, minerals, herbal supplements, and botanicals. You can find gummies, powders, liquids, tablets, and more.
But once you’ve settled on a prenatal vitamin, you can keep walking right past that aisle, Daniel says. No other supplements are usually necessary during your pregnancy. “In general, your
diet
and
prenatal vitamin
should be sufficient to get you all the nutrients you need throughout pregnancy,” she says.
There are a few exceptions to this. During your pregnancy, your doctor might want you to take additional:
Iron:
Many pregnant people are
iron deficient

. Your doctor will check your iron levels and let you know if you need a supplement. “Iron levels are usually checked between 26-28 weeks, along with your glucose test,” Daniel says. “Your doctor may ask you to add this supplement if you are low.”
Folate:

Folate, or folic acid, helps prevent birth defects and neural tube defects in babies. It’s important to take it before (if you can) and during your pregnancy. If your pregnancy is high-risk, your doctor might recommend an additional folate supplement.
Vitamin B12:
If you’re a vegetarian or vegan.
DHA:
If you’re vegan and/or your prenatal doesn’t contain DHA.
Vitamin D:
If you live in an area where you don’t get a lot of sunshine. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Your doctor will likely take a blood draw early in your pregnancy. This will test to see if you have
low iron
and more. Your doctor will let you know if you need to take any supplements if any of your levels are low.
What if you already took other supplements before getting pregnant?
If you already took other supplements before getting pregnant, be sure to let your doctor know. They can let you know if they’re safe to continue taking.
Some examples include:
Melatonin
Magnesium
Vitamin D
Probiotics REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Daniel says these likely won’t be harmful to continue taking during pregnancy. But keep in mind, these supplements aren’t approved by the FDA. That means their effect on pregnancy might not be well studied. “They aren’t considered dangerous during pregnancy, but you will want to run them by your doctor so they can check out the other ingredients and give you recommendations just in case,” Daniel says.
Supplements to avoid during pregnancy

Always ask your doctor if there are any other supplements you’re interested in or already take. They can let you know if they’re safe to continue during pregnancy. They can also let you know how much is safe to take, if needed.
Vitamin A, for example, isn’t safe to take in high amounts. It can be dangerous for baby’s development. Your prenatal vitamin usually has all the Vitamin A you’d need.
The bottom line

It can be tempting to stock up on supplements to give your health a boost during pregnancy. But take heart that you’re already doing a lot for yourself and your baby. Taking your daily prenatal and trying to
eat healthy

when you can might be all you need. If other supplements are important to you or you want to know if you need anything else, be sure to talk to your provider. You can also make an appointment to speak with a
Maven OB-GYN
or
Nutritionist
online for free anytime.

title.en-US: How to manage thyroid conditions while pregnant

content.value: What you need to know:
If you live with a thyroid condition, work closely with your doctor during your pregnancy.
Your doctor will let you know if your thyroid medication is safe to continue taking or if you need to change your prescription.
It’s possible to manage your thyroid condition safely during pregnancy and delivery. But untreated thyroid conditions can be dangerous for you and baby. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Living with a chronic condition during your pregnancy can be scary. So if you live with a thyroid condition or are diagnosed with one while pregnant, you probably have a lot of questions. You may be wondering how it can affect your pregnancy and the health of your growing baby.

Know that it’s entirely possible to safely manage your condition and go on to have a healthy pregnancy and baby, says Maven OB-GYN Kathleen Green. But you and your doctor will be a close team as you navigate through the next nine or so months.
Maven is also here for you throughout your pregnancy (and beyond) whenever you have questions or concerns. Reach out to make an appointment with an
OB-GYN
online for free anytime.
What’s a thyroid condition?
If you’re living with a thyroid condition, it means that your thyroid, the butterfly-shaped gland at the base of your neck, doesn’t work the way it should.
The two most common thyroid conditions are:
Hypothyroidism:

Hypothyroidism, or an underactive thyroid, is a condition where your thyroid doesn’t produce enough thyroid hormones. Some symptoms might be noticeable, like fatigue and weight gain. Or, you could have little to no obvious symptoms. If you’re diagnosed with Hashimoto’s Thyroiditis, that’s an autoimmune condition that typically causes hypothyroidism.
Hyperthyroidism:

Hyperthyroidism, or an overactive thyroid, is a condition where your thyroid over-produces thyroid hormones. It can affect your metabolism and other critical body functions. Grave’s disease is an autoimmune condition that can cause hyperthyroidism.
Will I be tested for thyroid conditions during pregnancy?

Your doctor might or might not test you for a thyroid condition as part of your other blood work taken early on in your pregnancy. But it’s important to always keep them updated on any symptoms that feel new, weird, or just “off”. More on that below.

Some pregnant people do end up getting diagnosed with a thyroid condition during pregnancy. But being pregnant doesn't mean you are more likely to be diagnosed with one. If you are new to this diagnosis, Maven is here to support you. You can make a free online appointment to speak with a
Maven OB-GYN
anytime to answer any questions you have.
What are the most common symptoms of a thyroid condition?

Some symptoms of an over- or underactive thyroid might overlap with your other pregnancy symptoms. (Hello, feeling tired all the time.) But don’t hesitate to let your doctor know just in case if you have:
Extreme fatigue (more than the usual pregnancy tired)
Feeling dizzy
Heart beating rapidly
Feeling sensitive to heat or cold
Hair changes like thinning or falling out
Difficulty sleeping
Sweating more than usual
Anxiety
Hand tremors
Losing weight even if you’re eating wellREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Thyroid conditions that are left untreated can be dangerous during pregnancy. So if you haven’t been diagnosed yet, but feel like you’re experiencing some symptoms, be sure to let your doctor know right away just to be safe. They can diagnose a thyroid condition based on a blood draw and on your symptoms.
How do thyroid conditions affect pregnancy?

Normally-functioning thyroid hormones during pregnancy are important for your baby’s brain development and growth. And if left untreated, thyroid conditions can be very dangerous for you and your baby.
Untreated, they might cause:
Premature birth (being born before 37 weeks of pregnancy)
Preeclampsia (high blood pressure that can be dangerous during pregnancy and delivery)
Placenta abruption (where the placenta separates from your uterus before delivery)
Miscarriage or stillbirth
Low birth weight
Your baby might be at risk of having a thyroid condition after they are born REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Your health can be affected as well. Untreated thyroid conditions can even lead to heart failure in the most severe cases.

Thankfully, if you continue to work with your doctor(s) and take pregnancy-safe thyroid medication, hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism don’t usually cause any additional problems during pregnancy and delivery. It’s only if they’re untreated that they become a cause for concern.
What do I need to do during pregnancy to safely manage my thyroid condition?

If you’re already taking medication to manage your thyroid conditions, don’t stop taking it when you find out you’re pregnant. But do be sure to let your doctor know which medications you take right away.
“Most thyroid medication is safe during the pregnancy,” Green says. “But your doctor can let you know if it’s safe to continue taking it and if you need to change the dose you’re taking at all.”
Your doctor might also recommend you see a specialist during your pregnancy. A
high-risk OB-GYN
or endocrinologist, for example. They can help you keep managing your medication and symptoms so you and your baby stay healthy.
If you are diagnosed with a thyroid condition for the first time during pregnancy, your doctor will advise you on safe medication to take.
The bottom line

Navigating a chronic thyroid condition and being pregnant is a lot. But you aren’t alone. Your doctor can help you figure out how to safely continue taking your medications and make any adjustments as needed. You can also see a specialist like a high-risk OB who specializes in high-risk pregnancies. Maven is also here for you. If any questions come up, book an appointment with a
Maven OB-GYN
anytime.
Sources
March of Dimes
Johns Hopkins Medicine
Mayo Clinic

title.en-US: How to manage pubic bone pain during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know:
Pubic bone pain is uncomfortable. But it doesn’t usually mean anything is wrong with you or your baby. It also doesn’t usually mean you’re in labor.
You might want to see a physical therapist who can recommend exercises to help.
Report any extreme pain to your doctor and/or seek emergency medical care right away. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Feeling some back and body aches later on in pregnancy? Not the most comfortable to deal with—but usually it’s just part of the experience. Feeling pain down below in your pubic region? That might raise a few more red flags for you.
Pubic pain during pregnancy can be really uncomfortable. It can even make it difficult to walk. You also might be worried that it’s a sign you’ll be going into labor sooner rather than later.
But know that pubic bone pain doesn’t usually mean anything is wrong with you or your baby, says Maven OB-GYN Yi-Lo Yu. It also doesn’t mean you’re in labor.
Here’s why pubic bone pain happens and why a physical therapist might be your new best friend until you deliver.
What is pubic bone pain and what does it feel like during pregnancy?
Pubic bone pain, or what doctors sometimes call
symphysis pubis dysfunction
, is felt around your pubic bone and/or pelvis. This is located at the bottom of your pelvis, just above your genital area. It’s also the area in line with the middle of the hips.
During your pregnancy, you might feel pubic pain:
In the center of your pubic bone (at the bottom of your pelvis)
In your perineum (area between your vagina and anus)
In your lower back or thighs REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

There are not a lot of ways to sugarcoat it: it can be downright uncomfortable, especially if it makes it challenging to walk or get dressed. It might feel worse when you walk, move around, or climb stairs, too.
What causes pubic bone pain during pregnancy?

So why is this happening? Like a lot of things in pregnancy, you can thank hormones for this one, too. “The pubic bone ligaments loosen in pregnancy in preparation for delivery. This is caused by pregnancy hormones,” Yu says. “This is usually what causes the discomfort in this area. Sometimes when your pelvis isn’t aligned because it's stretching and growing to make room for baby, that can cause some pain, too.”
Is pubic bone pain dangerous?
Here’s some good news, it might be painful, but mild or occasional pubic bone pain isn’t usually a sign that something’s wrong.

“Pubic pain isn’t dangerous, it’s just part of your body’s preparation for opening up the pelvis to get ready for a vaginal delivery,” Yu says. “However, if the pain is so severe that it is affecting your ability to walk or perform basic day-to-day tasks, then definitely talk to your OB-GYN or midwife about it.”

Sometimes, you may experience pubic pain because your pubic bones are separating during pregnancy. This is usually caused by relaxin (the pregnancy hormone that's loosening all the ligaments) and the pressure of your baby on your pubic symphysis joint.

Some minor separation is common. A larger separation, on the other hand, is rare. But it can happen. This is a more serious case. Your doctor can do an exam to check. They might suggest treatments like physical therapy (more on that below) if needed.
Be sure to let your doctor know right away or seek emergency care if you:
Feel sharp or stabbing pain
Pain along with fever or chills
Have other signs of labor like your water breaks, you feel contractions, or you have any vaginal bleeding
How to manage pubic bone pain
You can ask your OB-GYN or Midwife if it’s safe for you to take over-the-counter pain relievers like Tylenol.

They might also prescribe you a pelvic girdle (sometimes called a belt or cradle). This helps with some of the pressure and provides some stabilization to the area if your ligaments have loosened. You can get this fitted for you at a medical supply store or buy one online.
Here are some other tips that might help with pubic pain:
Use an ice or heat pack:
Place on your pubic bone region. This might help reduce inflammation and swelling and help with pain. Keep icing or heat to under 10 minutes and don’t put on your belly.
Wear flat, supportive shoes (like sneakers):
Helps you keep your balance, helps with your posture, and reduces your risk of falling.
Sleep with a pillow between your legs:
This helps cushion the gap between the hips and knees and keeps your body in alignment. In turn, you’ll feel less strain on your pubic bones.
Ask for help carrying anything heavy:
Heavy lifting can strain your pubic bone even more and cause more pain.
Working with a physical therapist
You can also start working with a physical therapist. They can make a plan to help manage your pain through the rest of your pregnancy and for delivery.
They can work with you to help with pregnancy-safe:
Strengthening exercises
Stretching
Ideas for relaxing and breathing through pain
Plans for delivering your baby comfortably (if you’re having a vaginal delivery) REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Need help getting started? You can book a free online appointment with a
Maven Physical Therapist
anytime.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
NHS

title.en-US: Should I get a second opinion after my glucose test?

content.value: What you need to know:
Most of the time, the glucose test results are correct.
If you’re concerned, though, you can always ask to take the test again or ask another provider to look at the results, or explain them further.
You might want a second opinion if you suspect bias from your provider or whoever was performing the test. Or if you don’t think the test was done correctly REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Hearing you might have
gestational diabetes

after your glucose tolerance test can be frustrating. You might feel like the plan you had for the rest of your pregnancy is thrown off. Or that it just isn’t fair that you’re dealing with this on top of exhaustion, back pain, and nausea. All of these feelings are valid and understandable—it’s a lot to process during an already busy time.

So if you find yourself questioning if the results from the test are right or accurate, you’re not alone. You can always ask to take the test again or ask another provider to look at the results or explain them further, says Maven OB-GYN Rana Daniel. But most of the time, the test results are correct.
Here’s what you need to know about getting a second opinion and how to get the support you need—no matter what the results say.
What is the glucose test looking for, exactly?
The first
glucose screening tests
for your risk of
gestational diabetes
. This is a condition where your blood glucose levels, or sugar levels, are too high during pregnancy.
If your test results show that your blood sugar is at a
normal level (usually less than 140 mg/dL)
, you’re all set. You can continue with your normal pregnancy diet and routine.
If your blood glucose levels are
high (usually more than 140 mg/dL)
, your doctor will schedule you for another test. This second-round test is called the glucose tolerance test.
This time you’ll be asked to not eat 8-12 hours before the test (you can have water)
You will have your blood drawn when you arrive at the clinic
You’ll then drink 3.6 ounces (100 grams) of glucose
Your blood will then be tested every hour for three hoursREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
With these results, your doctor rules out or diagnoses you with gestational diabetes.
Note that some providers or clinics might use slightly different cutoffs from the numbers listed above. If you want to know the exact number your clinic uses, always ask your OB or midwife.
How accurate are the results?

It’s important to follow all the instructions your doctor gives you for both the glucose screening test (like drinking the entire beverage) and the glucose tolerance test (like not eating for 8-12 hours before).

If you follow all of the instructions, you should feel pretty confident that the results are likely right. “The results of the glucose tolerance test are very accurate—over 95%,” Daniel says. “You could always request to do it again. But if the screening test was positive, it would be in the best interest of you and your baby to go onto the 3-hour tolerance test. The 3-hour test is also over 95% accurate, too.”
Can what I eat affect the results?

The answer is—sort of. What you eat in the weeks before the 1-hour test probably doesn’t matter, but what you eat that morning could mess with the results. “In general, what you eat in the weeks leading up to the test can't really change the results,” Daniel says. “But you can get a false result if you’re fasting before the test or if you have a super sugary breakfast like a bagel followed by a box of Fruit Loops.”

Your best bet is to stick to your regular old diet. Eat a balanced dinner the night before the 1-hour test (don’t go crazy on carbs or candy). And don’t skip breakfast that day. That way, your doctor will be able to get accurate results.
And always follow your doctor’s directions for fasting if you are taking the 3-hour test.

Remember, this test doesn’t exist to make you feel bad about what you eat. It exists to protect you and your baby from complications from gestational diabetes. Trying to “trick” the test can put you and your baby in danger if gestational diabetes isn’t caught early.
If you have any other questions about how your diet could affect your results, you can reach out to a
Maven Nutritionist
anytime.
When should I seek out a second opinion?

Your provider will get your results back and report the numbers to you. Usually, there’s no need for a second opinion. That’s because your doctor is reading you a number, and the numbers don’t leave a lot of room for bias, Daniel says.
That isn’t to say you can’t seek one out or request to take the test over. It’s for your health and the health of your baby—so it’s important you feel confident in your care.
You might want a second opinion if:
You suspect bias from your provider or whoever was performing the test
You don’t think the test was done correctly REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
You can also request an appointment on Maven anytime so that a
Maven Diabetes Coach
or
Maven OB-GYN
can help explain your results to you, too.
Where to turn for support
If you are diagnosed with
gestational diabetes
, know that you don’t have to go through it alone. Maven is here for you. You can talk to a
Maven Diabetes Coach
or
Maven Nutritionist

for free online anytime. They can offer support and nutritional advice as you navigate the rest of your pregnancy. If you need more support processing the results of your diabetes screening, you can also speak to a
Maven Mental Health Provider
anytime.

title.en-US: 5 labor relaxation and breathing techniques to try

content.value: What you need to know:
There are different ways to help your body feel more relaxed when you’re in labor (even though it might seem like the least relaxing time ever).
Play music, visualize joy, or get in the tub if you can.
You can also practice controlled breathing in through your nose and out through your mouth. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Relaxing when you’re in the middle of labor? It might seem impossible (and make you kind of want to laugh out loud at the idea).
But with a bit of prep, there are different techniques to try that can really help you to feel calmer as baby starts to make their way into the world, says Maven Doula Shannon Outchcunis.
Here are 5 ways to breathe, chill, and distract yourself from any labor pain you’re feeling.
Looking for more ways to prepare for childbirth? You can take free
on-demand labor and pain management classes
on Maven anytime.
1. Music or relaxation recordings

Create a playlist of music that soothes you or makes you feel relaxed. You can put on headphones and really zone in, or blast it out loud for the hospital room. (Pack a portable speaker in your hospital bag or play it off your phone).
Some pregnant people find reiki music relaxing, too. “You can find some great reiki music that is beneficial during labor and can be used months before your baby is born, too,” Outchcunis says.
Or if meditation or podcasts are more your thing, you can put one on and focus on that when things start to get more intense.
2. Massage

It’s hard to say no to a massage when those pregnancy aches and pains take over, right? Have your partner start practicing their massages during your third trimester, Outchcunis recommends. “Your partner or support person can work with you during pregnancy to find massage techniques that feel best for you that you can also use when you’re in labor,” she says. “Lower back and hip massage feel wonderful during early labor, for example.”
When labor starts, you can work on the amount of pressure that feels best as well as the positions you are in (standing, side-lying, on a birthing ball, or sitting) to find the right fit.
3. Water therapy

Another way to relax when you’re in labor is to get into water. “Using a bath or shower during labor is amazing,” Outchcunis says. “If you have a handheld shower nozzle, it can be used on the lower back or belly during contractions. Soaking in a bath is also helpful, you just want to remember to keep the water at an even warm temperature—not hot—to protect yourself and the baby.”

You can try this if your pregnancy is low-risk and you’re going through early labor at home. Also ask at your hospital tour if there will be a shower or tub available in your room that you’ll be able to use. Some hospitals have different policies about how long you can stay in the water and if it’s allowed, so be sure to ask. Most will not allow you to use the water facilities after your water has broken to prevent bacteria or infection from entering.
Note: If you’re laboring at home and your water breaks, it’s not safe to take a bath or go in the water. Call your provider and follow their instructions or go straight to the hospital.
4. Visualization
Visualization—where you look or think about something that brings you joy—can help you relax when labor takes over.

“Having pictures of other children who may be at home, your pets, a picture of you on vacation, or an image of your favorite place you went as a child is a great way to relax,” Outchcunis says. “Focusing in on things that only bring you joy can relieve stress and anxiety.”
5. Breathing

Most importantly, don’t forget to breathe! “Learning how to use controlled breathing during labor is extremely helpful,” Outchcunis says. “Deep breaths, in through your nose and out through your mouth, are most effective.”
Try practicing breathing like this:
Place one hand over your heart and close your eyes, slowly breathe in through your nose as deeply as you can without forcing it, then breathe long and slow out through your mouth.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Relax your neck and shoulders. Keeping your mouth closed, inhale through your nose for 2 counts.Pucker or purse your lips (as if you were going to whistle). Exhale slowly through your pursed lips for a 4 count.REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Inhale deep and slow for a 5 count, then exhale slowly for a 5 count. Keep breaths measured and slow focusing on the rise and fall of your chest. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Sit or lay down in a comfortable position. Close your eyes and place your hands over your ears to block out noise. Breathe in deep and slow, and as you exhale, keep your mouth closed and make a loud, even humming sound.
The bottom line

It’s not easy to relax when labor starts. But having some ideas in your back pocket for ways to relax when it starts to feel intense can go a long way. If you need more ideas or want to prep 1-1 for labor and delivery, you can make an appointment with a
Maven Doula
for free online anytime. You can also take free
labor and pain management classes
on Maven on-demand anytime.

title.en-US: How to improve work-life balance during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know:
It’s so important to practice work-life balance during pregnancy.
For you, that might look like taking your lunch break to nap or go for a walk, logging out at a decent time to enjoy a quiet evening, or working from home (if you can).
Focus on your mental and physical health during this time. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

During your pregnancy, it’s tempting to work longer hours. After all, you know you’ll soon be going on leave (if your workplace offers it) or taking time off. Squeezing in extra hours means you’ll be ahead of the game when you hand off your work and eventually return, right?

Not exactly. Working more hours or stressing yourself out about work can actually be unhealthy at a time when focusing on you, your growing baby, and managing your stress in healthy ways is most important.

Finding some work life balance isn’t ever easy. But during your pregnancy, it’s so important to try. Here’s why Maven Career Coach Stephanie Tishler says you can work smarter, not longer or harder, so you can focus on what matters right now—the health of you and your baby-to-be.
What is work-life balance during pregnancy?
With a healthy work-life balance, you have time to take care of yourself and enjoy time outside of work.
During pregnancy, work-life balance for you might look like:
Taking time to go to your prenatal appointments
Taking a lunch break every day (and squeezing in a nap during lunch at home or in your car if needed)
Going on walks throughout the day to stretch your legs
Leaving work at a decent time so you can enjoy a nice dinner with your partner or a friend
Not responding to calls or emails in the evening so you can go to bed early and get plenty of rest
Work from home some days (if possible)
Not working on the weekends or outside your scheduled hoursREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
So how can you make sure you are able to have some balance between your work and life? Read on to learn more.
How to set yourself up for smart work-life balance during pregnancy

The key to practicing work-life balance during your pregnancy is to set healthy boundaries and expectations early on—before you go on leave. Think about the support you need and hope to get from your team and make a plan.

“It’s very important that your manager hears your pregnancy news from you,” Tishler says. The more you keep them in the loop, the better. Ask them to help you announce the news to the team. Create a list of what you need with your manager (you’ll be out for prenatal appointments and need coverage, for example) and they can share it with the team. Remember, a team is there to support you!”
Beyond smart communication with your team, check your company’s policies. You might want to look into:
Working from home when/if possible
Flexible hours, if you need to start earlier or leave early, for example
Working from home more as your due date approaches REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

As you set up boundaries with your team, continue to communicate with them. Always let them know if you’ll be working from home that day or if you have an appointment. Try time-blocking and labeling your appointments on your shared calendar. You can also create a shared document with all your priorities your team can access, too.
Delegate what you can

Pregnancy is a busy time. Between prenatal appointments, getting ready for baby, and preparing to go on leave/take time off from work, you might be feeling a lot of stress. It can be tempting to work more hours right now to get work done before you have the baby. But instead, this is a great time to reevaluate priorities and the work on your plate. See what can be delegated, dropped, or delayed until your return. Work with your manager to decide where work will go and gain their support to keep your workload manageable.

By delegating some of your workload (if possible) your transition to leave will be easier, too, because everyone will already be clear on their tasks. And, ideally, they’ll already start to do them without you.

If you do this throughout your pregnancy, your workload should stay the same or even decrease. Which is a positive thing because you’ve got a lot going on. “Remind yourself that pregnancy is extra work,” Tishler says.
Keep up work-life balance practices as your due date approaches

Your due date is approaching, but pass on the temptation to make it crunch time. Hopefully you’ve been already practicing some of the work-life balance techniques listed above throughout your pregnancy. As long as you’ve got a solid plan in place, now is the time to follow the plan and transition work as needed to your team. Avoid trying to take on more for yourself.

There should be a clear hand-off plan in place with plenty of time. “Probably 2-4 weeks before you leave, the person covering for you can shadow you to learn your style, to be introduced to the process, and ask questions,” Tishler recommends.

You’ve planned well, so feel good knowing that your work is in a good place and will be organized when you return. Your teammates will also appreciate you letting go and trusting that they have it covered.
The bottom line:

It’s easy to feel stressed about work when you’ve got a baby on the way. But it’s most important to focus on your health—mentally and physically—right now. Always let your work know if it’s getting to be too much at any time. “It’s OK to say you are maxed out or you need help,” Tishler says. “It’s likely that your employer wants you to come back healthy after your leave, too, so give them the opportunity to help you do that starting now.”
If you need more help as you navigate balancing work and life during your pregnancy, reach out to a
Maven Career Coach
for free online anytime.

title.en-US: Should I work with an OB-GYN or a Midwife?

content.value: What you need to know:
OB-GYNs are trained to deliver babies, manage high-risk pregnancies, high-risk deliveries, and perform surgery like Cesareans (C-sections).
Certified Nurse Midwives are trained to deliver babies in lower-risk pregnancies. They do not perform C-sections or other surgeries.
Both can help manage primary care, prenatal and obstetric care, and routine gynecological care like annual exams, and help with birth control. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Throughout your pregnancy, there will be a lot of decisions to make. You can worry about most of them once you’re further along (like if you want a baby shower, if you want an epidural, which snacks to pack in your hospital bag—you know, important things). But one very important decision you will have to make early on is who your main pregnancy provider will be.

Choosing between an OB-GYN and a Certified Nurse Midwife (CNM) is a big decision. But it might be easier than you think. A lot of it will come down to if your pregnancy is high-risk or not, what your insurance covers, and what kind of birth/delivery experience you want.
Here’s a look at some of the exact differences between an OB-GYN and a CNM so you can make the best decision for you and your growing family.
OB-GYN vs. Certified Nurse Midwife: What’s the difference?

OB-GYNs and midwives: They both are well trained in prenatal care and birth. You’ll be in good hands with either. Still, it’s good to learn more about what they do so you can decide who you want to work with.
OB-GYN:

A doctor who is trained to deliver babies, manage high-risk pregnancies, high-risk deliveries, and perform surgery like Cesareans (C-sections). They are also trained to provide primary care, prenatal and obstetric care, and routine gynecological care like annual exams and help with birth control.
Certified Nurse Midwife (CNM):

Providers who are trained to deliver babies in lower-risk pregnancies. They do not perform C-sections or other surgeries. They are also trained to provide primary care, prenatal and obstetric care, and routine gynecological care like annual exams, and help with birth control. Additionally, a CNM might take a more holistic approach (for example, they may perform fewer ultrasounds or be less likely to promote induction).
Is your midwife’s certification important?
There are different certifications for midwives like certified nurse midwife, certified midwife, certified professional midwife, and unlicensed midwife.

Certified nurse midwives (or CNMs) have the highest standard certification. They’ve completed nursing school and have a graduate degree in midwifery. They can work in hospitals, homes, and birth centers. They are certified by the American Midwifery Certification Board and they work in all 50 states and Washington DC. You can search for a certified nurse midwife
here

If you choose to work with a midwife, it’s highly recommended to work with a CNM. (Make sure it says “CNM” on their clinic’s website under their credentials.) Be wary of midwives without this advanced training, formal certification, or licensure. If you aren’t sure about your midwife’s certification, just ask!
So which one should I work with during my pregnancy?

Still confused about if you want to work with an OB-GYN or CNM? You can start to think about where you want to have your baby to help you decide. If it’s a hospital or birth center, they may have only OBs or only CNMs who are able to deliver babies there. Or they might have both. You can always call and ask if you aren’t sure.

If your preferred hospital or delivery center has both OB-GYNs and CNMs, you will have the choice of who you want to work with. You should make the decision based on your comfort with that person, but there are other factors to think about, too.

You should also check with your insurance company (or call the number on the back of your Medicaid card) to ask if they cover OB-GYNs, CNMs, or both. Ask if your insurance covers birth center births, too, if you are interested. Some will only cover births that happen in a hospital.

If it’s important to you, ask if the OB-GYN or CNM you see for your prenatal appointments will be the provider who will attend your delivery as well. Some hospitals or birth centers might have different providers on call at different times, for example.
You may want to pick an OB-GYN if:
Your pregnancy is considered high risk (because of diabetes or high blood pressure, for example)
You’ve had a C-section before (in case another C-section needs to be performed, for example). You can also ask if they support VBACs (vaginal birth after cesarean) if you’re interested.
You may want to pick a CNM if:
Your pregnancy is considered low risk
You’ve had deliveries before that were not high risk
You’re interested in a more holistic approach (someone who supports avoiding induction, for example, or supports water births)
Some CNMs support and could assist with VBAC deliveries. Ask them about this early if you’re interested in having a VBAC. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Keep in mind that if you choose to work with a CNM and deliver at a hospital and end up needing a C-section, an OB-GYN at the hospital will perform the C-section. If you are delivering at a birth center or at home, you will need to be transported to a hospital if you need a C-section.
Can you switch doctors later?

You can switch doctors at any point during your pregnancy. If you start working with a CNM, for example, you can switch to an OB-GYN later. If your pregnancy becomes high-risk at any point or if you know you’re going to have a scheduled or emergency C-section, for example.

CNMs work independently, but they also usually work with a collaborating physician. That way, if your pregnancy becomes high-risk or they need help with your delivery, for example, they have an OB-GYN to refer you to. Sometimes, CNMs can also help with C-sections. Ask your CNM about this in case you end up needing a cesarean delivery.
Questions to ask an OB-GYN and/or CNM
If you’re not sure who you want to work with, you might want to meet with both an OB-GYN and a CNM early in your pregnancy. Have a list of questions for them on-hand.
Some questions you might want to ask at your first appointment(s):
Where do you deliver? At which hospital(s)? Birth center? Home birth?
Will you be the provider who attends my delivery? Or will it be a co-worker? Whoever is on call?
Do you support medicated/unmedicated births?
What are your policies on inductions?
Do you support VBACs (if you’ve had a C-section before)?
What if I want to have a water birth?
For a CNM: What happens if I need a C-section? Will you refer me to an OB-GYN? Will you be able to assist with the delivery?
The bottom line

Choosing an OB-GYN or CNM to take care of you during your pregnancy is a big decision. Remember, your health and the health of your baby is their main priority. You also want to be sure you are comfortable with your choice.
At your first appointment, ask any questions you have about their practice, delivery, and anything else that comes to mind.
If you have any questions or want to learn more, you can also talk to a
Maven OB-GYN
or
Maven Certified Nurse Midwife
for free online anytime.
Sources
Michigan Health

title.en-US: 6 ways to manage body aches and pains during pregnancy

content.value: What you need to know
Body aches and pains during pregnancy aren’t fun to deal with, but there are solutions to help.
At home, try stretching, strength training, and applying heat or ice (just make sure your doctor says these are safe for your pregnancy).
You can also work with a physical therapist who can make a plan to help you feel better. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Whether you’re feeling it in your back, hips, pelvis, or all over—body aches and pains when you’re pregnant can feel downright miserable.

But know that you don’t have to suffer through or just “tough it out” until you deliver. If you’re in pain, there are plenty of solutions out there that can help, says Maven Physical Therapist Heather Brooks.
Read on for some ideas you can try at home. Maven is also here to support you during this time. You can book a free online appointment with a
Maven Physical Therapist
anytime. They can offer exercises, stretches, and more to help you find some relief.
Note: Always ask your OB or midwife before you try any of the suggestions below. They might not be safe if your pregnancy is high-risk.
Where might you feel pain during pregnancy, and why?
Some common pain points are:
Sacroiliac (SI) joint pain (felt in your low back and glutes)
Pubic bone pain
Calf pain
Hip pain
Back pain
Pelvis painREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Pregnancy hormones might be to blame for some of the pain you’re feeling. “Feeling pain in these areas is common because of the increase in the pregnancy hormone relaxin that helps get the pelvis ready for vaginal delivery,” Brooks says. “This unfortunately makes the pelvis more relaxed and less stable and can cause the hips and pelvis to get out of alignment.”
1. Stretch

The first defense you can try against pain is some good old stretching. “Stretching is very important throughout pregnancy because of the change in body composition, posture, and center of gravity,” Brooks says. “Plus it feels really good!”
Some stretches to try:
Downward dog:
On a yoga mat or blanket, start on your hands and knees. Push with your hands and push your hips back while straightening your legs. You should end up in an upside down “V” position.
Cat/Cow:

On a yoga mat or blanket, start on your hands and knees with your wrists beneath your shoulders. Slowly lift your head and chest upward to make a “cow” shape. Then from there, drop your head while slightly rounding your back like a “cat”.
Child’s pose:

On a yoga mat or blanket, start on your hands and knees. Push your hips back so your knees are apart and toes will touch. You can rest your head on a pillow or the mat. To support your belly more, you can also stack pillows in front of you and rest your arms around the pillows.
Calf stretch:
Put both hands on a wall for support and lunge forward with one leg, keeping that knee bent. You should feel the stretch in your other supporting leg.
Piriformis (glute) stretch:
Sit on a chair with both legs on the floor. Place your left leg over your right knee. Lean forward slightly to feel the stretch. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Looking for more ways to stretch out? You can also take free
on-demand prenatal yoga classes
on the Maven app anytime.
2. Walk and strength train (when you’re up for it)

We know—exercise is probably the last thing you want to think about when you’re pregnant and in pain. But it turns out, getting some exercise helps keep your body moving and might actually help reduce pain in some cases. You can also strengthen some of the areas you might be feeling pain in, like your back, which might reduce or get rid of the pain altogether. Just get your doctor’s OK first to make sure exercise is safe for you during your pregnancy.
No need to run tons of miles or hit the weights, though. Some gentle exercises you enjoy like walking, prenatal yoga, and swimming are great ways to get some movement in.

And don’t discount strength training, either, which might help with some of the pain you’re feeling. Just get your doctor’s OK first to make sure it’s safe for your pregnancy. “Finding a good balance between cardio and strength training helps keep your body strong and your heart in good condition for the entire pregnancy and postpartum period,” Brooks says.
Some important areas to strengthen are the core, pelvic floor, upper back, and legs.
Try these exercises (if you’ve been given the OK to exercise and strength train by your doctor):
Modified planks (done on your knees)
Alternating extending arms and legs while on hands and knees (aka “bird dogs”)
Push ups against the wall
Lunges and squats
3. Wear a pregnancy support belt

A pregnancy support belt (sometimes called a belly band) might help with some of your back or hip pain. It supports your growing belly and might help with your posture, too. Science is limited as to how much help support belts offer—but some pregnant people swear by them. If they feel comfortable for you, go for it. You can find tons of inexpensive belts and bands online.
4. Get a prenatal massage

You don’t have to get a prenatal massage every week, but treating yourself once in a while can go a long way. A prenatal masseuse who specializes in pregnancy will know how to hit those hard to reach areas and work out any knots or tightness you might be feeling.
Be sure to let them know if there are any areas you feel a lot of pain in that you want them to focus on!
5. Apply heat or ice

Always ask your doctor if it’s OK if you use a heat or ice pack on your body during pregnancy. But if you get the go-ahead, this might help with the inflammation and pain that you might be feeling. Keep it on for only about 10 minutes at a time.
Just never apply heat or ice directly to your belly—that’s not safe during pregnancy.
6. Work with a physical therapist (PT)
If some of the at-home remedies like stretching and a pregnancy support belt aren’t working, you can also work with a physical therapist.
Physical therapists
who specialize in pregnancy can recommend exercises, stretches, and other ideas to help with your aches and pains. They can even help with ideas for making delivery more comfortable for you.
You can look for a PT in your area to see in person or message your Maven Care Advocate for help finding one. You can also make an appointment with a
Maven Physical Therapist
for free online anytime.

title.en-US: 5 ways to keep growing your career while growing a baby

content.value: What you need to know
You can keep going after your career goals during pregnancy, as long as your mental and physical health remains your top priority during this time.
Talk to your manager about your short- and long-term career goals before your parental leave or time off.
Keep working towards any promotions you’re after by highlighting all your achievements to your manager. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Pregnancy might not seem like the ideal time for moving up at work. But while it’s true that some things will change because you’re having a baby (and that’s a good thing!) it doesn't mean you need to give up on what’s important to you. So if that’s your career goals—continue to go after them!
As long as your physical and mental health remain your top priority right now, growing your career during pregnancy is entirely possible, says Maven Career Coach Sara Daly-Padron.
Here are 5 tips for talking to your manager about your short- and long-term goals, going after a promotion, and even switching jobs during your pregnancy.
1. Talk about your goals with your manager

It’s so important to talk with your manager about goals and expectations. So while you’re also probably going to have many conversations about what going on parental leave will look like and who will be covering for you when you’re out, take some time to have a separate conversation. This one should be just about your career goals. Do this before you go on parental leave (if your workplace offers it) or take time off to have your baby.

“Set some time on your calendar to talk about your goals and how you can continue to make progress before your anticipated leave or time off,” Daly-Padron says. ”In this 1:1 meeting, remind your manager that until your expected leave date, you are focused on furthering your goals at work.”

You should also back up this conversation with some specifics about how the work you’re doing now ties back to your goals. Talk about any performance improvements or progress you’ve made and what you want to work on in the near future.

“Now is also a great time to express any interest in new projects or assignments that would help to further your ambitions in the long-term and be clear about what work you anticipate picking back up when you return,” Daly-Padron says.
2. Focus on the long-term

Taking time off to have a baby can feel like a really big deal, but focus on the bigger picture when talking to your manager, too. “It can be helpful to talk about your leave in the context of a long career,” Daly-Padron says. “While being out for weeks or months may seem like an eternity now, in the scope of a few years at a company or even more broadly, upwards of 30 years in a career, it’s really quite short.”
She recommends using language that frames your leave in the long-term. Try, "Upon my return", "I look forward to...", "Next year I would like to...", etc.
3. Keep working towards a promotion (if you’re up for one soon)
Promotions are still very much on the table during your pregnancy. If you’re up for one soon, it’s so important to be clear about your expectations. Also keep talking about your amazing achievements.

“Ask your manager for the exact criteria for the promotion and where you stand in terms of progress,” Daly-Padron says. “Be clear about your intent to return after your leave and your long-term commitment to the organization (if you feel this way). Remind your manager about your desire to grow and that the promotion will be a great opportunity to do so.”
4. Communicate, communicate, communicate

Keep communicating with your manager and team throughout your pregnancy. Let them know your expected leave dates (if you’re taking it) and when you expect to return. Make a detailed plan for who will cover for you when you’re out. Let everyone know days when you plan to work from home and when you have prenatal appointments.

All this communication might seem like overkill. But it shows that you’re still dedicated to your work and team as much as you can be during this time. That can go a long way when it comes to your career growth.
5. Don’t be afraid to make moves
Not all careers follow a direct path. Sometimes you need to switch companies or workplaces in order to advance. Daly-Padron says not to let your pregnancy stop you from applying for other jobs.

“Disclosing your pregnancy isn’t required during a job application or interviewing process,” she says. “The decision to share the news (or not) before signing an offer letter is deeply personal. Whether you choose to share or not, in all discussions, you do need to focus on the expertise you will bring and the long-term impact that you will have on the organization during what hopes to be a lengthy career.”
When interviewing, she recommends highlighting how your past achievements brought value to your former role/employer. And also how you’ll bring value to the new role.
The bottom line

If your career is important to you, pregnancy doesn’t have to be a time to give up on your short- and long-term goals. As long as you’re not overdoing it at work and prioritizing your mental and physical health, there’s no reason you won’t achieve all that you’re after.
Maven Career Coaches
are also here for you. They can answer any questions you have and give you more tips on navigating tricky conversations at work.

title.en-US: How to collect and feed colostrum to baby

content.value: What you need to know:
Colostrum is early breast milk designed to nurture your baby in their first few days of life.
Some people like to try expressing and storing colostrum before their baby is born.
Ask your provider if it’s safe to try collecting colostrum during pregnancy.
What is colostrum?

Colostrum is the first type of breast milk your body produces. It contains high levels of antibodies and other nutrients for newborns. It’s usually thick and yellow. Most people will produce colostrum for 2-4 days after their baby is born, at which point your milk will start transitioning into “mature” breast milk.

“​​Everyone produces colostrum during pregnancy,” says Maven Lactation Consultant Michelle Poole. “In the early weeks of pregnancy, breast changes signify the body getting ready for lactation. By about 16 weeks (second trimester), colostrum is in the breasts, and ready to go. Some parents don't think they have colostrum because they don't see it, but it's always there. Leaking is normal, and not leaking is also normal, and neither speaks to the later milk supply.”

Some people can express and store colostrum ahead of time to feed to your baby once they’re born. Just know that this isn’t a must. Your provider might suggest trying it if you know you won’t be able to try breastfeeding right away, for example if your baby has special medical needs and will spend time in the NICU after birth.
When can I start collecting colostrum?

If you’re interested in collecting colostrum while you’re pregnant, ask your provider if it’s safe for you to do so after 37 weeks. If you are having a high-risk pregnancy or experiencing complications, your care team might recommend waiting until your baby is born to start expressing milk. That’s because there is a small risk that expressing milk could trigger labor. Also, many people will not leak colostrum during pregnancy. That’s perfectly normal, and doesn’t mean you will have problems producing milk after your baby is born.
How do I express and collect colostrum?
“First and foremost, know that it is
very

time consuming,” says Maven Lactation Consultant Lauren Olofsson, IBCLC. “So it helps to set low expectations!” Poole says you can expect to “only collect drops of colostrum, or around 1 ml total per hand expression session.”

The best way to harvest colostrum is by using hand expression to remove milk from your breasts. There are resources available online that show you how to do this. It can take some practice to get the hang of it, but here are the steps to follow:
After washing your hands, put your hand on one breast in the shape of a C, with your thumb above your nipple and four fingers below your nipple.
Press your thumb and fingers backwards, towards the wall of your chest

Gently compress your thumb and fingers, so they move towards each other to compress your nipple. This is the step where milk will come out. It can take a few minutes before any drops of colostrum come out, which is normal.
Release your breast.
Repeat until your breast feels empty, then switch to the other side. REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
You can also make a free online appointment with a
Maven Lactation Consultant
for more guidance.
Olofsson says you should collect colostrum on a sterilized spoon, and store it either in a sterile 1ml syringe or a sterile colostrum collection container (you can buy these online).
How should I store colostrum?

“Freeze the colostrum in the back or bottom of the freezer,” Olofsson says. Don’t use the side door of the freezer or store colostrum near the front, since the temperature in those areas can drop when the door is opened.
When you’re ready to use it you can thaw colostrum in the fridge or by running it under lukewarm water. Once the colostrum is fully thawed, you should use it within 24 hours.
How and when should I feed colostrum to my baby?

Colostrum is designed to provide all the nutrients your baby needs during their first few days of life. Once your baby is born, you can feed them harvested colostrum from a syringe or colostrum collector. “If you are harvesting in the hospital post-delivery, you can simply hand express onto a spoon and spoon-feed your baby,” Olofsson says. “Don’t hesitate to ask your nurse or in-hospital lactation consultant for help.”

During nursing, your baby will receive colostrum directly from your breasts. “When baby feeds on that colostrum, your body begins the process of creating transitional and then later, mature breast milk,’ Olofsson says. “This is supply-and-demand based.” Meaning: The more you nurse, hand express, or pump after delivery, the more milk your body will produce.

If you plan to nurse, you should offer harvested colostrum to your baby after a nursing session if your baby still looks hungry. “Because milk making is a supply-and-demand situation, if the baby is filling up on the syringes of colostrum, then they will not go to the breast as often as they would have otherwise,” Poole says. “This could negatively impact the milk supply.”
Some people who collect colostrum ahead of time don’t end up using it, since the baby is satisfied by nursing directly. Poole says this is totally normal.
What if I can’t collect colostrum before my baby is born?

Collecting colostrum while you’re pregnant is not necessary to establish a breastfeeding relationship or to successfully pump breast milk. It’s a way to store food for your baby’s first few days, but it’s completely optional. You should only try to harvest colostrum during pregnancy if your provider says it’s safe for you to do so.
The bottom line:

Some people might produce and be able to collect colostrum before having their baby, while others might not. Rest assured that this has no bearing on whether or not you can successfully breastfeed your baby after delivery. Got more questions? You can meet with a
Maven Lactation Consultant
online—for free—any time.
Sources
Cleveland Clinic
La Leche League International
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

title.en-US: Should I get a second opinion about an induction?

content.value: What you need to know:
An induction is when your care team starts labor for you with medication or other methods.
Doctors might recommend one if you have certain medical conditions, risk factors, or if you are overdue (usually 41 weeks pregnant or more).
Ask your doctor to explain the benefits and risks of an induction. You can also always ask another
OB-GYN
or a
provider on Maven
for a second opinion.
What is an induction?

An induction is when your care team starts labor for you, rather than waiting for you to go into labor on your own. They can do this in a variety of ways, like using a balloon to dilate your cervix, giving you medication to start contractions, or breaking your waters.
Inductions usually happen at a hospital or birth center. Your care team might recommend an induction for medical reasons, or because you are past your due date.
It’s important to always ask your provider about the benefits and risks so you can make an informed choice.
Why do doctors sometimes recommend an induction?
Induction for medical reasons
