This is when providers suggest inducing because you and/or your baby are having health problems that will be easier to treat once the baby has been born. Doctors might recommend an induction for people dealing with:
Growth restriction in the baby, which is when your baby is smaller than expected (this can be caused by problems with the placenta)
Pregnancy with multiples
Preeclampsia, which is a complication linked to high blood pressure that is extremely dangerous if it goes untreated for too long
Complications from high blood pressure
Complications from gestational diabetesREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

Some people with these conditions do not need to be induced, and go into labor on their own. But because every case is different, you and your providers should work together to talk about the benefits and risks of a scheduled induction if that’s something your care team recommends for you.
Induction for being “overdue”

What your doctor considers “overdue” can vary. Anything after 41 weeks is considered a “late term” pregnancy, and 42 weeks onwards is a “post-term pregnancy.” Some providers will allow inductions from 39 weeks onwards, while others will wait until 40 or 41 weeks to suggest it.
That’s because the longer you are pregnant, the higher your risks are for:
Stillbirth
Your baby inhaling meconium (fecal matter) in the womb
Having low amniotic fluid
Having an extremely large baby, which might cause complications during birthREPLACEWITHLINEBREAK

If you are close to or past your due date with no sign of labor, your care team will recommend regular checks to see how you and the baby are doing (usually ultrasounds and non-stress tests). They will also probably talk to you about an induction if you don’t go into labor on your own.
What are the risks and benefits of an induction?
You should ask your care team about the risks and benefits in your specific scenario, especially if they are suggesting an induction due to medical risks. Here’s why:
Inductions can slightly increase your risk of getting an infection
Sometimes the medication used in an induction can affect the baby’s heart rate
You may be more likely to bleed after delivery
People who have inductions are more likely to request an epidural (because the medication used to kickstart labor can make contractions feel very intense right away)REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
Your care team should weigh these risks against the risks of you waiting to go into labor on your own.
One important note: You might have heard that inductions increase your risk of having a C-section. According to the
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
, this is not true. If there are no pregnancy complications, people who are induced and people who wait to go into labor spontaneously have similar rates of C-section births.
When should I push back or ask for a second opinion?
You can always ask for a second opinion from another doctor, or a
Maven OB-GYN
or
Midwife
. It’s important to ask your provider any questions you have about why they are recommending an induction.
If your care provider suggests an induction for medical reasons
, they should explain to you exactly what the risks of waiting for spontaneous labor are, and how an induction will lessen those risks. Here are some example questions you can ask:
If they are suggesting an induction for high blood pressure:
What are their concerns about your blood pressure now?
What happens if your blood pressure gets worse?
How will being induced help prevent complications for you and the baby? REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If you have gestational diabetes:
Is your blood sugar under control?
What happens if it gets worse?
How will being induced help prevent complications for you and the baby? REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If they are concerned that your baby is too small:
What do they think is causing the baby’s small size?
Are they worried there is an issue with the placenta that could get worse over time?
Is it better to give the baby more time to grow before they are born?REPLACEWITHLINEBREAK
If your team suggests an induction because you are overdue
and you don’t want to be induced, you should ask your care provider:
What are the risks associated with waiting to go into labor?
What is the latest date you are comfortable scheduling an induction?
If I choose to wait, what tests or checks would you recommend to ensure the baby is safe?
The bottom line

No one can force you to have an induction if you don’t want one. But if your provider suggests one for medical reasons or because you are overdue, you need to understand the risks and benefits of having an induction or not having one. If you have more questions, you can meet with a
Maven OB-GYN
or
Midwife
for free at any time.
Sources
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG)
March of Dimes
Mayo Clinic
